{"15430656": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 02:47:44", "url": "https://www.easydns.com/blog/2013/10/08/whatever-happened-to-due-process/", "text": "<html><body><div><div>\n<p>The request came from The City of London (UK) Police Intellectual Property Crime Unit, and it had me thinking about this issue all morning, whether I should write anything about it, etc. It\u2019s a strongly worded email <em>\u201cThe domain(s) continues to be accessible by members of the public and is still making illicit financial gains for the criminals operating it.\u201d\u00a0</em> Ok, what exactly makes the website operators criminals (the website in question is a bittorrent search engine, I don\u2019t even think they\u2019re hosting the torrent files locally).<span id=\"more-3275\"/></p>\n<p>It wasn\u2019t until I got to the office that I realized that there was a <a href=\"http://www.scribd.com/doc/174459491/City-of-London-UK-Takedown-request-to-easyDNS\" target=\"_blank\">PDF attached</a> to the email request, in it were further details/instructions:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>It referenced the section 5.5.2.1.3 of the ICANN RAA which states <em>\u201caccreditation as a Registrar can be terminated if the Registrar is found to have \u2018permitted illegal activity in the registration or use of domain names\u2019.\u201d </em>(Although I cannot find this text in the <a href=\"http://www.icann.org/en/resources/registrars/raa/ra-agreement-21may09-en.htm\" target=\"_blank\">current RAA</a>)</li>\n<li>It requests that we freeze the whois record and permit no further changes to it.</li>\n<li>It directs us to redirect the DNS for the domain to <strong>83.138.166.114</strong></li>\n<li>It \u201creserves the right\u201d to refer the matter to ICANN</li>\n</ul>\n<p>After I read the attached order I realized I had to post because this opens all kinds of thorny philosophical issues which we\u2019ve been talking about for years.</p>\n<h2>The lack of any semblance of due process when it comes to domain name takedowns.</h2>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>Who decides what is illegal? What makes somebody a criminal?\u00a0 Given that the subtext of the request contains a threat to refer the matter to ICANN if we don\u2019t play along, this is a non-trivial question. Correct me if I\u2019m wrong, but I always thought it was something that gets decided in a\u00a0<em><strong>c</strong><strong>ourt of</strong> <strong>law</strong></em>, as opposed to \u201csome guy on the internet\u201d sending emails. While that\u2019s <a href=\"http://torrentfreak.com/uk-police-orders-registrars-to-suspend-domains-of-major-torrent-sites-131009/\" target=\"_blank\">plenty reason enough for some registrars to take down domain names</a>, it doesn\u2019t fly here.</p>\n<p>We have an obligation to our customers and we are bound by our Registrar Accreditation Agreements <em>not</em> to make arbitrary changes to our customers settings without a <em>valid </em>FOA (Form of <em>Authorization</em>). To supersede that we need a <strong>legal</strong> basis. To get a legal basis something has to happen <strong><em>in</em><em> court.</em></strong></p>\n<p>The request also suggests we look at the whois contact information for the domain (which looks perfectly valid) and go ahead and suspend the domain based on invalid whois data. Again, there\u2019s a <em><strong>process</strong></em> for that, you have to go through the <a href=\"http://www.icann.org/en/resources/compliance/complaints/whois/inaccuracy-form\" target=\"_blank\">ICANN Whois Inaccuracy Complaint </a>process and most of the time that doesn\u2019t result in a takedown anyway.</p>\n<p>What gets me about all of this is that the largest, most egregious perpetrators of online criminal activity right now are our own governments, spying on their own citizens, illegally wiretapping our own private communications and <em>nobody cares</em>, nobody will answer for it, it\u2019s just an out-of-scope conversation that is expected to blend into the overall background malaise of our ever increasing serfdom.</p>\n<p>If I can\u2019t make various governments and law enforcement agencies get warrants or court orders before they crack my private communications then I can at least\u00a0 require a court order before I takedown my own customer.</p>\n<p>Before anybody tells me \u201cthis is just some bittorrent domain, just take it down\u201d, remember what we said back in 2010: <a title=\"First they came for the file-sharing domains\u2026\" href=\"https://www.easydns.com/blog/2010/11/27/first-they-came-for-the-file-sharing-domains/\" target=\"_blank\">First They Came For the File Sharing Domains</a>.</p>\n<p>About a week after that was posted Senator Lieberman and friends went batshit crazy trying to take down wikileaks. Why? Egregious truth telling. Again, this is the entire point of <em><strong>due</strong> <strong>process</strong></em>\u00a0<strong><em/></strong>it\u2019s there to keep us collectively away from the top end of the slippery slope.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately, we\u2019re\u00a0 most of the way down that slope and into the mud of blatant mass online surveillance \u2013 the next phase will be concerted repression of inconvenient truth-tellers and facts.</p>\n<h2>Further Reading</h2>\n\n<h2>Update:</h2>\n<p>We took a look at <span><a href=\"http://83.138.166.114/\" rel=\"nofollow\">http://83.138.166.114/</a></span> \u2013 the IP address they wanted us to redirect all of this domain\u2019s traffic to.</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.easydns.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/Screen-Shot-2013-10-08-at-12.40.20-PM.png\"><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-3284\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2013-10-08 at 12.40.20 PM\" src=\"http://www.easydns.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/Screen-Shot-2013-10-08-at-12.40.20-PM-300x243.png\"/></a>Note that they are <strong>promoting</strong> paid, <strong>commercial</strong> alternatives to the websites they want us to takedown.</p>\n<p>In other words, they are <em>ordering us</em> to take down <em>competing</em> websites, with <strong>no legal basis</strong>, <span><em>hijacking</em></span> the traffic, and redirecting it to <span>competing commercial services</span>, all of which are based out of (guess where?) <strong>London, UK</strong>.</p>\n<p>And here they are complaining about \u201cprofiting from illegal activity\u201d.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<h2>Update #2</h2>\n<p>I\u2019ve seen a few comments around the internet that this was so over-the-top <em>wrong</em> that it couldn\u2019t be real and was probably an elaborate phishing attempt.</p>\n<p>I too suspected as much, so I looked at the headers before writing this post, it looks like the real deal:</p>\n<p><code/></p>\n<p>Return-Path: &lt;PIPCUantipiracy@city-of-london.pnn.police.uk&gt;</p>\n<p>X-Original-To: markjr@[redacted]</p>\n<p>Delivered-To: servers.</p>\n<h2>Update #3</h2>\n<p>A friend emailed me and said that after reading this post, it wasn\u2019t crystal clear what we did about this or what our policy is. I\u2019ve seen a couple comments (<a href=\"http://news.slashdot.org/story/13/10/08/1814236/police-demand-summary-domain-takedown-traffic-redirection\" target=\"_blank\">slashdot story here</a>, etc) that seem to allude that the domain in question now points to the IP we mentioned.</p>\n<p>So just to clarify:</p>\n<p><strong>1) We haven\u2019t taken down the domain.</strong></p>\n<p>2) We told them to get a court order.</p>\n<p>Also, some people have observed that our own AUP mentions copyright infringement as grounds for termination. This is true and we have referred to\u00a0 it in the past in cases where the domain was actually hosting copyrighted material and refusing or ignoring legitimate takedown requests for that material.</p>\n<p>That said, our AUP states clearly: <em>What constitutes a violation of our AUP is at the sole discretion of easyDNS.</em> I cannot possibly imagine who else should be the final arbiters of that. An AUP and ToS is an agreement between the customer and the service provider. It is not a mechanism for third-parties to shoehorn their whims into somebody else\u2019s affairs. If you want to do that, get a court order.</p>\n<h2>Update #4</h2>\n<p>It also occurs to us that any registrars that <em>did </em>comply with these requests <a href=\"https://www.easydns.com/blog/2013/10/10/registrars-that-complied-with-shakedown-requests-may-now-be-in-violation-of-icann-transfers-policy/\">may now be in violation of the ICANN transfers policy</a> if they don\u2019t let those domains transfer away.</p>\n<h2>Update #5</h2>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.easydns.com/blog/2013/10/29/tdrp-proceedings-initiated-in-response-to-uk-police-shakedown/\" target=\"_blank\">We have initiated a Transfer Dispute Resolution Process against another registrar </a>who has complied with these takedown requests and will not let 3 domains transfer-away to easyDNS.</p>\n<h2>Update #6</h2>\n<p>It was a long haul, but the NAF panel found in our favor and <a href=\"https://www.easydns.com/blog/2014/01/09/domains-locked-in-london-police-takedown-ordered-to-be-transferred/\">ordered the three domains locked down at another registrar to be transferred to easyDNS.</a></p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430657": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 02:47:49", "url": "15431170": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:15:08", "url": "https://www.itwire.com/open-sauce/80256-the-algorithm-did-it-facebook-s-stamos-tries-to-shift-blame.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"itemIntroText\">\n<p>Facebook's chief security office Alex Stamos has taken to the digital airwaves (read Twitter) to try and counter the assumption that the social media giant is sitting on its hands when it comes to preventing the spread of fake news on its channels.</p>&#13;\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"itemFullText\">\n<p>But perhaps he should have sat down and composed a more sober response in a long-form essay, rather than write what appear to be a series of disjointed tweets - they aren't even numbered in the way people normally do when they tweet something that crosses over into multiple stanzas.</p>&#13;\n<p>Facebook has been under pressure ever since it was found that numerous posts on its website had been works of fiction that spread canards about the Democrats in the run-up to last year's presidential election. Worse has followed with the discovery of US$100,000 worth of advertising that has been said to have Russian links.</p>&#13;\n<p>And in an atmosphere where anything to do with Russia is seen as the devil's handiwork, Stamos, as the man who is seen as the one barring the way to evil forces that attempt to disturb Mark Zuckerberg's peace of mind, appears to have got more than a little rattled.</p>&#13;\n<p>\t</p><p>\n\tHave a look </p><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexstamos\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">at the tweets</a></strong><p> for yourself, dear reader.&#13;\n</p><p>Stamos claims that he (and all other techies presumably, including the equally incompetent members of the Silicon Valley tribe over at Google) are aware of the shortcomings of machine-learning and artificial intelligence in discerning what is, and what is now, fake news.</p>&#13;\n<p><img src=\"https://www.itwire.com/images/authors-images/samvarghese/blame_big2.jpg\" alt=\"blame big2\"/></p>&#13;\n<p>Pity that he found out only after Facebook accumulated two billion users.</p>&#13;\n<p>Google was similarly out in action recently, blaming its algorithms \u2014 created by itself, but now held somewhat at hands-length like a disreputable third-cousin \u2014 when <strong>it <a href=\"https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2017/10/google-admits-citing-4chan-to-spread-fake-vegas-shooter-news/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">placed links</a></strong> from the notorious 4chan forum among the top news links about the Las Vegas shooting.</p>&#13;\n<p>Here's <strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexstamos/status/916699893535694848\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">one</a></strong> of the many gems from Stamos: \"A lot of people aren't thinking hard about the world they are asking SV to build. When the gods wish to punish us they answer our prayers.\"</p>&#13;\n<p>Presumably, he means software vendors by that acronym. I'm not sure who asked any vendor to fashion the world we live in; the vendors do it because they want to make money, lots of it. Snap out of it Alex, nobody vested you with this or any other task.</p>&#13;\n<p>Stamos has been particularly critical of journalists. \"If your piece assumes that a problem hasn't been addressed because everybody at these companies is a nerd, you are incorrect,\" <strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexstamos/status/916698696124788736\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">runs</a></strong> another tweet.</p>&#13;\n<p>My assumption, dear Alex, is that problems are not addressed because it would cost money and reduce your profits. You build up an audience in the billions that you are incapable of handling, refuse to admit the reality that you are a media company, and then attempt to ladle out blame when you are caught with your pants down.</p>&#13;\n<p>Here's <strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexstamos/status/916697792369717248\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">another</a></strong> of the tweets: \"My suggestion for journalists is to try to talk to people who have actually had to solve these problems and live with the consequences.\"</p>&#13;\n<p>Sure, Alex, but what is point of asking any questions when you tech overlords avoid talking in plain lingo and stick to bizspeak to say a lot, and at the same time say nothing?</p>&#13;\n<p>Stamos reminds me of a man who jumps out of a plane, looks for his parachute on the way down, and then starts blaming the airline/pilot/stewards when he cannot find it. Facebook has taken on a task that is beyond its level of competence \u2014 look up that phrase in The Peter Principle, dear Alex \u2014 and is now looking to cover its arse.</p>&#13;\n<p>This has happened numerous times before in Silicon Valley so one should take Stamos's rant with a pinch \u2014 nay a tonne \u2014 of salt. Please visit https:&#x2F;&#x2F;j.vlinx.io to have a try."}, "15431174": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:16:02", "url": "https://www.ghacks.net/2017/10/06/mozilla-to-launch-firefox-cliqz-experiment-with-data-collecting/", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"entry\"><p>Mozilla plans to launch a new Firefox experiment for Cliqz next week for German Firefox users who download the browser from the organization's website.</p><p>Mozilla has a business relationship with Cliqz GMBH. <a href=\"https://www.ghacks.net/2017/02/15/cliqz-acquires-ghostery/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\">The German company acquired Ghostery recently</a>, and maintains its own web browser as well as browser extensions.</p><p>Mozilla's relationship with Cliqz began when the company <a href=\"https://www.ghacks.net/2013/04/10/mozilla-adds-cliqz-msnnow-and-mixi-as-social-providers-to-firefox/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\">added Cliqz as a social provider in Firefox</a>. <a href=\"https://www.ghacks.net/2017/01/11/firefox-cliqz-test-pilot-experiment-available/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\">Cliqz was launched in early 2017</a> as a Firefox Test Pilot experiment.</p><p>Cliqz adds real-time results and suggestions to Firefox's address bar. If you type \"weather Amsterdam\" for instance, a weather forecast is displayed directly in the Firefox address bar.</p><p><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-129090\" src=\"//cdn.ghacks.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/cliqz-test-pilot-firefox.png\" alt=\"cliqz test pilot firefox\" srcset=\"//cdn.ghacks.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/cliqz-test-pilot-firefox.png 707w, //cdn.ghacks.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/cliqz-test-pilot-firefox-660x414.png 660w, //cdn.ghacks.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/cliqz-test-pilot-firefox-100x63.png 100w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 707px) 100vw, 707px\"/></p><p>Mozilla announced today on its German press blog that it plans to run a Cliqz experiment in the coming weeks.</p><p>This experiment will run only in Germany, and for less than one percent of users who download Firefox from Mozilla's website. These users will have Cliqz activated as an add-on automatically according to Mozilla.</p><p>Mozilla notes that it is necessary to transfer address bar content to Cliqz servers to power the functionality. This means, essentially that anything that is entered into the address bar, either automatically or manually, is transferred to Cliqz.</p><p>In other words, users who are selected for participation are opted-in automatically in the data collecting.</p><p>Cliqz runs cleanup routines according to Mozilla to ensure that sensitive information is not transferred. The company deletes IP address furthermore, and does not create user browsing profiles either.</p><p>Mozilla Firefox users who don't want to use Cliqz may deactivate the add-on or disable it instead.</p><ol><li>Load about:addons in the browser's address bar to open the Add-ons Manager.</li><li>You take part in the experiment if you see Cliqz listed there (and have not added it through other means).</li><li>You may disable or remove Cliqz from Firefox using buttons provided on the page.</li></ol><p>A German support page <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/de/kb/cliqz-vorschlage-firefox\" data-wpel-link=\"external\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"external noopener noreferrer\">offers</a> additional information on Cliqz and the removal.</p><h3>My Take</h3><p>Firefox users are probably more privacy conscious than any other browser users, with the exception of the Tor browser probably. The browser is less privacy invasive than Google Chrome for instance, and offers plenty of settings and options to improve privacy further.</p><p>Mozilla started to change its stance on data collecting in the past year or so however. Opting users in automatically is something that I'm not fond off. I don't know whether Firefox installations with Cliqz added to them will inform the user about this behavior. I think that is the least that Mozilla could do to prevent a total privacy disaster.</p><p><strong>Now You</strong>: What's your take on this?</p><div id=\"snippet-box\"><p class=\"snippet-title\">Summary</p><div itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Article\"><div class=\"aio-info\"><p class=\"snippet-label-img\">Article Name</p><p class=\"snippet-data-img\"><span itemprop=\"headline\">Mozilla to launch Firefox Cliqz Experiment with data collecting</span></p><p class=\"snippet-clear\"/><p class=\"snippet-label-img\">Description</p><p class=\"snippet-data-img\"><span itemprop=\"description\">Mozilla plans to launch a new Firefox experiment for Cliqz next week for German Firefox users who download the browser from the organization's website.</span></p><p class=\"snippet-clear\"/><p class=\"snippet-label-img\">Author</p><p class=\"snippet-data-img\" itemprop=\"author\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"https://schema.org/Person\"> <span itemprop=\"name\">Martin Brinkmann</span></p><p class=\"snippet-clear\"/><p class=\"snippet-label-img\">Publisher</p><div itemprop=\"publisher\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"https://schema.org/Organization\"><p class=\"snippet-data-img\"> <span itemprop=\"name\">Ghacks Technology News</span></p><p class=\"snippet-clear\"/><p class=\"snippet-label-img\">Logo</p></div><meta itemscope=\"\" itemprop=\"mainEntityOfPage\" itemtype=\"https://schema.org/WebPage\" itemid=\"https://www.ghacks.net/2017/10/06/mozilla-to-launch-firefox-cliqz-experiment-with-data-collecting/\"/><meta itemprop=\"datePublished\" content=\"2017-10-06T13:53:21+00:00\"/><meta itemprop=\"dateModified\" content=\"2017-10-07T05:10:25+00:00\"/></div></div></div><p class=\"snippet-clear\"/></section><aside id=\"post-author\"><p class=\"profile-image\"/><div class=\"profile-content\"><h4>About Martin Brinkmann</h4><p> Martin Brinkmann is a journalist from Germany who founded Ghacks Technology News Back in 2005. I was surprised, a few years ago, in performing anachronism consulting for the show \"Masters of Sex,\" set in the early 1960s, to see my algorithms reject one character's suggestion that Masters and Johnson needed to publish in peer reviewed journals as hopelessly anachronistic. But that is indeed the case.\u00a0</span><span>Google Ngrams shows only sporadic uses\nbefore about 1970; the adjectival form \"peer reviewed,\" as adhering to scholarship, barely exists before 1980. (As always, you should basically ignore Google Ngrams results from after 2000, but why not include them?)</span>\n\n<span><br/></span>\n<span>Of course the thing may exist before the word: but one thing I've found invariably in looking at these etymologies is words usually do not march straight out of the primordial ooze into widespread use for no reason at all, particularly words describing so specific and unpoetic as a practice like this. Usually there is some reason, some new thing in the world that requires a new term to distinguish it from what has come before.</span>\n<span><br/></span>\n<span>So what new thing gave rise to peer review? Reading through the texts gives some sense. JStor contains no uses of the phrase until 1965, in reference\nto \u201cpeer review groups\u201d at the NIH. Through the late 1960s the phrase was only\nused in the context of doctors supervising medical care of other doctors. The\nfirst use outside of medicine I find is in 1969, in a library sciences context,</span><span>1 </span><span>also about\nprofessional self-evaluation. An early usage for grants is in 1970.</span><span>2\u00a0</span><span>The first usage of the phrase in the American Historical Review is in 1978, in a\ndecidedly negative evaluation of the \u201cpeer review bureaucracies of foundations\nand government,\u201d \u201cmanned by scientists of lesser achievement.\u201d</span>\n<span><br/></span><p>\nSo what is the new thing being described here? As best as I can tell, the reason for its existence is the rise of the new government funding bureaucracy in the 1960s; the NIH, the NSF, and their smaller cousins like the NEH all needed mechanisms to distribute their new government largess: and peer review was a way to ensure that government money was not handed out by the government, but by experts from the scientific community. (This story, by the way, bears an interesting relationship to the one I wrote earlier this month about </p><a href=\"http://sappingattention.blogspot.com/2017/07/what-is-described-as-belonging-to.html\">government attributes versus public ones</a><p>; that sentence would have a different valence if I said that scholars wished to ensure the \"public money was not handed out by the public.\") Its use in non-publication situations--peer review boards investigating medical malpractice, for example--is almost entirely about protecting professional organizations from state or other bureaucratic interference. And when there are large-scale discussions of peer review in science--as in a </p><a href=\"http://journals.sagepub.com/toc/sthd/10/3\">special 1985 edition of \"Science, Technology, and Human values,\"</a><p>\u00a0they frequently take grant-making as the archetypal form, not the refereeing of scholarship.\n</p><p>\nThe central technology that causes this new term to spread to scholarship, then, is the grantmaking state. But this relies on a more prosaic technology, as well. Peer review is the archetypal form of scholarly organization in the age of the xerox machine. Without it, a sheaf of grant proposal could not be easily snapped into a binder, mailed across the country, and then (perhaps) flown back to Washington with its expert reader for discussion.\n</p><p>\nDigging around a little recently, I see that historian of science Alex Czsisar wrote a short piece for Nature in 2016 (after I gave this as a talk, so not fully incorporated here) where he says this, which is very much along the same lines.\n</p><blockquote class=\"tr_bq\">\n<span>'Peer review' was a term borrowed from the procedures that government agencies used to decide who would receive financial support for scientific and medical research. When 'referee systems' turned into 'peer review', the process became a mighty public symbol of the claim that these powerful and expensive investigators of the natural world had procedures for regulating themselves and for producing consensus, even though some observers quietly wondered whether scientific referees were up to this grand calling.</span></blockquote>\n<p>\nAll of this suggests, though it doesn't prove, that the shift to a language of \"peer review\" involves a model of research that draws on a nationally organized scientific funding system that merges with a series of older traditions. Most of the histories of peer review in the sciences note how late journals were to adopt it: leading British publications like the Lancet and Nature don't take up outside peer reviewers until the 1970s.</p>\n<p>\n<br/></p>\n<div><p>\nIf the history of peer review in the sciences is young, the history of peer review in the humanities is even younger. T</p><span>he earliest usage in the front-or-back matter of the American Historical Review that I see at first glance is from 1996, in describing who can perform book reviews; the second use outside a history-of-science context is in 1997, when Sheila Fitzpatrick notes unhappily that a book has obviously \"undergone extensive peer review\" in a way that weakens it, serving as an \"uncomfortable reminder that peer review may function not only as a gate-keeping procedure but also as a kind of censorship of unpopular opinions.\" (Here's <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23054375\">a similar 2012 argument</a> in favor of editorial review, *not* peer review, in a science journal). (Not far down the list is Ayers and Thomas's 2003 digital article \"The Differences Slavery Made;\" rather than showing up to challenge decades of consensus on peer review, digital scholarship was already arriving on the hardly after the consensus had set).</span>\n\n<span><span>I'd have to do more research to really understand what the outside review policies of leading journals were in the (say) 1950s and 1960s. I have the impression, but have lost the reference, that at least single-copy referee reviewing was common, if not mandatory, in the period. (\"Outside referee,\" though, is another 1960s neologism.) Still, the technology of mimeographs and carbon copies makes for different forms of outside review: In 1956, the <a href=\"https://www.jstor.org/stable/1848581?Search=yes&amp;resultItemClick=true&amp;searchText=%22carbon%20copy%22&amp;searchUri=%2Faction%2FdoBasicSearch%3Ffilter%3Djid%253A10.2307%252Fj100010%26amp%3BQuery%3D%2522carbon%2Bcopy%2522&amp;refreqid=search%3A4774cf3ea701092e473e6c5d6bac3339&amp;seq=2#page_scan_tab_contents\">AHR only demanded a single paper copy of each article</a> submitted. (The ribbon copy, please; keep the carbon copy for yourself.) This <a href=\"https://www.jstor.org/stable/1848020?seq=4#page_scan_tab_contents\">seems to have been still true in 1970</a>; I suppose by then the AHR could have been paying for photocopies on their own, but I doubt they did. By 1980, the number of required copies number has increased to 2; by the late 1990s, the frontmatter demanded four, or a Microsoft-compatible disk, which is what it would take for a really modern peer review system. But surely I've said enough now that someone will chime in in the comments about how mimeographs were sent to various reviewers in serial.</span></span>\n<span><br/></span>\n<span>I know even less about monographs; but it should be widely known that some important work in the field *continues* to be published as part of edited volumes, trade presses, and other channels subject only to editorial review, not peer review.</span>\n<span><br/></span>\n<span>So what? Obviously peer review didn't *really* come into being in the historical profession in 1995. That's ridiculous! Books and journals had various forms of outside referees in the mimeograph/carbon copy age as well. But the point is this: something did change, and more recently than we might think. Peer review was created, rather than always existing in the humanities; its rhetorical adoption in those fields as a core term may be less connected to eternal ideas of scholarship, and have more to do with the effort to make them more like the sciences in the postwar university. Be skeptical of the administrative-ese, buzzword-inflected vogue for the digital humanities all you want: but also, be aware that if you say \"peer review is fundamental to sound scholarship,\" you're speaking in the buzzwords of not long ago, yourself.</span>\n<p>\nI wouldn't argue in good faith that peer review is new, so it's bad. It might be that the scholarly practices from 1970 to 2010 are indeed worth preserving.</p></div>\n<p>\nBut at the same time, I'm not sure that digital scholarship could ever fully reconcile itself to peer review in the traditional sense without transforming it enough that we'll need a whole new phrase to describe the new regime to come.<br/>\n<br/></p>\n<p>\nRandomly selected bibliography:\n</p><p>\nSome early citations, and some previous histories.</p><span><br/></span>\n<span><br/></span><span>\u201cAtlantic City Conference: A Great Show\u2013in Two Parts and a Cast of Thousands.\u201d </span><span>ALA Bulletin </span><span>63, no. 7 (): 915\u2013964. http://www.jstor.org/stable/\n25698237.\n</span>\n<span><br/></span>\n\n     <span>Cooper, Joseph D. \u201cOnward the Management of Science: The Wooldridge Report.\u201d </span><span>Science </span><span>148, no. 3676. Wondering what the context of that statement could possibly be. Any successful cryptocurrency must solve the double-spend problem or there&#x27;s no value in the ledger at all.", "Here&#x27;s a stack exchange question:<p><a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;monero.stackexchange.com&#x2F;questions&#x2F;2158&#x2F;what-is-moneros-mechanism-for-defending-against-a-double-spend-attack\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;monero.stackexchange.com&#x2F;questions&#x2F;2158&#x2F;what-is-mone...</a><p>TL;DR Monero requires every transaction input to include a &quot;key image&quot; (an elliptic curve point, looks like a public key). The key image is deterministically constructed from the actual coin being spent, without actually revealing which one it is. So making sure the chain never contains a repeated key image is sufficient to make sure that no coin is ever spent more than once, without actually knowing whether any one specific coin is spent. This is how Monero achieves its inflation&#x2F;non-cloning guarantee.<p>(There was a famous double-spending bug in CryptoNote protocols you might have heard about that resulted in limitless inflation. This was because the Ed25519 signature scheme used has a co-factor of 8, a stupid performance &quot;enhancement&quot; that DJB should really re-think. As a result, a given key-image had a 1-in-8 chance of being malleable by adding a point of order 8. It&#x27;s fixed by checking that the key image is actually contained in the group. These sorts of unexpected consequences are why serious cryptographers don&#x27;t use co-factors other than 1, or other fiddly tricks that get you small constant implementation gains with risky not well studied trade-offs. This is also why the current push to standardize on DJB designed crypto solutions is borderline insanity. But I digress.)<p>The mathematics of what zerocash does is wildly different, but it serves essentially the same purpose. Each private&#x2F;anonymous spend in zerocash has some bits associated with it that are generated in a non-linking way from the input being spent. As long as there are never two transactions in the entire block chain history with the same value for this field, there are no double-spends.<p>-----<p>The problem is that these can never go away. In bitcoin if a coin is spent, you can prune knowledge of that coin from your local history. This is what the &quot;-prune&quot; option does in recent versions of Bitcoin Core. You still need to receive and process the transaction once when you sync the chain, but you can then throw it away if you are space constrained. Mimblewimble potentially improves the situation even better by boiling down each transaction to just a single EC point, the script kernel, such that a client needs only the current UTXO set and the full history of all these kernels to do initial sync. The rest of the data can well and truly be forgotten. But although those kernels are needed for initial sync, pruning nodes can throw them away afterwards. They are not needed for the validation of future blocks in any way.<p>TL;DR: The amount of data a verifier needs to keep around to validate a new block in bitcoin depends only on the number of unspent outputs. The full block chain is only needed for initial sync. This is asymptotically O(current size of bitcoin ecosystem). The amount of data needed by Monero or Zerocash, on the other hand, is (a constant factor of) the entire block chain used by these systems. This is asymptotically O(every transaction ever). Monero and ZCash are chugging along now, but every single block found increases the amount of data a verifier needs to keep around. That doesn&#x27;t scale....", "Very good summary of the issue.  This is actually a solveable problem. You use a tree of spent serial numbers  and non-membership proofs. This basically eliminates the over head to the network of managing serial numbers and checking for double spends. However, it requires they be stored somewhere because some of that data is needed to make non-membership proofs and update the tree.  To further reduce it, keep separate serial number data structures per some long epoch and reveal which epoch a coin was create in on spending. Now the burden epochs is only one people with coins in that epoch. For most reasonable scales, epochs can be very very long. Like 10 years.<p>As an aside, the fact that mimbelwimble does not have this issue should make you wonder just how much privacy it provides.", "That doesn\u2019t solve the issue. Maybe you should take a look at the genesis block of bitcoin, in case you don&#x27;t know what it is about."], "time": "2017-10-09 02:51:22", "url": "https://cryptopotato.com/zcashs-encrypted-blockchain-satoshis-vision-interview-zooko/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry-content col-sm-11\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<p>The following is an interview with Zooko Wilcox discusses the Zcash project and talks about the Crypto world in general, a very interesting talk with one of the leaders of the Crypto eco-system.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_3754\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-3754 size-full\" src=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Zooko-Wilcox-Criptomoneda-Zcash.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Zooko-Wilcox-Criptomoneda-Zcash.jpg 800w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Zooko-Wilcox-Criptomoneda-Zcash-300x200.jpg 300w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Zooko-Wilcox-Criptomoneda-Zcash-768x511.jpg 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\">Zooko Wilcox, Co-founder of Zcash</figcaption></figure>\n<h2>eCash (1983) \u2013 anonymous electronic cryptographic money</h2>\n<p>\u201cI had wanted something like bitcoin to exist for many years, before I heard about it. In fact, I\u2019m 43 now, more than half of my life ago, I discovered these science papers by a scientist named <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Chaum\">David Chaum</a> who invented the notion of encrypted crypto currency, internet money that was protected by cryptography.\u201d, according to Zooko, \u201cIt didn\u2019t have a decentralized monetary base. There was a central third party but it couldn\u2019t spy on the transactions of the users because of cryptography. It wasn\u2019t a complete solution.\u201d</p>\n<p><em>David Chaum invented </em><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecash\"><em>eCash</em></a><em>, as anonymous cryptographic electronic money in 1983. In 1990, he founded the </em><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DigiCash\"><em>DigiCash </em></a><em>company for the implementation of eCash by third party corporations (mainly banks). The eCash solution ensures the privacy of its users. eCash was implemented by one bank in the US and a few banks in Europe.</em></p>\n<p><em>\u00a0<img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-3752\" src=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ecash.png\" alt=\"ecash\"/></em></p>\n<h2>It\u2019s all about Berlin\u2019s wall, internet and crypto</h2>\n<p>\u201cA couple of years before I came across David Chaum\u2019s invention, I discovered the internet. The internet was pretty new then. I thought it was really exciting that distance and national borders were no longer complete barriers to communication. Before the internet, people didn\u2019t really talk to, or learn the thoughts, of people from other countries. The only way was if you read a book or could take from whatever the newspapers or the TV stations chose to tell you about people\u2019s thoughts from other countries.</p>\n<p>Another formative event in my life was the fall of the Berlin Wall. It meant that national borders would stop being jail cells to people. In 1993, I discovered Cryptocurrency through DigiCash, and I thought this was the third part of the revolution; so distance and borders would no longer be barriers to resource sharing and going into business together \u2013 that one unfortunately didn\u2019t work out.\u201d</p>\n<p>In Zooko\u2019s vision, there are the three parts of the revolution \u2013 The fall of the Berlin wall, the invention of the internet and the invention of cryptocurrencies which represent a world with open borders, global open communication and an open economy without a distance or origin barrier.</p>\n<p><strong>INTERNET \u2013 Are we moving in the wrong direction?</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cYears later, the internet revolution started to roll back, it became more of the case that national borders are barriers to communication between people. It is profoundly the case in China. In the West we are used to using the internet, and it is like an extension of our brains. When I went to China it felt like having a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lobotomy\">lobotomy</a>, I couldn\u2019t Google anything. No Facebook, no New-York Times, no Wikipedia\u2026 It is moving in the wrong direction.\u201c</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_3755\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/censorship.jpg\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-3755\" src=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/censorship.jpg\" alt=\"censorship\" srcset=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/censorship.jpg 620w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/censorship-300x155.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 620px) 100vw, 620px\"/></a><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\">Internet Censorship map (Source: www.isoc.org)</figcaption></figure>\n<h2>Bitcoin vs. Zcash</h2>\n<p>\u201cBitcoin and Zcash represent to me the third part that will help sustain the other two \u2013 <em>open borders and global open communication</em> \u2013 and will keep the internet open and global\u201d.</p>\n<p><strong>Our data is owned by private companies</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cThe potential for protecting and expanding human freedom is exciting. We are currently on a very dangerous pattern. The level of surveillance available for government is unprecedented in human history. Since humans were born until 15 years ago, there was never anything like that. There were cases throughout history when governments were more proactive in collecting data.</p>\n<p>Though, the modern large companies and the governments have way more data on us than the German secret police ever had. East German secret police had about one half of their citizens secretly reporting on the other half and they had buildings full of folders and files with the data of all the citizens in the country. But this is nothing compared to the data about us that Google owns today. There is a big difference if you have one data point from everyday compared to a data point of every micro-second.\u201d</p>\n<p><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-3756\" src=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cyber-security-2765707_640.jpg\" alt=\"cyber-security\" srcset=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cyber-security-2765707_640.jpg 640w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cyber-security-2765707_640-300x200.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/></p>\n<p><strong>How is all of the above background related to Zcash</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cWell, that\u2019s really why I started Zcash 3 years ago, because I was concerned about these issues and thought Zcash could make a big difference\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Zcash explained to the normal human being</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cIt is a kind of money that doesn\u2019t come from any government or company and it protects the information about your transaction so that information is not disclosed to hackers or anyone. That\u2019s basically Zcash.\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Tahoe LAFS</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cI made a company that made a cryptographically protected distributed storage system called, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tahoe-LAFS\">Tahoe LAFS</a>. That\u2019s a distributed encrypted storage system like <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InterPlanetary_File_System\">IPFS</a>. Tahoe LAFS, which is still going on, is a very interesting project. One difference between it and IPFS is that the files are encrypted so you have control over who gets to see the content of them.</p>\n<p>Another thing that the startup does is security audits for cryptographic software. For example, we were hired by the<strong> Ethereum </strong>development team before the launch of Ethereum to do security auditing of Ethereum. We were hired by many other good projects to do security audits.\u201d</p>\n<h2>I wanted to work on Zcash day and night for the rest of my life</h2>\n<p>\u201cOne day, a team of scientists from the USA and Israel, who developed the idea behind Zcash approached me and asked me to commercialize the new project. They knew of my previous work at Tahoe LAFS. At first I said no. Even though I thought privacy is really important to me and is important for society, Bitcoin had a head start. So this new thing (Zcash) would just be a niche product for special purposes and wouldn\u2019t be a mainstream product.\u201d</p>\n<p>However, after some deeper thinking, I realized that privacy is necessary for the mainstream users too and eventually I said Yes. And from that point, I wanted to work on Zcash day and night for the rest of my life. In addition to privacy\u2019s importance for humanity, civil rights and the safety of society is also necessary for business. \u00a0Every mainstream business that wants to use cryptocurrency will need it.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cIf you want to use a cryptocurrency to buy and sell goods and services for your business you need privacy so that you are not leaking information about your transactions to competitors, criminals and unauthorized parties. In the US, it is absolutely illegal for any business that manages customer\u2019s money, to leak information about it to an unauthorized party.\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Fungibility</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cFor a thing to serve as <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money\">money</a>, it needs to be transferable, easy to count, and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fungibility\">fungible</a>.</p>\n<p>If you are selling your used bike for 100 USD, and someone offers you two 100 USD bills, you probably don\u2019t care which one of them you take. Two 100 USD bills means the same to you. However, if you are selling your used bike and someone offers you one of two used laptops, you really care about which used laptop to take. No used laptop is worth exactly the same as another to you. That\u2019s why dollars have fungibility and used laptops don\u2019t have fungibility.\u201d</p>\n<h2>\u201cSome people don\u2019t trust JP Morgan\u201d</h2>\n<p><strong>What value does Bitcoin bring to the world?</strong><em>The question was asked a few days after </em><em>Jamie Dimon, </em><em>J.P. Morgan</em><em>\u2019s CEO, called Bitcoin a </em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/sep/13/bitcoin-fraud-jp-morgan-cryptocurrency-drug-dealers\"><em>fraud</em></a></p>\n<p>\u201cI think the core value proposition is that some people don\u2019t trust JP Morgan. There isn\u2019t any government or a person that everyone on the planet trusts. One can say, let\u2019s make a world bank that everyone trusts. Fact is, that\u2019s not the world we live in. That is the unique value proposition of Bitcoin and Zcash, not the technology. But a thing that you and someone else can rely on, even though you and the other person don\u2019t trust the same bank or the same government. I love Bitcoin, it is a revolution. I\u2019m the author of the first ever <a href=\"http://web.archive.org/web/20090426214618/http:/testgrid.allmydata.org:3567/uri/URI:DIR2-RO:j74uhg25nwdpjpacl6rkat2yhm:kav7ijeft5h7r7rxdp5bgtlt3viv32yabqajkrdykozia5544jqa/wiki.html#%5B%5BDecentralized%20Money%5D%5D\">blog post</a> about Bitcoin (Jan 26, 2009). In fact, Satoshi Nakamoto\u2019s home page linked to my home page at one point\u201d</p>\n<p><em>Satoshi Nakamoto\u2019s Bitcoin </em><a href=\"http://web.archive.org/web/20090303195936/http:/bitcoin.org:80/\"><em>alpha release blog</em></a><em> post (March 3rd, 2009) linked to the following blog post written by Zooko: </em><em>Decentralized Money, 26 January 2009 (created 26 January 2009)</em></p>\n<p><em>\u201cI\u2019ve been spending a little bit of time thinking about how gaming services like </em><em>World of Warcraft</em><em> and (don\u2019t-call-it-a-gaming-service) </em><em>Second Life</em><em> have succeeded where we at DigiCash failed \u2014 convenient, widely-used, programmable digital cash. A problem is that each of these new currencies are centrally controlled by one entity. This limits the scope of who will rely on that currency and how much value they will risk on that currency. There are ideas floating around about how to facilitate transactions between currencies, but this would not solve the problem. </em><em>A plethora of competing centralized services is not the same as a decentralized service.</em><em> Even if it were cheap and convenient to trade some LindenBucks for some WoW Gold, this would only lead us back to the equivalent of the modern nation-state currencies: mostly centralized (because of </em><em>the Network Externality</em><em>), heavily taxed/regulated/manipulated, and prone to disastrous failure. What I want is a currency which everyone can cheaply and conveniently use but which </em><strong><em>no-one</em></strong><em> has the power to manipulate. No-one has the power to inflate or deflate the currency supply, no-one has the power to monitor, tax, or prevent transactions. Truly the digital equivalent of gold, during the times and places when gold was the universal currency. See the </em><a href=\"http://unenumerated.blogspot.com/2005/12/bit-gold.html\"><em>BitGold</em></a><em> idea by Nick Szabo and </em><a href=\"http://www.weidai.com/bmoney.txt\"><em>b-money</em></a><em> idea by Wei Dai, and recent effort to actually implement something along these lines: </em><a href=\"http://www.bitcoin.org/\"><em>BitCoin</em></a><em> by Satoshi Nakamoto.\u201d</em></p>\n<p><strong>What value does Zcash bring to the world that Bitcoin does not?</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cThere is a huge flaw in Bitcoin. Satoshi knew this, he also valued <strong>privacy</strong>. He talked about how he hoped Bitcoin\u2019s privacy would be sufficient and of the possible ways to improve its privacy using encryption. Bitcoin\u2019s privacy is a total failure. The only reason Satoshi didn\u2019t put better privacy into Bitcoin originally is that we didn\u2019t have sophisticated enough cryptography back then. It was after Satoshi was doing his work that we discovered the new mathematics of efficient Zero Knowledge Proofs that allow us to do it correctly in Zcash.\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Zero Knowledge Proofs </strong></p>\n<p><strong>\u00a0</strong>\u201cZero Knowledge Proof is not what gives you privacy, it is just the necessary glue to allow us to use encryption. The way privacy is provided in Zcash is the same way privacy is provided with every high security computer and network (Secured databases of banks in the world for example). The reason transactions are public in Bitcoin is so the miners can detect invalid transactions and exclude them in order for Bitcoin to work. That\u2019s why Satoshi couldn\u2019t encrypt the transactions; otherwise he would have done it. The innovation of Zero Knowledge Proof allows us to prove that a transaction is valid even though the transaction is encrypted.</p>\n<p>It is an interesting discovery that was made about 30 years ago. <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shafi_Goldwasser\"><strong>Shafi Goldwasser</strong></a> is one of the scientists behind this proof. She later won the Turing award for this discovery, which is one of the most prestigious awards for a computer scientist. They identified the concept of proving the solution without revealing the solution, and proved that it was possible to do it. But, the way that they showed that it was possible to do it, was totally impractical, that\u2019s why Satoshi couldn\u2019t use it in 2008.<strong>\u201c</strong></p>\n<p><em>The following is a great example, we came by, for the Zero Knowledge proof: </em></p>\n<p><em>Imagine your friend is color-blind. You have two billiard balls; one is red, one is green, but they are otherwise identical. To your friend they seem completely identical, and he is skeptical that they are actually distinguishable. You want to prove to him that they are in fact differently-colored. On the other hand, you do not want him to learn which is red and which is green.</em></p>\n<p><em>Here is the proof system: You give the two balls to your friend so that he is holding one in each hand. You can see the balls at this point, but you don\u2019t tell him which is which. Your friend then puts both hands behind his back. Next, he either switches the balls between his hands, or leaves them be, with probability 1/2 each. Finally, he brings them out from behind his back. You now have to \u201cguess\u201d whether or not he switched the balls. By looking at their colors, you can, of course, say with certainty whether or not he switched them. On the other hand, if they were the same color and hence indistinguishable, there is no way you could guess correctly with probability higher than 1/2.</em></p>\n<p><em>If you and your friend repeat this \u201cproof\u201d\u00a0 </em> <em>\u00a0times (for large t), your friend should become convinced that the balls are indeed differently colored; otherwise, the probability that you would have succeeded at identifying all the switch/non-switches is at most t^-2</em> <em>. Furthermore, the proof is \u201czero-knowledge\u201d because your friend never learns which ball is green and which is red; indeed, he gains no knowledge about how to distinguish the balls.</em></p>\n<p><em>The same idea works for Zcash. The miner can verify an encrypted transaction without seeing the transaction itself. He repeats some mathematical proof where each time he gains some more certainty that the transaction is indeed valid. After a large number of proofs the probability that the miner will approve an un-valid transaction becomes negligible. </em></p>\n<p><strong>Government recognition of Zcash</strong></p>\n<p><em>Japan as an example:\u00a0</em>\u201cIf you are the financial services authority of Japan, you don\u2019t want Japanese people using a payment system which discloses all of their transaction to North Korea (as in Bitcoin).\u00a0Bitcoin is more dangerous for Japanese people in that way than Zcash is.\u201d</p>\n<p><em>Just logon to </em><a href=\"https://blockchain.info/\"><em>Blockchain.info</em></a><em> to see the latest Bitcoin transactions, as seen here for example: everyone can see the sender and receiver addresses, the amount of money transferred and when.</em></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-3753\" src=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5.png 1125w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5-300x142.png 300w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5-768x362.png 768w, https://cryptopotato.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/p5-1024x483.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1125px) 100vw, 1125px\"/></a></p>\n<p>\u201cThere are tradeoffs. If the Japanese people use Zcash, you do lose traceability, but it is ok because you don\u2019t have that traceability for cash or even for credit cards\u201d (<em>a third party discloses the transaction information if needed, but it is not open to anyone \u2013 selective transparency</em>). That\u2019s the same thing you can do with Zcash, it also has selective transparency. \u201c</p>\n<p><em>Selective transparency is a feature in the Zcash protocol that gives a user the ability to disclose his transaction history to a certain party. For other parties, all the user\u2019s transaction history is encrypted.</em></p>\n<p>\u201cMost of the bitcoin payment transactions rely on a third party intermediary (like CoinBase, BitStamp, Bitflyer etc.). As long as people rely on a third party intermediary, Zcash acts more like the conventional banking system does from the perspective of regulation. In that model, the encryption in Zcash is not hiding the information from the provider and it\u2019s not hiding the information from the Japanese government. It\u2019s hiding the information from the North Korean government.\u00a0People that don\u2019t use a third party cannot use the banking system, but they can use Bitcoin or Zcash. If you use Bitcoin, your information is disclosed to anyone on the internet.\u00a0With Zcash the information is protected.\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Adding private information to a transaction on the Zcash blockchain</strong></p>\n<p><strong>\u00a0</strong>\u201cAnother virtue of Zcash, is that it allows you to put more information into the transaction.</p>\n<p>Because the transaction is only visible to authorized parties, you don\u2019t mind adding to the transaction. For example \u2013 \u2018this is for the shaving brush\u2019, whereas in Bitcoin, you might not want to add further information to it as it is transparent to the world.</p>\n<p>That information will be visible to the government either if you use a third party intermediary or you choose to disclose that information to the government.</p>\n<p>In conclusion, Zcash might be better for the government in some cases because once the user is compliant or uses a third party for his payments, the information is richer. There is a law which Bitcoin companies cannot satisfy and Zcash can. The <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Know_your_customer\">KYC </a>(know your customer) of the customer has to travel with the payment if you transfer money on behalf of the customer from one financial institution to another.\u201d</p>\n<p><strong>Nowadays, Bitcoin and Zcash serve mainly as a store of value. Will it ever serve as a currency?</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cThat is my goal; for Zcash and for Bitcoin to serve as a currency. A good strategy for that, is to look for opportunities where the competition is weak. Wherever the competition is worst, that\u2019s where Zcash and Bitcoin can shine. I really want Zcash to take over the USD, but it is going to take a long time, that is a bigger challenge. Currently, I\u2019m really excited about Zcash against the Venezuelan Bolivar, Zcash is obviously way better than it.\u201d</p>\n<p><em>A cup of coffee in eastern Caracas, Venezuela, today costs 460% more bolivar than it cost a year ago (450 to 2,800 Bolivar). As published on the </em><a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2016-venezuela-cafe-con-leche-index/\"><em>Venezuelan cafe con leche index</em></a>.</p>\n<p>\u201cThere are around 250 fiat currencies in the world, the average currency lasts just 100 years.\u00a0You can basically expect one fiat currency to completely fail every few years. Currently it is the Venezuelan Bolivar.</p>\n<p>The great competitor for a failed currency is the USD, one way Zcash and Bitcoin could benefit from that, is to serve as the gateway to USD for these countries. In Venezuela, you cannot have USD in your bank account. I would be happy if Zcash and Bitcoin could serve as a gateway from an unstable currency (Venezuelan Bolivar) to a stable currency (EURO/USD)\u201d</p>\n<h3>Comments</h3><p class=\"fb-comments\" data-href=\"http://cryptopotato.com/zcashs-encrypted-blockchain-satoshis-vision-interview-zooko/\" data-num-posts=\"5\" data-width=\"100%\" data-colorscheme=\"light\"/>\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<footer class=\"entry-footer\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<p class=\"entry-edit\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</p>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<nav class=\"post-navigation\" rel=\"navigation\"/>\t\t\t\t\t</footer>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15431184": {"score": 4, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:21:12", "url": "https://medium.com/@braddwyer/behind-the-magic-how-we-built-the-arkit-sudoku-solver-e586e5b685b0", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><p name=\"7aed\" id=\"7aed\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Magic Sudoku uses a combination of Computer Vision, Machine Learning, and Augmented Reality to give a magical user experience that \u201cjust works\u201d when you point your phone at a Sudoku puzzle. The basic flow of the application is this:</p><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"3862\" id=\"3862\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">ARKit gets a new frame from the camera.</li><li name=\"0716\" id=\"0716\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">We use <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/documentation/vision\" data-href=\"https://developer.apple.com/documentation/vision\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">iOS11\u2019s Vision Library</a> to detect rectangles in the image.</li><li name=\"2399\" id=\"2399\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">If rectangles are found we determine whether they are a Sudoku.</li><li name=\"5a03\" id=\"5a03\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">If we find a puzzle we split it up into 81 square images.</li><li name=\"d3d2\" id=\"d3d2\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">Each square is run through <a href=\"https://medium.com/towards-data-science/handwritten-digit-recognition-with-mnist-on-ios-with-keras-e85e194f9fa5\" data-href=\"https://medium.com/towards-data-science/handwritten-digit-recognition-with-mnist-on-ios-with-keras-e85e194f9fa5\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" target=\"_blank\">a neural network we trained</a> to determine what number (if any) it represents.</li><li name=\"34ea\" id=\"34ea\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">Once enough numbers are gathered we use a <a href=\"https://spin.atomicobject.com/2012/06/18/solving-sudoku-in-c-with-recursive-backtracking/\" data-href=\"https://spin.atomicobject.com/2012/06/18/solving-sudoku-in-c-with-recursive-backtracking/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">traditional recursive algorithm</a> to solve the puzzle.</li><li name=\"fc94\" id=\"fc94\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">We pass a 3D model representing the solved puzzle <a href=\"https://github.com/mludowise/ARKitRectangleDetection\" data-href=\"https://github.com/mludowise/ARKitRectangleDetection\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">back to ARKit to display on top of the original image</a> from the camera.</li></ul><p name=\"c7c7\" id=\"c7c7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--li\">All of this happens several times each second.</p><p name=\"aed5\" id=\"aed5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I won\u2019t dwell too much on the ARKit portion, the Sudoku solving algorithm, or the actual Machine Learning model itself (there are plenty of tutorials written about those subjects already).</p><p name=\"150d\" id=\"150d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">What was most interesting to me were the practical aspects I learned <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">while</em> training my first machine learning algorithm.</p><h3 name=\"bb74\" id=\"bb74\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Machine Learning: Lessons\u00a0Learned</h3><h4 name=\"8c04\" id=\"8c04\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--h3\">I first learned several ways that wouldn\u2019t\u00a0work</h4><p name=\"60f1\" id=\"60f1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">One of the original reasons I chose a Sudoku solver as our first AR app was that I knew classifying digits is basically <a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=hello+world+of+deep+learning\" data-href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=hello+world+of+deep+learning\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">the \u201chello world\u201d of Machine Learning</a>. I wanted to dip my toe in the water of Machine Learning while working on a real-world problem. This seemed like a realistic app to tackle.</p><p name=\"80b3\" id=\"80b3\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Before I set out on training my own model, I tried a few strategies that would have made things a lot easier if they had worked.</p><p name=\"99ac\" id=\"99ac\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The first thing I tried was using an optical character recognition library called <a href=\"https://github.com/garnele007/SwiftOCR\" data-href=\"https://github.com/garnele007/SwiftOCR\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">SwiftOCR</a>. The problem with using SwiftOCR for my use case was that it is designed for reading strings (like giftcard codes) rather than individual numbers. I also couldn\u2019t get it to differentiate between \u201cthis is an empty square\u201d and \u201cI couldn\u2019t read this digit\u201d. After several hours of experimentation it wasn\u2019t doing much better than randomly guessing digits. That\u2019s not a knock on SwiftOCR. It\u2019s a great library; it\u2019s just not well suited for this particular problem.</p><p name=\"0024\" id=\"0024\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Second, I moved on to <a href=\"https://github.com/ph1ps/MNIST-CoreML\" data-href=\"https://github.com/ph1ps/MNIST-CoreML\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">a pre-trained MNIST model</a> that had already been converted to CoreML. MNIST is an open dataset of handwritten digits released in the 1990s. Using a pre-trained model would have been nice because it could have been a drop-in solution. The\u00a0<code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">.mlmodel</code> file is completely self contained and exposes a class in Swift that you can basically use as a black box oracle. Using MNIST was how I reached the milestone of having my first internal prototype that \u201cworked\u201d from start to finish. Unfortunately, the MNIST dataset of handwritten digits is not close enough to computer fonts to generalize well and that first prototype was very finicky and prone to errors.</p><p name=\"be17\" id=\"be17\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">By this point things were working well enough that I knew I was on the right track. I hoped that if I could train my own Machine Learning model on real-world data extracted from Sudoku puzzles that it would become a lot more accurate and reliable.</p><h4 name=\"7ecb\" id=\"7ecb\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Gathering data</h4><p name=\"8c53\" id=\"8c53\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">The next step was to gather as many examples of Sudoku puzzles as I could. I went to our local <a href=\"https://www.hpb.com/home\" data-href=\"https://www.hpb.com/home\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Half Price Book Store</a> and bought out their entire stock of Sudoku books.</p><p name=\"942d\" id=\"942d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I had the team at <a href=\"http://about.hatchlings.com\" data-href=\"http://about.hatchlings.com\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Hatchlings</a> help me rip them apart and I modified the prototype app to upload each of the small squares it scanned to a server instead of running them through the CoreML model.</p><figure name=\"5003\" id=\"5003\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Our treasure trove of real-world data acquired from the local secondhand book\u00a0store.</figcaption></figure><h4 name=\"52b8\" id=\"52b8\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--figure\">Many hands make for light\u00a0work</h4><p name=\"541a\" id=\"541a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Now I had a problem. After I scanned a wide variety of puzzles from each book, my server had stored about 600,000 images\u2026 but they were completely unlabeled.</p><figure name=\"7c04\" id=\"7c04\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--layoutOutsetLeft graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Simple classification tool</figcaption></figure><p name=\"189e\" id=\"189e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">So I cheated a little; I tapped into my secret superpower: thousands of <a href=\"http://about.hatchlings.com\" data-href=\"http://about.hatchlings.com\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Hatchlings</a> users happy to help the developer of their favorite game.</p><p name=\"992f\" id=\"992f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I made a simple admin tool that let users classify images by pressing the number keys on their keyboard. After putting out a call for help in our Hatchlings Facebook Group, our users made quick work of things and within 24 hours they had classified all 600,000 images!</p><figure name=\"4470\" id=\"4470\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--layoutOutsetLeft graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Admin tool to send mistakes back to the\u00a0pool</figcaption></figure><p name=\"2ed7\" id=\"2ed7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Unfortunately, a small minority had misunderstood the task and there were a significant number of misidentified images.</p><p name=\"3a44\" id=\"3a44\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">To correct this I made a second tool that showed you 100 images (all supposed to be the same number) and asked you to click the ones that didn\u2019t match (which then threw them back into the first tool to be reclassified).</p><p name=\"56ed\" id=\"56ed\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">After the first pass I had enough verified data that I was able to add an automatic accuracy checker into both tools for future data runs (it would periodically show the user known images and check their work to determine how much to trust their answers going forward).</p><p name=\"9ef6\" id=\"9ef6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Over the next few weeks our players classified several more batches of scanned data. By the time we launched the app it was trained on over a million images of Sudoku squares.</p><p name=\"8c51\" id=\"8c51\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I used this dataset in place of the MNIST dataset and used <a href=\"https://sriraghu.com/2017/07/06/computer-vision-in-ios-coremlkerasmnist/\" data-href=\"https://sriraghu.com/2017/07/06/computer-vision-in-ios-coremlkerasmnist/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">a tutorial to help me craft a neural network</a> using Keras. The results turned out better than I expected: 98.6% accuracy! We\u2019ve been able to improve that to above 99% accuracy in subsequent versions.</p><h4 name=\"201c\" id=\"201c\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Train on real world\u00a0data</h4><p name=\"24a1\" id=\"24a1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">At this point things were working well on the corpus of Sudoku puzzles we had collected from the bookstore. What we didn\u2019t realize was that this was only a small subset of the Sudoku puzzle layouts out there waiting for us in the wild.</p><p name=\"cd00\" id=\"cd00\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Immediately after launch we started receiving reports that our app wasn\u2019t working with on-screen puzzles. Of course! People wanted to try our app but they didn\u2019t have a Sudoku in front of them so they searched on Google for a puzzle to try it out. This is obvious in retrospect, but it blindsided us on launch day.</p><p name=\"acc7\" id=\"acc7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Problem number one was that our machine learning model was only trained on paper puzzles; it didn\u2019t know what to think about pixels on a screen. I pulled an all nighter that first week and re-trained our model with puzzles on computer screens.</p><p name=\"0211\" id=\"0211\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Problem number two was that ARKit only supports horizontal planes like tables and floors (not vertical planes like computer monitors). Solving this was a trickier problem but I did come up with a hacky workaround. I used a combination of some heuristics and <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">FeaturePoint</code> detection to place puzzles on non-horizontal planes.</p><figure name=\"b617\" id=\"b617\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--layoutOutsetLeft graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Our ML model is now trained on blurry images as\u00a0well</figcaption></figure><p name=\"9178\" id=\"9178\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Another unexpected issue we discovered after launch was that <a href=\"https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ufkTnSVvahEJ:https://forums.developer.apple.com/thread/78954+&amp;cd=2&amp;hl=en&amp;ct=clnk&amp;gl=us\" data-href=\"https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ufkTnSVvahEJ:https://forums.developer.apple.com/thread/78954+&amp;cd=2&amp;hl=en&amp;ct=clnk&amp;gl=us\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">ARKit has a fixed (and hard-coded) focal length</a>; it doesn\u2019t autofocus. There is also some variation between devices (things work Ok on my iPhone 7 camera sensor but iPhone 6S has trouble focusing up close). Our \u201cfix\u201d to this was to add blurrycam images to the training set. I wasn\u2019t sure whether it would be able to grok useful info from these images that I couldn\u2019t even read myself... but adding them didn\u2019t seem to affect accuracy of the model much if at all! The current version of the app works well even when the numbers in the image are super blurry.</p><h4 name=\"05f5\" id=\"05f5\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">The cloud</h4><p name=\"61cb\" id=\"61cb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Finally, I had heard a lot of hype about <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/amazon-ai/amis/\" data-href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/amazon-ai/amis/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">AWS\u2019s GPU Instances for Deep Learning</a> and <a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/products/machine-learning/\" data-href=\"https://cloud.google.com/products/machine-learning/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Google Cloud\u2019s Deep Learning offerings</a> so I tried them out (and also tried the \u201cHeroku for Deep Learning\u201d platform <a href=\"https://www.floydhub.com/\" data-href=\"https://www.floydhub.com/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">FloydHub</a>).</p><p name=\"5b5c\" id=\"5b5c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">They worked. But they were slow. My 2016 Macbook Pro running <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">tensorflow-cpu</code> was outperforming the AWS <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">p2.xlarge</code> GPU instance. My suspicion is that the training runs were being bottlenecked by disk not compute.</p><p name=\"c503\" id=\"c503\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The cloud instances are also expensive. By my calculations, the payoff period of building my own box would be less than 2 months of cloud run-time. So I <a href=\"https://pcpartpicker.com/list/FRmGCy\" data-href=\"https://pcpartpicker.com/list/FRmGCy\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">built a machine with relatively modest specs for about $1200</a> and parked it in my parents\u2019 basement. It\u2019s over 3x faster on my dataset than the AWS GPU instance I was experimenting with and should pay for itself soon.</p><h3 name=\"8c84\" id=\"8c84\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">What\u2019s Next</h3><p name=\"38b5\" id=\"38b5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">I\u2019m still a Machine Learning beginner but I\u2019ve learned a lot through making Magic Sudoku.</p><p name=\"cb43\" id=\"cb43\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Over the next few weeks I have a pretty long to-do list of bug fixes and minor improvements of the current feature-set. Now that I\u2019ve fixed most of the issues with weird fonts, weights, padding, and blurriness, the next step is to improve my heuristics to better identify puzzles.</p><p name=\"784f\" id=\"784f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The current version (v1.4) can get into trouble if there isn\u2019t much padding between the puzzle and the edge of the sheet of paper or if there is text near the edges. I have some theories on how I can improve this but it will probably be a lot of trial and error to get it right.</p><p name=\"7085\" id=\"7085\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">If I can\u2019t get the heuristics to work I\u2019ve been collecting a dataset of properly aligned puzzles and bad scans that I can use to train another neural network to filter out the bad scans.</p><p name=\"e9e0\" id=\"e9e0\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In the longer term we have plans to add some pretty awesome features. For example, we\u2019d like to add a \u201cchecker\u201d feature for completed puzzles. Most of the new features we have planned will require us to read and separate handwriting from computer-given numbers so we\u2019ve been collecting handwriting samples from users around the world to train a new machine learning model.</p><p name=\"e746\" id=\"e746\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">We also need to work out our business model. But that\u2019s a story that will have to wait for part three.</p><h3 name=\"02f3\" id=\"02f3\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Stay tuned\u2026</h3><p name=\"504f\" id=\"504f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">This is the second post in a 3-part series. </em><a href=\"https://blog.prototypr.io/why-we-built-magic-sudoku-the-arkit-sudoku-solver-306dde6c0a77\" data-href=\"https://blog.prototypr.io/why-we-built-magic-sudoku-the-arkit-sudoku-solver-306dde6c0a77\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" target=\"_blank\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Part one</em></a><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> explained why we decided to make Magic Sudoku and what makes it unique. Part three will explore the business side of launching an app like this and how it\u2019s been going so far.</em></p><p name=\"3986\" id=\"3986\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\"><a href=\"https://medium.com/@braddwyer\" data-href=\"https://medium.com/@braddwyer\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" target=\"_blank\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Subscribe</em></a><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> or </em><a href=\"https://www.twitter.com/braddwyer\" data-href=\"https://www.twitter.com/braddwyer\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">follow me on twitter</em></a><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> and you\u2019ll be the first to know when part three comes out. Spot can then fulfill your request by restarting instances from a stopped state when capacity is available within your price and time requirements. To use this new feature, choose \u201cstop\u201d instead of \u201cterminate\u201d as the interruption behavior when submitting a persistent Spot request. When you choose \u201cstop\u201d, Spot will shut down your instance upon interruption. The EBS root device and attached EBS volumes are saved, and their data persists. When capacity is available again within your price and time requirements, Spot will restart your instance. Upon restart, the EBS root device is restored from its prior state, previously attached data volumes are reattached, and the instance retains its instance ID. \u00a0</p>\n\n  \n</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429651": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:50:34", "url": "http://www.notemine.co", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"row bg-location-content\">\n                <div class=\"col-md-10 col-md-offset-1 text-center text-center card-comment\">\n                    <p id=\"retro_comment\" class=\"first-letter\">Dreaming of cruising into the sunset and never looking back</p>\n                </div>\n               <div class=\"testimonials text-center\">\n                    <div class=\"quote-author\">\n                        <img id=\"retro_avatar\" class=\"img-circle voffset2\" alt=\"avatar\" src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/uifaces/faces/twitter/sethsandler/128.jpg\"/>\n                        <h6 class=\"uppercase\" id=\"retro_display_name\">Seth Sendler</h6>\n                        <span id=\"date\">04.07.2016</span>\n                    </div> \n                </div>   \n                   \n            </div>\n            \n            </div></body></html>"}, "15429653": {"score": 252, "comments": ["I\u2019m a little confused why only 48 hours after his return from space, he\u2019s sleeping at home with his girlfriend and debating whether to take aspirin or go to the emergency room.
