As I walk by Samantha, I put my hand on her shoulder and she smiles up at me.</p><p data-reactid=\"498\">I make it to my bedroom without incident and close the door behind me. Every part of my body hurts. All my joints and all of my muscles are protesting the crushing pressure of gravity. I'm also nauseated, though I haven't thrown up. I strip off my clothes and get into bed, relishing the feeling of sheets, the light pressure of the blanket over me, the fluff of the pillow under my head.</p><p data-reactid=\"500\">All these are things I've missed dearly for the past year. I can hear the happy chatter of my family behind the door, voices I haven't heard for a long time without the distortion of phones bouncing signals off satellites. I drift off to sleep to the comforting sound of their talking and laughing.</p><p data-reactid=\"502\">A crack of light wakes me: Is it morning? No, it's just Amiko coming to bed. I've only been asleep for a couple of hours but I feel delirious. It's a struggle to come to consciousness enough to move, to tell her how awful I feel. I'm seriously nauseated now, feverish, and my pain has gotten worse. This isn't like how I felt after my last mission. This is much, much worse.</p><div data-reactid=\"504\"><figure class=\"_3ujPS _1ilMH\" data-reactid=\"505\"><a href=\"\" data-reactid=\"506\"><picture data-reactid=\"507\"><source media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.6230031948881789,$ratio_0.666667,$width_626,$x_14,$y_45/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/86a6d0c459e25b3e35e76f2809fc6b99941587f6\" data-reactid=\"508\"/><source media=\"(min-width: 768px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.6389776357827476,$ratio_0.666667,$width_626,$x_14,$y_45/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/86a6d0c459e25b3e35e76f2809fc6b99941587f6\" data-reactid=\"509\"/><img alt=\"Scott Kelly and partner Amiko in Red Square, Moscow.\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.5878594249201278,$ratio_0.666667,$width_626,$x_14,$y_45/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/86a6d0c459e25b3e35e76f2809fc6b99941587f6\" data-reactid=\"510\"/></picture></a><figcaption class=\"_3CZmy\" data-reactid=\"511\"><p data-reactid=\"512\">Scott Kelly and partner Amiko in Red Square, Moscow.</p><cite data-reactid=\"513\">Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite></figcaption></figure></div><p data-reactid=\"517\">\"Amiko,\" I finally manage to say. She is alarmed by the sound of my voice.</p><p data-reactid=\"519\">\"What is it?\" Her hand is on my arm, then on my forehead.</p><div data-reactid=\"521\"><figure class=\"_3ujPS _1ilMH\" data-reactid=\"522\"><a href=\"\" data-reactid=\"523\"><picture data-reactid=\"524\"><source media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.35911602209944754,$ratio_0.666667,$width_1086,$x_209,$y_0/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/311d5d6888cb9d48e34e63c40b14fd57371a90a5\" data-reactid=\"525\"/><source media=\"(min-width: 768px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.3683241252302026,$ratio_0.666667,$width_1086,$x_209,$y_0/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/311d5d6888cb9d48e34e63c40b14fd57371a90a5\" data-reactid=\"526\"/><img alt=\"Twin future astronauts Mark (left) and Scott Kelly, in 1967.&#10;\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_1,$multiply_0.3388581952117864,$ratio_0.666667,$width_1086,$x_209,$y_0/t_crop_custom/t_quality_best,f_auto/311d5d6888cb9d48e34e63c40b14fd57371a90a5\" data-reactid=\"527\"/></picture></a><figcaption class=\"_3CZmy\" data-reactid=\"528\"><p data-reactid=\"529\">Twin future astronauts Mark (left) and Scott Kelly, in 1967.\n</p><cite data-reactid=\"530\">Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite></figcaption></figure></div><p data-reactid=\"534\">Her skin feels chilled, but it's just that I'm so hot. \"I don't feel good,\" I say.</p><p data-reactid=\"536\"><strong data-reactid=\"537\">Over the past year</strong>, I've spent 340 days alongside Russian astronaut Mikhail \"Misha\" Kornienko on the International Space Station (ISS). As part of NASA's planned journey to Mars, we're members of a program designed to discover what effect such long-term time in space has on human beings. This was my fourth trip to space, and by the end of the mission I'd spent 520 days up there, more than any other NASA astronaut. Amiko has gone through the whole process with me as my main support once before, when I spent 159 days on the ISS in 2010-11. I had a reaction to coming back from space that time, but it was nothing like this.</p><div data-reactid=\"540\"><figure class=\"_3ujPS _3g3zI\" data-reactid=\"541\"><a href=\"\" data-reactid=\"542\"><picture data-reactid=\"543\"><source media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_780,$height_439/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/302972e4a206c58b90c82dc5f093cd668030d4a7\" data-reactid=\"544\"/><source media=\"(min-width: 768px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_960,$height_540/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/302972e4a206c58b90c82dc5f093cd668030d4a7\" data-reactid=\"545\"/><img alt=\"The International Space Station, where Scott Kelly spent 340 consecutive days.\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_768,$height_432/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/302972e4a206c58b90c82dc5f093cd668030d4a7\" data-reactid=\"546\"/></picture></a><figcaption class=\"_3CZmy\" data-reactid=\"547\"><p data-reactid=\"548\">The International Space Station, where Scott Kelly spent 340 consecutive days.</p><cite data-reactid=\"549\">Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite></figcaption></figure></div><p data-reactid=\"553\">I struggle to get up. Find the edge of the bed. Feet down. Sit up. Stand up. At every stage I feel like I'm fighting through quicksand. When I'm finally vertical, the pain in my legs is awful, and on top of that pain I feel a sensation that's even more alarming: it feels as though all the blood in my body is rushing to my legs, like the sensation of the blood rushing to your head when you do a handstand, but in reverse.</p><p data-reactid=\"555\">I can feel the tissue in my legs swelling. I shuffle my way to the bath room, moving my weight from one foot to the other with deliberate effort. Left. Right. Left. Right. I make it to the bathroom, flip on the light, and look down at my legs. They are swollen and alien stumps, not legs at all. \"Oh shit,\" I say. \"Amiko, come look at this.\" She kneels down and squeezes one ankle, and it squishes like a water balloon. She looks up at me with worried eyes. \"I can't even feel your ankle bones,\" she says.</p><p data-reactid=\"557\">\"My skin is burning, too,\" I tell her. Amiko frantically examines me. I have a strange rash all over my back, the backs of my legs, the back of my head and neck \u2013 everywhere I was in contact with the bed. I can feel her cool hands moving over my inflamed skin. \"It looks like an allergic rash,\" she says. \"Like hives.\"</p><p data-reactid=\"559\">I use the bathroom and shuffle back to bed, wondering what I should do. Normally if I woke up feeling like this, I would go to the emergency room. But no one at the hospital will have seen symptoms of having been in space for a year. I crawl back into bed, trying to find a way to lie down without touching my rash.</p><p data-reactid=\"561\">I can hear Amiko rummaging in the medicine cabinet. She returns with two ibuprofen and a glass of water. As she settles down, I can tell from her every movement, every breath, that she is worried about me. We both knew the risks of the mission I signed on for. After six years together, I can understand her perfectly, even in the wordless dark.</p><p data-reactid=\"563\">As I try to will myself to sleep, I wonder whether my friend Misha, by now back in Moscow, is also suffering from swollen legs and painful rashes. I suspect so. This is why we volunteered for this mission, after all: to discover more about how the human body is affected by long-term space flight. Scientists will study the data on Misha and my 53-year-old self for the rest of our lives and beyond. Our space agencies won't be able to push out farther into space, to a destination like Mars, until we can learn more about how to strengthen the weakest links in the chain that make space flight possible: the human body and mind.</p><p data-reactid=\"565\">People often ask me why I volunteered for this mission, knowing the risks: the risk of launch, the risk inherent in space walks, the risk of returning to Earth, the risks I would be exposed to every moment I lived in a metal container orbiting the Earth at 28,100 kilometres an hour. I have a few answers I give to this question, but none of them feels fully satisfying to me. None of them quite answers it.</p><div data-reactid=\"567\"><figure class=\"_3ujPS _3g3zI\" data-reactid=\"568\"><a href=\"\" data-reactid=\"569\"><picture data-reactid=\"570\"><source media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_780,$height_439/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/574254561d25e642679f244026b8ede85aa2c487\" data-reactid=\"571\"/><source media=\"(min-width: 768px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_960,$height_540/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/574254561d25e642679f244026b8ede85aa2c487\" data-reactid=\"572\"/><img alt=\"Scott Kelly (at left) undertaking a dangerous space walk outside the International Space Station.\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_768,$height_432/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/574254561d25e642679f244026b8ede85aa2c487\" data-reactid=\"573\"/></picture></a><figcaption class=\"_3CZmy\" data-reactid=\"574\"><p data-reactid=\"575\">Scott Kelly (at left) undertaking a dangerous space walk outside the International Space Station.</p><cite data-reactid=\"576\">Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite></figcaption></figure></div><p data-reactid=\"580\"><strong data-reactid=\"581\">A normal mission to the International Space Station</strong> lasts five to six months, so scientists have a good deal of data about what happens to the human body in space for that length of time. But very little is known about what occurs after month six. The symptoms may get precipitously worse in the ninth month, for instance, or they may level off. We don't know, and there is only one way to find out.</p><p data-reactid=\"584\">During our mission, Misha and I collected various types of data for studies on our selves, which took a significant amount of our time. Because Mark and I were identical twins, I also took part in an extensive study comparing the two of us throughout the year, down to the genetic level. The ISS was a world-class orbiting laboratory, and in addition to the human studies of which I was one of the main subjects, I also spent a lot of my time during the year working on other experiments, like fluid physics, botany, combustion and Earth observation.</p><p data-reactid=\"586\">When I talked about the ISS to audiences, I always shared with them the importance of the science being done there. But to me, it was just as important that the station was serving as a foothold for our species in space. From here, we could learn more about how to push out further into the cosmos. The costs were high, as were the risks.</p><p data-reactid=\"588\">On my previous flight to the space station, a mission of 159 days, I lost bone mass, my muscles atrophied, and my blood redistributed itself in my body, which strained and shrank the walls of my heart. More troubling, I experienced problems with my vision, as many other astronauts had. I had been exposed to more than 30 times the radiation of a person on Earth, equivalent to about 10 chest X-rays every day. This exposure would increase my risk of a fatal cancer for the rest of my life.</p><p data-reactid=\"590\">None of this compared, though, to the most troubling risk: that something bad could happen to someone I love while I was in space with no way for me to come home.</p><p data-reactid=\"592\"><strong data-reactid=\"593\">I had been on the station for a week</strong>, and was getting better at knowing where I was when I first woke up. If I had a headache, I knew it was because I had drifted too far from the vent blowing clean air at my face. I was often still disoriented about how my body was positioned: I would wake up convinced that I was upside down, because in the dark and without gravity, my inner ear took a random guess as to how my body was positioned in the small space. When I turned on a light, I had a sort of visual illusion that the room was rotating rapidly as it reoriented itself around me, though I knew it was actually my brain readjusting in response to new sensory input.</p><p data-reactid=\"596\">The light in my crew quarters took a minute to warm up to full brightness. The space was just barely big enough for me and my sleeping bag, two laptops, some clothes, toiletries, photos of Amiko and my daughters, a few paperback books. I looked at my schedule for today. I clicked through new emails, stretched and yawned, then fished around in my toiletries bag, attached to the wall down by my left knee, for my toothpaste and toothbrush. I brushed, still in my sleeping bag, then swallowed the toothpaste and chased it with a sip of water out of a bag with a straw. There wasn't really a good way to spit in space.</p><p data-reactid=\"598\"><strong data-reactid=\"599\">I didn't get to spend time outside the station</strong> until my first of two planned space walks, which was almost seven months in. This was one of the things that some people found difficult to imagine about living on the space station, the fact that I couldn't step outside when I felt like it. Putting on a spacesuit and leaving the station for a space walk was an hours-long process that required the full attention of at least three people on station and dozens more on the ground.</p><p data-reactid=\"602\">Space walks were the most dangerous thing we did in orbit. Even if the station was on fire, even if it was filling up with poison gas, even if a meteoroid had crashed through a module and outer space was rushing in, the only way to escape the station was in a Soyuz capsule, which also needed preparation and planning to depart safely. We practised dealing with emergency scenarios regularly, and in many of these drills we raced to prepare the Soyuz as quickly as we could. No one had ever had to use the Soyuz as a lifeboat, and no one hoped to.</p><p data-reactid=\"604\"><strong data-reactid=\"605\">I opened a food container</strong> attached to the wall and fished out a pouch of dehydrated coffee with cream and sugar. I floated over to the hot-water dispenser in the ceiling of the lab, which worked by insert ing a needle into a nozzle on the bag. When the bag was full, I replaced the needle with a drinking straw \u2013 this way the liquid didn't escape into the module. It had been oddly unsatisfying at first to drink coffee from a plastic bag sipped through a straw, but now I wasn't bothered by it.</p><p data-reactid=\"608\">I flipped through the breakfast options, looking for a packet of the granola I liked. Unfortunately, everyone else seemed to like it, too. I chose some dehydrated eggs instead and reconstituted them with the same hot water dispenser, then warmed up some irradiated sausage links in the food warmer box, which looked a lot like a metal briefcase. I cut the bag open, then, since we had no sink, cleaned the scissors by licking them (we each had our own scissors). I spooned the eggs out of the bag onto a tortilla \u2013 conveniently, surface tension held them in place \u2013 added the sausage and some hot sauce, rolled it up, and ate the burrito while catch ing up with the morning's news on <em data-reactid=\"610\">CNN</em>.</p><p data-reactid=\"613\">All the while I was holding myself in place with my right big toe tucked ever so slightly under a handrail on the floor. Handrails were placed on the walls, floors and ceilings of every module and at the hatches where modules connected, allowing us to propel ourselves through the modules or to stay in place rather than drifting away. There were a lot of things about living in weightlessness that were fun, but eating was not one of them. I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal, relaxing and pausing to connect with other people.</p><div data-reactid=\"615\"><figure class=\"_3ujPS _3g3zI\" data-reactid=\"616\"><a href=\"\" data-reactid=\"617\"><picture data-reactid=\"618\"><source media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_780,$height_439/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/20260c0bec151874ede9935989e3e48e93fe7229\" data-reactid=\"619\"/><source media=\"(min-width: 768px)\" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_960,$height_540/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/20260c0bec151874ede9935989e3e48e93fe7229\" data-reactid=\"620\"/><img alt=\"&quot;I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal, relaxing and pausing to connect with other people,&quot; writes Kelly of life on the ISS. \" srcset=\"https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_768,$height_432/t_crop_fill/t_quality_best,f_auto/20260c0bec151874ede9935989e3e48e93fe7229\" data-reactid=\"621\"/></picture></a><figcaption class=\"_3CZmy\" data-reactid=\"622\"><p data-reactid=\"623\">\"I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal, relaxing and pausing to connect with other people,\" writes Kelly of life on the ISS. </p><cite data-reactid=\"624\">Photo: Marco Grob</cite></figcaption></figure></div><p data-reactid=\"628\"><strong data-reactid=\"629\">More than 400 experiments </strong>took place on ISS during this expedition. NASA scientists talked about the research falling into two major categories. The first had to do with studies that might benefit life on Earth. These included research on the properties of chemicals that could be used in new drugs, combustion studies that were unlocking new ways to get more efficiency out of the fuel we burnt, and the development of new materials. The second large category had to do with solving problems for future space exploration: testing new life-support equipment, solving technical problems of spaceflight and studying new ways of handling the demands of the human body in space.</p><p data-reactid=\"632\">Science took up about a third of my time, human studies about three-quarters of that. I had to take blood samples from myself and my crew mates for analysis back on Earth, and I kept a log of everything, from what I ate to my moods. I tested my reaction skills at various points throughout the day. I took ultrasounds of blood vessels, my heart, my eyes and my muscles. I also took part in an experiment called Fluid Shifts, using a device that sucked the blood down to the lower half of my body, where gravity normally kept it. This tested a leading theory about why space flight caused damage to some astronauts' vision.</p><p data-reactid=\"634\">In fact, there was much crossover between these categories of research. If we could learn how to counteract the devastating impact of bone loss in microgravity, the solutions could well be applied to osteoporosis and other bone diseases. If we could learn how to keep our hearts healthy in space, that knowledge could be useful on Earth. </p><p data-reactid=\"636\">The effects of living in space looked a lot like the effects of ageing, which affected us all. The lettuce we grew was a study for future space travel \u2013 astronauts on their way to Mars will have no fresh food but what they can grow \u2013 but it also taught us more about growing food efficiently on Earth. The ISS's closed water system, where we processed our urine into clean water, will be crucial for getting to Mars, but it also has promising implications for treating water on Earth \u2013 especially in places where clean water was scarce.</p><p data-reactid=\"638\"><strong data-reactid=\"639\">I tell my flight surgeon, Steve,</strong> that I feel well enough to get right to work immediately upon returning from space, and I do, but within a few days I feel much worse. This is what it means to have allowed my body to be used for science. I will be a test subject for the rest of my life. A few months after arriving back on Earth, though, I feel distinctly better. I've been travelling the country and the world talking about my experiences in space. It's gratifying to see how curious people are about my mission, how much children instinctively feel the excitement and wonder of space flight, and how many people think, as I do, that Mars is the next step.</p><p data-reactid=\"642\">I also know that if we want to go to Mars, it will be very, very difficult, it will cost a great deal of money and it may likely cost human lives. But I know now that if we decide to do it, we can. </p><p data-reactid=\"644\"><strong data-reactid=\"645\">Edited extract from <em data-reactid=\"647\">Endurance: A Year in Space, A Lifetime of Discovery</em> by Scott Kelly (Doubleday, $35), published on October 19.</strong></p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15430678": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 02:54:03", "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/amazon-is-on-the-brink-of-deciding-if-it-will-make-a-big-move-into-selling-drugs-online/ar-AAsZXbj", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"richtext\" data-aop=\"articlebody\">\n <div class=\"xnetvidplayer\" data-aop=\"xnet-mod\" aria-label=\"Video 'Amazon's health ambitions' \" tabindex=\"0\"><button class=\"overlay-open\"><span>Click to expand</span></button><button class=\"overlay-close\"/><div class=\"nextvideo-outer\"><div class=\"nextvideo-inner\"><img alt=\"UP NEXT\" class=\"vid-image\"/><p class=\"coming-up\">&#13;\n UP NEXT&#13;\n</p><p class=\"vid-title\"/><p class=\"circle\"/><p class=\"next-seconds\"/><button class=\"cancel\"/></div></div></div><p><a href=\"https://pub.cnbc.com/id/1502862?__source=msn|money|inline|story|&amp;par=msn&amp;doc=104757634\"><strong>Amazon</strong></a> is in the final stages of figuring out its strategy to get into the multibillion dollar prescription drug market.\u00a0<br/></p>\n\n\n<p>The company will decide before Thanksgiving whether to move into selling prescription drugs online, according to an email from Amazon viewed by CNBC and a source familiar with the situation. If it decides to make that move, it will start expanding its senior team with drug supply chain experts. </p><p>Amazon typically spends years researching opportunities before it telegraphs its intentions. The opportunity to sell drugs online is alluring given its market size -- <a href=\"http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/early/2015/07/15/hlthaff.2015.0600\">analysts have estimated</a> the U.S. prescription drug market at $560 billion per year. Amazon is well aware of the complexities, say sources familiar with the company's thinking. </p><p>Amazon did not immediately reply to a request for comment.</p><p>In the past year, Amazon has ramped up its hiring and consulted with dozens of people about a potential move into the pharmacy market. The consumables team which includes groceries <a href=\"https://pub.cnbc.com/id/104473820?__source=msn|money|inline|story|&amp;par=msn&amp;doc=104757634\"><strong>kicked off the research</strong></a>, with division vice president Eric French taking the lead. </p><p>It brought on Mark Lyons from Premera Blue Cross to build an internal pharmacy benefits manager for its own employees, say multiple people familiar. According to one of the people, it's possible that the push into the broader drug supply chain hinges on its success with this effort.</p><p>In May, company kicked off its search for a general manager to lead its pharmacy push, externally dubbed \"healthcare.\"</p><p>Analyst firm Leerink has separately reported that Amazon will get into the pharmacy management space and expects an announcement within the next year or two.</p><p>Goldman Sachs published a report on the topic in August of this year, speculating that Amazon <a href=\"https://pub.cnbc.com/id/104648478?__source=msn|money|inline|story|&amp;par=msn&amp;doc=104757634\"><strong>will ultimately look to improve price transparency</strong></a> for consumers and reduce out-of-pocket costs.</p><p>Amazon already has a business selling medical supplies online, such as gauze and thermometers. <a href=\"https://pub.cnbc.com/id/104611091?__source=msn|money|inline|story|&amp;par=msn&amp;doc=104757634\"><strong>It also has a health team called 1492</strong></a>, which is focused on both hardware and software projects, like developing health applications for the Echo and Dash Wand. Its cloud service, Amazon Web Services, continues to dominate the health and life sciences market.</p>\n</div>\n </div></body></html>"}, "15429656": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:51:15", "url": "https://www.scientificcomputing.com/news/2017/10/error-correcting-things-go-wrong-quantum-computing-scale", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"field-item even\"><p>Computing power has <a href=\"https://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2017/1/211094-exponential-laws-of-computing-growth/fulltext\">grown exponentially</a> over many decades, so why is the much-promised next leap of quantum computers taking so long to arrive?</p>\n<p>One reason is that the information in a quantum system is sensitive to error-inducing noise in a way that classical information is not. This noise is everywhere and unavoidable, arising from microscopic oscillations of atoms and electrons in all matter. So we have to invent new ways of dealing with quantum errors.</p>\n<p>When you make a phone call in a congested network, or scratch a CD, the technology can still work: conversations remain comprehensible and music still plays.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://theconversation.com/hype-and-cash-are-muddying-public-understanding-of-quantum-computing-82647\">Hype and cash are muddying public understanding of quantum computing</a></em></p>\n<p>This is because these devices use <a href=\"https://www.encyclopediaofmath.org/index.php/Error-correcting_code\">error correcting codes</a>: even if errors corrupt the raw data stream, the important logical information can still be reconstructed. And these can be adapted for quantum computing.</p>\n<h2>A time you can count on</h2>\n<p>To see how this works for classical coding, consider the solution used by early navigators.</p>\n<p>They knew that longitude could be calculated from the elevation of the Sun so long as the time at home port was known \u2014 hence the naval imperative to build accurate, stable clocks.</p>\n<p>Ideally, one clock would be sufficient, but what if something went wrong? Two clocks are better, so long as they both agree. But if they disagree, which is right? With three clocks, a majority vote allows the timekeeper to detect and reset a wayward timepiece.</p>\n<p>For binary data, represented by 0s and 1s, repetition protects information: a logical bit \u201c0\u201d is represented in three physical bits as 000, while \u201c1\u201d is represented as 111.</p>\n<p>Suppose during data transmission of \u201c0\u201d, the last physical bit was accidentally flipped, so that the received message is 001. The recipient would immediately see that an error had corrupted the data.</p>\n<p>Further, by taking a majority vote, she would guess that an error affected the third physical bit, and correctly decode the logical bit: \u201c0\u201d. As long as errors are rare, the repetition code will allow logical data to be transmitted reliably over a noisy, error-prone channel.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>Error detection and error correction if the data is sent in threes. The Conversation, <a class=\"license\" href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nd/4.0/\">CC BY-ND</a></p>\n<h2>Known unknowns</h2>\n<p>One quantum wrinkle in this picture is that it involves a \u201cmeasurement\u201d. The receiver knows exactly what physical bits she received (001 in the example, above), which implies that she had to measure them (that is, look at them).</p>\n<p>But <a href=\"https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/qt-issues/#MeasProb\">quantum mechanics</a> tells us that the act of measurement fundamentally changes the state of a quantum system. Simply measuring quantum bits (qubits) changes the message.</p>\n<p>So a quantum receiver isn\u2019t allowed to measure the qubits directly, but she still needs to figure out whether errors have occurred, and where.</p>\n<p>To resolve this we return to the repetition code for guidance. Instead of looking at the bit values, the receiver could instead ask the following two questions:</p>\n<blockquote><p>Q1: is the first bit the same as the second bit?</p>\n<p>Q2: is the second bit the same as the third bit?</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>If there were no errors, the answer to both of these questions would be \u201cyes\u201d, regardless of whether the message was 000 or 111.</p>\n<p>But if the last bit suffered an error (receiving 001 or 110), the answer to Q1 would be \u201cyes\u201d but Q2 would be \u201cno\u201d. From this response, the recipient can infer the existence of an error and its location.</p>\n<p>Similarly, an error on the first bit will be revealed by the pattern Q1=\u201cNo\u201d, Q2=\u201cYes\u201d. An error on the middle bit will be revealed by Q1=Q2=\u201cNo\u201d. Thus, any single error will be uniquely determined by these answers, and can be repaired.</p>\n<p>Knowing which physical bit suffered an error, she would fix it by deliberately flipping that bit, to reverse the effect of the original error. This can happen without knowing the state of the damaged bit.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>Error detection and correction at the quantum computer scale. The Conversation, <a class=\"license\" href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nd/4.0/\">CC BY-ND</a></p>\n<p>Notice that answering these questions only requires comparative knowledge of the received bits. It does not depend on their particular value, nor the encoded logical information.</p>\n<p>This principle captures the essence of quantum error correcting codes. It allows us to simultaneously identify errors and avoid damaging quantum information.</p>\n<p>Rather than measuring the value of individual physical qubits, a series of comparative questions are asked: \u201cAre the qubits in group A the same as each other?\u201d, \u201cAre the qubits in group B the same as each other?\u201d and so on. The answers to these questions yield clues as to the whereabouts of errors, but without revealing the message itself.</p>\n<p>These answers are then used to infer and correct the likely errors.</p>\n<p>The logical quantum information is encoded in yet another combination of qubits, which we measure only when we really do want to discover the logical quantum state.</p>\n<p>This approach is active, and computationally expensive for large data sets. For some applications, it is necessary. But if engineers in the 1940s had faced a similar struggle to develop early computers, I suspect that the laptop I\u2019m writing this on would never have been built.</p>\n<h2>Magnetic stability</h2>\n<p>Instead, they were lucky, as nature itself does classical error correction for free. Magnets are incredibly stable, so they are used to store vast amounts of information in hard disks with almost no active error correction.</p>\n<p>Magnets are just collections of many magnetic atoms that tend to align their magnetic axes with one another, so they all point \u201cnorth\u201d.</p>\n<p>If a cosmic ray spontaneously kicks the magnetic orientation of one atom, its atomic neighbours exert a magnetic force that realigns it with the majority direction. So a magnet can be thought of as a piece of matter that passively error corrects itself, by a local majority vote.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately for quantum computers, we know of no such passively stable state of quantum matter. In fact, we have <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1011.3529.pdf\">mathematical proofs</a> that such matter cannot exist in a two-dimensional universe, while it can in a four-dimensional universe.</p>\n<p>So far, we don\u2019t know whether passively stable quantum matter exists in our own three-dimensional universe.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://theconversation.com/all-you-need-for-quantum-computing-at-room-temperature-is-some-mothballs-62549\">All you need for quantum computing at room temperature is some mothballs</a></em></p>\n<p>We do know that with enough skill and resources, we can actively correct quantum errors.</p>\n<p>But to build a quantum memory is an ongoing challenge. There is nothing like a \u201cquantum magnet\u201d to easily store quantum information for us. We have to design and build such a system from the ground up, almost literally atom by atom.</p>\n<p>One of the first major tasks a quantum computer will do is to perform quantum error correction on itself. Prosaic though this sounds, it will be the first instance in our known universe of truly quantum matter.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://theconversation.com/profiles/thomas-stace-9511\">Thomas Stace</a>, Associate Professor in Physics, <em><a href=\"http://theconversation.com/institutions/the-university-of-queensland-805\">The University of Queensland</a></em></p>\n<p>This article was originally published on <a href=\"http://theconversation.com\">The Conversation</a>. Read the <a href=\"https://theconversation.com/error-correcting-the-things-that-go-wrong-at-the-quantum-computing-scale-84846\">original article</a>.</p>\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15431193": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:23:15", "url": "https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/10/8/16444566/trump-fema-director-brock-long-san-juan-mayor-carmen-yulin-cruz", "text": "<body id=\"readabilityBody\"><p>Forbidden</p></body>"}, "15429658": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:51:28", "url": "https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/blog-post/secure-development-and-deployment", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"field-body\">\n            \n<p>Today we are pleased to share with you an alpha draft of our\u00a0<a href=\"https://github.com/ukncsc/secure-development-and-deployment\" rel=\"nofollow\">secure development and deployment guidance</a><a href=\"http://github%20linky%20link/\" rel=\"nofollow\">.</a>\u00a0You may be wondering, 'who this is aimed at?' And 'why is it in alpha?' This blog post will answer those questions.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Increased automation</strong></p>\n\n<p>We have noticed the steady growth of agile development\u00a0using\u00a0<em>continuous integration</em>\u00a0and\u00a0<em>delivery</em>. You probably have too. Well, one of the chief characteristics of this relatively new approach to software development is increased automation. This puts incredible power in the hands of the developer, allowing entire system architectures to be defined in code and tied to tooling which will automate both testing\u00a0<em>and</em>\u00a0deployment. There's a lot going for this approach, you can see why it's catching on so fast.</p>\n\n<p>But (there is always a 'but') with this power comes a new set of risks and security considerations. It's these which our guidance addresses.\u00a0<a href=\"/blog-post/developers-need-help-too\" rel=\"nofollow\">We've tried to ensure that every recommendation is possible</a>. And though there might be some pain were you to adopt our advice wholesale, now is the time to make the effort - before insecure practices have had time to take root culturally.\u00a0</p>\n\n<p><strong>Audience</strong></p>\n\n<p>The primary audience for this guidance is development teams practicing\u00a0<em>continuous integration and deployment</em>, an approach which is more common for the development of digital services. Despite this, we hope the advice we give will be of use to\u00a0<em>everyone involved</em>\u00a0in software development and procurement,\u00a0whatever\u00a0your style of development.</p>\n\n<p>That's quite ambitious - 'everyone.' But the guidance itself is high\u00a0level:\u00a0there is no\u00a0language-specific\u00a0advice. It's human readable. Our goal is to help secure the entire process of software development, so we've looked at everything from establishing a security-friendly culture, through to implementation and ongoing management. This work is complementary to our existing\u00a0<a href=\"/guidance/security-design-principles-digital-services-main\" rel=\"nofollow\">design guidance</a>.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Github first</strong></p>\n\n<p>We are publishing this guidance as alpha, acknowledging that we are dealing with a new and rapidly evolving field -\u00a0one\u00a0in which there are still questions to be settled about best practice. We\u00a0welcome your feedback to help us refine our advice, before moving it to 'beta' and 'live' versions.\u00a0</p>\n\n<p>And, due to the nature of the guidance, it seemed appropriate to\u00a0<a href=\"https://github.com/ukncsc/secure-development-and-deployment/\" rel=\"nofollow\">share this with you on Github</a>\u00a0first.\u00a0We welcome your feedback through comments and pull requests. class=\"article-content post-page\">\n          \n<figure class=\"intro-image intro-left\">\n  <img src=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/smartjewelry2-800x533.jpg\"/>\n      <figcaption class=\"caption\"><p class=\"caption-credit\">Valentina Palladino</p></figcaption>  </figure>\n\n  <aside id=\"social-left\"><a title=\"33 posters participating\" class=\"comment-count class=\"comment-count-before\">reader comments</span>\n    <span class=\"comment-count-number\">44</span>\n  </a>  \n\n\n</aside>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p>Technology is shrinking, but that doesn't mean it's getting more subtle. Smartwatches are gaining popularity in the wearable world, but most make themselves painfully known by looking like high-tech gadgets. Not all wearables are fashion crimes, though; there's a sector of smart jewelry trying to thrive in this space by fighting against the cold, gadget-like aesthetic.</p>\n<p>These devices take the shape of traditional jewelry\u2014like bracelets, rings, and necklaces\u2014but include technology that lets them track basic activity, health, and other data. While devices like <a href=\"https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/10/fossil-infiltrates-nearly-all-of-its-brands-with-hybrid-smartwatches/\">Fossil's Q hybrid devices</a> toe the line between smartwatches and smart jewelry, other devices focus more on style and personality than they do on tech.</p>\n<p>I tested out a few of these pieces of smart jewelry to see if their fashion sense, combined with their tech chops, really set them apart from their traditional wearable counterparts.</p>\n<h2>Ela</h2>\n<h3>Design</h3>\n<p>The Warren Buffet-backed <a href=\"http://elajewelry.com/\">Ela line</a> keeps the sentimentality in jewelry while adding smart features.\u00a0Let's take a look at Ela's design\u2014all of its bracelets have a large, rounded-square stone of Italian marbleized quartz\u00a0as the main decor, fitted on either a leather strap or a metal bangle. Underneath the stone is an LED that glows in eight different colors depending on who's calling or messaging you. In the Ela app, you can assign colors to contacts so you'll be alerted when they contact you even when your phone is out of sight. The bangles are luxurious,\u00a0while the leather straps give the bracelet a more relaxed look.\u00a0The design is attractive yet simple enough to go with any kind of outfit, but I wouldn't say the overall look warrants the $195 price tag.</p>\n      <div class=\"gallery shortcode-gallery\">\n      <ul>\n                  <li steps throughout the day, but it doesn't do so by default. You need to turn the feature on in the Ela app, and it warns that doing so will decrease the device's battery life. Ela recommends charging the bracelet every night when you go to bed, which makes sense since most people\u00a0don't wear jewelry when they sleep. But the company only promises two to three days of battery life for the bracelet when step tracking is disabled. When turned on, you will certainly need to charge the battery every night.</p>\n<p>Compared to today's technology, that's kind of crazy\u2014<a href=\"https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2016/08/fitbits-charge-2-and-flex-2-are-next-gen-trackers-that-blend-fitness-and-style/\">Fitbit's $99\u00a0Flex 2</a>\u2014which you can style with accessories to be arguably just as pleasant as an Ela bracelet\u2014tracks steps\u2014has color-coded LED notifications and gets five days of battery life without breaking a sweat. Battery life may be less important for a device like Ela because you don't wear it to bed, while the Flex 2 needs that extra juice to track movement and sleep over five days. Regardless, a device like Ela that does relatively little compared to a device like the Flex 2 shouldn't need to be charged every night.</p>\n<h3>Data and Memories</h3>\n<aside class=\"pullbox sidebar story-sidebar right\"/>\n<p>Arguably the most idiosyncratic feature of any Ela device is Memories, which lets you save photos and audio clips to the device that can only be seen by you and the device's wearer (or only you, if those people are one in the same). The concept makes the most sense when giving an Ela bracelet as a gift. Imagine you purchased the bracelet for your significant other for their birthday. Before gifting it, you can connect the device to your smartphone and, using the Ela mobile app, save content to the device that your significant other will see immediately when they pair\u00a0their new bracelet to their own smartphone.</p>\n<p>Ela jewelry doesn't have a screen, speakers, or onboard storage, so saving content to it really just associates the content to that device and stores it in the cloud. Those photos and clips\u00a0live in the Ela app, so you'll need to revisit the app whenever you want to see those memories, and you can only save about 100MB work of data as Memories. Jewelry, smart or not, can often evoke memories, so this is a modern way of making those memories more accessible.</p>\n<p>However, the accessibility of this content makes it feel a little less personal. Anyone could open up the Ela app on your phone and immediately see those special photos and clips. On the flip side, now many of us look back, deep into our smartphone's photo albums, to relive past memories via photos, videos, gifs, and more.</p>\n      <div class=\"gallery shortcode-gallery\">\n      <ul>\n                  <li data-thumb=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/elaapp1-150x150.jpg\"                            </figcaption>\n                          </figure>\n          </li>\n              </ul>\n    </div>\n  \n\n<p>Maybe I put too much emphasis on the sacredness of memories between two individuals, but I'd rather be given physical photographs or special objects instead of a piece of jewelry attached to an app that holds a few digital images. Those who grew up reliving memories through a screen and the Internet may not feel the same way. Personally, the novelty of Memories would wear off for me after a few weeks.\u00a0Also, there's no real use for Memories if you buy an Ela bracelet for yourself. Sure, you can populate it regularly with your favorite photos and audio clips, but you probably already do that in other apps like Facebook, Instagram, and Spotify.</p>\n<p>I feel safe predicting that Ela's LED-and-vibrating contact notifications will be more useful than Memories in the long-term. It may seem like a lot to remember if you assign all eight colors to different contacts, but that many color-coded contacts is not unheard of. Companies like Fossil Group use color-coded lights or windows on watches and bracelets to show incoming calls and texts from important contacts. I only program three to four colors on any of these devices, so I never have a hard time remembering that\u00a0a text from my mom will make the bracelet glow blue while a call from my boyfriend will produce a pink light.</p>\n<h2>Bellabeat</h2>\n<h3>Design</h3>\n<p>Bellabeat's <a href=\"https://webshop.bellabeat.com/\">Leaf activity tracker</a> will likely appeal to nature-lovers at first glance. The device's design mimics a minimalist plant\u00a0with a metal leaf-shaped case surrounding the activity tracking module. You can get the Leaf Nature with a module made from natural wood that's splash-proof, or you can get the Leaf Urban with a module made of a wood-composite with the appearance and texture of stone. I tested the Leaf Urban, and it's a bit more resistant to water than its Nature counterpart because it's not made entirely out of wood.</p>\n      <div class=\"gallery shortcode-gallery\">\n data-src=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf2.jpg\" data-responsive=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf2-980x653.jpg 1080, https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf2-1440x960.jpg 2560\" data-sub-html=\"#caption-1145401\">\n            <figure>\n              <p class=\"image\"/>\n                              <figcaption id=\"caption-1145401\">\n                  <span class=\"icon caption-arrow icon-drop-indicator\"/>\n                                      <p class=\"caption\">\n                      The back panel can be removed with a small, included screwdriver (this gives you access to the battery).                    </p>\n                                                        <p class=\"credit\">\n                      <span class=\"icon icon-camera\"/>\n                                              Valentina Palladino                                          </p>\n                                  </figcaption>\n                          </figure>\n          </li>\n                  <li data-thumb=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf3-150x150.jpg\" data-src=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf3.jpg\" data-responsive=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf3-980x653.jpg 1080, https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf3-1440x960.jpg 2560\" data-sub-html=\"#caption-1145403\">\n            <figure>\n              <p class=\"image\"/>\n                              <figcaption id=\"caption-1145403\">\n                  <span class=\"icon caption-arrow icon-drop-indicator\"/>\n                                      <p class=\"caption\">\n                      The Leaf Urban also comes with a two-part bracelet.                    </p>\n                                                        <p class=\"credit\">\n                      <span class=\"icon icon-camera\"/>\n                                              Valentina Palladino                                          </p>\n                                  </figcaption>\n                          </figure>\n          </li>\n                  <li data-thumb=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf4-150x150.jpg\" data-src=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf4.jpg\" data-responsive=\"https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf4-980x653.jpg 1080, https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/bellabeatleaf4-1440x960.jpg 2560\" data-sub-html=\"#caption-1145405\">\n            <figure>\n              <p class=\"image\"/>\n                              <figcaption id=\"caption-1145405\">\n                  <span class=\"icon caption-arrow icon-drop-indicator\"/>\n                                      <p class=\"caption\">\n                      The hook attachments don't do a good job holding on to the module.                    </p>\n                                                        <p class=\"credit\">\n                      <span class=\"icon icon-camera\"/>\n                                              Valentina Palladino                                          </p>\n                                  </figcaption>\n                          </figure>\n          </li>\n              </ul>\n    </div>\n  \n\n<p>Weighing 0.59 ounces and measuring\u00a01.8\u00a0x 1.1 x 0.43 inches, the Leaf is small enough to fit on a necklace or bracelet. However, it might be too big to comfortably wear on certain clothing\u2014the metal case construction lets you clip the Leaf to your clothing (the company shows it worn as a decorative brooch on your collar). But it seems slightly heavy for flimsy or flowy fabrics like rayon.</p>\n<p>After wearing the Leaf as a bracelet for a few days, I promptly switched it to its necklace chain because I couldn't stand the included double-wrap wristband. It's difficult to secure mainly because\u00a0the\u00a0two hooks that attach to the Leaf's metal case aren't malleable, so the Leaf module easily falls out of one or both of them because of the size of the hooks' openings. You also have to wrap the band around your wrist twice, which not only takes more time, but it also gives the Leaf module more time and opportunity to fall out of the secure hooks. The bracelet combination looks nice when you finally get it on your wrist, but it's not worth the hassle when you also get a necklace with the device.</p>\n<h3>Data and the Bellabeat app</h3>\n<p>The only reason I'd recommend wearing the Leaf on your wrist is for sleep tracking, which it does automatically.\u00a0Wearing a necklace to bed seems like a recipe for entanglement, but to each their\u00a0own. The Leaf's sleep tracking has pros and cons\u2014it automatically enters sleep mode\u00a0(there are no buttons on the device, so it has to do that), but it's not that great at estimating exactly when you fell asleep. After the first night I slept with the device, I synced data to the Leaf smartphone app and the device thought I fell asleep two hours after I actually did. Thankfully, an in-app pop-up lets you immediately edit sleep and wake-up times.\u00a0The Leaf did get better over time, mostly with more accurate wake-up times as it never totally got my fall-sleep time correct.</p>\n<p>Aside from sleep, the Leaf tracks activity, stress, mediation, and menstrual cycles for women. Activity stats are generic but still accurate as far as step counts go. I wish the Leaf could identify periods of intense activity like workouts, but it doesn't, and you'll have to input those yourself. The menu of activities you can log\u00a0is vast, which is a great perk, and a small star over your activity bar graph indicates when during the day you met your move goal. Along with a daily activity graph, the app also shows you daily and weekly averages of active time, steps, and distance, as well as calories burned through activity and resting.</p>\n<p>I'm not the best at meditating regularly (I'm trying to get better), but I was pleasantly surprised by the ease of the meditation program in the Leaf app. After you set goals for how often or long you meditate, you can choose from a number of pre-made programs in the app. Categories include \"feeling grounded\" and \"de-stress,\" among others, and have at least four or five guided meditation programs to complete. In total, there are about 25 meditation options to choose from if you want the Leaf app to guide you, otherwise you can log meditation minutes manually.</p>\n<aside class=\"pullbox sidebar story-sidebar right\"/>\n<p>Each meditation session has a long and short version. I typically completed the four-minute short versions, but there are eight- or 10-minute versions as well. Each has a soothing voice guiding you through a fanciful scenario meant to relax you, while instructing you to breathe deeply, close your eyes, and other small body movements. There are sound effects involved (one \"back pain\" session I did featured the sounds of a babbling brook, chirping birds, and peaceful winds), but not much music because you're meant to focus on your own thoughts, breathing patterns, and the instructions of the app's voice coach.</p>\n<p>The Leaf's guided meditation sessions proved to me that the hardest part of meditation is setting aside time and doing it. I enjoyed the few four-minute sessions I completed, and I felt relaxed after each one. Most wearable companies are incorporating guided breathing exercises into their wristbands, but they typically involve on-screen animation and no sounds or voice coach. Using a mobile app that provides soothing sound effects and a helpful voice, on the other hand, immerses you in the mediation world better than a silent, blinking screen can.</p>\n<p>Leaf also estimates your \"stress level\" as well as giving you a way to manage that stress via guided meditation. This is the most peculiar piece of data in the Leaf app because the program estimates both your level of stress and how prone your body may be to getting stressed out. Leaf uses\u00a0every piece of information at its disposal\u00a0to predict stress\u00a0habits, including how much sleep you got, when you went to bed, how active you've been, how much (or how little) you've meditated, and more. Stress level is represented by a colored geometric shape with four points that lean toward different health aspects that affect stress: steps, sleep, menstrual cycle, and meditation. A red shape indicates high-stress sensitivity while an orange shape indicates a moderate stress sensitivity. A green shape shows you have \"everything under control,\" presumably because every\u00a0trackable health aspect is balanced.</p>\n      <div class=\"gallery shortcode-gallery\">\n      <ul>\n                                     </figcaption>\n                          </figure>\n          </li>\n              </ul>\n    </div>\n  \n\n<p>Leaf makes stress tracking more complicated than it should be because the device essentially says you will be highly sensitive to stress when you haven't been meeting your health goals. The app presumes that when you've been slacking on your movement, meditation, and sleep (and when you're close to That Time of the Month), you'll be more stressed out because your body isn't performing at its peak. Personally, I know when I haven't slept well or when I've missed a workout or two. I don't need to see those points laid out in an app to know when my body isn't in balance\u2014but others may have other priorities and responsibilities that get in the way of that kind of self-awareness.</p>\n<p>This isn't the most accurate way to determine stress levels because it's based on the accuracy of the information Leaf detects and the information you provide. The Leaf doesn't track heart rate either, so it won't be able to tell you if something physiologically strange is going on. While no fitness tracker or smartwatch can account for the mental factors that may cause stress, I trust devices with heart-rate monitors to provide insight into stress levels more than those without pulse sensors.</p>\n\n        </div>\n\n        \n                  </div></body></html>"}, "15430178": {"score": 3, "comments": ["I&#x27;ve been working through the tutorials on this: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.turbo360.co&#x2F;tutorials\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.turbo360.co&#x2F;tutorials</a>. class=\"noprint\">\n\n\n<p/>\nAll statistics correct as of 9 October 2017<br/>\n<small>(including any matches not played but awarded)</small>.</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>The <b>2018 FIFA World Cup qualification</b> process is a series of tournaments organised by the six <a href=\"/wiki/FIFA\" title=\"FIFA\">FIFA</a> <a href=\"/wiki/FIFA#Structure\" title=\"FIFA\">confederations</a> to decide 31 of the 32 teams which will play in the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, with <a href=\"/wiki/Russia_national_football_team\" title=\"Russia national football team\">Russia</a> qualifying automatically as hosts. All 210 remaining FIFA member associations were eligible to enter the <a href=\"/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification\" title=\"FIFA World Cup qualification\">qualifying process</a>, and for the first time in World Cup history, all eligible national teams registered for the preliminary competition,<sup id=\"cite_ref-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> but <a href=\"/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_football_team\" title=\"Zimbabwe national football team\">Zimbabwe</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Indonesia_national_football_team\" title=\"Indonesia national football team\">Indonesia</a> were disqualified before playing their first matches.<sup id=\"cite_ref-zimbabwe_2-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-zimbabwe-2\">[2]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-indonesia_3-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-indonesia-3\">[3]</a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Bhutan_national_football_team\" title=\"Bhutan national football team\">Bhutan</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/South_Sudan_national_football_team\" title=\"South Sudan national football team\">South Sudan</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Gibraltar_national_football_team\" title=\"Gibraltar national football team\">Gibraltar</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Kosovo_national_football_team\" title=\"Kosovo national football team\">Kosovo</a> made their FIFA World Cup qualification debuts.<sup id=\"cite_ref-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups_7-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups-7\">[7]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups2_8-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups2-8\">[8]</a></sup></p>\n<p>While the main qualifying draw took place at the Konstantinovsky Palace in <a href=\"/wiki/Strelna\" title=\"Strelna\">Strelna</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Saint_Petersburg\" title=\"Saint Petersburg\">Saint Petersburg</a>, on 25 July 2015,<sup id=\"cite_ref-9\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-10\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-10\">[10]</a></sup> a number of qualification matches were played before that.<sup id=\"cite_ref-11\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> The first began in <a href=\"/wiki/Dili\" title=\"Dili\">Dili</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Timor_Leste\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Timor Leste\">Timor Leste</a>, on 12 March 2015 as part of the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(AFC)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)\">AFC</a>'s qualification,<sup id=\"cite_ref-12\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> with <a href=\"/wiki/East_Timor_national_football_team\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"East Timor national football team\">East Timorese</a> player <a href=\"/wiki/Chiquito_do_Carmo\" title=\"Chiquito do Carmo\">Chiquito do Carmo</a> scoring the first goal of qualification. Matches were also played in <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(CONCACAF)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)\">CONCACAF</a> prior to the main draw.</p>\n<p/>\n\n<p/>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Qualified_teams\">Qualified teams</span></h2>\n<div class=\"center\">\n<div class=\"thumb tnone\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\"><a This is the 4th appearance of Russia at the FIFA World Cup. However, FIFA considers Russia as the successor team of the <a href=\"/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team\" title=\"Soviet Union national football team\">Soviet Union</a> who themselves qualified on 7 occasions.</li>\n<li>2: Russia's best result is group stage in <a href=\"/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"1994 FIFA World Cup\">1994</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2002 FIFA World Cup\">2002</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2014 FIFA World Cup\">2014</a>. However, FIFA considers Russia as the successor team of the <a href=\"/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team\" title=\"Soviet Union national football team\">Soviet Union</a> who achieved this result.</li>\n<li>3: Germany between 1951 and 1990 is often referred to as \"West Germany\", as a separate East German state and <a href=\"/wiki/East_Germany_national_football_team\" title=\"East Germany national football team\">team</a> existed then.</li>\n<li>4: This is the 2nd appearance of Serbia at the FIFA World Cup. However, FIFA considers Serbia as the successor team of the <a href=\"/wiki/Yugoslavia_national_football_team\" title=\"Yugoslavia national football team\">Yugoslavia</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Serbia_and_Montenegro_national_football_team\" title=\"Serbia and Montenegro national football team\">Serbia and Montenegro</a> who all themselves qualified on 10 occasions.</li>\n<li>5: No official third place match took place in 1930 and no official third place was awarded at the time; both United States and Yugoslavia lost in the semi-finals. However, FIFA lists the teams as third and fourth respectively.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Qualification_process\">Qualification process</span></h2>\n<p>The number of teams participating in the final tournament is 32. Even though the qualification process began in March 2015, the allocation of slots for each confederation was discussed by the <a href=\"/wiki/FIFA_Council\" title=\"FIFA Council\">FIFA Executive Committee</a> on 30 May 2015 in <a href=\"/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich\" title=\"Z\u00fcrich\">Z\u00fcrich</a> after the <a href=\"/wiki/FIFA_Congress\" title=\"FIFA Congress\">FIFA Congress</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-13\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> It was decided that the same allocation as 2014 would be kept for the 2018 and 2022 tournaments.<sup id=\"cite_ref-14\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Summary_of_qualification\">Summary of qualification</span></h3>\n<p>While all FIFA members entered the tournament, not all competed. <a href=\"/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_football_team\" title=\"Zimbabwe national football team\">Zimbabwe</a> were expelled from the competition on 12 March 2015 for their failure to pay former coach <a href=\"/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Claudinei\" title=\"Jos\u00e9 Claudinei\">Jos\u00e9 Claudinei</a> a severance fee and <a href=\"/wiki/Indonesia_national_football_team\" title=\"Indonesia national football team\">Indonesia</a> were excluded from the qualifying competition following the suspension of their football association by FIFA on 30 May 2015.<sup id=\"cite_ref-indonesia_3-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-indonesia-3\">[3]</a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Kuwait_national_football_team\" title=\"Kuwait national football team\">Kuwait</a> had a number of their qualifiers cancelled for a similar suspension that began while their campaign was underway,<sup id=\"cite_ref-15\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-15\">[15]</a></sup> which eventually resulted in their elimination.</p>\n<dl>\n<dd><i>As of all matches played on 9 October 2017</i></dd>\n</dl>\n<table class=\"wikitable\">\n<tr>\n<td colspan=\"10\"><a
