CONMEBOL).</i></p>\n<p><i>Note: UEFA total includes</i> +1 <i>for Russia as hosts.</i></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Format\">Format</span></h2>\n<p>The formats of the qualifying competitions depend on each confederation <i>(see below)</i>. Each round may be played in either of the following formats:<sup id=\"cite_ref-regulations_16-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-regulations-16\">[16]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li>League format, where more than two teams form groups to play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin matches</a>, or in exceptions permitted by the FIFA Organizing Committee, single round-robin matches hosted by one of the participating teams or on neutral territory.</li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament\" title=\"Single-elimination tournament\">Knockout format</a>, where two teams play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two-legged matches</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tiebreakers\">Tiebreakers</span></h3>\n<p>In league format, the ranking of teams in each group is based on the following criteria (regulations Articles 20.6 and 20.7):<sup id=\"cite_ref-regulations_16-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-regulations-16\">[16]</a></sup></p>\n<ol>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Three_points_for_a_win\" title=\"Three points for a win\">Points</a> (3 points for a win, 1 point for a draw, 0 points for a loss)</li>\n<li>Overall <a href=\"/wiki/Goal_difference\" title=\"Goal difference\">goal difference</a></li>\n<li>Overall goals scored</li>\n<li>Points in matches between tied teams</li>\n<li>Goal difference in matches between tied teams</li>\n<li>Goals scored in matches between tied teams</li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Away_goals_rule\" title=\"Away goals rule\">Away goals</a> scored in matches between tied teams (if the tie is only between two teams in home-and-away league format)</li>\n<li>Fair play points\n<ul>\n<li>first yellow card: minus 1 point</li>\n<li>indirect red card (second yellow card): minus 3 points</li>\n<li>direct red card: minus 4 points</li>\n<li>yellow card and direct red card: minus 5 points</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li>Drawing of lots by the FIFA Organising Committee</li>\n</ol>\n<p>In cases where teams finishing in the same position across different groups are compared for determining which teams advance to the next stage, the criteria is decided by the confederation and require the approval of FIFA (regulations Article 20.8).<sup id=\"cite_ref-regulations_16-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-regulations-16\">[16]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In knockout format, the team that has the higher aggregate score over the two legs progresses to the next round. In the event that aggregate scores finish level, the <a href=\"/wiki/Away_goals_rule\" title=\"Away goals rule\">away goals rule</a> is applied, i.e. the team that scored more goals away from home over the two legs progresses. If away goals are also equal, then thirty minutes of <a href=\"/wiki/Extra_time_(association_football)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Extra time (association football)\">extra time</a> are played, divided into two fifteen-minutes halves. The away goals rule is again applied after extra time, i.e. if there are goals scored during extra time and the aggregate score is still level, the visiting team qualifies by virtue of more away goals scored. If no goals are scored during extra time, the tie is decided by <a href=\"/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_(association_football)\" title=\"Penalty shoot-out (association football)\">penalty shoot-out</a> (regulations Article 20.9).<sup id=\"cite_ref-regulations_16-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-regulations-16\">[16]</a></sup></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Confederation_qualification\">Confederation qualification</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"AFC\">AFC</span></h3>\n\n<p>The AFC Executive Committee meeting on 16 April 2014 approved the proposal to merge the preliminary qualification rounds of the FIFA World Cup and the <a href=\"/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup\" title=\"AFC Asian Cup\">AFC Asian Cup</a>, which will be expanded to 24 teams starting in <a href=\"/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup\" title=\"2019 AFC Asian Cup\">2019</a>:<sup id=\"cite_ref-17\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>First round</b>: A total of 12 teams (teams ranked 35\u201346) played home-and-away over <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two legs</a>. The six winners advanced to the second round.</li>\n<li><b>Second round</b>: A total of 40 teams (teams ranked 1\u201334 and six first round winners) were divided into eight groups of five teams to play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin</a> matches. The eight group winners and the four best group runners-up advanced to the third round of FIFA World Cup qualification as well as qualified for the <a href=\"/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup\" title=\"2019 AFC Asian Cup\">2019 AFC Asian Cup</a> finals.</li>\n<li><b>Third round</b>: The 12 teams (an increase from 10 for <a href=\"/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(AFC)\" title=\"2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)\">2014</a>) which advanced from the second round were divided into two groups of six teams to play home-and-away round-robin matches. The top two teams of each group qualified for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, and the two third-placed teams advanced to the fourth round.</li>\n<li><b>Fourth round</b>: The two third-placed teams of each group from the third round will play home-and-away over two legs. The winner will advance to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>, playing the fourth-placed CONCACAF team.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>A total of 24 teams eliminated from World Cup qualification in the second round compete in the <a href=\"/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup_qualification#Third_round\" title=\"2019 AFC Asian Cup qualification\">third round of 2019 AFC Asian Cup qualification</a> (which is separate from the third round of 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification), where they are divided into six groups of four teams and compete for the remaining slots of the 2019 AFC Asian Cup. The 24 teams consist of the 16 highest ranked teams eliminated in the second round, and the eight teams that advanced from the <a href=\"/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup_qualification#Play-off_round\" title=\"2019 AFC Asian Cup qualification\">play-off round of 2019 AFC Asian Cup qualification</a> which are contested by the remaining 12 teams eliminated in the second round.<sup id=\"cite_ref-fifa20150413_18-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-fifa20150413-18\">[18]</a></sup></p>\n<h4><span id=\"Final_positions_(third_round)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Final_positions_.28third_round.29\">Final positions (third round)</span></h4>\n\n<p>The draw for the third round was held on 12 April 2016 at the <a href=\"/wiki/Mandarin_Oriental_Hotel_Group#Kuala_Lumpur\" title=\"Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group\">Mandarin Oriental Hotel</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur\" title=\"Kuala Lumpur\">Kuala Lumpur</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Malaysia\" title=\"Malaysia\">Malaysia</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-19\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></p>\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_AFC_Third_Round#Group_A\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 AFC Third Round\">Group A</a></b></p>\n\n\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_AFC_Third_Round#Group_B\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 AFC Third Round\">Group B</a></b></p>\n\n\n<h4><span id=\"Current_stage_(fourth_round)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Current_stage_.28fourth_round.29\">Current stage (fourth round)</span></h4>\n\n<p>The third-placed teams from each group in the third round will play against each other home-and-away over two legs to determine which team will advance to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>.</p>\n\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"CAF\">CAF</span></h3>\n\n<p>The CAF Executive Committee approved the format for the qualifiers of the 2018 FIFA World Cup on 14 January 2015.<sup id=\"cite_ref-20\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-20\">[20]</a></sup> However, on 9 July 2015 FIFA officially announced that only three rounds will be played instead of four.<sup id=\"cite_ref-PreliminaryDrawProcedure_21-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PreliminaryDrawProcedure-21\">[21]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>First round</b>: A total of 26 teams (teams ranked 28\u201353) played home-and-away over <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two legs</a>. The 13 winners advanced to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Second_Round\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Second Round\">second round</a>.</li>\n<li><b>Second round</b>: A total of 40 teams (teams ranked 1\u201327 and 13 first round winners) played home-and-away over <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two legs</a>. The 20 winners advanced to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">third round</a>.</li>\n<li><b>Third round</b>: The 20 teams which advance from the second round were divided into five groups of four teams to play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin</a> matches. The winners of each group will qualify for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_football_team\" title=\"Zimbabwe national football team\">Zimbabwe</a>, even though they entered the competition, were expelled on 12 March 2015 for their failure to pay former coach <a href=\"/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Claudinei\" title=\"Jos\u00e9 Claudinei\">Jos\u00e9 Claudinei</a> a severance fee.<sup id=\"cite_ref-zimbabwe_2-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-zimbabwe-2\">[2]</a></sup> Therefore, only 53 African teams were involved in the draw.</p>\n<h4><span id=\"Current_stage_(third_round)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Current_stage_.28third_round.29\">Current stage (third round)</span></h4>\n\n<p>The draw for the third round was held on 24 June 2016 at the CAF headquarters in <a href=\"/wiki/Cairo\" title=\"Cairo\">Cairo</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Egypt\" title=\"Egypt\">Egypt</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-22\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-22\">[22]</a></sup></p>\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round#Group_A\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">Group A</a></b></p>\n\n\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round#Group_B\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">Group B</a></b></p>\n\n<div class=\"reflist\"><p>Updated to match(es) played on 7 October 2017. Source: </p><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/group=276445/index.html\">FIFA</a><p>\nRules for classification: </p><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification#Tiebreakers\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification\">Qualification tiebreakers</a>\n<span>(E)</span><p> Eliminated; </p><span>(Q)</span><p> Qualified to the phase indicated.</p></div>\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round#Group_C\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">Group C</a></b></p>\n\n\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round#Group_D\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">Group D</a></b></p>\n\n\n\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_CAF_Third_Round#Group_E\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 CAF Third Round\">Group E</a></b></p>\n\n<div class=\"reflist\"><p>Updated to match(es) played on 8 October 2017. Source: </p><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/group=276414/index.html\">FIFA</a><p>\nRules for classification: </p><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification#Tiebreakers\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification\">Qualification tiebreakers</a>\n<span>(E)</span><p> Eliminated; </p><span>(Q)</span><p> Qualified to the phase indicated.</p></div>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"CONCACAF\">CONCACAF</span></h3>\n\n<p>An amendment to the qualification process for this tournament had been suggested,<sup id=\"cite_ref-25\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-25\">[24]</a></sup> which would see the first three rounds played as knockout rounds, with both the fourth round and the final round (referred to as '<a href=\"/wiki/Hexagonal_(CONCACAF)\" title=\"Hexagonal (CONCACAF)\">The Hex</a>') played as group stages. The first round would be played during the FIFA international dates of 23\u201331 March 2015.<sup id=\"cite_ref-26\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-26\">[25]</a></sup> CONCACAF announced the full details on 12 January 2015:<sup id=\"cite_ref-27\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-27\">[26]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-28\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-28\">[27]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>First round</b>: A total of 14 teams (teams ranked 22\u201335) played home-and-away over <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two legs</a>. The seven winners advanced to the second round.</li>\n<li><b>Second round</b>: A total of 20 teams (teams ranked 9\u201321 and seven first round winners) played home-and-away over two legs. The ten winners advanced to the third round.</li>\n<li><b>Third round</b>: A total of 12 teams (teams ranked 7\u20138 and ten second round winners) played home-and-away over two legs. The six winners advanced to the fourth round.</li>\n<li><b>Fourth round</b>: A total of 12 teams (teams ranked 1\u20136 and six third round winners) were divided into three groups of four teams to play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin</a> matches. The top two teams of each group advanced to the fifth round.</li>\n<li><b>Fifth round</b>: The six teams which advanced from the fourth round will play home-and-away round-robin matches in one single group. The top three teams will qualify for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, and the fourth-placed team will advance to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>, playing the winner of the Asian Football Confederation play-off.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4><span id=\"Current_stage_(fifth_round)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Current_stage_.28fifth_round.29\">Current stage (fifth round)</span></h4>\n\n<p>The draw for the fifth round (to decide the fixtures) was held on 8 July 2016 at the CONCACAF headquarters in <a href=\"/wiki/Miami_Beach,_Florida\" title=\"Miami Beach, Florida\">Miami Beach</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/United_States\" title=\"United States\">United States</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-29\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-29\">[28]</a></sup></p>\n\n<div class=\"reflist\"><p>Updated to match(es) played on 7 October 2017. Source: </p><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/nccamerica/group=276450/index.html\">FIFA</a><p>\nRules for classification: </p><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification#Tiebreakers\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification\">Qualification tiebreakers</a>\n<span>(E)</span><p> Eliminated; </p><span>(Q)</span><p> Qualified to the phase indicated.</p></div>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"CONMEBOL\">CONMEBOL</span></h3>\n\n<p>The qualification structure is the same as the previous five editions. The ten teams will play in a league of home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin</a> matches. The top four teams will qualify for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, and the fifth-placed team will advance to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>, playing the winner of the Oceania Football Confederation qualifying competition.</p>\n<p>Unlike previous qualifying tournaments where the fixtures were pre-determined, the fixtures were decided by a draw held on 25 July 2015, at the Konstantinovsky Palace in <a href=\"/wiki/Strelna\" title=\"Strelna\">Strelna</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Saint_Petersburg\" title=\"Saint Petersburg\">Saint Petersburg</a>, Russia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-approval_30-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-approval-30\">[29]</a></sup></p>\n<h4><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Current_stage\">Current stage</span></h4>\n\n\n<div class=\"reflist\">\n<div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n<ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"cite_note-table_note_BOL_PER0.98419783030832-32\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\">^ <a href=\"#cite_ref-table_note_BOL_PER0.98419783030832_32-0\"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href=\"#cite_ref-table_note_BOL_PER0.98419783030832_32-1\"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">FIFA awarded Peru and Chile 3\u20130 wins as a result of Bolivia fielding the ineligible player <a href=\"/wiki/Nelson_David_Cabrera\" title=\"Nelson David Cabrera\">Nelson Cabrera</a>. Originally Bolivia had defeated Peru 2\u20130 and drawn 0\u20130 with Chile. Cabrera had previously represented Paraguay and did not meet eligibility rules.<sup id=\"cite_ref-bolivia_sanctioned_31-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-bolivia_sanctioned-31\">[30]</a></sup></span></li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"OFC\">OFC</span></h3>\n\n<p>The qualification structure was as follows:<sup id=\"cite_ref-33\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-33\">[31]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-PreliminaryDrawProcedure_21-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PreliminaryDrawProcedure-21\">[21]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>First round</b>: <a href=\"/wiki/American_Samoa_national_football_team\" title=\"American Samoa national football team\">American Samoa</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Cook_Islands_national_football_team\" title=\"Cook Islands national football team\">Cook Islands</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Samoa_national_football_team\" title=\"Samoa national football team\">Samoa</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Tonga_national_football_team\" title=\"Tonga national football team\">Tonga</a> played a <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin tournament</a> at a single country. The winner advanced to the second round.</li>\n<li><b>Second round (OFC Nations Cup)</b>: A total of eight teams (<a href=\"/wiki/Fiji_national_football_team\" title=\"Fiji national football team\">Fiji</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/New_Caledonia_national_football_team\" title=\"New Caledonia national football team\">New Caledonia</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team\" title=\"New Zealand national football team\">New Zealand</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea_national_football_team\" title=\"Papua New Guinea national football team\">Papua New Guinea</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Solomon_Islands_national_football_team\" title=\"Solomon Islands national football team\">Solomon Islands</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Tahiti_national_football_team\" title=\"Tahiti national football team\">Tahiti</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Vanuatu_national_football_team\" title=\"Vanuatu national football team\">Vanuatu</a>, and the first round winner) played the tournament at a single country. For the group stage, they were divided into two groups of four teams. The top three teams of each group advanced to the third round of World Cup qualifying. The top two teams of each group also advanced to the knockout stage (semi-finals and final) to decide the <a href=\"/wiki/2016_OFC_Nations_Cup\" title=\"2016 OFC Nations Cup\">2016 OFC Nations Cup</a> winner which would play in the <a href=\"/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup\" title=\"2017 FIFA Confederations Cup\">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>.</li>\n<li><b>Third round</b>: The six teams which advanced from the second round were divided into two groups of three teams to play home-and-away round-robin matches. The two group winners met in a <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_match\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Two-legged match\">two-legged match</a> with the winner advancing to the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>, playing the fifth-placed South American team.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The OFC had considered different proposals of the qualifying tournament.<sup id=\"cite_ref-OFC_Executive_34-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-OFC_Executive-34\">[32]</a></sup> A previous proposal adopted by the OFC in October 2014 would have the eight teams divided into two groups of four teams to play home-and-away round-robin matches in the second round, followed by the top two teams of each group advancing to the third round to play in a single group of home-and-away round-robin matches to decide the winner of the 2016 OFC Nations Cup which would qualify to the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup and advance to the inter-confederation play-offs.<sup id=\"cite_ref-35\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-35\">[33]</a></sup> However, it was later reported in April 2015 that the OFC had reversed its decision, and the 2016 OFC Nations Cup was played as a one-off tournament similar to the <a href=\"/wiki/2012_OFC_Nations_Cup\" title=\"2012 OFC Nations Cup\">2012 OFC Nations Cup</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-36\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-36\">[34]</a></sup></p>\n<h4><span id=\"Final_positions_(third_round)_2\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Final_positions_.28third_round.29_2\">Final positions (third round)</span></h4>\n\n<p>The draw for the third round was held on 8 July 2016 at the OFC headquarters in <a href=\"/wiki/Auckland\" title=\"Auckland\">Auckland</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/New_Zealand\" title=\"New Zealand\">New Zealand</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-draw_37-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-draw-37\">[35]</a></sup></p>\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_OFC_Third_Round#Group_A\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 OFC Third Round\">Group A</a></b></p>\n\n\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_OFC_Third_Round#Group_B\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 OFC Third Round\">Group B</a></b></p>\n\n\n<div class=\"reflist\">\n<div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n<ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"cite_note-table_note_TAH_SOL0.85576411190245-39\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-table_note_TAH_SOL0.85576411190245_39-0\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">FIFA awarded Tahiti a 3\u20130 win as a result of the Solomon Islands fielding the ineligible player <a href=\"/wiki/Henry_Fa%27arodo\" title=\"Henry Fa'arodo\">Henry Fa'arodo</a>, after Tahiti had defeated the Solomon Islands 1\u20130. Fa'arodo failed to serve a one-game ban after receiving two yellow cards in the <a href=\"/wiki/2016_OFC_Nations_Cup\" title=\"2016 OFC Nations Cup\">2016 OFC Nations Cup</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-solomon_islands_sanctioned_38-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-solomon_islands_sanctioned-38\">[36]</a></sup></span></li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><b><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_OFC_Third_Round#Final\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification \u2013 OFC Third Round\">Final</a></b><br/>\nThe draw for the final (which decided the order of legs) was held on 15 June 2017 at the OFC headquarters in <a href=\"/wiki/Auckland\" title=\"Auckland\">Auckland</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/New_Zealand\" title=\"New Zealand\">New Zealand</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-OFC_final_draw_40-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-OFC_final_draw-40\">[37]</a></sup> The winner of the final advances to <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(inter-confederation_play-offs)\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (inter-confederation play-offs)\">inter-confederation play-offs</a>.</p>\n\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"UEFA\">UEFA</span></h3>\n\n<p>Russia have qualified automatically as hosts. The qualifying format for the remaining FIFA-affiliated UEFA teams was confirmed by the UEFA Executive Committee meeting on 22\u201323 March 2015 in <a href=\"/wiki/Vienna\" title=\"Vienna\">Vienna</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-41\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-41\">[38]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-42\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-42\">[39]</a></sup> The draw for the UEFA zone took place on 25 July 2015 in St. Petersburg.<sup id=\"cite_ref-43\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-43\">[40]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-PreliminaryDrawProcedure_21-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PreliminaryDrawProcedure-21\">[21]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li><b>First round (group stage)</b>: The 52 UEFA teams affiliated with FIFA at the time of the draw were divided into nine groups (seven groups of six teams and two groups of five teams) to play home-and-away <a href=\"/wiki/Round-robin_tournament\" title=\"Round-robin tournament\">round-robin</a> matches. The winners of each group qualify for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, and the eight best runners-up advance to the second round (play-offs). With the admission of <a href=\"/wiki/Gibraltar_national_football_team\" title=\"Gibraltar national football team\">Gibraltar</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Kosovo_national_football_team\" title=\"Kosovo national football team\">Kosovo</a> as FIFA members in May 2016, both national teams were eligible to make their debuts in World Cup qualifying.<sup id=\"cite_ref-FIFA_Congress_drives_football_forward.2C_first_female_secretary_general_appointed_-_FIFA.com_6-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FIFA_Congress_drives_football_forward.2C_first_female_secretary_general_appointed_-_FIFA.com-6\">[6]</a></sup> With initially two groups in the first round having only five teams, Kosovo was assigned to Group I as it was decided that Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia should not play against Kosovo for security reasons, and Gibraltar was then added to Group H,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups_7-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups-7\">[7]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups2_8-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kosovo_and_Gibraltar_assigned_groups2-8\">[8]</a></sup> so that each of the nine groups then had six teams.</li>\n<li><b>Second round (play-offs)</b>: The eight best runners-up from the first round play one other team over <a href=\"/wiki/Two-legged_tie\" title=\"Two-legged tie\">two legs</a>, home and away, the draw being 17 October 2017. The four winners will qualify for the <a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup\">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>. In deciding the eight best runners-up, the matches against the sixth-placed team in each group is discarded.<sup id=\"cite_ref-44\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-44\">[41]</a></sup></li>\n</ul>\n<h4><span id=\"Current_stage_(first_round)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Current_stage_.28first_round.29\">Current stage (first round)</span></h4>\n<p>The draw for the first round was held on 25 July 2015, at the Konstantinovsky Palace in <a href=\"/wiki/Strelna\" title=\"Strelna\">Strelna</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Saint_Petersburg\" title=\"Saint Petersburg\">Saint Petersburg</a>, Russia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-PreliminaryDrawProcedure_21-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PreliminaryDrawProcedure-21\">[21]</a></sup></p>\n\n\n<table>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th align=\"center\"><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_A\" World Cup qualification \u2013 UEFA Group B\">Group B</a></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><a href=\"/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_C\" title=\"2018 FIFA World Cup of at least play-offs;\n</p><span>(Z)</span><p> Cannot qualify directly, but can still qualify via play-offs.</p></div>\n</td>\n<td align=\"left\">\n\n<div class=\"reflist\"><p>Updated to match(es) qualify for the World Cup.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Inter-confederation_play-offs\">Inter-confederation play-offs</span></h2>\n\n<p>The inter-confederation play-offs are scheduled to be played between 6\u201314 November 2017.<sup id=\"cite_ref-48\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-48\">[45]</a></sup></p>\n<p>The matchups were decided at the preliminary draw which was held on 25 July 2015, at the Konstantinovsky Palace in <a href=\"/wiki/Strelna\" title=\"Strelna\">Strelna</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Saint_Petersburg\" title=\"Saint Petersburg\">Saint Petersburg</a>, Russia.<sup id=\"cite_ref-PreliminaryDrawProcedure_21-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PreliminaryDrawProcedure-21\">[21]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"External_links\">External links</span></h2>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429677": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:55:02", "url": "https://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/diy-jet-180963198/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body pagination-first\">\n      \n      \n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>At first, Elliot Seguin thought he\u2019d been decapitated. He knew that his brain would briefly keep on ticking after being severed from his body. <em>My last 10 seconds</em>, he said to himself, looking through the hole his tiny turbine-powered airplane had just punched through a trailer.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n    \n\n    \n      \n        \n          <p class=\"associated-container\">\n            \n              \n            \n            \n\n            \n          </p>\n        \n      \n    \n  \n\n  <p>Skeletons of scrapped 747s cast shadows all around him. He\u2019d taken off from Mojave Air and Space Port, situated in a featureless Southern California plain, miles of nothing extending in every direction. Somehow he\u2019d still managed to crash into Mojave\u2019s aircraft cemetery\u00ad. Not as bad as hitting one of the populated airport buildings, obviously, but still impressive.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Gradually he became conscious of a voice, belonging to Justin Gillen, his airplane-building partner and a Scaled Composites engineer, screaming over his ruined headset. \u201cTower, I need to get to the boneyard right now!\u201d Gillen yelled, over and over.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Seguin, knowing Gillen couldn\u2019t hear or see him, stood up in the wreckage like Bruce Willis in a <em>Die Hard</em> sequel. He had a black eye. He needed a CT scan. But he was alive, and he watched Gillen drive over the dusty road toward their destroyed aircraft: a tiny, tandem-wing airplane to which they\u2019d added two jet engines. TWERP, they called it. <em>Had</em> called it. There wasn\u2019t much left.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n        \n      \n    \n  \n\n  <p>Seguin, 34, and Gillen, 37, are two of the most adventurous of a subset of Mojave aerospace designers who build and fly their own airplanes in their free time. And when there are no boards or bosses to answer to, they have the liberty of (within federal government limits) using a different metric for \u201crisk.\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>\u201cSure, it is safer to sit at my house,\u201d Seguin says, pulling back the tarp to show me TWERP\u2019s wreckage, which looks like a bunch of ripped-up packing material. \u201cBut I will never be like my heroes if I sit at my house.\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>TWERP\u2014for Twin Engine Research Project\u2014ended in pieces. But it began with Seguin and Gillen coveting their neighbor\u2019s goods.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <h3>CATCH UP-22</h3>\n\n\n\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n  \n\n  <p>Seguin started Wasabi Air Racing with his girlfriend (now wife), Jennifer Whaley, in 2007. Gillen joined them in the enterprise soon after. At the time, the three of them all worked for Scaled Composites; Gillen and Whaley still do. Seguin is now an experimental test pilot for Mooney International. Wasabi was just \u201cthe hobby of a few aviation dorks who use the company to get more experience designing, building, and testing cool airplanes,\u201d Seguin says.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n    \n  \n\n  <p>They began modestly: In the 2008 Reno Air Races, Seguin flew a Cassutt he\u2019d bought from a Bay Area museum and repaired. He hung in through the Formula One Silver race, finishing eighth. He knew he didn\u2019t have a real shot at winning in that airplane; he just wanted to get some testing and racing experience.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>And tinkering experience: The following year, Seguin and Gillen modified the Cassutt with a tighter cowling, increasing its top speed by 17 mph. Seguin finished in fourth place in the Formula One Bronze race.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>After that, Seguin and Gillen focused on designing their own airplane. Their creation, the Wasabi Siren\u2014a white bullet powered by the Formula One category\u2019s requisite Continental O-200 engine\u2014first flew in 2012. Two years later, on July 28, 2014, Seguin set a world record in the Siren when it became the fastest piston-powered aircraft in its weight class to fly from Mojave to Oshkosh, Wisconsin, clocking a speed of 163.31 mph. \u201cThe cool thing for me was to set a record that effectively drew a line between the two Meccas for experimental aircraft: Mojave and Oshkosh,\u201d Seguin wrote in an email.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>By 2013, he was ready to return to Reno. Flying the Siren, he finished in eighth place in the Formula One Gold Race. But he improved in each of the following two years, taking fourth place in 2014 and then third place in 2015, with a time of 6:33.844.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>For a long time, Gillen and Seguin had been content to help each other with their own projects. Eventually they started getting offers from other pilots who wanted them to test their aircraft.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>One of their first clients needed help with turbo controllers on a Continental TSIO-550 race engine. After the two worked on it, the aircraft, a Lancair Legacy, set four world records in three days at the 2015 Mojave Experimental Fly-in: two for Time to Climb to 3,000 Meters (2:03 and 1:59) and two for Speed Over a 3-Kilometer Course (391 and 388 mph).</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Now Seguin owns a hangar at the Mojave airport (he also rents three others). The space is littered with project patches, fuselage molds, and empty energy-drink cans.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Mojave is full of caves like this one: While it\u2019s home to big-name customers like Scaled Composites and Virgin Galactic, its many smaller hangars belong to enthusiasts and employees who fly in their spare time. For some, it\u2019s just a hobby for blowing off steam. Others want to bolster their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s so they get noticed at work, standing out among the hundreds of other ambitious engineers and pilots.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Seguin and Gillen are in that second category. One day they spotted an opportunity in the hangar right next door: Hanging like a museum display was a Rutan Quickie Q1 homebuilt\u2014a featherweight taildragger designed by Scaled Composites founder Burt Rutan\u2014that had been abandoned by its original owner before it ever flew. Seguin and Gillen\u2019s neighbor had rescued it from the airport dumpster, then held onto it for a decade, always intending to do something with it.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Of the many oddball Rutan designs, the Quickie is one of the oddest. It has tandem wings, with the main gear located at the tips of the main wing. It has the profile of a wasp and the aura of a spaceship.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>But this modification had never flown. Its controls weren\u2019t installed, nor were the electrical systems. The brakes needed to be tweaked.</p>\n\n\n\n\n    \n        \n    \n        \n\n\n  \n\n  <div class=\"slideshow-wrapper\">\n            \n            \n\n            \n            <div class=\"slideshow\">\n                <a class=\"slideshow-prev GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Previous\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-left\"> </i>\n                </a>\n                <a class=\"slideshow-next GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Next\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-right\"> </i>\n                </a>\n\n                <div class=\"slideshow-slides\">\n                    <div class=\"slideshow-wrap\">\n                        \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img                                          \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/vZ4E8M0pTECLz-yXniIdHFX0eXc=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/5e/70/5e704a82-8123-4e09-a45f-3e548ae70f25/11p_jj2017_img_20150920_193114517_hdr_live-wr.jpg\" alt=\"\"/>\n                                            <figcaption class=\"caption\">\n                                                Seguin's dad Drew and wife-to-be Jenn Whaley supported the 2008 attempt. In 2015 Seguin raced the Wasabi Siren and, with RX Aerosport\u2019s Rick Poe (center) and Gillen (right), collected a trophy.\n                                                \n                                                    <span class=\"credits\">(Jenn Seguin)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            </div>\n                        \n                </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n    \n\n    \n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Scheming, Seguin and Gillen asked Quickie\u2019s owner if they could finish it for him. They\u2019d bring it up to spec and even do the tests necessary to secure its airworthiness certificate.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>The owner agreed, encouraging the pair to \u201cdo something cool with it,\u201d Seguin recalls.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>They pitched the owner several ideas, but he chose the one Seguin and Gillen had hoped he would go for: They would turn his wasp of an airplane into a jet.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Out went the 18-horsepower engine from a motor home generator. In its place they installed two PBS TJ-40s, each rated at 85 pounds of thrust.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Call it an upgrade.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <h3>My Hobby, My Business</h3>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Seguin described Wasabi\u2019s main business as \u201ccontract flight test.\u201d In his words, they \u201ctrade engineering and fabrication resources for exotic flight test experience.\u201d Sometimes this means finding homebuilts that other people have left unfinished and completing the jobs, perhaps with a modification or two, then certifying the airplanes so the owners can jump straight to Sunday joyrides.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>In the case of the Quickie, they made short work of replacing its old 80-pound engine with 16 pounds of turbines, a modification that would demand 28 more gallons of fuel per hour. Replacing one heavy engine with two lightweight ones unbalanced the airplane, so more modifications were called for to make it stable. \u201cThe obvious solution is to put the new engines where the old one was,\u201d says Seguin. But then the hot exhaust, traveling the whole length of the airplane, would bake the fuselage.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Instead, they moved the engines to the back and added two additional fuel tanks\u2014one in the new nose and one under the rear wing spar\u2014and let gas flow between them. Then they built a new nose using a mold they had created from 50 pounds of foam purchased at a hardware store, and filled it with ballast to re-balance their airplane.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>As they worked, they posted pictures and videos online. Their YouTube plays hit the tens of thousands in a day. And watching progress on #projectTWERP, people began to get excited: \u201cYou actually plan to fly that thing?!?!? This has quickly turned into my favorite Instagram acct,\u201d said one commenter.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Some of their Mojave peers disapprove of their habit of inviting the public to peek behind the curtain. Gillen himself used to feel this way, he says: Social media is for braggarts. One sponsor told Seguin the posts made him look like a fraud. If he were really doing such great work, he\u2019d just do it and stay quiet.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>But Seguin\u2019s view is that the general public isn\u2019t living and breathing aviation the way his peers do. Isn\u2019t a little showing off warranted, he asks, if it helps get a new group of people interested in flight? He also says that posting their work in public forums invites feedback that he and his cohorts can use to do their jobs better\u2014a sort of informal peer review.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Gillen has come around to that opinion. Sharing is fun. \u201cAnd if you\u2019re a couple dudes who want to generate excitement about whatever, it\u2019s not going to happen without exposure,\u201d he says.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <h3>Certified and Certifiable</h3>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>With engines and fuel tanks installed and aligned, Seguin and Gillen worked with the Federal Aviation Administration to get an airworthiness certificate for their airplane as an experimental craft. Because it didn\u2019t fit neatly into the turbojet category, they knew the bureaucratic wheels might require some greasing: They visited the FAA\u2019s Flight Standards District Office in Van Nuys\u2014about a 60-mile drive from Seguin\u2019s home in Chino\u00ad\u2014in person to talk officials through their unconventional project.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Finally, certificate in hand, they began dreaming of the future: setting a record on the three-kilometer (1.9-mile) closed course, flying higher than 6,000 meters, going longer than 250 miles. But like all things that go up, TWERP had to be tested on the ground first.</p>\n\n\n\n\n    \n        \n    \n        \n\n\n  \n\n  <div class=\"slideshow-wrapper\">\n            \n            \n\n            \n            <div class=\"slideshow\">\n                <a class=\"slideshow-prev GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Previous\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-left\"> </i>\n                </a>\n                <a class=\"slideshow-next GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Next\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-right\"> </i>\n                </a>\n\n                <div class=\"slideshow-slides\">\n                    <div class=\"slideshow-wrap\">\n                        \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/Bo1h7KWN-AtmDMzWw7INGSXMoWM=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/c6/8b/c68bc5d3-9ea9-477e-a5b7-cb88ee09e5e1/11b_jj2017_tfi_quickie_02_live.jpg\" alt=\"\"/>\n                                            <figcaption class=\"caption\">\n                                                TWERP on its second flight, with Seguin in the cockpit, as photographed by Gillen from his own aircraft, <em>Tango Time Machine.</em>\n                                                \n                                                    <span class=\"credits\">(Doug Glover)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/OGGKWn9swMFWVDFOwCFRKQO-nK0=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/69/b8/69b8a637-7add-4abb-84c3-0ce973870a44/11o_jj2017_nm_160409_breakingtheday_0005_live.jpg\" alt=\"\"/>\n                                            <figcaption class=\"caption\">\n                                                Seguin inspects TWERP on the ground. After the May 2016 crash last year, he suffered a crisis of confidence.\n                                                \n                                                    <span class=\"credits\">(Nick Miller)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            </div>\n                        \n                </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n    \n\n    \n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>And there, a problem immediately flew up at them: When the engines ran at low power, they sometimes died. The engines sucked a lot of battery power at the start, they found, so when the airplane idled on the runway, the system voltage dipped, and the engines shut off. It was an easy fix: They just agreed that right after every spool-up, they would run the engines at a minimum of 40 percent power for two minutes to charge the battery.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>\u201cI think we both knew that we hadn\u2019t licked the engine failure problem all the way,\u201d says Gillen, \u201cbut we had rationalized it by saying that the worst place for the engine to fail is on the takeoff run.\u201d In that scenario, Mojave\u2019s 12,000-foot runway gave them plenty of room to land safely after liftoff.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>They moved on to taxi testing, with Seguin and Gillen taking turns gunning the airplane up and down the runway. TWERP was shifty in its ground handling, but in exactly the same quirky ways all Quickies were\u2014not in ways that pointed fingers at their engines.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>It was time to fly.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>On May 13, 2016, the first two flights went off without any hitches, shutdowns, or spinouts. Fire poured from the engines\u2019 nozzles, and the airplane went up and came down. It was a little scary, this unproven machine, but they trusted their build; they trusted their tests; they trusted themselves. They wouldn\u2019t have gone up if they thought something would go wrong.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Resting up from the two initial flights, Seguin and Gillen sat in the Voyager restaurant at Mojave with a Red Bull film crew, there to shoot Seguin and Gillen for a TV special. The walls were adorned with maps of famous flight paths and portraits of aviation heroes, and the team could watch all manner of aircraft taxi by while they ate their pancakes. They talked, as one does, about the weather.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>The desert winds were up, and forecast to stay that way. But as they ate, the air calmed.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>\u201cMan, it would be great to get one more flight off,\u201d Seguin said. In his memory, the team agreed it was a good idea. Or maybe he means that no one actively objected; Gillen remembers it differently. \u201cI long ago decided that Elliot makes his own decisions on go or no-go, and I would do the same for myself,\u201d he says. \u201cI thought, \u2018Well, I wouldn\u2019t do that, but it\u2019s not me.\u2019\u00a0\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Seguin and Gillen now go back and forth about the decision. Was it simply \u201cKodak courage\u201d\u2014going forward with a feat you shouldn\u2019t just because the Red Bull cameras were there? Or was it an informed decision that just happened to turn out poorly?</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <h3>Third Time\u2019s the Harm</h3>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>For the third flight, Seguin taxied hard down the runway, just as before. And TWERP lifted up, just as before. But as soon as Seguin was at altitude, the winds reappeared. \u201cThe weird thing was they didn\u2019t come right up,\u201d he recalls. \u201cThey were kind of gasping through the area.\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He pulled the engine power to idle and started descent. The ground approached, the Joshua trees and cars on Highway 58 appearing larger underneath him. But five feet from touchdown, a gust blew up from the right. Suddenly, the airplane rolled 45 degrees. He couldn\u2019t land like that.</p>\n\n\n\n\n    \n        \n    \n        \n\n\n  \n\n  <div class=\"slideshow-wrapper\">\n            \n            \n\n            \n            <div class=\"slideshow\">\n                <a class=\"slideshow-prev GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Previous\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-left\"> </i>\n                </a>\n                <a class=\"slideshow-next GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Next\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-right\"> </i>\n                </a>\n\n                <div class=\"slideshow-slides\">\n                    <div class=\"slideshow-wrap\">\n                        \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/7a1xBOVyRBL0JiMhjeDh3F-nWWE=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/e7/aa/e7aa6047-12d8-4559-a40a-bec7fb2be997/11e_jj2017_nzm_160513_elliotseguin_09_live.jpg\" alt=\"\"/>\n                                            <figcaption class=\"caption\">\n                                                High-speed taxi tests of TWERP at Mojave bore out that the Quickie was tricky to handle even on land.\n                                                \n                                                    <span class=\"credits\">(Nick Miller)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/Oey8HN8q84VkvvGoAnOM4xJVNqc=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/59/a8/59a8c9cc-9f6e-45db-bb66-2a7a7955141f/11s_jj2017_img_2335_live-wr.jpg\" alt=\"\"/>\n                                            <figcaption class=\"caption\">\n                                                The wreckage in the boneyard, after the crash-landing\n                                                \n                                                    <span class=\"credits\">(Elliot Seguin)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            </div>\n                        \n                </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n    \n\n    \n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He pushed the engines to full power, intending to ascend and come back around. But just as the turbines\u2019 thrust pressed him into his seat and the nose lifted, he heard the silence no pilot ever wants to hear: an engine, gone.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>The airplane was still tilted from the gust, and tilted into the now-dead engine. The nose was slicing to the left. And as soon as he could see over it, Seguin realized it was pointing right toward the hard, heavy, jagged 747s of the boneyard.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Although the Wasabi protocols\u2014which accounted for an engine out\u2014dictated that the pilot shut the second engine off and land straight ahead, his airplane was so skewed that there was no \u201cstraight ahead.\u201d Seguin kept the right engine on and willed the airplane to climb. But he knew that the more power he gave, the less control he would have, and the less power he gave, the sooner he was going down\u2014right into the side of a leftover Lufthansa.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He frantically tried different power levels, different controls. It was no use. \u201cI\u2019m looking at where I\u2019m going to go, and it\u2019s the worst place,\u201d he says.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He dove TWERP between two 747s. The small volume of air between the metallic hulks and his wingtips whizzed. But he\u2019d avoided them only to find himself staring at the side of a Convair.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Increasing the power and pulling away, he soon found two more 747s in his view. He couldn\u2019t go over; he couldn\u2019t go between. It was game over.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>And then he saw the trailer.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He didn\u2019t know what was inside, but he figured\u2014perhaps foolishly\u2014it had to be softer than an airliner.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>He pushed the nose down, pulled the throttle to idle, and closed his eyes.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <h3>Aftermath</h3>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>\u201cThere are so many stories [TWERP] never got to tell,\u201d he says now, mourning the strange airplane\u2019s premature demise. He and Gillen hadn\u2019t learned all they could from the experiment. In its final report on the accident, the National Transportation Safety Board noted that \u201c[t]he purpose of the accident flight was to begin exploring the crosswind handling characteristics and capabilities of the airplane\u201d and that \u201c[t]here was insufficient evidence to determine the reason(s) for the loss of engine power, and none of the three most likely causes (fuel flow interruption, air flow interruption, or flameout due to rapid and large throttle input) could be definitively ruled out.\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n    \n        \n    \n        \n\n\n  \n\n  <div class=\"slideshow-wrapper\">\n            \n            \n\n            \n            <div class=\"slideshow\">\n                <a class=\"slideshow-prev GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Previous\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-left\"> </i>\n                </a>\n                <a class=\"slideshow-next GTM-slideshow-large-arrow\" title=\"Next\">\n                    <i class=\"icon-large icon-chevron-right\"> </i>\n                </a>\n\n                <div class=\"slideshow-slides\">\n                    <div class=\"slideshow-wrap\">\n                        \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img class=\"credits\">(Daniel Tou)</span>\n                                                \n                                                \n\n\n\n                                            </figcaption>\n                                        </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                                \n                                    <div class=\"slide\">\n                                        <figure>\n                                            <img src=\"https://thumbs-prod.si-cdn.com/BOjM1r7sNJIyqI0i0kPBVHXnJs8=/fit-in/1072x0/https://public-media.smithsonianmag.com/filer/b5/18/b518ba5c-729d-43fa-9a4f-1b8bdc8d0fa3/11zb_jj2017_img_9844_live.jpg\"                     </figure>\n                                    </div>\n                                \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            \n                            </div>\n                        \n                </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n    \n\n    \n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>In his Pilot/Operator Accident Report to the NTSB, Seguin had recounted: \u201cLeft and right canard sheared at fuselage. Right wing sheared at fuselage. Both engines sheared at fuselage. Canopy destroyed\u2026.\u201d That doesn\u2019t capture the effect it had on him: Along with a black eye and a dent in his helmet, the crash gave him an existential crisis. For a long time afterward, he panicked on every flight he made.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>\u201cIt took 40 or 50 landings [for the panic to abate] and it took half that to figure out what it was,\u201d he says. \u201cIt was \u2018Oh, you\u2019re about to die.\u2019\u00a0\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Though it\u2019s been a year since the crash, Seguin says it doesn\u2019t seem to have hurt their business. Some at Mojave say they knew all along that modifying the airplane was ill-advised. But that doesn\u2019t mean they\u2019re right. Sometimes a gust just comes, an engine just fails, and you just find yourself headed into a field filled with airliners.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>That\u2019s what bothers Seguin most. \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that there\u2019s a limit to what I can control,\u201d he says. \u201cAnd the other side of that limit is really scary.\u201d</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>But he\u2019s come around to this: He\u2019s glad he smelled what he calls \u201cthe breath of the dragon.\u201d It\u2019s changed him. And he knows that in the face of a monster, he won\u2019t freeze up: He\u2019ll work the problem, always. Even if it means choosing between crashing into an empty 747 or crashing into a trailer.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <p>Soon, he and Gillen plan to put those same turbines on another small airplane\u2014maybe a Cessna\u2014and take a new fire-breather into the skies.</p>\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n  <div class=\"external-associated-products\">\n    <section class=\"article-teaser "<html><body><div><div class=\"main-content\">\n\t<p>I\u2019m often asked how to get started with Distributed Systems, so this post documents my path and some of the resources I found most helpful. \u00a0It is by no means meant to be an exhaustive list.</p>\n<p>It is worth noting that I am not classically trained in Distributed Systems. \u00a0I am mostly self taught via independent study and on the job experience. \u00a0I do have a B.S. in Computer Science from Cornell, but focused mostly on graphics and security in my specialization classes. \u00a0My love of Distributed Systems and education in it came once I entered industry. \u00a0The moral of this story is that understanding distributed systems doesn\u2019t require academic intervention to learn and excel at.</p>\n<h2>Books on Theory &amp; Background</h2>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Reliable-Secure-Distributed-Programming/dp/3642152597/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_14_img_1?_encoding=UTF8&amp;psc=1&amp;refRID=HDFPXW5JSGV2A8DRYZQK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Introduction to Reliable and Secure Distributed Programming</a>: This book is an excellent introduction to the fundamentals of distributed computing. \u00a0It definitely takes an academic approach. \u00a0But is a good place to start to understand the terminology and challenges in the field.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Replication-Practice-Lecture-Computer-Science/dp/3642112935\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Replication: Theory and Practice</a>: This book is a summary of 30 years of distributed systems research on replication up to 2007. \u00a0Its a great starter and contains all the references to the original work. \u00a0Each chapter is incredibly dense, and led me down multiple paper rabbit holes.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2>Papers</h2>\n<p>This is by no means an exhaustive list, but these papers I keep coming back to, and they have significantly shaped the way I think about Distributed Systems.</p>\n\n<h2>A Note on Reading Papers</h2>\n<p>A note on reading papers: I start with the Abstract, if I find in interesting I\u2019ll proceed onto the Introduction, then the Conclusion. \u00a0Only then if I am incredibly interested in the implementation or details will I read the whole thing. \u00a0Also the References are a gold mine, they cite related and foundational work. \u00a0Often times reading papers is a recursive process. \u00a0I\u2019ll start on one then find a concept I\u2019m unfamiliar with or don\u2019t understand, so I\u2019ll read the referenced paper and so on. \u00a0This often times results in going down the paper rabbit holes, and one time resulted in me reading a dissertation from the 1980s but it is a great way to learn.</p>\n<p>I also highly recommend Michael Bernstein\u2019s blog post \u201c<a href=\"http://michaelrbernste.in/2014/10/21/should-i-read-papers.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Should I Read Papers?</a>\u201d for more on the motivations and how to read an academic paper.</p>\n<h2>Blog Posts &amp; Talks</h2>\n<p>Below is a list of some of my favorite blog posts and talks that shaped how I think about building Distributed Systems. \u00a0Most of these are old, but I keep coming back to them, and still find them relevant today.</p>\n\n<h2>Learning from Industry</h2>\n<p>The art of building, operating, and running distributed systems in industry is orthogonal to the theory of Distributed Systems. \u00a0I truly believe that the best way to learn about Distributed Systems is to get hands on experience working on one.</p>\n<p>In addition Post Mortems are another great source of information. \u00a0Large tech companies, like <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/message/65648/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://medium.com/netflix-techblog/lessons-netflix-learned-from-the-aws-outage-deefe5fd0c04\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Netflix</a>, <a href=\"https://status.cloud.google.com/incident/compute/16007\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Google</a>, and <a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/update-on-azure-storage-service-interruption/\">Microsoft</a>, often publish a post mortem after a major outage. \u00a0These are usually pretty dry to read, but contain some hard learned lessons.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p><em>You should follow me on Twitter\u00a0<a title=\"here\" href=\"https://twitter.com/Caitie\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a></em></p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<div id=\"jp-post-flair\" class=\"sharedaddy sd-like-enabled\"><div class=\"sharedaddy sd-block sd-like jetpack-likes-widget-wrapper
