Writing by Dominic Evans; Editing by Daren Butler and Mark Heinrich</p></div></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429687": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:57:18", "url": "https://www.mottocosmos.com/ugly-happy-beauty-ugliness/", "text": "<html><body><div><div><h2>\u201cYou are ugly and you are pretty\u201d.</h2>\n<p>-Who can define <strong>ugliness</strong> and <strong>beauty</strong>?</p>\n<p>-Who has the right to decide where the one conception begins and where the other ends?</p>\n<p>-Why are there <strong>ugly people</strong> and why are you stamping there ones outward?</p>\n<p>A lot of question, which over decades divide into categories and assign to a certain amount of people.</p>\n<p>Are <strong>ugly people</strong> able to lead a <strong>happy life</strong>? The answer is \u2018yes\u2019, or rather \u2018no\u2019?</p>\n<p>When the phrase \u201cugly people are really unhappy\u201d is true, we can talk about the fate of ugliness. Initially, we could say that <strong>beautiful people</strong> have an advantage in each position of life. Whether at school, at work or in their love life, one thing is clear. Attractive people usually have an <strong>easier life</strong>. But who is hiding behind these concepts? It is none less than the whole society.</p>\n<p>Psychologist <a href=\"https://www.google.gr/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=1&amp;cad=rja&amp;uact=8&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiD_sa_jdzWAhUoCcAKHd0UAEsQFggqMAA&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ursula-nuber.de%2F&amp;usg=AOvVaw1ftjBjmGitgxUbXzexsfEo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ursula Nuber</a> writes in her book \u201c<a href=\"https://www.google.gr/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=1&amp;cad=rja&amp;uact=8&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiBgcWyjdzWAhXmA8AKHY-_BaYQFggqMAA&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.de%2FDas-elfte-Gebot-Gelassenheit-meistern%2Fdp%2F3426654938&amp;usg=AOvVaw3kqEhGLC8LUrMGLFOOhbyn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Das 11.Gebot- Mit Gelassenheit das Leben meistern</a>\u201d, that the society is firmly convinced that beautiful people lead a happy life. Thereupon, people and especially young people strive to outward beauty, and think that they have to be beautiful to lead a happy life.</p>\n<p>And indeed, numerous studies prove that <strong>beautiful people</strong> have many <strong>advantages</strong> in their society. An US American psychologist <a href=\"https://www.google.gr/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=4&amp;cad=rja&amp;uact=8&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjr4dDTjdzWAhVEOMAKHb45B44QFghDMAM&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ritafreedman.com%2F&amp;usg=AOvVaw0RZ1s4txSixfc5Oy8-6Vav\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Rita Freedmann</a> explains \u201cMothers react more frequently to their babies when they are pretty.\u201d This means they receive more attention and love, which increases the well-being of their babies.</p>\n<p>But which body structure and which external features make a beautiful person, always depends on the respective society.</p>\n<p>The <strong>beauty</strong> ideals of our present society are long legs, full lips, big breasts, narrow waist, big eyes and a small nose. People who do not have these characteristics are automatically excluded from the \u201cbeauty ones\u201d of the society. On the other hand, it is seems that <strong>ugly people</strong> often look stupid, more unsympathetic, with no self-confidence, uncreative, lonely, listless, dissatisfied, self-dependent and untried. From the very beginning, you feel that ugly people do not have friends, go alone through life and go out less, are generally sad. Also, they have fewer partners and get a job harder.</p>\n<h3>But is this the real life of \u201cugly people\u201d?</h3>\n<p>Surveys have shown that <strong>beautiful people</strong> with more <strong>self-esteem</strong> are more faithful and present with the result to advertise themselves better than ugly people.</p>\n<p>This means at the second eye, that the most important is not the external appearance, but the way we exist and the enormity we practice in various situations in our lives. By saying the above, we have to notice that <strong>ugly people</strong> have to try more to achieve aims and conquer things in their lives than <strong>beautiful people</strong>, who are externally more acceptable in our society. This points to the fact that the reach to a goal with great effort and difficulty and finally success, makes people feel automatically happier than someone who did not bother to do it. Even great names, such as Cleopatra and Maria Felix, may have been<strong> beautiful women</strong> of their time, but they stayed in history not for their beauty but for their intelligence, charisma and <strong>self-confidence</strong>.</p>\n<p>Well or wrongly, no one is the same as the other. We all differ externally and internally. And that\u2019s good. We are different and above all we are unique in this world. Don\u2019t forget that <strong>beautiful people</strong> have also their own complexes. Many of these \u201cbeauties\u201d have nothing to give to society but their beauty. Inside them they are empty and have nothing to offer. You can\u2019t buy charisma and self-confidence, nor beauty.</p>\n<p>The psychologist Alexandra Emm. Vasila said: \u201cOutdoor beauty can\u2019t replace the character, the personality, the behavior, the wit, the talent, the creativity \u2026\u201d Beauty is not the issue, but the way you find to take your interest into someone, the confidence you will transfer, your courtesy, your humor and the intelligence you own. This skill transcends the outer beauty and goes into the love you will initially show to yourself. Love yourself and you will see that those around you will love you too. Nobody is perfect. And if you do not think you are beautiful in your society, remind yourself that you are simply at the wrong society. In another one, you may have been nice, maybe not. It doesn\u2019t matter, because as ugly as you are considered, you may feel so lucky, happy and blessed, because you are not left in his outward appearance. You know that you are not accepted externally. The affect? You try to reveal other features that stand out. And that\u2019s it the point. Anyway, the beauty sometime goes away, but the true inner beauty of human stays.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Ugliness and beauty are strictly related with our character.\u00a0 Read our following article:<a href=\"https://www.mottocosmos.com/egoism-humility-thats-question/\"> Egoism or humility? That\u2019s the question</a></strong></em></p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430201": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 00:52:33", "url": "https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/08/dear-silicon-valley-americas-fallen-out-of-love-with-you/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-entry text\">\n\n\n<img src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-12-29-53-pm.png?w=738\" class=\"\"/>\n<p>\n</p><div class=\"byline contributor-byline\">\n\t\n\n\t\t\t<p class=\"bio\">Ross Baird is the founder and executive director of <a href=\"http://www.vilcap.com/\">Village Capital</a>.</p>\n\t\n\t\t\t<div class=\"more-posts\"><p>\n\t\t\tMore posts by this contributor:\t\t\t</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\n</div>\n\n\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Dear Silicon Valley,\u00a0</span><span lang=\"EN\"><br/></span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">You used to be the envy of the world. Over the last decade I\u2019ve seen countless cities try to become you, from\u00a0<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_technology_centers#Places_with_.22Silicon.22_names\" rel=\"noopener\">the Silicon Savannah to the Silicon Bayou</a>. </span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">At last year\u2019s Global Entrepreneurship Summit on Stanford\u2019s campus, hundreds of entrepreneurs from Mongolia to South Sudan came to listen to President Obama and Mark Zuckerberg and get a touch of your magic fairy dust. The American Dream \u2014 anyone with an idea, a garage and a good work ethic can build a great company \u2014 might as well have been born in your backyard. I admire your innovation, openness, creativity and all you stand for.</span></p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-im\">In case you haven\u2019t noticed, though, you\u2019ve changed from hero to villain. You\u2019re too expensive and exclusive for the rest of the world: The garages that gave us Hewlett-Packard and Google now cost millions of dollars. You\u2019ve moved from icon to joke \u2014 the show that bears your name is a cringe-worthy, true-to-life satire.</span></p>\n<p><span class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-im\"> You\u2019re churning out companies that are raising hundreds of millions of dollars, and going bankrupt in literal satires of themselves: a $700 million blood-testing company that never had any actual results; a $120 million juicer with packets that can actually be squeezed by hand.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Now\u00a0<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/40472189/why-the-publics-love-affair-with-silicon-valley-might-be-over\" rel=\"noopener\">Fast Company is declaring the end of the public\u2019s \u201clove affair\u201d</a>\u00a0with the Silicon Valley ideal, and everyone from socialist Bernie Sanders to hard-right Steve Bannon is calling for your biggest companies to be heavily regulated, and your reputation is fast approaching that of Wall Street (which used to have a good reputation, too).</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Here are a few places that you went wrong \u2014 and what you can do to fix it.</span></p>\n<div id=\"attachment_1496120\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-1496120 size-full\" src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg?w=2000&amp;h=1000\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg 2000w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg?w=150&amp;h=75 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg?w=300&amp;h=150 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg?w=768&amp;h=384 768w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/o-silicon-valley-facebook.jpg?w=680&amp;h=340 680w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2000px) 100vw, 2000px\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Courtesy of HBO and \u201cSilicon Valley\u201d</p></div>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><b><span lang=\"EN\">Your ideas are only as good as the people in the room. And your door is shut to most people.</span></b><b><span lang=\"EN\">\u00a0</span></b></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\">As evidenced by the major backlash over the recent launch of a company called Bodega \u2014 where the founders and investors genuinely didn\u2019t understand why the name was problematic \u2014 you don\u2019t always have the best handle on how your ideas will be received outside of the Silicon Valley bubble. You\u2019ve got major blind spots.</p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Why might this be? Face the facts: When Silicon Valley investors are considering new ideas, you don\u2019t have very many different perspectives around the table. More than 90 percent of the decision-makers in the venture capital industry are white men. </span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">You\u2019ve known this is a problem for a while, but haven\u2019t done anything to fix it: Less than 5 percent of the new ideas that get funding are founded by women, and less than 1 percent of venture funding goes to Latinos and African-Americans.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">You\u2019ve concentrated capital in the hands of a few people (nearly all white guys) who have huge power to determine which people, places and industries get funding. And your decision-makers are often (unintentionally) overlooking ideas that come from people who aren\u2019t like them, which exacerbates gender, racial and geographic divides in our country. Much worse, this financial privilege creates power dynamics that lead to too-frequent cases of <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/08/21/proposed-bill-targets-sexual-harassment-in-venture-capital-industry/\" rel=\"noopener\">investors sexually harassing founders</a> or <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.eater.com/2017/9/13/16302386/bodega-startup-corner-store-silicon-valley\" rel=\"noopener\">tone-deaf ideas like Bodega</a>.<br/></span></p>\n<div id=\"attachment_1511708\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-1511708 \" src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/07/investor-founder-sexual-harassment-policy-newsletter.jpg?w=772&amp;h=434\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/07/investor-founder-sexual-harassment-policy-newsletter.jpg 640w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/07/investor-founder-sexual-harassment-policy-newsletter.jpg?w=150&amp;h=84 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/07/investor-founder-sexual-harassment-policy-newsletter.jpg?w=300&amp;h=169 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 772px) 100vw, 772px\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image courtesy of Bryce Durbin</p></div>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><b><span>Your rainforest of innovation has turned into a factory farm.</span></b></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\">Silicon Valley, perhaps your greatest achievement is that you\u2019ve built a community where the little guy could build a great company to disrupt the establishment. Silicon Valley\u2019s innovation engine has been driven by the creation of iconic companies \u2014 HP, Intel, Apple, Google, Facebook \u2014 that took on bigger competitors.</p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">But that\u2019s changing. In his famous book\u00a0<i>Zero to One</i>, Peter Thiel writes, \u201cCompetition is for losers. Be a monopoly.\u201d And that philosophy has come to prevail \u2014 the average venture capitalist would say that in a portfolio of 20, they are OK with 19 losers and one grand slam. Follow that to its logical conclusion: for every billionaire Peter Thiel, Silicon Valley, you\u2019re OK with 19 broke people. It\u2019s no wonder that inequality is at a 100-year high, entrepreneurial activity is at a 40-year low and eight men control half the world\u2019s wealth.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Over the past 15 years, big has crushed little in Silicon Valley, to an increasing degree. The former giant-slayers like Apple and Google have become giants themselves, shutting out or buying up new entrants.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">The worst of it: you\u2019re even controlling which ideas get out there \u2014 as we saw when Google chairman Eric Schmidt complained to the New America Foundation for criticizing the company\u2019s monopolistic practices.\u00a0<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/30/us/politics/eric-schmidt-google-new-america.html?mcubz=1&amp;_r=0\" rel=\"noopener\">The entire team got fired</a>.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">In short, your present leaders are cannibalizing your future. If a startup is raising money today, one of the first questions they\u2019ll be asked is, \u201cWhat\u2019s your exit strategy?\u201d Specifically, that means, \u201cWhom among Google, Facebook and a few other companies will acquire you?\u201d A few tech giants are dictating which problems founders want to work on, and how we\u2019ll solve them.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">The result? You haven\u2019t produced a new firm that has cracked the world\u2019s top 200 since Facebook\u2019s founding in 2003.</span></p>\n<p><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-1287229 size-full\" src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg?w=5417&amp;h=3750\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg 5417w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg?w=150&amp;h=104 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg?w=300&amp;h=208 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg?w=768&amp;h=532 768w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/ouroborous.jpg?w=680&amp;h=471 680w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 5417px) 100vw, 5417px\"/></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><b><span>Your insulation makes tomorrow\u2019s problems harder to solve.</span></b></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Your leaders are increasingly coming from a narrower group of universities, companies and socioeconomic classes. Your companies are now solving \u201cmy-world problems\u201d (food delivery, cold-pressed on-demand juice) versus the \u201creal-world problems\u201d you used to solve (getting affordable computers in the hands of everyone; inventing the internet). Your solutions literally create the script for a satire show on HBO \u2014 and you don\u2019t see what a big problem it is.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">And because of the first problem \u2014 the lack of new ideas in the room \u2014 you don\u2019t know how to solve this. Your best idea for social inequality: universal basic income, where the wealth of the billionaires will continue to grow, but don\u2019t worry, the rest of the serfs (who are otherwise unable to do any work!) will receive a daily stipend. </span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">To you, in the words of one Silicon Valley investor, this seems like \u201cthe only logical conclusion.\u201d To the average person, this seems like the height of arrogance. People are uncomfortable with universal basic income because you\u2019re essentially saying their labor isn\u2019t worth anything \u2014 but you don\u2019t see it!</span></p>\n<div id=\"attachment_1426325\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-1426325 size-full\" src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png?w=2560&amp;h=1440\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png 2560w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png?w=150&amp;h=84 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png?w=300&amp;h=169 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png?w=768&amp;h=432 768w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/robot-blinders-alt.png?w=680&amp;h=383 680w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2560px) 100vw, 2560px\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image courtesy of Bryce Durbin</p></div>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span><b>So, what can you do about it?</b><b>\u00a0</b></span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Maybe I was a little harsh on you when I said you didn\u2019t see any of this happening: We\u2019ve seen the beginnings of conversations around diversity and inclusion, and mea culpas have recently been flying out of your board rooms as fast as rejection e-mails.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">So now that you\u2019re paying attention, what can you do? Here are a few ideas:</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><b>Put as much attention into finding founders as you do deal flow.</b><span lang=\"EN\">\u00a0Your leaders talk a lot about investing in diverse companies; well, that won\u2019t be easy unless you invest in the infrastructure to find them. We spend billions of dollars to make sure that the best high school and college athletes have their shot at the pros; why don\u2019t we do the same for entrepreneurs? Instead of asking entrepreneurs for a \u201cwarm introduction,\u201d build technology that actively encourages cold calls and outreach from founders \u2014 and can help them. </span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><span lang=\"EN\">(I\u2019m particularly inspired by a firm, Backstage Capital, that intentionally invests in what founder Arlan Hamilton calls under-estimated founders; one of their metrics of success is the percentage of cold-emails that they fund.)</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><b>Create conditions for the little guy to thrive.</b><span lang=\"EN\">\u00a0Think about\u00a0<i>how</i>\u00a0you invest as well as\u00a0<i>what</i>\u00a0you invest in. There\u2019s a real problem with equity investing as a one-size-fits-all model in Silicon Valley; explore alternate models like revenue-sharing, which encourages companies to build for lasting success, not acquisition (<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://medium.com/village-capital/why-an-equity-only-investment-strategy-overlooks-many-promising-entrepreneurs-ec5f69bd104c\" rel=\"noopener\">more on that here</a>). Or make sure that your unprecedented prosperity is actually shared among the employees. From New Belgium Brewing to Chobani, there are stories across the country of billion-dollar unicorns where employee ownership is shared broadly, helping janitors and factory workers create wealth alongside management.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><b>Recognize that business and society are together \u2014 not in separate worlds.</b><span lang=\"EN\">\u00a0You\u2019re full of incredibly generous philanthropists. But the market value of just two companies \u2014 Google and Facebook \u2014 is more than all the charitable foundations in the world. You need to help lead society in your day job, not just at fundraisers and thought leadership conferences. For all the lip service that Silicon Valley has given to \u201cchanging the world,\u201d when ProPublica tried to buy targeted ads for \u201cJew haters,\u201d Facebook didn\u2019t question whether this was good, or right \u2014 they asked them how they\u2019d like to pay for it.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><span lang=\"EN\">You own the platforms that dominate consumer behavior, and the data that can determine people\u2019s retirements, relationships and decisions \u2014 you need to ask \u201cis this the right thing to do?\u201d as often as you ask \u201cwhat is monetizable?\u201d How can you help small businesses and entrepreneurs thrive as much as they used to 40 years ago? How can you help local journalists keep citizens informed and governments accountable? You\u2019ve connected society \u2014 how can you help us be more resilient and sustainable in the face of a dramatically shifting climate?</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1CxSpMiddle\"><span lang=\"EN\">I\u2019m encouraged by some early steps. Facebook, for example, is launching a pilot to help local journalism (though I\u2019d go a hundred times further and enable success for all kinds of local businesses). PayPal has used its massive platform and data advantage to lend an incredible $2 billion to small businesses in the last two years \u2014 more than most banks. But that\u2019s just a tiny fraction of the talent and resources in the Valley.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\"><span lang=\"EN\">Silicon Valley, there\u2019s still time to regain your image as a positive force in America and the world. Just don\u2019t wait until it\u2019s too late.</span></p>\n<p class=\"m_8682927492432925989gmail-m_-8653187843881757139gmail-m_-1724516925904706591m_-3482983802917832813gmail-Normal1\">\n</p>\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430714": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:06:43", "url": "https://ramblingspace.com/posts/on-building-a-new-world/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry-content\">\n\t\t<p>With a new unicorn popping up seemingly every other week, it\u2019s easy to forget that the new behemoths that shape our lives, the technology firms, existed more than a few years. Behind the shiny veneer, however, there is a rich history of how this world came about to be. And just like any other history, it\u2019s one that keeps repeating itself.</p>\n<p>The latest iteration of the history, though, is not its finest one. Nazis are back.</p>\n<p>A quick recap.\u00a0The informed citizens of the greatest country on earth have collectively voted to elect a white supremacist sympathizer, with <a href=\"http://www.thedailybeast.com/palmer-luckey-the-facebook-near-billionaire-secretly-funding-trumps-meme-machine\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">overt</a>, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/facebook-says-it-sold-political-ads-to-russian-company-during-2016-election/2017/09/06/32f01fd2-931e-11e7-89fa-bb822a46da5b_story.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">covert</a>, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/fashion/peter-thiel-donald-trump-silicon-valley-technology-gawker.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">voluntary</a>, and <a href=\"http://nymag.com/selectall/2016/11/donald-trump-won-because-of-facebook.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">involuntary</a> help of practically every tech company and its acolytes. By the time we all woke up to what we did, it was too late; the Nazis were emboldened, chanting in the streets of Virginia, among many places. Then a <a href=\"https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/08/cloudflare-ceo-the-people-behind-the-daily-stormer-are-assholes/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">guy woke up</a>, literally, and decided to kick the Nazis off the internet, until they find a new home.</p>\n<figure>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cI woke up this morning in a bad mood and decided to kick them off the Internet.\u201d</p></blockquote><figcaption class=\"source\">\u2014 Matthew Prince, Cloudflare CEO</figcaption></figure>\n<p>For some observers of the technology, this latest kerfuffle might just be a new chapter in the upcoming book by a Vanity Fair writer. For those a bit more in the know, they would note that the Nazis (a word I am using as a short for white supremacists), never really left the internet. They practically populated the every platform you did; they were on newsgroups, mailing lists, 4chan, reddit, Facebook, Twitter, and probably still are.</p>\n<p>But, go down a bit farther back in the Wayback Machine, and it\u2019s easy to remember that Nazis and some part of their history was on the internet as far as 2000s, and it points to one of the most interesting tensions of the Internet with capital I; the constant tension between the borderlessness of it, yet the levers of it being controlled just a few. This is subject of this essay; how the current gatekeepers of the internet\u2019s aims to create a new type of statelessness state is just a clumsy reiteration of past attempts.</p>\n<figure>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cYour legal concepts of property, expression, identity, movement, and context do not apply to us. They are all based on matter, and there is no matter here.\u201d</p></blockquote><figcaption class=\"source\">\u2014 John Perry Barlow, EFF CO-Founder</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The aspirational extraterrestrial culture of the internet is a messy and deep subject but the \u201c<a href=\"https://www.eff.org/cyberspace-independence\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Declaration of Independence of Cyberspace</a>\u201d is a good start. Penned by John Perry Barlow, one of the founders of Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), at a World Economic Forum, the declaration pulls no punches. In fact, more than just statelessness, you can hear the subtext of cyberspace being not just an international entity but almost an supranational one. It is a good read, both as a way to understand the libertarian thinking of early residents of the cyberspace and also as a Marxist approach to how zero marginal cost of production of technology changes the entire dynamics of economy and of course societies. It is also remarkably prescient, not necessarily in the types of world early adopters would eventually create but the conflicts they would face.</p>\n<p>Scroll your way up to 2000. Not just to the days Before iPhone or Before Facebook but <em>Before Google</em>. In 2000, a French human-rights organization discovers that Yahoo, on its auction platform, allows sale of Nazi and Third Reich memorabilia. While still not tasteful and unpresidential at the time, such activity was not illegal under US law, but quite so under French law. In what\u2019s considered a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LICRA_v._Yahoo!\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">landmark case</a>, French court eventually ordered Yahoo to not just pull such items from its French store (fr.yahoo.com) but also make the items in the US store inaccessible in France.</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.ramblingspace.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/3740159059_da82c90772_o.jpg?w=525&amp;ssl=1\" alt=\"Front page of the internet, 2000\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"/> Front page of the internet, 2000</p>\n<p>The entire <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2000/nov/20/internetnews.freespeech\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">discourse around the case</a> is extremely fascinating, and some of the statements from both sides have a very timeless quality. To an American audience, where only freedom of speech is more paramount to right to carry a firearm, an interference by a French court of all courts, is an international overreach of unseen proportions. However, this analysis misses the continent-wide trauma Europeans experienced with Nazism in 1940s. While America has its fair share of World War 2 scars, it pales in comparison to the destruction Europe endured. This suffering was so profound, so widespread and so deep, and Nazism such a vile idea that the entire continent\u2019s new identity, European Union is largely built around this reaction.</p>\n<p>It is worth pulling out a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2000/aug/11/qanda.simonjeffery\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">few quotes here</a> especially, just to see how prescient some of the predictions from the French philosophers are. Mark Knoebel, the French activist whose letters sparked the entire shebang says that American internet is becoming a \u201cdumping ground\u201d for racists all over.</p>\n<p>Any discussion of censorship on the internet would be amiss without bringing up everyone\u2019s once-favorite liberal reformer turned autocrat strongmen Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey. Even as far back as 2008, just 4 years after Google\u2019s IPO, the Turkish government was in cahoots with YouTube over a couple of videos making fun of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkish Republic. In what would become the norm for Turkish government (or already was, depending on your ethnicity in Turkey), the state decided to block YouTube entirely, and demand the videos be taken down. The case went on for literally years, during which time YouTube stayed blocked in Turkey for almost two years. <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2008/08/17/web-censorship-is-so-bad-in-turkey-that-blogs-are-shutting-themselves-down-in-protest/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Turkish bloggers took the matters to their hands</a>, where they shut down their own sites to protest the government\u2019s block. However, the block itself was so ham-fisted that even the then Prime Minister Erdogan himself mentioned that \u201ceveryone knows how to access YouTube\u201d.</p>\n<figure>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cI think the Decider model is an inconsistent model because the Internet is big and Google isn\u2019t the only one making the decisions\u201d</p></blockquote><figcaption class=\"source\">\u2014 Nicole Wong, Google</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Still, the details of this 2008 already signals the awkward situations tech companies would themselves with government.\u00a0Impossible to imagine now, though,\u00a0Google employees felt comfortable jokingly calling themselves <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/30/magazine/30google-t.html\">\u201cThe Decider</a>\u201d with a New York Times journalist in the room. The employees in charge, many with law degrees, were aware of their power, felt obviously uncomfortable with the levers they held, but, in the end they held on to them.</p>\n<p>A common theme that underlies most of the Silicon Valley thinking is that computers, internet and associated technologies changes everything; from mode of production to distribution to how information is generated to how it is disseminated.\u00a0No incumbent is too big to not upend, no industry without with inefficiencies a couple of scripts can eliminate. A common complaint of the less-STEM focused side of the world, then is that Silicon Valley\u2019s casual disregard for the history and the rules of the world is bordering on recklessness.</p>\n<p>This is largely a political argument, which means it\u2019s an <em>everything</em> argument, but the singular point is that sometimes the Internet company\u2019s casual disregard for history is not just hurtful for the entire world, but also for themselves (a statement whose irony is quite obvious to yours truly).</p>\n<p>Silicon Valley companies love to invoke <a href=\"http://opentranscripts.org/transcript/beyond-legal-talismans/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">legal talismans</a>, a phrase (I think) coined by <a href=\"https://kendraalbert.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Kendra Albert</a>. In short, they love to evoke feelings of a legal proceeding, such as a due process, where there is none, to mostly justify their own decision making. But sometimes, such invocations are just symptoms of delusions of grandeur and they do come with consequences for everyone, as mentioned, including the companies themselves.</p>\n<p>Consider the time Twitter UK General Manager called Twitter not just a bastion of free speech but the \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/mar/22/twitter-tony-wang-free-speech\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">free speech wing of the free speech party</a>\u201d in 2012 and try not to cringe. But you can definitely see a direct line from the EFF declaration to such an inane statement. A new world is being born, called the cyberspace (as opposed to what, meatspace?) and the rules are written by whoever is creating this world. Considering the current situation Twitter find itself in right now, with user growth barely chugging along, a stock hugely under its IPO levels, its value possibly <a href=\"http://fortune.com/2017/08/17/trump-worth-to-twitter/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">held up significantly</a> by an orange White House resident, it\u2019s hard to imagine Twitter would be behaving the same way if they had a better understanding of the nuances of free speech laws, and how it protects people from state because, unlike corporations, state is allowed to jail and sometimes, kill, its people.</p>\n<figure>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cThat means more than one-sixteenth of the average user\u2019s waking time is spent on Facebook\u201d</p></blockquote>\n</figure>\n<p>Of course, this aspirational statelessness of guardians of the cyberspace does go the other way too. It\u2019s easy to write off your overzealous application of freedom of speech as a mistake, \u00a0but harder to do, when you do the opposite. When a tech company counts \u00a0\u2153 of the world\u2019s population as its users (and <a href=\"http://www.pewinternet.org/2016/11/11/social-media-update-2016/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">80% of online Americans</a>), and those users spend a <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/06/business/facebook-bends-the-rules-of-audience-engagement-to-its-advantage.html?mcubz=1&amp;_r=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">considerable amount of their waking moments</a> looking at things pushed on to them by that company, it\u2019s practically impossible to for a one-in-a-million event to not happen with exceeding frequency when you are dealing with billions.</p>\n<p>Probably one of the more eye-opening cases of this American overreach into cultures involves bodies, or more specifically naked ones. For Americans, a sight of a covered breast at a sporting event is a cause of national debate, but for many Northern Europeans, nudity is just another state of undress, as normal as any other. Especially so, when it is presented in a historical, artistic or just non-sexualized context. And even more especially so, when it is the Conservative Norwegian Prime Minister who happens to share a Pulitzer-prize winning photo. Is Facebook, run largely by a bunch of white men in America, not making cultural statements about an unashamedly progressive country?</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.ramblingspace.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/napalm-girl-88f02cbaad205d1edf5f19e683c39e6cb4df9c3c-s700-c85.jpg?w=525&amp;ssl=1\" alt=\"Banned in California\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"/> Banned in California</p>\n<p>It is easy to write off these high profile instances as simple mistakes, and having worked in a similar user-generated content site before, it is mind-blowing to me that Facebook is as free of spam as it is. But what does that mean when these types of \u00a0incidents happen so often that you slowly start shifting values of other cultures to your own, which whether you like it or not, were shaped by your own American upbringing? One cannot just create a culture in such a transactional manner.</p>\n<p>It is one thing, as an academic exercise to imagine a world without governments, a libertarian paradise.\u00a0And if someone wants to take his academic exercise to the <a href=\"https://www.seasteading.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">seas</a> or to other planets, it is only within their rights to do so.</p>\n<p>But for a generation that wants to eventually not just govern the cyberspace but also one of the most <a href=\"https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2017/05/15/sam-altman-may-run-for-california-governor.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">important states in the world</a>, the utter clumsiness of the entire enterprise should give one a pause. A common joke in Silicon Valley, the place about the Silicon Valley, the hit HBO show is that many of the absurd plot twists in the series is really toned down to be believable to the general public.</p>\n<p>Consider the case of Reddit. When a bunch of celebrity\u2019s iCloud accounts got hacked and their private photos were posted on the site, the company decided, reasonably, to remove that content. But in doing so, the CEO of the company said that they were <a href=\"https://redditblog.com/2014/09/06/every-man-is-responsible-for-his-own-soul/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">considering reddit</a> not just a private company, but \u201ca government for a new type of community\u201d. He even went to describe how he sees the actions by the moderators akin to law enforcement officers. But, how do you reconcile such great ambition with the fact that your CEO, or president, resigns from the government because of a <a href=\"http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2014/11/14/reddit_ceo_resigns_why_didn_t_reddit_want_to_move_to_daly_city.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">seating arrangement</a> issue? (Disclaimer: I worked at a Reddit competitor briefly, around 7 years ago, partly because I was and still am quite interested in the space. I even wore a Reddit t-shirt when they came to visit us)</p>\n<figure>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cWe consider ourselves not just a company running a website where one can post links and discuss them, but the government of a new type of community\u201d</p></blockquote><figcaption class=\"source\">\u2014 Yishan Wong, Former Reddit CEO</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Building a new world, one that is more just, more humane, one that is safer, cleaner, more efficient all great goals. When I decided to study computer science in 2005, my main motivation was similar. I grew up in a town in Turkey where I didn\u2019t always fit in and it was through the internet where I could see more of the world easily enough and find people that I could connect with, on many levels. I wanted to extend that world, which seemed reasonably better than the one I lived in, more to the real world.</p>\n<p>And personal politics matter too.\u00a0As an immigrant to US, unlike most of my more left-leaning friends, I find the idea of statelessness, or a post-nation-state world an experiment that humanity owes itself to try. While the supranational organizations such as the EU and World Trade Organization do have their flaws and globalization comes with this unsettling feeling of homogeneity, I stay largely optimistic that as a species, we are better off in a more integrated society.</p>\n<p>However, that does not mean I advocate for a world where we outsource our thinking, our values, our cultures, our judicial decisions and certainly not our free press wholesale to a small number of people, who are unelected, unvetted, and largely unaccountable.</p>\n<p>What I would like to see, however is less of the reckless attitude but a more thoughtful approach. An informed, inclusive, global debate about the kind of digital world we can create together. One that learns from our previous mistakes, and does better.\u00a0Time for this discussion is running out, and we have repeated our mistakes enough times. We need to do better now.</p>\n\n<p id=\"jp-relatedposts\" class=\"jp-relatedposts\">\n\t<h3 class=\"jp-relatedposts-headline\"><em>Related</em></h3>\n</p>\t</div>\n\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15431233": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:38:53", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NH1Tta7purM&feature=youtu.be", "text": "<html><body><div><div id=\"watch-description-text\" class=\"\"><p id=\"eow-description\" class=\"\"><a href=\"/redirect?q=http%3A%2F%2FCppCon.org&amp;redir_token=fs9k9mUx6BUs1tuFHOwsCwFT2rp8MTUwNzY4MTk0MkAxNTA3NTk1NTQy&amp;event=video_description&amp;v=NH1Tta7purM\" class=\"yt-uix-sessionlink  \" data-target-new-window=\"True\" data-url=\"/redirect?q=http%3A%2F%2FCppCon.org&amp;redir_token=fs9k9mUx6BUs1tuFHOwsCwFT2rp8MTUwNzY4MTk0MkAxNTA3NTk1NTQy&amp;event=video_description&amp;v=NH1Tta7purM\" data-sessionlink=\"itct=CDAQ6TgYACITCJKylIbn5NYCFVDAHQodtqYHKCj4HUiz9ab32vbUvjQ\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">http://CppCon.org</a><br/>\u2014<br/>Presentation Slides, PDFs, Source Code and other presenter materials are available at: <a href=\"/redirect?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FCppCon%2FCppCon2017&amp;redir_token=fs9k9mUx6BUs1tuFHOwsCwFT2rp8MTUwNzY4MTk0MkAxNTA3NTk1NTQy&amp;event=video_description&amp;v=NH1Tta7purM\" class=\"yt-uix-sessionlink  \" data-target-new-window=\"True\" data-url=\"/redirect?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FCppCon%2FCppCon2017&amp;redir_token=fs9k9mUx6BUs1tuFHOwsCwFT2rp8MTUwNzY4MTk0MkAxNTA3NTk1NTQy&amp;event=video_description&amp;v=NH1Tta7purM\" data-sessionlink=\"itct=CDAQ6TgYACITCJKylIbn5NYCFVDAHQodtqYHKCj4HUiz9ab32vbUvjQ\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/CppCon/CppCon2017</a><br/>\u2014<br/>Automated trading involves submitting electronic orders rapidly when opportunities arise. But it\u2019s harder than it seems: either your system is the fastest and you make the trade, or you get nothing. <br/><br/>This is a considerable challenge for any C++ developer - the critical path is only a fraction of the total codebase, it is invoked infrequently and unpredictably, yet must execute quickly and without delay. Unfortunately we can\u2019t rely on the help of compilers, operating systems and standard hardware, as they typically aim for maximum throughput and fairness across all processes. <br/><br/>This talk describes how successful low latency trading systems can be developed in C++, demonstrating common coding techniques used to reduce execution times. While automated trading is used as the motivation for this talk, the topics discussed are equally valid to other domains such as game development and soft real-time processing.<br/>\u2014 <br/>Carl Cook: Optiver, Software Engineer<br/><br/>Carl has a Ph.D. from the University of Canterbury, New Zealand, graduating in 2006.
