Editing by Sandra Maler</p></div></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429708": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:02:08", "url": "https://medium.com/@nathankpeck/microservice-testing-unit-tests-d795194fe14e", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><h1 name=\"0f25\" id=\"0f25\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf--leading graf--title\">Microservice Testing: Unit\u00a0Tests</h1><h2 name=\"4695\" id=\"4695\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--h3 graf--subtitle\">How to build and use unit tests for distributed systems</h2><p name=\"4a5e\" id=\"4a5e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">The <a href=\"https://medium.com/@nathankpeck/microservice-testing-introduction-347d2f74095e\" data-href=\"https://medium.com/@nathankpeck/microservice-testing-introduction-347d2f74095e\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" target=\"_blank\">previous article</a> introduced the test pyramid, and some of the basics of how to apply it to a distributed system:</p><figure name=\"1572\" id=\"1572\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"0c46\" id=\"0c46\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">This article zooms in on the unit test layer of the testing pyramid and explores ways to build effective unit tests for distributed systems such as microservice deployments.</p><h3 name=\"4afa\" id=\"4afa\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Identify the Test Boundaries</h3><p name=\"a8c1\" id=\"a8c1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">For any test to be effective you first have to find the boundaries of that test. The goal of the test is to verify all behavior inside the \u201cblack box\u201d of the test boundaries by manipulating the inputs to the black box, and verifying that the correct output is produced by the black box for each set of inputs.</p><p name=\"161d\" id=\"161d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In a unit test the black box that is being tested is a function or class method. The goal is to test the behavior of that specific block of code in isolation. To understand how this works consider a basic user signup function:</p><figure name=\"251b\" id=\"251b\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"d052\" id=\"d052\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">There are some obvious input and outputs to this function. The black box of the function accepts basic user signup details as parameter inputs, and it returns outputs such as the ID of the newly created user.</p><p name=\"e819\" id=\"e819\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">But there are also some less obvious inputs to this function. The function makes two external function calls: one call to a database to insert a record, and one call to a class that is responsible for password hashing and persistence. Under some conditions the database insert condition may return an error back into the user signup function. For example maybe there is a constraint that username must be unique and the database insert fails because the username is already taken. Or perhaps the password interface is a thin wrapper around an external password microservice, and behind the scenes it makes a network call. If there was a connectivity issue or the password service was overloaded and timed out it could cause that password function to return an error.</p><p name=\"bb4f\" id=\"bb4f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In order to fully test the behavior of the user signup function a unit test needs to do more than just pass different user signup parameters. It also needs to reproduce the inputs that external dependencies may introduce in order to verify that this function behaves appropriately based on those inputs as well. This especially important when it comes to testing the error handling of a function.</p><h3 name=\"4f3c\" id=\"4f3c\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Test Stubs &amp;\u00a0Mocks</h3><p name=\"1e44\" id=\"1e44\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">In order to reproduce input conditions that come from side effects it is necessary to implement function stubs, also called mocks. This can be done using dependency injection or method swizzling. Both techniques allow a test framework to execute a tested function while ensuring that any calls out to an underlying function dependency are redirected to a different function that is a stub used for testing:</p><figure name=\"1098\" id=\"1098\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"eb18\" id=\"eb18\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The function stub can be used to do a number of different things:</p><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"8ac2\" id=\"8ac2\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">The stub can be setup to do nothing. This is a way to speed up the execution of a particular unit test by disabling the side effects of the tested function, especially if those side effects will be tested by another dedicated unit test that runs later.</li><li name=\"90e7\" id=\"90e7\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">The stub can be used to return arbitrary values to simulate responses from external functions. This is useful for testing function behavior under conditions that may be hard to replicate, such as code that handles error conditions that rarely occur or are hard to reproduce.</li><li name=\"25ee\" id=\"25ee\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">The stub can be used to capture parameters that the function attempted to pass to an external function, or just record the fact that the call was made to an external function. This allows the unit test to verify expectations about what external calls the function should have attempted to make, and what parameters should have been passed.</li></ul><p name=\"e5f8\" id=\"e5f8\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--li\">Having good stubs is essential for unit testing a distributed system because it allows unit tests to be run while disabling or simulating any external interactions with other services. Here is a list of tools that can be used to help you develop stubs in various runtime languages:</p><h4 name=\"b6a8\" id=\"b6a8\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Node.js / JavaScript</h4><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"db08\" id=\"db08\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--h4\"><a href=\"http://sinonjs.org/\" data-href=\"http://sinonjs.org/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">sinon.js</a> (Supplies both stub and spy functionality that makes it easy to build test assertions)</li><li name=\"427c\" id=\"427c\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\"><a href=\"https://github.com/testdouble/testdouble.js\" data-href=\"https://github.com/testdouble/testdouble.js\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">testdouble.js</a> (Stub generator with a focus on expressive object oriented API)</li><li name=\"0c07\" id=\"0c07\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\"><a href=\"https://github.com/node-nock/nock\" data-href=\"https://github.com/node-nock/nock\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--li-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">nock</a> (A library that is focused on making it easy to stub out HTTP request behavior)</li></ul><h4 name=\"3a84\" id=\"3a84\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--li\">Python</h4><h4 name=\"d1e4\" id=\"d1e4\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--li\">Go</h4><h4 name=\"4d24\" id=\"4d24\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--li\">Java</h4><p name=\"2286\" id=\"2286\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--li\">If you have more suggestions for test stub / mock frameworks to add to this list please comment below this article, and I\u2019ll add on to the list.</p><h3 name=\"5486\" id=\"5486\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Unit Test\u00a0Workflow</h3><p name=\"165f\" id=\"165f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">The goal of unit tests is to give developers a way to rapidly verify the behavior of their code in between edits. Because the unit test are just making function calls to exercise logic flows while all external dependencies are stubbed out it is common to be able to execute and verify thousands of unit tests within a few seconds. The speed of these tests allows developers to run tests as part of their coding workflow, either directly integrated into their IDE, or by having a terminal to the side of their editor. By frequently rerunning the unit tests while editing code developers are able to identify potential issues before they even finish writing the code.</p><p name=\"c056\" id=\"c056\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Once developers are in the habit of running and rerunning tests as they write code it is a small step up to test driven development. In this strategy developers actually write new test expectations prior to writing a new feature. The new test fails initially, until the new feature is added. The full functionality of the feature is built up as a process of repeatedly adding a failing test, then adding new feature code, then rerunning the failing test to verify that it now passes.</p><p name=\"24ba\" id=\"24ba\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The role of unit tests goes beyond code development. They should also be integrated into the code merge process. Github supports status checks that work with all mainstream continuous integration servers. A common process is to make the \u201cmaster\u201d branch of your git repository a protected branch. Developers can\u2019t commit directly to the master branch. Instead they make working commits on a feature branch forked from master. When it comes time to merge the feature branch back into the master branch Github can require that status checks pass before code can be merged.</p><p name=\"af1f\" id=\"af1f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The status checks are hooked up to providers such as <a href=\"https://jenkins.io/\" data-href=\"https://jenkins.io/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Jenkins</a>, <a href=\"https://circleci.com/\" data-href=\"https://circleci.com/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">CircleCI</a>, or <a href=\"https://travis-ci.org/\" data-href=\"https://travis-ci.org/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">TravisCI</a>, which take the code from that branch and run unit tests against it. If status checks succeed then merging is enabled, but if status checks fail Github will not allow the failing branch to be merged.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429035": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 20:20:55", "url": "https://aiimpacts.org/2016-expert-survey-on-progress-in-ai/", "text": "<body id=\"readabilityBody\">&#13;\n<center><h1>403 Forbidden</h1></center>&#13;\n<hr/><center>nginx</center>&#13;\n</body>&#13;\n"}, "15431246": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:42:12", "url": "https://thenextweb.com/artificial-intelligence/2017/10/06/1082787/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-body fb-quotable u-m-3\">\n                            <p>Sometimes you run into an idea that seems so ridiculous, you simply have to know more about it \u2013 even if it\u2019s just to scoff at idiocy. In most cases, thankfully, that\u2019s where it ends. But in some rare cases, crazy ideas follow a different curve. Allow me to sketch it out:</p>\n<p><figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1082796 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" data-src=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph.png\" data-srcset=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph.png 1024w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph-280x164.png 280w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph-460x270.png 460w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph-230x135.png 230w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Graph-796x467.png 796w\"/></figure></p>\n<p id=\"spotxvideo\"/>\n<p>I\u2019m quite obviously no designer, but the y-axis of this graph represents brilliance, the x-axis ridiculousness. Now, on the far left, you\u2019ll notice the curve approaching a horizontal asymptote at 0 \u2013 an idea always has a sliver of ridiculousness, just stemming from the fact that we can think of ideas at all.</p>\n<p>Moving away from there, ideas become less brilliant as they become more ridiculous \u2013 up to a certain inflection point, where perceived ridiculousness can suddenly turn into brilliance.</p>\n<p>I digress.</p>\n<p>In a recent email announcing the winners of the Dutch Accenture Innovation Awards, which I opened out of sheer post-lunch boredom, the first entry under the category \u2018Perfect Cities\u2019 was a startup called Crowbar (Crowded Cities). The description read: \u2018A smart machine that trains crows to pick up cigarette butts from the street.\u2019 Right, I thought.</p>\n<p>But then I thought more.</p>\n<p>I thought of this:</p>\n<p/>\n<p>And this:</p>\n<p/>\n<p>And opened the link.</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.crowdedcities.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Crowded Cities</a> started more or less on a lark. Industrial designers Ruben van der Vleuten and Bob Spikman came up with the idea when they noticed the tremendous amount of cigarette butts around them in a park in Amsterdam \u2013 and started theorizing a solution.</p>\n<p>The most obvious answer was robots, but neither of them thought it would be very elegant to pull off the complex programming needed to vacuum up butts in-between bike wheels and other city nooks and crannies. So they turned their attention to birds.</p>\n<p>\u201cFirst we thought of pigeons,\u201d Ruben tells me in their design studio in the center of Amsterdam, \u201cwhich would have been great because there are so many of them in cities.\u201d Unfortunately, a quick search revealed that there was not much known about the intelligence of pigeons, and that training them would be hard.</p>\n<p>Luckily there\u2019s another type of bird that loves living near humans and possesses the ability to problem-solve and learn autonomously. I can try to stretch this, but you know I\u2019m talking about crows.</p>\n<p>For those who are not aware of the wonderful intelligence the corvid family possesses: I envy you. You have an incredible <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HWXe7Js6GnI\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">YouTube journey</a> ahead of you.</p>\n<p>For those marginally aware: Most of what you\u2019ve heard is true. Crows are currently ranked among the most intelligent species on the planet, with an encephalization quotient (fancy word for smarts) equal to that of chimpanzees.</p>\n<p>Thanks to their understanding of causality, crows can conceptualize, create, and use tools. They play, learn from each other, and can manipulate humans into helping them out. Some types of crows can even count. No joke.</p>\n<p>\u201cThen we bumped into this project by a guy named Joshua Klein, and everything clicked,\u201d Ruben tells me.</p>\n<figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-1082799 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" data-src=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg.jpg\" data-srcset=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg.jpg 1024w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-280x210.jpg 280w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-360x270.jpg 360w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-180x135.jpg 180w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-796x597.jpg 796w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-368x276.jpg 368w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-736x552.jpg 736w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-632x474.jpg 632w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/kit_lg-536x402.jpg 536w\"/><figcaption>Credit: <a href=\"http://www.thecrowbox.com/\" target=\"_blank\">The Crow Box</a></figcaption><figcaption><a href=\"#\" data-url=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fthenextweb.com%2Fartificial-intelligence%2F2017%2F10%2F06%2F1082787%2F&amp;via=thenextweb&amp;related=thenextweb&amp;text=Check out this picture on: The Crow Box by Joshua Klein\" data-title=\"Share The Crow Box by Joshua Klein on Twitter\" data-width=\"685\" data-height=\"500\" class=\"post-image-share popitup\" title=\"Share The Crow Box by Joshua Klein on Twitter\"><i class=\"icon icon--inline icon--twitter--dark\"/></a>The Crow Box by Joshua Klein</figcaption></figure><p>Joshua Klein is creator of the <a href=\"http://www.thecrowbox.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Crow Box</a>, an open source project that\u2019s basically a vending machine for crows. The machine is designed to autonomously train crows to pick up change and bring it back in exchange for peanuts.</p>\n<p>\u201cAnd if they can do that, we thought they could also pick up butts,\u201d Bob tells me. But why butts? Well, look around you if you\u2019re outside: You\u2019ll see them everywhere. Estimates say that of the 6 trillion cigarettes we puff away every year, around two-thirds end up in the environment.</p>\n<p>That\u2019s approximately four trillion butts containing all the fine carcinogens, nicotine and toxins found in cigarettes that end up in some form of nature. To put that into a very clich\u00e9d perspective, those are enough butts to fill 2.5 million Olympic swimming pools. Added up, they weigh slightly less than the weight of two of these babies:</p>\n<p><figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1082798 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1234px) 100vw, 1234px\" data-src=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063.jpg\" data-srcset=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063.jpg 1234w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063-280x186.jpg 280w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063-406x270.jpg 406w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063-203x135.jpg 203w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063-796x529.jpg 796w\"/><figcaption>Credit: <a href=\"https://allseas.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/02-Gallery_2014-1129-PS-Singapore-anchorage-b-1600x1063.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">Allseas</a></figcaption></figure></p>\n<p>Summarizing: Cigarette butts are a serious problem. A problem that could be addressed with the Crow Bar.</p>\n<p>\u201cWhat you want is that the crows associate food with butts,\u201d Ruben explains. To achieve this, the machine follows Klein\u2019s <a href=\"http://www.josh.is/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/crows_JoshKlein.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">tried and simple four-step process</a> to train crows.</p>\n<p>The first step presents the crow with food and a butt on a tray in the machine. The food is always there, next to the butt, so the crow learns to come back for more.</p>\n<p>The second step takes away the food, and only drops it just after the crow arrives. \u201cSo the crow gets used to the machine doing things,\u201d Bob says.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe third step is crucial,\u201d they tell me. In this step, the food is completely removed, leaving only the butt on the tray. The crow, used to getting food only for being there, will start to nose (beak?) around, eventually knocking the butt off the tray into the butt receptacle. The food drops when that happens.</p>\n<p><figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1082801 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1093px) 100vw, 1093px\" data-src=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801.jpg\" data-srcset=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801.jpg 1093w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-280x210.jpg 280w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-360x270.jpg 360w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-180x135.jpg 180w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-796x597.jpg 796w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-368x276.jpg 368w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-736x552.jpg 736w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-1044x783.jpg 1044w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-632x474.jpg 632w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170622_203801-536x402.jpg 536w\"/></figure></p>\n<p>This step is repeated until the crow learns to associate dropping the butt with getting food.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe fourth step is the only step where humans are involved. When the crow is comfortable with step 3, a person scatters a couple dozen butts around the machine. Now the crow has to find out it can pick up those butts and deposit them in the machine,\u201d Ruben concludes.</p>\n<p>Once the butts around the machine are finished, the crow will go looking for butts in the \u2018wild\u2019. And presto; A beautiful machine-animal symbiosis to help out humans with a behavioral problem that\u2019s poisoning the environment.</p>\n<p>\u201cBut what about the crows?\u201d you ask, as I did too. \u201cWon\u2019t they be harmed by picking up our disgusting toxic garbage with \u2013 essentially \u2013 their mouths?\u201d</p>\n<p>Well, maybe, but the designer duo is pragmatic about this. \u201cThe effect is on nature is huge, and we feel that a few crows are a small price to pay. Moreover, the short contact with the butt ensures the effect is minimal,\u201d Bob assures me. \u201cWe can regulate the machine to limit the number of crows that are trained. But indeed, we still need to do extensive research on this, because if the effects are found out to be bad for crows we have to look for another solution.\u201d</p>\n<p>There\u2019s another species they\u2019re planning to train with their project. Us. In the end, it\u2019s a flaw in human behavior that\u2019s causing the problem. \u201cIt\u2019s also about starting a discussion,\u201d Ruben says. \u201cWhen we tell people about this project, and they realize how large the problem is, it changes their behavior.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cWe hope a concept like this can create a lot of awareness. Most people somehow don\u2019t really think of throwing their cigarettes the same way they\u2019d think of a plastic candy wrapper.\u201d Which is weird.</p>\n<p>Bob and Ruben still have a ways to go with their machine, before any of the above becomes a reality.</p>\n<p><figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1082802 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1093px) 100vw, 1093px\" data-src=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828.jpg\" data-srcset=\"https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828.jpg 1093w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-280x210.jpg 280w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-360x270.jpg 360w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-180x135.jpg 180w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-796x597.jpg 796w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-368x276.jpg 368w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-736x552.jpg 736w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-1044x783.jpg 1044w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-632x474.jpg 632w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/IMG_20170903_165828-536x402.jpg 536w\"/></figure></p>\n<p>\u201cWe have all parts working separately, but not together yet,\u201d they tell me, pulling bits and pieces of electronics out of a big plastic box. Ruben shows me the crude butt dispenser needed for the first steps of the training, and Bob talks about the difficulty of training machine learning software to tell a cigarette butt apart from a lollipop stick.</p>\n<p>To able to complete the project, the pair is currently looking for ways to fund a serious experiment. I ask them if they\u2019d already considered CROWdfunding, and thoroughly hate myself for it.</p>\n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s really a first test, and if it turns out it doesn\u2019t work, we\u2019d feel very responsible toward lots of people,\u201d Bob says, ignoring my idiot joke. \u201cIt\u2019s also not really known how long it takes to train wild crows. We\u2019ll just have to test.\u201d</p>\n<p>With fingers crossed, I reached out to <a href=\"http://sefs.washington.edu/research.acl/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\">professor John Marzluff</a>, a world-renown corvid expert who has written multiple books on the species, to ask if he saw anything in the project.</p>\n<p>\u201cI am sure crows could learn to do this. They are quick studies when rewarded for their actions. I\u2019ve heard stories of crows picking up cigarettes elsewhere and have wondered if it had a purpose. Pet crows often steal their owners\u2019 cigs, and Indian house crows have been photographed with cigs in their beaks. But why? Maybe just trying potential food sources they see us put in our mouths? Or perhaps they are using the spent filters as insecticides for their nests as some other birds have been found to do? So, yes they could do it,\u201d he wrote back.</p>\n<p>Marzluff was quick to point out the ethical implications as well though: \u201cIt is equally important to ask, should we enslave crows to do our dirty work for us? To me the answer to that question is NO. Crows have lives of their own to live and we should just marvel at their lives, rather than try to coerce them into working for us. It would be more ethical to devise a machine to pick up butts, create biodegradable butts, or better yet, train our smoking conspecifics to pick up after themselves.\u201d</p>\n<p>The resounding, capitalized \u2018NO\u2019 in professor Marzluff answer only adds to the brilliance of the idea, in my opinion.</p>\n<p>The project doesn\u2019t only look at nature for solutions to purely human problems, pitting millions of years of evolution against our puny attempts, it also combines the beauty of our most advanced technology with the strengths of some of the smartest animals on earth. And to boot, it\u2019s not only a physical solution, it\u2019s a psychological one as well.</p>\n<p>Pissed off people make for great conduits of ideas, and even though the upper layer \u2013 exploiting crows \u2013 might be perceived as problematic, it\u2019s a great way to get people talking about the underlying layer: Our own problems.</p>\n<p>It\u2019s glorious. An idea for a machine that trains crows to solve a waste problem we\u2019re creating, ends up training us to be more conscious of the root of the problem, thus hopefully putting a dent in the production of waste, and eliminating the need for the idea itself.</p>\n<p>In other words: The machine doesn\u2019t only train crows. It trains humans.</p>\n<p><figure class=\"post-image post-mediaBleed aligncenter\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1082806 lazy\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Super-brain-360x270.jpg 360w, https://cdn0.tnwcdn.com/wp-content/blogs.dir/1/files/2017/10/Super-brain-180x135.jpg 180w, 536w\"/></figure></p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n\n<p class=\"post-article-read-next\">\n    <b>Read next:</b>\n    <a class=\"gtm-article-read-next\" data-event-category=\"Article\" data-event-action=\"Next blockchain research platform helps investors to avoid ICO scams    </a>\n</p>\n\n\n                            \n\n                        </div>\n\n                        \n</div></body></html>"}, "15429201": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:02:00", "url": null, "text": "What&#x27;s a contemporary (state of the art) way of authenticating users on the web? Where &#x2F; how do you learn about it?"}, "15430499": {"score": 5, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:58:02", "url": "https://www.gwern.net/Embryo-selection", "text": "<html><body><div><p>Intelligence is one of the most valuable traits to select on, and one of the easiest to analyze, but we shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t forget that it is neither necessary nor desirable to select <em>only</em> on intelligence. Selecting only on one trait means that most of the genotype information is being ignored; at best, this is a lost opportunity, and at worst, it is harmful - in the very long run (dozens of generations), selection only on one trait, particularly in a small breeding population, will have <q>unintended consequences</q> like greater disease rates, shorter lifespans, etc (see Falconer 1960\u00e2\u0080\u0099s <em>Introduction to Quantitative Genetics</em>, <a href=\"https://archive.org/stream/introductiontoq00falc#page/312/mode/2up\">Ch. 19 <q>Correlated Characters</q></a>).</p>\n<p>This is why animal breeders do not select purely on a single valuable trait like egglaying rate but on an index of many traits, from maturity speed to disease resistance to lifespan; when breeding is done out of ignorance or with regard only to a few traits, one may wind up with problematic breeds like some purebred dog breeds which have serious health issues due to inbreeding, small founding populations, no selection against negative mutations popping up, and variants which increase the selected trait at the expense of another trait.</p>\n<p>In our case, a weak polygenic score can be strengthened by better GWASes, but it can also be combined with other polygenic scores to do selection on multiple traits by summing the scores per embryo and taking the maximum. This can be done almost for free, since if one did sequencing on a comprehensive SNP array chip to compute 1 polygenic score, one probably has all the information needed. (Indeed, you could see selection on a single trait as a multiple selection procedure where all traits\u00e2\u0080\u0099 values are implausibly set to 0 except for 1 trait.) In reality, while some traits are of much more value than others, there are few traits with <em>no</em> value at all; an embryo which scores mediocrely on our primary trait may still have many other advantages which more than compensate, so why not check? (It is a general principle that more information is better than less.) Intelligence is valuable, but it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also valuable to live a long time, have less risk for schizophrenia, lower BMI, be happier, and so on.</p>\n<p>A quick demonstration of the possible gain is to imagine the total of 1 normal deviate (<math display=\"inline\" xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML\"><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathvariant=\"script\"><mi>\u00f0\u009d\u0092\u00a9</mi></mstyle><mo stretchy=\"false\" form=\"prefix\">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy=\"false\" form=\"postfix\">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding=\"application/x-tex\">\\mathcal{N}(0,1)</annotation></semantics></math>) vs picking the most extreme out of several normal deviates. With 1 deviate, our average extreme is 0, and most of the time will be \u00c2\u00b11SD. But if we can pick out of batches of 10, we can generally get +1.53SD:</p>\n<p>What if we have 4 different scores (with two downweighted substantially to reflect that they are less valuable)? We get 0.23SD for free:</p>\n<p>This is just like selecting among multiple embryos: the more we have to pick from, the better the chance one will be particularly good. So in selecting embryos, we want to compute multiple polygenic scores for each embryo, weight them by the overall value of that trait, sum them to get a total score for each embryo, then select the best embryo for implantation.</p>\n<p>Let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s imagine a US example but with 3 traits now, IQ and 2 we consider to be roughly half as valuable as IQ, but which have better polygenic scores available of 60% and 5%. What sort of gain can we expect above our starting point?</p>\n<p>So we double our gains by considering 3 traits instead of 1.</p>\n<section id=\"multiple-selection-on-genetically-correlated-traits\" class=\"level4\">\n<h4>Multiple selection on genetically correlated traits</h4>\n<p>In single selection, the embryo selected is picked from the batch solely based on its polygenic score on 1 trait, even if the gain is small and some of the other embryos have large genetic advantages on other, almost as important, traits. In multiple selection, we take the maximum from the embryos based on all the scores summed together, allowing for excellence on 1 trait or general high quality on a few other traits.</p>\n<p>What sort of advantage do we expect? It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not as simple as generating some random numbers independently from a distribution and then summing them, because the actual genetic scores will turn out to be intercorrelated: a high polygenic score for intelligence will also tend to lower the BMI polygenic score, and a high BMI polygenic score will increase the childhood obesity polygenic score or the smoking polygenic score because they genetically overlap on the same SNPs. In fact, all traits will tend to be a little (or a lot) genetically correlated. If we ignore this, we may badly over or underestimate the advantage of multiple selection: the advantage of selection on a good trait may be partially negated if it drags in a bad trait, or the advantage may be amplified if it comes with other good traits.</p>\n<p>We need a dataset giving the pairwise genetic correlations of a lot of important traits, and then we can generate hypothetical multivariate sets of polygenic scores which follow what the real-world distribution of polygenic scores would look like, and <em>then</em> we can sum them up, maximize, and see what sort of gain we have.</p>\n<p>A specific genetic correlation can be estimated from twin studies, or as part of GWAS studies using an algorithm like GCTA or LD score regression. LD score regression has the notable advantage of being usable on solely the polygenic scores for individual traits released by GWASes, without requiring the same subjects to be phenotyped or access to subject-level data, and computationally tractable; hence it is possible to collect various publicly released polygenic scores for any traits and calculate the correlations for all pairs of traits.</p>\n<p>This has been done by done by <a href=\"http://ldsc.broadinstitute.org/\">LD Hub</a> (described in <a href=\"http://biorxiv.org/content/biorxiv/early/2016/05/03/051094.full.pdf\" title=\"LD Hub: a centralized database and web interface to perform LD score regression that maximizes the potential of summary level GWAS data for SNP heritability and genetic correlation analysis\">Zheng et al 2016</a>), which provides a web interface to an implementation of LD score regression and &gt;100 public polygenic scores which are now also available for estimating SNP heritability or genetic correlations. Zheng et al 2016 describes the initial correlation matrix for 49 traits, a number which are of practical interest in multiple selection; <a href=\"http://ldsc.broadinstitute.org/static/media/LD-Hub_genetic_correlation_49x49.xlsx\">the spreadsheet</a> can be downloaded, saved as CSV, and the first lines edited to provide a usable file in R.</p>\n<p>Several of the traits are redundant or overlapping: it is scientifically useful to know that height as measured in one study is the same thing as measured in a different study (implying that the relevant genetics in the two populations are the same, and that the phenotype data was collected in a similar manner, which is something you might take for granted for a trait like height, but would be in considerable doubt for mental illnesses), but we really don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t need 4 slightly different traits related to tobacco use or ~9 traits about obesity. So before turning into a correlation matrix, we need to drop those to leave with 34 relevant traits:</p>\n<div class=\"sourceCode\"><pre class=\"sourceCode R\"><code class=\"sourceCode r\">rg &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"kw\">read.csv</span>(<span class=\"st\">\"https://www.gwern.net/docs/genetics/correlation/2016-zheng-ldhub-49x49geneticcorrelation.csv\"</span>)\n<span class=\"co\"># delete redundant/overlapping/obsolete ones:</span>\ndupes &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"kw\">c</span>(<span class=\"st\">\"BMI 2010\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Childhood Obesity\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Extreme BMI\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Obesity Class 1\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Obesity Class 2\"</span>,\n           <span class=\"st\">\"Obesity Class 3\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Overweight\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Waist Circumference\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Waist-Hip Ratio\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Cigarettes per Day\"</span>,\n           <span class=\"st\">\"Ever/Never Smoked\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Age at Smoking\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Extreme Height\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Height 2010\"</span>)\nrgClean &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span>rg[!(rg$Trait1 %in%<span class=\"st\"> </span>dupes |<span class=\"st\"> </span>rg$Trait2 %in%<span class=\"st\"> </span>dupes),]\nrgClean &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"kw\">subset</span>(rgClean, <span class=\"dt\">select=</span><span class=\"kw\">c</span>(<span class=\"st\">\"Trait1\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"Trait2\"</span>, <span class=\"st\">\"rg\"</span>))\n\n<span class=\"kw\">library</span>(reshape2)\nrgMatrix &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"kw\">acast</span>(rgClean, Trait2 ~<span class=\"st\"> </span>Trait1)\n\n<span class=\"co\"># convert from half-matrix to full symmetric matrix</span>\n<span class=\"kw\">library</span>(psych)\nrgMatrix &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"kw\">lowerUpper</span>(<span class=\"kw\">t</span>(rgMatrix), rgMatrix)\nrgMatrix[<span class=\"kw\">is.na</span>(rgMatrix)] &lt;-<span class=\"st\"> </span><span class=\"dv\">1</span></code></pre></div>\n<p>For a baseline, let\u00e2\u0080\u0099s revisit the single selection case, in which we have 1 trait where higher=better with a heritability of 0.33 where we are choosing from 10 half-related embryos: we can get +0.62SD in this case. For a multiple selection version, we can consider a correlation matrix for 34 traits in which every trait is uncorrelated, with the same settings (higher=better, 0.33 heritability, 10 half-related siblings): with more traits to sum, the best choice becomes much better, giving us +3.644SDs on an overall index. Finally, what if we populate the correlation matrix with genetic correlations like those in the LD Hub dataset (ignoring the issues of trait-specific heritabilities, losses/gains, and available polygenic scores)? Do we get less or more than 3.644SD because traits cancel out? We get much more, +5.19SDs, because the pattern of correlations turn out to be favorable.</p>\n<div class=\"sourceCode\"><pre class=\"sourceCode R\"><code class=\"sourceCode r\"><span class=\"kw\">mean</span>(<span class=\"kw\">replicate</span>(<span class=\"dv\">100000</span>, <span class=\"kw\">max</span>(<span class=\"kw\">rnorm</span>(<span class=\"dv\">10</span>, <span we include SNP heritabilities (which set upper bounds on the polygenic scores, but see earlier GCTA discussion on why they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re loose upper bounds in practice). The heritabilities for 173 traits are provided by LD Hub in <a href=\"http://ldsc.broadinstitute.org/static/media/LD-Hub_study_information_and_SNP_heritability.xlsx\">a different</a> spreadsheet but the trait names don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t always match up with the names in the correlation spreadsheet ones, so I had to convert them manually. (The height heritability is also missing from the heritability page &amp; spreadsheet so I borrowed a GCTA estimate from <a href=\"http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/2/417.full\" title=\"Application of linear mixed models to study genetic stability of height and body mass index across countries and time\">Trzaskowski et al 2016</a>.) While we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re at it, I classified the traits by desirability to consistently set higher=better:</p>\n<div class=\"sourceCode\"><pre class=\"sourceCode R\"><code class=\"sourceCode 2.936800189</span>\n<span class=\"kw\">mean</span>(<span class=\"kw\">replicate</span>(<span class=\"dv\">100000</span>, <span class=\"kw\">max</span>(<span class=\"kw\">rowSums</span>(<span </span>utilities$Sign))))\n<span class=\"co\"># [1] 3.286329413</span></code></pre></div>\n<p>Re-estimating with higher=better corrected, the original multiple selection turned out to be somewhat overestimated. Adding the real trait heritabilities, we see that the gains to multiple selection remain large compared to single selection (2.9 or 3.3SDs vs 0.6SDs), and that the genetic correlations do <em>not</em> substantially reduce gains to multiple selection but in fact benefits multiple selection by adding +0.35SD.</p>\n<p>Continuing onward: if multiple selection is helpful, what sort of net benefit to selection would we get after assigning some reasonable costs to each trait &amp; using current polygenic scores? (One intriguing possibility I won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t cover here: fertility is highly heritable, so one could select for greater fertility; combined with selection on other traits, could this eventually eliminate dysgenic trends at their source?)</p>\n<p>Coming up with that information for 34 traits in the same detail as I have for intelligence would be extremely challenging, so I will settle for some quicker and dirtier estimates; in cases where the causal impact is not clear or I cannot find reasonably reliable cost estimates, I will simply drop the trait (which will be conservative and underestimate possible gains from multiple selection). The traits:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Age at <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menarche\" title=\"Wikipedia: Menarche\">Menarche</a>: <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4185210/\" title=\"Parent-of-origin specific allelic associations among 106 genomic loci for age at menarche\">Perry et al 2014</a> reports a polygenic score explaining 15.8% of variance. <a href=\"./docs/genetics/correlation/2016-day.pdf\" title=\"Physical and neurobehavioral determinants of reproductive onset and success\">Day et al 2016</a> demonstrates a causal impact of early puberty on <q>earlier first sexual intercourse, earlier first birth and lower educational attainment</q>, consistent with the intercorrelations (strong negative correlation with childhood IQ); clearly the sign should be negative, and early puberty has been linked to all sorts of problems (<a href=\"http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/06/the-long-term-risks-of-early-puberty/488834/\"><em>Atlantic</em></a>: <q>greater risk for breast cancer, teen pregnancy, HPV, heart disease, diabetes, and all-cause mortality, which is the risk of dying from any cause. There are psychological risks as well. Girls who develop early are at greater risk for depression, are more likely to drink, smoke tobacco and marijuana, and tend to have sex earlier.</q>) but no costs are available</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alzheimer%27s%20disease\" title=\"Wikipedia: Alzheimer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disease\">Alzheimer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disease</a>: <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5006219/\" title=\"Common polygenic variation enhances risk prediction for Alzheimer's disease\">Escott-Price et al 2015</a> report a polygenic score of 0.021 for AD. The lifetime risk at age 65 is 9% men &amp; 17% women; few people die before age 65 so I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll take the average 13% as the lifetime risk at birth (since Alzheimer\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rates tend to increase, this should be conservative for future rates). Costs rise steeply before death as the dementia cripples the patient, imposing extraordinary costs for daily care &amp; on families &amp; caregivers. USA total costs have been estimated at &gt;$200b; for dementia, the last 5 years of life can incur <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4809412/\" title=\"'The Burden of Health Care Costs in the Last 5 Years of Life', Kelley et al 2016\">$287k in costs</a>. Discounting Alzheimer treatment cost is a little tricky: unlike height/BMI/IQ or BPD which we could treat on an annual cost/gain basis and discount out indefinitely, that $287k of expenses will only be incurred 60+ years after birth on average. We can treat it as a single lump sum expense incurred 70 years in the future, discounted at 5% (as usual to be conservative): <code>287000 / (1+0.05)^70 ~&gt; 9432</code>. (In discounting late-life diseases, one might say that an ounce of prevention is worth less than a pound of cure.)</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anorexia\" title=\"Wikipedia: Anorexia\">Anorexia</a>: ~1% prevalence. <a href=\"http://europepmc.org/articles/pmc4325090\" title=\"A genome-wide association study of anorexia nervosa\">Boraska et al 2014</a> does not report a polygenic score.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autism\" title=\"Wikipedia: Autism\">Autism</a>: ~1.4% prevalence. <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3714010/\" title=\"Common polygenic risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is associated with cognitive ability in the general population\">Clarke et al 2016</a> report that the earlier PGS results found 17% of liability explained (though this does not seem to be reported in the cited original paper/appendix that I can find). <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autism%23Cost\" title=\"Wikipedia: Autism#Cost\">Cost</a> ~$4m.</li>\n<li>Birth length, weight: skip as difficult to pin down the causal effects</li>\n<li>College: ~42% of younger Americans have <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational%20attainment%20in%20the%20United%20States\" title=\"Wikipedia: Educational attainment in the United States\">a college degree</a>. Rietveld reports a polygenic score ~2% for both college &amp; <q>years of education</q>. A college degree is worth an estimating $250k+ for an American.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronary%20Artery%20Disease\" title=\"Wikipedia: Coronary Artery Disease\">Coronary Artery Disease</a>: ~40% lifetime risk. <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3679547/\" title=\"Large-scale association analysis identifies new risk loci for coronary artery disease\">Deloukas et al 2013</a> report a limited polygenic score explaining 10.6% of the estimated 40% additive heritability or 4.24% of variance. Cardiovascular diseases are some of the most common, expensive, and fatal diseases, and US costs range into the hundreds of billions of dollars. <a href=\"./docs/2003-birnbaum.pdf\" title=\"Lifetime medical costs for women: Cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and stress urinary incontinence\">Birnbaum et al 2003</a> estimates annual costs ~$7k up to age 64 but then ~$31k annually afterwards for total lifetime costs of $599k. Around half of people will be diagnosed by ~age 60, so at a first cut, we might discount it at <code>423000 / (1+0.05)^60 ~&gt; 32067</code> or $32k.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crohn%27s%20disease\" title=\"Wikipedia: Crohn\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disease\">Crohn\u00e2\u0080\u0099s disease</a>: 0.32% incidence. <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3491803/\" title=\"Host-microbe interactions have shaped the genetic architecture of inflammatory bowel disease\">Jostins et al 2012</a> reports a polygenic score explaining 13.6% of variance. Crohn\u00e2\u0080\u0099s strikes young and lasts a lifetime; <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20170721085617/http://www.crohns.org/congress/submission00/appendix2.htm\" title=\"Appendix II: Cost savings from curing Crohn's Disease (CD)\">PARA</a> estimates $8330 annually or $374850 over the estimated 45 years after diagnosis around age 20, suggesting a discounting of <code>(8330/log(1.05)) / ((1+0.05)^20) ~&gt; 64346</code>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major%20depressive%20disorder\" title=\"Wikipedia: Major depressive disorder\">Major depressive disorder</a>: <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiology%20of%20depression\" title=\"Wikipedia: Epidemiology of depression\">17% lifetime rate</a>. <a href=\"http://neurogenetics.qimrberghofer.edu.au/papers/Ripke2013MolPsychiatry.pdf\" title=\"A mega-analysis of genome-wide association studies for major depressive disorder\">Sullivan et al 2013</a> reports a polygenic score of 0.6%. (<a href=\"./docs/genetics/correlation/2016-hyde.pdf\" title=\"Identification of 15 genetic loci associated with risk of major depression in individuals of European descent\">Hyde et al 2016</a>\u00e2\u0080\u0099s polygenic score used only the top 17 SNPs, and they don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t report the variance explained of MDD, just the secondary phenotypes.) Another major burden of disease, both common and crippling and frequently fatal, depression has large direct costs for treatment and larger indirect costs from wages, worse health etc. <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2887689/\" title=\"Long-Term Economic Costs of Psychological Problems During Childhood\">Smith et al</a> finds children with depression have $300k less lifetime income, which doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t take into account the medical treatment costs or suicide etc and is a lower bound. I can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t find any lifetime costs so I will guesstimate that as the total cost for adults, starting at age 32, giving ~$63k as the cost.</li>\n<li>Fasting glucose/insulin/proinsulin, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HbA1C\" title=\"Wikipedia: HbA1C\">HbA1C</a>: skip as their effects should be covered by diabetes.</li>\n<li>Former/Current Smoker: <a href=\"http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5542a1.htm\" title=\"Tobacco Use Among Adults --- United States, 2005\">~42% of the American population circa 2005</a> has smoked &gt;100 cigarettes (although by 2016 currently smoking adults were down to ~15% of the population). Supplemental material for <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4048635/\" title=\"Polygenic risk scores for smoking: predictors for alcohol and cannabis use?\">Vink et al 2014</a> reports a polygenic score for ever smoking of 6.7%. The lifetime cost of tobacco smoking includes the direct cost of tobacco, increased lung cancer risk, lower work output, fires, general worsened health, any second hand or fetal effects, and early mortality; the cost, from various perspectives (individual vs national healthcare systems etc) has been heavily debated, but I think it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s safe to put it at least $100k over a lifetime or $27k discounted.</li>\n<li>Hip Circumference: should be covered by BMI</li>\n<li>HOMA-B/HOMA-IR/Lumbar Spine BMD/Neck BMD: I have no idea where to start with these, so skipping</li>\n<li>Infant Head Circumference: should be covered by IQ and education?</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheumatoid%20Arthritis\" title=\"Wikipedia: Rheumatoid Arthritis\">Rheumatoid Arthritis</a>: <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3078757/\" title=\"'The Lifetime Risk of Adult-Onset Rheumatoid Arthritis and Other Inflammatory Autoimmune Rheumatic Diseases', Crowson et al 2012\">2.65%</a>. <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major%20histocompatibility%20complex\" title=\"Wikipedia: Major histocompatibility complex\">MHC</a> hits explain ~12% and <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3944098/\" title=\"Genetics of rheumatoid arthritis contributes to biology and drug discovery\">Okada et al 2014</a> report a polygenic score providing another 5.5%. <a href=\"http://rheumatology.oxfordjournals.org/content/39/1/28.long\" title=\"Economic burden of rheumatoid arthritis: a systematic review\">Cooper 2000</a> estimates total annual costs for RA at ~$11542/year and cites a Stone 1984 estimate of lifetime cost of $15,504 ($35,909 in 2016); with typical age of onset around 60, the total annual cost might be discounted to $13k.</li>\n<li>LDL, total cholesterol, triglycerides: harmful effects should be redundant with coronary artery disease</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulcerative%20colitis\" title=\"Wikipedia: Ulcerative colitis\">Ulcerative colitis</a>: 0.3%. <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3491803/\" title=\"Host-microbe interactions have shaped the genetic architecture of inflammatory bowel disease\">Jostins et al 2012</a> reports a polygenic score of 7.5%. <a href=\"http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2036.2010.04234.x/pdf\" title=\"Systematic review: the costs of ulcerative colitis in Western countries\">Cohen et al 2010</a> &amp; <a href=\"./docs/2011-park.pdf\" title=\"Inflammatory Bowel Disease-Attributable Costs and Cost-effective Strategies in the United States: A Review\">Park &amp; Bass 2011</a> report $15k medical expenses annually &amp; $5k employment loss. With mean age diagnosis of ~35 (<a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4110577/\" title=\"Epidemiology, demographic characteristics and prognostic predictors of ulcerative colitis\">da Silva et al 2014</a>), something like <code>(20000/log(1.05)) / ((1+0.05)^35) ~&gt; 74314</code>.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>This gives us 16 usable traits:</p>\n<div class=\"sourceCode\"><pre class=\"sourceCode Some<a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/john-greathouse-apologizes-for-op-ed-2016-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u00a0<strong>suggest</strong></a><strong>\u00a0</strong>women aren\u2019t cut out for the tech world at all. And t<span>hese </span><strong><a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/40456604/these-women-entrepreneurs-created-a-fake-male-cofounder-to-dodge-startup-sexism\">women entrepreneurs</a></strong><span> even created a fake male cofounder to dodge startup sexism.</span></p>\n<p>But more and more women are building multimillion-dollar startups, It\u2019s paying off across Australian and New Zealand.</p>\n<p><span>Here is our round-up of 27 fierce ladies, in 25 startups to keep an eye on taking the ANZ tech space by storm.</span></p>\n\n<img class=\"wp-image-4292 aligncenter\" src=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090518/Female-Tech-Founders-Petcloud.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090518/Female-Tech-Founders-Petcloud.jpg 1088w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090518/Female-Tech-Founders-Petcloud-300x202.jpg 300w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090518/Female-Tech-Founders-Petcloud-768x517.jpg 768w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090518/Female-Tech-Founders-Petcloud-902x608.jpg 902w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 697px) 100vw, 697px\"/>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.petcloud.com.au/\"><span>PetCloud</span></a> is an online community for pet parents to connect with pet sitters who have been screened and are ready to care for your pet. They are partnered with RSPCA across most States, and now with Greencross &amp; Petbarn, making them one of Australia\u2019s most trusted and convenient pet care service providers. All reservations include insurance, 24/7 customer support, and daily photo updates of your pet enjoying their own vacation, letting you enjoy yours.</p>\n<p><strong>On being a female founder, Deb says:</strong><br/>\n\u201c<em>I encourage other women in tech to get out there and pursue their dreams. Get good advice. Be multiskilled. Get connected with a co-workspace hub. Test your product on your target market\u2026 I am an example of what women can achieve once they realise their purpose, worth, and value. Stay on course. Good things happen when you don\u2019t give u</em>p.\u201d</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://travelshoot.com/\"><span>Travelshoot</span></a> is a service that helps you book a local photographer while travelling. The platform provides a way to connect travellers with local and professional photographers. People that know their city like no one else, whom you can book to get personal, unique travel photos, without breaking the budget. Travelshoot won the \u201cMy Shark Tank Australia competition\u201d in 2015 and have been going from strength to strength since.</p>\n<p><strong>On women in the industry Sarah wanted to say this:</strong><br/>\n\u201c<em>I\u2019ve been fortunate to have some wonderful female advisors and mentoring opportunities during my journey so far. My standout moment was the brilliant Emma Isaacs who kicked my arse and really inspired me to go for my first investment round when I was pregnant \u2013 and so many others had warned me perhaps it \u2018wasn\u2019t the best time\u2019 to do so. Her advice was so true \u2013 work with investors that are family friendly, and by being pregnant and securing investment is a great time to find out who truly is. I try to pay it forward and always make the time to grab a coffee with any female founders who are starting their journey and reach out to learn about my journey, I think it\u2019s really important and always incredible how many tips and tricks you can pick up over a face to face coffee.</em>\u201d</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.veromo.com/\"><span>Veromo</span></a> is a platform to get your business off to the ground by streamlining and automating most of the setup process of starting a business. Their first round of funding circa $935k helped to get their MVP to market. Luscheyne and co-founder Andy started Veromo when Luscheyne had just given birth to her daughter. Before she knew it they had secured funding, proving that there is no need for women to choose between their career and parenthood.</p>\n<p><strong>On the changing perception of female founders Luscheyne says:</strong><br/>\n\u201c<em>I think that the tides are changing. With more women joining the ranks in entrepreneurship, no matter how big or small their venture \u2013 it can only inspire more to say it\u2019s possible. Creating a new business is a wonderful way of expressing yourself, weaving together years of experience and shaping something new. As I reflect upon the last three years in taking the idea for </em>Veromo<em> to market, the moments that brought me the most joy were when we rallied together a talented group of people and created a great platform. A platform to help inspire more people to take the entrepreneurial leap and do what they love.</em>\u201d</p>\n\n<img class=\"wp-image-4290 aligncenter\" src=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090505/Female-Tech-Founders-Automio.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090505/Female-Tech-Founders-Automio.jpg 1088w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090505/Female-Tech-Founders-Automio-300x202.jpg 300w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090505/Female-Tech-Founders-Automio-768x517.jpg 768w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090505/Female-Tech-Founders-Automio-902x608.jpg 902w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 698px) 100vw, 698px\"/>\n<p><a href=\"https://autom.io/\"><span>Automio\u00a0</span></a>is a clever interview-bot and document builder that people can train to automate the processes used within their business. When Automio is trained to do a new skill or carry out a new process, a \u201cFlow\u201d is created \u2013 an automated product that can be used, bought and sold over and over again without any extra effort. To date, they have raised $1.224 million in capital, gained NZ, Australia, the UK, the US and Europe. Claudia recently won an individual award in the Janders Dean and LexisNexis 2017 Legal Innovation Index.</p>\n<p><strong>Claudia\u2019s advice to other female entrepreneurs:</strong><br/>\n\u201c<em>Be bold. Get better, not bitter. Enjoy the freedom to be creative. So many people don\u2019t have the mental space to be creative in their jobs, but when working in tech you can be creative and try stuff out. There\u2019s a lot of tough decisions to make as a tech company founder so trust yo\u2019self and don\u2019t get all up in your head and over think things all the time. Also, life as a tech company founder is a whole lot easier if your partner or spouse believes in your vision 100% #justsayin</em>.\u201d</p>\n<h2><strong>Melanie Perkins \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a></strong></h2>\n<img class=\" wp-image-4476 aligncenter\" src=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20171003145524/Mel-Canva.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20171003145524/Mel-Canva.jpg 1280w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20171003145524/Mel-Canva-300x200.jpg 300w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20171003145524/Mel-Canva-768x512.jpg 768w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20171003145524/Mel-Canva-902x601.jpg 902w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 699px) 100vw, 699px\"/>\n<p><span><strong><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a> </strong>makes design simple for everyone. Create designs for Web or print including blog graphics, presentations, Facebook covers, flyers, posters, and invitations. The Canva journey began back in 2007 when Melanie Perkins was studying at the University of Western Australia. Melanie taught students how to use programs such as InDesign and Photoshop \u2014 programs that people found hard to learn and even harder to use.</span><span><br/>\n</span><span><br/>\n</span><span>Fast forward to 2017, from animations to launching a print house and continuing global expansion, it\u2019s been another big year for Surrey Hills based Canva.</span></p>\n<p>The team has grown massively in 2017, with 120 in Sydney and 250 globally. That\u2019s an increase of 50 percent this year alone.</p>\n\n<img class=\"wp-image-4291 aligncenter\" src=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090511/Female-Tech-Founders-Nano-X.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090511/Female-Tech-Founders-Nano-X.jpg 1088w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090511/Female-Tech-Founders-Nano-X-300x202.jpg 300w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090511/Female-Tech-Founders-Nano-X-768x517.jpg 768w, https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/kudzus/20170927090511/Female-Tech-Founders-Nano-X-902x608.jpg 902w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 698px) 100vw, 698px\"/>\n<p><span><a href=\"http://nano-x.com.au/\">Nano-X</a>\u00a0</span>is an innovative cancer treatment system being designed and developed in Australia. Using blockchain technology they provide a transparent, auditable and automated market trading and clearing mechanism for the benefit of producers and consumers. She also finds time to be an independent councillor at the City of Perth, a board member of the Water Corp, Heritage Perth and Carbon Tracker, wife and a mother of one.</span></p>\n<p><b>Jemma shares her excitement on women in Blockchain:</b></p>\n<p><i><span>\u201cI love being a woman in tech. (1779)\" data-kind=\"article-image\" id=\"article-image-46680\"/><figcaption class=\"caption structured-caption noskim\">A skeleton awakens! (1779) <a class=\"caption-credit\" rel=\"nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A_skeleton,_seated_on_his_grave,_awakes_to_the_last_trump_Wellcome_V0008801.jpg\">Wellcome Images</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\"><span class=\"section-start-text\">Here are some instructions for </span>preparing human bones for display, from circa 1543:</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Step 1. Acquire a corpse. No, no hints about where or how. You\u2019re on your own there.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Step 2. Cut away as much flesh as you can. Watch the joints and ligaments\u2014you need those intact.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Step 3. Acquire a body-length box, with holes in the walls. Place the bones inside, and cover with quicklime (used for centuries in agriculture, warfare, and cemeteries, and now <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B071R6SRHV/ref=asc_df_B071R6SRHV5197417/?tag=hyprod-20&amp;creative=395033&amp;creativeASIN=B071R6SRHV&amp;linkCode=df0&amp;hvadid=198107334619&amp;hvpos=1o1&amp;hvnetw=g&amp;hvrand=5786039409177638114&amp;hvpone=&amp;hvptwo=&amp;hvqmt=&amp;hvdev=c&amp;hvdvcmdl=&amp;hvlocint=&amp;hvlocphy=9004351&amp;hvtargid=pla-350801413911\">available online</a>). Sprinkle with water and wait a week. Presumably, leave the box someplace where no one will accidentally open it.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Step 4. Locate a stream or other body of running water in which to place the box. Give it a week, to allow the stream wash away the now loose and decaying flesh.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Step 5. Clean off any leftover flesh, and leave the skeleton to dry in the sun. The ligaments should keep the bones together.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">There\u2014your very own human skeleton.</p>\n<figure class=\" contains-caption \"><img class=\"article-image with-structured-caption \" src=\"http://assets.atlasobscura.com/article_images/46674/image.jpg\" alt=\"An 1833 study of bones.\" data-kind=\"article-image\" id=\"article-image-46674\"/><figcaption class=\"caption structured-caption noskim\">An 1833 study of bones. <a class=\"caption-credit\" rel=\"nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Skeletons_from_%22Anatomical_studies_of_bones...%22,_J._Flaxman_Wellcome_L0011906.jpg\">Wellcome Images</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">If you find this set of instructions foul, so did Andreas Vesalius, the 16th-century author from whom they\u2019re derived. Vesalius was a hotshot Renaissance scientist with a talent for self-promotion. He was young, cocky, and skeptical of the medical establishment, which was still reliant on ancient Greek medical work that was already more than a millennium old at the time. In Vesalius\u2019s opinion, skeleton-making was \u201ctime-consuming, dirty, and difficult,\u201d according to Oregon State University historian <a href=\"https://anitaguerrini.com\">Anita Guerrini</a>.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">He preferred a different strategy for revealing human skeletal anatomy. First, boil the body in a \u201ccapacious cauldron,\u201d then skim away the fat and clean the boiled flesh from the bones. That way, you could actually see the joints, instead of leaving them hidden behind blackened ligaments.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">\u201cNow most of the skeletons used in medical schools are plastic, but the ones that were used a couple hundred years ago\u2014they were all people,\u201d says Guerrini. For centuries human skeletons have been bought and sold, though it\u2019s rare for a commodity to have once been part of a person. But despite the long practice of hanging human bones in museums and academic institutions, \u201cwe really don\u2019t have a good history of skeletons,\u201d says Guerrini. After noticing how overlooked they had been, she began investigating the history and iconography of skeletons\u2014how they were they used, how they were made, and how that knowledge was passed down through generations of scientists. Vesalius\u2019s technique was one among many proposed strategies for creating a pristine set of human bones.</p>\n<figure class=\" contains-caption \"><img class=\"article-image with-structured-caption  image-outlined\" src=\"http://assets.atlasobscura.com/article_images/46675/image.jpg\" alt=\"Skeleton of Richard Helain, 1493.\" data-kind=\"article-image\" id=\"article-image-46675\"/><figcaption class=\"caption structured-caption noskim\">Skeleton of Richard Helain, 1493. <a class=\"caption-credit\" rel=\"nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Skeleton_of_Richard_Helain,_1493._Wellcome_M0000411.jpg\">Wellcome Images</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Vesalius\u2019s description is the oldest-known set of such instructions, but by the 1540s, the practice had been around for some time, perhaps going as far back as the 1300s, as Guerrini recounted in <a href=\"http://heymancenter.org/events/explorations-in-the-medical-humanities/\">a talk at Columbia University</a> this past September. One 14th-century scientist, for instance, mentions \u201cmaking an anatomy\u201d from fleshless bones.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Vesalius became a professor in Padua, as chief of surgery and anatomy, in 1537, when he was just 23 years old, and he wrote <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_humani_corporis_fabrica\"><em>De humani corporis fabrica</em></a> (<em>On the Fabric of the Human Body</em>)<em>, </em>which contains the skeleton instructions, before he turned 30. \u201cHe was brilliant, and he was very brash,\u201d says Guerrini. His book, unusually, had a portrait of himself on the title page, and another on the frontispiece. While his older colleagues deferred to the medical works of Galen, the Greek physician who lived in the 2nd century, Vesalius preferred direct observation of the human body. He taught using dissection and seemed to have no qualms about using human remains. \u201cWith characteristic macabre whimsy he recommended posing the skeleton with a scythe, or a pike, or a javelin, and suggested stringing the ear bones onto a nerve to make a necklace,\u201d Guerrini said in her talk.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">He didn\u2019t care much about the aesthetics of the bones themselves, though. The boil-and-carve strategy he advocated for would have left the bones mottled and brown. As skeletons became more popular as objects of display and learning, their appearance became more important.</p>\n<figure class=\" contains-caption \"><img class=\"article-image with-structured-caption \" src=\"http://assets.atlasobscura.com/article_images/46678/image.jpg\" alt=\"An illustration of a skeleton from Vesalius's &lt;em&gt;De humani corporis fabrica&lt;/em&gt;. \" data-kind=\"article-image\" id=\"article-image-46678\"/><figcaption class=\"caption structured-caption noskim\">An illustration of a skeleton from Vesalius\u2019s <em>De humani corporis fabrica</em>. <a class=\"caption-credit\" rel=\"nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"hhttps://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Vesalius_Fabrica_p163.jpg\">Public domain</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">They remained rare objects, though, until the 17th century, when the new science of osteology, the study of bones, increased their use in anatomical study. By the middle of that century, skeletons, both human and animal, started showing up in the catalogues of natural history collections and cabinets of curiosities, such as the elaborate, skeleton-filled <a href=\"http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/ruysch-bidloo-anatomy-dutch-rivarly-17th-century\">dioramas built by Dutch anatomist Frederik Ruysch</a>.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">Soon students of both art and anatomy were expected to study human skeletons as part of their training, and the public grew curious as well. By the 1660s, there was a market for them in Europe. By the 18th century, displaying human skeletons became trendy. Guerrini found a 1716 advertisement for \u201c<a href=\"https://anitaguerrini.com/2015/10/30/on-slates-the-vault-blog-the-moving-skeleton/\">The Moving Skeleton</a>,\u201d a public attraction \u201cwhich by a mechanical projection performs several very strange and surprising actions, also groans like a dying person, smoaks[sic] a Pipe of Tobacco, and blows the Candle out, as naturally as if alive.\u201d</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">By this time, anatomists wanted to produce clean, white bones. One physician made sure to leave his bones out for months to bleach in the sun. Another eschewed boiling bones and instead left corpses to rot in water, changed periodically. This \u201cmaceration\u201d technique required pulling softened flesh away from the bones and would have required a steely constitution. But the demand for skeletons was high enough that more people were taking on this job: In the early 18th century, one surgeon offered a course in skeleton-making.</p>\n<figure class=\" contains-caption \"><img class=\"article-image with-structured-caption \" src=\"http://assets.atlasobscura.com/article_images/46676/image.jpg\" alt=\"A skeleton illustration from the work of 17th-century Dutch anatomist Govert Bidloo. \" data-kind=\"article-image\" id=\"article-image-46676\"/><figcaption class=\"caption structured-caption noskim\">A skeleton illustration from the work of 17th-century Dutch anatomist Govert Bidloo. <a class=\"caption-credit\" rel=\"nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/40/Bidloo_Ontleding_1690_88.jpg\">National Library of Medicine/Public domain</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">While researching this history, Guerrini found that, some time in the 200 years after Vesalius, anatomists became more circumspect about their habit of stripping corpses of flesh and putting it on display. Vesalius, with his ear-bone necklace and artfully posed skeletons, was boastful of his work. By the 18th century, anatomists were less eager to crow about it. Alexander Munro, an expert in osteology, wrote a whole book on bones without ever once mentioning how to make a skeleton. William Hunter, a generation later, told his students that they should acquire a skeleton for personal use, but never published his lecture notes explaining the process of creating one.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">\u201cI was struck by Hunter and Monroe\u2019s aura of secrecy,\u201d says Guerrini. \u201cLooking at Hunter, in particular, he never published his anatomy lectures.\u201d The only reason she knows about his skeleton how-tos is that his students took notes, and those notes are still in archives, hidden away from public view.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf\">There is something eerie about the instruction that all, say, 30 students in an anatomy class should somehow acquire their own human skeletons. Hunter, Guerrini says, never specified where they were to find bodies, but students likely would have had to resort to grave-robbery, \u201c<a href=\"https://www.archaeology.org/issues/89-1305/features/737-royal-london-hospital-burials\">resurrection men</a>,\u201d or bribing gravediggers or hospital workers. (Hunter\u2019s brother was apparently an ace at body procurement.) Attitudes toward death had been changing in Europe, and the idea of a carving up a not-insubstantial number of bodies and selling their bones started to seem distasteful, even morally reprehensible. While Vesalius could joke about the fate of these bodies, \u201cWilliam Hunter acknowledged the \u2018necessary inhumanity\u2019 of dissection,\u2019\u201d Guerrini says.</p>\n<p class=\"item-body-text-graf item-body-last\">That didn\u2019t stop him from offering his own new-fangled techniques for skeleton-making. Like Vesalius, Hunter had strong opinions about the best strategies. \u201cIf you want the Bones to be white inject by the Aorta for two or three Hours which will return by the Veins,\u201d he wrote, without specifying what, exactly, should be injected. \u201cThen expose them to maggots.\u201d Or, if you had enough time, you could simply bury a body in a box by an anthill. It was, at least, a less hands-on method of stripping flesh from bones.</p>\n\n</section>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429247": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:15:05", "url": "https://www.corposflex.com/ostrovit-saw-palmetto-90-tabs-beneficios-prostata", "text": "<html><body><div><div id=\"tab-description\" class=\"tab-content\" itemprop=\"description\"><h2><span><em><strong>Ostrovit Saw Palmetto 90 tabs 1000mg Beneficios </strong></em></span></h2>\n\u00a0<p><strong><em><a href=\"https://www.corposflex.com/ostrovit-suplementos-portugal\">Ostrovit</a> Saw Palmetto 90 tabs</em></strong> com poderosa dosagem de 1000mg por comprimido contendo puro extrato da planta. <strong>Ostrovit Saw Palmetto</strong> \u00e9 super suplemento nutricional com imensos benef\u00edcios para homens e mulheres e que pode comprar agora em Portugal com pre\u00e7o mais baixo online.<br/>\n<br/>\n<span><strong>Saw Palmetto Beneficios para Mulheres:</strong></span><br/>\nEst\u00e1 comprovado que baixos \u00edndices de testosterona no corpo de mulheres e homens s\u00e3o a causa de libido fraco.
