data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=640?w=640\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-233\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=640\" alt=\"disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367\" srcset=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=640 640w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=300 300w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg?w=768 768w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/disk-utility-password-prompt-800x367.jpg 800w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">The dreaded password hint bug: Here, \u201cdontdisplaythis\u201d is the actual password.</p></div>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>Apple was prompt to provide <a href=\"https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208165\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">macOS High Sierra Supplemental Update</a> to customers via the App Store, and ensured that every distribution of High Sierra in their servers included this update.</p>\n<p>I decided to apply a\u00a0<a href=\"https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2017/10/using-binary-diffing-to-discover.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">binary diffing</a> technique to the update to learn more about the root cause of this bug and hypothesize about how the defect could have been prevented.</p>\n<p>Inspecting the 51MB package, we can see that there are changes in the Disk Utility and Keychain Access apps, and also in related frameworks and command line tools:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"82\" data-permalink=\"https://cocoaengineering.com/2017/10/08/reverse-engineering-macos-high-sierra-supplemental-update/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am/\" data-orig-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=640\" data-orig-size=\"1602,1183\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"Screen Shot 2017-10-08 at 11.53.25 AM\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=640?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=640?w=640\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-82\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=640\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2017-10-08 at 11.53.25 AM\" srcset=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=640 640w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=1280 1280w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=300 300w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=768 768w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/screen-shot-2017-10-08-at-11-53-25-am.png?w=1024 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/></p>\n<p>This post will focus only on the password hint bug, so our first step is to extract\u00a0<code>Applications/Utilities/Disk Utility.app/Contents/MacOS/Disk Utility</code> \u00a0and to compare it with the same binary from a stock macOS 10.13 High Sierra. For this, I have written an Emacs extension that launches <a href=\"https://www.hex-rays.com/products/ida/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">IDA</a> whenever I load a Mach-O file in a buffer, generates a SQL database with information about the decompiled functions, loads the patched binary, and finally outputs a diff generated by <a href=\"https://github.com/joxeankoret/diaphora\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Diaphora</a>. This technique is useful for deconstructing binaries that have been updated by a minor patch release because there are usually just a few changes and common heuristics work well.</p>\n<p>The diff between both versions of the Disk Utility binary revealed no differences in the decompilation:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"126\" data-permalink=\"https://cocoaengineering.com/2017/10/08/reverse-engineering-macos-high-sierra-supplemental-update/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16/\" data-orig-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=640\" data-orig-size=\"409,46\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_13_20_16\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=640?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=640?w=409\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-126\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=640\" alt=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_13_20_16\" https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_20_16.png?w=300 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 409px) 100vw, 409px\"/></p>\n<p>That usually means that the only substantial changes reside in one of the linked frameworks. The most interesting one for this investigation is StorageKit, a private Apple framework that exposes APFS functionality to Disk Utility. It has two parts: a client library and a daemon, <code>storagekitd</code>. The client connects to the daemon using an Apple standard <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xpc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">XPC mechanism</a>. The daemon executes the operations (represented as subclasses of <code>NSOperation</code>) that the client demands. Here\u2019s an interesting usage of StorageKit\u00a0inside Disk Utility:</p>\n<div data-shortcode=\"caption\" id=\"attachment_118\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img data-attachment-id=\"118\" https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_13_42_24.png?w=1024 1024w, StorageKit structure from controller code in Disk Utility.</p></div>\n<p>This is part of the code that runs when you add a new APFS volume from the Disk Utility interface (concretely, the controller responsible for managing the new volume sheet).</p>\n<p>Diffing StorageKit provided much more interesting results:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"268\" data-permalink=\"https://cocoaengineering.com/2017/10/08/reverse-engineering-macos-high-sierra-supplemental-update/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_13-3/\" data-orig-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=640\" data-orig-size=\"1132,543\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_14_00_13\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=640?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=640?w=640\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-268\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=640\" alt=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_14_00_13\" srcset=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=640 640w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=300 300w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=768 768w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png?w=1024 1024w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_00_132.png 1132w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/></p>\n<p><code>\u200b\u200b\u200b[SKHelperClient addChildVolumeToAPFSContainer:name:caseSensitive:minSize:maxSize:password:passwordHint:progressBlock:completionBlock:]</code> was one of the functions modified by the supplemental update. Inspecting the differences in decompilation revealed the actual bug:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"354\" data-permalink=\"https://cocoaengineering.com/2017/10/08/reverse-engineering-macos-high-sierra-supplemental-update/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_16-2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=640\" data-orig-size=\"649,140\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_14_15_16\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=640?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=640?w=640\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-354\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=640\" alt=\"VirtualBox_Windows 10_08_10_2017_14_15_16\" srcset=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=640 640w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png?w=300 300w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/virtualbox_windows-10_08_10_2017_14_15_161.png 649w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/></p>\n<p>In the picture above, the old, vulnerable, StorageKit is diff\u2019d against the updated one. Removed lines removed are depicted in red, added lines in green, and changes in yellow. The above function basically creates an instance of <code>NSMutableDictionary</code>\u00a0(Cocoa\u2019s representation of a hash table) and fills it with information about the volume. This dictionary is passed to <code>addChildVolumeToAPFSContainer:optionsDictionary:handlingProgressForOperationUUID:completionBlock:</code>\u00a0as the <code>optionsDictionary</code>\u00a0argument.</p>\n<p>The most interesting keys in the dictionary are <code>kSKAPFSDiskPasswordOption</code>\u00a0and <code>kSKAPFSDiskPasswordHintOption</code>, which are responsible for storing the password and the password hint, respectively. The bug is that the same variable, which contains the password, (represented in the decompilation as the same virtual register, <code>v50</code>) was used as value for both\u00a0keys in the dictionary, meaning that the clear password was incorrectly sent as a password hint via XPC. In reconstructed Objective-C code, the bug would be something like this:</p>\n<pre class=\"brush: objc; title: ; notranslate\" title=\"\">\nNSMutableDictionary *optionsDictionary = [NSMutableDictionary alloc] init];\n[...]\noptionsDictionary[kSKAPFSDiskPasswordOption] = password;\n\noptionsDictionary[kSKAPFSDiskPasswordHintOption] = password;\n\n</pre>\n<p>Here\u2019s the corrected function from the supplemental update:</p>\n<div data-shortcode=\"caption\" id=\"attachment_362\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img data-attachment-id=\"362\" data-permalink=\"https://cocoaengineering.com/2017/10/08/reverse-engineering-macos-high-sierra-supplemental-update/updated/\" data-orig-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=640\" data-orig-size=\"857,140\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"Updated\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=640?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=640?w=640\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-362\" src=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=640\" alt=\"Updated\" srcset=\"https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=640 640w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=150 150w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=300 300w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png?w=768 768w, https://cocoaengineering.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/updated.png 857w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 640px) 100vw, 640px\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Note that the correct variables for the password and the password hint are set.</p></div>\n<p>This is an example of a common category of bugs where code with a common structure is copied and pasted but the developer forgets to make every required modification and consequently there\u2019s a fatal change in behavior. If you are curious, <a href=\"https://www.viva64.com/en/b/0260/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this blog post</a> shows you more examples of \u201cLast Line Effect\u201d bugs in open source software.</p>\n<p>It\u2019s important to emphasize that, although this particular dictionary is not stored anywhere (it\u2019s simply used to pack the information that is sent to <code>storagekitd</code>), the fact that the password was sent incorrectly as password hint meant that <code>storagekitd</code>\u00a0trusted its client and stored it as clear text, thinking it was a password hint.</p>\n<h2>Why did the bug not reproduce when using the command line?</h2>\n<p>This is a common question. Apparently, <code>Disk Utility</code>\u00a0and command line\u00a0<code>diskutil</code>\u00a0use different code paths. \u00a0<code>StorageKit</code>\u00a0does not appear as a direct dependency of <code>diskutil</code>, or in the transitive closure of its dependencies. Here\u2019s\u00a0<code>otool -L</code>\u00a0output:</p>\n<blockquote><p>/usr/lib/libcsfde.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0)/usr/lib/libcsfde.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0) /usr/lib/libCoreStorage.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0) /System/Library/Frameworks/Foundation.framework/Versions/C/Foundation (compatibility version 300.0.0, current version 1443.14.0) /System/Library/Frameworks/IOKit.framework/Versions/A/IOKit (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 275.0.0) /System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/DiskManagement.framework/Versions/A/DiskManagement (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0) /System/Library/Frameworks/DiscRecording.framework/Versions/A/DiscRecording (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0) /usr/lib/libncurses.5.4.dylib (compatibility version 5.4.0, current version 5.4.0) /System/Library/Frameworks/DiskArbitration.framework/Versions/A/DiskArbitration (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.0) /usr/lib/libicucore.A.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 59.1.0) /usr/lib/libobjc.A.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 228.0.0) /usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1252.0.0) /System/Library/Frameworks/CoreFoundation.framework/Versions/A/CoreFoundation (compatibility version 150.0.0, current version 1443.13.0)</p></blockquote>\n<p>This duplication in what\u2019s more or less the same functionality, while sometimes justified, certainly increases the opportunity for bugs.</p>\n<h2>How could this have been prevented?</h2>\n<p>There\u2019s two engineering practices that help with bugs like this (but do not eradicate them completely):</p>\n<h3>Unit testing</h3>\n<p>Unit testing is the practice of creating software tests that exercise a single unit in a computer program, where \u201cunit\u201d is typically a class or module. Effective unit testing requires sensing outputs reliably and asserting that they are expected, so side effects from functions complicate unit testing a bit. In this particular bug, the side effect is the communication with the XPC service, so separating the logic that creates the dictionary from the part that communicates with the service would help. When a software design is not easily testable, companies rely excessively on manual testing, which is not a very effective way of testing, given the high number of combinations that is typical in modern software (<i>did the QA engineer test setting a password *and* a password hint?, </i>easily\u00a0forgettable on a tight deadline).</p>\n<h3>Code review</h3>\n<p>Code review is the practice of reviewing code before or after it lands the main development branch in a software project. Code reviews should always be small, so that the reviewer\u2019s attention is focused and can suggest better improvements and even spot bugs like this. A \u201clast line\u201d bug can easily be ignored if it\u2019s part of a huge code review.</p>\n<h2>Conclusion</h2>\n<p>An unfortunate bug in macOS High Sierra stained a bit its generally well-received debut, and from this root-case analysis we can learn what happened exactly and how good software development practices (including testable design and strict code reviews) can help reduce the chance that this kind of problems happen again in the future.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n\t\t\t\t\t<div id=\"jp-post-flair\" class=\"sharedaddy sd-like-enabled sd-sharing-enabled\"><div class=\"sharedaddy sd-block sd-like jetpack-likes-widget-wrapper jetpack-likes-widget-unloaded\" id=\"like-post-wrapper-81265838-63-59dbe671a5bfd\" data-src=\"//widgets.wp.com/likes/#blog_id=81265838&amp;post_id=63&amp;origin=cocoaengineering.wordpress.com&amp;obj_id=81265838-63-59dbe671a5bfd\" data-name=\"like-post-frame-81265838-63-59dbe671a5bfd\"><h3 class=\"sd-title\">Like this:</h3><p class=\"likes-widget-placeholder post-likes-widget-placeholder\"><span class=\"button\"><span>Like</span></span> <span class=\"loading\">Loading...</span></p><span class=\"sd-text-color\"/><a class=\"sd-link-color\"/></div></div>\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429267": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:18:52", "url": "https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/10/death-spirals/542304/?single_page=true", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n    \n        <p class=\"injector-promo-wrapper--article-top js-inject-promo\"/>\n        \n\n        <section id=\"article-section-1\"><p>\u201cDeath spiral!\u201d President Trump <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realdonaldtrump/status/860108914624532480\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'0',r'542304'\">tweeted</a> in May, about the Affordable Care Act. It had been a common accusation of Republicans even earlier. <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/15/upshot/obamacare-isnt-in-a-death-spiral-its-replacement-probably-wont-be-either.html\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'1',r'542304'\">Media</a>, <a href=\"http://acadeathspiral.org/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'2',r'542304'\">pundits</a>, and <a href=\"http://www.heritage.org/health-care-reform/commentary/what-the-obamacare-death-spiral-debate-misses\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'3',r'542304'\">think tanks</a> all weighed in on whether or not the label applies to Obamacare and its health-care exchanges.</p><aside class=\"partner-box\"><h4>More From Our Partners</h4>&#13;\n&#13;\n<figure><a href=\"http://objectsobjectsobjects.com/%20\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'partner',r'0',r'542304'\"><img alt=\"Object Lessons\" src=\"https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/files/screen_shot_2015-12-03_at_2.11.19_pm.png\"/></a></figure></aside><p>Today, death spiral means \u201c<a href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-obamacare-marketplaces-arent-in-a-death-spiral/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'4',r'542304'\">a marketplace spinning out of control</a>,\u201d as <em>FiveThirtyEight</em>\u2019s Anna Maria Barry-Jester puts it. It\u2019s an accusation that demands an urgent response. In a death spiral, destruction is so near and so inevitable that any attempt to avoid it becomes valid. By evoking the dwindling seconds before a plane crash, every other option looks better by comparison.</p><p>Yet death spirals have another story to tell. Before the death spiral was a figure of speech, it was a physical problem aviators needed to solve: how to keep from crashing when they flew through clouds or fog. How they solved real death spirals in the air might help explain how to resist the narrowed choices metaphorical death spirals impose.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxinjector-wrapper\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxinjector1\" targeting-pos=\"boxinjector1\" class=\"ad ad-boxinjector\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"1\" data-object-name=\"boxinjector\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [300, 350], [1, 3], [320, 520], [320, 430], [1, 4], [1, 1], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[760, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1050, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1024, 350], [1, 3], [1600, 520], [1000, 350], [1600, 500], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-2\"><p align=\"center\">* * *</p><p>In the early decades of flight, aviators were bedeviled by bad weather. Those who encountered poor visibility mid-flight told harrowing tales of disorientation and confusion. Surrounded on all sides by milk-white fog or hazy darkness, pilots entered a world where nothing behaved as it should. When they observed the plane slipping into a gentle descent, they corrected to gain altitude, only to find the plane diving downward faster. Or, when they were certain the plane was flying level, the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_and_slip_indicator\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'5',r'542304'\">turn indicator</a> would register a turn to the right. What the instrument registered as level, meanwhile, felt like a turn to the left.</p><p>Under these conditions, bailing out often became the best option. Those who didn\u2019t often joined their plane as it crashed into the ground.</p><aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\">To tame the death spiral, devices had to become part of how aviators kept control of the plane.</aside><p>Lost in the clouds, these pilots had fallen prey to a form of sensory disorientation known as a <em>death spiral</em>, or, more commonly, a <em>graveyard spiral</em>. The term describes an almost instinctive set of maneuvers pilots undertake when they lose sight of the horizon. The graveyard spiral begins when a plane flying in these conditions enters a gentle turn. As it turns, the plane will begin to descend, picking up speed.</p><p>Death spirals occur because the pilot feels the descent but not the turn. That has to do with the way the human body relies both on the visual and vestibular systems to perceive its orientation in space. As fluid moves through the small canals in the inner ear, the brain registers the body\u2019s shifts in position. The fluid moves when the head turns, creating the sensation that the vessel under control is doing the turning. In mid-flight, though, the fluid can settle in place. If this happens, a turn can feel like level flight. In this situation, a pilot who follows the instruments and levels the plane\u2019s wings feels, with absolute certainty, that the craft is turning in the <em>opposite</em> direction.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxright-wrapper\" data-pos=\"boxright\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxright1\" targeting-pos=\"boxright1\" class=\"ad ad-boxright\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"3\" data-object-name=\"boxright\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [300, 600]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-3\"><p>A pilot who recorrects to what feels level in his or her body simply reinitiates the spiral dive. Likewise, pulling back on the yoke to gain altitude without leveling the wings only tightens the plane\u2019s downward spiral. Without a clear view of the horizon to correct against, the pilot can become so disoriented that a total loss of control results, ending in a crash. An Air Safety Institute scare-tactic training video, \u201c<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b7t4IR-3mSo\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'6',r'542304'\">178 Seconds to Live</a>,\u201d follows a pilot through the disorientation of a classic graveyard spiral.</p><p>Once it became clear that aviators were becoming disoriented in the clouds, they set themselves to the task of figuring out how to avoid it. This was the birth of what is known as \u201cinstrument flight.\u201d Planes already carried basic instruments, such as turn and bank indicators, but these were primarily seen as navigational devices\u2014implements that helped pilots reach a destination rather than keep the plane in the air. To tame the death spiral, these devices had to become part of how aviators kept control of the plane.</p><p>In 1932, William Ocker and Carl Crane published <em>Blind Flight in Theory and Practice</em>, a detailed guide to flying by instruments through darkness and fog. Ocker and Crane\u2019s method relied on giving the pilot a visual reference against which to double-check the body\u2019s fallible sensations. A turn and bank indicator shows the wings\u2019 departure from level flight, and an artificial horizon visually represents the plane\u2019s relation to the ground.</p><aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\">As pilots learned to trust their instruments, flight through clouds and fog became mundane.</aside><p>But designing and implementing instruments was the easy part. It was harder to teach pilots to <em>believe</em> what their instruments reported over (and against) the persuasive sensations they felt in their bodies. Here Ocker and Crane ran up against aviators\u2019 long-standing belief that they controlled the plane, at least in part, through their superior \u201c<a href=\"https://archive.org/stream/equilibriumverti00jonerich#page/32/mode/2up/search/air+sense\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'7',r'542304'\">air sense</a>\u201d\u2014their body\u2019s special ability to maintain its equilibrium in flight. The idea that skillful flight depended on the body\u2019s perception of its own weight and relative position, sometimes called \u201c<a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=Y80tAAAAIAAJ&amp;q=%22graveyard+spiral%22&amp;dq=%22graveyard+spiral%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjD3JvR5onVAhWlx4MKHZQFCs84oAEQ6AEINTAE\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'8',r'542304'\">deep sensibility</a>\u201d or kinesthesia, was a truism among pilots. (Aviators referred to this skill as their ability to \u201cfly by the seat of the pants,\u201d a phrase that connoted, perhaps falsely, skill more than luck.)</p><p>Ocker and Crane started demonstrating the limits of the pilot\u2019s body, spinning skeptical pilots in chairs until they were dizzy, or showing them the curves their bodies traced when they tried to walk a straight line without the aid of vision. They even blindfolded homing pigeons and threw them out of a plane to demonstrate that even nature\u2019s best fliers would lose all sense of orientation without sight. (The pigeons spiraled helplessly, <a href=\"https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015021077964;view=1up;seq=53\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'9',r'542304'\">Ocker and Crane reported</a>, until they finally spread their wings parachute-style and floated, unharmed, to the ground.) This \u201c<a href=\"https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015021077964;view=1up;seq=34\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'10',r'542304'\">inherent spiral tendency</a>\u201d lived in everyone, Ocker and Crane argued, and it would show itself if not restrained by a competing vision of the horizon. Hence the aviator\u2019s need for instruments: They gave back the horizon clouds and fog had obscured.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxinjector-wrapper\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxinjector2\" targeting-pos=\"boxinjector2\" class=\"ad ad-boxinjector\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"1\" data-object-name=\"boxinjector\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [300, 350], [1, 3], [320, 520], [320, 430], [1, 4], [1, 1], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[760, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1050, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1024, 350], [1, 3], [1600, 520], [1000, 350], [1600, 500], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-4\"><p>A wary stance toward bodily perceptions would become a guiding principle for instrument flight. Early U.S. military training documents instructed pilots that their inner ears provided information that was \u201cnot at all reliable,\u201d for instance. Ocker and Crane gave pilots a set of practical lessons in how to reference them to keep control of the plane. As pilots learned to trust their instruments, flight through clouds and fog became commonplace, safe, and mundane. The death spiral, meanwhile, was replaced by a simpler imperative: Check your instruments, and believe them.</p><p align=\"center\">* * *</p><p>Pilots still talk about death spirals, especially to warn amateurs of the dangers of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/jul/25/kennedy.usa\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'11',r'542304'\">flying into fog and haze</a>. More commonly, though, the term claims that a social organization is on the brink of collapse: <a href=\"http://articles.latimes.com/2001/apr/08/news/mn-48291\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'12',r'542304'\">small towns</a>, <a href=\"http://time.com/money/4623760/department-stores-struggle-macys-kohls-sears-amazon/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'13',r'542304'\">department stores</a>, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2017/09/25/three-ways-electric-utilities-can-avoid-a-death-spiral/#5bfd5d39758d\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'14',r'542304'\">utility markets</a>, <a href=\"http://time.com/money/3731250/sweet-briar-private-college-death-spiral/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'15',r'542304'\">liberal-arts colleges</a>, <a href=\"http://www.newsweek.com/death-spiral-174352\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'16',r'542304'\">Apple</a> before Steve Jobs\u2019s return as CEO, the island of Puerto Rico (<a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/how-puerto-rico-got-in-over-its-head-2015-8\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'17',r'542304'\">pre</a>- and <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/puerto-rico-devastation-hits-already-tattered-island-economy-2017-9\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'18',r'542304'\">post-Hurricane Maria</a>), even <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/a-death-spiral-tillerson-makes-nice-but-may-not-last-long-with-trump/2017/10/04/7ad19894-a921-11e7-850e-2bdd1236be5d_story.html?utm_term=.69063be333d1\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'19',r'542304'\">the State Department under Rex Tillerson</a>.</p><p>The use that is most resonant today\u2014the death spiral as what ails insurance markets\u2014traces back to a 1998 article by two economists describing an \u201c<a href=\"http://www.nber.org/chapters/c9822.pdf\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'20',r'542304'\">adverse-selection death spiral</a>,\u201d in which insurance plans become financially unsustainable when there are too few healthy, low-cost subscribers enrolled. Economists and businesspeople have played a leading role in the death spiral\u2019s transition to metaphor, converting the individual danger pilots faced into a shorthand for market forces endowed with the inevitability of natural law. They draw on the death spiral\u2019s sense of urgency, meanwhile, to heighten the stakes of corporate failures. The term demands drastic action while rationalizing choices that might follow that imperative.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxright-wrapper\" data-pos=\"boxright\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxright2\" targeting-pos=\"boxright2\" class=\"ad ad-boxright\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"3\" data-object-name=\"boxright\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [300, 600]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-5\"><p>But its metaphorical life abandons the work that made death spirals in aviation avoidable\u2014the steady, mundane habit of cross-referencing one\u2019s fallible perceptions to the reality of the horizon. As a metaphor, the death spiral is all problem and no solution; it preserves the original\u2019s diagnosis but abandons its cure.</p><aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\">Logic that seems intuitive needs to be calibrated against measured reality.</aside><p>This absence seems particularly lamentable in current discussions of the ACA, given how intensely <em>felt </em>most people\u2019s policy positions seem to be. The death spiral works as a metaphor in this case because it fits neatly into a larger narrative of scarcity. That young healthy people are not buying health insurance on the exchanges seems a rational choice, given their <a href=\"http://fortune.com/2016/03/04/young-millennials-job-market-losers/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'21',r'542304'\">precarious</a> <a href=\"https://blogs.wsj.com/experts/2015/10/05/the-alarming-facts-about-millennials-and-debt/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'22',r'542304'\">financial</a> <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-unsexy-truth-about-millennials-theyre-poor\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'23',r'542304'\">state</a>. When the majority of Americans <a href=\"http://news.gallup.com/poll/191174/americans-financial-worries-edge-2016.aspx\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'24',r'542304'\">worry they will be unable to maintain their standard of living</a>, the idea that benefits like Obamacare are about to collapse under their own weight makes intuitive sense similarly to how aviators\u2019 bodies rationalize their false perceptions in the air.</p><p>The death spiral\u2019s lesson is that logic that seems intuitive needs to be calibrated against measured reality. The perception that the ACA is in a death spiral, for example, requires calibration against the realities of spending decisions and wealth distribution. America pays more than any other industrialized country for its health care, which nevertheless does less to extend its <a href=\"http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/20/524774195/what-country-spends-the-most-and-least-on-health-care-per-person\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'25',r'542304'\">citizens\u2019 lives</a>. <a href=\"https://www.nationalpriorities.org/budget-basics/federal-budget-101/spending/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'26',r'542304'\">About half</a> of the nation\u2019s discretionary spending <a href=\"https://www.cbo.gov/publication/52408\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'27',r'542304'\">goes to</a> the military. Great wealth is concentrating in the <a href=\"http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/01/07/5-facts-about-economic-inequality/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'28',r'542304'\">hands of a diminishing few</a>.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxinjector-wrapper\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxinjector3\" targeting-pos=\"boxinjector3\" class=\"ad ad-boxinjector\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"1\" data-object-name=\"boxinjector\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [300, 350], [1, 3], [320, 520], [320, 430], [1, 4], [1, 1], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[760, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1050, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1024, 350], [1, 3], [1600, 520], [1000, 350], [1600, 500], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-6\"><p>Against this horizon, the urgency and narrowness implied by the ACA\u2019s supposed death spiral looks less insistent. If the aviators win more options when checking their bodily impulses against the horizon, so too the citizenry might find more room to maneuver by expanding its view of possible maneuvers.</p><p>I don\u2019t mean to make this process sound easy; it\u2019s not. There\u2019s a reason that the aviator and writer Wolfgang Langewiesche, writing in <em>Harper\u2019s</em> in 1941, described instrument flight as \u201cthe castigation of the flesh translated into aeronautical terms.\u201d Orienting their bodies to a horizon that was obscured required pilots to resist the sensations that keep humans upright at every moment. Likewise, resisting the death spiral as metaphor requires pushing back against the normal and the everyday.</p><p>Metaphorical death spirals lure people toward forced (and false) choices\u2014choices that endorse actions in concord with fear. It\u2019s not that it feels good to believe disaster is imminent; it\u2019s that it feels <em>real</em>\u2014the perceptions bodies and minds feel intuitively ground people\u2019s thoughts and actions. Perhaps this is why the death spiral is such a powerful metaphor today, when catastrophe feels like the background to everyday life. But there\u2019s also hope in the death spiral: Crashes aren\u2019t inevitable\u2014so long as there\u2019s instrumentation to help find a horizon.</p><hr/><p><small><em>This article appears courtesy of </em><a href=\"http://objectsobjectsobjects.com\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'29',r'542304'\">Object Lessons</a>.</small></p></section>\n    \n    </div>\n\n    </div></body></html>"}, "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/05/world/europe/belarus-minsk-technology.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"story-body story-body-2\">\n        <p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"315\" data-total-count=\"2377\" id=\"story-continues-4\">Ten days after the awards, Facebook bought the company for an undisclosed sum. The founders, whose average age was about 25 at the time, moved to London and the United States. Together with some of those co-workers, Mr. Kovalyov is developing a new Minsk start-up, AR Squad, which creates augmented reality content.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"349\" data-total-count=\"2726\">One of the first masks the other company developed was one resembling Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, Belarus\u2019s president, who has ruled for more than two decades. He is prone to publicity stunts like picking potatoes at his estate or taking his teenage son, Nikolai, commonly referred to as Kolya, to sit at international meetings in a military uniform.</p><figure id=\"media-100000005477783\" class=\"media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000005477783 ratio-tall\" data-media-action=\"modal\" itemprop=\"associatedMedia\" itemscope=\"\" itemid=\"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/10/06/world/06Minsk3/06Minsk3-master675.jpg\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" aria-label=\"media\" role=\"group\">\n    <span class=\"visually-hidden\">Photo</span>\n    \n        <figcaption class=\"caption\" itemprop=\"caption description\">\n                <span class=\"caption-text\">Dmitri Kovalyov, an artist in Minsk, helped develop a tool that lets people superimpose various masks in selfie videos.</span>\n                        <span class=\"credit\" itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\">\n            <span class=\"visually-hidden\">Credit</span>\n            Siarhei Hudzilin for The New York Times        </span>\n            </figcaption>\n    </figure>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"275\" data-total-count=\"3001\">Mr. Lukashenko\u2019s mask featured his trademark comb-over hair and bushy mustache, but was not considered offensive. On the contrary, Mr. Lukashenko began to believe that the tech industry could become a magic wand to help him end the country\u2019s chronic dependency on Russia.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"280\" data-total-count=\"3281\">\u201cCreation of an IT state is our ambitious but reachable goal,\u201d Mr. Lukashenko said at a gathering of lawmakers and bureaucrats this summer. \u201cThis will allow us to make Belarus even more modern and prosperous and will let Belarussians look into the future with confidence.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"303\" data-total-count=\"3584\">Mr. Lukashenko, who once called the internet \u201ca pile of garbage,\u201d began to utter improbable words for a former manager of a collective farm \u2014 about the need to develop artificial intelligence, driverless cars and blockchain technology, which allows multiple parties to keep shared digital records.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"331\" data-total-count=\"3915\">His government has taken several steps to encourage the tech industry\u2019s development, like granting visa-free entry to citizens of 79 countries, including all Western states, when entering through the Minsk airport. Mr. Lukashenko also wants to lift restrictions on currency transfers to encourage venture financing for start-ups.</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"195\" data-total-count=\"4110\" id=\"story-continues-5\">Belarus produces top-level technical talent, an inheritance from its Soviet past, said Arkady M. Dobkin, who immigrated to the United States in the 1990s and established a software company there.</p><figure id=\"media-100000005477785\" class=\"media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000005477785 ratio-tall\" data-media-action=\"modal\" itemprop=\"associatedMedia\" itemscope=\"\" itemid=\"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/10/05/world/06Minsk5/06Minsk5-master675.jpg\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" aria-label=\"media\" role=\"group\">\n    <span class=\"visually-hidden\">Photo</span>\n    \n        <figcaption class=\"caption\" itemprop=\"caption description\">\n                <span class=\"caption-text\">The Minsk office of Viber, the call and messaging app, whose space is in a former industrial zone that has gentrified.</span>\n                        <span class=\"credit\" itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\">\n            <span class=\"visually-hidden\">Credit</span>\n            Siarhei Hudzilin for The New York Times        </span>\n            </figcaption>\n    </figure>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"193\" data-total-count=\"4303\">Today, Mr. Dobkin is the chief executive of EPAM, which does programing for the world\u2019s leading tech companies and is considered <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/pictures/59234347a7ea434078d44581/12-epam-systems/#48beb5557e16\">one of the fastest-growing</a> public tech companies in the world.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"141\" data-total-count=\"4444\">EPAM\u2019s headquarters is in Newtown, Pa., but its main development hub is in Minsk, where more than 6,000 of its technology specialists work.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"186\" data-total-count=\"4630\">\u201cI think it was the absence of oil that made Belarus do this,\u201d said Mr. Dobkin, 57. \u201cHere, universities produce more highly qualified specialists than the internal market needs.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"183\" data-total-count=\"4813\">Many locals say the government\u2019s talk about growing as a tech hub is a comfortable distraction in a country that <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/world/europe/belarus-russia-aleksandr-lukashenko.html?mcubz=0\">heavily depends on Russia</a> for cut-rate fuel and political patronage.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"119\" data-total-count=\"4932\">Sergei Chaly, an outspoken economist and former government official, calls Belarus \u201ca dying country with bitcoins.\u201d</p><figure id=\"media-100000005477786\" class=\"media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000005477786 ratio-tall\" data-media-action=\"modal\" itemprop=\"associatedMedia\" itemscope=\"\" itemid=\"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/10/05/world/06Minsk4/06Minsk4-master675.jpg\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" aria-label=\"media\" role=\"group\">\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\">\n            <span class=\"visually-hidden\">Credit</span>\n            Siarhei Hudzilin for The New York Times        </span>\n            </figcaption>\n    </figure>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"317\" data-total-count=\"5249\">Yevgeny Lipkovich, a popular blogger who made a career out of ridiculing Belarusian bureaucrats, said the only reason the tech industry had found some success in Belarus is that the government \u201ccannot seize people\u2019s brains.\u201d He joked, \u201cIf they want to capture an IT company, what would they get, computers?\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"255\" data-total-count=\"5504\">Politics doesn\u2019t seem a big concern for many in the tech crowd, even if young political activists use group chats on the call and messaging app Viber \u2014 an Israeli company whose development hub is in Minsk \u2014 to coordinate activities and plan rallies.</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"263\" data-total-count=\"5767\" id=\"story-continues-6\">Mr. Lukashenko\u2019s son is a fan of World of Tanks, a multiplayer online game developed in Belarus in which people fight in tank battles. With more than 200 million registered users across the world, it is <a href=\"https://www.superdataresearch.com/us-digital-games-market/\">one of the top 10 games</a> in terms of total digital revenue.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"145\" data-total-count=\"5912\">Tanks have an important cultural meaning for Belarus and other former Soviet states, where almost every family has an ancestor who fought in one.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"120\" data-total-count=\"6032\">\u201cHe plays tanks, but this is controlled,\u201d Mr. Lukashenko said of his son at a televised meeting with schoolteachers.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"182\" data-total-count=\"6214\">\u201cOne hour for tanks, 1.5 hours for music,\u201d the president added, explaining how he controls his son\u2019s time spent on the game. \u201cTwo hours for tanks \u2014 four hours for music.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"104\" data-total-count=\"6318\">\u201cFour hours is difficult,\u201d Mr. Lukashenko said, \u201cso he doesn\u2019t play for longer than one hour.\u201d</p><div id=\"addenda\" class=\"addenda\">\n    <div class=\"story-addendum story-content theme-correction\">\n        <strong> Correction: October 7, 2017 </strong> \n        <p>The Minsk Journal article on Friday about the sprouting technology industry in Belarus misstated the given name of a popular blogger who made a career out of ridiculing Belarusian bureaucrats. "15429736": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:06:36", "url": "https://www.citylab.com/equity/2017/10/the-heterogeneous-future-of-urban-mobility/541206/", "text": "<html><body><div><article class=\"l-article s-cms-content\" itemscope=\"itemscope\" itemtype=\"https://schema.org/NewsArticle\">\n    <meta itemprop=\"datePublished\" content=\"2017-10-06T12:42:51-04:00\"/>\n    <meta itemprop=\"dateModified\" content=\"2017-10-06T12:42:51-04:00\"/>\n    <meta itemprop=\"mainEntityOfPage\" content=\"https://www.citylab.com/equity/2017/10/the-heterogeneous-future-of-urban-mobility/541206/\"/>\n    \n\n    \n    \n<figure class=\"c-lead-image\" itemprop=\"image\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\">\n  <picture class=\"c-lead-image__image\">\n    \n      <source srcset=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/940.jpg?mod=1507307517\" media=\"(min-width: 1024px)\">\n    \n    \n      <source srcset=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/lead_large.jpg?mod=1507307517\" media=\"(min-width: 576px)\">\n    \n    <meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"128\"/>\n    <meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"300\"/>\n    <meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/300.jpg?mod=1507307517\"/>\n    <source srcset=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/300.jpg?mod=1507307517\" media=\"(max-width: 575px)\">\n    <img class=\"c-lead-image__img\" srcset=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/300.jpg?mod=1507307517\" alt=\"\" itemprop=\"contentUrl\"/>\n    <noscript><img class=\"c-lead-image__img\" src=\"https://cdn.citylab.com/media/img/citylab/2017/10/RTX3BDHV/300.jpg?mod=1507307517\" alt=\"\"/></noscript>\n  </source></source></source></picture>\n  <figcaption class=\"c-lead-image__credit\">\n    <span class=\"c-lead-image__caption\" itemprop=\"caption\">A French-made autonomous bus cruises through a university campus in Taipei.</span>\n    <span class=\"c-lead-image__attribution\" itemprop=\"creator\">Tyrone Siu/Reuters</span>\n    </figcaption>\n</figure>\n\n    \n\n    <div class=\"l-article__meta\">\n      <h1 class=\"l-article__hed\" itemprop=\"headline\">The Heterogeneous Future of Urban Mobility </h1>\n      \n    </div>\n    <p class=\"l-article__dek o-small-container\" itemprop=\"description\">The authors of <em>Smarter, Faster, Greener </em>talk about the technologies that will revolutionize how we get around cities.</p>\n\n    <section class=\"c-tmp-share-sponsored-container o-small-container js-action-bar-active\">\n      \n      \n    </section>\n\n    \n\n    <section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-1\"><p>The telecommunications ecosystem has come a long way from land lines and fax machines. The field is now crowded with a schmorgasbord of options, from WhatsApp to Facetime to Skype to email. In <em>Smarter, Faster, Greener</em> Venkat Sumantran, Charles Fine, and David Gonsalvez envision a similar transformation of the urban mobility ecosystem in the coming years. Once limited almost exclusively to cars in most American cities, urban mobility in the future will be defined by a diverse range of modes, from bike share to autonomous transit, as well as more traditional options like rail and walking. As scholars of business who have worked with the auto industry, it is notable that these authors are making such bold claims about urban mobility. In the lightly edited interview that follows, we discuss the technologies powering this revolutionary shift, and how even the most auto-dependent cities can adapt to it.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><strong>You are the nation\u2019s leading experts on cars <s>\u2013 </s>some of you are part of the same research group that literally wrote the book on the automobile industry, <em>The Machine That Changed the World.</em> Now, a couple of decades later, <em>Faster, Smarter, Greener </em>details a veritable \u201cperfect storm\u201d of factors that is ushering in a new era of urban mobility. Indeed, you have shifted your own focus from how industries work better and become more competitive to the mobility ecosystems of cities and metropolitan areas. What are the factors contributing to this \u201cperfect storm?\u201d</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><p class=\"ad-box-wrapper\" data-pos=\"box\"><gpt-ad id=\"box1\" targeting-pos=\"box1\" class=\"native\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"219\" data-object-name=\"box\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [1, 3], [320, 430]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[884, 0]\" sizes=\"[]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-2\"><p>Accelerated urbanization has concentrated economic activity in localized centers. As a result of a denser urban population, many of the world\u2019s cities are choking on congestion and ground level pollution, driving up health costs, and grid-locking economic growth opportunities. On the global scale, carbon dioxide pollution, which automobiles contribute to significantly, is degrading the conditions of life on our planet, both for humans and the ecosystems on which we rely.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Furthermore, a population increasingly comprising digital natives and digital immigrants has altered expectations of how they want to live and move. Their world is perpetually connected and their lives are increasingly dependent on new service models across a wide swath of economic activity. The underpinnings of cars are being transformed by electrification, connectivity and \u201csmart\u201d technologies. As these forces converge, they will cause a disruptive transformation of urban mobility.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><strong>You write that we must look beyond cars to a broader range of options, from transit to walking and biking and more, and that our conversation about transportation must shift from cars to mobility.\u00a0 I\u2019m sure our readers would like to hear more of your thinking on that.</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The idea that we need to transport a 165 lb human in a 3,300 lb car seems wasteful. We think that enabling greater heterogeneity of urban transit options is one of the keys to reducing dependence on the single person automobile.\u00a0 When walking, biking, buses, railways, sharing services, and a wide range of lower-carbon vehicles such as micro- and mini-cars co-exist with cars, and are connected in an urban environment, mobility options and utility can be enhanced significantly.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><p class=\"ad-box-wrapper\" data-pos=\"box\"><gpt-ad id=\"box2\" targeting-pos=\"box2\" class=\"native\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"219\" data-object-name=\"box\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [1, 3], [320, 430]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[884, 0]\" sizes=\"[]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-3\"><p><strong>One of the most interesting points you make in the book is that: \u201cAutonomous ride-sharing cars can be to cities what elevators are to skyscrapers.\u201d Do tell us more.</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>For a long time, many drivers had a virtual love affairs with their cars. Affinity to their brands, including emotional attachment for certain styling themes and product images, was encouraged by automakers through carefully crafted marketing messages. Very few people feel much emotional attachment to an elevator that takes them on a short ride from one place to another.\u00a0 To the extent that autonomous taxi services begin to diminish the emotional attachment of the rider, the form of design, branding, and marketing of automobiles may change dramatically<em>.</em></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><strong>You say that the new world of urban mobility is moving toward what you call a \u201cCHIP\u201d mobility environment\u2014meaning connected, heterogeneous, intelligent, and personalized. How can cities best ready themselves and regulate this shift?</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Cities can do a great deal. They can encourage innovators and make space for a multitude of mobility solutions including pedestrians, bikes, and ride-sharing services. They need to invest in better physical and digital connectivity and develop hubs that ease the transitions across heterogeneous modes.<strong> </strong>Many cities are embarking on \u201csmart-city\u201d investments which can help provide system and real-time data to support smartphone apps. Cities are beginning to understand that they have many new levers with which to motivate commuters to choose more efficient solutions.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><p class=\"ad-box-wrapper\" data-pos=\"box\"><gpt-ad id=\"box3\" targeting-pos=\"box3\" class=\"native\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"219\" data-object-name=\"box\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [1, 3], [320, 430]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[884, 0]\" sizes=\"[]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-4\"><p><strong>We hear a lot about electric cars, driverless cars and ride sharing. What are the key technologies powering the shift in urban mobility?</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The drive to electrification will lead to at least two major benefits: reducing tail-pipe emissions and carbon dioxide emissions. Ride-sharing contributes through increasing utilization of cars and can contribute to easing congestion in cities. The average car in the U.S. sits idle for 96 percent of its life. Increasing asset use will have economic and environmental benefits. Further, as we gain experience with driver-less cars, we may anticipate a future when cars may be summoned, used and released with a few taps on a smartphone. The shift to treating mobility-as-a-service can trigger significant changes in layout of urban spaces and the economics of mobility.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\">Societies will benefit if mobility architectures are inclusive across demographic and economic sections of the population.</aside><p/>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><strong>A huge part of the US economy is built around the car. You note that Peter Drucker called the auto industry, the \u201cindustry of industries.\u201d\u00a0 The US also has a huge stake in the oil, petroleum and fossil fuel economy.\u00a0 We have all sorts of incentives for driving cars\u2014from lower gas prices compared to other countries to subsidies for suburban sprawl. How can our economy make the shift to other modes? </strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Horse breeders suffered from the proliferation of Ford Model T\u2019s, and long-distance telephone service companies shrunk in the face of the internet. Around the world, astute automotive companies and astute city and regional planners are working to get ahead of the shift in focus from cars to connected, heterogeneous, intelligent, and personalized mobility solutions. Innovation not only brings disruption\u2014it also brings opportunities for growth and new businesses.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><p class=\"ad-native-wrapper\" data-pos=\"native\"><gpt-ad id=\"native1\" targeting-pos=\"native1\" class=\"c-native-container\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"213\" data-object-name=\"native\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[1, 2]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-5\"><p><strong>Which cities and regions in the world do you see benefiting the most from the shift in urban mobility? Will existing automotive regions in the US, Europe and Asia prevail, or will we see a shift in the industry clusters of the new \u201cmobility industry\u201d to tech hubs like the San Francisco Bay Area?</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>There can be two kinds of winners in this game. There will be those cities and regions that embrace the idea of connected, heterogeneous, and intelligent mobility architectures, build coalitions of companies, citizens, and regional planners to work together, and align policies and investments accordingly. These cities will win in the sense that they provide improvement for their citizens in healthy and pleasant environments, as well as greater opportunities for economic growth. We do see that possibility in cities such as Singapore and Hong Kong, and countries such as Switzerland. In emerging economies such as China, we see aggressive experiments in a broad range of options, from bicycle sharing to high speed rail systems.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>There will be other winners\u2014ecosystems that are able to nurture technological innovation, and foster business model experimentation. They will emerge as homes for new mobility enterprises that can scale their business globally. We see this in places like the Silicon Valley, Israel, Helsinki and Bangalore, to name just a few. Although cities do compete for attention from providers of human and investment capital, improving mobility is a game where every city can \u201cwin.\u201d</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><aside class=\"c-related-content u-full-width\"><h4 class=\"c-related-content__title\">Recommended</h4>\n  \n</aside><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-6\"><p><strong>The rise of new modes of shared transportation, pooled ride sharing services like Lyft and also newer services like Chariot and Via, are increasingly blurring the traditional lines between public and private modes of transportation. What are the promises and perils of this change?</strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Our marketplaces are constantly innovating and interpolating with new combinations and manifestations. So the rigid divide between public and private modes will blur. Chariot, for example is an Uber-like app-hailed, dynamically-routed ride-sharing van service for 6-12 passengers and often complements public transit. A larger number of heterogeneous options, especially when well connected physically and digitally, will improve the options for mobility users and enhance overall value.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n</section><p class=\"ad-box-wrapper\" data-pos=\"box\"><gpt-ad id=\"box4\" targeting-pos=\"box4\" class=\"native\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"219\" data-object-name=\"box\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [1, 3], [320, 430]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[884, 0]\" sizes=\"[]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container\" id=\"article-section-7\"><p>On the other hand, thoughtful regulations and policies will be required to assure relatively smooth transitions.\u00a0 Some countries have actually defined mobility as a basic \u201cright\u201d. In the process of experimentation, societies will benefit if mobility architectures are inclusive across demographic and economic sections of the population. Nobody wins when one disaffected group flexes its muscles to shut down all transit options in favor of retaining an inefficient status quo. Far-sighted stewardship is needed to ensure that regulations provide for fair and open competition.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><strong>There are very different baseline predictions for this new era of urban mobility. Urbanists see it ushering in a new era of density, urbanity, a blurring of the lines between home and work, as well as less car use and more transit, walking and biking.\u00a0 But others see a combination of driverless cars, high-speed rail and wireless connectivity enabling us to spread ourselves further and further out. So, which will it be? </strong></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>As Einstein observed, \u201cnothing changes until something moves\u201d. Mobility is the lifeblood of human civilization and we must foster ease of mobility in our cities, whether to the next block or the neighboring suburb. Some cities will move towards greater efficiency with a sense of haste and other will straggle.\u00a0 Some will be innovators and others will be followers.\u00a0 Some will put a greater emphasis on individual preferences and some on the collective good. All we can hope is that the preponderance of our brethren will move in a direction towards the well-being of the many. The future of humanity depends on that.</p>&#13;\n</section>\n\n    \n      <section class=\"s-article__section o-small-container c-foundation-line\">\n        <p>This article is part of a <a href=\"https://www.citylab.com/special-report/30-days-to-citylab-paris\">series</a> highlighting the themes of <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/live/events/citylab-2017/2017/\">CityLab Paris</a>, a convening of urban leaders.</p>\n      </section>\n    \n\n    \n<section class=\"c-authors-article o-small-container\">\n  <h4 class=\"c-authors-article__about-title\">About the Author</h4>\n  \n But if it weren't for a Federal Communication Commission (FCC) regulatory decision in 2001, we might all still be using it.</p> <p>Sixteen years ago, the FCC, the regulatory body responsible for things like television and radio, approved a merger between American Online and Time Warner, but with several conditions. As part of the deal, AOL was <a href=\"http://cnnfn.cnn.com/2001/01/11/deals/hold_aol/\" target=\"_blank\">required</a> to make its web portal compatible with other chat apps. </p> <p>The government stopped AOL from building a closed system where everyone had to use AIM, meaning it had to adopt interoperability\u2014the ability to be compatible with other computer systems.</p> <p>The FCC required AOL to be compatible with at least one instant messaging rival immediately after the merger went through. Within six months, the FCC required AOL to make its portal compatible with at least two other rivals, or face penalties.</p> <p>\"What interoperability said in 2001 was that the relationships you have on AOL messenger are your relationships. And if you want to use a different product to access those relationships, you can,\" Matt Stoller, a fellow at the <a href=\"https://openmarketsinstitute.org/\" target=\"_blank\">Open Markets Institute</a> told me on a phone call. </p> <p>The FCC's decision changed how we communicate with each other on the internet. By forcing AIM to make room for competition, a range of messaging apps and services, as well as social networks emerged. Instead of being limited to AIM, people who used AOL's portal could choose other platforms.</p> <p>The FCC imposed the restrictions on AOL because the merger with Time Warner created the largest biggest media business in the country. Government regulators feared that the behemoth would become a powerful monopoly, particularly when it came to instant messaging. At the time, AOL <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/12/business/fcc-approves-aol-time-warner-deal-with-conditions.html\" target=\"_blank\">had over</a> 140 million customers\u2014or <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2000/06/ms-to-aol-end-im-stranglehold/\" target=\"_blank\">90 percent</a> of the market\u2014 using AIM as well as its other chat service, ICQ, combined.</p> <p>The FCC's decision to force AOL to remain open provides a blueprint for how the government could similarly regulate today's gigantic internet platforms, like Facebook.<br/><br/> Stoller said you can look at Facebook\u2014with its <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/06/27/facebook-2-billion-users/\" target=\"_blank\">over 2 billion monthly users</a>\u2014as having egregious control over our relationships on the internet, or what he calls the \"social grid.\" If Facebook were forced to make room for other services on its platform in the same way AOL made room for other chat apps, new services could emerge.</p> <p>\"Facebook has to allow people to access their relationships however they want through other businesses or tools that are not controlled by Facebook,\" Stoller said. \"Having them control and mediate the structure of those relationships\u2014that's not right.\"</p> <p>Of course, people can opt out of Facebook and choose to use other, smaller social networks. But those businesses are essentially unable to thrive because of the hold Facebook has on how we communicate online. All our friends and family are already on Facebook, and because the platform is not regulated to allow competition, it's incredibly difficult for other, newer ones to emerge.</p> <p>Trying to build a competitor to Facebook in 2017 is \"just insane, it doesn't make any sense,\" said Stoller, who is writing book on the history of monopoly power in the twentieth century. \"It would be like starting a competitor to your local water company.\"</p> <p>The FCC's decision freed other companies to build new, better <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/pg9x5b/best-messaging-apps-ranked\">instant-messaging apps</a> without AOL standing in their way. And frankly, AIM wasn't able to keep up with them. The AOL/Time Warner merger turned out to be <a href=\"http://fortune.com/2015/01/10/15-years-later-lessons-from-the-failed-aol-time-warner-merger/\" target=\"_blank\">a disaster</a>, and AOL couldn't figure out how to <a href=\"http://mashable.com/2014/04/15/aim-history/?utm_content=buffer4e87e&amp;utm_medium=social&amp;utm_source=twitter.com&amp;utm_campaign=buffer#RB10Z146GPqA\" target=\"_blank\">make much money</a> from AIM, which was a free service.</p> <p>If Facebook were to actually compete in the market, it might die too. And in its place, something better, or at least different, could emerge.</p> <p>\"Think about all of the different types of social networking tools and platforms that people could make and innovate if they have access to the social grid,\" Stoller said.</p></div>\n            </div></body></html>"}, "15429739": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:06:46", "url": "http://www.mistatech.com/2017/09/mistatech-things-to-know-about.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-body entry-content\" id=\"post-body-2186531466457150203\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n<meta content=\" It is a known fact that almost 90 percent of affiliates earn less than hundred dollars per month.
