alt=\"Coverage Status\" data-canonical-src=\"https://coveralls.io/repos/github/shezadkhan137/required/badge.svg?branch=master\"/></a></p>\n<p>Required is a simple library which allows you to validate dependencies\nacross multiple fields. The goal is to make writing things like Forms\nand Seralizers much easier by providing a declarative way to encode\nyour complex validation logic.</p>\n<p>Most Forms and Serializers limit you to doing validation on a single\nfield, and then have one single <code>clean</code> method where you can do\nmuti-field validation logic. The problem with this is that if you have a\nlarge number of optional fields which depend on each other, your\nvalidation code can quickly become unreadable, unmaintainable and\nnon-reusable.</p>\n<p>The aim of Required is to do the following:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>To have a declarative way to encode validation logic</li>\n<li>Allow you to maintain extremely complex multi field validation logic</li>\n<li>Allow you to reuse your validation logic easily</li>\n<li>Be flexible with what you want to validate</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If this all sounds good. Read On!</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#installation\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-installation\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Installation</h2>\n<p>Install using <code>pip</code></p>\n<pre><code>pip install required\n</code></pre>\n<h2><a href=\"#quickstart\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-quickstart\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Quickstart</h2>\n<p>Lets start with a quick example.</p>\n<p>You want to validate some business rules on some optional input parameters (for example to a API endpoint or function). They are <code>start_date</code> and <code>end_date</code>.</p>\n<p>The business rules:</p>\n\n<p>Theses rules can be written with <code>required</code> as follows:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-python\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> datetime\n<span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> required <span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> Requires, R\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> start_date requirements</span>\nstart_requires_end <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>)\nstart_after_2017 <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span> datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2017</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>))\nstart_before_2018 <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span> datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2018</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>))\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> end_date requirements</span>\nend_requires_start <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>)\nend_before_2018 <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span> datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2018</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>))\nend_after_start <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> Requires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span> R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>))</pre></div>\n<p>The above introduces the two important concepts of required; the <code>Requires</code> and <code>R</code> objects.</p>\n<p>The <code>Requires</code> object is used to define pair-wise dependencies. It has two non-optional arguments, the first one is the target (key) of the constraint, and the second argument is the constraint itself. <code>Requires(\"start_date\", \"end_date\")</code> means \"start_date requires end_date to be present\".</p>\n<p>The <code>R</code> object acts as a placeholder for a future value. If you require a future value of <code>end_date</code> to be more than <code>start_date</code>, you would write it as <code>R(\"end_date\") &gt; R(\"start_date)</code>. Any such expression can be used as the constraint for the <code>Requires</code> object.</p>\n<p>The last step is simply summing all the  <code>Requires</code> together in order to combine the rules:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-python\"><pre><span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> combine all the rules</span>\nall_rules <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> (\n    start_requires_end <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span> \n    start_after_2017 <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span>\n    start_before_2018 <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span>\n    end_requires_start <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span>\n    end_before_2018 <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span>\n    end_after_start\n)</pre></div>\n<p>Once you have combined all the rules, you can simply call validate on the <code>all_rules</code> object with a dict of your data you want to validate.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-python\"><pre>data <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> {\n    <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>: datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2017</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>),\n    <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>: datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2017</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">9</span>),\n}\n\nall_rules.validate(data)  \n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> RequirementError: end_date requires end_date to be greater than start_date</span></pre></div>\n<p>The above not only tells you that the data was invalid, but which rule it broke. The following correct data passes validation:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-python\"><pre>data <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> {\n    <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>: datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2017</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>),\n    <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>end_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>: datetime.date(<span class=\"pl-c1\">2017</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>, <span class=\"pl-c1\">11</span>),\n}\n\nall_rules.validate(data)  </pre></div>\n<h2><a href=\"#cookbook\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-cookbook\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Cookbook</h2>\n<p>The following shows some recipes for forming validation rules with the <code>R</code> object.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-python\"><pre><span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> Arithmetic on the `R` object follows normal maths rules.</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">+</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>)\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">-</span> R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>y<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>)\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> A value `x` needs to be in an array</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>).in_(array))\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> The length of x must be 10</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>).length() <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">10</span>)\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> The length of x and y must be the same</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>).length() <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>y<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>).length())\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> when x is present y must not be present</span>\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> from required import empty</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>y<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> empty)\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> x must be equal to the return value of a function</span>\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> this is useful if what you are checking is against</span>\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> is non-pure eg. current time</span>\n\nf <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">lambda</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">x</span>: <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>\nRequires(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> Func(f, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>)))\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> the above can be used to ensure that a value is not in the past</span>\nR(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>, R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>start_date<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span> Func(datetime.now))\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> Partial dependencies can be also specified with R objects</span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> x requires y when x is equal to 1</span>\nRequires(R(<span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>x<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>) <span class=\"pl-k\">==</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">1</span>, <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>y<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>)</pre></div>\n<h2><a href=\"#contributing\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-contributing\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 (i.e Financial, Political, Technological, Environmental, etc. )</p><h4 name=\"b98d\" id=\"b98d\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Security To Go:\u00a0EISF</h4><p name=\"2045\" id=\"2045\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--li\">This set of short security risk management modules are focused on international humanitarian aid agencies. It is a highly structured template that is focused on international security. But, it can be useful even if you don\u2019t fill in all the different components.</p></div></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429232": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:11:55", "url": "http://www.fortmorgantimes.com/fort-morgan-local-news/ci_31360959/water-under-colorados-eastern-plains-is-running-dry", "text": "<html><body><div><div id=\"articleBody\" class=\"articleBody\"><p class=\"articleViewerGroup\" id=\"articleViewerGroup\"><span class=\"articleEmbeddedViewerBox\"/></p><p>WRAY - Colorado farmers who defied nature's limits and nourished a pastoral paradise by irrigating drought-prone prairie are pushing ahead in the face of worsening environmental fallout: Overpumping of groundwater has drained the High Plains Aquifer to the point that streams are drying up at the rate of 6 miles a year.</p>\n<p>The drawdown has become so severe that highly resilient fish are disappearing, evidence of ecological collapse. A Denver Post analysis of federal data shows the aquifer shrank twice as fast over the past six years compared with the previous 60.</p>\n<p>While the drying out of America's agricultural bread basket ($35 billion in crops a year) ultimately may pinch people in cities, it is hitting rural areas hardest.</p>\n<p>\u201cNow I never know, from one minute to the next, when I turn on a faucet or hydrant, whether there will be water or not. The aquifer is being depleted,\u201d said Lois Scott, 75, who lives west of Cope, north of the frequently bone-dry bed of the Arikaree River.</p>\n<p>A 40-foot well her grandfather dug by hand in 1914 gave water until recently, she said, lamenting the loss of lawns where children once frolicked and green pastures for cows. Scott has been considering a move to Brush and leaving her family's historic homestead farm.</p>\n<p>\u201cThis will truly become the Great American Desert,\u201d she said.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2012/01/16/water-worries-in-colorados-san-luis-valley-come-to-surface/\">agricultural overpumping</a> from thousands of wells continues despite decades of warnings from researchers that the aquifer - also known as the Ogallala, the world's largest underground body of fresh water - is shrinking.</p>\n<p>Even if farmers radically reduced pumping, the latest research finds, the aquifer wouldn't refill for centuries. Farmers say they cannot handle this on their own.</p>\n<p>But there is no agreement among the eight affected states (Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, South Dakota) to try to save the aquifer. And state rules allow total depletion.</p>\n<p>In fact, Colorado officials faced with legal challenges from Kansas over dwindling surface water in the Republican River have found that their best option to comply with a 1942 compact is to take more water out of the aquifer. The state bought wells from farmers during the past decade and has been pumping out 11,500 acre-feet of water a year, enough to satisfy a small city, delivering it through a $60 million, <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2013/12/20/pipeline-from-colorado-wells-may-ease-republican-river-water-dispute/\">12-mile pipeline northeast of Wray</a> to artificially resuscitate the river.</p>\n<p>The overpumping reflects a pattern, seen worldwide, where people with knowledge that they're exceeding nature's limits nevertheless cling to destructive practices that hasten an environmental backlash.</p>\n<h3>The drawdown</h3>\n<img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2c0px%2c100%2c9999px\" alt=\"cattle gather around a water hole ...\"/>\n<p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p><p>\nCattle gather around a water hole at a ranch north of Burlington on Sept. 12, 2017 in Burlington. The feeder stream from the South Fork Republican River, one of three tributaries that originate in the High Plains of Northeastern Colorado, is slowly drying up.\n</p><p>The depletion of the High Plains Aquifer has been happening for decades, according to bulletins U.S. Geological Survey has put out since 1988. Colorado farmers this year pumped groundwater out of 4,000 wells, state records show, siphoning as much as 500 gallons a minute from each well to irrigate roughly 580,000 acres - mostly to grow corn, a water-intensive crop.</p>\n<p>The depth where groundwater can be tapped has fallen by as much as 100 feet in eastern Colorado, USGS data show. That means pump motors must work harder to pull up the same amount of water, using more energy - raising costs for farmers. The amount of water siphoned from the aquifer since 1950 to irrigate farm fields across the eight states tops 273 million acre-feet (89 trillion gallons) - about 70 percent of the water in Lake Erie.</p>\n<a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg\"><img class=\" lazyload\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2c0px%2c100%2c9999px\" alt=\" \"/></a><p>Click the graphic to enlarge it\n</p><p>On one hand, the industrial center-pivot irrigation techniques perfected after World War II have brought consistency to farming by tapping the \"sponge\" of saturated sediment that links the aquifer to surface water in streams and rivers. America's breadbasket produces $35 billion of crops a year. On the other hand, intense irrigation is breaking ecosystems apart.</p>\n<p>Overpumping has dried up 358 miles of surface rivers and streams across a 200-square-mile area covering eastern Colorado, western Kansas and Nebraska, according to U.S. Fish and Wildlife-backed researchers from Colorado State University and Kansas State University who published a peer-reviewed report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The researchers also determined that, if farmers keep pumping water at the current pace, another 177 miles of rivers and streams will be lost before 2060.</p>\n<p>\"Intermittent streams are more likely to be dry. Permanent streams are more likely to become intermittent. Large streams are more likely to be small. Everything has changed,\u201d said KSU conservation biologist Keith Gido, one of the authors. \u201cWe have almost completely changed the species of fish that can survive in those streams, compared with what was there historically. This is really a catastrophic change.\"</p>\n<p>Disappearing fish species - minnows, suckers, catfish that had evolved to endure periodic droughts - signal to biologists that ecological effects may be reaching a tipping point.</p>\n<p>The amount of water held in the aquifer under eastern Colorado decreased by 19.6 million acre-feet - 6.4 trillion gallons - from 1950 until 2015, USGS records show. That's an average loss of 300,000 acre-feet a year. Between 2011 and 2015, records show, the water available under Colorado in the aquifer decreased by 3.2 million acre-feet - an annual average shrinkage of 800,000 acre-feet. Climate change factors, including rainfall, play into the rate of the drawdown.</p>\n<p>If all pumping stopped immediately, it would still take hundreds of years for rain-fed streams and rivers to recharge the aquifer, Gido said.</p>\n<p>\"We're not living in as sustainable a fashion as we need to be. Much of the damage has been done,\" he said, \"and restoring what we've lost could be difficult.</p>\n<p>\"It is happening all over the world in places such as Pakistan. It causes conflicts. As human populations grow, the demand for water is going to be greater. Conflicts are going to increase - unless we become more efficient in using the water we have.\"</p>\n<h3>Farmers locked</h3>\n<img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2c0px%2c100%2c9999px\" alt=\"rod lenz, president of the republican ...\"/>\n<p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p><p>\nRod Lenz, president of the Republican River Water Conservation District, walks pass a storage tank filled with water that will free-flow down a pipeline to a outfall at the Republican River on Sept. 12, 2017 in Wray. The water delivery is part of the Republican River Compact among Colorado, Kansas, and Nebraska.\n</p><p>For farmers, weaning themselves off groundwater is proving difficult.</p>\n<p>They say they're trying. They've reduced the land irrigated in eastern Colorado by 30,000 acres since 2006. They plan to retire another 25,000 acres over the next decade, said Rod Lenz, president of the Republican River Water Conservation District, who for years has advocated use of technology to grow more crops with less water.</p>\n<p>\u201cWe have come to realize that, yeah, we are overmining it. We are acutely aware of that now. There's a definite attitude to make more than just the natural progression as far as efficiency,\u201d Lenz said, noting state officials monitor pumping and determine how many acres owners can irrigate.</p>\n<p>\"We're constantly trying to find ways to stay in compliance,\" he said. \"We're looking at serious conservation.\"</p>\n<p>For years, agriculture experts have pointed to drip-irrigation technology to do more with less.  Federal agencies in the past dangled help for farmers who invest. But few in eastern Colorado have installed these systems, largely because they are expensive.</p>\n<p>Farmer and cattleman Robert Boyd, a leader of the Arikaree Groundwater Management District, said the federal government should intervene to ensure survival of High Plains agriculture.</p>\n<p>\"Do you want us to be sustainable? Or not? It may come to a point where no one can actually irrigate,\" Boyd said.</p>\n<p>He pointed to proposals to divert water from the Missouri River Basin and move it westward through pipelines across the Great Plains.</p>\n<p>\"If the federal government wants agriculture to be sustainable, they need to pump water back toward the mountains. They need to figure out how to get water back toward the higher parts of the rivers,\" he said. \"The federal government needs to step in and make the states work together to make agriculture - and urban areas - sustainable.\"</p>\n<p>For now, farmers struggle, increasingly weighing water uncertainties in calculations that include corn prices falling to around $3.50 a bushel in recent years from $7. But drawing down the aquifer does not violate any law in Colorado. The state engineer's office monitors well levels and requires permits for wells, limiting the number of acres a farmer can irrigate. But there's no hard limit on how much water can be pumped.</p>\n<p>In contrast, state rules limit <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2011/04/26/south-denver-suburbs-preparing-to-end-reliance-on-super-deep-wells/\">groundwater withdrawals from the Denver Basin Aquifer</a> - a source for many of Denver's <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2014/12/09/denver-suburbs-drawing-down-groundwater-aim-for-renewable-supply/\">southern suburbs,</a> including Castle Rock and Parker - to less than 1 percent a year. This is meant to help natural recharge keep pace with human demands.</p>\n<p>But on the High Plains, the situation is like mining intended to fully exploit diamonds or gold.</p>\n<p>\"If you want to have it all back the way it was 150 years ago, you would have to remove everyone from the area. I'm not sure how we could do that today,\" deputy state engineer Mike Sullivan said in an interview.</p>\n<p>Sullivan and state engineer Kevin Rein emphasized that thousands of acres no longer are irrigated. \"And there need to be some more retirements of land to get us into a more balanced situation,\" Sullivan said.</p>\n<p>They defended Colorado's practice of pumping more groundwater out of the aquifer, saying this is necessary to comply with the Republican River Compact. Disputes over river flows have risen as far as the U.S. Supreme Court and Colorado's legal obligations to deliver water to Nebraska and Kansas are clear.</p>\n<p>\"What we do with the pumping does help the streams,\" Sullivan said. \"It does provide a wet stream. \u2026 We could not meet our (legal) obligation without that today, even if we turned off all the wells.\"</p>\n<p>But there's no end in sight for the drawdown of groundwater.</p>\n<img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2c0px%2c100%2c9999px\" alt=\"dust flies up as oscar ortiz, ...\"/>\n<p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p><p>\nDust flies up as Oscar Ortiz, a pen rider at Cure Feeders, works with the cattle on Sept. 13, 2017 in Idalia. The Cure family ranch sold water rights to 54 of their wells to the Republican River Water Conservation District. The water from those wells is now pumped to a holding tank that will free-flow down a pipeline to a outfall at the Republican River as part of the Republican River Compact among Colorado, Kansas, and Nebraska.\n</p><h3>Nature exhausted</h3>\n<p>And for farmers who built their world on the High Plains Aquifer, the environmental fallout is increasingly painful. In the rural view, it is a problem that cannot be addressed by farmers alone without help from people in cities. All of the industrial <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2017/03/05/gravel-pit-colorado-farmers-agriculture/\">agriculture is done with urban residents in mind - the people who consume the crops and cows that farmers grow</a>.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe world population is going to double. And we're not going to be able to grow more farmland. We're losing farming ground every day to development,\" said Cody Powell, manager of 21st Century Equipment, the John Deere dealer in Burlington, an agricultural hub. \u201cYou take away farm ground for development, bring in more people. Who's going to feed them? The only way to do that is to put water on crops.\"</p>\n<p>People in cities increasingly demand environmentally correct crops, which requires more water. \"If they want natural grain-fed cattle, and non-GMO (genetically modified organism) crops - all that good stuff - it is going to take water,\" he said.</p>\n<p>A farmer can grow more by using pesticides and genetically modified seeds, he said. \"With the same amount of water, you could get twice as much corn.\"</p>\n<p>He knows too well the perils of <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2011/03/11/colorado-farmland-goes-dry-as-suburbs-secure-water-supplies/\">losing water. He grew up in southern Colorado's Arkansas River Valley</a> at a time when Aurora and other Front Range suburbs were buying up rights from farmers. This buy-up to slake growing suburban thirsts ended up killing agriculture across hundreds of thousands of once-irrigated acres.</p>\n<p>And now when Powell goes back, he sees communities \"overrun with thugs\" near where his grandmother lived. \"It makes me feel sick,\" he said.</p>\n<p>In eastern Colorado, the problem now is that <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2015/08/01/colorado-farmers-grow-more-food-on-less-water-amid-rising-competition/\">few can afford to invest in high-efficiency water technology, such as irrigation drip tubes and tape installed underground to eliminate evaporation losses, and soil-sensor systems that let farmers irrigate only when absolutely necessary</a>.</p>\n<p>Federal programs to subsidize installation of this technology have withered. And the overpumping continues.</p>\n<p>\"The fear out here now is not that the aquifer is going to get ruined,\" Powell said. \"The fear is that the state is going to shut off wells.\"</p>\n<p>And prairie residents practically cringe to see the pipeline northeast of Wray that Colorado uses to convey groundwater away to Nebraska and Kansas to prevent future lawsuits.</p>\n<p>The interstate compact was negotiated back when there was more water and far fewer people, they say.</p>\n<p>\"Now we just have weeds. We are feeling the effect of losing the water that Kansas is enjoying,\" Scott said from her farmhouse. \"It is robbing families of life. That's what is happening to us. We should be entitled to the water underground.\"</p>\n<img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2c0px%2c100%2c9999px\" alt=\"a single stock of corn stands ...\"/>\n<p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p><p>\nA single stock of corn stands in a field, in Yuma County, after harvest on Sept. 12, 2017 in Idalia.\n</p><h3>Past becomes future</h3>\n<p>The depletion means water scarcity increasingly dictates survival.</p>\n<p>It is no surprise to historians. In the 1860s, John Wesley Powell's surveys for the U.S. government warned that the land west of central Kansas was practically a desert. His report \"On the Arid Lands of the Western United States\" warned that the only way for people to live here would be by irrigating land. Otherwise, he wrote, the place could not support permanent communities. Tribes for centuries used the Great Plains seasonally as a hunting ground.</p>\n<p>Settlers flocked in during the 19th century, initially relying on dryland farming. This led to massive soil erosion, culminating in the Dust Bowl environmental disaster of the 1930s.</p>\n<p>Industrial irrigation took off during the 1960s, with tens of thousands of wells drilled through the 1980s.</p>\n<p>But now, if people keep pumping, the dry-out will intensify, CSU senior research scientist Kevin Bestgen said.</p>\n<p>\"I appreciate it that people now are trying to reduce pumping. The reality is that the bucket they are pumping from does not refill. It is finite. And in order to allow recharge of that aquifer, farmers are going to have to get much more severe reductions in pumping levels. It has been going down and down and down,\" he said. \"People are getting what they can. This will turn out to be a tragedy. It is in the culture at this point. People want to grow corn now.\"</p>\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15430257": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:06:56", "url": "https://www.mottocosmos.com/spring-beautiful-lethal/", "text": "<html><body><div><div><blockquote><p>April is the cruellest month,<br/>\nbreeding lilacs out of the dead land,<br/>\nmixing memory and desire<br/>\nstirring dull roots with spring rain.</p></blockquote>\n<p><strong>T.S. The Go language was conceived in September 2007 by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson at Google. Go first appeared in November 2009, and the first version of the language was released in December 2012. The official web site of the Go project is http://golang.org/. Go has its own elegance and programming idioms that make the language productive and fun to code. Go also provides a comprehensive standard library. The standard library provides all the core packages programmers need to build real-world, web and network-based programs. Go is a statically typed, natively compiled, garbage-collected, concurrent programming language that belongs primarily to the C family of languages in terms of basic syntax.</p>&#13;\n<p>The Go Programming Language is an open source project that is distributed under a BSD-style license to make programmers more productive. Go is expressive, concise, clean, and efficient programming language. Go compiles quickly to machine code yet has the convenience of garbage collection and the power of run-time reflection. It's a faster, statically typed, compiled language that feels like a dynamically typed, interpreted language.</p>&#13;\n<p>Go is a compiled language, and like many languages, it makes heavy use of the command line. Go is both the name of the programming language and the name for the toolset used to build and interact with Go programs.</p>&#13;\n<p>Go is a statically typed programming language. What that means is the compiler always wants to know what the type is for every value in the program. When the compiler knows the type information ahead of time, it can help to make sure that the program is working with values in a safe way. This helps to reduce potential memory corruption and bugs, and provides the compiler the opportunity to produce more perform-ant code. Go struct lets you create your own types by combining one or more types, including both built-in and user-defined types. Structs are the only way to create concrete user-defined types in Go. When you create your own types using struct, it is important to understand that Go does not provide support for inheritance in its type system, but it favors composition of types that lets you create larger types by combining smaller types. The design philosophy of Go is to create larger components by combining smaller and modular components. If you are a pragmatic programmer, you will appreciate the design philosophy of Go that favors composition over inheritance because of its practical benefits. The inheritance of types sometimes introduces practical challenges with regard to maintainability.</p>&#13;\n<p>In the last decade, computer hardware has evolved to having many CPU cores and more power. Nowadays we heavily leverage cloud platforms for building and running applications where servers on the cloud have more power. Although modern computers and virtual machine instances on the cloud have more power and many CPU cores, we still can't leverage the power of modern computers using most of the existing programming languages and tools. Concurrency in Go is the ability for functions to run independent of each other. Its concurrency mechanisms make it easy to write programs that get the most out of multi core and networked machines, while its novel type system enables flexible and modular program construction. When a function is created as a goroutine, it's treated as an independent unit of work that gets scheduled and then executed on an available logical processor. Goroutines are created by calling the Go statement followed by the function or method that you want to run as an autonomous activity. The Go run-time scheduler is a sophisticated piece of software that manages all the goroutines that are created and need processor time. The scheduler sits on top of the operating system, binding operating system's threads to logical processors which, in turn, execute goroutines. The scheduler controls everything related to which goroutines are running on which logical processors at any given time.</p>\t<div class=\"hidden\">\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"dateCreated\">2017-03-06T10:55:05+05:30</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\" dateModified \">2017-03-06T10:55:05+05:30</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"keywords\">go language tutorial, go vs python, google go game, go language wiki, the go programming language pdf, go language ide, go vs java, go vs c++</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"description\">The Go Programming Language, also commonly referred to as Golang, is a general-purpose programming language, developed by a team at Google.</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"creator\">Amit Arora</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"author\">Amit Arora</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"about\">Go Programming Language Tutorial</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"alternateName\">Golang Tutorial</span>\n\t\t<span itemprop=\"educationalUse\">Programming Tutorial</span>\n\t\t <p itemprop=\"aggregateRating\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/AggregateRating\">\n\t\t   Rated <span itemprop=\"ratingValue\">4.5</span>/5\n\t\t   based on <span itemprop=\"reviewCount\">11</span>\n\t\t </p>\n\t</div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429754": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:09:47", "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/drsarahbond/2017/10/07/were-pagan-temples-all-smashed-or-just-converted-into-christian-ones/#4439c19b4f9f", "text": "<html><body><div><div _ngcontent-c23=\"\" innerhtml=\"&lt;p&gt;How and why were pagan temples converted into Christian churches in the later Roman empire? New research focused on the city of Rome suggests&amp;nbsp;a more peaceful transition from paganism to Christianity, rather than the clash, bash and &amp;quot;fall&amp;quot; championed for hundreds of years.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2081&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2081&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Cornelius-the-Centurion.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;638&quot; data-width=&quot;1024&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Wikimedia &lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Depiction of Cornelius the Centurion, a gentile who converted to Christianity as related in the Acts of the Apostles. When forced to sacrifice to idols, he caused an earthquake that brought down&amp;nbsp;the temple and its statues (Menologion of Basil II, 11th c. CE, in Vat.gr.1613 of the Vatican Library)&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;In a new article in the&amp;nbsp;&lt;em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://muse.jhu.edu/article/670877&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Journal of Late Antiquity,&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/em&gt;ancient historian&amp;nbsp;Feyo Schuddeboom argues that&amp;nbsp;while the&amp;nbsp;&lt;span&gt;conversion of pagan temples into churches &amp;quot;has traditionally been explained as a symbol of Christian triumph over pagan religions&amp;quot;, we should perhaps begin to see these changes to temples as more pragmatic.&amp;nbsp;Put simply: Why smash when you can renovate?&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;The image&amp;nbsp;of incensed early Christian mobs destroying Greco-Roman temples comes in part from the early modern period. Back in the late 18th century, armchair historian Edward Gibbon provided a view of temple destruction that had lasting repercussions. In his epic work, &lt;em&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://play.google.com/store/books/details?id=M9QLAAAAYAAJ&amp;amp;rdid=book-M9QLAAAAYAAJ&amp;amp;rdot=1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/em&gt;he described the tearing down of the Serapeum in Alexandria as illustrative of the empire as a whole. He also described it as a direct assault on Roman idolatry: &amp;quot;The compositions of ancient genius, so many of which have irretrievably perished, might surely have been excepted from the wreck of idolatry for the amusement and instruction of succeeding ages.&amp;quot; As Schuddeboom points out, it was not until much later&amp;nbsp;that historians began to more systematically look at the archaeological remains of pagan temples and to present a reasoning for their destructions.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt; &#10; &lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2083&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2083&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Gibbon.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;Wikimed&quot; data-height=&quot;768&quot; data-width=&quot;713&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Public Domain &lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Portrait frontispiece of Edward Gibbon (1737-1794): History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (W. Strahan and T. Cadell London 1780).&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;Chief among these was archaeologist and art historian&amp;nbsp;&lt;span&gt;&lt;a class=&quot;fl&quot; href=&quot;https://www.google.com/search?biw=1126&amp;amp;bih=566&amp;amp;tbm=bks&amp;amp;tbm=bks&amp;amp;q=inauthor:%22Friedrich+Wilhelm+Deichmann%22&amp;amp;sa=X&amp;amp;ved=0ahUKEwiA1JiAyN7WAhXMOCYKHXgGBDEQ9AgIMjAB&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Friedrich Wilhelm Deichmann&lt;/a&gt;, who in 1939 cast temple destruction as aimed at showing the&amp;nbsp;&amp;quot;triumphing&amp;quot; of Christianity over Greco-Roman paganism. &amp;nbsp;However, archaeologists in Rome and elsewhere have now begun to adopt a more pragmatic view of Christian treatment of pagan temples; demonstrating that many were renovated, consecrated and then reused as churches rather than smashed to bits.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div class=&quot;vestpocket&quot; vest-pocket=&quot;&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2084&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2084&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/IMG_6031.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;768&quot; data-width=&quot;1024&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Sarah E. Bond&lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Nicola Denzey Lewis, Margo L. Goldsmith Chair in Women\u2019s Studies in Religion at Claremont Graduate University, discusses the Pantheon with students from Brown University this past summer.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;Schuddeboom looks at the evidence from Rome, which experienced the most temple conversions of any known city in western Europe. Conversion is often not widely known. Those visiting the Pantheon today are often surprised to discover that it was converted into a church called&amp;nbsp;Santa Maria ad Martyres (or Santa Maria dei Martiri) at the beginning of the 7th century. Schuddeboom lists the known churches within Rome&amp;nbsp;that used to be pagan temples: &amp;quot;There are altogether eleven known temple conversion sites in Rome, at the churches of San Bartolomeo all\u2019Isola, San Basilio, San Lorenzo in Miranda, Santa Maria dei Martiri, Santa Maria de Secundicerio, San Nicola in Carcere, San Nicola dei Cesarini, San Sebastiano al Palatino, Santo Stefano delle Carrozze, Sant\u2019Urbano alla Caffarella, and the oratory of Saints Peter and Paul (now Santa Francesca Romana).&amp;quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2085&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2085&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Relief-of-Mithras.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;768&quot; data-width=&quot;1024&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Sarah E. Bond&lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Polychrome relief of Mithras killing a bull from the mithraeum previously in the Castra Peregrinorum of Rome's foreign soldiers, over which was built the Basilica of St. Stephen in the Round (Santo Stefano Rotondo) on Rome's Caelian Hill. This relief is from the 3rd c. CE and is&amp;nbsp;in the Baths of Diocletian in Rome.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span&gt;In addition to these, there are three&amp;nbsp;Roman sanctuaries to the god Mithras, called &lt;em&gt;Mithraea&lt;/em&gt;, that Christian authorities built over with new churches. One of the most famous of these can still be visited today under the church of&lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Clemente_al_Laterano&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt; San Clemente&lt;/a&gt;, near the Roman Colosseum.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;When Christianity first began to spread within the city of Rome and elsewhere in the empire, particularly following Constantine's triumph at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge on October 28th of the year 312, the city underwent a period of new building.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span&gt;Schuddeboom remarks that there was a craze to build new structures rather than convert temples:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;quot;In the fourth and fifth century, there were no conversions of temples in Rome at all. Instead, all the evidence that we have points to the new construction of churches on a monumental scale.&amp;quot; Major basilica building was the focus of the emperor and bishops within the city, but that didn't mean they forgot about the old Roman temples.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;In the&amp;nbsp;fourth century, Roman emperors actually took steps to protect key&amp;nbsp;pagan temples: &amp;quot;That Christian emperors continued to protect the temple buildings of Rome is evident from their legislation. A law by Constantius and Constans, issued to the urban prefect of Rome, already prescribed that 'although all superstitions must be completely eradicated, nevertheless, it is Our will that the buildings of the temples situated outside the walls shall remain untouched and uninjured'&amp;quot; (&lt;em&gt;Theodosian Code&lt;/em&gt;, 16.10.3).&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;The building boom went hand-in-hand with policy. The emperor Theodosius outlawed paganism and all connected rituals in 392 CE. Yet, into the fifth century, temples in Rome were not destroyed it seems. Only various sanctuaries of Mithras were smashed and filled in with rubble at this time, before ultimately being used as the foundation for new churches.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2087&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2087&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Santa-Maria-Antiqua.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;768&quot; data-width=&quot;1024&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Sarah E. Bond&lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;The early medieval frescoes within the church of Santa Maria Antiqua in Rome were recently restored. The guard house of the Palatine Hill was converted into the church between 565\u2013578 CE.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;In the&amp;nbsp;sixth and seventh centuries was when a new policy began to take root concerning Christian temples. The earlier Gothic War and sacks of&amp;nbsp;the city meant that new building within the city was limited. New construction&amp;nbsp;focused on smaller churches and places called &lt;em&gt;diaconiae&lt;/em&gt;, where the poor could be given charity. Into the sixth and seventh centuries, however, a&amp;nbsp;number of buildings and then pagan&amp;nbsp;temples were converted in and around the Roman Forum: Vespasian's Forum&amp;nbsp;of Peace was converted into a church dedicated to the physician saints&amp;nbsp;Cosmas and Damian, a Roman guardhouse was revamped into Santa Maria Antiqua and the Roman Senate House (the &lt;em&gt;Curia Senatus&lt;/em&gt;) was made into a church called&amp;nbsp;Sant\u2019Adriano.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;Into the eighth and ninth centuries of the early medieval period, a number of churches were built essentially upon the podium ruins of earlier Roman temples. Rather than having many building smashed to bits by angry Christians because they were pagan, many temples were quarried for materials that could be reused (e.g. for expensive marble, bronze and valuable wood) and then churches were built upon them.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;While&amp;nbsp;pragmatic temple conversion&amp;nbsp;is a far less &amp;quot;fire and brimstone&amp;quot; narrative than Gibbon may have liked, it is one much more in line with the archaeological evidence. It also&amp;nbsp;supports the idea of transformation rather than a &amp;quot;fall&amp;quot;; an approach championed by scholars such as &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Brown_(historian)&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Peter Brown&lt;/a&gt;. While some pagan temples were indeed destroyed completely for their idolatry, Rome's remains would suggest that far more were simply converted,&amp;nbsp;restored and reused in a new, more Christian context.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;If only HG-TV had been around in the early middle ages for this type of house-flipping. We'd probably have a pretty great show on our hands.&lt;/p&gt; &#10;&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_2088&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;size-full wp-image-2088&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Curia-Senatus.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;683&quot; data-width=&quot;1024&quot; /&gt; &#10;  &lt;small class=&quot;article-photo-credit&quot;&gt;Alvaro de Alvaris&lt;/small&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;The Church of S. Adriano (previously the Roman Senate House) interior before archeological destruction in 1935 after being bought by Mussolini and deconsecrated to be turned back into the Roman Senate (as imagined by the Fascist regime).&amp;nbsp;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\"><p>How and why were pagan temples converted into Christian churches in the later Roman empire? New research focused on the city of Rome suggests\u00a0a more peaceful transition from paganism to Christianity, rather than the clash, bash and \"fall\" championed for hundreds of years.</p> \n<div id=\"attachment_2081\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2081\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Cornelius-the-Centurion.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"\" data-height=\"638\" data-width=\"1024\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Wikimedia </small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>Depiction of Cornelius the Centurion, a gentile who converted to Christianity as related in the Acts of the Apostles. When forced to sacrifice to idols, he caused an earthquake that brought down\u00a0the temple and its statues (Menologion of Basil II, 11th c. CE, in Vat.gr.1613 of the Vatican Library)</em>.</p> \n   </fbs-accordion> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>In a new article in the\u00a0<em><a href=\"https://muse.jhu.edu/article/670877\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">Journal of Late Antiquity,</a>\u00a0 </em>ancient historian\u00a0Feyo Schuddeboom argues that\u00a0while the\u00a0<span>conversion of pagan temples into churches \"has traditionally been explained as a symbol of Christian triumph over pagan religions\", we should perhaps begin to see these changes to temples as more pragmatic.\u00a0Put simply: Why smash when you can renovate?\u00a0</span></p> \n<p>The image\u00a0of incensed early Christian mobs destroying Greco-Roman temples comes in part from the early modern period. Back in the late 18th century, armchair historian Edward Gibbon provided a view of temple destruction that had lasting repercussions. In his epic work, <em><a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/books/details?id=M9QLAAAAYAAJ&amp;rdid=book-M9QLAAAAYAAJ&amp;rdot=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire</a>\u00a0</em>he described the tearing down of the Serapeum in Alexandria as illustrative of the empire as a whole. He also described it as a direct assault on Roman idolatry: \"The compositions of ancient genius, so many of which have irretrievably perished, might surely have been excepted from the wreck of idolatry for the amusement and instruction of succeeding ages.\" As Schuddeboom points out, it was not until much later\u00a0that historians began to more systematically look at the archaeological remains of pagan temples and to present a reasoning for their destructions.</p> \n<p> \n </p> \n<div id=\"attachment_2083\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2083\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Gibbon.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"Wikimed\" data-height=\"768\" data-width=\"713\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Public Domain </small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>Portrait frontispiece of Edward Gibbon (1737-1794): History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (W. Strahan and T. Cadell London 1780).</em></p> \n   </fbs-accordion> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Chief among these was archaeologist and art historian\u00a0<span><a class=\"fl\" href=\"https://www.google.com/search?biw=1126&amp;bih=566&amp;tbm=bks&amp;tbm=bks&amp;q=inauthor:%22Friedrich+Wilhelm+Deichmann%22&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiA1JiAyN7WAhXMOCYKHXgGBDEQ9AgIMjAB\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">Friedrich Wilhelm Deichmann</a>, who in 1939 cast temple destruction as aimed at showing the\u00a0\"triumphing\" of Christianity over Greco-Roman paganism. \u00a0However, archaeologists in Rome and elsewhere have now begun to adopt a more pragmatic view of Christian treatment of pagan temples; demonstrating that many were renovated, consecrated and then reused as churches rather than smashed to bits.\u00a0</span></p> \n<p class=\"vestpocket\" vest-pocket=\"\"/> \n<div id=\"attachment_2084\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2084\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/IMG_6031.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"\" data-height=\"768\" data-width=\"1024\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Sarah E. Bond</small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>Nicola Denzey Lewis, Margo L. Goldsmith Chair in Women\u2019s Studies in Religion at Claremont Graduate University, discusses the Pantheon with students from Brown University this past summer.</em></p> \n   </fbs-accordion> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p><span>Schuddeboom looks at the evidence from Rome, which experienced the most temple conversions of any known city in western Europe. Conversion is often not widely known. Those visiting the Pantheon today are often surprised to discover that it was converted into a church called\u00a0Santa Maria ad Martyres (or Santa Maria dei Martiri) at the beginning of the 7th century. Schuddeboom lists the known churches within Rome\u00a0that used to be pagan temples: \"There are altogether eleven known temple conversion sites in Rome, at the churches of San Bartolomeo all\u2019Isola, San Basilio, San Lorenzo in Miranda, Santa Maria dei Martiri, Santa Maria de Secundicerio, San Nicola in Carcere, San Nicola dei Cesarini, San Sebastiano al Palatino, Santo Stefano delle Carrozze, Sant\u2019Urbano alla Caffarella, and the oratory of Saints Peter and Paul (now Santa Francesca Romana).\"</span></p> \n<div id=\"attachment_2085\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2085\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Relief-of-Mithras.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"\" data-height=\"768\" data-width=\"1024\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Sarah E. Bond</small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>Polychrome relief of Mithras killing a bull from the mithraeum previously in the Castra Peregrinorum of Rome's foreign soldiers, over which was built the Basilica of St. Stephen in the Round (Santo Stefano Rotondo) on Rome's Caelian Hill. This relief is from the 3rd c. CE and is\u00a0in the Baths of Diocletian in Rome.</em></p> \n   </fbs-accordion> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p><span>In addition to these, there are three\u00a0Roman sanctuaries to the god Mithras, called <em>Mithraea</em>, that Christian authorities built over with new churches. One of the most famous of these can still be visited today under the church of<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Clemente_al_Laterano\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"> San Clemente</a>, near the Roman Colosseum.\u00a0</span></p> \n<p>When Christianity first began to spread within the city of Rome and elsewhere in the empire, particularly following Constantine's triumph at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge on October 28th of the year 312, the city underwent a period of new building.\u00a0<span>Schuddeboom remarks that there was a craze to build new structures rather than convert temples:\u00a0</span>\"In the fourth and fifth century, there were no conversions of temples in Rome at all. Instead, all the evidence that we have points to the new construction of churches on a monumental scale.\" Major basilica building was the focus of the emperor and bishops within the city, but that didn't mean they forgot about the old Roman temples.</p> \n<p>In the\u00a0fourth century, Roman emperors actually took steps to protect key\u00a0pagan temples: \"That Christian emperors continued to protect the temple buildings of Rome is evident from their legislation. A law by Constantius and Constans, issued to the urban prefect of Rome, already prescribed that 'although all superstitions must be completely eradicated, nevertheless, it is Our will that the buildings of the temples situated outside the walls shall remain untouched and uninjured'\" (<em>Theodosian Code</em>, 16.10.3).</p> \n<p>The building boom went hand-in-hand with policy. The emperor Theodosius outlawed paganism and all connected rituals in 392 CE. Yet, into the fifth century, temples in Rome were not destroyed it seems. Only various sanctuaries of Mithras were smashed and filled in with rubble at this time, before ultimately being used as the foundation for new churches.</p> \n<div id=\"attachment_2087\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2087\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Santa-Maria-Antiqua.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"\" data-height=\"768\" data-width=\"1024\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Sarah E. Bond</small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>The early medieval frescoes within the church of Santa Maria Antiqua in Rome were recently restored. The guard house of the Palatine Hill was converted into the church between 565\u2013578 CE.\u00a0</em></p> \n   </fbs-accordion> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>In the\u00a0sixth and seventh centuries was when a new policy began to take root concerning Christian temples. The earlier Gothic War and sacks of\u00a0the city meant that new building within the city was limited. New construction\u00a0focused on smaller churches and places called <em>diaconiae</em>, where the poor could be given charity. Into the sixth and seventh centuries, however, a\u00a0number of buildings and then pagan\u00a0temples were converted in and around the Roman Forum: Vespasian's Forum\u00a0of Peace was converted into a church dedicated to the physician saints\u00a0Cosmas and Damian, a Roman guardhouse was revamped into Santa Maria Antiqua and the Roman Senate House (the <em>Curia Senatus</em>) was made into a church called\u00a0Sant\u2019Adriano.</p> \n<p>Into the eighth and ninth centuries of the early medieval period, a number of churches were built essentially upon the podium ruins of earlier Roman temples. Rather than having many building smashed to bits by angry Christians because they were pagan, many temples were quarried for materials that could be reused (e.g. for expensive marble, bronze and valuable wood) and then churches were built upon them.</p> \n<p>While\u00a0pragmatic temple conversion\u00a0is a far less \"fire and brimstone\" narrative than Gibbon may have liked, it is one much more in line with the archaeological evidence. It also\u00a0supports the idea of transformation rather than a \"fall\"; an approach championed by scholars such as <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Brown_(historian)\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">Peter Brown</a>. While some pagan temples were indeed destroyed completely for their idolatry, Rome's remains would suggest that far more were simply converted,\u00a0restored and reused in a new, more Christian context.</p> \n<p>If only HG-TV had been around in the early middle ages for this type of house-flipping. We'd probably have a pretty great show on our hands.</p> \n<div id=\"attachment_2088\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> \n <div class=\"article-body-image\"> \n  <img class=\"size-full wp-image-2088\" src=\"//blogs-images.forbes.com/drsarahbond/files/2017/10/Curia-Senatus.jpg?width=960\" alt=\"\" data-height=\"683\" data-width=\"1024\"/> \n  <small class=\"article-photo-credit\">Alvaro de Alvaris</small> \n </div> \n <div article-image-caption=\"\"> \n  <div class=\"caption-container\" ng-class=\"caption_state\"> \n   <fbs-accordion current=\"0\"> \n    <p class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em>The Church of S. The code will also be integrated into the Symphony collaboration platform, which is widely used by financial institutions.</p>\n<p>The move is Deutsche Bank\u00e2\u0080\u0099s first contribution to open source technology, in which firms provide public access to computer code so that other programmers can suggest improvements and new ways of using it, for example to provide new services. It marks a further step in the bank\u00e2\u0080\u0099s strategy of modernising, simplifying and standardising its technology.</p>\n<p>The code, known as Plexus Interop, is designed to connect thousands of different applications from across the financial services industry, enabling banks and clients\u00e2\u0080\u0099 systems to talk to each other. Currently, many market participants use multiple applications for data, news and trading that work independently of each other.</p>\n<p>Feedback from clients suggested that they were keen to use a standard platform for trading applications that was not the proprietary solution of a single provider. Deutsche Bank reviewed the commercial products available in the market and decided to create a solution when none of them fulfilled its needs.</p>\n<p>Peter Wharton-Hood, Chief Operating Officer of the Corporate &amp; Investment Bank at Deutsche Bank, said: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe want to be a leader in open source technology in the banking sector. By making this code publicly available, we aim to create a common industry standard that will deliver a faster and more convenient service to clients, strengthen controls and reduce costs.\u00e2\u0080\u009d</p>\n<p>David Gurle, Founder and CEO of Symphony, said: \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are thrilled to be working with Deutsche Bank on the integration of this open source solution with Symphony. Plexus Interop represents the largest outside contribution to the Symphony Software Foundation since its founding, and underscores the power of the community and our strong partnership with Deutsche Bank.\u00e2\u0080\u009d</p>\n<p>This announcement will be made at Symphony\u00e2\u0080\u0099s annual platform conference, <a href=\"https://innovate.symphony.com/\" class=\"alertBox\">Symphony Innovate 2017</a>, held in New York on October 4.</p>&#13;\n                            </div>&#13;\n                        </div></body></html>"}, "15429759": {"score": 2, "comments": ["That\u2019s stupid"], "time": "2017-10-08 23:11:14", "url": "https://github.com/KrauseFx/watch.user", "text": "<html><body><div><article class=\"markdown-body entry-content\" itemprop=\"text\"><p \u2022\n  <b>watch.user</b>\n</p>\n<hr/>\n<h1><a href=\"#watchuser\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-watchuser\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" 6z\"/></svg></a><code>watch.user</code></h1>\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/KrauseFx\"><img Do you want to take pictures of the user and their surrounding whenever they use your app? Do you want to use face recognition, upload the video material of both the front and the back camera to your server and understand how the user feels? Then this project is for you.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#disclaimer\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-disclaimer\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Disclaimer</h2>\n<p><code>watch.user</code> is not intended to be used in production. It's a proof of concept to highlight a privacy loophole that can be abused by iOS apps. Apps shouldn't use this. The goal is to close this loophole and give its users better privacy controls for the iPhone camera access.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#what-does-watchuser-demonstrate\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-what-does-watchuser-demonstrate\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>What does <code>watch.user</code> demonstrate?</h2>\n<p>Most users often granted camera access to an app a while ago (e.g. a messaging app or any news-feed-based app). Those apps can easily track the users face, take pictures, or live stream their front and back camera, without the user's consent.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Get access to the raw front and back camera of an iPhone/iPad any time your app is running (in the foreground)</li>\n<li>Using the built-in iOS 11 Vision framework, a developer can very easily parse facial features in real-time like the eyes, mouth, and the face frame.</li>\n<li>Use the front and the back camera to know what your user is doing right now and where the user is located based on image data</li>\n<li>Upload random frames of the video stream to your web service, and run a proper face recognition software, which enables you to\n<ul>\n<li>Find existing photos of you on the internet</li>\n<li>Learn how the user looks like and create a 3d model of the user's face (literally)</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li>Estimate the mood of the user based on what you show in your app (e.g. news feed of your app)</li>\n<li>Detect if the user is on their phone alone, or watching together with a second person</li>\n<li>With the recent innovation around faster internet connections, faster processors and more efficient video codecs, a user probably won't notice if you live stream their camera onto the internet (e.g. while they sit on the toilet)</li>\n<li>Recording stunning video material from bathrooms around the world, using both the front and the back camera, while the user scrolls through your feed</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#proposal\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-proposal\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Proposal</h2>\n<p>The MacBook has an elegant solution, where a small LED turns on whenever an app accesses the camera.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Offer a way to grant temporary access to the camera</li>\n<li>Show an icon in the status bar that the camera is active, and force the status bar to be visible whenever an app accesses the camera</li>\n<li>Add an LED to the iPhone's camera (both sides) that can't be worked around by sandboxed apps</li>\n</ul>\n<p>TODO: insert Radar here</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#about-the-demo\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" could be anything, a feed to scroll view, a book to read, an in-app browser.</p>\n<p>The point of the demo is to show how an app can take pictures of you while you use it, once you give it camera permission.</p>\n<p>Chances are, you say:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>Oh, obviously, I never grant camera permission</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>However, the point is, that if you use a messaging service, like Messenger, WhatsApp, Telegram or anything else, chances are high you already granted permission to access both your image library (<a href=\"https://github.com/KrauseFx/detect.location\">detect.location</a>), and your camera.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#license\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-license\"><svg It was a thrilling, and exhausting, entrepreneurial experience and customers loved it! One catch, we didn\u2019t make any money.\u00a0</p><p>Since then I\u2019ve lived in Europe and USA, claimed a Guinness Book of Record and sold my Silicon Valley Startup. During these adventures in innovation and entrepreneurship, I\u2019ve had my share of hits and misses.\u00a0</p><p>When I reflect on my experiences of designing products and launching them into the world, there are patterns in the efforts that worked. There are four truths I have distilled that are the most holistic, essential rules for success.</p><h1>Rule 1: Great companies build great products</h1><p>People and the way they work together is the starting point for a great company. When teams are communicating well, that usually means clarity and high frequency; their positive energies can come together.</p><p>And culture, the way they hire, retain and grow people, can turbo charge that communication energy and create massive momentum. You know it when you see. A company starts to crush it on a regular basis. It becomes a habit.</p><p>And all of these endeavours add up to something bigger. A mission. A real, meaningful, positive contribution to the world. And that's the platform that launches great products into the world.</p><h1>Rule 2: Growth is a result of solving big customer problems</h1><p>Profits are a result of companies enormous devotion to solving a big problem.</p><p>Don\u2019t solve a small problem. On reflection, a mistake I made too many times. Instead, Search out significant, nasty, hairy problems that seem entrenched. Find a challenge that others are not trying to solve.</p><p>What I've learnt is that solving big problems creates value for the customer. And the customer is always happy to pay for value. And this value exchange means more than a short-term product-market fit. It means room to explore new opportunities in adjunct verticals. But most of all profits give companies the sacred fuel: cash flow.</p><h1>Rule 3: Testing and learning with customers inspires innovation</h1><p>The answer to great products lies with the customers. There\u2019s no excuse for guessing what *might* work.</p><p>Prototyping has been one of the most profound discoveries in my career. Thanks to prototyping expert <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d5_h1VuwD6g&amp;vl=en\">Tom Chi</a>. Creating a prototype and testing an idea with customers is the most powerful way to determine how a product can be successful.</p><p>When prototyping under the conditions that feel like real life we create a \u2018direct experience\u2019. The combination of the prototype and all the conditions make the test feel authentic to the customers. Hence, they provide visceral unfiltered, sub-conscious feedback. And this is gold.\u00a0</p><p>Take this feedback and learn from it. And then the real magic begins because you can iterate and test again. And again.\u00a0</p><h1>Rule 4: Tell a story worth sharing</h1><p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://startwithwhy.com/\">Start With Why</a> by Simon Sinek is one of my all-time favourite books. It is the best framework I\u2019ve ever used because of its simplicity and breadth of application.\u00a0</p><p>At the heart of his Golden Circle, is this idea: People don\u2019t buy what you do but how and why you do it.\u00a0Here\u2019s an example for Apple.</p><ul><li>What: We make computers</li><li>How: Our products are beautifully designed and easy to use</li><li>Why: We believe in challenging the status quo and doing things differently</li></ul><p>Once you have this idea, you can start by testing with customers. I\u2019ve found this to be a source of great insight. By testing different versions of what/how/why statements I\u2019ve made enormous progress with branding and storytelling before the company or product has even launched.</p><p>And the story will always continue to grow. You'll discover what messages work best. You'll find some channels will deliver better results. And hopefully, you'll find influencers and communities who want to share your story with others.\u00a0</p><p>When creating a new company or product, I advise that you focus equally on product and marketing. And become laser focussed on working with customers throughout the process. This honest, yet hard work, will yield tremendous opportunities.</p><p>And if the team is led by good people, who communicate and hold themselves to a higher standard. Then, you might find yourself enjoying success.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429250": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:15:40", "url":
