{"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:26:52", "url": "https://mobile.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/magazine/my-life-as-an-undocumented-immigrant.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body\"><p class=\"p-block\">One August morning nearly two decades ago, my mother woke me and put me in a cab. She handed me a jacket. \u201c<em>Baka malamig doon</em>\u201d were among the few words she said. (\u201cIt might be cold there.\u201d) When I arrived at the Philippines\u2019 Ninoy Aquino International Airport with her, my aunt and a family friend, I was introduced to a man I\u2019d never seen. They told me he was my uncle. He held my hand as I boarded an airplane for the first time. It was 1993, and I was 12.</p><p class=\"p-block\">My mother wanted to give me a better life, so she sent me thousands of miles away to live with her parents in America \u2014 my grandfather (<em>Lolo</em> in Tagalog) and grandmother (<em>Lola</em>). After I arrived in Mountain View, Calif., in the San Francisco Bay Area, I entered sixth grade and quickly grew to love my new home, family and culture. I discovered a passion for language, though it was hard to learn the difference between formal English and American slang. One of my early memories is of a freckled kid in middle school asking me, \u201cWhat\u2019s up?\u201d I replied, \u201cThe sky,\u201d and he and a couple of other kids laughed. I won the eighth-grade spelling bee by memorizing words I couldn\u2019t properly pronounce. (The winning word was \u201cindefatigable.\u201d)</p><p class=\"p-block\">One day when I was 16, I rode my bike to the nearby D.M.V. office to get my driver\u2019s permit. Some of my friends already had their licenses, so I figured it was time. But when I handed the clerk my green card as proof of U.S. residency, she flipped it around, examining it. \u201cThis is fake,\u201d she whispered. \u201cDon\u2019t come back here again.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">Confused and scared, I pedaled home and confronted Lolo. I remember him sitting in the garage, cutting coupons. I dropped my bike and ran over to him, showing him the green card. \u201c<em>Peke ba ito</em>?\u201d I asked in Tagalog. (\u201cIs this fake?\u201d) My grandparents were naturalized American citizens \u2014 he worked as a security guard, she as a food server \u2014 and they had begun supporting my mother and me financially when I was 3, after my father\u2019s wandering eye and inability to properly provide for us led to my parents\u2019 separation. Lolo was a proud man, and I saw the shame on his face as he told me he purchased the card, along with other fake documents, for me. \u201cDon\u2019t show it to other people,\u201d he warned.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"4\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I decided then that I could never give anyone reason to doubt I was an American. I convinced myself that if I worked enough, if I achieved enough, I would be rewarded with citizenship. I felt I could earn it.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"5\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I\u2019ve tried. Over the past 14 years, I\u2019ve graduated from high school and college and built a career as a journalist, interviewing some of the most famous people in the country. On the surface, I\u2019ve created a good life. I\u2019ve lived the American dream.</p><p class=\"p-block\">But I am still an undocumented immigrant. And that means living a different kind of reality. It means going about my day in fear of being found out. It means rarely trusting people, even those closest to me, with who I really am. It means keeping my family photos in a shoebox rather than displaying them on shelves in my home, so friends don\u2019t ask about them. It means reluctantly, even painfully, doing things I know are wrong and unlawful. And it has meant relying on a sort of 21st-century underground railroad of supporters, people who took an interest in my future and took risks for me.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Last year I read about four students who walked from Miami to Washington to lobby for the Dream Act, a nearly decade-old immigration bill that would provide a path to legal permanent residency for young people who have been educated in this country. At the risk of deportation \u2014 the Obama administration has deported almost 800,000 people in the last two years \u2014 they are speaking out. Their courage has inspired me.</p><p class=\"p-block\">There are believed to be 11 million undocumented immigrants in the United States. We\u2019re not always who you think we are. Some pick your strawberries or care for your children. Some are in high school or college. And some, it turns out, write news articles you might read. I grew up here. This is my home. Yet even though I think of myself as an American and consider America my country, my country doesn\u2019t think of me as one of its own.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u00a0</p><p class=\"p-block\"><strong>My first challenge</strong> was the language. Though I learned English in the Philippines, I wanted to lose my accent. During high school, I spent hours at a time watching television (especially \u201cFrasier,\u201d \u201cHome Improvement\u201d and reruns of \u201cThe Golden Girls\u201d) and movies (from \u201cGoodfellas\u201d to \u201cAnne of Green Gables\u201d), pausing the VHS to try to copy how various characters enunciated their words. At the local library, I read magazines, books and newspapers \u2014 anything to learn how to write better. Kathy Dewar, my high-school English teacher, introduced me to journalism. From the moment I wrote my first article for the student paper, I convinced myself that having my name in print \u2014 writing in English, interviewing Americans \u2014 validated my presence here.</p><p class=\"p-block\">The debates over \u201cillegal aliens\u201d intensified my anxieties. In 1994, only a year after my flight from the Philippines, Gov. Pete Wilson was re-elected in part because of his support for Proposition 187, which prohibited undocumented immigrants from attending public school and accessing other services. (A federal court later found the law unconstitutional.) After my encounter at the D.M.V. in 1997, I grew more aware of anti-immigrant sentiments and stereotypes: <em>they don\u2019t want to assimilate, they are a drain on society. </em>They\u2019re not talking about me, I would tell myself. I have something to contribute.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"12\"/><p class=\"p-block\">To do that, I had to work \u2014 and for that, I needed a <a href=\"http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/s/social_security_us/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier\" title=\"More articles about Social Security.\" class=\"meta-classifier\">Social Security</a> number. Fortunately, my grandfather had already managed to get one for me. Lolo had always taken care of everyone in the family. He and my grandmother emigrated legally in 1984 from Zambales, a province in the Philippines of rice fields and bamboo houses\u00ad, following Lolo\u2019s sister, who married a Filipino-American serving in the American military. She petitioned for her brother and his wife to join her. When they got here, Lolo petitioned for his two children \u2014 my mother and her younger brother \u2014 to follow them. But instead of mentioning that my mother was a married woman, he listed her as single. Legal residents can\u2019t petition for their married children. Besides, Lolo didn\u2019t care for my father. He didn\u2019t want him coming here too.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"13\"/><p class=\"p-block\">But soon Lolo grew nervous that the immigration authorities reviewing the petition would discover my mother was married, thus derailing not only her chances of coming here but those of my uncle as well. So he withdrew her petition. After my uncle came to America legally in 1991, Lolo tried to get my mother here through a tourist visa, but she wasn\u2019t able to obtain one. That\u2019s when she decided to send me. My mother told me later that she figured she would follow me soon. She never did.</p><p class=\"p-block\">The \u201cuncle\u201d who brought me here turned out to be a coyote, not a relative, my grandfather later explained. Lolo scraped together enough money \u2014 I eventually learned it was $4,500, a huge sum for him \u2014 to pay him to smuggle me here under a fake name and fake passport. (I never saw the passport again after the flight and have always assumed that the coyote kept it.) After I arrived in America, Lolo obtained a new fake Filipino passport, in my real name this time, adorned with a fake student visa, in addition to the fraudulent green card.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Using the fake passport, we went to the local Social Security Administration office and applied for a Social Security number and card. It was, I remember, a quick visit. When the card came in the mail, it had my full, real name, but it also clearly stated: \u201cValid for work only with I.N.S. authorization.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">When I began looking for work, a short time after the D.M.V. incident, my grandfather and I took the Social Security card to Kinko\u2019s, where he covered the \u201cI.N.S. authorization\u201d text with a sliver of white tape. We then made photocopies of the card. At a glance, at least, the copies would look like copies of a regular, unrestricted Social Security card.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Lolo always imagined I would work the kind of low-paying jobs that undocumented people often take. (Once I married an American, he said, I would get my real papers, and everything would be fine.) But even menial jobs require documents, so he and I hoped the doctored card would work for now. The more documents I had, he said, the better.</p><p class=\"p-block\">While in high school, I worked part time at Subway, then at the front desk of the local Y.M.C.A., then at a tennis club, until I landed an unpaid internship at The Mountain View Voice, my hometown newspaper. First I brought coffee and helped around the office; eventually I began covering city-hall meetings and other assignments for pay.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"19\"/><p class=\"p-block\">For more than a decade of getting part-time and full-time jobs, employers have rarely asked to check my original Social Security card. When they did, I showed the photocopied version, which they accepted. Over time, I also began checking the citizenship box on my federal I-9 employment eligibility forms. (Claiming full citizenship was actually easier than declaring permanent resident \u201cgreen card\u201d status, which would have required me to provide an alien registration number.)</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"20\"/><p class=\"p-block\">This deceit never got easier. The more I did it, the more I felt like an impostor, the more guilt I carried \u2014 and the more I worried that I would get caught. But I kept doing it. I needed to live and survive on my own, and I decided this was the way.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Mountain View High School became my second home. I was elected to represent my school at school-board meetings, which gave me the chance to meet and befriend Rich Fischer, the superintendent for our school district. I joined the speech and debate team, acted in school plays and eventually became co-editor of The Oracle, the student newspaper. That drew the attention of my principal, Pat Hyland. \u201cYou\u2019re at school just as much as I am,\u201d she told me. Pat and Rich would soon become mentors, and over time, almost surrogate parents for me.</p><p class=\"p-block\">After a choir rehearsal during my junior year, Jill Denny, the choir director, told me she was considering a Japan trip for our singing group. I told her I couldn\u2019t afford it, but she said we\u2019d figure out a way. I hesitated, and then decided to tell her the truth. \u201cIt\u2019s not really the money,\u201d I remember saying. \u201cI don\u2019t have the right passport.\u201d When she assured me we\u2019d get the proper documents, I finally told her. \u201cI can\u2019t get the right passport,\u201d I said. \u201cI\u2019m not supposed to be here.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">She understood. So the choir toured Hawaii instead, with me in tow. (Mrs. Denny and I spoke a couple of months ago, and she told me she hadn\u2019t wanted to leave any student behind.)</p><p class=\"p-block\">Later that school year, my history class watched a documentary on Harvey Milk, the openly gay San Francisco city official who was assassinated. This was 1999, just six months after Matthew Shepard\u2019s body was found tied to a fence in Wyoming. During the discussion, I raised my hand and said something like: \u201cI\u2019m sorry Harvey Milk got killed for being gay. . . . I\u2019ve been meaning to say this. . . . I\u2019m gay.\u201d</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"25\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I hadn\u2019t planned on coming out that morning, though I had known that I was gay for several years. With that announcement, I became the only openly gay student at school, and it caused turmoil with my grandparents. Lolo kicked me out of the house for a few weeks. Though we eventually reconciled, I had disappointed him on two fronts. First, as a Catholic, he considered homosexuality a sin and was embarrassed about having \u201c<em>ang apo na bakla</em>\u201d (\u201ca grandson who is gay\u201d). Even worse, I was making matters more difficult for myself, he said. I needed to marry an American woman in order to gain a green card.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"26\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Tough as it was, coming out about being gay seemed less daunting than coming out about my legal status. I kept my other secret mostly hidden.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u00a0</p><p class=\"p-block\"><strong>While my classmates</strong> awaited their college acceptance letters, I hoped to get a full-time job at The Mountain View Voice after graduation. It\u2019s not that I didn\u2019t want to go to college, but I couldn\u2019t apply for state and federal financial aid. Without that, my family couldn\u2019t afford to send me.</p><p class=\"p-block\">But when I finally told Pat and Rich about my immigration \u201cproblem\u201d \u2014 as we called it from then on \u2014 they helped me look for a solution. At first, they even wondered if one of them could adopt me and fix the situation that way, but a lawyer Rich consulted told him it wouldn\u2019t change my legal status because I was too old. Eventually they connected me to a new scholarship fund for high-potential students who were usually the first in their families to attend college. Most important, the fund was not concerned with immigration status. I was among the first recipients, with the scholarship covering tuition, lodging, books and other expenses for my studies at San Francisco State University.</p><p class=\"p-block\">As a college freshman, I found a job working part time at The San Francisco Chronicle, where I sorted mail and wrote some freelance articles. My ambition was to get a reporting job, so I embarked on a series of internships. First I landed at The Philadelphia Daily News, in the summer of 2001, where I covered a drive-by shooting and the wedding of the 76ers star Allen Iverson. Using those articles, I applied to The Seattle Times and got an internship for the following summer.</p><p class=\"p-block\">But then my lack of proper documents became a problem again. The Times\u2019s recruiter, Pat Foote, asked all incoming interns to bring certain paperwork on their first day: a birth certificate, or a passport, or a driver\u2019s license plus an original Social Security card. I panicked, thinking my documents wouldn\u2019t pass muster. So before starting the job, I called Pat and told her about my legal status. After consulting with management, she called me back with the answer I feared: I couldn\u2019t do the internship.</p><p class=\"p-block\">This was devastating. What good was college if I couldn\u2019t then pursue the career I wanted? I decided then that if I was to succeed in a profession that is all about truth-telling, I couldn\u2019t tell the truth about myself.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"33\"/><p class=\"p-block\">After this episode, Jim Strand, the venture capitalist who sponsored my scholarship, offered to pay for an immigration lawyer. Rich and I went to meet her in San Francisco\u2019s financial district.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"34\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I was hopeful. This was in early 2002, shortly after Senators Orrin Hatch, the Utah Republican, and Dick Durbin, the Illinois Democrat, introduced the Dream Act \u2014 Development, Relief and Education for Alien Minors. It seemed like the legislative version of what I\u2019d told myself: If I work hard and contribute, things will work out.</p><p class=\"p-block\">But the meeting left me crushed. My only solution, the lawyer said, was to go back to the Philippines and accept a 10-year ban before I could apply to return legally.</p><p class=\"p-block\">If Rich was discouraged, he hid it well. \u201cPut this problem on a shelf,\u201d he told me. \u201cCompartmentalize it. Keep going.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">And I did. For the summer of 2003, I applied for internships across the country. Several newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal, The Boston Globe and The Chicago Tribune, expressed interest. But when The Washington Post offered me a spot, I knew where I would go. And this time, I had no intention of acknowledging my \u201cproblem.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">The Post internship posed a tricky obstacle: It required a driver\u2019s license. (After my close call at the California D.M.V., I\u2019d never gotten one.) So I spent an afternoon at The Mountain View Public Library, studying various states\u2019 requirements. Oregon was among the most welcoming \u2014 and it was just a few hours\u2019 drive north.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Again, my support network came through. A friend\u2019s father lived in Portland, and he allowed me to use his address as proof of residency. Pat, Rich and Rich\u2019s longtime assistant, Mary Moore, sent letters to me at that address. Rich taught me how to do three-point turns in a parking lot, and a friend accompanied me to Portland.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"40\"/><p class=\"p-block\">The license meant everything to me \u2014 it would let me drive, fly and work. But my grandparents worried about the Portland trip and the Washington internship. While Lola offered daily prayers so that I would not get caught, Lolo told me that I was dreaming too big, risking too much.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"41\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I was determined to pursue my ambitions. I was 22, I told them, responsible for my own actions. But this was different from Lolo\u2019s driving a confused teenager to Kinko\u2019s. I knew what I was doing now, and I knew it wasn\u2019t right. But what was I supposed to do?</p><p class=\"p-block\">I was paying state and federal taxes, but I was using an invalid Social Security card and writing false information on my employment forms. But that seemed better than depending on my grandparents or on Pat, Rich and Jim \u2014 or returning to a country I barely remembered. I convinced myself all would be O.K. if I lived up to the qualities of a \u201ccitizen\u201d: hard work, self-reliance, love of my country.</p><p class=\"p-block\">At the D.M.V. in Portland, I arrived with my photocopied Social Security card, my college I.D., a pay stub from The San Francisco Chronicle and my proof of state residence \u2014 the letters to the Portland address that my support network had sent. It worked. My license, issued in 2003, was set to expire eight years later, on my 30th birthday, on Feb. 3, 2011. I had eight years to succeed professionally, and to hope that some sort of immigration reform would pass in the meantime and allow me to stay.</p><p class=\"p-block\">It seemed like all the time in the world.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u00a0</p><p class=\"p-block\"><strong>My summer in</strong> Washington was exhilarating. I was intimidated to be in a major newsroom but was assigned a mentor \u2014 Peter Perl, a veteran magazine writer \u2014 to help me navigate it. A few weeks into the internship, he printed out one of my articles, about a guy who recovered a long-lost wallet, circled the first two paragraphs and left it on my desk. \u201cGreat eye for details \u2014 awesome!\u201d he wrote. Though I didn\u2019t know it then, Peter would become one more member of my network.</p><p class=\"p-block\">At the end of the summer, I returned to The San Francisco Chronicle. My plan was to finish school \u2014 I was now a senior \u2014 while I worked for The Chronicle as a reporter for the city desk. But when The Post beckoned again, offering me a full-time, two-year paid internship that I could start when I graduated in June 2004, it was too tempting to pass up. I moved back to Washington.</p><p class=\"p-block\">About four months into my job as a reporter for The Post, I began feeling increasingly paranoid, as if I had \u201cillegal immigrant\u201d tattooed on my forehead \u2014 and in Washington, of all places, where the debates over immigration seemed never-ending. I was so eager to prove myself that I feared I was annoying some colleagues and editors \u2014 and worried that any one of these professional journalists could discover my secret. The anxiety was nearly paralyzing. I decided I had to tell one of the higher-ups about my situation. I turned to Peter.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"49\"/><p class=\"p-block\">By this time, Peter, who still works at The Post, had become part of management as the paper\u2019s director of newsroom training and professional development. One afternoon in late October, we walked a couple of blocks to Lafayette Square, across from the White House. Over some 20 minutes, sitting on a bench, I told him everything: the Social Security card, the driver\u2019s license, Pat and Rich, my family.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"50\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Peter was shocked. \u201cI understand you 100 times better now,\u201d he said. He told me that I had done the right thing by telling him, and that it was now our shared problem. He said he didn\u2019t want to do anything about it just yet. I had just been hired, he said, and I needed to prove myself. \u201cWhen you\u2019ve done enough,\u201d he said, \u201cwe\u2019ll tell Don and Len together.\u201d (Don Graham is the chairman of The Washington Post Company; Leonard Downie Jr. was then the paper\u2019s executive editor.) A month later, I spent my first Thanksgiving in Washington with Peter and his family.</p><p class=\"p-block\">In the five years that followed, I did my best to \u201cdo enough.\u201d I was promoted to staff writer, reported on video-game culture, wrote a series on Washington\u2019s H.I.V./AIDS epidemic and covered the role of technology and social media in the 2008 presidential race. I visited the White House, where I interviewed senior aides and covered a state dinner \u2014 and gave the Secret Service the Social Security number I obtained with false documents.</p><p class=\"p-block\">I did my best to steer clear of reporting on immigration policy but couldn\u2019t always avoid it. On two occasions, I wrote about Hillary Clinton\u2019s position on driver\u2019s licenses for undocumented immigrants. I also wrote an article about Senator Mel Martinez of Florida, then the chairman of the Republican National Committee, who was defending his party\u2019s stance toward Latinos after only one Republican presidential candidate \u2014 John McCain, the co-author of a failed immigration bill \u2014 agreed to participate in a debate sponsored by Univision, the Spanish-language network.</p><p class=\"p-block\">It was an odd sort of dance: I was trying to stand out in a highly competitive newsroom, yet I was terrified that if I stood out too much, I\u2019d invite unwanted scrutiny. I tried to compartmentalize my fears, distract myself by reporting on the lives of other people, but there was no escaping the central conflict in my life. Maintaining a deception for so long distorts your sense of self. You start wondering who you\u2019ve become, and why.</p><p class=\"p-block\">In April 2008, I was part of a Post team that won a <a href=\"http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/p/pulitzer_prizes/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier\" title=\"More articles about the Pulitzer Prizes.\" class=\"meta-classifier\">Pulitzer Prize</a> for the paper\u2019s coverage of the Virginia Tech shootings a year earlier. Lolo died a year earlier, so it was Lola who called me the day of the announcement. The first thing she said was, \u201c<em>Anong mangyayari kung malaman ng mga tao</em>?\u201d</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"55\"/><p class=\"p-block\">What will happen if people find out?</p><p class=\"p-block\">I couldn\u2019t say anything. After we got off the phone, I rushed to the bathroom on the fourth floor of the newsroom, sat down on the toilet and cried.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"57\"/><p class=\"p-block\">\u00a0</p><p class=\"p-block\"><strong>In the summer</strong> of 2009, without ever having had that follow-up talk with top Post management, I left the paper and moved to New York to join The Huffington Post. I met Arianna Huffington at a Washington Press Club Foundation dinner I was covering for The Post two years earlier, and she later recruited me to join her news site. I wanted to learn more about Web publishing, and I thought the new job would provide a useful education.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Still, I was apprehensive about the move: many companies were already using E-Verify, a program set up by the Department of Homeland Security that checks if prospective employees are eligible to work, and I didn\u2019t know if my new employer was among them. But I\u2019d been able to get jobs in other newsrooms, I figured, so I filled out the paperwork as usual and succeeded in landing on the payroll.</p><p class=\"p-block\">While I worked at The Huffington Post, other opportunities emerged. My H.I.V./AIDS series became a documentary film called \u201cThe Other City,\u201d which opened at the <a href=\"http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/t/tribeca_film_festival_nyc/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier\" title=\"More articles about the Tribeca Film Festival.\" class=\"meta-classifier\">Tribeca Film Festival</a> last year and was broadcast on Showtime. I began writing for magazines and landed a dream assignment: profiling Facebook\u2019s Mark Zuckerberg for The New Yorker.</p><p class=\"p-block\">The more I achieved, the more scared and depressed I became. I was proud of my work, but there was always a cloud hanging over it, over me. My old eight-year deadline \u2014 the expiration of my Oregon driver\u2019s license \u2014 was approaching.</p><p class=\"p-block\">After slightly less than a year, I decided to leave The Huffington Post. In part, this was because I wanted to promote the documentary and write a book about online culture \u2014 or so I told my friends. But the real reason was, after so many years of trying to be a part of the system, of focusing all my energy on my professional life, I learned that no amount of professional success would solve my problem or ease the sense of loss and displacement I felt. I lied to a friend about why I couldn\u2019t take a weekend trip to Mexico. Another time I concocted an excuse for why I couldn\u2019t go on an all-expenses-paid trip to Switzerland. I have been unwilling, for years, to be in a long-term relationship because I never wanted anyone to get too close and ask too many questions. All the while, Lola\u2019s question was stuck in my head: What will happen if people find out?</p><p class=\"p-block\">Early this year, just two weeks before my 30th birthday, I won a small reprieve: I obtained a driver\u2019s license in the state of Washington. The license is valid until 2016. This offered me five more years of acceptable identification \u2014 but also five more years of fear, of lying to people I respect and institutions that trusted me, of running away from who I am.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"64\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I\u2019m done running. I\u2019m exhausted. I don\u2019t want that life anymore.</p><p class=\"p-block\">So I\u2019ve decided to come forward, own up to what I\u2019ve done, and tell my story to the best of my recollection. I\u2019ve reached out to former bosses\u00ad and employers and apologized for misleading them \u2014 a mix of humiliation and liberation coming with each disclosure. All the people mentioned in this article gave me permission to use their names. I\u2019ve also talked to family and friends about my situation and am working with legal counsel to review my options. I don\u2019t know what the consequences will be of telling my story.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"66\"/><p class=\"p-block\">I do know that I am grateful to my grandparents, my Lolo and Lola, for giving me the chance for a better life. I\u2019m also grateful to my other family \u2014 the support network I found here in America \u2014 for encouraging me to pursue my dreams.</p><p class=\"p-block\">It\u2019s been almost 18 years since I\u2019ve seen my mother. Early on, I was mad at her for putting me in this position, and then mad at myself for being angry and ungrateful. By the time I got to college, we rarely spoke by phone. It became too painful; after a while it was easier to just send money to help support her and my two half-siblings. My sister, almost 2 years old when I left, is almost 20 now. I\u2019ve never met my 14-year-old brother. I would love to see them.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Not long ago, I called my mother. I wanted to fill the gaps in my memory about that August morning so many years ago. We had never discussed it. Part of me wanted to shove the memory aside, but to write this article and face the facts of my life, I needed more details. Did I cry? Did she? Did we kiss goodbye?</p><p class=\"p-block\">My mother told me I was excited about meeting a stewardess, about getting on a plane. She also reminded me of the one piece of advice she gave me for blending in: If anyone asked why I was coming to America, I should say I was going to Disneyland.</p><div class=\"story-footer\"><div class=\"story-meta\"><div class=\"article-tagline\"><p>Jose Antonio Vargas (Jose@DefineAmerican.com) is a former reporter for The Washington Post and shared a Pulitzer Prize for coverage of the Virginia Tech shootings. He founded Define American, which seeks to change the conversation on immigration reform.  Editor: Chris Suellentrop (C.Suellentrop-MagGroup@nytimes.com)</p></div></div></div></div></div></body></html>"}, "15430277": {"score": 4, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:10:00", "url": "http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/07/world/automated-farm-harvest-england/index.html", "text": "<html><body><div><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph speakable\">From sowing the seeds to picking the grain, human workers were replaced with automated machines operated from a control room. The project, called Hands Free Hectare, was completed last month with a yield of 4 1/2 tons of barley, according to news releases.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph speakable\">The automated farm was a joint venture by Harper Adams University in Shropshire, England, and Precision Decisions, a farming specialist company in York. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"Previously, people have automated sections of agricultural systems, but funding and interest generally only goes towards one single area,\" said Kit Franklin, an agricultural engineer on the project. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Experts agree that automation technology has been available for some time now, but in recent years its implementation has been accelerated by decreasing costs and changing demographics in the workforce.</p><div class=\"zn-body__read-all\"><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"The rising cost of labor is a huge driver in the field of agriculture technology,\" explained Matt Nielsen of Autonomous Solutions, a Utah-based company that converts vehicles from manual to robotic control. \"It makes sense when you compare the cost of technology to the cost of labor.\"</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\"><h3>Harbinger of what's possible</h3></p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">However, there are limitations still to be assessed. For example, fresh fruits and vegetables are more delicate than sturdy grains and may be more susceptible to bruising in a harvest void of human touch.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">There are also social and country-specific considerations. In Japan, for instance, agricultural automation may be a necessity; in India, it could mean unemployment for millions. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"Technically, complete automation is feasible everywhere, but economically and socially it only makes sense in certain situations,\" said David Zilberman, a professor of agricultural and resource economics at the University of California, Berkeley.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Nonetheless, the complete mechanization accomplished in the UK is a harbinger of what's possible in agriculture production, according to experts.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">At Hands Free Hectare, agronomists and engineers used customized tractors and drones to cultivate the barley from an area roughly equivalent to two and a half acres.   </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Drones with multispectral sensors took aerial images of the field, while smaller machines at crop level took samples to assess what fertilizers to apply and where. Live camera feeds were used to detect invasive weeds or disease.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Earlier this year, the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization stressed the need for technological innovation to create alternatives to high-input and destructive farming practices -- methods that are unsustainable to meet global food needs, the FAO warned.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"Automation will facilitate a sustainable system,\" said Hands Free Hectare's Franklin. \"Different areas of the field, and possibly even individual plants can be treated separately.\"</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">The success at Hands Free Hectare also demonstrates the economic feasibility of complete automation, researchers say.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">The project was funded in part by Innovate UK, a government agency that helps British economic sectors transform from low-tech to high-tech. The whole enterprise cost around $250,000, Innovate UK said in a statement.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"The project itself was incredibly good value for money,\" said Martin Abell, a mechatronics researcher at Precision Decisions. \"This was only possible through the use of open-source software, allowing us to program our vehicles through low-cost drone-based autopilots.\"</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\"><h3>Skill set shift</h3></p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Researchers maintain that even machinery produced commercially -- as opposed to the prototypes used at Hands Free Hectare -- would be priced comparatively to traditional agricultural equipment. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"Just as computers used to be expensive, the cost of automation technology is decreasing and won't be a barrier for even small farms,\" explained Michael Boehlje, a professor of agricultural economics at Purdue University. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">Hands Free Hectare says the project is not about putting farmers out of work but instead modernizing their position. </p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"A change in skill set is inevitable,\" said Abell. \"Roles would transition, enabling the farmers to better use their time managing their farm and crops, opposed to carrying out the seemingly robotic task of driving up and down a field in a straight line.\"</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">By leaving the \"robotic\" jobs to the robots, agriculturalists say farmers could create more efficient work-flows free of burdensome labor.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">\"A farmer once told me he adopted robotic farming systems so he could have a life,\" recalled Boehlje.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">With the success of the summer harvest, Hands Free Hectare plans to continue its research into farming without any human tillage. At the end of October, the team plans to plant a full crop of winter wheat.</p><p class=\"zn-body__paragraph\">But first, they plan to celebrate their success -- by brewing their own beer, made from the spring barley harvested last month.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15430790": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:27:22", "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/laurengensler/2017/10/04/earnest-acquired-by-navient-fintech-student-loans/", "text": "<html><body><div><div _ngcontent-c23=\"\" innerhtml=\"&lt;div id=&quot;attachment_17835&quot; class=&quot;wp-caption alignnone&quot;&gt; &#10; &lt;div class=&quot;article-body-image&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;img class=&quot;wp-image-17835 size-large&quot; src=&quot;//blogs-images.forbes.com/laurengensler/files/2017/10/0116_lending-louis-beryl-earnest_1200x675-1200x675.jpg?width=960&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; data-height=&quot;675&quot; data-width=&quot;1200&quot; /&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;div article-image-caption=&quot;&quot;&gt; &#10;  &lt;div class=&quot;caption-container&quot; ng-class=&quot;caption_state&quot;&gt; &#10;   &lt;fbs-accordion current=&quot;0&quot;&gt; &#10;    &lt;p class=&quot;wp-caption-text&quot;&gt;Earnest founder and CEO Louis Beryl (Photo Credit: Timothy Archibald For Forbes)&lt;/p&gt; &#10;   &lt;/fbs-accordion&gt; &#10;  &lt;/div&gt; &#10; &lt;/div&gt; &#10;&lt;/div&gt;&#10;&lt;p&gt;Financial technology&amp;nbsp;start-up Earnest has agreed to be acquired by student loan servicing giant Navient for $155 million in cash, the companies said on Wednesday.&lt;/p&gt;&#10;&lt;p&gt;Earnest, an online lender that has focused on refinancing student loans, will remain a distinct brand and will continue to be led by its current management team, including founder and CEO Louis Beryl.&lt;/p&gt;&#10;&lt;p&gt;The acquisition will be a launching pad for Navient&amp;nbsp;to begin originating its own&amp;nbsp;student loans. One-shot containers accomplishes a particular task and stops. Long running containers runs for an indefinite period till it either gets stopped by the user or when the root process inside container crashes. It is necessary to gracefully handle container\u2019s death and to make sure that the Job running as container does not get impacted in an unexpected manner. When containers are run with Swarm orchestration, Swarm monitors the containers health, exit status and the entire lifecycle including upgrade and rollback. This will be a pretty long blog. I did not want to split it since it makes sense to look at this holistically. You can jump to specific sections by clicking on the links below if needed. In this blog, I will cover the following topics with examples:</p>\n\n<h3 id=\"signalexit\">Handling Signals and exit codes</h3>\n<p>When we pass a signal to container using Docker CLI, Docker passes the signal to the main process running inside container(PID-1). This <a href=\"http://www.comptechdoc.org/os/linux/programming/linux_pgsignals.html\">link </a>has the list of all Linux signals. <a href=\"https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/run/#exit-status\">Docker exit codes</a> follow the <a href=\"http://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/exitcodes.html\">chroot exit standard</a> for Docker defined exit codes. Other standard exit codes can come from the program running inside container. Container exit code can be seen from container events coming from Docker daemon when the container exits. For containers that have not been cleaned up, exit code can be found from \u201cdocker ps -a\u201d.<br/>\nFollowing is a sample \u201cdocker ps -a\u201d output where nginx container exited with exit code 0. Here, I used \u201cdocker stop\u201d to stop the container.</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps -a\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                       PORTS               NAMES\n32d675260384        nginx                  \"nginx -g 'daemon ...\"   18 seconds ago      <strong>Exited (0)</strong> 7 seconds ago                         web\n</pre>\n<p>Following is a sample \u201cdocker ps -a\u201d output where nginx container exited with exit code 137. Here, I used \u201cdocker kill\u201d to stop the container.</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps -a\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                       PORTS               NAMES\n9b5d8348cb89        nginx                  \"nginx -g 'daemon ...\"   11 seconds ago      <strong>Exited (137)</strong> 2 seconds ago                       web\n</pre>\n<p>Following is the list of standard and Docker defined exit codes:</p>\n<pre>0: Success\n125: Docker run itself fails\n126: Contained command cannot be invoked\n127: Containerd command cannot be found\n128 + n: Fatal error signal n:\n130: (128+2) Container terminated by Control-C\n137: (128+9) Container received a SIGKILL\n143: (128+15) Container received a SIGTERM\n255: Exit status out of range(-1)\n</pre>\n<p>Following is a simple Python program that handles Signals. This program will be run as Docker container to illustrate Docker signals and exit codes.</p>\n<pre>#!/usr/bin/python\n\nimport sys\nimport signal\nimport time\n\ndef signal_handler_int(sigid, frame):\n    print \"signal\", sigid, \",\", \"Handling Ctrl+C/SIGINT!\"\n    sys.exit(signal.SIGINT)\n\ndef signal_handler_term(sigid, frame):\n    print \"signal\", sigid, \",\", \"Handling SIGTERM!\"\n    sys.exit(signal.SIGTERM)\n\ndef signal_handler_usr(sigid, frame):\n    print \"signal\", sigid, \",\", \"Handling SIGUSR1!\"\n    sys.exit(0)\n\ndef main():\n    # Register signal handler\n    signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, signal_handler_int)\n    signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, signal_handler_term)\n    signal.signal(signal.SIGUSR1, signal_handler_usr)\n\n    while True:\n        print \"I am alive\"\n        sys.stdout.flush()\n        time.sleep(1)\n\n# This is the standard boilerplate that calls the main() function.\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    main()\n</pre>\n<p>Following is the Dockerfile to convert this to container:</p>\n<pre>FROM python:2.7\nCOPY ./signalexample.py ./signalexample.py\nENTRYPOINT [\"python\", \"signalexample.py\"]\n</pre>\n<p>Lets build the container:</p>\n<pre>docker build --no-cache -t smakam/signaltest:v1 .\n</pre>\n<p>Lets start the container:</p>\n<pre>docker run -d --name signaltest smakam/signaltest:v1 \n</pre>\n<p>We can watch the logs from container using docker logs:</p>\n<pre>docker logs -f signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>The Python program above handles SIGINT, SIGTERM and SIGUSR1. We can pass these signals to the container using Docker CLI.<br/>\nFollowing command sends SIGINT to the container:</p>\n<pre>docker kill --signal=SIGINT signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>In the Docker logs, we can see the following to show that this signal is handled:</p>\n<pre>signal 2 , Handling Ctrl+C/SIGINT!\n</pre>\n<p>Following output shows the container exit status:</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps -a\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                     PORTS               NAMES\nc06266e79a43        smakam/signaltest:v1   \"python signalexam...\"   36 seconds ago      Exited (2) 3 seconds ago                       signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>Following command sends SIGTERM to the container:</p>\n<pre>docker kill --signal=SIGTERM signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>In the Docker logs, we can see the following to show that this signal is handled:</p>\n<pre>signal 15 , Handling SIGTERM!\n</pre>\n<p>Following output shows the container exit status:</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps -a\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                      PORTS               NAMES\n0149708f42b2        smakam/signaltest:v1   \"python signalexam...\"   10 seconds ago      Exited (15) 2 seconds ago                       signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>Following command sends SIGUSR1 to the container:</p>\n<pre>docker kill --signal=SIGUSR1 signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>In the Docker logs, we can see the following to show that this signal is handled:</p>\n<pre>signal 15 , Handling SIGUSR1!\n</pre>\n<p>Following output shows the container exit status:</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps -a\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                     PORTS               NAMES\nc92f7b4dd45b        smakam/signaltest:v1   \"python signalexam...\"   12 seconds ago      Exited (0) 2 seconds ago                       signaltest\n</pre>\n<p>When we execute \u201cdocker stop \u201c, Docker first sends SIGTERM signal to the container, waits for some time and then sends SIGKILL. This is done so that the program executing inside the container can use the SIGTERM signal to do the graceful shutdown of the program.</p>\n<h4>Common mistake in Docker signal handling</h4>\n<p>In the above example, the python program runs as PID 1 inside container since we used the EXEC form of ENTRYPOINT in Dockerfile. If we use the background method of ENTRYPOINT, shell process runs as PID 1 and the python program runs as another process. Following is a sample Dockerfile for starting the program as background process.</p>\n<pre>FROM python:2.7\nCOPY ./signalexample.py ./signalexample.py\nENTRYPOINT python signalexample.py\n</pre>\n<p>In this example, Docker passes the signal to the shell process instead of to the Python program. This causes the python program to not see the signal sent to the container. If there are multiple processes running inside the container and we need to pass the signal, 1 possible approach is to run the ENTRYPOINT as a script, handle the signal in the script and pass it to the correct process. 1 example using this approach is mentioned <a href=\"https://medium.com/@gchudnov/trapping-signals-in-docker-containers-7a57fdda7d86\">here</a>.</p>\n<h4>Difference between \u201cdocker stop\u201d, \u201cdocker rm\u201d and \u201cdocker kill\u201d</h4>\n<p>\u201cdocker stop\u201d \u2013 Sends SIGTERM to container, waits some time for process to handle it and then sends SIGKILL. Container filesystem remains intact.<br/>\n\u201cdocker kill\u201d \u2013 Sends SIGKILL directly. Container filesystem remains intact.<br/>\n\u201cdocker rm\u201d \u2013 Removes container filesystem. \u201cdocker rm -f\u201d will send SIGKILL and then remove container filesystem.<br/>\nUsing \u201cdocker run\u201d with \u201c\u2013rm\u201d option will automatically remove containers including container filesystem when the container exits.</p>\n<p>When container exits without the container filesystem getting removed, we can still restart the container.</p>\n<h3 id=\"containerrestart\">Container restart policy</h3>\n<p>Container restart policy controls the restart actions when Container exits. Following are the supported restart options:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>no \u2013 This is default. Containers do not get restarted when they exit.</li>\n<li>on-failure \u2013 Containers restart only when there is a failure exit code. Any exit code other than 0 is treated as failure.</li>\n<li>unless-stopped \u2013 Containers restart as long as it was not manually stopped by user.</li>\n<li>always \u2013 Always restart container irrespective of exit status.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Following is an example of starting \u201csignaltest\u201d container with restart policy of \u201con-failure\u201d and retry count of 3. Retry count 3 is the number of restarts that will be done by Docker before giving up.</p>\n<pre>docker run -d --name=signaltest --restart=on-failure:3 smakam/signaltest:v1\n</pre>\n<p>To show the restart happening, we can manually try to send signals to the container. In the \u201csignaltest\u201d example, signals SIGTERM, SIGINT and SIGKILL will cause non-zero exit code and SIGUSR1 will cause zero exit code. 1 thing to remember is that restart does not work if we stop the container or send signals using \u201cdocker kill\u201d. I think this is because there must be an explicit check added by Docker to prevent restart in these cases since the action is triggered by user.<br/>\nLets send SIGINT to the container by passing the signal to the process. We can find the process id by doing \u201cps -eaf | grep signalexample\u201d in host machine.</p>\n<pre>kill -s SIGINT  \n</pre>\n<p>Lets check the \u201cdocker ps\u201d output. We can see that the \u201ccreated\u201d time is 50 seconds. Uptime is less than a second because container restarted.</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                  COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                  PORTS               NAMES\nb867543b110c        smakam/signaltest:v1   \"python signalexam...\"   <strong>50 seconds</strong> ago      <strong>Up Less than a second</strong> \n</pre>\n<p>Following command shows the restart policy and the restart count for the running container. In this example, container restart happened once.</p>\n<pre>$ docker inspect signaltest | grep -i -A 2 -B 2 restart\n        \"Name\": \"/signaltest\",\n        \"RestartCount\": 1,\n            \"RestartPolicy\": {\n                \"Name\": \"on-failure\",\n                \"MaximumRetryCount\": 3\n</pre>\n<p>To illustrate that restart does not work on exit code 0, lets send SIGUSR1 to the container that will cause exit code 0.</p>\n<pre>sudo kill -s SIGUSR1  \n</pre>\n<p>In this case, container exits, but it does not get restarted.</p>\n<p>Container restart does not work with \u201c\u2013rm\u201d option. This is because \u201c\u2013rm\u201d option causes container to be removed as soon as the container exit happens.</p>\n<h3 id=\"containerhealth\">Container health check</h3>\n<p>It is possible that container does not exit but it not performing as per the requirement. Health check probes can be used to identify misbehaving containers and take action rather than waiting till the end when container dies. Health check probes are used to accomplish the specific task of checking container health. For a container like webserver, health check probe can be as simple as sending curl request to webserver port. By using container\u2019s health, we can restart the container if health check fails.<br/>\nTo illustrate health check feature, I have used the container described <a href=\"https://hub.docker.com/r/effectivetrainings/docker-health/\">here</a>.<br/>\nFollowing command starts the webserver container with health check capability enabled.</p>\n<pre>docker run -p 8080:8080 -d --rm --name health-check --health-interval=1s --health-timeout=3s --health-retries=3 --health-cmd \"curl -f http://localhost:8080/health || exit 1\" effectivetrainings/docker-health \n</pre>\n<p>Following are all parameters related to healthcheck:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"8920\" data-permalink=\"https://sreeninet.wordpress.com/2017/08/15/docker-features-for-handling-containers-death-and-resurrection/container_healthcheck/\" 100vw, 604px\"/></p>\n<p>Following \u201cdocker ps\u201d output shows container health status:</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                              COMMAND                CREATED             STATUS                    PORTS                    NAMES\n947dad1c1412        effectivetrainings/docker-health   \"java -jar /app.jar\"   28 seconds ago      Up 26 seconds <strong>(healthy)</strong>   0.0.0.0:8080-&gt;8080/tcp   health-check\n</pre>\n<p>This container has a backdoor approach to mark container health as unhealthy. Lets use the backdoor approach to mark container as unhealthy like below:</p>\n<pre>curl \"http://localhost:8080/environment/health?status=false\"\n</pre>\n<p>Now, lets check the \u201cdocker ps\u201d output. The container\u2019s health has now become unhealthy.</p>\n<pre>$ docker ps\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                              COMMAND                CREATED             STATUS                     PORTS                    NAMES\n947dad1c1412        effectivetrainings/docker-health   \"java -jar /app.jar\"   3 minutes ago       Up 3 minutes <strong>(unhealthy)</strong>   0.0.0.0:8080-&gt;8080/tcp   health-check\n</pre>\n<h3 id=\"servicerestart\">Service restart with Swarm</h3>\n<p>Docker Swarm mode introduces a higher level of abstraction called Service and containers are part of the service. When we create a service, we specify the number of containers that needs to be part of the service using \u201creplicas\u201d parameter. Docker swarm will monitor the number of replicas and if any container dies, Swarm will create new container to keep the replica count as requested by the user.<br/>\nBelow command can be used to create signal service with 2 container replicas:</p>\n<pre>docker service create --name signaltest --replicas=2 smakam/signaltest:v1\n</pre>\n<p>Following command output shows the 2 containers that are part of \u201csignaltest\u201d service:</p>\n<pre>$ docker service ps signaltest\nID                  NAME                IMAGE                  NODE                DESIRED STATE       CURRENT STATE            ERROR               PORTS\nvsgtopkkxi55        signaltest.1        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Running             Running 36 seconds ago                       \ndbbm05w91wv7        signaltest.2        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Running             Running 36 seconds ago  \n</pre>\n<p>Following parameters control the container restart policy in a service:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"8921\" data-permalink=\"https://sreeninet.wordpress.com/2017/08/15/docker-features-for-handling-containers-death-and-resurrection/service_restart/\" data-orig-file=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=637&amp;h=192\" data-orig-size=\"1508,455\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"service_restart\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=637&amp;h=192?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=637&amp;h=192?w=604\" class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8921\" src=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=637&amp;h=192\" alt=\"service_restart\" srcset=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=637&amp;h=192 637w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=1274&amp;h=384 1274w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=150&amp;h=45 150w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=300&amp;h=91 300w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=768&amp;h=232 768w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_restart.png?w=1024&amp;h=309 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 637px) 100vw, 637px\"/><br/>\nLets start the \u201csignaltest\u201d service with restart-condition of \u201con-failure\u201d:</p>\n<pre>docker service create --name signaltest --replicas=2 --restart-condition=on-failure --restart-delay=3s smakam/signaltest:v1\n</pre>\n<p>Remember that sending signal \u201cSIGTERM\u201d, \u201cSIGINT\u201d, \u201cSIGKILL\u201d causes non-zero container exit codes and sending \u201cSIGUSR1\u201d causes zero container exit code.<br/>\nLets first send SIGTERM to 1 of the 2 containers:</p>\n<pre>docker kill --signal=SIGTERM \n</pre>\n<p>Following is the \u201csignaltest\u201d service output that shows the 3 containers including the one that has exited with non-zero status:</p>\n<pre>$ docker service ps signaltest\nID                  NAME                IMAGE                  NODE                DESIRED STATE       CURRENT STATE            ERROR                        PORTS\n35ndmu3jbpdb        signaltest.1        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Running             Running 4 seconds ago                                 \nullnsqio5151         \\_ signaltest.1    smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Shutdown            Failed 11 seconds ago    \"task: non-zero exit (15)\"   \n2rfwgq0388mt        signaltest.2        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Running             Running 49 seconds ago  \n</pre>\n<p>Following command sends SIGUSR1 signal to 1 of the containers which causes container to exit with status 0.</p>\n<pre>docker kill --signal=SIGUSR1 \n</pre>\n<p>Following command shows that the container did not restart since the container exit code is 0.</p>\n<pre>$ docker service ps signaltest\nID                  NAME                IMAGE                  NODE                DESIRED STATE       CURRENT STATE            ERROR                        PORTS\n35ndmu3jbpdb        signaltest.1        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Running             Running 52 seconds ago                                \nullnsqio5151         \\_ signaltest.1    smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Shutdown            Failed 59 seconds ago    \"task: non-zero exit (15)\"   \n2rfwgq0388mt        signaltest.2        smakam/signaltest:v1   ubuntu              Shutdown            Complete 3 seconds ago \n\n$ docker service ls\nID                  NAME                MODE                REPLICAS            IMAGE                  PORTS\nxs8lzbqlr69n        signaltest          replicated          1/2                 smakam/signaltest:v1 \n</pre>\n<p>I don\u2019t see a real need to change the default Swarm service restart policy from \u201cany\u201d.</p>\n<h3 id=\"servicehealth\">Service health check</h3>\n<p>In the previous sections, we saw how to use container health check with \u201ceffectivetrainings/docker-health\u201d container. Even though we could detect the container as unhealthy, we could not restart the container automatically. For standalone containers, Docker does not have native integration to restart the container on health check failure though we can achieve the same using Docker events and a script. Health check is better integrated with Swarm. With health check integrated to Swarm, when a container in a service is unhealthy, Swarm automatically shuts down the unhealthy container and starts a new container to maintain the container count as specified in the replica count of a service.</p>\n<p>\u201cdocker service\u201d command provides following options for health check and associated behavior.</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"8922\" data-permalink=\"https://sreeninet.wordpress.com/2017/08/15/docker-features-for-handling-containers-death-and-resurrection/service_health_check/\" data-orig-file=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=637&amp;h=194\" data-orig-size=\"1499,455\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"service_health_check\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=637&amp;h=194?w=300\" srcset=\"https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=637&amp;h=194 637w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=1274&amp;h=388 1274w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=150&amp;h=46 150w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=300&amp;h=91 300w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=768&amp;h=233 768w, https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_health_check.png?w=1024&amp;h=311 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 637px) 100vw, 637px\"/></p>\n<p>Lets create \u201cswarmhealth\u201d service with 2 replicas of \u201cdocker-health\u201d containers.</p>\n<pre>docker service create --name swarmhealth --replicas 2 -p 8080:8080 --health-interval=2s --health-timeout=10s --health-retries=10 --health-cmd \"curl -f http://localhost:8080/health || exit 1\" effectivetrainings/docker-health\n</pre>\n<p>Following output shows the \u201cswarmhealth\u201d service output and the 2 healthy containers:</p>\n<pre>$ docker service ps swarmhealth\nID                  NAME                IMAGE                                     NODE                DESIRED STATE       CURRENT STATE            ERROR               PORTS\njg8d78inw97n        swarmhealth.1       effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   ubuntu              Running             Running 21 seconds ago                       \nl3fdz5awv4u0        swarmhealth.2       effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   ubuntu              Running             Running 19 seconds ago \n\n$ docker ps\nCONTAINER ID        IMAGE                                     COMMAND                CREATED              STATUS                        PORTS                    NAMES\nd9b1f1b0a9b0        effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   \"java -jar /app.jar\"   About a minute ago   Up About a minute (healthy)                            swarmhealth.1.jg8d78inw97nmmbdtjzrscg1q\nbb15bfc6e588        effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   \"java -jar /app.jar\"   About a minute ago   Up About a minute (healthy)                            swarmhealth.2.l3fdz5awv4u045g2xiyrbpe2u\n</pre>\n<p>Lets mark 1 of the container unhealthy using backdoor command:</p>\n<pre>curl \"http://:8080/environment/health?status=false\"\n</pre>\n<p>Following output shows that 1 of the containers that has been shutdown which is the unhealthy container and 2 more running replicas. 1 of the replicas got restarted after the other container became unhealthy.</p>\n<pre>$ docker service ps swarmhealth\nID                  NAME                IMAGE                                     NODE                DESIRED STATE       CURRENT STATE           ERROR                              PORTS\nixxvzyuyqmcq        swarmhealth.1       effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   ubuntu              Running             Running 4 seconds ago                                      \njg8d78inw97n         \\_ swarmhealth.1   effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   ubuntu              Shutdown            Failed 23 seconds ago   \"task: non-zero exit (143): do\u2026\"   \nl3fdz5awv4u0        swarmhealth.2       effectivetrainings/docker-health:latest   ubuntu              Running             Running 5 minutes ago \n</pre>\n<h3 id=\"serviceupgrade\">Service upgrade and rollback</h3>\n<p>When we have new versions of service to be updated without taking service downtime, Docker provides many controls to do the upgrade and rollback. For example, we can control parameters like number of tasks to upgrade at a single time, actions on upgrade failure, delay between task upgrades etc. This helps us achieve release patterns like Blue green and Canary deployment patterns.</p>\n<p>Following options are provided by Docker in \u201cdocker service\u201d command to control rolling upgrade and rollback.</p>\n<p><strong>Rolling upgrade:</strong></p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"8923\" data-permalink=\"https://sreeninet.wordpress.com/2017/08/15/docker-features-for-handling-containers-death-and-resurrection/service_upgrade/\" https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_upgrade.png?w=768&amp;h=291 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 474px) 100vw, 474px\"/></p>\n<p><strong>Rollback:</strong></p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"8919\" data-permalink=\"https://sreeninet.wordpress.com/2017/08/15/docker-features-for-handling-containers-death-and-resurrection/service_rollback/\"
