https://sreeninet.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/service_rollback.png?w=1024 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 604px) 100vw, 604px\"/></p>\n<p>To illustrate service upgrade, I have a simple python webserver program running as container.<br/>\nFollowing is the Python program:</p>\n<pre>#!/usr/bin/python\n\nimport sys\nfrom BaseHTTPServer import BaseHTTPRequestHandler, HTTPServer\nimport urlparse\nimport json\n\nclass GetHandler(BaseHTTPRequestHandler):\n\n    def do_GET(self):\n        message = \"You are using version 1\\n\"\n        self.send_response(200)\n        self.end_headers()\n        self.wfile.write(message)\n        return\n\ndef main():\n    server = HTTPServer(('', 8000), GetHandler)\n    print 'Starting server at http://localhost:8000'\n    server.serve_forever()\n\n# This is the standard boilerplate that calls the main() function.\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    main()\n</pre>\n<p>This is the Dockerfile to create the Container:</p>\n<pre>FROM python:2.7\nCOPY ./webserver.py ./webserver.py\nENTRYPOINT [\"python\", \"webserver.py\"]\n</pre>\n<p>I have 2 versions of Container, smakam/webserver:v1 and smakam/webserver:v2. The only difference is the message output that either shows \u201cYou are using version 1\u201d or \u201cYou are using version 2\u201d.</p>\n<p>Lets create version 1 of the service with 2 replicas:</p>\n<pre>docker service create --name webserver --replicas=2 -p 8000:8000 smakam/webserver:v1\n</pre>\n<p>We can access the service using script. The service request will get load balanced between the 2 replicas.</p>\n<pre>while true; do curl -s \"localhost:8000\";sleep 1;done\n</pre>\n<p>Following is the service request output that shows we are using version 1 of the service:</p>\n<pre>You are using version 1\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 1\n</pre>\n<p>Lets upgrade to version 2 of the web service. Since we have specified update-delay of 3 seconds, there will be a 3 second gap between upgrades of 2 replicas. Since the \u201cupdate-parallelism\u201d default is 1, only 1 task will be upgraded at 1 time.</p>\n<pre>docker service update --update-delay=3s --image=smakam/webserver:v2 webserver\n</pre>\n<p>Following is the service request output output that shows the request slowly getting migrated to version 2 as the upgrade happens 1 replica at a time.</p>\n<pre>You are using version 1\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 2\n</pre>\n<p>Now, lets rollback to version 1 of the webserver:</p>\n<pre>docker service update --rollback webserver\n</pre>\n<p>Following is the service request output output that shows the request slowly getting downgraded from version 2 to version 1.</p>\n<pre>You are using version 2\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 2\nYou are using version 1\nYou are using version 1\n</pre>\n<p>Please let me know your feedback and if you want to see more details on any specific topic related to this. I have put the code associated with this blog <a href=\"https://github.com/smakam/docker/tree/master/container_lifecycle\">here</a>. The containers used in this blog(smakam/signaltest, smakam/webserver) are in Docker hub. </p>\n<h3>References</h3>\n\n<div id=\"jp-post-flair\" class=\"sharedaddy sd-like-enabled sd-sharing-enabled\"><div class=\"sharedaddy sd-block sd-like jetpack-likes-widget-wrapper jetpack-likes-widget-unloaded\" id=\"like-post-wrapper-59544823-8631-59dbe2e56dd92\" data-src=\"//widgets.wp.com/likes/#blog_id=59544823&amp;post_id=8631&amp;origin=sreeninet.wordpress.com&amp;obj_id=59544823-8631-59dbe2e56dd92\" data-name=\"like-post-frame-59544823-8631-59dbe2e56dd92\"><h3 class=\"sd-title\">Like this:</h3><p class=\"likes-widget-placeholder post-likes-widget-placeholder\"><span class=\"button\"><span>Like</span></span> <span class=\"loading\">Loading...</span></p><span class=\"sd-text-color\"/><a class=\"sd-link-color\"/></div>\n<p id=\"jp-relatedposts\" class=\"jp-relatedposts\">\n\t<h3 class=\"jp-relatedposts-headline\"><em>Related</em></h3>\n</p></div>\t</div>\n\t\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430794": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:28:23", "url": "https://hackernoon.com/why-is-erlang-the-only-true-computer-language-4c7d1f195a02", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><h1 name=\"7396\" id=\"7396\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf--leading graf--title\">Why Erlang is the only true computer\u00a0language</h1><p name=\"1dc7\" id=\"1dc7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">Imagine there is something wrong with the water pressure in your house. You have to call to the plumber service. They say that there is a guy, who is honest, and capable, and has a Ph. D. in plumbing, but\u2026 He doesn\u2019t speak English well. He came from Tajikistan and only speaks fluent Tajik. But it just so happens that you studied Tajik in college, so you say that they send the guy immediately.</p><p name=\"a132\" id=\"a132\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">When he arrives, you describe the problem (in Tajik), and he gets to work. Soon enough he finds the problem and tries to report it to you, apparently waiting for a reaction. But for some reason he doesn\u2019t use Tajik to report it, he uses English. Which\u2026 He doesn\u2019t really know. If you reply (in Tajik) that you don\u2019t understand, he will not switch to Tajik; he will only repeat the same phrase louder.</p><p name=\"ca1e\" id=\"ca1e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Which doesn\u2019t help to build a dialog at all.</p><p name=\"a918\" id=\"a918\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Nobody knows why he consistently chooses to reply in the language he doesn\u2019t speak well instead of his own. That you do. It is absurdly irritating, but that\u2019s just how the things work. It\u2019s how they always been. What he speaks in is basically a bad English mixed with professional jargonisms and Tajik obscenities. It looks something like this:</p><blockquote name=\"c42d\" id=\"c42d\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">In function \u2018int main()\u2019: 19:16: error: cannot bind \u2018std::ostream {aka std::basic_ostream&lt;char&gt;}\u2019 lvalue to \u2018std::basic_ostream&lt;char&gt;&amp;&amp;\u2019 In file included from /usr/include/c++/4.9/iostream:39:0, from 2: /usr/include/c++/4.9/ostream:602:5: note: initializing argument 1 of \u2018std::basic_ostream&lt;_CharT, _Traits&gt;&amp; std::operator&lt;&lt;(std::basic_ostream&lt;_CharT, _Traits&gt;&amp;&amp;, const _Tp&amp;) [with _CharT = char; _Traits = std::char_traits&lt;char&gt;; _Tp = Element]\u2019 operator&lt;&lt;(basic_ostream&lt;_CharT, _Traits&gt;&amp;&amp; __os, const _Tp&amp; __x)</blockquote><figure name=\"9f7d\" id=\"9f7d\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--blockquote\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">[CC BY-SA 2.5 (<a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5\" data-href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--figure-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5</a>)], via Wikimedia Commons</figcaption></figure><p name=\"d8de\" id=\"d8de\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Ok, it isn\u2019t about plumbing anymore. In fact, It never was about plumbing. It\u2019s about how we communicate with the machine. A programming language is something we use to tell it what to do, but the machine tries to speak back in English when something gets wrong. Computers don\u2019t speak English well, although they are good at processing formal languages. And presumably, the one who writes in formal language should be able to read it back with no problem. Wouldn\u2019t it be better, if the compiler or interpreter would respond in the same language it gets its commands in?</p><p name=\"c1b9\" id=\"c1b9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Somehow the idea seems not all that agreeable without a Tajik plumber.</p><p name=\"3ba2\" id=\"3ba2\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">So far the only language I know that reports errors in the same language you write code is Erlang. If you know more, please let me know in the comment section below.</p><p name=\"c7f1\" id=\"c7f1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Here\u2019s a simple example from \u201c<a href=\"https://pragprog.com/book/jaerlang2/programming-erlang\" data-href=\"https://pragprog.com/book/jaerlang2/programming-erlang\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Programming Erlang</a>\u201d:</p><pre name=\"fc2b\" id=\"fc2b\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">1&gt; Point = {point, 10, 45}.<br/>2&gt; {point, C, C} = Point.<br/>=ERROR REPORT==== 28-Oct-2006::17:17:00 ===<br/>Error in process &lt;0.32.0&gt; with exit value:<br/><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--pre-strong\">{{badmatch,{point,10,45}},[{erl_eval,expr,3}]}</strong></pre><p name=\"9db9\" id=\"9db9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">The string in bold is the error message, the rest is just a preamble from the interpreter. Indeed, it isn\u2019t entirely convenient for the casual reader. You have to know Erlang to read its errors. But since you still need to know Erlang to write the code that causes them, it\u2019s fine.</p><p name=\"cc55\" id=\"cc55\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The alternatives are much worse. With informal and non-standardized error messaging you would have to know not only the programming language itself but its error messaging Pidgin as well. Every C++ practitioner can confirm that reading STL messages is an art by itself. It takes knowledge, patience, determination and, occasionally, a crystal ball to build a firm understanding of a reported problem.</p><p name=\"47b5\" id=\"47b5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">For instance, the error message from above reads as \u201csorry, I can\u2019t print out an <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">element</code> for you, because its type doesn\u2019t have a <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">&lt;&lt;</code> operator.\u201d</p><p name=\"c6a2\" id=\"c6a2\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Normally the language is something you can build a dialog in. Programming languages are an unlucky exemption. Historically it was more important to tell a computer what to do rather than the opposite. When you write a small single-threaded program you can hope that there will be no errors whatsoever, so you don\u2019t really need a reporting at all. Error reporting was always viewed as an auxiliary feature.</p><p name=\"8789\" id=\"8789\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Erlang, however, aims at building highly complex distributed systems. Errors are not only most likely to happen, they are inherent to the nature of the domain. Everything that could go wrong eventually will. And you better have a decent reporting language for that.</p><p name=\"4d56\" id=\"4d56\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p graf--trailing\">The very fact that you can have a dialog, meaning writing code and receiving errors in the same language, makes Erlang not only programming but a true computer language.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15430796": {"score": 24, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:28:51", "url": "https://www.laphamsquarterly.org/lines-work/mutual-interest", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"content-wrapper\">\n            <p>I met Pierre Curie for the first time in the spring of the year 1894. I was then living in Paris where for three years I had been studying at the Sorbonne. I had passed the examinations for the licentiate in physics and was preparing for those in mathematics. At the same time I had begun to work in the research laboratory of Professor Lippmann. A Polish physicist whom I knew, and who was a great admirer of Pierre Curie, one day invited us together to spend the evening with himself and his wife.</p>\n<p>As I entered the room, Pierre Curie was standing in the recess of a French window opening on a balcony. He seemed to me very young, though he was at that time thirty-five years old. I was struck by the open expression of his face and by the slight suggestion of detachment in his whole attitude. His speech, rather slow and deliberate, his simplicity, and his smile, at once grave and youthful, inspired confidence. We began a conversation which soon became friendly. It first concerned certain scientific matters about which I was very glad to be able to ask his opinion. Then we discussed certain social and humanitarian subjects which interested us both. There was, between his conceptions and mine, despite the difference between our native countries, a surprising kinship, no doubt attributable to a certain likeness in the moral atmosphere in which we were both raised by our families.</p>\n<p>We met again at the Physics Society and in the laboratory. Then he asked if he might call upon me. I lived at that time in a room on the sixth floor of a house situated near the schools. It was a poor little room, for my resources were extremely limited. I was nevertheless very happy in it for I was now first realizing, although already twenty-five years old, the ardent desire I had so long cherished of carrying on advanced studies in science.\u00a0</p>\n<p/><div class=\"randomquote\"><div class=\"node-3627\"><article class=\"pull-quote-block block inline back-color-100\"><div class=\"pull-quote-wrapper border-color-35\"><div class=\"module-content\">\n  <p>I like work; it fascinates me. I can sit and look at it for hours.</p>\n<cite class=\"quote-author\">\u2014Jerome K. Jerome, \n  1889</cite></div></div></article></div></div>\n<p>Pierre Curie came to see me and showed a simple and sincere sympathy with my student life. Soon he caught the habit of speaking to me of his dream of an existence consecrated entirely to scientific research, and he asked me to share that life. It was not, however, easy for me to make such a decision, for it meant separation from my country and my family, and the renouncement of certain social projects that were dear to me. Having grown up in an atmosphere of patriotism kept alive by the oppression of Poland, I wished, like many other young people of my country, to contribute my effort toward the conservation of our national spirit.</p>\n<p>So matters stood when at the beginning of my vacation I left Paris to go to my father in Poland. Our correspondence during this separation helped to strengthen the bond of affection between us.</p>\n<p>During the year 1894, Pierre Curie wrote me letters that seem to me admirable in their form. No one of them was very long, for he had the habit of concise expression, but all were written in a spirit of sincerity and with an evident anxiety to make the one he desired as a companion know him as he was. It is appropriate to quote here a few lines which express how he looked on the possibility of our marriage:</p>\n<blockquote><p>It would, nevertheless, be a beautiful thing in which I hardly dare believe, to pass through life together hypnotized in our dreams: your dream for your country, our dream for humanity, our dream for science. Of all these dreams, I believe the last alone is legitimate. I mean to say by this that we are powerless to change the social order. Even if this were not true we should not know what to do. And in working without understanding, we should never be sure that we were not doing more harm than good, by retarding some inevitable evolution. From the point of view of science, on the contrary, we can pretend to accomplish something. The territory here is more solid and obvious, and however small it is, it is truly in our possession. I strongly advise you to return to Paris in October.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>One can understand from this letter that for Pierre Curie there was only one way of looking at the future. He had dedicated his life to his dream of science: he felt the need of a companion who could live his dream with him. He told me many times that the reason he had not married until he was thirty-six was because he did not believe in the possibility of a marriage which would meet this, his absolute necessity.</p>\n<p>After my return from my vacation, our friendship grew more and more precious to us; each realized that he or she could find no better life companion. We decided, therefore, to marry, and the ceremony took place in July 1895.\u00a0</p>\n<p>Professor Curie\u2019s salary was six thousand francs a year, and we held that he should not undertake any supplementary work, at least in the beginning. As for myself, I was preparing to take the examination for the aggregation of young women, in view of obtaining a teaching post. These I passed in 1896. We ordered our life to suit our scientific work and our days were passed in the laboratory, where it was permitted that I might work with my husband.</p>\n<p>He was then engaged in a research on the growth of crystals, which interested him keenly. He wished to know if certain faces of a crystal had a preferential development chiefly because they have a different rapidity of growth or because their solubility is different. He quickly obtained interesting results (not published), but he had to interrupt his investigations to undertake others on radioactivity. And he often regretted that he was never able to return to them. I was occupied at this time with the study of the magnetization of tempered steel.</p>\n<p/><div class=\"standard\"><div id=\"node-3665\" class=\"node-artwork clearfix art\">\n  <img typeof=\"foaf:Image\" src=\"https://www.laphamsquarterly.org/sites/default/files/images/artwork/18._89193.jpg\" alt=\"The White Feather Fan, by John William Waterhouse, 1879. Private Collection. \"/><figcaption><p><em>The White Feather Fan</em>, by John William Waterhouse, 1879. Private Collection.\u00a0</p>\n</figcaption></div></div>\n<p>The preparation of his class lectures was for Pierre Curie a genuine care. The chair was a new one and carried no prescribed course of study. He divided his lectures at first between crystallography and electricity. Then, as he recognized more and more the utility of a serious theoretical course in electricity for future engineers, he devoted himself entirely to this subject and succeeded in establishing a course (of about 120 lectures) that was the most complete and modern then to be had in Paris. This cost him a considerable effort, of which I was the daily witness, for he was always anxious to give a complete picture of the phenomena and of the evolution of theories, and of ideas. He was always anxious, too, that his mode of exposition should be clear and precise. He thought of publishing a treatise summing up this course, but unfortunately the many preoccupations of the following years prevented him from putting this plan into execution.</p>\n<p>We lived a very single life, interested in common, as we were, in our laboratory experiments and in the preparation of lectures and examinations. During eleven years we were scarcely ever separated, which means that there are very few lines of existing correspondence between us, representing that period. We spent our rest days and our vacations walking or bicycling either in the country near Paris, along the sea, or in the mountains. My husband was so engrossed in his researches, however, that it was very difficult for him to remain for any length of time in a place where he lacked facilities for work. After a few days, he would say, \u201cIt seems to me a very long time since we have accomplished anything.\u201d</p>\n            \n                <article id=\"contrib-bio-block\" class=\"wrapper\">\n                  <div class=\"bio-block back-color-15\">\n                                        \n                                        <p/><p>From <em>Pierre Curie and Autobiographical Notes</em>. In 1903 Marie, Pierre, and Henri Becquerel received the Nobel Prize in Physics for their discovery of radioactivity, and in 1911 she received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for isolating pure radium; she was the first woman to win a Nobel and the only one to have done so in two fields. During World War I, she and one of her daughters worked to develop X-radiography. </p>\n  </div>\n\n    </div></body></html>"}, "15429270": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:19:39", "url": "https://www.insidescience.org/news/why-do-so-many-americans-win-nobel-prize", "text": "<html><body><div><p class=\"field-subtitle\">\n    According to experts, it's strong historic investment in basic science, academic freedom for researchers and patience to see results.   </p>\n\n  <div class=\"field-body\">\n    <p>(Inside Science) -- Amidst talk of scientific revolutions at a press conference in Stockholm for the <a href=\"https://www.insidescience.org/news/update-three-share-chemistry-nobel-prize-developing-new-technique-image-molecules-life\">Nobel Prize in chemistry on Wednesday</a>, a woman identifying herself as a freelance radio reporter from China raised her hand in the camera-packed, wood-paneled room and asked why so many Americans win the Nobel Prize.</p>\n<p>Seven of the nine science Nobel winners this week are affiliated with American institutions, though not all were born here. Going back more than 100 years, some 264 winners were born in the United States, and many others immigrated to the U.S. to conduct research at American institutions. The next highest country is the U.K., as the birthplace of 84 winners, though it beats the U.S. in winners per capita.</p>\n<p>In response to the reporter's question on Wednesday, Goran Hansson, the secretary general of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, said the primary reasons are funding and academic freedom. Since the mid-20th century, the United States has spent a tremendous amount on fundamental or \"basic\" research, not forcing scientists to work on projects with an immediate application as the goal.</p>\n<p>Experts in science funding agreed that the overabundance of American Nobel Prize winners is no coincidence. Basic science is where the biggest long-term breakthroughs come from, and Nobel Prizes tend to recognize those breakthroughs. So, if you want to know the secret of today's Nobel Prizes, you have to look to the past.</p>\n<p>\"These prizes are a lagging indicator,\" said Marc Kastner, a physicist in California who heads an organization called the Science Philanthropy Alliance, which works with donors on ways to direct their giving toward basic science research. \"They show us what we were doing right decades ago.\"</p>\n<h3><strong>The strength of American post-war science</strong></h3>\n<p>Although this year\u2019s chemistry Nobel Prize recognized only one American researcher -- German-born Joachim Frank -- in its trio of winners, the development of cryo-electron microscopy -- the technique behind the prize -- still illustrates the payoffs that can come from basic science research in the United States.</p>\n<p>\"This prize is based mainly on steady advances in cryo-EM made in the 'golden era' of funding for basic science in the USA, following Sputnik,\" said John Spence of Arizona State University.</p>\n<p>Though much of the work took place in Europe, the portion of work taking place in the United States benefitted from a permissive climate for basic science research. Kastner traces that climate back to the end of World War II and to the vision of engineer and science administrator Vannevar Bush, who led the Office of Scientific Research and Development, which oversaw the Manhattan project.</p>\n<p>At the end of the war, Bush prepared a report to the president that placed a strong emphasis on basic research and eventually led to the creation of the National Science Foundation in 1950. He adopted the position that it was the government's responsibility to do basic research through the universities. That model became enshrined in the U.S. approach to financing science after the war, one fruit of which is the overabundance of Nobel Prizes for researchers at American universities.</p>\n<p>\"The resources for smart people to try creative things have been there because the federal government has been willing to take the gamble,\" Kastner said.</p>\n<p>Kastner's organization seeks to offer advice to philanthropists and to increase philanthropic support for basic research. \"It will never take the place of federal funding, but it can do things the federal government has trouble doing,\" he said.</p>\n<p>National Institute of General Medical Sciences director Jon Lorsch leads an agency that funds about 11 percent of all NIH grants, including the work of many <a href=\"https://www.nigms.nih.gov/education/pages/factsheet_NIGMSNobelists.aspx\" target=\"_blank\">past and present</a> Nobel laureates. He said historically about half of the research funds at NIGMS and other NIH agencies have gone toward basic research, much of it funded through investigator-initiated grants where the agencies fund the ideas the scientists themselves come up with.</p>\n<p>Last year, he was one of several agency heads who co-authored a letter with NIH Director Francis Collins in <em>Science</em> Magazine affirming the NIH's support for basic science. It specifically mentioned cryo-electron microscopy as a transformative area that has yielded \"spectacular\" returns on taxpayer investment.</p>\n<p>Lorsch also pointed to his agency's creation of a new funding mechanism for basic research into technology that seeks to give grants to physicists, engineers and other people who are not themselves biologists but who might develop basic technology biologists may use.</p>\n<p>\"We wanted to find a way to support those crazy ideas that are going to transform biology in the coming decade,\" Lorsch said.</p>\n<p>But if crazy ideas take decades to come to fruition, to what extent does the public understand and appreciate the connection between basic research funding and scientific advances?</p>\n<h3><strong>The case of missing returns</strong></h3>\n<p>You can blame Archimedes, in part, for any expectation of immediate returns. That ancient, apocryphal story of him pondering how to weigh the gold in the king's crown, crawling into the brimming bath, tipping the water from the tub, and then running naked through the streets of Syracuse shouting, \"Eureka!\" belies the long, deliberative process that modern science has become.</p>\n<p>\"It can be decades before a basic science finding leads to a breakthrough in terms of applications,\" Lorsch said.\u00a0</p>\n<p>Because the practical applications of all basic discoveries are not always immediately obvious, he added, funding agencies often evaluate basic research by looking at things like the number and quality of publications stemming from the research, derivative technologies, patents or collaborations that emerge.</p>\n<p>But does the general public get that?</p>\n<p>\"We have been incredibly ineffective at communicating the products of basic research,\" said David Helfand, an astronomer at Columbia University who serves on the board of the nonprofit organization Science Counts, which seeks to promote public awareness and support of science.</p>\n<p><em>(Editor's note: Helfand also sits on the board of directors of the American Institute of Physics, which publishes Inside Science.)</em></p>\n<p>If you ask the public their views on science, most will consistently say they love it, Helfand said. But when you ask people what they would cut if they could cut any discretionary spending, he added, \"scientific research comes out number one every time.\"</p>\n<p>This hints at a disconnect between appreciating the tangible results of science and the slow, accumulation of knowledge that drives those advances. People love discovery but not paying for discovery, Helfand said.</p>\n<p>Helfand and his colleagues just launched a test campaign this week that seeks to engage the public beginning next spring in several midsized cities like Dallas, Texas that will seek to gain insight into public attitudes toward science in order to inform public outreach.</p>\n<p>\"We are going to engage people in a serious way and see if they will take action,\" Helfand said.</p>\n<p>Other efforts are also underway to connect the dots.</p>\n<p>This summer a group from Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois published a study that surveyed 5 million U.S. patents and 32 million research articles from around the world and attempted to map the connection between the two. It found that most new patents can be tied back to research articles.</p>\n<p>Another group at the University of California, San Francisco and the Gladstone Institute examined two different recently FDA-approved drugs and used the tools of network analysis to attempt an unbiased approach to linking the success of those drugs to the constellation of research articles that led to their approval.\u00a0</p>\n<p>\"What we found when we analyzed that was rather surprising,\" said R.\u00a0Sanders Williams from the Gladstone Institutes and the University of California, San Francisco.</p>\n<p>Their work showed that the basic and clinical research behind the new drugs involved thousands of different researchers at thousands of different institutions who published some 1,500 papers, some going back many years.</p>\n<p>\"Much of that work was purely basic science,\" Lorsch said.</p>\n<p>What the work showed, said Williams, was evidence for the need to fund a broad base of basic science. \"Everyone wants to fund that last step, and few recognize you have to fund that broad base,\" he said.</p>\n<p>\"If you want a cure for currently unsolved diseases, it's going to take decades, it's going to be unpredictable and it's going to take a large base.\"</p>\n  </div>\n  </div></body></html>"}, "15431317": {"score": 5, "comments": ["Was really looking for loading time stats and similar instead of just CPU and GPU benchmarks. The user experience is what matters, brute hardware performance is immaterial. A crappy device with heavily optimized software can work much better than a more powerful device that has a bloated software stack with no optimization."], "time": "2017-10-09 06:00:18", "url": "https://www.futuremark.com/pressreleases/is-it-true-that-iphones-get-slower-over-time", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"padding\">\n                \n                  <p>\n                    </p><p>Last week, a story went viral that claimed Apple was intentionally slowing down older iPhones to push people to buy its latest models.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The claim was based on data which shows <a href=\"https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?date=2007-05-09%202017-10-05&amp;q=iPhone%20slow\">Google searches for \"iPhone slow\" spiking dramatically</a> with the release of each new model.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>And while plenty of reputable sites debunked the logic of that claim, no one looked at actual performance data to tell the true story.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Fortunately, we have plenty of real-world data we can use. Since 2016, we have collected more than a hundred thousand benchmark results for seven different iPhone models across three different versions of iOS.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>These benchmark results provide a unique insight into the everyday performance of each iPhone model over time. And, as you'll see, there are no signs of a conspiracy.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<h2>How we test iPhone performance</h2>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>3DMark is a free benchmarking app for testing the performance of smartphones. It works by running a demanding series of tests. Each test produces a set of scores that you can use to compare devices. The recommended test for recent iPhone models is called <i>Sling Shot Extreme</i>.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<h2>Are older iPhones being deliberately slowed?</h2>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>We looked at data for the iPhone 5s first because, if older devices are being deliberately slowed, the effect should be most obvious with models that have been around for longer.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The chart below shows iPhone 5s GPU performance over time. Each bar shows the average 3DMark Sling Shot Extreme Graphics test score calculated from all results submitted during that month. A higher score indicated better performance. The bars are coloured according to iOS version.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>As you can see, iPhone 5s GPU performance has remained consistent from iOS 9 to iOS 11 with only minor variations that fall well within normal levels.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><a href=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone5s-sling-shot-extreme-gpu-performance.jpg\"><img src=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone5s-sling-shot-extreme-gpu-performance.jpg\" alt=\"iPhone 5s Sling Shot Extreme GPU performance\" class=\"imagestretch\"/></a></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The next chart below shows CPU performance over time as measured by the 3DMark Sling Shot Extreme Physics test. Again, it is clear that iOS updates have not had a significant effect on performance.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><a href=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone5s-sling-shot-extreme-cpu-performance.jpg\"><img src=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone5s-sling-shot-extreme-cpu-performance.jpg\" alt=\"iPhone 5s Sling Shot Extreme CPU performance\" class=\"imagestretch\"/></a></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The charts for the iPhone 6, iPhone 6s, and iPhone 7 tell a similar story. GPU performance has remained consistent across iOS versions with only minor variations.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>The graphs for CPU performance show a very slight drop in performance over time - possibly due to minor iOS updates or other factors - but a user would be unlikely to notice this small difference in everyday use.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><a href=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone-gpu-and-cpu-performance-in-sling-shot-extreme.jpg\"><img src=\"https://www.futuremark.com/hwc/tmp/iphone-gpu-and-cpu-performance-in-sling-shot-extreme.jpg\" alt=\"iPhone GPU and CPU performance in Sling Shot Extreme\" class=\"imagestretch\"/></a></p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<h2>Why do searches for \"iPhone slow\" spike when new models are released?</h2>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>Our benchmarking data shows that, rather than intentionally degrading the performance of older models, Apple actually does a good job of supporting its older devices with regular updates that maintain a consistent level of performance across iOS versions.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>That said, there are some factors that might affect people's perception of performance after updating an older device with a newer version of iOS. An update might add new features that use more resources or require more processing power. New apps developed for the latest models might not run as smoothly on older devices. Conversely, apps designed for an earlier version of iOS might not take full advantage of optimizations in the latest version. And then there is always the\u00a0 psychological effect of knowing that there is a new and improved model available, which can make your own device seem outdated.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<h2>How to test your own Android or Apple phone\u00a0</h2>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>3DMark is a free benchmarking app available from the <a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/app/3dmark-sling-shot-benchmark/id1015301759?ls=1&amp;mt=8&quot;\">Apple App Store</a> and <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.futuremark.dmandroid.application\">Google Play</a>. Benchmark your phone and see how it compares with the latest models.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p><a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/app/3dmark-sling-shot-benchmark/id1015301759?ls=1&amp;mt=8\"><img src=\"http://www.futuremark.com/images/icons/appstore60.png\" alt=\"Download 3DMark Sling Shot Apple benchmark from the App Store\"/></a>\u00a0\u00a0<a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.futuremark.dmandroid.application\"><img src=\"http://www.futuremark.com/images/icons/googleplay60.png\" alt=\"Download 3DMark Android benchmark from Google Play\"/></a></p>\n                  \n                \n              </div>\n            </div></body></html>"}, "15429782": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:14:58", "url": "https://99percentinvisible.org/article/unheard-catastrophic-collapse-worlds-tallest-tower/", "text": "<body class=\"article-template-default single single-article postid-10515 unheard-catastrophic-collapse-worlds-tallest-tower sidebar-primary page_one\" id=\"readabilityBody\">\n    \n    <header id=\"site-header\">\n  \n  </header></body>"}, "15429913": {"score": 5, "comments": ["I&#x27;ve seen far more dirtbag middle managers than anyone on the top or bottom. Many want to make themselves look good, so will do whatever it takes."], "time": "2017-10-08 23:45:42", "url": "http://news.psu.edu/story/485920/2017/10/05/research/middle-managers-may-turn-unethical-behavior-face-unrealistic", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"field-item even\" property=\"content:encoded\"><p>UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. \u2014 While unethical behavior in organizations is often portrayed as flowing down from top management, or creeping up from low-level positions, a team of researchers suggest that middle management also can play a key role in promoting wide-spread unethical behavior among their subordinates.</p>\n<p>In a study of a large telecommunications company, researchers found that middle managers used a range of tactics to inflate their subordinates' performance and deceive top management, according to Linda Trevi\u00f1o, distinguished professor of organizational behavior and ethics, Smeal College of Business, Penn State. The managers may have been motivated to engage in this behavior because leadership instituted performance targets that were unrealizable, she added.</p>\n<p>When creating a new unit, a company's top management usually also sketches out the unit's performance routines \u2014 for example, they set goals, develop incentives and designate certain responsibilities, according to the researchers. Middle managers are then tasked with carrying out these new directives. But, in the company studied by the researchers, this turned out to be impossible.</p>\n<p>\"What we found in this particular case \u2014 but I think it happens a lot \u2014 is that there were obstacles in the way of achieving these goals set by top management,\" said Trevi\u00f1o. \"For a variety of reasons, the goals were unrealistic and unachievable. The workers didn't have enough training. They didn't feel competent. They didn't know the products well enough. There weren't enough customers and there wasn't even enough time to get all the work done.\"</p>\n<p>Facing these obstacles, middle management enacted a series of moves designed to deceive top management into believing that teams were actually meeting their goals, according to Trevi\u00f1o, who worked with Niki A. den Nieuwenboer, assistant professor of organizational behavior and business ethics, University of Kansas; and Joa\u1dc3o Viera da Cunha, associate professor, IESEG School of Management.</p>\n<p>\"It became clear to middle managers that there was no way their people could meet these goals,\" said Trevi\u00f1o. \"They got really creative because their bonuses are tied to what their people do, or because they didn't want to lose their jobs. Middle managers exploited vulnerabilities they identified in the organization to come up with ways to make it look like their workers were achieving goals when they weren't.\"</p>\n<p>According to the researchers, these strategies included coopting sales from another unit, portraying orders as actual sales and ensuring that the flow of sales data reported in the company's IT system looked normal. Middle managers created some of these behaviors on their own, but they also learned tactics from other managers, according to the researchers, who report their findings in Organization Science, online now.</p>\n<p>Middle managers also used a range of tactics to coerce their subordinates to keep up the ruse, including rewards for unethical behavior and public shaming for those who were reluctant to engage in the unethical tactics.</p>\n<p>\"Interestingly, what we didn't see is managers speaking up, we didn't see them pushing back against the unrealistic goals,\" said Trevi\u00f1o. \"We know a lot about what we refer to as 'voice' in an organization and people are fearful and they tend to keep quiet for the most part.\"</p>\n<p>The researchers suggested that the findings could offer insights into other scandals, such as the Wells Fargo and the U.S. Veteran Administration hospital misconduct. They added that top management in organizations should do more in-depth work to institute realistic goals and incentives.</p>\n<p>\"Everybody has goals and goals are motivating, but there are nuances,\" said Trevi\u00f1o. \"What goal-setting theory says is that if you're not committed to the goal because you think it's unachievable, you'll just throw your hands up and give up. Most front-line employees wanted to do that. But the managers intervened, coercing them to engage in the unethical behaviors.\"</p>\n<p>This type of deception can harm an organization in several ways, including its bottom line through the awarding of bonuses based on this deceptive performance, but also because upper management made strategic decisions and allocated resources based on the unit's feigned success.</p>\n<p>\"How can you lead a company if the performance information you get is fake? You end up making bad decisions,\" den Nieuwenboer said.</p>\n<p>One of the researchers gathered data for over a year as part of an ethnographic study, a type of study that requires researchers to immerse themselves in the culture and the lives of their subjects. In this case, the ethnographer studied the implementation of a new unit in the telecom company. As part of the data collection, the researcher spent 273 days shadowing workers, 20 days observing middle managers, listened to approximately 15 to 22 informal \u2014 lunch or watercooler \u2014 breaks between workers per week and conducted 105 formal interviews. Interactions on the phone, through email and in face-to-face meetings were observed and documented.</p>\n<p>\"One of the advantages that this kind of data affords you is the opportunity to observe what's going on across hierarchical levels,\" said Trevi\u00f1o. \"The middle management role is largely an invisible role. As a researcher, you just don't get to see that role very often.\"</p>\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15429784": {"score": 80, "comments": ["Man-oh-man did that take a while to load...<p>You can always tell you&#x27;ve landed on a wix site when you&#x27;re faced with blank screen for a while.<p>Edit: 10MB... this page is 10MB. <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;i.imgur.com&#x2F;uAoc05H.png\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;i.imgur.com&#x2F;uAoc05H.png</a>", "Scroll down to the bottom... it goes up to 40MB.<p><a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;imgur.com&#x2F;a&#x2F;eylvt\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;imgur.com&#x2F;a&#x2F;eylvt</a>", "On the one hand, at least they&#x27;re doing progressive loading.<p>On the other hand <i>oh my god it&#x27;s 40MB, this is pants-on-head crazy</i>.<p>That&#x27;s 20X the average web-page size, which is already bloated. <i>20X</i> . Someone like me, or no doubt many others on HN, can build you a site that does more or less anything and adopts whatever distinctive branding you need. However, we&#x27;re going to charge about as much for an hour or two of our time as the whole thing costs with one of the site builder tools, and your final bill is going to have at least two more zeroes on it to do roughly the same job and probably more if we&#x27;re doing anything that makes it worth using us in the first place.<p>There isn&#x27;t much room in between any longer. The days of getting your neighbour&#x27;s kid&#x27;s school friend to build your company web site for $500 are gone. The site builder tools have commoditised the low end of the market, and for that kind of money they&#x27;ll probably offer better results, while no agency nor even any established freelancer is likely to get out of bed for a gig that small.<p>In short, hiring a professional doesn&#x27;t really make sense for a lot of small business or community web sites any more. Of course new comers to ICO will dry up or stop immediately and the music will stop for a while.</p><p name=\"6e6e\" id=\"6e6e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Facebook, Apple and all fast growing marketplaces have acted in a similar way when they want to stop a wave of apps acting in a negative way in their market. Just insane.</p></div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><p name=\"d3df\" id=\"d3df\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Those who raised will be tested during this dry period. Every year you have more and more passwords to deal with, and every year they get easier and easier to break. You need a strategy.</p>\n\n<p>The best way to explain how to choose a good password is to explain how they're broken. The general attack model is what's known as an offline password-guessing attack. In this scenario, the attacker gets a file of encrypted passwords from somewhere people want to authenticate to. His goal is to turn that encrypted file into unencrypted passwords he can use to authenticate himself. He does this by guessing passwords, and then seeing if they're correct. He can try guesses as fast as his computer will process them -- and he can parallelize the attack -- and gets immediate confirmation if he guesses correctly. Yes, there are ways to foil this attack, and that's why we can still have four-digit PINs on ATM cards, but it's the correct model for breaking passwords.</p>\n\n<p>There are commercial programs that do password cracking, sold primarily to police departments. There are also <a href=\"http://www.openwall.com/john/\">hacker</a> <a href=\"http://hashcat.net/\">tools</a> that do the same thing. And they're <i>really</i> good.</p>\n\n<p>The efficiency of password cracking <a href=\"http://www.lightbluetouchpaper.org/2012/09/03/password-cracking-part-i-how-much-has-cracking-improved/\">depends</a> <a href=\"http://www.lightbluetouchpaper.org/2012/09/04/password-cracking-part-ii-when-does-password-cracking-matter/\">on</a> two largely independent things: power and efficiency.</p>\n\n<p>Power is simply computing power. As computers have become faster, they're able to test more passwords per second; one program advertises <a href=\"http://hackersnewsbulletin.com/2013/09/new-password-cracking-software-tries-8-million-times-per-second-crack-password.html\">eight million</a> per second. These crackers might run for days, on many machines simultaneously.  For a high-profile police case, they might run for months.</p>\n\n<p>Efficiency is the ability to guess passwords cleverly. It doesn't make sense to run through every eight-letter combination from \"aaaaaaaa\" to \"zzzzzzzz\" in order. That's 200 billion possible passwords, most of them very unlikely. Password crackers try the most <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2006/12/realworld_passw.html\">common</a> <a href=\"http://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-25-most-common-passwords-of-2013/\">passwords</a> first.</p>\n\n<p>A typical password consists of a root plus an appendage. The root isn't necessarily a dictionary word, but it's usually something pronounceable. An appendage is either a suffix (90% of the time) or a prefix (10% of the time). One cracking program I saw started with a dictionary of about 1,000 common passwords, things like \"letmein,\" \"temp,\" \"123456,\" and so on. Then it tested them each with about 100 common suffix appendages: \"1,\" \"4u,\" \"69,\" \"abc,\" \"!,\" and so on. It recovered about a quarter of all passwords with just these 100,000 combinations.</p>\n\n<p>Crackers use different dictionaries: English words, names, foreign words, phonetic patterns and so on for roots; two digits, dates, single symbols and so on for appendages. They run the dictionaries with various capitalizations and common substitutions: \"$\" for \"s\", \"@\" for \"a,\" \"1\" for \"l\" and so on. This guessing strategy quickly breaks about two-thirds of all passwords.</p>\n\n<p>Modern password crackers <a href=\"http://arstechnica.com/security/2013/05/how-crackers-make-minced-meat-out-of-your-passwords/\">combine different words</a> from their dictionaries:</p>\n\n<blockquote><p>What was remarkable about all three cracking sessions were the types of plains that got revealed. They included passcodes such as \"k1araj0hns0n,\" \"Sh1a-labe0uf,\" \"Apr!l221973,\" \"Qbesancon321,\" \"DG091101%,\" \"@Yourmom69,\" \"ilovetofunot,\" \"windermere2313,\" \"tmdmmj17,\" and \"BandGeek2014.\" Also included in the list: \"all of the lights\" (yes, spaces are allowed on many sites), \"i hate hackers,\" \"allineedislove,\" \"ilovemySister31,\" \"iloveyousomuch,\" \"Philippians4:13,\" \"Philippians4:6-7,\" and \"qeadzcwrsfxv1331.\" \"gonefishing1125\" was another password Steube saw appear on his computer screen. Seconds after it was cracked, he noted, \"You won't ever find it using brute force.\"</p></blockquote>\n\n<p>This is why the oft-cited <a href=\"http://xkcd.com/936/\">XKCD</a> <a href=\"https://subrabbit.wordpress.com/2011/08/26/how-much-entropy-in-that-password/\">scheme</a> for generating passwords -- string together individual words like \"correcthorsebatterystaple\" --  is no longer good advice.  The password crackers are on to this trick.</p>\n\n<p>The attacker will feed any personal information he has access to about the password creator into the password crackers.  A good password cracker will test names and addresses from the address book, meaningful dates, and any other personal information it has. Postal codes are common appendages.  If it can, the guesser will index the target hard drive and create a dictionary that includes every printable string, including deleted files. If you ever saved an e-mail with your password, or kept it in an obscure file somewhere, or if your program ever stored it in memory, this process will grab it. And it will speed the process of recovering your password.</p>\n\n<p>Last year, Ars Technica <a href=\"http://arstechnica.com/security/2013/05/how-crackers-make-minced-meat-out-of-your-passwords/\">gave three experts</a> a 16,000-entry encrypted password file, and asked them to break as many as possible. The winner got 90% of them, the loser 62% -- in a few hours.  It's the same sort of thing we saw in <a href=\"http://arstechnica.com/security/2012/08/passwords-under-assault/\">2012</a>, <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2007/01/choosing_secure.html\">2007</a>, and earlier.  If there's any new news, it's that this kind of thing is getting easier faster than people think.</p>\n\n<p>Pretty much anything that can be remembered can be cracked.</p>\n\n<p>There's still one scheme that works.  Back in 2008, I <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/essay-246.html\">described</a> the \"Schneier scheme\":</p>\n\n<blockquote><p>So if you want your password to be hard to guess, you should choose something that this process will miss. My advice is to take a sentence and turn it into a password. Something like \"This little piggy went to market\" might become \"tlpWENT2m\". That nine-character password won't be in anyone's dictionary. Of course, don't use this one, because I've written about it. Choose your own sentence -- something personal.</p></blockquote>\n\n<p>Here are <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2013/06/a_really_good_a.html\">some examples</a>:</p>\n\n<ul><li>WIw7,mstmsritt... = When I was seven, my sister threw my stuffed rabbit in the toilet.\n\n<p/></li><li>Wow...doestcst = Wow, does that couch smell terrible.\n\n<p/></li><li>Ltime@go-inag~faaa! = Long time ago in a galaxy not far away at all.\n\n<p/></li><li>uTVM,TPw55:utvm,tpwstillsecure = Until this very moment, these passwords were still secure.</li></ul>\n\n<p>You get the idea. Combine a personally memorable sentence with some personally memorable tricks to modify that sentence into a password to create a lengthy password.  Of course, the site has to accept all of those non-alpha-numeric characters and an arbitrarily long password.  Otherwise, it's much harder.</p>\n\n<p>Even better is to use random unmemorable alphanumeric passwords (with symbols, if the site will allow them), and a password manager like <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/passsafe.html\">Password Safe</a> to create and store them. Password Safe includes a random password generation function.  Tell it how many characters you want -- twelve is my default -- and it'll give you passwords like y.)v_|.7)7Bl, B3h4_[%}kgv), and QG6,FN4nFAm_.  The program supports cut and paste, so you're not actually typing those characters very much.  I'm recommending Password Safe for Windows because I wrote the first version, know the person currently in charge of the code, and trust its security.  There are ports of Password Safe to other OSs, but I had nothing to do with those.  There are also other password managers out there, if you want to shop around.</p>\n\n<p>There's more to passwords than simply choosing a good one:</p>\n\n<ol><li>Never reuse a password you care about.  Even if you choose a secure password, the site it's for could leak it because of its own incompetence.  You don't want someone who gets your password for one application or site to be able to use it for another.</li>\n\n<p/><li>Don't bother updating your password regularly.  Sites that require 90-day -- or whatever -- password upgrades do more harm than good.  Unless you think your password might be compromised, don't change it.</li>\n\n<p/><li>Beware the \"secret question.\"  You don't want a backup system for when you forget your password to be easier to break than your password.  Really, it's smart to use a password manager.  Or to write your passwords down on a piece of paper and <i>secure that piece of paper</i>.</li>\n\n<p/><li>One more piece of advice: if a  site offers two-factor authentication, seriously consider using it.  It's almost certainly a security improvement.</li></ol>\n\n<p><i>This essay <a href=\"http://boingboing.net/2014/02/25/choosing-a-secure-password.html\">previously appeared</a> on BoingBoing.</i></p>\n    \n\t\n\t\n\t\n\n    \n\t<p class=\"entry-tags\">Tags: <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/cgi-bin/mt/mt-search.cgi?search=cracking&amp;__mode=tag&amp;IncludeBlogs=2&amp;limit=10&amp;page=1\" rel=\"tag\">cracking</a>, <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/cgi-bin/mt/mt-search.cgi?search=essays&amp;__mode=tag&amp;IncludeBlogs=2&amp;limit=10&amp;page=1\" rel=\"tag\">essays</a>, <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/cgi-bin/mt/mt-search.cgi?search=passwords&amp;__mode=tag&amp;IncludeBlogs=2&amp;limit=10&amp;page=1\" rel=\"tag\">passwords</a>, <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/cgi-bin/mt/mt-search.cgi?search=security%20awareness&amp;__mode=tag&amp;IncludeBlogs=2&amp;limit=10&amp;page=1\" rel=\"tag\">security awareness</a>, <a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/cgi-bin/mt/mt-search.cgi?search=usability&amp;__mode=tag&amp;IncludeBlogs=2&amp;limit=10&amp;page=1\" rel=\"tag\">usability</a></p>\n\n\n\t\n\t<p class=\"posted\"><a href=\"https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2014/03/choosing_secure_1.html\">Posted on March  3, 2014 at  7:48 AM</a>\n\t \u2022 \n\t221 Comments\n\t\n\t</p>\n\t<aside><p class=\"share\" id=\"share005263\"/></aside>\n\t</div></div></body></html>"}, "15431327": {"score": 2, "comments": ["<a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=15416615\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=15416615</a>"], "time": "2017-10-09 06:04:49", "url": "http://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/local/2017/10/06/her-disability-check-was-gone-and-now-the-only-option-left-was-also-one-of-the-worst/?tid=sm_tw&utm_term=.edc1b277791b", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"span8 marT30 col\">\n<p><span class=\"firstcharacter\">I</span>t had been a bad night. Her brother-in-law\u2019s dog, caged outside his trailer nearby, had barked the entire length of it. Donna Jean got out of bed, angry. It was the worst day of the month, and soon she was pulling on the same ripped jeans and soiled flannel for the ninth day in a row. She put on her glasses, walked outside past the shower she kept in case she got running water and crossed the street to see if Bobby was awake yet.</p>\n<p>\u201cWould you like a cup of coffee?\u201d he asked.</p>\n<p>\u201cI guess we\u2019ll drink that and go ahead and take that stuff over there to Tommy\u2019s,\u201d she said.</p>\n<p>\u201cAin\u2019t got much,\u201d he said.</p>\n<p>\u201cWell,\u201d she sighed irritably, \u201cI tried to get you to go [digging] yesterday, and you wouldn\u2019t go.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cI was beat,\u201d he said. \u201cYesterday was my rest day.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cMy rest day will be when I\u2019m six foot in the ground.\u201d</p>\n<p>She looked at the trailer belonging to Kenneth, her brother-in-law, owner of the barking dog, and shook her head.</p>\n<p>\u201cBark, bark, bark,\u201d she said. \u201cDay in and day out.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cI block that stuff right out of my mind,\u201d he said.</p>\n<p>Donna Jean wished she could, like she wished she could block out so many other things. Her parents had warned her that life wouldn\u2019t be easy. There would be times she wouldn\u2019t have enough money. But she hadn\u2019t thought that would be her entire life, that she would be 51 and living like this still, some days fantasizing about an amount of money that would barely register with many people but would mean everything to her. Five hundred dollars. What would she do if she found some Virginia snakeroot \u2014 rare, fragile and worth $120 per pound \u2014 and made $500? What would she buy? There would be a bed. A real one. Not just a mattress on the floor. And a cabinet, too, something small. But instead, she slept where she slept, she had what she had, and that dog wouldn\u2019t stop barking.</p>\n<p>\u201cWhy don\u2019t you do something about that barking-ass dog down there?\u201d she yelled at Kenneth when he came by. \u201cI\u2019m going to turn it loose!\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cIf I catch you on that property \u2014 \u201d Kenneth began.</p>\n<p>\u201cKenneth, get out of my face!\u201d she said. \u201cBobby and them might take it from you, but I don\u2019t.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cHey!\u201d Bobby, sitting on the porch in a camping chair, told Donna Jean. \u201cKeep your mouth shut.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019m <em>tired</em>,\u201d she said. \u201cEvery day, every day, every day. I can\u2019t sit on my porch or nothing else.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cThis is not going to be here,\u201d Bobby said. \u201cZip it.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019ve got health problems,\u201d she said. \u201cWhat\u2019s he got?\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019ve got health problems, too,\u201d said Kenneth, who spent years on disability before the government cut off his benefits.</p>\n<p>\u201cMy wife\u2019s got health problems, too,\u201d Bobby said. \u201cGo home. This got me intrigued, so I wanted to build something useful using this technology to better understand what are the challenges and opportunities in this space. This post is the first of two describing my experience of building my first distributed Ethereum Blockchain app.</p><p name=\"e43b\" id=\"e43b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I\u2019ll go over the steps needed to build a Smart Contract, how to compile and deploy it to a local Blockchain network and how to build a server side rendering React app in order to interact with our contract.</p><p concepts and terms down before proceeding.</p><p name=\"52fc\" id=\"52fc\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In this post I\u2019ll go over:</p><ol class=\"postList\"><li name=\"523c\" id=\"523c\" markup--h4-em\">decentralized application)</em></h4><p name=\"0d15\" id=\"0d15\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">As the fall tv season just started in the US, we would like to use the Blockchain (Ethereum) as an efficient way to handle the mapping of a user\u2019s and their favorite tv shows.</p><p name=\"05fb\" id=\"05fb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The app displays a list of shows coming from <a href=\"https://www.rottentomatoes.com/\" data-href=\"https://www.rottentomatoes.com/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noopener\" target=\"_blank\">rotten tomatoes</a> unofficial API. Split into three categories: Fresh, New and Popular.</p><p name=\"68a2\" id=\"68a2\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">A special section in the app \u201cBookmarks\u201d displays a list of user\u2019s favorite shows which are currently stored on the Blockchain.</p><p name=\"2cc7\" id=\"2cc7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Users are able to add or remove shows from their Bookmarks section. Every time a user adds or removes a show a Smart Contract function is invoked and the change is stored on the Blockchain.</p><p name=\"9fe4\" id=\"9fe4\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The front-end app is a server side rendering React app powered by <a href=\"https://github.com/zeit/next.js/\" data-href=\"https://github.com/zeit/next.js/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Next.js</a>, for state management we\u2019ll use M<a href=\"https://mobx.js.org/\" data-href=\"https://mobx.js.org/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">ob</a>X, styling and layout will come from the awesome <a href=\"http://tachyons.io/\" data-href=\"http://tachyons.io/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">tachyons</a> project and in order to interact with the Blockchain we\u2019ll write a Smart Contact in solidity, write tests for it in JavaScript and deploy it the dependencies:</p><pre name=\"828c\" id=\"828c\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">//clone the repo<br/>git clone <a href=\"mailto:git@github.com\" data-href=\"mailto:git@github.com\" We start by declaring a contract which we name Bookmark. The contract has two public APIs.</p><ol class=\"postList\"><li name=\"f81c\" id=\"f81c\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">bookmark\u200a\u2014\u200awhich except a string that represent a show. I choose to store a JSON that will be reuse in our app UI. As another approach one could store a reference ID to some external storage.</li><li name=\"205c\" id=\"205c\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">getBookmarks\u200a\u2014\u200awhich will return an array of shows per account.</li></ol><h4 name=\"de49\" id=\"de49\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--li\">Testing the Smart\u00a0Contract</h4><p name=\"53ff\" id=\"53ff\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">You can write tests to Smart Contracts in either solidity or JavaScript.</p><p name=\"c8ae\" id=\"c8ae\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">For JavaScript tests Truffle uses the <a href=\"https://mochajs.org/\" data-href=\"https://mochajs.org/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Mocha</a> testing framework and <a href=\"http://chaijs.com/\" data-href=\"http://chaijs.com/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Chai</a> for assertions.</p><p name=\"77c0\" id=\"77c0\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Under the /tests directory you can find a bookmark.js file:</p><figure name=\"6b59\" id=\"6b59\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--iframe graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"abbe\" id=\"abbe\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">In order to run the tests you first have to have a local instance of testrpc. Once your EthereumJS TestRPC session start you can execute the tests:</p><pre name=\"45bc\" id=\"45bc\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">yarn test</pre><p name=\"1cd8\" id=\"1cd8\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">Let\u2019s go over the cases we would like to cover:</p><ol class=\"postList\"><li name=\"699e\" id=\"699e\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">A case when a client requests to bookmark a show\u200a\u2014\u200aIn this case we first get the instance of our contract, then call the public API \u2018bookmark\u2019 which except a string as it\u2019s first argument and a configuration object that includes the \u2018from\u2019 attribute. We then call the second getBookmarks public API as a result we get back a promise which when resolved should contain the show (string) we pass to the bookmark function.</li><li name=\"b048\" id=\"b048\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--li\">A case when a client requests to bookmark a list of shows\u200a\u2014\u200aSame as our first use-case, but now we want to make sure we can store a list of shows, as such we will first bookmark few shows by passing an array of JSON objects and call our getBookmarks function to verify our Smart Contract is valid.</li></ol><h4 name=\"fd19\" id=\"fd19\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--li\">Deploying our Smart Contract to a local Blockchain</h4><p name=\"89c9\" id=\"89c9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">We have just implemented and tested our Bookmark Smart Contract, it\u2019s time to compile it and migrate (deploy) it to our test network.</p><h4 name=\"d1c5\" id=\"d1c5\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Compilation</h4><p name=\"a8ef\" id=\"a8ef\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Solidity is a compiled language, meaning we need to compile our Solidity to bytecode for the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) to execute.</p><ol class=\"postList\"><li name=\"0db9\" id=\"0db9\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">Start a new terminal window and invoke the testrpc module we installed globally:</li></ol><pre name=\"62eb\" id=\"62eb\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--li\">testrpc</pre><p name=\"9a82\" id=\"9a82\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">This starts a local Ethereum blockchain instance.</p><p name=\"cbda\" id=\"cbda\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">2. Now let\u2019s compile the Smart Contract we implemented:</p><pre name=\"7fb6\" id=\"7fb6\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">truffle compile</pre><p name=\"454a\" id=\"454a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">This will compile our\u00a0.sol file(s). You should see the output of this compilation as JSON(s) files in build/contracts folder.</p><h4 name=\"ead7\" id=\"ead7\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Deploying/Migration</h4><p name=\"06d6\" id=\"06d6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">I\u2019ve used the default migration file provided when you run truffle init. This file requires our Smart Contract i.e., Bookmark.sol and deploy it:</p><pre name=\"97c9\" id=\"97c9\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">const Bookmark = artifacts.require('./Bookmark.sol')</pre><pre name=\"3d97\" id=\"3d97\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--pre\">module.exports = deployer =&gt; deployer.deploy(Bookmark)</pre><p name=\"457c\" id=\"457c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">In order to execute this script run:</p><pre name=\"bac6\" id=\"bac6\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">truffle migrate</pre><p name=\"9995\" id=\"9995\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">We have just deployed our contract to a local Blockchain network!</p><p name=\"1dc3\" id=\"1dc3\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In the next post we\u2019ll go over our React app and see how we can use Next.js, MobX and web3.js to build a UI that interacts with our Smart Contract we just implemented.</p><p name=\"9685\" id=\"9685\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The complete code for this app is available on <a href=\"https://github.com/liors/tvdapp\" data-href=\"https://github.com/liors/tvdapp\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">github</a>.</p><p name=\"f741\" id=\"f741\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">A live version of the app is deployed <a href=\"https://tvdapp.herokuapp.com\" data-href=\"https://tvdapp.herokuapp.com\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">here</a>\u200a\u2014\u200aPlease make sure your browser can run DApps, I\u2019ve been using <a href=\"https://metamask.io/\" data-href=\"https://metamask.io/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">MetaMask</a> chrome extension.</p><p name=\"0c1c\" id=\"0c1c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p graf--trailing\">Thanks for reading.
