You can skip this step if you already have Meteor installed.<br/>\nOpen your command prompt and paste this command:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ curl https://install.meteor.com/ | sh\n</code></pre>\n<p>Or if you use Windows, <a href=\"https://install.meteor.com/windows\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">download the official Meteor installer.</a></p>\n<p>Now let's create a new meteor app.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ meteor create forum\n</code></pre>\n<p>Open the new <code>forum</code> directory and delete the automatically generated <code>forum.css</code>,  <code>forum.html</code> and <code>forum.js</code> files.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ <span class=\"hljs-built_in\">cd</span> forum\n$ rm forum.css forum.html forum.js\n</code></pre>\n<p>We are going to set up Angular-Meteor by adding <code>angular</code>, and removing the<br/>\nunnecessary <code>blaze-html-templates</code>, <code>ecmascript</code>, <code>autopublish</code> and <code>insecure</code> packages.<br/>\nSince Meteor v1.2, you also have to add <code>check</code> manually to be able to perform basic input sanitization.<br/>\nWe want our application to be lightweight and secure.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ meteor remove blaze-html-templates ecmascript autopublish insecure\n$ meteor add angular check\n</code></pre>\n<p>Let's create two directories in the project root, <code>client</code> and <code>views</code>.<br/>\nThe first is a special Meteor directory that contains code used only on the client side.<br/>\nEven though in Meteor you can write code executed both on the client and server side,<br/>\nit's still a good idea to separate some business logic for security reasons.<br/>\nWe are going to put HTML templates for the layout, pages and AngularJS directives into the <code>views</code> folder.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ mkdir client\n$ mkdir views\n</code></pre>\n<p>Create a new <code>index.html</code> file in the project root and place this code inside.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">head</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">title</span>&gt;</span>Angular-Meteor Forum<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">title</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">head</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">body</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ng-app</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"forum\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ng-include</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"'views/forum.html'\"</span>&gt;</span><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">body</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>This will bootstrap the <code>forum</code> AngularJS module, which doesn't exist yet, and<br/>\ninclude the <code>views/forum.html</code> template, which doesn't exist either. Let's fix this.</p>\n<p>First, the AngularJS module. Create a new file <code>client/app.js</code> and define the module:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">angular.module(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'forum'</span>, [<span class=\"hljs-string\">'angular-meteor'</span>]);\n</code></pre>\n<p>Next, create the forum template <code>views/forum.html</code>. This is going to be the common layout used by all subpages.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"forum\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  FORUM\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>At this point you can run the app.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ meteor\n</code></pre>\n<p>Open a browser and navigate to <code>http://localhost:3000</code> . You should see the text <code>FORUM</code>.<br/>\nThis is all great, but not very impressive yet.</p>\n<p>Let's create the template <code>views/pages/topics.html</code> to display the forum topics.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"page\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">h1</span>&gt;</span>Topics<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">h1</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ng-repeat</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"topic in topics\"</span>&gt;</span>\n    <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">a</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ui-sref</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"topic({topicId: topic._id})\"</span>&gt;</span>{{ topic.name }}<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">a</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>To see this template in action, we will install the de-facto routing solution in AngularJS, <code>angular-ui-router</code>, and set up some basic routes. Either exit meteor with <code>Ctrl+C</code>, or open another command prompt, and navigate to your apps root directory.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">meteor add angularui:angular-ui-router\n</code></pre>\n<p>Our <code>app.js</code> is a great place to set up routing and controllers. However, you may want to put these into different files in a real-life application. If you do so, make sure to pay attention to the order of how Meteor loads files. Place the module definition into a file under <code>client/lib/</code>, otherwise it will be loaded after the<br/>\ncontroller/directive/etc. definitions triggering an AngularJS exception.</p>\n<p>Replace the contents of <code>app.js</code> with:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">angular.module(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'forum'</span>, [<span class=\"hljs-string\">'angular-meteor'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'ui.router'</span>])\n.config(<span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">$urlRouterProvider, $stateProvider</span>)</span>{\n\n  <span class=\"hljs-comment\">// Set the default route </span>\n  $urlRouterProvider\n    .when(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'/'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'/topics'</span>)\n    .otherwise(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'/topics'</span>);\n\n  <span class=\"hljs-comment\">// Add states</span>\n  $stateProvider.state(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topics'</span>, {\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">url</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'/topics'</span>,\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">templateUrl</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'views/pages/topics.html'</span>\n  });\n})\n.run(<span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">$state</span>)</span>{\n  <span class=\"hljs-comment\">// We inject $state here to initialize ui.router </span>\n})\n</code></pre>\n<p>Before you can see the topics list in the browser, <code>views/forum.html</code> needs a little tweaking.<br/>\nAn element with <code>ui-view</code> attribute is required to render the template associated with the current route.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"forum\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"page-container\"</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ui-view</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>Navigate to <code>http://localhost:3000</code> now, and notice how it redirects instantly to the topics page.<br/>\nHowever, we don't have any topics yet. Since we will probably want to add or remove topics later,<br/>\nit's a good idea to store them in a database.</p>\n<p>Meteor uses MongoDB for persistent storage.<br/>\nYou can define MongoDB collections with <code>new Meteor.Collection(collectionName)</code>.<br/>\nThis should be present both on the client and server side, so let's create a directory called <code>common</code>, and place this into <code>common/db.js</code>:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">Topics = <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">new</span> Meteor.Collection(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'Topics'</span>);\n</code></pre>\n<p>In Meteor, publication is the way you construct a set of data to send to a client.<br/>\nYou call <code>Meteor.publish</code> with the name of the dataset, and a callback function that may or may not have arguments and returns a MongoDB cursor. Meteor uses some magic behind the scenes to read changes from the MongoDB oplog (or polls the database if oplog is not set up properly) and updates the cursor when data is added, removed or modified.</p>\n<p>A publication should be defined in a server-only file, so let's create a directory called <code>server</code>. Every JavaScript file you place here will run only on the server.<br/>\nLet's create the file <code>server/publications.js</code>:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">Meteor.publish(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topics'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\"/>)</span>{\n  <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> Topics.find();\n});\n\nMeteor.publish(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topic'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">id</span>)</span>{\n  check(id, <span class=\"hljs-built_in\">String</span>);\n  <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> Topics.find({<span class=\"hljs-attr\">_id</span>: id});\n});\n</code></pre>\n<p>This will define two publications, one for all the topics, and one for a single topic requested by id. Also, let's insert some topics by default if the collection is empty. Put this in <code>server/defaults.js</code>:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">if</span> (Topics.find().count() === <span class=\"hljs-number\">0</span>) {\n  _.each([<span class=\"hljs-string\">'General Discussion'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'Tutorials'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'Help'</span>],\n  <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">topicName</span>)</span>{\n    Topics.insert({<span class=\"hljs-attr\">name</span>: topicName});\n  });\n}\n</code></pre>\n<p>A client initiates a subscription which connects to a publication, and receives that data. Let's see how to do this using Angular-Meteor. In <code>client/app.js</code>, add a controller option to the definition of the <code>topics</code> state called <code>TopicsContoller</code>, and define the controller after <code>.run()</code>:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\"><span class=\"hljs-comment\">// ...</span>\n  $stateProvider.state(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topics'</span>, {\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">url</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'/topics'</span>,\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">templateUrl</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'views/pages/topics.html'</span>,\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">controller</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'TopicsContoller'</span>\n  });\n<span class=\"hljs-comment\">// ...</span>\n.controller(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'TopicsContoller'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">$scope</span>)</span>{\n  $scope.subscribe(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topics'</span>);\n  $scope.helpers({\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">topics</span>: <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\"/>) </span>{\n      <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> Topics.find({}, {<span class=\"hljs-attr\">sort</span>: {<span class=\"hljs-attr\">name</span>:<span class=\"hljs-number\">1</span>}});\n    }\n  });\n})\n</code></pre>\n<p>Here we subscribe to the <code>topics</code> publication, and add a helper called <code>topics</code> that simply returns a MongoDB cursor to the list of topics sorted by name. From the AngularJS perspective, this will be a simple array available in the <code>$scope.topics</code> variable.</p>\n<p>View your forum in the browser. You should see the three topics under the heading. However, if you try to click on them, nothing happens. This is because we haven't defined our <code>topic</code> state yet. Let's do that and define the <code>TopicController</code> as well.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\"><span class=\"hljs-comment\">// ...</span>\n  $stateProvider.state(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topic'</span>, {\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">url</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'/topic/:topicId'</span>,\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">templateUrl</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'views/pages/topic.html'</span>,\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">controller</span>: <span class=\"hljs-string\">'TopicContoller'</span>\n  });\n<span class=\"hljs-comment\">// ...</span>\n.controller(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'TopicContoller'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">$scope, $stateParams</span>)</span>{\n  $scope.subscribe(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'topic'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\"/>)</span>{ \n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> [$stateParams.topicId];\n  });\n  $scope.helpers({\n    <span class=\"hljs-attr\">topic</span>: <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\"/>)</span>{\n      <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> Topics.findOne({<span class=\"hljs-attr\">_id</span>: $stateParams.topicId});\n    }\n  });\n})\n</code></pre>\n<p>It's pretty straight-forward, but note that we have to use a function to pass the id argument to the <code>topic</code> publication, and return a single topic with <code>findOne</code> instead of <code>find</code>.</p>\n<p>The template <code>views/pages/topic.html</code> will be quite simple, but don't worry, we'll add the list of threads soon.</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"page\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">h1</span>&gt;</span>{{ topic.name }}<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">h1</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>To use the forum, we have to be able to identify users.<br/>\nMeteor has some useful packages for authentication:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><code>accounts-base</code>: This package implements the basic functions necessary for user accounts and lets other packages register login services.</li>\n<li><code>accounts-password</code>: A login service that enables secure password-based login.</li>\n<li><code>dotansimha:accounts-ui-angular</code>: AngularJS wrapper for Meteor's Account-UI package.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Let's install these:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-bash\">$ meteor add accounts-base accounts-password dotansimha:accounts-ui-angular\n</code></pre>\n<p>To use <code>dotansimha:accounts-ui-angular</code>, your AngularJS module should list<br/>\n<code>accounts.ui</code> as a dependency:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">angular.module(<span class=\"hljs-string\">'forum'</span>, [<span class=\"hljs-string\">'angular-meteor'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'ui.router'</span>, <span class=\"hljs-string\">'accounts.ui'</span>])\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now we can add authentication, signup, forgot password and change password features with a single line. A good place would be in <code>views/forum.html</code>, since it's the root layout for all of our pages:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-html\"><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">class</span>=<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"forum\"</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">login-buttons</span>&gt;</span><span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">login-buttons</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span> <span class=\"hljs-attr\">ui-view</span>&gt;</span>\n  <span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"hljs-tag\">&lt;/<span class=\"hljs-name\">div</span>&gt;</span>\n</code></pre>\n<p>Nice! It's time to create some threads. We are going to ...</p>\n<ul>\n<li>define the collection in <code>common/db.js</code>:</li>\n</ul>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">Threads = <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">new</span> We use it to call the server-side <code>createThread</code><br/>\nMeteor method which is yet to be created.</p>\n<p>Paste this into <code>server/methods.js</code>:</p>\n<pre><code class=\"language-js\">Meteor.methods({\n  <span class=\"hljs-attr\">createThread</span>: <span class=\"hljs-function\"><span class=\"hljs-keyword\">function</span>(<span class=\"hljs-params\">topicId, content</span>)</span>{\n    check(topicId, <span class=\"hljs-built_in\">String</span>);\n    check(content, <span class=\"hljs-built_in\">String</span>);\n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">var</span> user = Meteor.user();\n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">if</span> (!user) {\n      <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">throw</span> <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">new</span> Meteor.Error(<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"You are not logged in!\"</span>);\n    }\n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">if</span> (!content){\n      <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">throw</span> <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">new</span> Meteor.Error(<span class=\"hljs-string\">\"Content is required!\"</span>);\n    }\n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">var</span> thread = {\n      <span class=\"hljs-attr\">author</span>: user.emails[<span class=\"hljs-number\">0</span>].address,\n      <span class=\"hljs-attr\">createdAt</span>: <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">new</span> <span class=\"hljs-built_in\">Date</span>(),\n      <span class=\"hljs-attr\">topicId</span>: topicId,\n      <span class=\"hljs-attr\">content</span>: content\n    };\n    <span class=\"hljs-keyword\">return</span> Threads.insert(thread);\n  }       \n});\n</code></pre>\n<p><code>Meteor.methods</code> expects an object, where keys are method names, and values are method definitions. Methods may have arguments and can return anything that can be serialized to JSON. Meteor cursors are not serializable, so avoid returning<code>collection.find(...)</code> as it will crash your app.</p>\n<p>Let's summarize where we are right now. We can:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>List topics</li>\n<li>Open topics to list threads</li>\n<li>Create threads</li>\n<li>Sign up/in/out, reset forgotten password and change password</li>\n</ul>\n<p>What's left? We have to:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Define the <code>Posts</code> collection and publish it <em>just like we did with <code>Threads</code></em></li>\n<li>Create a route for a single thread to list its posts <em>just like we did with <code>topic</code></em></li>\n<li>Create a form to be able to post on a thread <em>just like we did with <code>topic</code></em></li>\n<li>Write a method to handle post creation <em>just like we did with <code>createThread</code></em></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Are you ready for some practice? repository</a>.</p>\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15431331": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 06:06:26", "url": familiar, the \u201cbump stock\u201d is a legal rifle modification that is just two pieces of plastic with a spring between them.\u00a0 The spring allows the trigger to release itself using the kinetic energy of the gun, allowing for the firing of the next round far faster than would be possible by manually releasing the trigger.\u00a0 They are sold for as little as $100, and some <a href=\"http://www.tigerdroppings.com/rant/politics/it-is-possible-to-bump-fire-a-semi-auto-rifle-without-a-stock/72631507/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">gun enthusiasts have pointed out</a> that with practice, you can use your shoulder like the spring and get faster rate of fire <em>even without the $100 mod</em>.</p>\n<p>But when I went back to the video that I had posted, I got the following message:</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"6701\" data-permalink=\"https://professional-troublemaker.com/2017/10/08/youtube-removes-gun-videos-showing-legal-bump-stocks-after-vegas-shooting/removed/\" 736px\"/></p>\n<p>YouTube, it seems, has now decided that videos showing perfectly legal guns in perfectly legal ways are \u201charmful or dangerous content\u201d that violates its content policy.\u00a0 People shooting real machine guns <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=machine+gun+range\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">can still be found all over the site</a>, and indeed, they <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F__tcYYBmTo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">haven\u2019t gotten around to banning all the videos yet</a>, but several of the videos that had been around for years have now disappeared.</p>\n<p>I\u2019m apparently <a href=\"http://www.thetruthaboutguns.com/2017/10/daniel-zimmerman/youtube-begins-deleting-videos-featuring-bump-fire-stocks/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">not the only one who noticed</a>.</p>\n<p>I must assume that reason behind this is to make a political statement in favor of gun control, but why?\u00a0 Watching videos of bump fire in action is pretty shocking when you\u2019ve never seen it before, and if anything, I\u2019d expect it would prompt the public to call for their immediate ban.\u00a0 Google has, quite simply, taken it upon itself to impose its morals on all of us and to deprive the public of information.\u00a0 Given the control over the Internet that Google has, I think we have a right to demand some objectivity rather than moderation practices based on emotions and feelings.</p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<div id=\"jp-post-flair\" class=\"sharedaddy sd-like-enabled sd-sharing-enabled\"><div class=\"sharedaddy sd-block sd-like class=\"KonaBody post-content\">\n                        \n<p><span class=\"KonaFilter image-container float_right no-rightrail\"><span data-post-image=\"\" class=\"image on-image\"><img Statue of Liberty.</span><span class=\"source\"><span>Chester Higgins/Documerica</span></span></span></span><p/></span>The Trump administration plans to <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-clean-power-plan-epa-pruitt-trump-obama-2017-10\">kill the Clean Power Plan</a>, the Obama administration's main initiative to fight climate change by lowering emissions, the Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Scott Pruitt, said Monday.</p>\n<p>The Clean Power Plan aimed to help the US reach the goals set in the Paris climate agreement by curbing emissions from power plants.</p>\n<p>Pruitt has <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/03/us/politics/epa-scott-pruitt-calendar-industries-coal-oil-environmentalists.html\">reportedly the regulatory agency.</p>\n<p>Under Pruitt, the EPA has already <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/scott-pruitt-trumps-epa-chief-met-with-dow-chemical-exec-before-rolling-back-a-ban-on-pesticides-2017-6\">reversed a ban on a pesticide</a> that can harm Act to prohibit industries from dumping pollutants into streams and wetlands. Some of these moves have been <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/06/climate/trump-administration-environmental-regulations.html\">challenged in court</a>, but others are already in effect.</p>\n<p>If Pruitt succeeds in rolling back a significant portion of the rules meant to protect air and water quality, we'd return to the state the US was in before these things were regulated.</p>\n<p>The EPA was founded in 1970 and soon after <a href=\"https://www.epa.gov/history/historical-photos-and-images\">began</a> a photo project called <a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/usnationalarchives/sets/72157620856436476/with/3703575717/\">Documerica</a> that captured more than 81,000 images showing what the US looked like from 1971 to 1977. More than 20,000 photos were archived, and at least <a href=\"https://catalog.archives.gov/id/542493\">15,000 have been digitized</a> by the National Archives.</p>\n<p>Here's a selection of those photos, many of which show what the US looked like without the air and water protections that exist today.</p>\n                        \n                        <p class=\"clearfix\"/>\n                        </div></body></html>"}, "15429285": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:24:19", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_singularity", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n\n<p>The <b>technological singularity</b> (also, simply, the <b>singularity</b>)<sup id=\"cite_ref-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> is the hypothesis that the invention of <a href=\"/wiki/Superintelligence\" title=\"Superintelligence\">artificial superintelligence</a> will abruptly trigger runaway technological growth, resulting in unfathomable changes to human civilization.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Singularity_hypotheses_2-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Singularity_hypotheses-2\">[2]</a></sup> According to this hypothesis, an upgradable intelligent agent (such as a computer running software-based <a href=\"/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence\" title=\"Artificial general intelligence\">artificial general intelligence</a>) would enter a \"runaway reaction\" of self-improvement cycles, with each new and more intelligent generation appearing more and more rapidly, causing an <a href=\"/wiki/Intelligence_explosion\" title=\"Intelligence explosion\">intelligence explosion</a> and resulting in a powerful <a href=\"/wiki/Superintelligence\" title=\"Superintelligence\">superintelligence</a> that would, qualitatively, far surpass all <a href=\"/wiki/Human_intelligence\" title=\"Human intelligence\">human intelligence</a>. <a href=\"/wiki/John_von_Neumann\" title=\"John von Neumann\">John von Neumann</a> first used the term \"singularity\" (c. 1950s<sup id=\"cite_ref-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>), in the context of technological progress causing accelerating change: \"The accelerating progress of technology and changes in the mode of human life, give the appearance of approaching some essential singularity in the history of the race beyond which human affairs, as we know them, could not continue\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-mathematical_4-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-mathematical-4\">[4]</a></sup> Subsequent authors have echoed this viewpoint.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Singularity_hypotheses_2-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Singularity_hypotheses-2\">[2]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-chalmers_5-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-chalmers-5\">[5]</a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/I._J._Good\" title=\"I. J. Good\">I. J. Good</a>'s \"intelligence explosion\" model predicts that a future superintelligence will trigger a singularity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup> Emeritus professor of computer science at San Diego State University and <a href=\"/wiki/Science_fiction\" title=\"Science fiction\">science fiction</a> author <a href=\"/wiki/Vernor_Vinge\" title=\"Vernor Vinge\">Vernor Vinge</a> said in his 1993 essay <i>The Coming Technological Singularity</i> that this would signal the end of the human era, as the new superintelligence would continue to upgrade itself and would advance technologically at an incomprehensible rate.<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup></p>\n<p>At the 2012 <a href=\"/wiki/Singularity_Summit\" title=\"Singularity Summit\">Singularity Summit</a>, Stuart Armstrong did a study of artificial general intelligence (AGI) predictions by experts and found a wide range of predicted dates, with a median value of 2040. <sup id=\"cite_ref-armstrong2012_7-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-armstrong2012-7\">[7]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Many notable personalities, including <a href=\"/wiki/Stephen_Hawking\" title=\"Stephen Hawking\">Stephen Hawking</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Elon_Musk\" title=\"Elon Musk\">Elon Musk</a> consider the uncontrolled rise of artificial intelligence as a matter of alarm and concern for humanity's future. The consequences of the singularity and its potential benefit or harm to the human race has been hotly debated by various intellectual circles.</p>\n<p>The concept has become a standard trope in science fiction. For example, in 2004, <a href=\"/wiki/Charles_Stross\" title=\"Charles Stross\">Charles Stross</a> was a finalist for the Hugo award for his novel <i><a href=\"/wiki/Singularity_Sky\" title=\"Singularity Sky\">Singularity Sky</a></i>, which dealt with the disruptive effects of the technological singularity on societies.</p>\n<p/>\n\n<p/>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Manifestations\">Manifestations</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Manifestations\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Intelligence_explosion\">Intelligence explosion</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Intelligence explosion\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/I._J._Good\" title=\"I. J. Good\">I. J. Good</a> speculated in 1965 that <a href=\"/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence\" title=\"Artificial general intelligence\">artificial general intelligence</a> might bring about an intelligence explosion. Good's scenario runs as follows: as computers increase in power, it becomes possible for people to build a machine that is more intelligent than humanity; this superhuman intelligence possesses greater problem-solving and inventive skills than current humans are capable of. This superintelligent machine then designs an even more capable machine, or re-writes its own software to become even more intelligent; this (ever more capable) machine then goes on to design a machine of yet greater capability, and so on. These iterations of recursive self-improvement accelerate, allowing enormous qualitative change before any upper limits imposed by the laws of physics or theoretical computation set in.<sup id=\"cite_ref-stat_8-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-stat-8\">[8]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Emergence_of_superintelligence\">Emergence of superintelligence</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Emergence of superintelligence\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n\n<p>John von Neumann, Vernor Vinge and <a href=\"/wiki/Ray_Kurzweil\" title=\"Ray Kurzweil\">Ray Kurzweil</a> define the concept in terms of the technological creation of superintelligence. They argue that it is difficult or impossible for present-day humans to predict what human beings' lives would be like in a post-singularity world.<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-singularity_9-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-singularity-9\">[9]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Non-AI_singularity\">Non-AI singularity</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Non-AI singularity\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Some writers use \"the singularity\" in a broader way to refer to any radical changes in our society brought about by new technologies such as <a href=\"/wiki/Molecular_nanotechnology\" title=\"Molecular nanotechnology\">molecular nanotechnology</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-hplusmagazine_10-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-hplusmagazine-10\">[10]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-yudkowsky.net_11-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-yudkowsky.net-11\">[11]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-agi-conf_12-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-agi-conf-12\">[12]</a></sup> although Vinge and other writers specifically state that without superintelligence, such changes would not qualify as a true singularity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup> Many writers also tie the singularity to observations of exponential growth in various technologies (with <a href=\"/wiki/Moore%27s_Law\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Moore's Law\">Moore's Law</a> being the most prominent example), using such observations as a basis for predicting that the singularity is likely to happen sometime within the 21st century.<sup id=\"cite_ref-yudkowsky.net_11-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-yudkowsky.net-11\">[11]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-kurzweilai.net_13-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-kurzweilai.net-13\">[13]</a></sup></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Plausibility\">Plausibility</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Plausibility\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n\n<p>Many prominent technologists and academics dispute the plausibility of a technological singularity, including <a href=\"/wiki/Paul_Allen\" title=\"Paul Allen\">Paul Allen</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Jeff_Hawkins\" title=\"Jeff Hawkins\">Jeff Hawkins</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/John_Henry_Holland\" title=\"John Henry Holland\">John Holland</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Jaron_Lanier\" title=\"Jaron Lanier\">Jaron Lanier</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Gordon_Moore\" title=\"Gordon Moore\">Gordon Moore</a>, whose <a href=\"/wiki/Moore%27s_Law\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Moore's Law\">Moore's Law</a> is often cited in support of the concept.<sup id=\"cite_ref-spectrum.ieee.org_14-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-spectrum.ieee.org-14\">[14]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-ieee_15-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-ieee-15\">[15]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Allen_16-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allen-16\">[16]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Claimed_cause:_exponential_growth\">Claimed cause: exponential growth</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Claimed cause: exponential growth\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n\n\n<p>The exponential growth in computing technology suggested by Moore's Law is commonly cited as a reason to expect a singularity in the relatively near future, and a number of authors have proposed generalizations of Moore's Law. Computer scientist and futurist <a href=\"/wiki/Hans_Moravec\" title=\"Hans Moravec\">Hans Moravec</a> proposed in a 1998 book<sup id=\"cite_ref-17\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-17\">[17]</a></sup> that the exponential growth curve could be extended back through earlier computing technologies prior to the <a href=\"/wiki/Integrated_circuit\" title=\"Integrated circuit\">integrated circuit</a>.</p>\n<p>Ray Kurzweil postulates a <a href=\"/wiki/Law_of_accelerating_returns\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Law of accelerating returns\">law of accelerating returns</a> in which the speed of technological change (and more generally, all evolutionary processes<sup id=\"cite_ref-google_18-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-google-18\">[18]</a></sup>) increases exponentially, generalizing Moore's Law in the same manner as Moravec's proposal, and also including material technology (especially as applied to <a href=\"/wiki/Nanotechnology\" title=\"Nanotechnology\">nanotechnology</a>), medical technology and others.<sup id=\"cite_ref-singularity2_19-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-singularity2-19\">[19]</a></sup> Between 1986 and 2007, machines' application-specific capacity to compute information per capita roughly doubled every 14 months; the per capita capacity of the world's general-purpose computers has doubled every 18 months; the global telecommunication capacity per capita doubled every 34 months; and the world's storage capacity per capita doubled every 40 months.<sup id=\"cite_ref-HilbertLopez2011_20-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-HilbertLopez2011-20\">[20]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Mr. Kurzweil reserves the term \"singularity\" for a rapid increase in artificial intelligence (as opposed to other technologies), writing for example that \"The Singularity will allow us to transcend these limitations of our biological bodies and brains ... There will be no distinction, post-Singularity, between human and machine\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-singularity3_21-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-singularity3-21\">[21]</a></sup> He also defines his predicted date of the singularity (2045) in terms of when he expects computer-based intelligences to significantly exceed the sum total of human brainpower, writing that advances in computing before that date \"will not represent the Singularity\" because they do \"not yet correspond to a profound expansion of our intelligence.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-transformation_22-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transformation-22\">[22]</a></sup></p>\n<h4><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Accelerating_change\">Accelerating change</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Accelerating change\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h4>\n\n\n<p>Some singularity proponents argue its inevitability through extrapolation of past trends, especially those pertaining to shortening gaps between improvements to technology. In one of the first uses of the term \"singularity\" in the context of technological progress, Ulam tells of a conversation with <a href=\"/wiki/John_von_Neumann\" title=\"John von Neumann\">John von Neumann</a> about accelerating change:</p>\n<blockquote class=\"templatequote\">\n<p>One conversation centered on the ever accelerating progress of technology and changes in the mode of human life, which gives the appearance of approaching some essential singularity in the history of the race beyond which human affairs, as we know them, could not continue.<sup id=\"cite_ref-mathematical_4-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-mathematical-4\">[4]</a></sup></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Kurzweil claims that technological progress follows a pattern of <a href=\"/wiki/Exponential_growth\" title=\"Exponential growth\">exponential growth</a>, following what he calls the \"<a href=\"/wiki/Law_of_accelerating_returns\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Law of accelerating returns\">Law of Accelerating Returns</a>\". Whenever technology approaches a barrier, Kurzweil writes, new technologies will surmount it. He predicts <a href=\"/wiki/Paradigm_shift\" title=\"Paradigm shift\">paradigm shifts</a> will become increasingly common, leading to \"technological change so rapid and profound it represents a rupture in the fabric of human history\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-Kurzweil_2001_23-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Kurzweil_2001-23\">[23]</a></sup> Kurzweil believes that the singularity will occur by approximately <a href=\"/wiki/Predictions_made_by_Raymond_Kurzweil#2045:_The_Singularity\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Predictions made by Raymond Kurzweil\">2045</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-24\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-24\">[24]</a></sup> His predictions differ from Vinge's in that he predicts a gradual ascent to the singularity, rather than Vinge's rapidly self-improving superhuman intelligence.</p>\n<p>Oft-cited dangers include those commonly associated with molecular nanotechnology and <a href=\"/wiki/Genetic_engineering\" title=\"Genetic engineering\">genetic engineering</a>. These threats are major issues for both singularity advocates and critics, and were the subject of <a href=\"/wiki/Bill_Joy\" title=\"Bill Joy\">Bill Joy</a>'s <i><a href=\"/wiki/Wired_(magazine)\" title=\"Wired (magazine)\">Wired</a></i> magazine article \"<a href=\"/wiki/Why_the_future_doesn%27t_need_us\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Why the future doesn't need us\">Why the future doesn't need us</a>\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-chalmers_5-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-chalmers-5\">[5]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-JoyFuture_25-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-JoyFuture-25\">[25]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Criticisms\">Criticisms</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Criticisms\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Some critics assert that no computer or machine will ever achieve <a href=\"/wiki/Human_intelligence\" title=\"Human intelligence\">human intelligence</a>, while others hold that the definition of intelligence is irrelevant if the net result is the same.<sup id=\"cite_ref-dreyfus_26-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-dreyfus-26\">[26]</a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Steven_Pinker\" title=\"Steven Pinker\">Steven Pinker</a> stated in 2008:</p>\n<blockquote class=\"templatequote\">\n<p>(...) There is not the slightest reason to believe in a coming singularity. The fact that you can visualize a future in your imagination is not evidence that it is likely or even possible. Look at domed cities, jet-pack commuting, underwater cities, mile-high buildings, and nuclear-powered automobiles\u2014all staples of futuristic fantasies when I was a child that have never arrived. Sheer processing power is not a pixie dust that magically solves all your problems. (...)<sup id=\"cite_ref-spectrum.ieee.org_14-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-spectrum.ieee.org-14\">[14]</a></sup></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley\" title=\"University of California, Berkeley\">University of California, Berkeley</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Philosophy\" title=\"Philosophy\">philosophy</a> professor <a href=\"/wiki/John_Searle\" title=\"John Searle\">John Searle</a> writes:</p>\n<blockquote class=\"templatequote\">\n<p>[Computers] have, literally [\u2026], no <a href=\"/wiki/Intelligence\" title=\"Intelligence\">intelligence</a>, no <a href=\"/wiki/Motivation\" title=\"Motivation\">motivation</a>, no <a href=\"/wiki/Autonomy\" title=\"Autonomy\">autonomy</a>, and no agency. We design them to behave as if they had certain sorts of <a href=\"/wiki/Psychology\" title=\"Psychology\">psychology</a>, but there is no psychological reality to the corresponding processes or behavior. [\u2026] [T]he machinery has no beliefs, desires, [or] motivations.<sup id=\"cite_ref-27\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-27\">[27]</a></sup></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Martin Ford in <i>The Lights in the Tunnel: Automation, Accelerating Technology and the Economy of the Future</i><sup id=\"cite_ref-thelightsinthetunnel_28-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-thelightsinthetunnel-28\">[28]</a></sup> postulates a \"technology paradox\" in that before the singularity could occur most routine jobs in the economy would be automated, since this would require a level of technology inferior to that of the singularity. This would cause massive unemployment and plummeting consumer demand, which in turn would destroy the incentive to invest in the technologies that would be required to bring about the Singularity. Job displacement is increasingly no longer limited to work traditionally considered to be \"routine\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-nytimes_29-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-nytimes-29\">[29]</a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Jared_Diamond\" title=\"Jared Diamond\">Jared Diamond</a>, in <i><a href=\"/wiki/Collapse:_How_Societies_Choose_to_Fail_or_Succeed\" title=\"Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed\">Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed</a></i>, argues that cultures self-limit when they exceed the sustainable carrying capacity of their environment, and the consumption of strategic resources (frequently timber, soils or water) creates a deleterious positive feedback loop that leads eventually to social collapse and technological retrogression.<sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Synthesis_of_published_material\" title=\"Wikipedia:No original research\"><span title=\"The material near this tag may be based upon an improper synthesis of sources. (August 2016)\">improper synthesis?</span></a></i>]</sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Theodore_Modis\" title=\"Theodore Modis\">Theodore Modis</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-google13_30-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-google13-30\">[30]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Singularity_Myth_31-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Singularity_Myth-31\">[31]</a></sup> and <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Jonathan_Huebner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Jonathan Huebner (page does not exist)\">Jonathan Huebner</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-technological14_32-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-technological14-32\">[32]</a></sup> argue that the rate of technological innovation has not only ceased to rise, but is actually now declining. Evidence for this decline is that the rise in computer <a href=\"/wiki/Clock_rate\" title=\"Clock rate\">clock rates</a> is slowing, even while Moore's prediction of exponentially increasing circuit density continues to hold. This is due to excessive heat build-up from the chip, which cannot be dissipated quickly enough to prevent the chip from melting when operating at higher speeds. Advancements in speed may be possible in the future by virtue of more power-efficient CPU designs and multi-cell processors.<sup id=\"cite_ref-cnet_33-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-cnet-33\">[33]</a></sup> While Kurzweil used Modis' resources, and Modis' work was around accelerating change, Modis distanced himself from Kurzweil's thesis of a \"technological singularity\", claiming that it lacks scientific rigor.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Singularity_Myth_31-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Singularity_Myth-31\">[31]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Others<sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions\" title=\"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch\"><span title=\"The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (November 2014)\">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> propose that other \"singularities\" can be found through analysis of trends in <a href=\"/wiki/World_population\" title=\"World population\">world population</a>, world <a href=\"/wiki/Gross_domestic_product\" title=\"Gross domestic product\">gross domestic product</a>, and other indices. <a href=\"/wiki/Andrey_Korotayev\" title=\"Andrey Korotayev\">Andrey Korotayev</a> and others argue that historical <a href=\"/wiki/Hyperbolic_growth\" title=\"Hyperbolic growth\">hyperbolic growth</a> curves can be attributed to <a href=\"/wiki/Feedback_loop\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Feedback loop\">feedback loops</a> that ceased to affect global trends in the 1970s, and thus hyperbolic growth should not be expected in the future.<sup id=\"cite_ref-cliodynamics_34-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-cliodynamics-34\">[34]</a></sup><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Synthesis_of_published_material\" title=\"Wikipedia:No original research\"><span title=\"The material near this tag may be based upon an improper synthesis of sources. (August 2016)\">improper synthesis?</span></a></i>]</sup></p>\n<p>In a detailed empirical accounting, <i>The Progress of Computing</i>, <a href=\"/wiki/William_Nordhaus\" title=\"William Nordhaus\">William Nordhaus</a> argued that, prior to 1940, computers followed the much slower growth of a traditional industrial economy, thus rejecting extrapolations of Moore's law to 19th-century computers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-35\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-35\">[35]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In a 2007 paper, Schmidhuber stated that the frequency of subjectively \"notable events\" appears to be approaching a 21st-century singularity, but cautioned readers to take such plots of subjective events with a grain of salt: perhaps differences in memory of recent and distant events could create an illusion of accelerating change where none exists.<sup id=\"cite_ref-36\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-36\">[36]</a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Paul_Allen\" title=\"Paul Allen\">Paul Allen</a> argues the opposite of accelerating returns, the complexity brake;<sup id=\"cite_ref-Allen_16-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Allen-16\">[16]</a></sup> the more progress science makes towards understanding intelligence, the more difficult it becomes to make additional progress. A study of the number of patents shows that human creativity does not show accelerating returns, but in fact, as suggested by <a href=\"/wiki/Joseph_Tainter\" title=\"Joseph Tainter\">Joseph Tainter</a> in his <i>The Collapse of Complex Societies</i>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-university_37-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-university-37\">[37]</a></sup> a law of <a href=\"/wiki/Diminishing_returns\" title=\"Diminishing returns\">diminishing returns</a>. The number of patents per thousand peaked in the period from 1850 to 1900, and has been declining since.<sup id=\"cite_ref-technological14_32-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-technological14-32\">[32]</a></sup> The growth of complexity eventually becomes self-limiting, and leads to a widespread \"general systems collapse\".</p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Jaron_Lanier\" title=\"Jaron Lanier\">Jaron Lanier</a> refutes the idea that the Singularity is inevitable. He states: \"I do not think the technology is creating itself. It's not an autonomous process.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-lanier_38-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-lanier-38\">[38]</a></sup> He goes on to assert: \"The reason to believe in human agency over technological determinism is that you can then have an economy where people earn their own way and invent their own lives. If you structure a society on <i>not</i> emphasizing individual human agency, it's the same thing operationally as denying people clout, dignity, and self-determination ... to embrace [the idea of the Singularity] would be a celebration of bad data and bad politics.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-lanier_38-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-lanier-38\">[38]</a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Economics\" title=\"Economics\">Economist</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Robert_J._Gordon\" title=\"Robert J. Gordon\">Robert J. Gordon</a>, in <i>The Rise and Fall of American Growth: The U.S. Standard of Living Since the Civil War</i> (2016), points out that measured economic growth has slowed around 1970 and slowed even further since the <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2008\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Financial crisis of 2008\">financial crisis of 2008</a>, and argues that the economic data show no trace of a coming Singularity as imagined by mathematician <a href=\"/wiki/I.J._Good\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"I.J. Good\">I.J. Good</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-39\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-39\">[39]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In addition to general criticisms of the singularity concept, several critics have raised issues with Kurzweil's iconic chart. One line of criticism is that a <a href=\"/wiki/Log-log_plot\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Log-log plot\">log-log</a> chart of this nature is inherently biased toward a straight-line result. Others identify selection bias in the points that Kurzweil chooses to use. For example, biologist <a href=\"/wiki/PZ_Myers\" title=\"PZ Myers\">PZ Myers</a> points out that many of the early evolutionary \"events\" were picked arbitrarily.<sup id=\"cite_ref-PZMyers_40-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-PZMyers-40\">[40]</a></sup> Kurzweil has rebutted this by charting evolutionary events from 15 neutral sources, and showing that they fit a straight line on <a href=\"/wiki/File:ParadigmShiftsFrr15Events.svg\" title=\"File:ParadigmShiftsFrr15Events.svg\">a log-log chart</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Economist\" title=\"The Economist\">The Economist</a></i> mocked the concept with a graph extrapolating that the number of blades on a razor, which has increased over the years from one to as many as five, will increase ever-faster to infinity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-moreblades_41-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-moreblades-41\">[41]</a></sup></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ramifications\">Ramifications</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Ramifications\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Uncertainty_and_risk\">Uncertainty and risk</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Uncertainty and risk\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n\n<p>The term \"technological singularity\" reflects the idea that such change may happen suddenly, and that it is difficult to predict how the resulting new world would operate.<sup id=\"cite_ref-positive-and-negative_42-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-positive-and-negative-42\">[42]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-theuncertainfuture_43-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-theuncertainfuture-43\">[43]</a></sup> It is unclear whether an intelligence explosion of this kind would be beneficial or harmful, or even an <a href=\"/wiki/Existential_risk\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Existential risk\">existential threat</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-catastrophic_44-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-catastrophic-44\">[44]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-nickbostrom_45-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-nickbostrom-45\">[45]</a></sup> as the issue has not been dealt with by most <a href=\"/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence\" title=\"Artificial general intelligence\">artificial general intelligence</a> researchers, although the topic of <a href=\"/wiki/Friendly_artificial_intelligence\" title=\"Friendly artificial intelligence\">friendly artificial intelligence</a> is investigated by the <a href=\"/wiki/Future_of_Humanity_Institute\" title=\"Future of Humanity Institute\">Future of Humanity Institute</a> and the <a href=\"/wiki/Machine_Intelligence_Research_Institute\" title=\"Machine Intelligence Research Institute\">Machine Intelligence Research Institute</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-positive-and-negative_42-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-positive-and-negative-42\">[42]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Next_step_of_sociobiological_evolution\">Next step of sociobiological evolution</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Next step of sociobiological evolution\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n\n\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg/220px-Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg/330px-Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg/440px-Biological_vs._digital_information.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1343\" data-file-height=\"1085\"/></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<p>\nAmount of digital information worldwide (5x10^21 bytes) versus human genome information worldwide (10^19 bytes) in 2014.</p><sup id=\"cite_ref-InfoBiosphere2016_46-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-InfoBiosphere2016-46\">[46]</a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>While the technological singularity is usually seen as a sudden event, some scholars argue the current speed of change already fits this description. In addition, some argue that we are already in the midst of a <a href=\"/wiki/The_Major_Transitions_in_Evolution\" title=\"The Major Transitions in Evolution\">major evolutionary transition</a> that merges technology, biology, and society. Digital technology has infiltrated the fabric of human society to a degree of indisputable and often life-sustaining dependence. A 2016 article in <i><a href=\"/wiki/Trends_in_Ecology_%26_Evolution\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Trends in Ecology &amp; Evolution\">Trends in Ecology &amp; Evolution</a></i> argues that \"humans already embrace fusions of biology and technology. We spend most of our waking time communicating through digitally mediated channels... we trust <a href=\"/wiki/Artificial_intelligence\" title=\"Artificial intelligence\">artificial intelligence</a> with our lives through <a href=\"/wiki/Anti-lock_braking_system\" title=\"Anti-lock braking system\">antilock braking in cars</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Autopilot\" title=\"Autopilot\">autopilots</a> in planes... With one in three marriages in America beginning online, digital algorithms are also taking a role in human pair bonding and reproduction\". The article argues that from the perspective of the <a href=\"/wiki/Evolution\" title=\"Evolution\">evolution</a>, several previous <a href=\"/wiki/The_Major_Transitions_in_Evolution\" title=\"The Major Transitions in Evolution\">Major Transitions in Evolution</a> have transformed life through innovations in information storage and replication (<a href=\"/wiki/RNA\" title=\"RNA\">RNA</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/DNA\" title=\"DNA\">DNA</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Multicellularity\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Multicellularity\">multicellularity</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Culture\" title=\"Culture\">culture</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Language\" title=\"Language\">language</a>). In the current stage of life's evolution, the carbon-based biosphere has generated a <a href=\"/wiki/Cognitive_system\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Cognitive system\">cognitive system</a> (humans) capable of creating technology that will result in a comparable <a href=\"/wiki/The_Major_Transitions_in_Evolution\" title=\"The Major Transitions in Evolution\">evolutionary transition</a>. The digital information created by humans has reached a similar magnitude to biological information in the biosphere. Since the 1980s, \"the quantity of digital information stored has doubled about every 2.5 years, reaching about 5 zettabytes in 2014 (5x10^21 bytes). In biological terms, there are 7.2 billion humans on the planet, each having a genome of 6.2 billion nucleotides. Since one byte can encode four nucleotide pairs, the individual genomes of every human on the planet could be encoded by approximately 1x10^19 bytes. The digital realm stored 500 times more information than this in 2014 (...see Figure)... The total amount of DNA contained in all of the cells on Earth is estimated to be about 5.3x10^37 base pairs, equivalent to 1.325x10^37 bytes of information. If growth in digital storage continues at its current rate of 30\u201338% compound annual growth per year,<sup id=\"cite_ref-HilbertLopez2011_20-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-HilbertLopez2011-20\">[20]</a></sup> it will rival the total information content contained in all of the DNA in all of the cells on Earth in about 110 years. This would represent a doubling of the amount of information stored in the biosphere across a total time period of just 150 years\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-InfoBiosphere2016_46-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-InfoBiosphere2016-46\">[46]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Implications_for_human_society\">Implications for human society</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Implications for human society\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In February 2009, under the auspices of the <a href=\"/wiki/Association_for_the_Advancement_of_Artificial_Intelligence\" title=\"Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence\">Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence</a> (AAAI), <a href=\"/wiki/Eric_Horvitz\" title=\"Eric Horvitz\">Eric Horvitz</a> chaired a meeting of leading computer scientists, artificial intelligence researchers and roboticists at Asilomar in Pacific Grove, California. The goal was to discuss the potential impact of the hypothetical possibility that robots could become self-sufficient and able to make their own decisions. They discussed the extent to which computers and robots might be able to acquire <a href=\"/wiki/Autonomy\" title=\"Autonomy\">autonomy</a>, and to what degree they could use such abilities to pose threats or hazards.<sup id=\"cite_ref-nytimes_july09_47-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-nytimes_july09-47\">[47]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Some machines are programmed with various forms of semi-autonomy, including the ability to locate their own power sources and choose targets to attack with weapons. Also, some <a href=\"/wiki/Computer_viruses\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Computer viruses\">computer viruses</a> can evade elimination and, according to scientists in attendance, could therefore be said to have reached a \"cockroach\" stage of machine intelligence. The conference attendees noted that self-awareness as depicted in science-fiction is probably unlikely, but that other potential hazards and pitfalls exist.<sup id=\"cite_ref-nytimes_july09_47-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-nytimes_july09-47\">[47]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Some experts and academics have questioned the use of <a href=\"/wiki/Robot\" title=\"Robot\">robots</a> for military combat, especially when such robots are given some degree of autonomous functions.<sup id=\"cite_ref-palmer_48-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-palmer-48\">[48]</a></sup><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Synthesis_of_published_material\" title=\"Wikipedia:No original research\"><span title=\"The material near this tag may be based upon an improper synthesis of sources. (August 2016)\">improper synthesis?</span></a></i>]</sup></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Immortality\">Immortality</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Immortality\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>In his 2005 book, <i>The Singularity is Near</i>, Kurzweil suggests that medical advances would allow people to protect their bodies from the effects of aging, making the life expectancy limitless. Kurzweil argues that the technological advances in medicine would allow us to continuously repair and replace defective components in our bodies, prolonging life to an undetermined age.<sup id=\"cite_ref-49\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-49\">[49]</a></sup> Kurzweil further buttresses his argument by discussing current bio-engineering advances. Kurzweil suggests <a href=\"/wiki/Somatic_gene_therapy\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Somatic gene therapy\">somatic gene therapy</a>; after synthetic viruses with specific genetic information, the next step would be to apply this technology to gene therapy, replacing human DNA with synthesized genes.<sup id=\"cite_ref-50\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-50\">[50]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Beyond merely extending the operational life of the physical body, <a href=\"/wiki/Jaron_Lanier\" title=\"Jaron Lanier\">Jaron Lanier</a> argues for a form of immortality called \"Digital Ascension\" that involves \"people dying in the flesh and being uploaded into a computer and remaining conscious\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-51\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-51\">[51]</a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Singularitarianism\" title=\"Singularitarianism\">Singularitarianism</a> has also been likened to a religion by <a href=\"/wiki/John_Horgan_(American_journalist)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"John Horgan (American journalist)\">John Horgan</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Horgan_2008_52-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Horgan_2008-52\">[52]</a></sup></p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"History_of_the_concept\">History of the concept</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: History of the concept\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>In his obituary for John von Neumann, Ulam recalled a conversation with von Neumann about the \"ever accelerating progress of technology and changes in the mode of human life, which gives the appearance of approaching some essential singularity in the history of the race beyond which human affairs, as we know them, could not continue.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-mathematical_4-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-mathematical-4\">[4]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 1965, Good wrote his essay postulating an \"intelligence explosion\" of recursive self-improvement of a machine intelligence. In 1985, in \"The Time Scale of Artificial Intelligence\", artificial intelligence researcher <a href=\"/wiki/Ray_Solomonoff\" title=\"Ray Solomonoff\">Ray Solomonoff</a> articulated mathematically the related notion of what he called an \"infinity point\": if a research community of human-level self-improving AIs take four years to double their own speed, then two years, then one year and so on, their capabilities increase infinitely in finite time.<sup id=\"cite_ref-chalmers_5-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-chalmers-5\">[5]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-std_53-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-std-53\">[53]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 1983, Vinge greatly popularized Good's intelligence explosion in a number of writings, first addressing the topic in print in the January 1983 issue of <i><a href=\"/wiki/Omni_(magazine)\" title=\"Omni (magazine)\">Omni</a></i> magazine. In this op-ed piece, Vinge seems to have been the first to use the term \"singularity\" in a way that was specifically tied to the creation of intelligent machines:<sup id=\"cite_ref-google4_54-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-google4-54\">[54]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-technological_55-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-technological-55\">[55]</a></sup> writing</p>\n<blockquote class=\"templatequote\">\n<p>We will soon create intelligences greater than our own. When this happens, human history will have reached a kind of singularity, an intellectual transition as impenetrable as the knotted space-time at the center of a black hole, and the world will pass far beyond our understanding. This singularity, I believe, already haunts a number of science-fiction writers. It makes realistic extrapolation to an interstellar future impossible. To write a story set more than a century hence, one needs a nuclear war in between ... so that the world remains intelligible.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Vinge's 1993 article \"The Coming Technological Singularity: How to Survive in the Post-Human Era\",<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup> spread widely on the internet and helped to popularize the idea.<sup id=\"cite_ref-google5_56-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-google5-56\">[56]</a></sup> This article contains the statement, \"Within thirty years, we will have the technological means to create superhuman intelligence. Shortly after, the human era will be ended.\" Vinge argues that science-fiction authors cannot write realistic post-singularity characters who surpass the human intellect, as the thoughts of such an intellect would be beyond the ability of humans to express.<sup id=\"cite_ref-vinge1993_6-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-vinge1993-6\">[6]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2000, <a href=\"/wiki/Bill_Joy\" title=\"Bill Joy\">Bill Joy</a>, a prominent technologist and a co-founder of <a href=\"/wiki/Sun_Microsystems\" title=\"Sun Microsystems\">Sun Microsystems</a>, voiced concern over the potential dangers of the singularity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-JoyFuture_25-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-JoyFuture-25\">[25]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2005, Kurzweil published <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Singularity_is_Near\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"The Singularity is Near\">The Singularity is Near</a></i>. Kurzweil's publicity campaign included an appearance on <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Daily_Show_with_Jon_Stewart\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"The Daily Show with Jon Stewart\">The Daily Show with Jon Stewart</a></i>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-episode_57-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-episode-57\">[57]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2007, <a href=\"/wiki/Eliezer_Yudkowsky\" title=\"Eliezer Yudkowsky\">Eliezer Yudkowsky</a> suggested that many of the varied definitions that have been assigned to \"singularity\" are mutually incompatible rather than mutually supporting.<sup id=\"cite_ref-yudkowsky.net_11-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-yudkowsky.net-11\">[11]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-58\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-58\">[58]</a></sup> For example, Kurzweil extrapolates current technological trajectories past the arrival of self-improving AI or superhuman intelligence, which Yudkowsky argues represents a tension with both I. J. Good's proposed discontinuous upswing in intelligence and Vinge's thesis on unpredictability.<sup id=\"cite_ref-yudkowsky.net_11-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-yudkowsky.net-11\">[11]</a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2009, Kurzweil and <a href=\"/wiki/X-Prize\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"X-Prize\">X-Prize</a> founder <a href=\"/wiki/Peter_Diamandis\" title=\"Peter Diamandis\">Peter Diamandis</a> announced the establishment of <a href=\"/wiki/Singularity_University\" title=\"Singularity University\">Singularity University</a>, a nonaccredited private institute whose stated mission is \"to educate, inspire and empower leaders to apply exponential technologies to address humanity's grand challenges.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-singularityu_59-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-singularityu-59\">[59]</a></sup> Funded by <a href=\"/wiki/Google\" title=\"Google\">Google</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Autodesk\" title=\"Autodesk\">Autodesk</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/EPlanet_Ventures\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"EPlanet Ventures\">ePlanet Ventures</a>, and a group of <a href=\"/wiki/High_tech\" title=\"High tech\">technology industry</a> leaders, Singularity University is based at <a href=\"/wiki/NASA\" title=\"NASA\">NASA</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/Ames_Research_Center\" title=\"Ames Research Center\">Ames Research Center</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Mountain_View,_California\" title=\"Mountain View, California\">Mountain View</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/California\" title=\"California\">California</a>. The not-for-profit organization runs an annual ten-week graduate program during the northern-hemisphere summer that covers ten different technology and allied tracks, and a series of executive programs throughout the year.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"In_politics\">In politics</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15\" title=\"Edit section: In politics\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>In 2007, the joint Economic Committee of the <a href=\"/wiki/United_States_Congress\" title=\"United States Congress\">United States Congress</a> released a report about the future of nanotechnology. It predicts significant technological and political changes in the mid-term future, including possible technological singularity.<sup id=\"cite_ref-60\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-60\">[60]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-61\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-61\">[61]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-62\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-62\">[62]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Former President of the United States <a href=\"/wiki/Barack_Obama\" title=\"Barack Obama\">Barack Obama</a> spoke about singularity in his interview to <i><a href=\"/wiki/Wired_(magazine)\" title=\"Wired (magazine)\">Wired</a></i> in 2016:<sup id=\"cite_ref-63\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-63\">[63]</a></sup></p>\n<blockquote class=\"templatequote\">\n<p>One thing that we haven\u2019t talked about too much, and I just want to go back to, is we really have to think through the economic implications. Because most people aren\u2019t spending a lot of time right now worrying about singularity\u2014they are worrying about \u201cWell, is my job going to be replaced by a machine?\u201d</p>\n</blockquote>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"See_also\">See also</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Technological_singularity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16\" title=\"Edit section: See also\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"reflist columns references-column-width\">\n<ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"cite_note-1\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-1\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Cadwalladr, Carole (2014). \"<a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/feb/22/robots-google-ray-kurzweil-terminator-singularity-artificial-intelligence\">Are the robots about to rise? Penguin Group, 2005</span></li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-transformation-22\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-transformation_22-0\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">Ray Kurzweil, <i>The Singularity is Near</i>, pp. 135\u2013136. Penguin Group, 2005. \"So we will be producing about 10<sup>26</sup> to 10<sup>29</sup> cps of nonbiological computation per year in the early 2030s. This is roughly equal to our estimate for the capacity of all living biological human intelligence ... This state of computation in the early 2030s will not represent the Singularity, however, because it does not yet correspond to a profound expansion of our intelligence. By the mid-2040s, however, that one thousand dollars' worth of computation will be equal to 10<sup>26</sup> cps, so the intelligence created per year (at a total cost of about $10<sup>12</sup>) will be about one billion times more powerful than all human intelligence today. That <i>will</i> indeed represent a profound change, and it is for that reason that I set the date for the Singularity\u2014representing a profound and disruptive transformation in human capability\u2014as 2045.\"</span></li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-Kurzweil_2001-23\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-Kurzweil_2001_23-0\">^</a></b></span> <span
