Current plan is to forward emails to fastmail and just start replying with my new email address and overtime have people&#x27;s contacts update automatically."}, "15429806": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:19:33", "url": "https://medium.com/the-spike/the-loneliest-neuron-91e06432a01e", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><p name=\"6366\" id=\"6366\" class=\"graf graf--p graf--leading\">Take seeing. At the back of our retinas is a complex circuit, from the photoreceptors that ping when a photon hits them, that tickle multiple layers of neurons into life, who then spit their signal out to the rest of the brain (wired backwards, with the neurons sitting in front of the photoreceptors, like trying to watch a TV with the wires hanging in front of the screen). Immediately, the signal splits, some going up to the first \u201cvisual\u2019\u2019 cortex, some down to the brainstem. From these first way-stations, the signal travels onward, deeper into cortex, deeper into the brain. As we charge forward from your retina, we move deep into your brain, from neuron to neuron to neuron.</p><p name=\"639d\" id=\"639d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Take reaching for your phone. Your arm and shoulder muscles variously contract and relax to move your hand from where it was to where your phone is. Neurons in your spinal cord connect directly to these muscles; firing these neurons contracts the muscle. Behind those neurons are other neurons in your spinal cord; further behind them, the neurons in your brain stem and motor cortex. As we pull back from the muscles, we move up and through your brain, from neuron to neuron to neuron.</p><p name=\"8017\" id=\"8017\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">And, somewhere, we hit the loneliest neurons. The neurons the most steps forward from the senses; the most steps back from the muscles. But they are connected to them. To them all, eventually. Shouldn\u2019t this mean we find the activity of the loneliest neurons is related to, well, everything?</p><p name=\"3d9e\" id=\"3d9e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Yes it does. The loneliest neurons may well be somewhere in the darkest corner of the prefrontal cortex\u200a\u2014\u200asay, the infralimbic\u200a\u2014\u200amany steps removed from the regions of cortex that get direct input from the senses or talk down to the neurons in the spinal cord. Yet neural activity in prefrontal cortex seems to know about everything. Neurons there can change their activity according to the past (memory) and the future (upcoming decisions); to the colour and motion of objects in the world; to where the animal is right now. Some, perhaps most, of the neurons in prefrontal cortex even respond to combinations of these things.</p><p name=\"dd65\" id=\"dd65\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Or the loneliest neurons may well be in the obliquely obscure globus pallidus\u200a\u2014\u200aa pale globe of neurons, tucked underneath the striatum, reaching their tendrils into all the other nuclei of the basal ganglia. Far, far from the senses and motion. Yet neurons here have different activity according to how the arm is about to moved; and respond differently to when a reward is delivered to when it is not.</p><p name=\"e112\" id=\"e112\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p graf--trailing\">Wherever they are, when we record activity from the loneliest neurons, we indeed see they respond to both sensory and motor events, to both the past and future.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429807": {"score": 226, "comments": ["Pittsburgher here. by curbing emissions from power plants.</p>\n<p>Pruitt has <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/03/us/politics/epa-scott-pruitt-calendar-industries-coal-oil-environmentalists.html\">reportedly the regulatory agency.</p>\n<p>Under Pruitt, the EPA has already <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/scott-pruitt-trumps-epa-chief-met-with-dow-chemical-exec-before-rolling-back-a-ban-on-pesticides-2017-6\">reversed a ban on a pesticide</a> that can harm Act to prohibit industries from dumping pollutants into streams and wetlands. The agency has also <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/epa-challenging-climate-change-science-scott-pruitt-2017-6\">reportedly begun an initiative</a> to challenge climate science, among other rollbacks. Some of these moves have been <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/06/climate/trump-administration-environmental-regulations.html\">challenged in court</a>, but others are already in effect.</p>\n<p>If Pruitt succeeds in rolling back a significant portion of the rules meant to protect air and water quality, we'd return to the state the US was in before these things were regulated.</p>\n<p>The EPA was founded in 1970 and soon after <a href=\"https://www.epa.gov/history/historical-photos-and-images\">began</a> a photo project called <a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/usnationalarchives/sets/72157620856436476/with/3703575717/\">Documerica</a> that captured more than 81,000 images showing what the US looked like from 1971 to 1977. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo - RTX32ECV\" data-mce-source=\"Thomson Reuters\" data-mce-caption=\"FILE PHOTO: A picture illustration shows a YouTube logo reflected in a person's eye\"/>\n      <span class=\"source-only source\">Thomson\n  Reuters</span>\n    </span>\n  </p>\n  <p>\n  It wasn't until Thursday,\u00c2\u00a0more than three days after the\n  shooting, that <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/youtube-changes-search-results-conspiracy-theories-2017-10\">\n  YouTube decided to do something</a>\u00c2\u00a0and rushed\u00c2\u00a0out a\n  planned\u00c2\u00a0change to the search algorithm designed to promote\n  news videos from authoritative sources. A source close to YouTube\n  told me the earlier-than-planned rollout of the\n  change\u00c2\u00a0was\u00c2\u00a0in response to criticism of how it handled\n  the Las Vegas shooting videos.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  It's been 11 months since the 2016 US election, when\n  the\u00c2\u00a0plague\u00c2\u00a0of fake news and abuse on internet platforms\n  became a mainstream problem. Since then, Facebook, Google, and\n  Twitter have all made attempts to change their algorithms and\n  services to combat the problem. But despite their efforts and\n  all\u00c2\u00a0that\u00c2\u00a0time, it still\u00c2\u00a0requires a journalist or\n  noisy critic to point out a problem\u00c2\u00a0before something gets\n  fixed.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  Then come the half-hearted apologies and promises to do better.\n  And the cycle repeats itself.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  In April, for example, Google said it <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/google-launches-new-search-tools-to-combat-fake-news-2017-4\">\n  made changes to its search algorithm</a> to favor authoritative\n  sources for news, just like YouTube did this week. Every new\n  update, every new press release, every new headline\u00c2\u00a0designed\n  to show there's\u00c2\u00a0an investment into the problem ends up being\n  trumped by a new controversy. When Facebook announced this week\n  it was <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-needs-to-stop-hiding-behind-excuses-and-release-the-fake-russian-ads-2017-10http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-blew-its-response-to-fake-russian-ads-2017-10\">\n  throwing 1,000 new employees at the ad abuse problem</a> on its\n  site, NYU professor and author of the tech business book \"The\n  Four\", Scott Galloway <a href=\"https://twitter.com/profgalloway/status/914950619529703424\">called\n  it</a> \"pissing in the ocean.\"\n</p>\n  <p>\n  The problem is too big for incremental updates and promises to do\n  better after each screwup.\u00c2\u00a0 And these sites have become so\n  massive and influential, that they have a responsibility to get\n  it right.\u00c2\u00a0\n</p>\n  <h2>\n  Unfortunate timing\n</h2>\n  <p>\n    <span class=\"KonaFilter image-container display-table image on-image\" data-post-image=\"\">\n      <img src=\"http://static6.businessinsider.com/image/59b1a51c45e2381d008b50da-2400/sundarclose.jpg\" alt=\"Sundar Pichai\" data-mce-source=\"Justin Sullivan / Getty Staff\"/>\n      <span class=\"source-only source\">Justin Sullivan / Getty Staff</span>\n    </span>\n  </p>\n  <p>\n  In an<a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/4/16405174/ceo-sundar-pichai-interview-google-ai-artificial-intelligence-interface\">\u00c2\u00a0interview\n  with The Verge</a> last week Google CEO Sundar Pichai discussed\n  the responsibility Google has as the distributor of massive\n  amounts\u00c2\u00a0of information.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  \"Today, we overwhelmingly get it right. But I think every single\n  time we stumble. I feel the pain, and I think we should be held\n  accountable,\"\u00c2\u00a0Pichai said.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  In a telling case of unfortunate timing, at the\u00c2\u00a0very moment\n  Pichai's comments\u00c2\u00a0were published, the online\n  platforms\u00c2\u00a0he\u00c2\u00a0oversees were promoting a bunch of garbage\n  about Las Vegas.\u00c2\u00a0\n</p>\n  <p>\n  Google, YouTube's parent company, <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/las-vegas-shooting-mandalay-bay-facebook-twitter-google-2017-10\">\n  promoted\u00c2\u00a0</a><span><a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/las-vegas-shooting-mandalay-bay-facebook-twitter-google-2017-10\">a\n  conspiracy theory thread on 4Chan in its search</a> results and\n  took hours to get rid of it. And competitors like\n  Facebook\u00c2\u00a0performed equally poorly, with the social\n  network's\u00c2\u00a0\"crisis response\"\u00c2\u00a0page for the Las Vegas\n  shooting promoting unconfirmed reports and conspiracy theories\n  from sites like Gateway Pundit</span>\n</p>\n  <p>\n  One way to be held accountable is to be proactive and\n  transparent, something none of the companies claiming they feel a\n  sense of responsibility have adequately done. For example,\n  Facebook's pledge to hire those 1,000 new employees to monitor ad\n  abuse and tweak its algorithm came with a <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-needs-to-stop-hiding-behind-excuses-and-release-the-fake-russian-ads-2017-10http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-blew-its-response-to-fake-russian-ads-2017-10\">\n  shocking lack of detail and transparency</a>. We have no\n  clarification on how the employees will be trained, whether\n  they're contractors or full-time workers, or what standards\n  they'll be operating under. It's the latest promise to do\n  something from a company that has proven over and over that it's\n  ill-prepared, or un-motivated, to handle the darker edges of its\n  platform. The same goes for its peers.\n</p>\n  <p>\n  These\u00c2\u00a0companies\u00c2\u00a0employ some most brilliant minds in the\n  world. They\u00c2\u00a0should be more than capable of\u00c2\u00a0tackling\n  this problem and fixing it. Instead, they routinely wait for\n  someone on the outside to point out a mistake before it gets\n  fixed.\u00c2\u00a0\n</p>\n  <p>\n  That's\u00c2\u00a0embarrassing. But even worse, it's dangerous.\u00c2\u00a0\n</p>\n</div>\n            </div></body></html>"}, "15430333": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:20:58", "url": "https://blog.ethereum.org/2015/11/24/applications-of-security-deposits-and-prediction-markets-you-might-not-have-thought-about/", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"postbody\">&#13;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<p><em>Special thanks to Vlad Zamfir for his work in developing many of the ideas behind prediction markets for content curation.</em></p>\n<p>For the past six years, people have been searching to try to find those elusive applications of blockchain technology that could finally break out into the mainstream. For cryptocurrency, the applications are largely already known \u2013 though it of course remains to be seen just how well it will be able to retain its advantages as traditional payment systems continue to become more efficient. But what about smart contracts and crypto 2.0? One route that we can take is to simply look where legal contracts are being used today, and see where we can increase efficiencies by \u201csmart-ifying\u201d as many of them as possible. Another route, however, is the Peter Thiel-ian <a href=\"http://zerotoonebook.com/\">zero-to-one</a> approach: see if it\u2019s possible to use these tools to create industries that currently do not exist. Hence, let us take a detour along that path, and see some of the more underappreciated and interesting applications that smart contracts can provide.</p>\n<h3>Hashcash meets Proof of Stake</h3>\n<p>Although proof of work is today known primarily for its function in blockchain consensus algorithms, its original function was in fact something quite different. The first major use of proof of work was Adam Back\u2019s <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hashcash\">Hashcash</a>, a protocol that tries to fight email spam by making spam emails more expensive to generate. Proof of stake is today similarly best known for its applications in blockchain consensus, and the theory is that because of the way modern proof of stake works \u2013 allowing users to <em>put at stake</em> large amounts of economic resources for security without, in the normal case, <em>actually spending them</em> \u2013 it could potentially be vastly more efficient. So this leads to an interesting question: can we apply these advantages to make a more efficient version of Hashcash using proof of stake as well?</p>\n<p>Let us start by describing the problem. The basic principle behind Hashcash rests on the idea that email today tends to be split into two categories: desirable email (\u201cham\u201d), which people spend a reasonably large amount of effort writing and which people derive high value from reading, and undesirable email (\u201cspam\u201d), which people normally spend a much smaller amount of effort per email writing and which people derive a <em>negative</em> amount of value from reading. Hence, the theory goes, by attaching a small mandatory cost to each email sent, the \u201cham\u201d can get through with only slight additional burden, whereas \u201cspam\u201d would be made entirely unprofitable. This \u201ccost\u201d is paid in the form of electricity and computational effort which is used to solve a mathematical puzzle that can be quickly verified by the recipient\u2019s client before showing the email to the recipient.</p>\n<p>The problem with this approach is threefold. First, spammers may simply switch to a strategy of spending slightly more effort on each email (eg. spending five seconds of human labor per message to make it more likely to catch the reader\u2019s attention or bypass spam filters), and the threshold of computational work that would be needed to actually stop the majority of spam would be quite large. Second, spammers are more professional and have better access to specialized computer hardware that can quickly and cheaply solve these computational puzzles, so a cost that might be five cents to the ordinary user might only be a tenth of a cent to a spammer. Third, as this <a href=\"http://craphound.com/spamsolutions.txt\">now-famous checklist</a> listing flaws in popular proposed solutions to email spam points out, it is considered highly desirable to have a system where \u201csending email should be free\u201d.</p>\n<p>So here is a proof-of-stake alternative. When you send an email, you do not need to compute an expensive computational puzzle; instead, send a transaction to the blockchain which creates a contract containing some amount of money as a security deposit. As part of the email, send a private key to the recipient, which the recipient can submit into the contract to destroy the deposit (or donate it to a standardized charity) <b>if they want to</b>. If the deposit is not destroyed for some number of days, it is refunded to the sender. Note that there would be no gain to the recipient in destroying the deposit \u2013 the only motivation to do so would be pure spite. As a result, we get an asymmetry: the average cost for normal people to send an email would be small, because the recipient would only click \u201cReport Spam\u201d in the rare case that <em>they</em> are malicious, but the average cost for spammers would be quite high indeed \u2013 and specialized hardware asymmetries would not help spammers one bit.</p>\n<p>One could see deposits going as high as a dollar in size, and one can even adopt a graduated scheme: senders can send whatever deposits they want above some minimum, but the <em>level of notification</em> that the recipient sees would depend on the exact amount. If it\u2019s $0.1, then it\u2019s just an email in their mailbox. If it\u2019s $1, then a few phone notifications. If it\u2019s $500, then their phone would ring at maximum volume overriding all other settings \u2013 but the sender best be prepared to pay the price if the recipient deems the sender\u2019s intrusion unjustified.</p>\n<p>One can create more advanced versions of this scheme that do not require sending a transaction to create a new deposit for each email; one can imagine a scheme where the sender sends out many keys to destroy portions of the same security deposit, alongside signatures saying that those keys are valid, and recipients publish the signatures (but not the keys!) to a Whisper-like channel allowing them to quickly sample and make sure that a particular deposit is not \u201cover-subscribed\u201d with destruction keys (one precise mechanism for doing this is to only treat signatures containing an index from 1 to N as valid, and add a rule that states that two signatures with the same index can be submitted to destroy the entire deposit with 10% transferred to the submitter; hence, one can be fairly sure that at most N signatures for that deposit exist). This would reduce the transaction load to roughly something like one transaction per email sender per year. In any case, smart contracts offer near-infinite room for creativity in optimizing the details.</p>\n<h3>Prediction Markets and Reddit</h3>\n<p>One of the largest debates in online communities like Reddit is the question of exactly how much centralized moderation is justified. One view is that the very power of the internet comes in large part from its egalitarian decentralized nature, and the fact that no single party has a higher class of authority than any other. Some people may be more influential than others, but (i) that is a difference of degree and not a categorical distinction of class, and (ii) it is fundamentally the audience\u2019s choice to be influenced. The other view is that without centralized moderation, communities inevitably collapse into mediocrity and chaos of the undesirable kind; essentially, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eternal_September\">Eternal September</a>, and so having a small number of users ultimately in charge is, as is in many places the case, a \u201cnecessary evil\u201d.</p>\n<p>In practice, community voting moderation is quite powerful, but the centralist view also seems to have some merit. Although comments that a community does not want to see do eventually get voted down, at least on Reddit specifically the process takes time, and there is still a period of one or two hours during which such content remains on the front page. Within a voting framework, to some extent this is unavoidable: if it was possible for a barrage of downvotes to very quickly remove content from the front page, that itself would turn into a censorship vector for vocal minorities. However, what if there was a third way to solve this problem, by using our favorite governance mechanism: <a href=\"https://blog.ethereum.org/2014/08/21/introduction-futarchy/\">prediction markets</a>?</p>\n<p>Prediction markets have so far, including by myself, often been introduced as a governance mechanism that could one day be employed for very large-scale decisions: whether or not we should bail out the banks, hire or fire a particular CEO, or enter a particular trade agreement. However, perhaps it might be better to introduce prediction markets into the world as a tool for decisions which are far more small-scale and non-threatening \u2013 perhaps on the scale of hundreds or tens of dollars, or even ten cents.</p>\n<p>One could imagine a design that works as follows. Rather than simply being votes, upvotes and downvotes to a comment on a hypothetical PredictionReddit would be bets on a prediction market specific to that comment. The prediction market would be seeded by a mandatory bet that would need to be made by the person making the comment that their comment will be accepted as good; from there, upvotes and downvotes would shift the \u201cprice\u201d of the market depending on how people vote. 99% of the time, the market would have no effect except that comments with high prices would be shown more prominently on the interface; the remaining 1% of the time, however, the comment would be submitted to a meta-moderation panel, which would vote on whether the comment is good or bad (or perhaps some score in between), and the participants in the prediction market would be compensated appropriately based on how well they predicted this score.</p>\n<p>The meta-moderation panel could in principle be quite large; potentially every single participant in the community could be included, provided an effective anti-sybil mechanism was in place. Even a <a href=\"https://blog.ethereum.org/2014/03/28/schellingcoin-a-minimal-trust-universal-data-feed/\">SchellingCoin oracle</a> could be used. It also does not have to be the case that 99% of markets are discarded; one could instead have a model where <em>all</em> markets are processed, but only a small portion of the meta-moderation panel sees each individual post; the number of people need only be large enough that they cannot practically collude for the purpose of insider trading the prediction markets. Another alternative is to have the size or probability of meta-moderation be proportional to the volume of the market, so that the posts that receive the most attention are the ones where the stakes are highest. In any case, this particular means of combining Reddit and cryptocurrency seems at least a bit more promising than simply integrating the ability to express condolences for someone\u2019s death <a href=\"http://hackingdistributed.com/2014/12/17/changetip-must-die/\">by micro-tipping their relatives three cents</a>.</p>\n<p>In principle, either of these two models could be extended quite a bit: imagine ads that are more expensive to maintain the more annoying they are to viewers, or a decentralized search engine where anyone can \u201cplug in\u201d their ranking algorithms by participating in the prediction markets, and profiting only if the algorithms are effective. Oleg Andreev\u2019s <a href=\"http://blog.oleganza.com/post/58240549599/contracts-without-trust-or-third-parties\">2-of-2 escrow</a> could be augmented with a reputation system via a prediction market on the probability that the escrow deposit will be destroyed or payment delayed. Just remember, security deposits and prediction markets are essentially equivalent: <b>a prediction market is a security deposit where anyone can challenge and require a higher deposit in response, and anyone else can back the original depositor up, and a security deposit is a prediction market where one particular party is forced to make a mandatory bet</b>.</p>\n<p>Perhaps this is a large part of the potential of what crypto 2.0 technology can offer: bring the internet from simple <em>information technologies</em> to <em>economic information technologies</em> that could potentially radically increase efficiencies, at least in a few sectors of the digital economy, by using incentives to more cleverly elicit the information that we all individually have. In any case, let\u2019s build these tools and find out.</p>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</section>&#13;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429311": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:29:09", "url": "https://medium.com/@copyconstruct/monitoring-in-the-time-of-cloud-native-c87c7a5bfa3e", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><h1 name=\"e3ef\" id=\"e3ef\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf--leading graf--title\">Monitoring in the time of Cloud\u00a0Native</h1><p name=\"8181\" id=\"8181\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Note\u200a\u2014\u200aHuge thanks to Jamie Wilkinson and Julius Volz, Google SREs present and past, for reading a draft of this and giving me invaluable suggestions. All mistakes and opinions however, are solely mine. This was, in essence, </em><a href=\"https://conferences.oreilly.com/velocity/vl-ny/public/schedule/detail/61529\" data-href=\"https://conferences.oreilly.com/velocity/vl-ny/public/schedule/detail/61529\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">my Velocity 2017 talk</em></a><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">.</em></p><p name=\"0a3c\" id=\"0a3c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The infrastructure space is in the midst of a paradigm-shifting change. The way organizations\u200a\u2014\u200afrom the smallest of startups to established companies\u200a\u2014\u200abuild and operate systems has evolved.</p><p name=\"bf01\" id=\"bf01\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Containers, Kubernetes, microservices, service meshes, immutable infrastructure are all incredibly <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">promising</em> ideas which fundamentally change the way we operate software. As more and more organizations move toward these paradigms, the systems we build have become more distributed and in the case of containerization, more ephemeral.</p><p name=\"aab8\" id=\"aab8\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">While we\u2019re still at the stage of early adoption with the failure modes of these new paradigms still very nebulous and not widely advertised, it\u2019s also true that these tools are only going to get increasingly better with time. Soon enough, if not already, we\u2019ll be at that point where the network and underlying hardware failures have been robustly abstracted away from us, leaving us with the sole responsibility to ensure our <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">application </em>is good enough to piggy bank on top of the latest and greatest in networking and scheduling abstractions.</p><p name=\"3093\" id=\"3093\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">No amount of GIFEE (Google Infrastructure for Everyone Else) or industrial-grade service mesh is going to fix the software we write. Better resilience and failure-tolerant paradigms from off-the-shelf components now means that\u200a\u2014\u200aassuming said off-the-shelf components have been configured correctly\u200a\u2014\u200amost failures will arise from the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">application layer</em> or from the complex interactions between different applications. Trusting Kubernetes and friends to do their job makes it more important than ever for us to focus on the vagaries of the performance characteristics of <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">our</em></strong> application and business logic. Application developers now have <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">one job</em>. We\u2019re at a time when it has never been easier for application developers to focus on just making their service more robust and trust that if they do so, then the open source software they are building on top of will pay the concomitant dividends.</p><p name=\"d93d\" id=\"d93d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In order to manoeuvre this brave new world successfully, gaining <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">visibility</em> into our services and infrastructure becomes more important than ever before to successfully understand, operate, maintain and evolve these.</p><p name=\"56dc\" id=\"56dc\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Fortunately for us, newer tools have emerged to help us meet this challenge. While one might argue that these tools suffer from the selfsame problem they assist us in solving\u200a\u2014\u200aviz, the tools themselves are every bit as nascent and emergent as the infrastructural paradigms they help us gain visibility into\u200a\u2014\u200astrong community interest, community driven development and an open governance model do a lot to promote the sustainability and development of these tools.</p><p name=\"6e51\" id=\"6e51\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In addition to a surge in open source tooling, SaaS tooling modeled along the lines of Google, Twitter, and Facebook\u2019s internal tools have emerged to address the real need felt by the the early adopters of cloud native paradigms. Given how far both categories of tools have evolved in recent years, we now have an embarrassment of tools to choose from.</p><h4 name=\"8664\" id=\"8664\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Decision Making in the Time of Cloud\u00a0Native</h4><p name=\"98d9\" id=\"98d9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">A plethora of tools at our disposal to adopt or buy, however, presents a different problem\u200a\u2014\u200aone of decision making.</p><p name=\"e9fe\" id=\"e9fe\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">How do we choose the best tool for our needs? How do we even tell the difference between these tools when several of these more or less do the same thing? We might\u2019ve heard that monitoring is dead and \u201cObservability\u201d is all the rage now. Does that mean we stop monitoring? We hear a lot about the \u201cthree pillars of observability\u201d, but what even is Observability and why should we care? What really is the difference between logs and metrics, except where we send them to? We might\u2019ve heard a lot of tracing\u200a\u2014\u200abut how useful can tracing really be if it\u2019s only just a log with some context? Is a metric just a log or trace that occurs too frequently for a backend system to store? Do we <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">really </em>need all three of them?</p><p name=\"a85e\" id=\"a85e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I\u2019ve said this before in one of my posts, but it bears reiterating. It\u2019s tempting, especially when enamored by a new piece of technology that promises the moon, to retrofit our problem space with the solution space of said technology, however minimal the intersection. Before buying or building a tool, it becomes important to evaluate the maximum utility it can provide for the unique set of engineering challenges specific teams face. In order to be able to make better technological choices\u200a\u2014\u200aespecially when it comes down to choosing something as critical as a monitoring stack\u200a\u2014\u200ait becomes absolutely necessary for us to first fully understand:</p><p name=\"8dce\" id=\"8dce\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 the strengths and weaknesses of each category of tools\u00a0<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200athe problems they solve<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200athe tradeoffs they make<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200atheir ease of adoption/integration into an existing infrastructure</p><p name=\"6c45\" id=\"6c45\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Most importantly, it becomes important to make sure that we are solving the problems <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">we have, </em>not using the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">solutions</em> these new crop of tools provide. Starting over from scratch isn\u2019t a luxury most of us enjoy and the most challenging part about modernizing one\u2019s monitoring stack is iteratively evolving it. Iterative evolution\u200a\u2014\u200aof <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">refactoring</em>, if you will\u200a\u2014\u200aof one\u2019s monitoring stack in turn presents a large number of challenges from both a technical as well as an organizational standpoint.</p><p name=\"7f61\" id=\"7f61\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The goal of this post is to shed light on these technologies and primarily frame the discussion in the context of the problems that we will be solving and the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">tradeoffs </em>we might be making. It\u2019s important for me to state upfront that the main purpose of this post isn\u2019t to provide catch-all <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">answers</em> or solutions or demos of specific tools. What I hope to achieve with this post is leave you with some ideas and hopefully some questions that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">you </em>can try to answer as you design systems with the goal of bringing better visibility to them.</p><h4 name=\"03c6\" id=\"03c6\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Outline</h4><p name=\"a4af\" id=\"a4af\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">\u2014 What even is Observability and how is it different from Monitoring?<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aAn overview of the three pillars of modern observability: logging, metrics collection, and request tracing\u00a0<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aThe pros and cons of each in terms of resource utilization, ease of use, ease of operation, and cost effectiveness<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aAn honest look at the challenges involved in scaling all the three when used in conjunction\u00a0<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aWhat to monitor and how in a modern cloud native environment; what is better-suited to be aggregated as metrics versus being logged; how and when to use the data from all the three sources to derive actionable alerts and insightful analysis\u00a0<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aWhen it makes sense to augment the three aforementioned tools with additional tools</p><h4 name=\"4db7\" id=\"4db7\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">What to \u201cmonitor\u201d and how in a modern cloud native environment?</h4><p name=\"469a\" id=\"469a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">This post/talk is titled <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Monitoring in the time of Cloud Native</em></strong>. I\u2019ve been asked why I chose to call it Monitoring and not Observability. I was expecting more snark about the buzzword that\u2019s actually <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">in </em>the title\u200a\u2014\u200a<strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Cloud Native\u200a</em></strong>\u2014\u200athan the one conspicuous by its absence. I chose not to call it Observability for this very same reason\u200a\u2014\u200atwo buzzwords was one too many for my liking.</p><p name=\"1c2d\" id=\"1c2d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">In all seriousness though, I do believe there\u2019s a difference between the two. The reason I believe so is because the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">nature</em> <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">of</em> <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">failure </em>is changing, the way our systems behave (or <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">misbehave</em>) as a whole is changing, the requirements these systems need to meet are changing, the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">guarantees</em> these systems need to provide are changing. In order to rise to these challenges successfully, it becomes <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">necessary </em>to not just change the way we build and operate software, but also to then follow that up with better visibility into our services, which in turn gives us a shorter feedback loop about the performance of our services in production, which in turn enables us to build better services. In order to craft this virtuous cycle, it becomes important to understand what\u2019s Observability and how it differs from Monitoring.</p><figure name=\"2428\" id=\"2428\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Virtuous cycle of better Observability</figcaption></figure><h4 name=\"2011\" id=\"2011\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--figure\">Monitoring</h4><p name=\"cf27\" id=\"cf27\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">When I type \u201cmonitoring\u201d into Google, the first two results that come up are the following:</p><blockquote name=\"baad\" id=\"baad\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">\u2014 observe and check the progress or quality of (something) <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--blockquote-strong\">over a period of time</strong>; keep under systematic review.</blockquote><blockquote name=\"7210\" id=\"7210\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--blockquote\">\u2014 maintain regular surveillance over.</blockquote><p name=\"fa91\" id=\"fa91\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Monitoring, to me, connotes something that is inherently both <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">failure</em> as well as <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">human </em>centric<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">. </em>Let\u2019s talk a bit more about this because this forms the bedrock of this post.</p><figure name=\"5e0b\" id=\"5e0b\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"f20c\" id=\"f20c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">In the past, we might\u2019ve first tested our application.</p><figure name=\"c4c7\" id=\"c4c7\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Application Development and Release Lifecycle</figcaption></figure><p name=\"9448\" id=\"9448\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">This might\u2019ve been followed by a QA cycle.</p><figure name=\"4877\" id=\"4877\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Application Development and Release Lifecycle</figcaption></figure><p name=\"822d\" id=\"822d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Then we might\u2019ve released our code, followed by \u201cmonitoring\u201d it.</p><figure name=\"88ad\" id=\"88ad\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Application Development and Release Lifecycle</figcaption></figure><p name=\"96d6\" id=\"96d6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Followed by leaving a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">lot </em>to chance.</p><figure name=\"2dcc\" id=\"2dcc\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Application Development and Release Lifecycle</figcaption></figure><p name=\"6174\" id=\"6174\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Now, I honestly don\u2019t think this was how <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">everyone </em>has been managing software lifecycle, but it makes for a good caricature of what\u2019s often considered \u201cthe old way\u201d.</p><p name=\"6e06\" id=\"6e06\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">We \u201cmonitored\u201d something because we expected something to behave a certain way. What\u2019s worse, we expected something to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">fail</em> in a very <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">specific manner</em> and wanted to keep tabs on this specific failure. An \u201cexplicit, predictable failure\u201d centric approach to monitoring becomes a problem when the number of failure modes both increases and failure itself becomes more <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">implicit</em>.</p><p name=\"54a6\" id=\"54a6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">As we adopt increasingly complex architectures, the number of \u201cthings that can go wrong\u201d exponentially increases. We often hear that we live in an era when failure is the norm. The <a href=\"https://landing.google.com/sre/book/index.html\" data-href=\"https://landing.google.com/sre/book/index.html\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">SRE book</a> states that:</p><blockquote name=\"9546\" id=\"9546\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">It turns out that past a certain point, however, increasing reliability is worse for a service (and its users) rather than better! Extreme reliability comes at a cost: maximizing stability limits how fast new features can be developed and how quickly products can be delivered to users, and dramatically increases their cost, which in turn reduces the number of features a team can afford to offer.</blockquote><blockquote name=\"dcf7\" id=\"dcf7\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--blockquote\">Our goal is to explicitly align the risk taken by a given service with the risk the business is willing to bear. We strive to make a service reliable enough, but no <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--blockquote-strong\">more</strong> reliable than it needs to be.</blockquote><p name=\"d21e\" id=\"d21e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Opting in to the model of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">embracing </em>failure entails designing our services to behave gracefully in the face of failure. In other words, this means turning hard, explicit failure modes into partial, implicit and soft failure modes. Failure modes that could be papered over with graceful degradation mechanisms like retries, timeouts, circuit breaking and rate limiting. Failure modes that can be tolerated owing to relaxed consistency guarantees with mechanisms like eventual consistency or aggressive multi-tiered caching. Failure modes that can be even <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">triggered</em> deliberately with load shedding in the event of increased load that has the potential to take down our service entirely, thereby operating in a degraded state.</p><p name=\"aa42\" id=\"aa42\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">But all of this comes at the cost of increased overall <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">complexity</em> and the buyer\u2019s remorse often acutely felt is the loss of ability to easily reason about systems.</p><p name=\"4c5e\" id=\"4c5e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Which brings me to the second characteristic of \u201cmonitoring\u201d\u200a\u2014\u200ain that it\u2019s <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">human</em> centric. The reason we chose to \u201cmonitor\u201d something was because we knew or suspected something <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">could</em> go wrong, and that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">when</em> it <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">did</em> go wrong there were consequences. Real consequences. High severity consequences that needed to be remedied as soon as possible. Consequences that needed human intervention.</p><p name=\"57ef\" id=\"57ef\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Now I\u2019m not someone who believes that automating everything is a panacea, but the advent of platforms like Kubernetes means that several of the problems that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">human and failure</em> centric monitoring tools of yore helped \u201cmonitor\u201d are already solved. Health-checking, load balancing and taking failed services out of rotation and so forth are features these platforms provide for free. That\u2019s their primary value prop.</p><p name=\"8fb0\" id=\"8fb0\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">With more of the traditional monitoring responsibilities being automated away, \u201cmonitoring\u201d has become\u200a\u2014\u200aor will soon be\u200a\u2014\u200aless <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">human</em> <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">centric</em>. While none of these platforms will truly make a service <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">impregnable </em>to failure, if used correctly, they can help reduce the number of hard failures, leaving us as engineers to contend with the subtle, nebulous, unpredictable behaviors our system can exhibit. The sort of failures that are far less catastrophic but ever more numerous than before.</p><p name=\"b63f\" id=\"b63f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Which then begs the question\u200a\u2014\u200ahow do we design <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">monitoring </em>for such systems?</p><p name=\"c373\" id=\"c373\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">It really isn\u2019t even so much about how to design <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">monitoring </em>for these systems, than how to design the systems<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> themselves</em>.</p><p name=\"18ec\" id=\"18ec\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I\u2019d argue that \u201cmonitoring\u201d should <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">still</em> be both hard failure as well as human centric even in this brave new world. The <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">goal </em>of \u201cmonitoring\u201d hasn\u2019t changed, even if the scope has <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">shrunk </em>drastically, and the challenge that now lies ahead of us is identifying and minimizing the bits of \u201cmonitoring\u201d that still remain human centric. We need to design our systems such that only a small sliver of the overall failure domain is now of the hard, urgently human actionable sort.</p><p name=\"e0cc\" id=\"e0cc\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">But there\u2019s a paradox. Minimizing the number of \u201chard, predictable\u201d failure modes doesn\u2019t in any way mean that the system itself as a whole is any simpler. In other words, even as infrastructure management becomes more automated and requiring less human elbow grease, application lifecycle management is becoming harder. As the number of hard failure modes shrink at the expense of a drastic rise in implicit failure modes and <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">overall</em> complexity, \u201cmonitoring\u201d every failure explicitly becomes infeasible and also unnecessary.</p><h4 name=\"dbf8\" id=\"dbf8\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Observability</h4><p name=\"532d\" id=\"532d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Observability, in my opinion, is really about being able to understand how a system is behaving in production. If \u201cmonitoring\u201d is best suited to report the overall health of systems, \u201cobservability\u201d, on the other hand, aims to provide highly granular insights into the behavior of systems along with rich context, perfect for providing visibility into <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">implicit failure modes</em> and on the fly generation of information required for debugging. Monitoring is being on the lookout for failures, which in turn requires us to be able to predict these failures proactively. An observable system is one that exposes enough <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">data</em> about itself so that<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> generating information </em>(finding answers to questions yet to be formulated) and easily accessing this information becomes simple.</p><h4 name=\"e08f\" id=\"e08f\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">An interlude\u200a\u2014\u200aBlackbox Monitoring</h4><p name=\"515b\" id=\"515b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">For the uninitiated, blackbox monitoring refers to the category of monitoring derived by treating the system as a blackbox and examining it from the outside. While some believe that with more sophisticated tooling at our disposal blackbox monitoring is a thing of the past, I\u2019d argue that blackbox monitoring still has its place, what with large parts of core business and infrastructural components being outsourced to third-party vendors. While the amount of control we might have over the performance of the vendor might be limited, having <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">visibility</em> into how services we own are impacted by the vagaries of outsourced components becomes exceedingly crucial insofar as it affects our system\u2019s performance as a whole.</p><figure name=\"00cd\" id=\"00cd\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Blackbox monitoring</figcaption></figure><p name=\"ffb4\" id=\"ffb4\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Even outside of third-party integrations, treating our own systems as blackboxes might still have some value, especially in a microservices environment where several services owned by different teams might be involved in servicing a request. In the words of an engineer I know:</p><blockquote name=\"6818\" id=\"6818\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">It\u2019s so nice being in an org that communicates quantitatively about systems.</blockquote><p name=\"3a32\" id=\"3a32\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">It seems pragmatic for individual teams to treat services owned by other teams as blackboxes. This enables individual teams to design better integrations with other systems owned by different teams based on the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">contracts</em> they expose and <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">guarantees</em> they offer\u200a\u2014\u200atheir SLA, in other words.</p><figure name=\"58b9\" id=\"58b9\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Whitebox vs Blackbox monitoring</figcaption></figure><h4 name=\"691b\" id=\"691b\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--figure\">Whitebox Monitoring versus Observability</h4><p name=\"8d6b\" id=\"8d6b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf--startsWithDoubleQuote graf-after--h4\">\u201c<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Whitebox </em>monitoring\u201d refers to a category of \u201cmonitoring\u201d based on the information derived from the internals of systems. Whitebox monitoring isn\u2019t really a revolutionary idea anymore. Time series, logs and traces are all more in vogue than ever these days and have been for a few years.</p><p name=\"c5b6\" id=\"c5b6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">So then. Is Observability just whitebox monitoring by another name?</p><p name=\"c1bb\" id=\"c1bb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Well, not <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">quite</em>.</p><h4 name=\"3676\" id=\"3676\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Data and Information</h4><p name=\"f95d\" id=\"f95d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">The difference between whitebox monitoring and observability really is the difference between data and information. The formal definition of information is:</p><blockquote name=\"2a5c\" id=\"2a5c\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--blockquote-strong\">Data</strong> are simply facts or figures\u200a\u2014\u200a<em class=\"markup--em markup--blockquote-em\">bits</em> of information, but not information itself. When data are processed, interpreted, organized, structured or presented so as to make them meaningful or useful, they are called <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--blockquote-strong\">information</strong>. Information provides context for data.</blockquote><p name=\"0311\" id=\"0311\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">The distinction between monitoring and observability isn\u2019t just about if the data is being reported from the bowels of the system or if it\u2019s collected via treating the system as a blackbox. The distinction, in my opinion, is more <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">purpose-driven</em>, than origin-driven. It\u2019s not so much about <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">where</em> this data comes from than <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">what we plan to do with it </em>and how <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">easily</em> we can achieve this<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">.</em></p><p name=\"867d\" id=\"867d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Whitebox monitoring is a fantastic <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">source of</em> <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">data. </em>Observability<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> </em>is our ability to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">easily</em> and <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">quickly</em> find <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">germane information</em> from this data <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">when</em> we need it. Observability is more about <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">what </em>information we might require about the behavior of our system in production and whether we will be able to have access to this information. It doesn\u2019t matter so much if this information is pre-processed or if it\u2019s derived from the data on the fly. It\u2019s also not about <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">how</em> we plan to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">process</em> and <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">use</em> the raw data. This raw data we\u2019re collecting could have various uses \u2014</p><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"2149\" id=\"2149\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--p\">We could use the data we\u2019re gathering to be on the lookout for explicit failure modes that have high severity consequences\u200a\u2014\u200aan imminent outage, in other words\u200a\u2014\u200athat we\u2019re trying to stave off or firefight, in which case we\u2019re using the data to <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">alert based on symptoms.</em></li></ul><figure name=\"c33b\" id=\"c33b\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--li\"/><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"b470\" id=\"b470\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--figure\">We could use this data to know the <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">overall health </em>of a service, in which case we\u2019re thinking in terms of overviews.</li></ul><figure name=\"55c4\" id=\"55c4\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--li\"/><p name=\"95bb\" id=\"95bb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Both of these cases, I\u2019d argue, fall under \u201cmonitoring\u201d.</p><figure name=\"c695\" id=\"c695\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"ff92\" id=\"ff92\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--figure\">We could use this data to debug rare and/or implicit failure modes that we couldn\u2019t have predicted beforehand. In which case, we\u2019re using the data to <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">debug </em>our systems.</li></ul><figure name=\"3139\" id=\"3139\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--li\"/><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"939f\" id=\"939f\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--figure\">We could also use the data for purposes like <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">profiling</em> to<em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\"> </em>derive better understanding about the behavior of our system in production even during the normal, steady state, in which case, we\u2019re using the data to <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">understand </em>our system as it exists <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">today</em>.</li></ul><figure name=\"2c11\" id=\"2c11\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--li\"/><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"ad28\" id=\"ad28\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--figure\">We might also want to understand how our service depends on other services <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">currently</em>, so as to enable us to understand if our service is being impacted by another service, or worse, if we are contributing to the poor performance of another service, in which case we\u2019re using this data for <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">dependency analysis.</em></li></ul><figure name=\"dac2\" id=\"dac2\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--li\"/><ul class=\"postList\"><li name=\"2299\" id=\"2299\" class=\"graf graf--li graf-after--figure\">We could also aim to be more ambitious and make sure our system is functional not just right <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">now </em>but also ensure<em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\"> </em>we have the data to understand the behavior of our system so that we can work on <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">evolving</em> it and <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">maintaining</em> it, not just tomorrow but for the duration of its entire lifecycle. While it\u2019s true that solving tomorrow\u2019s problems should not be our goal for today, it\u2019s still important to be <em class=\"markup--em markup--li-em\">cognizant</em> of them. There\u2019s nothing worse than being blindsided by a problem only to realize we could\u2019ve done better had we had better visibility into it sooner. We can anticipate the known, hard failure modes of today and \u201cmonitor\u201d for them, but the known, hard failure modes of tomorrow most often don\u2019t exhibit themselves in a very explicit manner today. They need to be teased from subtle behaviors only exhibited by our system during certain anomalous situations or under certain traffic patterns that might be rare or not a cause of concern or immediately actionable today.</li></ul><p name=\"5582\" id=\"5582\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--li\">These are all different goals. We could optimize for <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">some </em>of these or maybe even <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">all </em>of these<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">. </em>Whitebox monitoring is an important component (possibly <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">the </em>most important component) that helps us achieve all of these aforementioned goals, but whitebox monitoring, <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">per se</em>, isn\u2019t observability.</p><figure name=\"f082\" id=\"f082\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Monitoring vs Observability</figcaption></figure><p name=\"32aa\" id=\"32aa\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Different organizations might have different requirements for what falls under \u201cmonitoring\u201d. For some, dependency analysis might be an active part of their \u201cmonitoring\u201d. For others, security auditing might be an indispensable part of their Monitoring goals. As such, I see Observability as a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">spectrum</em> and something constantly evolving as a service evolves.</p><p name=\"6fb7\" id=\"6fb7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Another way of looking at what falls under \u201cmonitoring\u201d as opposed to what\u2019s \u201cobservability\u201d is by differentiating what we do <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">reactively</em> as opposed to what we do <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">proactively</em>.</p><figure name=\"aae3\" id=\"aae3\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"9a37\" id=\"9a37\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Again, this might be different for different organizations, but I think it\u2019s important to differentiate between the two purposes. Proactively generating information from data because we feel we might need them at all times is different from generating information on the fly at the time of debugging or analysis from data proactively collected.</p><p name=\"8239\" id=\"8239\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Yet another way of looking at this spectrum is to perhaps distinguish based on the Ops versus Dev responsibilities. I see \u201cmonitoring\u201d as something that requires being on-call. Observability I see as something that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">mandatorily</em> requires developer/software engineer participation.</p><figure name=\"20ca\" id=\"20ca\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"1493\" id=\"1493\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Furthermore, it\u2019s worth noting at there\u2019s a cause/effect relationship at play here in the spectrum. A lot of times what people \u201cmonitor\u201d at one layer (metrics like error rate and duration of request) are often the \u201csymptoms\u201d, with the cause being several layers down the spectrum.</p><figure name=\"8614\" id=\"8614\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"addf\" id=\"addf\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Being able to troubleshoot a problem involves often starting with a symptom reported by a coarse-grained metric (increased error rate or response time) or a trace (service B is slow for certain types of requests from downstream service C) that provides a bird\u2019s eye view of the problem and then iteratively drilling down to corroborate or invalidate our theories thereby reducing the search space at every iteration, until we finally reach the information needed to until we arrive at the root cause.</p><figure name=\"cb0c\" id=\"cb0c\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"7086\" id=\"7086\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Which brings me to my next point about \u2014</p><h4 name=\"44c3\" id=\"44c3\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Observability isn\u2019t just about data collection</h4><p name=\"b1b1\" id=\"b1b1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">While having access to data becomes a requirement if we wish to derive information from it, Observability isn\u2019t just about data collection alone. Once we have the data, it becomes important to be able to get answers/information from this data easily.</p><figure name=\"69d4\" id=\"69d4\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"559a\" id=\"559a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">While it\u2019s true that raw data is more malleable than pre-processed information, deferring processing of information until we actually need it incurs other overheads, namely that of collection, storage and on-the-fly processing. While it might sound all very well in theory to state that implementation details don\u2019t matter so long as we can get to our Observability goals, how the data that is being gathered can be best processed and stored becomes a key <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">practical consideration</em> if we wish to achieve the dream of establishing and sustaining the virtuous cycle. <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Usability</em> of data becomes a key concern as well, as does the barrier to data collection.</p><p name=\"7775\" id=\"7775\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">And lastly, I\u2019d argue that the most overarching aspect of Observability isn\u2019t data collection or processing. Having data at our disposal alone doesn\u2019t solve problems. Problem solving also involves the right amount of engineering intuition and domain experience to ask the right questions of the data to be able to get to the bottom of it. In fact, good Observability isn\u2019t possible without having good engineering intuition and domain knowledge, even if one had all the tools at one\u2019s disposal. And that really is what the rest of this post aims to address, by hopefully giving you some food for thought in terms of how to build systems to make it possible to gain better insights from them.</p><h4 name=\"adba\" id=\"adba\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">The Three Pillars of Observability</h4><p name=\"de8c\" id=\"de8c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">A more concrete example would help us understand logs, metrics and traces better. Let us assume the architecture of our system or sub-system looks like the following:</p><figure name=\"2883\" id=\"2883\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><h4 name=\"8b86\" id=\"8b86\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--figure\">Logs</h4><p name=\"a49f\" id=\"a49f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">A log is an immutable record of discrete <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">events</em> that happened over time. Some people take the view that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">events</em> are distinct compared to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">logs</em>, but I\u2019d argue that for all intents and purposes they can be used interchangeably.</p><p name=\"3bbc\" id=\"3bbc\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Event logs in general come in three forms:</p><p name=\"6953\" id=\"6953\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">1.</strong> <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">Plaintext</strong>\u200a\u2014\u200aA log record might take the form of free-form text. This is also the most common format of logs.<br/><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">2.</strong> <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">Structured</strong>\u200a\u2014\u200aMuch evangelized and advocated for in recent days. Typically this is logs emitted in the JSON format.<br/><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">3.</strong> <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">Binary</strong>\u200a\u2014\u200athink logs in the Protobuf format, MySQL <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">binlogs</em> used for replication and point-in-time recovery, systemd <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">journal</em> logs, the <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">pflog</code>format used by the BSD firewall <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">pf</code> which often serves as a frontend to <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">tcpdump</code>.</p><p name=\"0fb1\" id=\"0fb1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Logs, in particular, shine when it comes to providing valuable insight along with <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">ample context</em> into the long tail that averages and percentiles don\u2019t surface. Coming back to the example we saw above, let us assume that all of these various services also emit logs at varying degrees of granularity. Some services might emit more log information per request than others. Looking at logs alone, our data landscape might look like the following:</p><figure name=\"9760\" id=\"9760\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"c836\" id=\"c836\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The very first thing that jumps out to me when I look at the above diagram is abundance of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">data</em> points. Recording anything and everything that might be of interest to us becomes incredibly useful when we are searching at a very fine level of granularity, but simply looking at this mass of data, it\u2019s impossible to infer at a glance what the request lifecycle was or even which systems the request traversed through or even the overall health of any particular system. Sure, the data might be <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">rich</em> but without further processing, it\u2019s pretty <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">impenetrable</em>.</p><p name=\"cfe7\" id=\"cfe7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">What we require, in short, is <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">information</em>. The interesting aspect of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">information </em>in the context of this discussion is <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">what </em>information we\u2019re looking for? Do we want information about the lifecycle of a request? Or do we want information about the resource utilization of a specific service? Or do we want information about the health of a specific host? Or do we want information about why a specific service crashed? Or do we want information about the replication lag in a distributed key value store? Or are we looking for information about how long it took an eventually consistent system to converge? Or are we looking for information about GC pauses? Or are we trying to glean information about the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">symptoms </em>or are we trying to find the root <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">cause</em>? There is, quite frankly, an <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">endless </em>amount of data points we can collect and an <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">endless </em>number of questions we can answer, from the most trivial to the most difficult.</p><p name=\"8994\" id=\"8994\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Two very important pieces of information, however, pertains to the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">fate of requests </em>throughout their lifecycle (which is usually short lived)<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> </em>and the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">fate of a system as a whole </em>(measured over a duration that is orders of magnitudes longer than request lifecycles)<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">. </em>I see both traces and metrics as an <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">abstraction</em> built on top of logs that <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">pre-process</em> and encode information along two orthogonal axes, one being <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">request </em>centric, the other being <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">system </em>centric.</p><figure name=\"d94c\" id=\"d94c\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><h4 name=\"af64\" id=\"af64\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--figure\">Traces</h4><p name=\"b76c\" id=\"b76c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">A trace is a representation of a series of causally-related distributed events that encode the end-to-end request flow through a distributed system. A single trace can provide visibility into both the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">path</em> traversed by a request as well as the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">structure</em> of a request. The path of a request allows us to understand the services involved in the servicing of a request, and the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">structure </em>of a trace helps one understand the junctures and effects of asynchrony in the execution of a request.</p><figure name=\"1c96\" id=\"1c96\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"1b87\" id=\"1b87\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Albeit discussions around tracing pivot around their utility in a microservices environment, I think it\u2019s fair to suggest that any sufficiently complex application that interacts with\u200a\u2014\u200aor rather, <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">contends</em> for\u200a\u2014\u200aresources such as the network or disk in a non-trivial manner can benefit from the benefits tracing can provide.</p><p name=\"f3c1\" id=\"f3c1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The basic idea behind tracing is straightforward\u200a\u2014\u200aidentify specific points in an application, proxy, framework, library, middleware and anything else that might lie in the path of execution of a request, instrument these points and have these coordinate with each other. These points are of particular interest since they represent forks in execution flow (OS thread or a green thread) or a hop or a fan out across network or process boundaries that a request might encounter in the course of its lifecycle.</p><p name=\"dff7\" id=\"dff7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Usually represented as a directed acyclic graph, they are used to identify the amount of work done at each layer while preserving causality using <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">happens-before</em> semantics. The way this is achieved is by adding instrumentation to specific points in code. When a request begins, it\u2019s assigned a globally unique ID, which is then propagated throughout the request path, so that each point of instrumentation is able to insert or enrich metadata before passing the ID around to the next hop in the meandering flow of a request. When the execution flow reaches the instrumented point at one of these services, a record is emitted along with metadata. These records are usually asynchronously logged to disk before being submitted out of band to a collector, which then can reconstruct the flow of execution based on different records emitted by different parts of the system.</p><p name=\"877e\" id=\"877e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Collecting this information and reconstructing the flow of execution while preserving causality for retrospective analysis and troubleshooting enables one to understand the lifecycle of a request better. Most importantly, having an understanding of the entire request lifecycle makes it possible to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">debug requests spanning multiple services</em> to pinpoint the source of increased response time or resource utilization. As such, traces largely help one understand the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">which </em>and sometimes even the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">why\u200a\u2014\u200a</em>like <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">which </em>component of a system is even touched during the lifecycle of a request and is slowing the response?</p><h4 name=\"5d9f\" id=\"5d9f\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Metrics</h4><p name=\"8f05\" id=\"8f05\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">The official definition of metrics is:</p><blockquote name=\"42f1\" id=\"42f1\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">a set of numbers that give information about a particular process or activity.</blockquote><p name=\"6991\" id=\"6991\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Metrics are a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">numeric</em> representation of our data and as such can fully harness the power of mathematical modeling and prediction to derive knowledge of the behavior of our system over intervals of time in the present and future\u2014 in other words, a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">time series</em>. The official definition of time series\u00a0:</p><blockquote name=\"2db5\" id=\"2db5\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">a list of numbers relating to a particular activity, which is recorded at regular periods of time and then studied. Time series are typically used to study, for example, sales, orders, income, etc.</blockquote><p name=\"5c4a\" id=\"5c4a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Metrics are just <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">numbers</em> measured over intervals of time, and numbers are optimized for storage, processing, compression and retrieval. As such, metrics enable longer retention of data as well as easier querying, which can in turn be used to build dashboards to reflect historical trends. Additionally, metrics better allow for gradual reduction of data resolution over time, so that after a certain period of time data can be aggregated into daily or weekly frequency.</p><p name=\"4406\" id=\"4406\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">One of the biggest drawback of historical time series databases has been the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">identification</em> of metrics which didn\u2019t lend itself very well toward exploratory analysis or filtering. The hierarchical metric model and the lack of tags or labels in systems like Graphite especially hurt in this regard. Modern monitoring systems like Prometheus represent every time series using a metric <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">name</em> as well as additional key-value pairs called <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">labels</em>.</p><figure name=\"4f93\" id=\"4f93\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">The anatomy of a Prometheus metric</figcaption></figure><p name=\"fa4c\" id=\"fa4c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">This allows for a high degree of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">dimensionality</em> in the data model. A metric is identified using both the metric name and the labels. Metrics in Prometheus are immutable; changing the name of the metric or adding or removing a label will result in a new time series. The actual data stored in the time-series is called a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">sample </em>and it consists of two components\u200a\u2014\u200aa <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">float64</em> value and a millisecond precision timestamp.</p><h4 name=\"affc\" id=\"affc\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">The pros and cons of each in terms of resource utilization, ease of use, ease of operation, and cost effectiveness</h4><p name=\"f68c\" id=\"f68c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Let\u2019s evaluate each of the three in terms of three criteria before we see how we can leverage the strengths of each to craft a great Observability experience:</p><p name=\"4b72\" id=\"4b72\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 Ease of generation/instrumentation<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aEase of processing\u00a0<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aEase of querying/searching<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aQuality of information<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aCost Effectiveness</p><h4 name=\"aeb3\" id=\"aeb3\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--h4-strong\">Logs</strong></h4><p name=\"bde4\" id=\"bde4\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Logs are, by far, the easiest to generate since there is no initial processing involved. The fact that it is just a string or a blob of JSON makes it incredibly easy to represent any data we want to emit in the form of a log line. Most languages, application frameworks and libraries come with in built support for logging. Logs are also easy to instrument, since logs are just <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">printfs</code> in production, and adding a log line is quite as trivial as adding a print statement. Logs also perform really well in terms of surfacing highly granular information pregnant with rich <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">local </em>context that can be great for drill down analysis, so long as our search space is <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">localized </em>to a single service.</p><p name=\"f44a\" id=\"f44a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The utility of logs, unfortunately, ends right there. Everything else I\u2019m going to tell you about logs is only going to be painful. While log <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">generation </em>might be easy, the performance idiosyncrasies of various popular logging libraries leave a lot to be desired. Most performant logging libraries allocate very little, if any, and are extremely fast. However, the default logging libraries of many languages and frameworks are not the cream of the crop, which means the application as a whole becomes susceptible to suboptimal performance due to the overhead of logging. Additionally, log messages can also be lost unless one uses a protocol like <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reliable_Event_Logging_Protocol\" data-href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reliable_Event_Logging_Protocol\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">RELP</a> to guarantee reliable delivery of messages. This becomes especially important if one is using log data for billing or payment purposes. Lastly, unless the logging library can dynamically sample logs, logging has the capability to adversely affect application performance as a whole. As someone mentioned on a Slack:</p><blockquote name=\"9e68\" id=\"9e68\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">A fun thing I had seen while at [redacted] was that turning off most logging almost doubled performance on the instances we were running on because logs ate through AWS\u2019 EC2 classic\u2019s packet allocations like mad. It was interesting for us to discover that more than 50% of our performance would be lost to trying to control and monitor performance.</blockquote><p name=\"2e39\" id=\"2e39\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">On the processing side, raw logs are almost always normalized, filtered and processed by a tool like Logstash, fluentd, Scribe or Heka before they\u2019re persisted in a data store like Elasticsearch or BigQuery. If an application generates a large volume of logs, then the logs might require further buffering in a broker like Kafka before they can be processed by Logstash. Hosted solutions like BigQuery have quotas you cannot exceed. On the storage side, while Elasticsearch might be a fantastic search engine, there\u2019s a real operational cost involved in running it. Even if your organization is staffed with a team of Operations engineers who are experts in operating ELK, there might be other drawbacks.
