Case in point\u200a\u2014\u200aone of my friends was telling me about how he would often see a sharp downward slope in the graphs in Kibana, not because traffic to the service was dropping but because ELK couldn\u2019t keep up with the indexing of the sheer volume of data being thrown at it. Even if log ingestion processing isn\u2019t an issue with ELK, no one I know of seems to have fully figured out how to use Kibana\u2019s UI, let alone <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">enjoy </em>using it.</p><p name=\"d495\" id=\"d495\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">While there is no dearth of hosted SaaS offerings for log management, they are probably better known for their obscene pricing. The fact that a large number of organizations choose to outsource log management <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">despite </em>the cost is a testament to how operationally hard, expensive and fragile running it in-house is.</p><p name=\"ab14\" id=\"ab14\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">An antidote often proposed to the problem of the cost overhead of logging is to sample or to only log actionable data. But even when sampled aggressively, it requires us to make decisions <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">a priori</em> as to what might be actionable. As such, our ability to log \u201cactionable\u201d data is entirely contingent on our ability to be able to predict what will be actionable or what data might be needed in the future. While it\u2019s true that better understanding of a system might allow us to make an educated guess as to what data now gathered can prove to be a veritable source of information in the future, potentially every line of code is point of failure and as such could become the source of a log line.</p><h4 name=\"577b\" id=\"577b\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Metrics</h4><p name=\"ff78\" id=\"ff78\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">By and large, the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">biggest</em> advantage of metrics based monitoring over logs is the fact that unlike log generation and storage, metrics transfer and storage has a constant overhead. Unlike logs, the cost of metrics doesn\u2019t increase in lockstep with user traffic or any other system activity that could result in a sharp uptick in data.</p><p name=\"8ec3\" id=\"8ec3\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">What this means is that with metrics, an increase in traffic to an application will not incur a significant increase in disk utilization, processing complexity, speed of visualization and operational costs the way logs do. Metrics <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">storage </em>increases with the number of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">time series</em> being captured (when more hosts/containers are spun up, or when new services get added or when existing services are instrumented more), but unlike statsd clients that send a UDP packet <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">every time</em> a metric is recorded<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> </em>to the statsd daemon (resulting in a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">directly proportional</em> increase in the number of metrics being submitted to statsd compared to the traffic being reported on!), client libraries of systems like Prometheus aggregate time series samples <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">in-process</em> and submit them to the Prometheus server upon a successful scrape (which happens once every few seconds and can be configured).</p><p name=\"f8d1\" id=\"f8d1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Metrics, once collected, are also more malleable to mathematical, probabilistic and statistical transformations such as sampling, aggregation, summarization and correlation, which make it better suited to report the overall health of a system.</p><p name=\"3819\" id=\"3819\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Metrics are also better suited to trigger <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">alerts</em>, since running queries against an in-memory time series database is far more efficient, not to mention more reliable, than running a query against a distributed system like ELK and then aggregating the results before deciding if an alert needs to be triggered. Of course, there are systems that strictly query only in-memory structured event data for alerting that might be a little less expensive than ELK, but the operational overhead of running large distributed in-memory databases, even if they were open source, isn\u2019t something worth the trouble for most when there are far easier ways to derive equally actionable alerts. Metrics are akin to blackbox frontends of a system\u2019s performance and as such are best suited to furnish this information.</p><figure name=\"4cc2\" id=\"4cc2\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Metrics as blackbox frontends</figcaption></figure><p name=\"0b0b\" id=\"0b0b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The biggest drawback with both logs and metrics is that they are <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">system</em> scoped, making it hard to understand anything else other than what\u2019s happening inside of a particular system. Sure, metrics can also be request scoped, but that entails a concomitant increase in label fanout which results in an increase in storage. While the new Prometheus storage engine has been optimized for high churn in time series, it\u2019s also true that metrics aren\u2019t the best suited for highly granular request scoped information. With logs, without fancy joins, a single log line or metric doesn\u2019t give much information about what happened to a request across all components of a system. Together and when used optimally, logs and metrics give us complete omniscience into a <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">silo</em>, but nothing more. While these might be sufficient for understanding the performance and behavior of <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">individual systems\u200a\u2014\u200a</em>both stateful and stateless\u200a\u2014\u200athey come a cropper when it comes to understanding the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">lifetime </em>of a request that traverses through multiple systems.</p><p name=\"6a2a\" id=\"6a2a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">Traces</strong></p><figure name=\"c20f\" id=\"c20f\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"5220\" id=\"5220\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Tracing captures the lifetime of requests as they flow through the various components of a distributed system. The support for enriching the context that\u2019s being propagated with additional key value pairs makes it possible to encode application specific metadata in the trace, which might give developers more debugging power.</p><p name=\"75bb\" id=\"75bb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The use cases of distributed tracing are myriad. While used primarily for inter service dependency analysis, distributed profiling and debugging steady-state problems, tracing can also help with chargeback and capacity planning.</p><p name=\"ff4d\" id=\"ff4d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Tracing is, by far, the hardest to retrofit into an existing infrastructure, owing to the fact that for tracing to be truly effective, every component in the path of a request needs to be modified to propagate tracing information. Depending on whom you ask, you\u2019d either be told that gaps in the flow of a request doesn\u2019t outweigh the cons or be told that these gaps are blind spots that make debugging harder.</p><blockquote name=\"bab4\" id=\"bab4\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\"><a href=\"https://blog.netsil.com/beyond-google-sre-what-is-site-reliability-engineering-like-at-medium-71c65bd35f4e\" data-href=\"https://blog.netsil.com/beyond-google-sre-what-is-site-reliability-engineering-like-at-medium-71c65bd35f4e\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--blockquote-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">We\u2019ve been</a> implementing a request tracing service for over a year and it\u2019s not complete yet. The challenge with these type of tools is that, we need to add code around each span to truly understand what\u2019s happening during the lifetime of our requests. The frustrating part is that if the code is not instrumented or header is not carrying the id, that code becomes a risky blind spot for operations.</blockquote><p name=\"be37\" id=\"be37\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">The second problem with tracing instrumentation is that it\u2019s not sufficient for developers to instrument <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">their </em>code. A large number of applications in the wild are built using open source frameworks or libraries which might require additional instrumentation. This becomes all the more challenging at places with polyglot architectures, since every language, framework and wire protocol with widely disparate concurrency patterns and guarantees need to cooperate. Indeed, tracing is most successfully deployed in organizations where there are a core set of languages and frameworks used uniformly across the company.</p><p name=\"53fc\" id=\"53fc\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The cost of tracing isn\u2019t quite as catastrophic as that of logging, mainly owing to the fact that traces are almost always sampled heavily to reduce runtime overhead as well as storage costs. Sampling decisions can be made:</p><p name=\"02d9\" id=\"02d9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 at the start of a request before any traces are generated<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aat the end once all participating systems have recorded the traces for the entire course of the request execution<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200amidway through the request flow, when only downstream services would then report the trace</p><p name=\"3d95\" id=\"3d95\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">All <a href=\"http://www.pdl.cmu.edu/PDL-FTP/SelfStar/CMU-PDL-14-102.pdf\" data-href=\"http://www.pdl.cmu.edu/PDL-FTP/SelfStar/CMU-PDL-14-102.pdf\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">approaches have their own pros and cons</a>.</p><h3 name=\"63c1\" id=\"63c1\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Best practices</h3><p name=\"e3a3\" id=\"e3a3\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">Given the aforementioned characteristics of logs, any talk about best practices for logging inherently embodies a tradeoff. There are a couple of approaches that I think can help alleviate the problem on log generation, processing, storage and analysis.</p><h4 name=\"7fe0\" id=\"7fe0\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Quotas</h4><p name=\"eb19\" id=\"eb19\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">We either log <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">everything </em>that might be of interest and pay a processing and storage penalty, or we log selectively, knowing that we are sacrificing fidelity but making it possible to still have access to important data. Most talk around logging revolves around log levels, but rarely have I seen quotas imposed on the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">amount</em> of log data a service can generate. While logstash and friends do have plugins for throttling log ingestion, most of these filters are based on <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">keys </em>and certain thresholds, with throttling happening <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">after the event </em>has been generated.</p><p name=\"62a4\" id=\"62a4\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">If logging is provided as an internal service\u200a\u2014\u200aand there are many companies where this is the case\u200a\u2014\u200athen establishing service tiers with quotas and priorities can be a first step. Any user facing request or service gets assigned the highest priority, while infrastructural tasks or background jobs or anything that can tolerate a bounded delay are lower on the priority list.</p><h4 name=\"b23e\" id=\"b23e\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Dynamic Sampling</h4><p name=\"a527\" id=\"a527\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">With or without quotas, it becomes important to be able to dynamically sample logs, so that the rate of log generation can be adjusted on the fly to ease the burden on the log forwarding, processing and storage systems. In the words of the aforementioned acquaintance who saw a 50% boost by turning off logging on EC2:</p><blockquote name=\"a349\" id=\"a349\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">The only thing it kind of convinced me to is the need for the ability to dynamically increase or decrease logging on a per-need basis. But the caveat there is always that if you don\u2019t always run the full blown logging, eventually the system can\u2019t cope to run with it enabled.</blockquote><h4 name=\"13e0\" id=\"13e0\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--blockquote\">Logging is a Stream Processing Problem</h4><p name=\"f80f\" id=\"f80f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Data isn\u2019t only ever used for application performance and debugging use cases. It also forms the source of all analytics data as well. This data is often of tremendous utility from a business intelligence perspective, and usually businesses are willing to pay for both the technology and the personnel required to make sense of this data in order to make better product decisions.</p><p name=\"0fd9\" id=\"0fd9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The interesting aspect to me here is that there are striking similarities between questions a business might want answered and questions we might want answered during debugging. For example, a question that might be of business importance is the following:</p><p name=\"3a26\" id=\"3a26\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\"><em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">\u2014 Filter to outlier countries from where users viewed this article fewer than 100 times in total.</em></p><p name=\"1eb9\" id=\"1eb9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Whereas, from a debugging perspective, the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook-engineering/under-the-hood-data-diving-with-scuba/10150599692628920/\" data-href=\"https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook-engineering/under-the-hood-data-diving-with-scuba/10150599692628920/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">question might look more like</a>:</p><p name=\"68e2\" id=\"68e2\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Filter to outlier page loads that performed more than 100 database queries.</em><br/>\u00a0\u2014<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">Or, show me only page loads from Indonesia that took more than 10 seconds to load.</em></p><p name=\"b18f\" id=\"b18f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">While these aren\u2019t similar queries from a technical perspective, the infrastructure required to perform these sort of analysis or answer these kinds of queries is largely the same.</p><p name=\"06ef\" id=\"06ef\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">What might of interest to the business might be the fact that:</p><p name=\"900a\" id=\"900a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 User A viewed Product X.</p><p name=\"fea5\" id=\"fea5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Augmenting this data with some extra information might make it ripe for Observability purposes:</p><p name=\"07ec\" id=\"07ec\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">\u2014 User A viewed Product X and the page took 0.5s to load<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aUser A viewed Product X whose image was not served from cache<br/>\u200a\u2014\u200aUser A viewed Product X and read review Z for which the response time for the API call was 300ms.</p><p name=\"16ca\" id=\"16ca\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Both these queries are made possible by events. Events are essentially structured (optionally typed) key value pairs. Marrying business information along with information about the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">lifetime</em> of the request (timers, durations and so forth) makes it possible to repurpose analytics tooling for Observability purposes.</p><figure name=\"da1f\" id=\"da1f\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--iframe graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"5da6\" id=\"5da6\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">If you think about this, log processing neatly fits into the bill of Online Analytics Processing (OLAP). Information derived from OLAP systems is not very different compared to information derived for debugging or performance analysis or anomaly detection at the edge of the system. Most analytics pipelines use Kafka as an event bus. Sending enriched event data to Kafka allows one to search in real time over streams with KSQL, <a href=\"https://www.confluent.io/blog/ksql-open-source-streaming-sql-for-apache-kafka/\" data-href=\"https://www.confluent.io/blog/ksql-open-source-streaming-sql-for-apache-kafka/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">a streaming SQL engine for Kafka </a>from the fine folks at Confluent.</p><blockquote name=\"2c55\" id=\"2c55\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">KSQL supports a wide range of powerful stream processing operations including aggregations, joins, windowing, sessionization, and much more. The Kafka log is the core storage abstraction for streaming data, allowing same data that went into your offline data warehouse is to now be available for stream processing. Everything else is a streaming materialized view over the log, be it various databases, search indexes, or other data serving systems in the company. All data enrichment and ETL needed to create these derived views can now be done in a streaming fashion using KSQL. Monitoring, security, anomaly and threat detection, analytics, and response to failures can be done in real-time versus when it is too late. All this is available for just about anyone to use through a simple and familiar SQL interface to all your Kafka data: KSQL.</blockquote><p name=\"50cf\" id=\"50cf\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Enriching business events that go into Kafka anyway with additional timing and other metadata required for Observability use cases can be helpful when repurposing existing stream processing infrastructures. A further benefit this pattern provides is that this data can be expired from the Kafka log regularly. Most event data required for debugging purposes are only valuable for a relatively short period of time after the event has been generated, unlike any business centric information that normally would\u2019ve been evaluated and persisted by an ETL job. Of course, this makes most sense when Kafka already is an integral part of an organization. Introducing Kafka into a stack purely for real time log analytics is a bit of an overkill, especially in non-JVM shops without any significant JVM operational expertise.</p><h4 name=\"bc2f\" id=\"bc2f\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">A new hope for the\u00a0future</h4><p name=\"8b31\" id=\"8b31\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">The fact that logging still remains an unsolved problem makes me wish for an OpenLogging spec, in the vein of OpenTracing which serves as a shining example and a testament to the power of community driven development. A spec designed ground up for the cloud-native era, blessed by the CNCF, implemented by many backends. A spec that enshrines that logs <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">must be structured events </em>and<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\"> </em>codifies rules around dynamic sampling for high volume, low fidelity events. A spec that can be implemented as libraries in all major languages and supported by all major application frameworks and middleware. A spec that allows us to make the most of advances in stream processing<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">. </em>A spec that becomes the lingua franca logging format of all CNCF projects, especially Kubernetes.</p><h4 name=\"c55c\" id=\"c55c\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Metrics</h4><blockquote name=\"1f94\" id=\"1f94\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--h4\"><a href=\"https://www.influxdata.com/blog/influxdb-now-supports-prometheus-remote-read-write-natively/\" data-href=\"https://www.influxdata.com/blog/influxdb-now-supports-prometheus-remote-read-write-natively/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--blockquote-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Prometheus is much more than just the server.</a> I see Prometheus as a set of standards and projects, with the server being just one part of a much greater whole.</blockquote><p name=\"ed4a\" id=\"ed4a\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">Prometheus does a great job of codifying the exposition format for metrics, and I\u2019d love to see this become the standard. While Prometheus doesn\u2019t offer long term storage, the remote write feature that was added to Prometheus about a year ago allowed one to write Prometheus metrics to a custom remote storage engine like OpenTSDB or Graphite, effectively turning Prometheus into a write-through cache. With the recent introduction of the generic write backend, one can transport time-series from Prometheus over HTTP and Protobuf to any storage system like Kafka or Cassandra.</p><p name=\"8811\" id=\"8811\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Remote reads, though, is slightly newer and I\u2019ve only been seeing efforts coalesce into something meaningful in the last few months. InfluxDB now natively supports both Prometheus remote reads and writes. Remote reads allows Prometheus to read raw samples from a remote backend during query execution time and compute the results in the Prometheus server.</p><p name=\"899e\" id=\"899e\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Furthermore, improvements to the Prometheus storage engine in the upcoming 2.0 release makes Prometheus all the more conducive to cloud-native workloads with vast churn in time-series names. The powerful query language of Prometheus coupled with the ability to define alerts using the same query language and enrich the alerts with templated annotations makes it perfect for all \u201cmonitoring purposes\u201d.</p><p name=\"6fcb\" id=\"6fcb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">With metrics, however, it\u2019s important to be careful not to explode the label space. Labels should be so chosen so that it remains limited to a small set of attributes that can remain somewhat uniform. It also becomes important to resist the temptation to alert on <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">everything</em>. For alerting to be <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">effective, </em>it becomes salient to be able to identify a small set of hard failure modes of a system. Some believe that the ideal number of signals to be \u201cmonitored\u201d is anywhere between 3\u20135, and definitely no more than 7\u201310. One of the common pain points that keeps cropping up in my conversations with friends is how <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">noisy </em>their \u201cmonitoring\u201d is. Noisy monitoring leads to either metric data that\u2019s never looked at\u200a\u2014\u200awhich in other words is a waste of storage space of the metrics server\u200a\u2014\u200aor worse, false alerts leading to a severe case of alert fatigue.</p><h4 name=\"4de8\" id=\"4de8\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Traces</h4><p name=\"f744\" id=\"f744\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">While historically tracing has been difficult to implement, the rise of service meshes make integrating tracing functionality almost effortless. Lyft famously got tracing support for all of their applications without changing a single line of code by adopting the service mesh pattern. Service meshes help with the DRYing of observability by implementing tracing and stats collections at the mesh level, which allows one to treat individual services as blackboxes but still get incredible observability onto the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">mesh </em>as a whole. Even with the caveat that the applications forming the mesh need to be able to forward headers to the next hop in the mesh, this pattern is incredibly useful for retrofitting tracing into existing infrastructures with the least amount of code change.</p><h4 name=\"2abe\" id=\"2abe\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">When it makes sense to augment the three aforementioned tools with additional tools</h4><p name=\"df56\" id=\"df56\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Exception trackers (I think of these as logs++) have come a long way in the last few years and provide a far superior UI than a plaintext file or blobs of JSON to inspect exceptions. Exception trackers also provide full tracebacks, local variables, inputs at every subroutine or method invocation call, frequency of occurrence of the error/exception and other metadata invaluable for debugging. Exception trackers aim to do one thing\u200a\u2014\u200atrack exceptions and application crashes\u200a\u2014\u200aand they tend to do this <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">really</em> well. While they don\u2019t eliminate the need for logs, exception trackers augment logs\u200a\u2014\u200aif you\u2019ll pardon the pun\u200a\u2014\u200a<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">exceptionally</em> well.</p><p name=\"b2ae\" id=\"b2ae\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Some new tools also help achieve visibility by treating the network packets as the source of truth and using packet capture to build the overall service topology. While this definitely has less overhead than instrumenting all application code throughout the stack, it\u2019s primarily useful for analyzing network interactions between different components. While it cannot help with debugging issues with the asynchronous behavior of a multithreaded service or unexpected event loop stalls in a single threaded service, augmenting it with metrics or logs to better understand what\u2019s happening inside a single service can help one gain enough visibility into the entire architecture.</p><h3 name=\"75f3\" id=\"75f3\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Conclusion</h3><p name=\"0e03\" id=\"0e03\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">Observability isn\u2019t quite the same as monitoring. Observability connotes something more holistic and encompasses \u201cmonitoring\u201d, application code instrumentation, proactive instrumentation for just-in-time debugging and a culture of more thorough understanding of various components of the system.</p><p name=\"57e9\" id=\"57e9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Observability means having the ability\u200a\u2014\u200aand the confidence\u200a\u2014\u200ato be able to build systems knowing that these systems can turn into a frankensystem in production. It\u2019s about understanding that the software we\u2019re building can be\u200a\u2014\u200aand almost always is\u200a\u2014\u200abroken (or prone to break soon) to varying degrees despite our best efforts. A good analogy between getting code working on one\u2019s laptop or in CI to having code running in production would be the difference between swimming in an indoor pool versus swimming in choppy rivers full of piranhas. The feeling of being unable to fix one\u2019s own service running in a foreign environment for the want to being able to debug isn\u2019t acceptable, not if we want to pride ourselves on our uptime and quality of service.</p><p name=\"814b\" id=\"814b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I want to conclude this post with how I think software development and operation should happen in the time of cloud-native.</p><h4 name=\"52c3\" id=\"52c3\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Pre-Production Testing</h4><figure name=\"e5cb\" id=\"e5cb\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h4\"/><p name=\"6410\" id=\"6410\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">It\u2019s important to understand that testing is a best effort verification of the correctness of a system as well as a best effort simulation of failure modes. Unit tests only ever test the behavior of a system against a specified set of inputs. Furthermore, tests are conducted in very controlled (often heavily mocked) environments. While the very few who do fuzz their code benefit from having their code tested against a set of randomly generated input, fuzzing can only comprehensively test against the set of inputs to <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">one</em> service. End-to-end testing might allow for some degree of holistic testing of the system and fault injection/chaos engineering might help us gain a reasonable degree of confidence about our system\u2019s ability to withstand these failures, but <a href=\"http://web.mit.edu/2.75/resources/random/How%20Complex%20Systems%20Fail.pdf\" data-href=\"http://web.mit.edu/2.75/resources/random/How%20Complex%20Systems%20Fail.pdf\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow noopener nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">complex systems fail in complex ways</a> and there\u2019s is no testing under the sun that enables one to predict every last vector that could contribute towards a failure.</p><p name=\"254d\" id=\"254d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Despite these shortcomings, testing is as important as ever. If nothing else, testing our code allows us to write better and more maintainable code. More importantly, <a href=\"https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/osdi14/osdi14-paper-yuan.pdf\" data-href=\"https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/osdi14/osdi14-paper-yuan.pdf\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">research</a> has proven that something as simple as \u201ctesting error handling code could have prevented 58% of catastrophic failures<em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">\u201d</em> in many distributed systems. The renaissance of tooling aimed to understand the behavior of our services in production does not obviate the need for testing.</p><h4 name=\"b569\" id=\"b569\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Testing in Production</h4><figure name=\"3fb5\" id=\"3fb5\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h4\"/><p name=\"b1ad\" id=\"b1ad\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Testing in production <a href=\"https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/seliot/2011/06/07/testing-in-production-tip-it-really-happensexamples-from-facebook-amazon-google-and-microsoft/\" data-href=\"https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/seliot/2011/06/07/testing-in-production-tip-it-really-happensexamples-from-facebook-amazon-google-and-microsoft/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">isn\u2019t really a very new idea</a>. Methodologies such as A/B testing, canary deployments, dark traffic testing (some call this shadowing) have been around for a while.</p><p name=\"3507\" id=\"3507\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Being able to test in production however absolutely requires that the release can be halted and rolled back if the need arises. This in turn means that one can only test in production if one has a quick feedback loop about the behavior of the system one\u2019s testing in production. It also means being on the lookout for changes to key performance indicators of the service. For an HTTP service this could mean attributes like error rate and latencies of key endpoints. For a user facing service, this could additionally mean a change in user engagement. Testing in production essentially means proactively \u201cmonitoring\u201d the change in production. Which brings me to my next point.</p><h4 name=\"606d\" id=\"606d\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Monitoring</h4><p name=\"eb67\" id=\"eb67\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4\">Monitoring isn\u2019t dead. Monitoring, in fact, is so important that I\u2019d argue it occupies the pride of place in your Observability spectrum.</p><figure name=\"bbd4\" id=\"bbd4\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"5cc7\" id=\"5cc7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">In order to test in production, one <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">needs </em>good, effective monitoring. Monitoring that is both failure centric (in that we proactively monitor for changes to KPI\u2019s) as well as human centric (we want the developer who pushed out the change to test in production to be alerted as soon as possible).</p><p name=\"c861\" id=\"c861\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">I chose to call this Tier I Monitoring, for the want of better word, since I believe these are table stakes. It\u2019s the very minimum <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">any </em>service thats going to be in production needs to have. It\u2019s what alerts are derived from and I believe that time-series metrics are the best suited for this purpose.</p><p name=\"51d0\" id=\"51d0\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">However, there are several other bits and pieces of information we might capture but not use for alerting. There\u2019s a school of thought that all such information isn\u2019t of much value and needs to be discarded. I, however, believe that this is the sort of information I often find myself requiring often enough that I want it presented to me in the form of a dashboard.</p><figure name=\"328c\" id=\"328c\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"4293\" id=\"4293\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">A good example of this sort of tier II monitoring would be <a href=\"http://monitor.gitlab.net/dashboard/db/fleet-overview?refresh=5m&amp;orgId=1\" data-href=\"http://monitor.gitlab.net/dashboard/db/fleet-overview?refresh=5m&amp;orgId=1\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">this dashboard</a> of GitLab\u2019s which is aptly named <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">fleet overview </em>or <a href=\"http://monitor.gitlab.net/dashboard/db/go-processes?refresh=30s&amp;orgId=1\" data-href=\"http://monitor.gitlab.net/dashboard/db/go-processes?refresh=30s&amp;orgId=1\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">this one</a> which gives information about the running Go processes. I picked these examples because GitLab is famously known for their transparency and these are real, live production dashboards of a real company. I find analyzing these dashboards more interesting than cooking up toy examples for the purpose of a blog post.</p><p name=\"0c77\" id=\"0c77\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">While these metrics don\u2019t particularly help with debugging of gremlins or problems we don\u2019t even know exist, having such dashboards gives me a bird\u2019s eye view of the system, which I find invaluable especially after a release, since it gives me extremely quick feedback about how known key metrics might have been impacted by the change, but weren\u2019t severe enough to trigger an alert. Measuring heap usage for a potential memory leak would be a good example of such Tier II monitoring. I would really like to know if I pushed out a code that\u2019s leaking memory, but I don\u2019t consider it something I necessarily want to be <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">alerted </em>on.</p><h4 name=\"30a5\" id=\"30a5\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Exploration</h4><figure name=\"d352\" id=\"d352\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h4\"/><p name=\"73f5\" id=\"73f5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">Then there\u2019s exploration, which I find useful to answer questions one could not have proactively thought about. Usually based on the querying of raw events which support massive dimensionality, these are usually extremely powerful for surfacing answers we couldn\u2019t have predicted beforehand.</p><h4 name=\"5466\" id=\"5466\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Dynamic Exploration</h4><figure name=\"dd8c\" id=\"dd8c\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h4\"/><p name=\"0bec\" id=\"0bec\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The problem with all of the three approaches seen until now is that they require that we record information about our systems <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">a priori. </em>What this means is the the data we need is generated before we can derive any useful information from it.</p><p name=\"4320\" id=\"4320\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Dynamic instrumentation techniques aren\u2019t new, but the most famous implementations like DTrace were primarily machine centric and mostly correlate events that remain confined to an address-space or specific machine. However, <a href=\"http://sigops.org/sosp/sosp15/current/2015-Monterey/printable/122-mace.pdf\" data-href=\"http://sigops.org/sosp/sosp15/current/2015-Monterey/printable/122-mace.pdf\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">recent academic research</a> has married these ideas with some of the ideas pioneered by distributed tracing, allowing one to \u201cto obtain an arbitrary metric at one point of the system,while selecting, filtering, and grouping by events meaningful at other parts of the system, even when crossing component or machine boundaries\u201d.</p><p name=\"3200\" id=\"3200\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The primary breakthrough demonstrated this paper proposed is the <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">baggage </em>abstraction.</p><blockquote name=\"cb00\" id=\"cb00\" class=\"graf graf--blockquote graf-after--p\">Baggage is a per-request container for tuples that is propagated alongside a request as it traverses thread, application and machine boundaries. Tuples follow the request\u2019s execution path and therefore explicitly capture the happened-before relationship. Using baggage, Pivot Tracing efficiently evaluates happened-before joins in situ during the execution of a request.</blockquote><p name=\"25ba\" id=\"25ba\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--blockquote\">The idea of baggage propagation has been <a href=\"https://github.com/opentracing/specification/blob/master/specification.md#set-a-baggage-item\" data-href=\"https://github.com/opentracing/specification/blob/master/specification.md#set-a-baggage-item\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">incorporated into the OpenTracing </a>spec, which now enables \u201carbitrary application data from a mobile app can make it, transparently, all the way into the depths of a storage system\u201d. While this still isn\u2019t quite the same as what the whitepaper describes, it still gets us one step closer to true end-to-end tracing and the ability to dynamically enrich tracing data for better visibility.</p><h4 name=\"e332\" id=\"e332\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Unknowables</h4><figure name=\"5866\" id=\"5866\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h4\"/><p name=\"21d7\" id=\"21d7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">And finally there are the unknowables. Things we can\u2019t know about or don\u2019t need to know about. Even if we have complete omniscience into our application and hardware performance, it\u2019s simply not feasible\u200a\u2014\u200aor required\u200a\u2014\u200ato have complete visibility into the various layers of abstractions underneath the application layer. Think ARP packet losses, BGP announcements or recursive BGP lookups, OSFP states and all manner of other implementation details of abstractions we rely on without a second thought. We simply have to get comfortable with the fact that there are things we possibly cannot know, and that it\u2019s OK.</p><p name=\"64ae\" id=\"64ae\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Which brings me to my final point \u2014</p><h4 name=\"4c0e\" id=\"4c0e\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--p\">Choose your own Observability Adventure</h4><p name=\"8eab\" id=\"8eab\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h4 graf--trailing\">Observability\u200a\u2014\u200ain and of itself, and like most other things\u200a\u2014\u200aisn\u2019t particularly useful. The <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">value</em> of the Observability of a system directly stems from the business value we derive from it. For many businesses, having a good alerting strategy and time-series based \u201cmonitoring\u201d is probably all that\u2019s required to be able to deliver on the business goals. For others, being able to debug needle-in-a-haystack type of problems might be what\u2019s needed to generate the most business value. Observability, as such, isn\u2019t an absolute. Pick your own Observability target based on the requirements of your service.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429824": {"score": 375, "comments": ["An appropriate quote: &quot;If you can&#x27;t intelligently argue for both sides of an issue, you don&#x27;t understand the issue well enough to argue for either.&quot;<p>There are many people for whom the declarative paradigm is a huge plus. There is an option (allow_growth) to only incrementally allocate memory but when I tried it recently it was broken. This means there aren&#x27;t easy ways to figure out exactly how much memory TF is using (e.g. if you want to increase the batch size). I believe you can use their undocumented profiler, but I ended up just tweaking batch sizes until TF stopped crashing (yikes).<p>TF does not have in-place operation support for some common operations that could use it, like dropout (other operations do have this support, I believe). That and I had a real bad experience with trying to build Tensorflow (and Bazel) to run on an HPC cluster.", "TF doesn\u2019t use Maven. I&#x27;m sure it&#x27;s all the rage in the cube-farms, but that doesn&#x27;t necessarily make one&#x27;s life easier.", "So what would you include in the next-generation ML tool?", "I feel like a lot a people in this thread are like &quot;omg he said declarative is bad. but declarative programming is good! so he must be wrong about everything&quot;. And then they come up with arguments against the article and imply he is an idiot.", "For nice looking basic statistics of your dataset the pandas-profiling library will do the trick <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;JosPolfliet&#x2F;pandas-profiling\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;JosPolfliet&#x2F;pandas-profiling</a>"], "time": "2017-10-08 23:24:44", "url": "http://nicodjimenez.github.io/2017/10/08/tensorflow.html", "text": "<html><body><div><article class=\"post-content\">\n    <h1 id=\"introduction\">Introduction</h1>\n\n<p>Every few months I enter the following query into Google: \u201cTensorflow sucks\u201d or \u201cf*** Tensorflow\u201d, hoping to find like-minded folk on the internet. Unfortunately, although Tensorflow has been around for about two years, I still cannot find a bashing of Tensorflow that leaves me fully satisfied.</p>\n\n<p>Although I suppose it\u2019s possible I might be asking the wrong search engine, I think there\u2019s a different force at work here: Google envy.  The phenomenon known as \u201cGoogle deep envy\u201d is the following set of assumptions made by engineers across the world:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>People who work at Google are more intelligent and competent than yourself</li>\n  <li>If you learn Tensorflow you could get a deep learning job at Google! (keep deep dreaming young fellow)</li>\n  <li>If your mediocre startup uses Tensorflow and you blog about its virtues maybe Google will want to buy it</li>\n  <li>If you don\u2019t \u201cget\u201d Tensorflow\u2019s unintuitive design, you\u2019re just dumb</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Let\u2019s leave our assumptions behind us for now and give Tensorflow an honest look.</p>\n\n<p>When Tensorflow first came out, we were promised an end to the endless nightmare of poorly designed or poorly maintained deep learning frameworks. (e.g. <a href=\"https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/issues\">https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/issues</a>).  What we got instead, was the deep learning framework equivalent of Java (write once, run everywhere), but less fun to work with, and with a purely declarative paradigm.  Yuck.</p>\n\n<p>Where did things go wrong? In trying to build a tool to satisfy everyone\u2019s needs, it seems that Google built a product that does a so-so job of satisfying anyone\u2019s needs.</p>\n\n<p>For researchers, Tensorflow is hard to learn and hard to use.  Research is all about flexibility, and lack of flexibility is baked into Tensorflow at a deep level.</p>\n\n<p>Want to extract the values of intermediate layers of a neural net? You\u2019ll need to define a graph, and then execute it with the data passed in as a dictionary, and oh don\u2019t forget to add the intermediate layers as outputs of the graph, or else you won\u2019t be able to retrieve their values.  Ok, that hurt, but it\u2019s doable.</p>\n\n<p>Want to execute layers conditionally, such as an RNN that stops whenever an end-of-sentence (EOS) token is produced? Someone using Pytorch will be on their 3rd failed AI startup by the time you\u2019re done with that.</p>\n\n<p>For machine learning practitioners such as myself, Tensorflow is not a great choice either.  The declarative nature of the framework makes debugging much more difficult.  The advantage of being able to run models on Android or iOS looks great until you see how big the framework binaries are (20MB+), or you try to look at the nearly non-existent C++ documentation, or you want to do any kind of conditional network execution, which is super useful in low resource situations such as mobile.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"comparisons-with-other-frameworks\">Comparisons with other frameworks</h1>\n<p>It is true that the developers of Tensorflow are deep learning superstars.  However, the original developer of Tensorflow that is probably most widely known and respected, Yangquing Jia, has recently left Google to join Facebook, where his Caffe2 project is quietly picking up steam: (<a href=\"https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/graphs/contributors\">https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/graphs/contributors</a>,  <a href=\"https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/issues\">https://github.com/caffe2/caffe2/issues</a>).  Unlike Tensorflow, Caffe2 allows the user to execute a layer on a piece of data in one line of code.  Radical!</p>\n\n<p>In addition, Pytorch is quickly developing popularity amongst top AI researchers.  Torch users, although nursing RSI injuries from writing Lua code to perform simple string operations, simply aren\u2019t deserting in droves to Tensorflow \u2013 they are switching to Pytorch.  It appears that Tensorflow is just not good enough for top AI labs.  Sorry, Google.</p>\n\n<p>The most interesting question to me is why Google chose a purely declarative paradigm for Tensorflow in spite of the obvious downsides of this approach.  Did they feel that encapsulating all the computation in a single computation graph would simplify executing models on their TPU\u2019s so they can cut Nvidia out of the millions of dollars to be made from cloud hosting of deep learning powered applications? It\u2019s difficult to say.  Overall, Tensorflow does not feel like a pure open source project for the common good.  Which I would have no problem with, had their design been sound.  In comparison with beautiful Google open source projects out there such as Protobuf, Golang, and Kubernetes, Tensorflow falls dramatically short.</p>\n\n<p>While declarative paradigms are great for UI programming, there are many reasons why it is a problematic choice for deep learning.</p>\n\n<p>Take the React Javascript library as an example, the standard choice today for interactive web applications.  In React, the complexity of how data flows through the application makes sense to be hidden from the developer, since Javascript execution is generally orders of magnitudes faster than updates to the DOM.  React developers don\u2019t want to worry about the mechanics of how state is propagated, so long as the end user experience is \u201cgood enough\u201d.</p>\n\n<p>On the other hand, in deep learning, a single layer can literally execute billions of FLOP\u2019s! And deep learning researchers care very much about the mechanics of how computation is done and want fine control because they are constantly pushing the edge of what\u2019s possible (e.g. dynamic networks) and want easy access to intermediate results.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"a-concrete-example\">A concrete example</h1>\n\n<p>Let\u2019s look at a simple example of training a model to multiply its input by 3.</p>\n\n<p>First, let\u2019s look at the Tensorflow example:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-python\" data-lang=\"python\"><span class=\"kn\">import</span> <span class=\"n\">sess</span><span class=\"p\">:</span>\n    <span class=\"n\">sess</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">run</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">init</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"k\">for</span> <span class=\"n\">t</span> <span class=\"ow\">in</span> <span class=\"nb\">range</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span <span class=\"n\">y</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"n\">x</span> <span class=\"o\">*</span> <span class=\"mi\">3</span>\n    <span class=\"n\">y_pred</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"n\">model</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">x</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"n\">loss</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"p\">]</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>Although the Pytorch example is one less line of code, the operations are much more explicit, and the syntax follows the actual learning process much more closely inside the training loop:</p>\n\n<ol>\n  <li>Forward pass of input</li>\n  <li>Generate loss</li>\n  <li>Compute gradients</li>\n  <li>Backprop</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>whereas in Tensorflow the core operation is a magic <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">sess.run</code> call.</p>\n\n<p>Why would you want to write more lines of code to end up with something more difficult to understand and maintain? Pytorch\u2019s interface is objectively much better than Tensorflow\u2019s.  It\u2019s not even close.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion</h1>\n\n<p>With Tensorflow, Google has created a framework that is simultaneously too low level to use comfortably for rapid prototyping, yet too high level to use comfortably in cutting edge research or in production environments that are resource constrained.</p>\n\n<p>Let\u2019s be honest, when you have about half a dozen open source high-level libraries out there built on top of your already high-level library to make your library usable, you know something has gone terribly wrong:</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Note: I will concede that Tensorboard (Tensorflow\u2019s monitoring tool) is a really good idea.  If you want a beautiful monitoring solution for your machine learning project that includes advanced model comparison features, check out Losswise (<a href=\"https://losswise.com\">https://losswise.com</a>). I developed it to allow machine learning developers such as myself to decouple tracking their model\u2019s performance from whatever machine learning library they use, and to implement many awesome features that I wanted which Tensorboard does not provide.</p>\n\n\n  </article>\n\n  \n \n</div></body></html>"}, "15429826": {"score": 123, "comments": ["The reason glasses cost so much is because one company owns:\n(1) nearly all brand name frames including Ray-Ban, Oakley, Prada eyewear, Armani eyewear and so on, \n(2) nearly all retail stores such as LensCrafters, Pearle Vision, Sears Optical and Target Optical and \n(3) EyeMed, one of the largest vision insurance companies.<p>Luxottica retail brands: <a href=\"http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;retail-brands\" rel=\"nofollow\">http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;retail-brands</a><p>Luxottica eyewear brands: <a href=\"http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;eyewear-brands\" rel=\"nofollow\">http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;eyewear-brands</a><p>Luxottica vision insurance: <a href=\"http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;node&#x2F;6336\" rel=\"nofollow\">http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.luxottica.com&#x2F;en&#x2F;node&#x2F;6336</a><p>See 60 Minutes story on Luxottica:\n<a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.youtube.com&#x2F;watch?v=gDdq2rIqAlM\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.youtube.com&#x2F;watch?v=gDdq2rIqAlM</a>", "In Jan 2017, Luxottica announced a merger with the largest lens maker, Essilor. Kering\u2019s decision to move its eyewear business in-house was dubbed a \u201crevolution\u201d by an Exane BNP Paribas report on the matter. But what are the wider implications for the eyewear market, and how will the market develop in the coming years?</p>\n<p><strong>The Market Today</strong></p>\n<p>Eyewear is big business. Market sources estimate that the global market, which includes frames, contact lenses and sunglasses, is worth $90 billion, and will reach $140 billion by 2020.\u00a0In 2012, Exane BNP Paribas estimated that frames and sunglasses represented 40 percent of the eyewear market. Within that segment it estimates that premium frames and sunglasses, the sort produced by fashion labels, represent 35 percent. Applying those estimates to today\u2019s market values the premium fashion segment at just below $13 billion.</p>\n<p>Traditionally, five specialist eyewear players have dominated the premium fashion segment of the market, developing, manufacturing and distributing their own brands, as well as entering into licensing deals to produce frames for fashion houses. Although the terms of these deals vary, the specialist players typically design the eyewear, with input from the brands, before developing, manufacturing and distributing it in the market.</p>\n<div class=\"article-special article-special-left article-special-medium\">\n<p><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-155452\" src=\"https://images.businessoffashion.com/site/uploads/2015/05/Screen_Shot_2015-05-15_at_141312-500x511.png?ixlib=php-1.1.0\" alt=\"eyewear\"/></p>\n</div>\n<p>Luxottica, the dominant frame producer, owns a portfolio of eyewear brands that includes Persol and Ray-Ban, the latter of which is the biggest brand in the market. It holds the licenses to produce eyewear for global fashion brands such as Chanel, Armani, Prada and <span id=\"328\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/michael-kors\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_328\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"328\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Michael Kors\" subtitle=\"Designer, Michael Kors\" img=\"profiles/asset/328/c243393a572c39311d61b6778d0fa163eecdca6b.jpeg\" content=\"The designer and previous Project Runway personality infused his once-bankrupt brand with a clean, sporty glamour and took the company public in 2011.\">Michael Kors</a></span> and manages the distribution of its products through 200,000 wholesale doors. In 2014, the Italian company generated over \u20ac7.6 billion (about $8.5 billion) in revenue. In addition, Luxottica owns the Sunglass Hut retail brand and is a retail company in its own right, with over 7,000 stores worldwide, giving it a majority share of the eyewear market.</p>\n<p>The second biggest player, the Safilo Group, holds licenses for Dior, Fendi, C\u00e9line and <span id=\"306\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/marc-jacobs\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_306\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"306\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Marc Jacobs\" subtitle=\"Founder &amp; Creative Director, Marc Jacobs\" img=\"profiles/asset/306/6b26c705f407318c64e448932915e49901076a9d.jpeg\" content=\"The decorated American designer was the first to introduce 1990s grunge on the catwalk and has since grown his namesake brand into a global fashion force.\">Marc Jacobs</a></span>. It employs more than 150 designers, adding more than 3,000 new models to the market a year, sold through a network of 90,000 wholesale doors. The company reported \u20ac1.17 billion (about $1.33 billion) in revenue in 2014 and annual growth of about five percent.</p>\n<p>Marchon Eyewear, De Rigo and Marcolin, the three smaller players in the market, each have licensing deals with major global brands. Marchon holds licenses from <span id=\"1889\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/calvin-klein\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_1889\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"1889\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Calvin Klein\" subtitle=\"Founder, Calvin Klein\" img=\"profiles/asset/1889/50bc1806873394ead18ef1d8be8cc6b3f71cba30.jpeg\" content=\"With his minimalist aesthetic and sensual imagery, he launched an iconic American lifestyle brand encompassing apparel, fragrance and jewelry.\">Calvin Klein</a></span>, Valentino, Salvatore Ferragamo\u00a0and Chlo\u00e9; De Rigo holds Lanvin, <span id=\"692\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/loewe\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_692\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"692\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Loewe\" subtitle=\"Madrid, Spain\" img=\"uploads/media/bof_company_logo/0001/97/0e5ff6189f0cc42b72eb580963a5b17b74e058fb.jpeg\" content=\"LOEWE approaches 170 years as one of the major luxury houses, defined by the modernity of its past, an confidence in the present.\">Loewe</a></span> and <span id=\"1145\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/carolina-herrera-2\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_1145\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"1145\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Carolina Herrera\" subtitle=\"Designer, Carolina Herrera\" img=\"profiles/asset/1145/0c9f1742b8575ae40168a5cb8ec84c2c22475177.jpeg\" content=\"One of the first ladies of fashion, her unflagging energy has seen her company expand internationally.\">Carolina Herrera</a></span>; and Marcolin holds <span id=\"474\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/tom-ford\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_474\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"474\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Tom Ford\" subtitle=\"Creative Director, Tom Ford\" img=\"profiles/asset/474/c848ceb44822f9acb62f62bd39e2b41666571592.jpeg\" content=\"The acclaimed American designer, now at his own billion-dollar label, is credited with injecting sex appeal into Gucci and YSL.\">Tom Ford</a></span>, Balenciaga, Tod\u2019s and\u00a0Ermenegildo Zegna.</p>\n<p><strong>A New Number Five?</strong></p>\n<p>In September, Kering told press, \u201cThe current size of the Kering brands\u2019 business is roughly \u20ac350 million [making] Kering one of the top five players in this industry\u2026 Kering will fully control the eyewear value chain, from design to product development and supply chain, and from branding and marketing to sales.\u201d</p>\n<p>But why did Kering choose to go it alone? In the statement announcing the launch of its eyewear division, Kering highlighted that, \"The premium segment of the eyewear business is currently growing in the high double-digits.\"</p>\n<p>The importance of eyewear as an entry-level product for its brands speaks to the other key advantage stemming from Kering\u2019s move: control. The Exane BNP Paribas report states, \u201cThe ubiquitous distribution typical of most license contracts adds to brand trivialisation risk.\u201d By taking its eyewear in-house, controlling development, distribution and sales, Kering could \u201cmaintain desirability through perceived exclusivity.\u201d</p>\n<p>What's more, Kering is now free to work with multiple manufacturing partners \u2014 including the Safilo Group \u2014 on a case-by-case basis. This freedom will allow the company to build out each of its eleven brands\u2019 eyewear businesses in a way that is carefully tailored to the consumer profile and DNA of each brand.</p>\n<p><strong>A Question of Scale</strong></p>\n<p>The scale of Kering\u2019s eyewear business is significantly smaller than that of Luxottica and Safilo. \u201cThe major challenge in eyewear is to serve a very fragmented customer base \u2014 reaching it with sales and logistics is expensive and demands local scale. Building scale is important for Kering as it will operate at a commercial and distribution cost disadvantage versus Safilo,\u201d says Luca Solca, head of luxury goods at Exane BNP Paribas.</p>\n<p>Kering is not the first luxury group to bring its eyewear business in-house. In 1999, Prada ceased licensing its brand to Luxottica and formed its own eyewear company, Eyewear International Distribution S.A, in partnership with De Rigo. The venture was short-lived. When Prada ended its dealings with De Rigo in 2002, to return to Luxottica, the joint venture company's\u00a0sales stood at $33.6 million. At the time, Luxottica said in a statement that it expected Prada\u2019s eyewear sales to jump to $120 million in its first year back with the company: clear evidence of the power of Luxottica\u2019s distribution network.</p>\n<p>Indeed, although Kering has a global network of stores (respectively, <span id=\"658\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/gucci\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_658\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"658\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Gucci\" subtitle=\"Firenze, Italy\" img=\"uploads/media/header_image/0001/12/53469d8823eb8221083f8bee94b1195a34c6c58a.jpeg\" content=\"Founded in Florence in 1921, Gucci is one of the world\u2019s  leading luxury fashion brands, with a renowned reputation for creativity\">Gucci</a></span> and <span id=\"794\"><a href=\"http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/saint-laurent\" bof-track=\"\" class=\"kws_link imp clk profile_id_794\" data-e=\"profile.link\" data-id=\"794\" profile-popover=\"\" title=\"Saint Laurent\" subtitle=\"Paris, France\" img=\"uploads/media/bof_company_logo/0002/61/fe34cee86591f50f5057759f9c3803e048a6904f.jpeg\" content=\"Synonymous to youth and freedom, Yves Saint Laurent was the first couture house to introduce the concept of luxury pr\u00eat-\u00e0-porter\">Saint Laurent</a></span> had 408 and 91 monobrand points of sale in 2014, according to statistics compiled by Exane BNP Paribas), it pales in significance compared to the own-retail network of Luxottica. In the unlikely event that Luxottica, the largest eyewear retailer in the world, stopped buying Kering eyewear, Kering would lose key distribution points, especially outside of its own stores in\u00a0North America. Furthermore, Kering would have to develop\u00a0wholesale relationships with local eyewear retailers to achieve full reach: most small regional towns have an optician \u2014 few, however, have a Gucci store.</p>\n<p>\u201cIf you're coming in new and you're trying to leverage a brand, I think you have a very long way to go. It's very difficult to build a solution, work-wise, when your three largest competitors could block you out of parts of the market,\u201d said Claudio Gottardi, chief executive of Marchon. \u201cThe question is: What could a new entrant into the market offer that will allow that company to enter the market without a return for the people who they are going to be competing [with],\u201d he continued.</p>\n<p><strong>A Growing Global Market</strong></p>\n<p>\u201cThe market, structurally, globally, is really growing,\u201d said Luisa Delgado, chief executive of the Safilo Group. \u201cOn one side, it\u2019s driven by demographics: the development of certain markets where an increasing middle class is getting access to interesting brands. But then there's also education, an ageing population: it [all] stimulates the growth of our industry,\u201d she continued, highlighting how higher rates of education and longer life expectancy are increasing the demand for prescription glasses.</p>\n<p>To capitalise on this growth, the eyewear market\u2019s biggest players have expanded internationally \u2014 and continue to do so. \u201cIn 2009 I started opening sister companies across the globe,\u201d said Marchon\u2019s Gottardi. \u201cI went directly to China, Singapore, Portugal, Scandinavia, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and all of the [Arabian] Gulf. Just to give you an idea, in Brazil, our revenues are about six times higher than four years ago.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cExpansion into market areas, especially in emerging markets, has been the biggest driver of our growth over the last five years,\u201d said Massimo Vian, co-chief executive of Luxottica. Indeed, Luxottica\u2019s Q1 2015 results for Asia-Pacific and Latin America reported growth of 18.7 percent and 21.7 percent, respectively. Luxottica is also treating North America as an emerging market, in terms of potential for further penetration.</p>\n<p>And then there is the digital opportunity. Due to the product's\u00a0small size and one-size-fits-all model,\u00a0eyewear is well-suited to digital retail, creating further\u00a0opportunity for growth. \u201cWe have been active as a company over the last three years, with the Glasses.com acquisition [in January 2014] and the new Ray-Ban [digital sales] platform,\u201d said Vian. Tapping into the current consumer trend for customisation, the platform allows consumers to choose any combination of lens, frame style and colour. \u201cThat service has been growing 100 percent year-on-year, starting from a relatively low base and small numbers, but it is developed enough to understand the potential of that channel,\u201d Vian continued.</p>\n<p>Clearly, new markets, emerging consumer demographics and new product streams are driving growth across the eyewear market. These drivers are particularly germane\u00a0to the premium fashion segment \u2014 a fact Kering is well aware of. As an established player in the eyewear market, Kering has powerful, pre-existing relationships between its brands and global consumers, but it will need to operationalise this in a market with additional distribution channels in order to compete with the incumbents.</p>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429067": {"score": 148, "comments": ["See extensive discussion on HN (1054 points, 406 comments) of this issue back in May.<p><a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=14287235\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=14287235</a>", "Thank you; I looked up that post\u2019s title on HN before posting it but got no result.", "I am the author of the Wikipedia essay &quot;Wikipedia has Cancer&quot;. The Wikipedia page on the <a href=\"/wiki/Wheat_and_chessboard_problem\" title=\"Wheat and chessboard problem\">wheat and chessboard problem</a> explains that nothing can keep growing exponentially forever. In biology, the unwanted growth usually terminates with the death of the host. So, it's really gotten to be a huge thing. And everything is managed by the volunteers and the total monthly cost for our bandwidth is about <span>US$</span>5,000, and that's essentially our main cost. We could actually do without the employee \u2026 We actually hired Brion because he was working part-time for two years and full-time at Wikipedia so we actually hired him so he could get a life and go to the movies sometimes.\"</i></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>According to the WMF, Wikipedia (in all language editions) now receives 16 billion page views per month.<sup id=\"cite_ref-12\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> The WMF spends roughly $2 million USD per year on Internet hosting<sup id=\"cite_ref-2015-16_11-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-2015-16-11\">[11]</a></sup> and employs some 300 staff.<sup id=\"cite_ref-13\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> The modern Wikipedia hosts 11\u201312 times as many pages as it did in 2005,<sup id=\"cite_ref-14\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-14\">[14]</a></sup> but the WMF is spending 33 times as much on hosting,<sup id=\"cite_ref-15\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-15\">[15]</a></sup> has about 300 times as many employees, and is spending 1,250 times as much overall.<sup id=\"cite_ref-16\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-16\">[16]</a></sup> WMF's spending has gone up by 85% over the past three years.<sup id=\"cite_ref-17\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Sounds a lot like cancer, doesn't it? For those readers who were around three years ago, did you notice at the time any unmet needs that would have caused you to conclude that the WMF needed to increase spending by $30 million dollars? I certainly didn't.</p>\n<p>From 2005 to 2015, annual inflation in the US was between 1% and 3% per year, and cumulative inflation for the entire decade was 21.4%\u2014far less than the increase in WMF spending. We are even <a href=\"/wiki/Metastasis\" title=\"Metastasis\">metastasizing</a> the cancer by bankrolling local chapters, rewarding them for finding new ways to spend money.<sup id=\"cite_ref-18\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-19\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Nothing can grow forever. Sooner or later, something is going to happen that causes the donations to decline instead of increase. It could be a scandal (real or perceived). It could be the WMF taking a political position that offends many donors. Or it could be a recession, leaving people with less money to give. It might even be a lawsuit that forces the WMF to pay out a judgement that is larger than the reserve. Whatever the reason is, it <i>will</i> happen. It would be na\u00efve to think that the WMF, which up to this point has never seriously considered any sort of spending limits, will suddenly discover fiscal prudence when the revenues start to decline. It is far more likely that the WMF will not react to a drop in donations by decreasing spending, but instead will ramp up fund-raising efforts while burning through our reserves and our endowment.</p>\n<p>Although this essay focuses on spending, not fundraising, it could be argued that the ever-increasing spending is a direct cause of the kind of fund-raising that has generated a storm of criticism.<sup id=\"cite_ref-20\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-21\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-22\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-22\">[22]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-23\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-23\">[23]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-24\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-24\">[24]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-25\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-25\">[25]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-26\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-26\">[26]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-27\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-27\">[27]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-28\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-28\">[28]</a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-29\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-29\">[29]</a></sup> These complaints have been around for years,<sup id=\"cite_ref-30\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-30\">[30]</a></sup> leading one member of a major Wikimedia mailing list to automate his yearly complaint about the dishonesty he sees every year in our fundraising banners.<sup id=\"cite_ref-31\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-31\">[31]</a></sup></p>\n<p>No organization can sustain this sort of spending on a long-term basis. We should have leveled off our spending years ago. Like cancer, WMF spending is growing at an exponential rate. Like cancer, this will kill the patient unless the growth is stopped. Some charities can safely grow without limits. If you are feeding 1,000 starving orphans per week, a ten times increase in revenue means that you will be able to feed 10,000 orphans per week. Wikipedia isn't like that. It costs a certain amount to have reliable severs, run a good legal team, maintain the core software, etc. But none of the things that the WMF needs to do require ever-expanding spending.</p>\n<p>The reason I have so little faith in the WMF's ability to adapt to declining revenues (note that I specified the WMF; I think <i>Wikipedia</i> has shown an excellent ability to adapt to multiple problems) is the horrific track record they have regarding adapting to other kinds of problems.</p>\n<p>In particular, their poor handling of software development has been well known for many years. The answer to the WMF's problems with software development has been well known for decades and is extensively documented in books such as <i><a href=\"/wiki/The_Mythical_Man-Month\" title=\"The Mythical Man-Month\">The Mythical Man-Month</a></i> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/Peopleware:_Productive_Projects_and_Teams\" title=\"Peopleware: Productive Projects and Teams\">Peopleware: Productive Projects and Teams</a></i>, yet I have never seen any evidence that the WMF has been following standard software engineering principles that were well-known when <i>Mythical Man-Month</i> was first published in 1975. If they had, we would be seeing things like requirements documents and schedules with measurable milestones. This failure is almost certainly a systemic problem directly caused by top management, not by the developers doing the actual work.</p>\n<p>This is not to imply that decades-old software development methods are somehow superior to modern ones, but rather that the WMF is violating basic principles that are common to both. Nothing about Agile or SCRUM means that the developers do not have to talk to end users, create requirements, or meet milestones. In fact, modern software development methods require <i>more</i> communication and interaction with the final end users. Take as an example the way Visual Editor was developed. There are many pages of documentation on the WMF servers and mailing lists, but no evidence that any developer had any serious discussions with the actual editors of Wikipedia who would be using the software. Instead. the role of \"customer\" was played by paid WMF staffers who thought that they knew what Wikipedia editors need better than the editors themselves do. Then they threw the result over the wall, and the community of Wikipedia editors largely rejected it. Or Knowledge Engine, which was developed in secret before being cancelled when word got out about what the WMF was planning. Another example: The MediaWiki edit toolbar ended up being used by a whopping 0.03% of active editors.<sup id=\"cite_ref-32\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-32\">[32]</a></sup></p>\n<p>After we burn through our reserves, it seems likely that the next step for the WMF will be going into debt to support continued runaway spending, followed by bankruptcy. At that point there are several large corporations (Google and Facebook come to mind) that will be more than happy to pay off the debts, take over the encyclopedia, fire the WMF staff, and start running Wikipedia as a profit-making platform. There are a lot of ways to monetize Wikipedia, all undesirable. The new owners could sell banner advertising, allow uneditable \"sponsored articles\" for those willing to pay for the privilege, or even sell information about editors and users.</p>\n<p>If we want to avoid disaster, we need to start shrinking the cancer now, before it is too late. We should make spending transparent, publish a detailed account of what the money is being spent on and answer any reasonable questions asking for more details. We should limit spending increases to no more than inflation plus some percentage (adjusted for any increases in page views), build up our endowment, and structure the endowment so that the WMF cannot legally dip into the principal when times get bad.</p>\n<p>If we do these things now, in a few short years we could be in a position to do everything we are doing now, while living off of the endowment interest, and would have no need for further fundraising. Or we could keep fundraising, using the donations to do many new and useful things, knowing that whatever we do there is a guaranteed income stream from the endowment that will keep the servers running indefinitely.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a
