so why does it keep pestering you?</a> <i>The Register</i></span></li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-31\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-31\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.gossamer-threads.com/lists/wiki/foundation/534599#534599\">Fundraising banners (again)</a> <i>Wikimedia-l</i></span></li>\n<li id=\"cite_note-32\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-32\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a class=\"external text\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk%3AJimbo_Wales&amp;type=revision&amp;diff=779581521&amp;oldid=779577018\">Editing News #1\u20142017</a> <i>Wikimedia Foundation</i></span></li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Also_see\">Also see</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=User:Guy_Macon/Wikipedia_has_Cancer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Also see\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430854": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:45:16", "url": "https://medium.com/@colinsholes/getting-in-touch-with-my-past-the-typewriter-museum-c491ced4a96", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><h1 name=\"3df5\" id=\"3df5\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf--leading graf--title\">Getting in Touch With My Past: The Typewriter Museum</h1><figure name=\"d691\" id=\"d691\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--h3\"/><p name=\"53d1\" id=\"53d1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">I have an unusual last name. I know this because for my entire life people have been unable to spell it, even when I spell it for them, and I nearly always do. I went to Disneyland with my parents and we visited a booth selling framed copies of family crests, thinking it would be a fun thing to hang on the wall. Sholes was in the book, but the booth operator could not find it in the computer to print. He told us he\u2019d never seen that happen in 10 years. Long story short\u200a\u2014\u200athere aren\u2019t many Sholeses in the world.</p><p name=\"7ee5\" id=\"7ee5\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">A couple of years back I\u2019d been told by my father that one of our distant ancestors invented the QWERTY keyboard for the typewriter. It was a cool tidbit, but I didn\u2019t think much more about it. Then, last year, I read a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mwichary/status/791709895083102209?lang=en\" data-href=\"https://twitter.com/mwichary/status/791709895083102209?lang=en\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">viral tweet</a> from a guy who\u2019d run across an odd little museum in Spain. I told my friend who lives in Barcelona that next time I was in town we had to check it out\u200a\u2014\u200ahe agreed.</p><p name=\"1049\" id=\"1049\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The <a href=\"http://www.mte.cat/\" data-href=\"http://www.mte.cat/\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">Museu de la T\u00e8cnica de l\u2019Empord\u00e0</a> is down a side street off the main square in Figueres. We strolled over there after visiting the Dali museum, the common tourist attraction in the city. We\u2019d called a day ahead of time to make sure someone would be there\u200a\u2014\u200athe museum website said it was open only 3 hours a day, so I wanted to be sure. Walking in, we saw an assortment of curiosities, from original Vespas to an 1800s automobile to old gas pumps. Two typewriters sat on the main display by the door. We paid the older gentleman at the desk our 3 Euro and he told us to go to the third floor for the \u2018tour\u2019.</p><p name=\"bf75\" id=\"bf75\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The two of us rode up in a small elevator, and it opened out into the scene we\u2019d read about. Typewriters everywhere. Rooms full of them. We were immediately greeted by the proprietress Margarita, who was giving a tour to a Spanish family. My friend translated for me, because she did not speak any English. She took us through the origin story of the typewriter, from its early days through the 20th century.</p><figure name=\"a3f2\" id=\"a3f2\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">Original Sholes &amp; Glidden, circa\u00a01874</figcaption></figure><p name=\"3bb7\" id=\"3bb7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">When we reached the first Sholes prototype at the museum, Margarita explained how it worked\u200a\u2014\u200ait was foot powered and the paper was propelled along the top of the machine with dual rollers, while the arms swung from beneath into the ink roll. This model was built prior to functional refinements by the Remington company, which led to the creation of the modern typewriter with the Sholes keyboard. Early Sholes &amp; Glidden machines were beautifully painted to appeal to a better class of customer, since the price tag was high for the day.</p><figure name=\"7a62\" id=\"7a62\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"ecc9\" id=\"ecc9\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">After she explained the history of the machine on display, I stopped her to show her my driver\u2019s license, explaining that I was a Sholes. Margarita lit up, and immediately held out her hand to me. She told me (via my friend\u2019s translation) that she would show me books after the tour about my ancestor, and the story of his inventions. It was an emotional moment, hearing this from someone who had dedicated her life to collecting these machines.</p><p name=\"ac85\" id=\"ac85\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The museum is incredible\u200a\u2014\u200anot only for the size of the collection, but because you can touch most of the models. Perhaps two-thirds of the typewriters on display were not behind glass. Margarita demonstrated how some of the more esoteric machines worked\u200a\u2014\u200aChinese typewriters, music typewriters, single-press typewriters with swing arms to peck out individual letters. She told the story of an old machine they found at a flea market that, when it was cleaned up, turned out to be a typewriter Mussolini had commissioned to give as a gift and was thought lost forever in the War.</p><figure name=\"a012\" id=\"a012\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--startsWithDoubleQuote graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">\u201cMussolini\u201d typewriter, made of solid\u00a0bronze</figcaption></figure><p name=\"eb37\" id=\"eb37\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">We made our way down to the second floor full of sewing machines. Margarita told us the history of the sewing machine, from hand-crank devices to the invention of the foot pedal and on through the development of electric motors and battery power. They had hundreds on display, some of them ornately painted and some very clearly designed with function in mind. The sewing machine was an important part of any houeshold in the 19th and 20th century, and the museum\u2019s collection had a huge variety. Singer was the brand most represented, but they also had boutique machines from French and Spanish manufacturers, as well as commercial devices intended to mass produce clothing. They had a device designed to repair pantyhose, which at the time were too expensive to replace often.</p><p name=\"bc8c\" id=\"bc8c\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">The ground floor housed many of the random curiosities the couple had come across during their years of collecting. There was an original Edison Dictaphone along with the shaving machine to \u201cerase\u201d the wax cylinders it inscribed.</p><figure name=\"7738\" id=\"7738\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"bf35\" id=\"bf35\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The tour was now over, and she introduced us to her husband Pere, the other proprietor of the museum. He walks with a crutch and no longer does tours himself. The origin story of the collection was that the couple owned a transportation company and Pere was\u200a\u2014\u200ain her words\u200a\u2014\u200a\u201cvery busy\u201d with work until one day he decided to purchase and fix up an old typewriter from a flea market. He was hooked. Since their business took them all over Europe, they began to collect the machines and store them in warehouses they owned in Spain. Over years the collection expanded to fill the museum. Incredibly, Margarita said they had over <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">thirty-five hundred </em>typewriters in storage that were not on display, along with many other items they did not have the room for.</p><p name=\"35ae\" id=\"35ae\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">As we marveled at the collection Margarita brought out books to show me, in English, that told the story of my ancestor, Latham-Sholes. My friend spoke with the couple in Spanish, learning about their lives as I read. We left reluctantly, after going back upstairs to take photos of all the typewriters. They had turned some of the lights out, so I was unable to get photos of the sewing machine floor\u200a\u2014\u200aI felt it rude to inconvenience them any further. The experience was a bit overwhelming\u200a\u2014\u200athe museum contains so many machines from so many different origins I find it hard to recount all of it now, even after a guided tour.</p><p name=\"ac5f\" id=\"ac5f\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">As I read about my ancestor the narrative of his challenges and the process of his invention emerged. I could relate. As a young entrepreneur, I faced many of the hurdles he did\u200a\u2014\u200adoubters, repeated failures, bad business partners. In the end he did not become rich\u200a\u2014\u200ahe sold his portion of the patent to Remington for somewhere between six and twelve thousand dollars. He wasn\u2019t particularly well-known for his invention, though his name did feature on a number of machines over the next few decades. The Latham-Sholes contribution to history was the refinement of the typewriter keyboard; his became the optimal layout for keys to avoid the arms jamming during typing. Touching some of his original creations from a hundred and forty years ago, actually <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">typing</em> on a Sholes from the 1800s, was an incredible way to connect with an ancestor. The machines he made <em class=\"markup--em markup--p-em\">still work</em>. His flash of genius solved a small problem in his time, and his legacy is now on billions of electronic devices around the world. I got a window into my past, and I clacked away on it to my heart\u2019s content.</p><figure name=\"acf3\" id=\"acf3\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf-after--p\"><figcaption class=\"imageCaption\">A Sholes, typing on a\u00a0Sholes</figcaption></figure><p name=\"7995\" id=\"7995\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">I took a lot of other photos after the tour of the varied and bizarre machines on display. The gallery is <a href=\"https://photos.app.goo.gl/XsIqqPjfa3hzrWtn2\" data-href=\"https://photos.app.goo.gl/XsIqqPjfa3hzrWtn2\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">here</a>.</p><p name=\"2588\" id=\"2588\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p graf--trailing\">Thanks again to Margarita and Pere, my friend Francesc who translated everything, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mwichary\" data-href=\"https://twitter.com/mwichary\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Marcin Wichary</a> for sharing this discovery with Twitter.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429831": {"score": 142, "comments": ["You&#x27;d assume that a device as sensitive as a hardware security key would get extensive testing from the vendor, from 3rd parties contracted to the vendor, and from random unauthorized 3rd parties testing out of personal or public interest.<p>But in fact there are almost certainly commercial hardware security keys that receive <i>no testing at all</i> at the level AGL is working at --- which, while impressive and super interesting, isn&#x27;t as low-level as serious third party specialized crypto validation goes.<p>My takeaway from this is: buy the most popular U2F key (which happens to be Yubico&#x27;s). Though the TPMs might commonly be easier to physically hack than good USB devices.", "For U2F, there are two issues. First, communication doesn&#x27;t use a smart card protocol, it uses a custom protocol over USB&#x2F;HID. So to implement U2F using the TPM you would need to write a virtual USB device driver, which is a pain. Github wrote one for Mac, but there&#x27;s nothing for Linux or Windows to my knowledge. Second, U2F calls for a physical presence check. With most existing hardware, there&#x27;s no way for the TPM to verify physical presence, so it has to be done in the client software, which reduces the point somewhat. I wanted to experiment with the technology. I&#x27;ve since backed off the idea due to several serious challenges with designing secure hardware for this purpose.<p>* By necessity there&#x27;s a pretty large attack surface, you&#x27;ve likely got a vendor specific bluetooth stack and coprocessor. The same goes for wired solutions with hardware USB peripherals (though atleast significantly less complex).  Being sure the hardware peripheral doesn&#x27;t have any major memory safety issues is a complete bear to test, and that&#x27;s not even touching on sidechannel analysis.<p>* Running public key crypto on microcontroller (excluding specific hardware crypto support) is a little more novel than a desktop machine, the leading libraries are no where near as extensively battle tested. And there&#x27;s architectural concerns about sidechannel attacks and often the lack of any memory protection units (bigger chips solve these issues, but power budget concerns are tricky).<p>* And given all software has bugs, how do you update the firmware? Signed firmware patches as part of driver update? Who&#x27;s to say somebody hasn&#x27;t already owned your bootloader.<p>I think the solution to all this, is to abandon the idea of additional hardware, what if your smartphone could act as a two factor hardware token over Bluetooth? The big problem is pairing really, and how to make this an easy process for users, I never figured that out. On the other hand I did come up with a scheme that would allow usb based hardware tokens to work without additional drivers &#x2F; software and on all current major operating systems and browsers. I really ought to work on it, but as above I don&#x27;t trust embedded hardware (embedded hardware is such an antithesis to, move fast and break things).", "How&#x27;d your scheme work? (my main browser).", "On Firefox Nightly, it works without extensions, but you have to set <i>security.webauth.u2f</i> to true in <i>about:config</i>.<p>It only worked with some sites that I tried, for others you probably have to fake the user agent.", "Yeah... The Google Cloud Console and Google Accounts do that for one. I can&#x27;t set up or use my U2F key in anything but Chrome. Hangouts similarly barfs when you&#x27;re using Firefox because they believe the WebRTC support is missing (instead of checking). Works fine with GitHub though :).", "There&#x27;s an extension: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;addons.mozilla.org&#x2F;en-GB&#x2F;firefox&#x2F;addon&#x2F;u2f-support-add-on&#x2F;\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;addons.mozilla.org&#x2F;en-GB&#x2F;firefox&#x2F;addon&#x2F;u2f-support-a...</a><p>Works perfectly for me.", "This extension will become deprecated with Firefox 57 (WebExtensions update).<p>Unfortunately, it seems that they&#x27;ve failed with shipping U2F support in Firefox at the time, so the browser support seems to be coming to 58 (currently in Nightly). So, your options in November will be either Firefox ESR or switching to Firefox Beta.<p>EDIT: Source: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;prefiks&#x2F;u2f4moz&#x2F;issues&#x2F;59#issuecomment-325768286\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;prefiks&#x2F;u2f4moz&#x2F;issues&#x2F;59#issuecomment-32...</a><p>EDIT2: My previous coworker also discovered some high-CPU issues with that add-on on Ubuntu, so be aware of that as well: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;prefiks&#x2F;u2f4moz&#x2F;issues&#x2F;51\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;prefiks&#x2F;u2f4moz&#x2F;issues&#x2F;51</a>", "lastpass supports yubikeys as 2fa, but you have to have a subscription to premium for it to be enforced. i let mine lapse for a while and it simply stopped making me use my yubikey. i&#x27;m not really sure what was going on behind the scenes but it made me a little less confident in the particular aspect of lastpass.", "That was the last drop. I switched to an alternative immediately as soon as I&#x27;ve noticed LastPass requesting premium for something as essential as a 2FA method.", "Here&#x27;s a list of sites that support 2FA, via hardware tokens and other methods: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;twofactorauth.org\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;twofactorauth.org</a>", "At Google we also use it internally on all corp systems.", "I cannot fathom that folks still can&#x27;t parse DER correctly.  It really isn&#x27;t complicated."], "time": "2017-10-08 23:26:24", "url": "https://www.imperialviolet.org/2017/10/08/securitykeytest.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post\">\n      <p><a href=\"https://www.imperialviolet.org/2017/08/13/securitykeys.html\">Last time</a> I reviewed various security keys at a fairly superficial level: basic function, physical characteristics etc. This post considers lower-level behaviour.</p>\n\n<p>Security Keys implement the FIDO <a href=\"https://fidoalliance.org/specs/fido-u2f-v1.2-ps-20170411/fido-u2f-raw-message-formats-v1.2-ps-20170411.html\">U2F spec</a>, which borrows a lot from ISO 7816-4. Each possible transport (i.e. USB, NFC, or Bluetooth) has its own spec for how to encapsulate the U2F messages over that transport (e.g. <a href=\"https://fidoalliance.org/specs/fido-u2f-v1.2-ps-20170411/fido-u2f-hid-protocol-v1.2-ps-20170411.html\">here's the USB one</a>). FIDO is working on much more complex (and more capable) second versions of these specs, but currently all security keys implement the basic ones.</p>\n\n<p>In essence, the U2F spec only contains three functions: Register, Authenticate, and Check. Register creates a new key-pair. Authenticate signs with an existing key-pair, after the user confirms physical presence, and Check confirms whether or not a key-pair is known to a security key.</p>\n\n<p>In more detail, Register takes a 32-byte challenge and a 32-byte appID. These are intended to be SHA-256 hashes, but are opaque and can be anything. The challenge acts as a nonce, while the appID is bound to the resulting key and represents the context of the key. For web browsers, the appID is the hash of a URL in the origin of the login page.</p>\n\n<p>Register returns a P-256 public key, an opaque key handle, the security key's batch certificate, and a signature, by the public key in the certificate, of the challenge, appID, key handle, and public key. Since the security keys are small devices with limited storage, it's universally the case in the ones that I've looked at that the key handle is actually an encrypted private key, i.e. the token offloads storage of private keys. However, in theory, the key handle could just be an integer that indexes storage within the token.</p>\n\n<p>Authenticate takes a challenge, an appID, and a key handle, verifies that the appID matches the value given to Register, and returns a signature, from the public key associated with that key handle, over the challenge and appID.</p>\n\n<p>Check takes a key handle and an appID and returns a positive result if the key handle came from this security key and the appID matches.</p>\n\n<p>Given that, there are a number of properties that should hold. Some of the most critical:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\t<li>The key handle should be encrypted; i.e. we shouldn't be able to find an ECDSA private key in there.</li>\n\t<li>A key handle from one security key should not work with another, even of the same type.</li>\n\t<li>If a security key is asked to generate hundreds of key-pairs, they should all be distinct.</li>\n\t<li>All the signatures should have unique nonces, otherwise you have the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm#Security\">PlayStation bug</a> and can extract private keys.</li>\n\t<li>The appID should actually be checked.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>But there are a number of other things that would be nice to test:</p>\n\n<ul>\n\t<li>Does the key handle have patterns? Ideally it would be indistinguishable from random to outside observers.</li>\n\t<li>Is the key handle mutable? Really the whole thing should be authenticated.</li>\n\t<li>Are the signatures correctly encoded? It's a very simple structure, but it's ASN.1 so there are corner-cases.</li>\n\t<li>The USB protocol transmits 64-byte packets, the padding bytes at the end should all be zero, not random bits of memory. Are they?</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>So given all those desirable properties, how do various security keys manage?</p>\n\n<p><b>Yubico</b></p>\n\n<p>Easy one first: I can find no flaws in Yubico's U2F Security Key.</p>\n\n<p><b>VASCO SecureClick</b></p>\n\n<img src=\"data:image/jpeg;base64,\"/>\n\n<p>I've acquired one of these since the round-up of security keys that I did <a href=\"/2017/08/13/securitykeys.html\">last time</a> so I'll give a full introduction here. (See also <a href=\"https://github.com/hillbrad/U2FReviews#secureclick\">Brad's review</a>.)</p>\n\n<p>This is a Bluetooth Low-Energy (BLE) token, which means that it works with both Android and iOS devices. For non-mobile devices, it includes a USB-A BLE dongle. The SecureClick uses a Chrome extension for configuring and pairing the dongle, which works across platforms. The dongle appears as a normal USB device until it sees a BLE signal from the token, at which point it \u201cdisconnects\u201d and reconnects as a different device for actually doing the U2F operation. Once an operation that requires user-presence (i.e. a Register or Authenticate) has completed, the token powers down and the dongle disconnects and reconnects as the original USB device again.</p>\n\n<p>If you're using Linux and you configure udev to grant access to the vendor ID &amp; product ID of the token as it appears normally, nothing will work because the vendor ID and product ID are different when it's active. The Chrome extension will get very confused about this.</p>\n\n<p>However, once I'd figured that out, everything else worked well. The problem, as is inherent with BLE devices, is that the token needs a battery that will run out eventually. (It takes a CR2012 and can be replaced.) VASCO claims that it can be used 10 times a day for two years, which seems plausible. I did run the battery out during testing, but testing involves a lot of operations. Like the Yubico, I did not find any problems with this token.</p>\n\n<p>I did have it working with iOS, but it didn't work when I tried to check the battery level just now, and I'm not sure what changed. (Perhaps iOS 11?)</p>\n\n<p><b>Feitian ePass</b></p>\n\n<p>ASN.1 DER is designed to be a \u201cdistinguished\u201d encoding, i.e. there should be a unique serialisation for a given value and all other representations are invalid. As such, numbers are supposed to be encoded minimally, with no leading zeros (unless necessary to make a number positive). Feitian doesn't get that right with this security key: numbers that start with 9 leading zero bits have an invalid zero byte at the beginning. Presumably, numbers starting with 17 zero bits have two invalid zero bytes at the beginning and so on, but I wasn't able to press the button enough times to get such an example. Thus something like one in 256 signatures produced by this security key are invalid.</p>\n\n<p>Also, the final eight bytes of the key handle seem to be superfluous: you can change them to whatever value you like and the security key doesn't care. That is not immediately a problem, but it does beg the question: if they're not being used, what are they?</p>\n\n<p>Lastly, the padding data in USB packets isn't zeroed. However, it's obviously just the previous contents of the transmit buffer, so there's nothing sensitive getting leaked.</p>\n\n<p><b>Thetis</b></p>\n\n<p>With this device, I can't test things like key handle mutability and whether the appID is being checked because of some odd behaviour. The response to the first Check is invalid, according to the spec: it returns status 0x9000 (\u201cNO_ERROR\u201d), when it should be 0x6985 or 0x6a80. After that, it starts rejecting all key handles (even valid ones) with 0x6a80 until it's unplugged and reinserted.</p>\n\n<p>This device has the same non-minimal signature encoding issue as the Feitian ePass. Also, if you click too fast, this security key gets upset and rejects a few requests with status 0x6ffe.</p>\n\n<p>USB padding bytes aren't zeroed, but appear to be parts of the request message and thus nothing interesting.</p>\n\n<p><b>U2F Zero</b></p>\n\n<p>A 1KiB ping message crashes this device (i.e. it stops responding to USB messages and needs to be unplugged and reinserted). Testing a corrupted key handle also crashes it and thus I wasn't able to run many tests.</p>\n\n<p><b>KEY-ID / HyperFIDO</b></p>\n\n<p>The Key-ID (and HyperFIDO devices, which have the same firmware, I think) have the same non-minimal encoding issue as the Feitian ePass, but also have a second ASN.1 flaw. In ASN.1 DER, if the most-significant bit of a number is set, that number is negative. If it's not supposed to be negative, then a zero pad byte is needed. I think what happened here is that, when testing the most-significant bit, the security key checks whether the first byte is &gt; 0x80, but it should be checking whether it's &gt;= 0x80. The upshot is the sometimes it produces signatures that contain negative numbers and are thus invalid.</p>\n\n<p>USB padding bytes aren't zeroed, and include data that was not part of the request or response. It's unlikely to be material, but it does beg the question of where it comes from.</p>\n\n<p>The wrapped keys also have some unfortunate properties. Firstly, bytes 16 through 31 are a function of the device and the appID, thus a given site can passively identify the same token when used by different accounts. Bytes 48 through 79 are unauthenticated and, when altered, everything still works except the signatures are wrong. That suggests that these bytes are the encrypted private key (or the encrypted seed to generate it). It's not obvious that there's any vulnerability from being able to tweak the private key like this, but all bytes of the key handle should be authenticated as a matter of best practice. Lastly, bytes 32 through 47 can't be arbitrarily manipulated, but can be substituted with the same bytes from a different key handle, which causes the signatures to be incorrect. I don't know what's going on there.</p>\n\n<p>Overall, the key handle structure is sufficiently far from the obvious construction to cause worry, but not an obvious vulnerability.</p>\n\n    </div>\n  </div></body></html>"}, "15430427": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:39:34", "url": "https://changelog.com/podcast/264", "text": "<html><body/></html>"}, "15430347": {"score": 2, "15430349": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:23:52", "url": "http://volumeintegration.com/computational-propaganda/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry-content\" itemprop=\"text\"><div class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/posts/scanograph-14383818\"><img src=\"https://i.imgur.com/WaYgvce.jpg\" alt=\"future fear art by BardIonson.com\"/></a><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Future Fear \u2013 BardIonson.com</p></div>\n<p><strong>Countering Computational Propaganda</strong></p>\n<p>There is something new happening in computer science and social media. It is computational propaganda. Computational propaganda is the use of computer information systems for political purposes according to the journal <a href=\"http://comprop.oii.ox.ac.uk/2017/01/17/call-for-papers-special-issue-on-computational-propaganda-and-political-big-data/\">Big Data</a>. This would also include the efforts of governments to influence public opinion of another country in order to change the foreign relations and policy of that country or to cause dissent of citizens against their government.</p>\n<h2 id=\"countering-propaganda\">Countering Propaganda</h2>\n<p>The first step and most important to take is to realize that propaganda is real. And then to admit that propaganda does impact the thought process of citizens. So I will start with the first step of describing computational propaganda and then ways to computationally identify it.</p>\n<h2 id=\"elements-of-computational-propaganda\">Elements of Computational Propaganda</h2>\n<p>There are various elements to computational propaganda that I will attempt to outline. Some of the elements include: algorithms, automation, human curation <a href=\"http://comprop.oii.ox.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/sites/89/2017/06/Casestudies-ExecutiveSummary.pdf\">source</a>, artificial intelligence, social media bots, sock puppets, troll farms, cyber attacks and stolen information, disinformation and data science.</p>\n<p>This new generation of propaganda has gone through a process of computerized automation. It is not totally automated but computers, networks and the internet have made it possible to deliver it in an automated manner. It is also enabling the delivery in a personal manner, in a way that makes it seem to be coming from a real human. Technology is also making strides in the automatic production of propaganda.</p>\n<p>Previously propaganda was slower moving and required getting news and editorials published. One used to have to own or control media outlets and then put people in place to spread disinformation. Our new modern way of spreading information online with social media has lowered the cost of spreading propaganda.</p>\n<h2 id=\"what-is-propaganda?\">What is propaganda?</h2>\n<p>Propaganda is not just pure lies and conspiracy theories. It has come a long way from the Nazi and the communist USSR mode of operation that might obvious to us now. Current propaganda is infused with truth although it is also either partly true or out of context in hidden ways to individual audiences. This information can now be tailored and targeted at individuals. Often this information is geared to lead people to action as all good propaganda should.</p>\n<p>Jacques Ellul in <em>Propaganda The formation of Men\u2019s Attitudes</em> says that it is difficult to determine what propaganda is because it is a \u201csecret action\u201d. Ellul finds it impossible to pin down an exact definition of propaganda that did not take up an entire book. Our society has propaganda baked in that we are not aware of. In short, propaganda for Ellul covered the following areas:</p>\n<ul id=\"draft_check_box_list_0\">\n<li>Psychological Action \u2013 seeks to modify opinions by pure psychological methods</li>\n<li>Psychological Warfare \u2013 destroy the morale of an adversary so that the opponent begins to doubt the validity of his beliefs and actions</li>\n<li>Brainwashing \u2013 only used on prisoners to turn enemies to allies</li>\n<li>Public and Human Relations \u2013 These group activities are also propaganda as they seek to adapt a person to a society. As we will see foreign governments use this technique in social media today.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Ellul says: \u201cmodern propaganda is based on scientific analysis of psychology and sociology\u2026 the propagandist builds his techniques on the basis of his knowledge of man\u201d Then the effects of the propaganda are measured for results and refined.</p>\n<p>These thoughts written in 1956 have only continued to be refined. They are now at work on the internet and in social media. And now there is a faster way to measure the results with computers and tracking of online activity.</p>\n<p>In reality, there are competing propaganda efforts happening online. There is a democratic propaganda that competes with anti-democratic strains and militant islamic ones also.</p>\n<h2 id=\"computational-propaganda-in-action\">Computational Propaganda in Action</h2>\n<p>But to take a step back I want to outline what this looks like online at the moment as I understand it.</p>\n<h3 id=\"2016\">2016</h3>\n<p>Computational propaganda burst onto the awareness of the public during the 2016 US presidential election and continues today. This effort by Russian actors over many years and I will outline some of the features that are computational in nature. The entire propaganda system is co-dependant but attempts to hide as disconnected entities.</p>\n<p>Recently it has been reported that Russian based accounts on Facebook and Twitter have been spreading propaganda to divide the American public. They used <a href=\"http://money.cnn.com/2017/09/27/media/facebook-black-lives-matter-targeting/index.html\">Facebook</a> to support both sides of the Black Lives Matter protests, promote gun rights and anti-immigration. This has also been observed on <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/sep/27/trump-russia-investigation-reddit\">Reddit</a> and <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/technology/twitter-russia-election.html\">Twitter</a>. Some accounts were bots or semi-automated bots and other accounts were used to purchase targeted advertisements.</p>\n<h3 id=\"cyber-war\">Cyber War</h3>\n<p>One element was stealing information through cyber attacks and social engineering. This exhibited itself in the taking of information from the Democratic National Convention and utilizing classified leaks given to WikiLeaks.</p>\n<p>Personal information on American citizens by foreign intelligence services has been stolen. Security questionnaires were taken by Chinese services. And recently credit information was appropriated in addition to voter rolls from an unknown number of states during the elections. This personal information is <a href=\"http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-jared-kushner-russia-hacking-20170712-story.html\">alleged</a> to have enabled the more precise targeting of propaganda to specific populations.</p>\n<h3 id=\"propganda-generation\">Propaganda Generation</h3>\n<p>Then this information was selectively transformed into propaganda by taking it out of context and targeting it at select audiences. I can assume that producers of the propaganda used computer software to search the massive amounts of information that was stolen. Then they edited the most damaging of the information to refine it for maximum effect on specific audiences.</p>\n<h3 id=\"targeting-propaganda\">Targeting Propaganda</h3>\n<p>This was also the case for the efforts of the Trump campaign where they took comments damaging to an opponent and targeted voter suppression ads at specific <a href=\"https://medium.com/startup-grind/how-the-trump-campaign-built-an-identity-database-and-used-facebook-ads-to-win-the-election-4ff7d24269ac\">people</a>. Social media ad networks and databases were used in these efforts. These systems allow anyone to target a message at thousands of different personal identifiers, location and income brackets. This can be done on Facebook and Twitter.</p>\n<div class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/posts/efficiency-you-14407157\"><img src=\"https://c10.patreonusercontent.com/3/eyJwIjoxfQ%3D%3D/patreon-media/post/14407157/6d777fb07d394c018ca37d0684d71370?token-time=1507766400&amp;token-hash=JZUHdeDdSKpRORcXCW0kPlVt5Dfrk8RD2SPloPq1w_o%3D\" alt=\"Targeting Ad on Facebook\"/></a><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Targeting Ad on Facebook</p></div>\n<p>The advertisement above is being targeted at people in NY City who engage with liberal political content and have a net worth between 1 million and 2 million.</p>\n<h3 id=\"personal-propaganda\">Personal Propaganda</h3>\n<p>In addition there are stores of personal data that was correlated with computational algorithms to determine specific personality traits of individuals. Using this information messaging was crafted and target it at psychological vulnerabilities of individuals to change their thinking or push them to action. <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/mg9vvn/how-our-likes-helped-trump-win\">source</a></p>\n<h3 id=\"the-troll-factory\">The Troll Factory</h3>\n<p>On top of this paid targeting there are places called troll factories where armies of people engage in social interactions on social media and blogs. There is one of these in St. Petersburg called <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/07/magazine/the-agency.html\">The Factory</a>. People will engage with online content to discredit it with propaganda techniques such as \u201cwhataboutism\u201d. This is where people contest valid facts by pointing out a perceived hypocrisy on the other side of the issue. They will also attempt to generate fake news to cause panic in a particular community.</p>\n<h3 id=\"bots-and-sock-puppets\">Bots and Sock Puppets</h3>\n<p>These efforts combine with a computational technique of online bots, trolls and sock puppets. Sock puppets are online fake personas. They appear to be real people online often appearing as Americans but they just broadcast propaganda.</p>\n<p>Bots are pieces of software that perform online tasks. They may just pickup other people\u2019s messages on line and rebroadcast them. Other bots are more human like and engage in conversations. They often search for keywords in conversations and generate a \u201cwhatboutism\u201d or some disparaging message to confuse readers. There are other bots that are semi-automated. Once these are challenged as being bots or have a question they cannot respond to, a human will intervene and manually provide responses.</p>\n<h3 id=\"bot-networks\">Bot networks</h3>\n<p>These bots and sock puppet accounts often work as a team. They will gang up on conversations and re-broadcast each others messages. The goal is to make their message seem mainstream by its volume or popularity. They can confuse rational conversations and arguments online by misdirecting them and triggering emotional responses.</p>\n<h3 id=\"suppression-of-speech-bots\">Suppression of Speech Bots</h3>\n<p>Recently bots have been suppressing messaging from people who are attempting to get out messages to counter disinformation. In the case of <a href=\"https://krebsonsecurity.com/2017/08/twitter-bots-use-likes-rts-for-intimidation/\">Brian Krebs</a> who was attacking the messaging of bots that support Putin they tricked Twitter into disabling Brians account. They did this by causing thousands of accounts to follow him and then retweet his tweets in mass. This effort caused Twitter to automatically assume that Brian was paying bots to promote his account. So they turned it off.</p>\n<h3 id=\"artifical-intelligence\">Artificial Intelligence</h3>\n<p>Artificial intelligence and machine learning are additional computation techniques being weaponized in this information battle. Not only is AI used to automate bots to appear human but it also can to create messaging content. Artificial intelligence processes source documents or training data. Then programmers configure the system to output new messages. It multiplies the efforts of a human to generate new content. This output is then curated or even tested out online. This validates the effectiveness of the content. This feedback loop is used to create more effective triggers for people.</p>\n<h3 id=\"attacking-the-disenfranchised\">Attacking the Disenfranchised</h3>\n<p>Often these efforts to trigger action leverage marginalized groups in society. The bots and troll factories can take domestic content and amplify it for their own purposes. It has been shown that Russian based bots often rebroadcast messages that attempt to increase divisions in US citizens. <a href=\"http://dashboard.securingdemocracy.org/\">Hamilton68</a> illustrates these efforts.</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://i.imgur.com/UCKWHa1.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2017-09-16 at 10.43.50 AM.png\"/><br/>\nThis is a dashboard that tracks known Russian bots and exposes what they are promoting. Often this is anything that breeds mistrust in the US government and pits groups against each other.</p>\n<p>Some countries also invest in traditional media like newspapers,radio and television stations to broadcast messages. They attempt to make this look like real news but it is actually disinformation and propaganda. This \u201cnews\u201d is picked up as legitimate by other news outlets and rebroadcast. People who buy into the messaging with use the source as proof of their opinions.</p>\n<h3 id=\"conspiracy-theories\">Conspiracy Theories</h3>\n<p>Propagandists often use current running conspiracy theories to oppose competing messages or true news. They neutralize the opposition by coming up with a secret conspiracy or amplifying one in circulation.</p>\n<h3 id=\"live-events\">Live events</h3>\n<p>Recently <a href=\"http://www.thedailybeast.com/exclusive-russia-used-facebook-events-to-organize-anti-immigrant-rallies-on-us-soil\">The DailyBeast</a> reported that Russian operatives organized and promoted rallies on Facebook. This illustrates the purpose of propaganda which is to move people to action. Once they are acting on the beliefs pushed by the propaganda it can tip into political action.</p>\n<h2 id=\"politics\">Politics</h2>\n<p>At the moment in the US propaganda from Russia seems aimed at changing the foreign policy of the US government. The Russians have secured the information space of their citizens in an authoritarian way that is not acceptable in American society. And they have leveraged the lack of privacy controls in the American capitalist system, where information about people is sold for marketing purposes. It seems that Russian propaganda efforts are only aimed at the destruction of democracy or western values according to <a href=\"http://www.theage.com.au/world/as-facebook-disclosure-shows-russian-influence-campaigns-seek-to-divide-cripple-democracy-20170907-gycgdt.html\">Chris Zappone of The Age</a></p>\n<h1 id=\"computational-countermeasures\">Computational Countermeasures</h1>\n<p>There are hundreds of ideas on how to counter this online propaganda. Some are government policies, industry self policing and educational programs. But I want to focus on countermeasures that are computational. In effect an attempt to fight fire with fire.</p>\n<h2 id=\"innoculation\">Inoculation</h2>\n<p>One way to minimize the impact of propaganda is to have tools that alert an individual of the event. Another type of computational tool is one that allows a community to monitor what others in their community are being targeted with. This can prevent individual weaknesses from being exploited. There are efforts underway in this space but there are opportunities for continual improvement.</p>\n<h3 id=\"current-concepts\">Current concepts</h3>\n\n<h3 id=\"ideas-from-volume\">Ideas from Volume</h3>\n<ul id=\"draft_check_box_list_2\">\n<li>A dark advertisement exposure network. Volunteers install browser agents to gather ads and put them in a public searchable database with the targeting criteria. Could also use fake personas to collect advertisements.</li>\n<li>Public searchable databases of bots and sock puppets identified by computational techniques, such as time of day analysis, linguistic patterns and rebroadcasting behaviours.</li>\n<li>The bot collection database would also hold the relationships between accounts, messages and motives.</li>\n<li>Computational methods software package to identify bots that pretend to be human and out them as bots on the social media</li>\n<li>Browser plug-in that will show a user the motives of a bot and expose a network of bots that link or help each other. It enables a person to ignore and discount ideas coming from that entity.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>In a <a href=\"https://blog.twitter.com/official/en_us/topics/company/2017/Our-Approach-Bots-Misinformation.html\">blog post</a> Colin Crowell, Twitter\u2019s vice president of public policy, government and philanthropy, said in a blog post that Twitter itself is a \u201cpowerful antidote to the spreading of all types of false information\u201d and \u201cjournalists, experts and engaged citizens Tweet side-by-side correcting and challenging public discourse in seconds.\u201d</p>\n<p>The issue with this is that the bots are programmatically generating information using artificial intelligence or have armies of cheap labor. How can citizens and journalists keep up with researching and debunking half truths, obvious lies and nonsense?</p>\n<p>Perhaps we need to build counter bot networks. Of course, ones that fit into the social media companies terms of service.</p>\n<h2 id=\"bot-combat\">Bot Combat</h2>\n<h4>(more ideas from Volume Integration)</h4>\n<ul id=\"draft_check_box_list_3\">\n<li>Bots that disrupt bot networks by sending trigger words to them and keep them busy and away from meaningful conversations.</li>\n<li>Bots that look for disinformation and hoaxes and broadcast information to debunk it</li>\n<li>Artificial intelligence social bots that can automatically research messaging from propaganda bots and counter the messaging</li>\n<li>Crafting fact checking messaging to target back at organizations running troll factories and bot networks</li>\n<li>A force of vetted volunteers that could perform analysis tasks to find bots and propagandists and then write counter arguments to them</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"analysis\">Analysis</h2>\n<p>Of course this rests on the concept of analysis so we would need tools to visualize the data and perform the human effort needed to find relationships and motives of the actors. Some of this effort would be utilizing the many algorithms already designed to detect bots and online propaganda. In addition Volume Integration has a tool that can help monitor and alert on social media account activity and messaging. See our <a href=\"https://volumeintegration.com/products/\">products</a>.</p>\n<p>At the end of the post is a list of papers on methods and analysis techniques to find automated bots online.</p>\n<h2 id=\"prevention-(cybersecurity)\">Prevention (CyberSecurity)</h2>\n<p>One factor in recent propaganda has been the ability for bad actors to obtain classified or private information. In this case we need better cyber security is needed. Sometimes the information is gathered via social engineering. Outside actors manipulate a person inside an organization into providing the information or access to the computer systems.</p>\n<h3 id=\"ideas-from-volume\">Ideas from Volume</h3>\n<ul id=\"draft_check_box_list_4\">\n<li>Separate internal corporate networks from the internet</li>\n<li>Increase Cybersecurity methods and policies (patching schedules, inventory control, multiple factor authentication, firewalls, packet inspection, audits)</li>\n<li>Trust / Risk Verification Systems like <a href=\"https://volumeintegration.com/products/\">Volume Analytics</a> which monitor events on a computer network to alert on unauthorized or risky behaviour.</li>\n</ul>\n<h1 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion</h1>\n<p>I am afraid that there is no real collusion. We are at the beginning of our abilities to counter computational propaganda. It is going to be an arms race as tactics and systems change. Technology and technique will breed more technology and technique. I hope we are able to separate out the false information and come a bit closer to truth. In the end, it will be the next phase of human conflict and manipulation to gain power and wealth over personal freedom.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://volumeintegration.com/contact/\">Contact</a> us if you want to know more about our work or follow us on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/volumeint\">Twitter</a>, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/4974487/\">LinkedIn</a> or <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/VolumeIntegration/\">Facebook</a>.</p>\n<h3 id=\"current-studies-on-automating-analysis\">Current Studies on Automating Analysis</h3>\n\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15430350": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:23:58", "url": "http://click.pocoo.org/5/", "text": "<html><body><div><p>Click is a Python package for creating beautiful command line interfaces\nin a composable way with as little code as necessary. "<html><body><div><div class=\"modal-content\">\n\n          <div class=\"card p-50 mb-0\">\n            <h3 class=\"text-center\">Thanks!</h3>\n            <hr/>\n            <p>\n This is to give an idea of what to expect in terms\nof cost and profit from a \u00e2\u0080\u009cDIY-to-market\u00e2\u0080\u009d kind of project like this.</p>\n\n<p>For those unfamiliar, <a href=\"https://github.com/conorpp/u2f-zero\">U2F Zero</a> is an\nopen-source secure USB device used for two factor authentication.  I made it\nback in 2016 and did a <a href=\"https://conorpp.com/designing-and-producing-2fa-tokens-to-sell-on-amazon\">semi-large PCB-A run and sold them on\nAmazon</a>.</p>\n\n<p>At the time, I didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t really know what to expect.  Were people actually going\nto buy these?  Was I going to get bad reviews?  Was someone going to find some\nsecurity bug in the implementation (open-source)?  Is the profit worth the effort?\nNow I can answer all of these questions.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"starting-out\">Starting out</h1>\n\n<p>I started on U2F Zero because I wanted to work on something interesting and\nlearn how to make a PCB.  Here was my first one.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/pcbs/r1-front-dirty.jpg.small.jpg\" alt=\"first PCB\"/></p>\n\n<p>It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s poorly laid out.  The traces don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t give a crap about EMF.  And what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a\nground plane?</p>\n\n<p>Eventually, I got better at it.  The project even got an awesome <a href=\"https://github.com/conorpp/u2f-zero/pull/37\">pull\nrequest</a> from <a href=\"https://github.com/cpavlina\">Chris\nPavlina</a>, who is better at layout than I am.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"business-plan\">Business plan</h1>\n\n<p>Eventually, I got the U2F Zero \u00e2\u0080\u009cminimum viable product,\u00e2\u0080\u009d and it was ready to\nhit the market.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/proshot.jpg\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>I basically guessed that the market would sustain 1000/units per year.  So I\nput in an order of 1100 units to a Chinese PCBA fab\n(<a href=\"https://www.pcbcart.com/\">PCBCart</a>) totaling about $4,000.  The cost is made up of the PCB (~$0.22/unit), the assembly (~$0.44/unit) and the components\n(~$2.26/unit).  All the costs scale with quantity.  Had I ordered 3000 units, I\nwould have saved about $0.35 for each U2F Zero.  But the last thing you want is\n2000 U2F Zeros that no one is buying sitting in a warehouse somewhere\ncollecting Amazon storage fees.</p>\n\n<p>I didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t want to deal with sales and distribution.  I was in the middle of grad\nschool and didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have the time or the interest.  So after manufacturing the\ntokens, I shipped them to Amazon to be fulfilled.  This\ndoes come with a cost, of about $1.02-$2.02 in fees per U2F Token sold by Amazon.</p>\n\n<p>After manufacturing and distribution was handled, it was time to execute my\nelaborate market entry plan: write a blog post and post it to Hacker News and\nTwitter.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"sales\">Sales</h1>\n\n<p>I spent almost a whole weekend drafting my <a href=\"https://conorpp.com/designing-and-producing-2fa-tokens-to-sell-on-amazon\">U2F Zero\npost</a>.\nI posted it\u00e2\u0080\u00a6 and it worked.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/2016_sales.png\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>For the first month, the time between the Amazon shipment and the blog post, there\nwere almost no sales.  Then after the post, there was a spike of <em>207 sales</em>\nover the following week.  Then it balanced out to about 6-7 units per day.  And\n4 months later, they sold out.</p>\n\n<p>There was even an increase in sales around Christmas time.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/reviews.png\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>And people left mostly good reviews.  I wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t sure if people\nwould leave good reviews since it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s just a cheap token with no case.  But it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s\nvery clear from the listing what it is.  So most people will know what\nthey are purchasing \u00e2\u0080\u0093 and as long as it does a good job fulfilling that image\n\u00e2\u0080\u0093 it has the potential for good reviews.  I think that was an important\ntakeaway.</p>\n\n<p>I did get some negative feedback.  Some customers didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t like that Firefox didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t support\nU2F at the time or that the token didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t come with instructions.</p>\n\n<p>There was one <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R2T5OCAPAFMO2/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_viewpnt\">technical review that tore U2F Zero to\npieces</a>.\nAmongst the issues the reviewer found, there was privacy issue in my\nimplementation.  Not a critical security flaw, but something that would allow\neach U2F Zero to be uniquely identified when it is used.  It was my mistake and\nthere was roughly 1000 units out there with it.  I ended up fixing it and am\noffering replacements for those that purchased an old token.</p>\n\n<p>The reviewer kindly took to opening issues on Github and even updated his\nreview after the firmware issues were fixed.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"profits\">Profits</h1>\n\n<p>As mentioned previously, each token cost about $3.00 to make.  But when\naccounting for the cost of prototyping, packaging, labeling, import taxes,\ntools, and holding 100 units in stock, the unit cost is really about $4.18.\nThere was about $2.02 in fees from Amazon.  The listing price was $8.00.  So\nthat works out to be roughly $2k in profit over 4 months which is about a 42%\nROI.  Not a drop-out-of school kind of haul by any means, but it was a great\nexperience for me and I hope to make similar ventures in the future.</p>\n\n<p>For those interested, I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll list the various costs here.</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>PCBs: $351.10</li>\n  <li>Assembly + components: $3,062.85</li>\n  <li>Shipping: $59.72</li>\n  <li>Tariffs (from China to U.S.): $126.32</li>\n  <li>Labels: $13.98</li>\n  <li>Polybags: $63.25</li>\n  <li>Tools: $164.94</li>\n  <li>Prototyping: ~$350.00</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h1 id=\"other-opportunities-and-events\">Other opportunities and events</h1>\n\n<p>There were some cool unexpected things that happened as a result of U2F Zero.\nA lot of awesome people reached out or shared how they made their own U2F Zero(s) or\npurchased them on Amazon.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/twitter.png\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>One of which was <a href=\"https://twitter.com/land0ngreer\">Landon\nGreer</a>, who helped organize an infosec conference\nand made custom U2F Zeros as a conference badge.\nLater, the <a href=\"https://cryptovillage.org/\">Crypto &amp; Privacy Village</a> at Defcon\nforked the U2F Zero design and included it in their unofficial 2016 defcon\nbadge.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/acpe.jpg\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>More recently, the Association for Computers Professionals in Education (ACPE)\nmade a custom order for 400 units and invited me to come spend some time in\nOregon and speak at their conference.  I really enjoyed it.  It was great to\nlearn about a different field and meet new people.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"u2f-zero-round-2\">U2F Zero, round 2</h1>\n\n<p>A few months after selling out, I decided to do another run.  This time I added\nsome improvements to the PCB layout and fix issues in the firmware.  I also\ndecided to order 3000 this time (saved that $0.35 per unit) and support markets\nin <a href=\"https://www.amazon.ca/U2F-Zero/dp/B01L9DUPK6\">Canada</a>, <a href=\"https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B01L9DUPK6\">U.K.</a>, and <a href=\"https://u2fzero.ch/products/u2f-zero-1/\">Europe</a>.  I think the U2F standard is\npicking up in popularity so the U2F demand shouldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t go away.  I\u00e2\u0080\u0099m curious to\nsee how U2F Zero sales differ between different countries.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/box.jpg\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<p>At the time of this writing, I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve sent 1500 units to the <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/U2F-Zero/dp/B01L9DUPK6\">U.S.\nmarketplace</a>, 300 to\n<a href=\"https://www.amazon.ca/U2F-Zero/dp/B01L9DUPK6\">Canada</a>, 300 to the\n<a href=\"https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B01L9DUPK6\">U.K.</a>, and 100 to a <a href=\"https://u2fzero.ch/products/u2f-zero-1/\">distributor in\nSwitzerland</a> that will handle shipments to other countries in Europe.  I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve kept\nthe rest in storage so I can replenish a marketplace easily if inventory gets\nlow.</p>\n\n<p>U2F Zero has been back on the U.S. market for about 4 months now, after being\nout of stock for about 6 months.  Sales slowly picked back up and average\nabout 5 units per day currently.</p>\n\n<p>My goal is to keep the supply up with minimal effort and not have anymore\ngaping out-of-stock periods.  In the meantime, I can work on the next project.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"thanks\">Thanks!</h1>\n\n<p>Thank you to everyone that has taken an interest in U2F Zero and to those that\nhave contributed to the open source project so far:</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Thank you to everyone that supported U2F Zero and made this possible.  I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve\nlearned a lot since first making this crappy first prototype and will have more\nprojects to launch later.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"/assets/images/u2f-zero-2/early_proto.jpg\" alt=\"\"/></p>\n\n<h4>\nHave any questions or comments?  <a href=\"/contact\" target=\"_blank\">Contact me</a> or comment below!\n</h4>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/_conorpp\" class=\"twitter-follow-button\" data-show-count=\"false\">Follow @_conorpp</a>\n<a href=\"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?screen_name=_conorpp\" class=\"twitter-mention-button\" data-show-count=\"false\">Tweet to @_conorpp</a></p>\n\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429329": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:33:09", "url": "https://icowatchlist.com/blog/icos-profitable-investments-future-mark-cuban/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry-content clearfix\">\n\t\t<p><a href=\"https://icowatchlist.com/blog/mark-cuban-backs-20m-cryptocurrency-start/\">Mark Cuban</a> has said that he sees Bitcoin and its underlying Blockchain or Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) as the way into the future.</p>\n<p>The American tech billionaire and investor countered claims by certain quarters that digital currencies are not real. Now female founder-CEOs of tech companies, like <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/magazine/201710/maria-aspan/blackline-therese-tucker.html\">BlackLine's Therese Tucker</a>, are outliers.</p>&#13;\n<h2><b>1941-45</b></h2>&#13;\n<div class=\"inlineimage inlineimage-48016 inlineobject inc_editable inline-fullwidth\" data-editor-class=\"InlineImageEditor\" data-label=\"Inline Image\" data-content-type=\"inlineimage\" data-content-id=\"48016\" data-parent-class=\"bodycopy\" data-parent-content-type=\"article\" data-parent-content-id=\"185571\"><img src=\"https://www.incimages.com/uploaded_files/inlineimage/630x0/IN1017IFW03_inline_48016.jpg\"/><p class=\"inlinecredit\">CREDIT: Getty Images</p><p class=\"clearme\"/></div>&#13;\n<p>The first digital computers are built for wartime purposes, including <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.columbia.edu/cu/computinghistory/eniac.html\">Eniac</a> (pictured), the first fully electronic American computer, which in 1946 is originally programmed by six women recruited by the Army. Others include Great Britain's Colossus machines at Bletchley Park--which are operated by women in the British Navy, also known as Wrens.</p>&#13;\n<h2>1942</h2>&#13;\n<div class=\"inlineimage inlineimage-48021 inlineobject inc_editable inline-list\" data-editor-class=\"InlineImageEditor\" data-label=\"Inline Image\" data-content-type=\"inlineimage\" data-content-id=\"48021\" data-parent-class=\"bodycopy\" data-parent-content-type=\"article\" data-parent-content-id=\"185571\"><img src=\"https://www.incimages.com/uploaded_files/inlineimage/130x0/IN1017IFW07_inline_48021.jpg\"/><p class=\"inlinecredit\">CREDIT: Getty Images</p><p class=\"clearme\"/></div>&#13;\n<p>Movie star Hedy Lamarr, a design-obsessed <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.npr.org/2011/11/27/142664182/most-beautiful-woman-by-day-inventor-by-night\">inventor</a> in her spare time, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.google.com/patents/US2292387\">patents</a> a tech\u00adnology that is later used to make U.S. missiles undetectable during the Cold War--and for the spread-spectrum communication technology that makes modern Wi-Fi and cell phones work.</p>&#13;\n<h2>1945</h2>&#13;\n<p>After World War II, as the commercial demand for computers and their programmers ramps up, employment opportunities for women increase. \"There was no preexisting male work force to push them out,\" Janet Abbate <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/recoding-gender\">writes</a> in <em>Recoding Gender: Women's Changing Participation in Computing</em>. \"Most of the sciences were closed to them,\" Abbate tells <em>Inc</em>., \"but computing seemed wide open.\"</p>&#13;\n<h2>1949</h2>&#13;\n<div class=\"inlineimage inlineimage-48026 inlineobject inc_editable inline-list\" data-editor-class=\"InlineImageEditor\" data-label=\"Inline Image\" data-content-type=\"inlineimage\" data-content-id=\"48026\" data-parent-class=\"bodycopy\" data-parent-content-type=\"article\" data-parent-content-id=\"185571\"><img src=\"https://www.incimages.com/uploaded_files/inlineimage/130x0/IN1017IFW05_inline_48026.jpg\"/><p class=\"inlinecredit\">CREDIT: Getty Images</p><p class=\"clearme\"/></div>&#13;\n<p>The creators of the Eniac, who had started the civilian computing company that developed the Univac machine, hire <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"http://www.public.navy.mil/surfor/ddg70/Pages/namesake.aspx#.WcAnjUqGPyE\">Grace Hopper</a> (pictured left) as senior mathematician. She starts developing the first computer languages, including the Cobol programming language.</p>&#13;\n<h2>1956</h2>&#13;\n<p>Companies increasingly \"employ only women\" or \"a high percentage of women\" in their computing groups, according to the U.S. Department of Labor. This is the result of corporate America's needing people to write the code and move the cards in big punch-card-operated machines, so it hires women with and without college degrees who can pick up the job quickly.</p>&#13;\n<h2>1967</h2>&#13;\n<div class=\"inlineimage inlineimage-48031 inlineobject inc_editable inline-fullwidth\" data-editor-class=\"InlineImageEditor\" data-label=\"Inline Image\" data-content-type=\"inlineimage\" data-content-id=\"48031\" data-parent-class=\"bodycopy\" data-parent-content-type=\"article\" data-parent-content-id=\"185571\"><img src=\"https://www.incimages.com/uploaded_files/inlineimage/630x0/IN1017IFW02_inline_48031.jpg\"/><p class=\"inlinecredit\">CREDIT: Courtesy Company</p><p class=\"clearme\"/></div>&#13;\n<p>\"This is the age of the Computer Girls,\" <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://boingboing.net/2015/07/31/the-computer-girls-1967-c.html\">declares</a> <em>Cosmopolitan</em> magazine. Once considered unglamorous clerical work, computer programming soon becomes coveted, highly skilled labor.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<p>As tech becomes a major industry and the number of people studying computer science increases, the gulf between men and women <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d16/tables/dt16_325.35.asp?current=yes\">receiving degrees</a> widens.</p></div>\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429335": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:33:53", "url": "https://www.sfsite.com/vault/john38.htm", "text": "<html><body><div><font size=\"2\">&#13;\n<p>&#13;\n<i>Click on any of the covers below for a larger image</i>.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n&#13;\n<i><b>Perry Rhodan</b></i> practically introduced me to science fiction.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\nI suppose he doesn't shoulder the entire blame.  Like most other kids my age, I was taking my first&#13;\ncautious steps out of the realm of comics and young adult literature into the world of large words&#13;\nand small print.  My guide and mentor was my friend John MacMaster, fellow inmate at St. Francis Xavier&#13;\nJunior High in Halifax, Nova Scotia.  It was the Fall of 1975, and I was eleven years old.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p><table align=\"left\" border=\"0\">&#13;\n<tr><td>&#13;\n<a href=\"../gif/9807/pr14-2.jpg\"><img src=\"../gif/9807/pr14.jpg\" hspace=\"8\" border=\"0\"/></a>&#13;\n<br clear=\"all\"/>&#13;\n<center><font size=\"1\"><i>Art by Gray Morrow</i></font></center>&#13;\n</td></tr>&#13;\n</table>&#13;\nJohn was into some pretty weird stuff in 1975.  For one thing, there was this book he kept waving at me&#13;\ncalled <b>Dune</b>.  The cover had a bunch of <i>Lawrence of Arabia</i> types standing around on rocks and&#13;\nsand, looking boring.  I passed.  John also bought his very own albums, which I thought was pretty funky,&#13;\nand he sat me down to listen to a composition titled \"Welcome to the Machine\" by an outfit called <i>Pink Floyd</i>.&#13;\nIt was... okay.  Although why they couldn't afford to record in a studio without all that talking and banging&#13;\ncoming through the walls was beyond me.&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nJohn also gave me short stories to read by some guy named <i>Harlan Ellison</i> -- who used bad words.&#13;\nHe dragged me outdoors in the middle of a Nova Scotia winter to look at stars in his telescope.  And&#13;\non Halloween he pulled me six blocks to an apartment building he knew where the superintendent dumped all his&#13;\ngoods in the first half hour... only to end up with two bags full of apples.  All in all,&#13;\nJohn was a swell guy, but it was obvious the stuff he was into was far too bent to ever catch on.&#13;\n&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\nBut I hit paydirt when he loaned me a tattered copy of <b><i>Perry Rhodan #17</i>: The Venus Trap</b>.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n<b>The Venus Trap</b>, by <i>Kurt Mahr</i> (Ace, 1972), didn't have a lot of boring gentlemen on the cover.&#13;\nIt had dinosaurs.  And spacesuits.  And a guy with a raygun.  Now this was more like it.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p>&#13;\nAlthough I didn't know it at the time, <b>The Venus Trap</b> borrowed fairly liberally from some of the&#13;\ntruly canonical works of SF -- including <i>Otis Adelbert Kline</i>'s <b><i>Grandson of Terra</i></b> series,&#13;\n<i>Ralph Milne Farley</i>'s tales of <i><b>Spaceman Miles Cabot</b></i>, and of course the Venus series&#13;\nof <i>Edgar Rice Burroughs</i> (also his <b><i>Mars</i></b> series, and a handful of his <b><i>Tarzan</i></b> books, but it was doubtless&#13;\na package deal).  But everything it borrowed, it returned in spades.&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nYou see, by 1975 science fiction that predicted life on Venus -- especially big-lizards-with-pointy-fangs life,&#13;\nor toothy vegetation that mimicked the steamy jungles of the Amazon -- had gone the way of the dinosaurs itself.&#13;\nBy the late 50s, the surface of Venus was known to be an atmospheric boiler room, an environment where even&#13;\nhardened space probes got all sweaty and quickly packed it in.  And when that long-held romantic notion of old&#13;\nschool SF passed away, the pulp adventure tale succumbed soon after.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\nIn 1961, the German language version of <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b> almost single-handedly began to breathe&#13;\nnew life into the moribund pulp genre.  By the time the ever-energetic <i>Forrest J. Ackerman</i> and his editor&#13;\n<i>Frederik Pohl</i> introduced an English language version in North America eight years later, Rhodan had enjoyed&#13;\nover 400 installments and attained a weekly circulation of 130,000.  Literally hundreds of fan clubs existed,&#13;\nat least one feature film had been made, and total sales were approaching 70 million copies.  <b><i>Perry&#13;\nRhodan</i></b> was a phenomenon -- and in issue number 14, <b>Venus in Danger</b>, it brought its beloved companion,&#13;\nthe Venus romance, back from the cryogenic freeze as well.&#13;\n&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p><table align=\"right\" border=\"0\">&#13;\n<tr><td>&#13;\n<a href=\"../gif/9807/pr94-2.jpg\"><img src=\"../gif/9807/pr94.jpg\" hspace=\"8\" border=\"0\"/></a>&#13;\n<br clear=\"all\"/>&#13;\n<center><font size=\"1\"><i>Art by Gray Morrow</i></font></center>&#13;\n</td></tr>&#13;\n</table>&#13;\nIt did it with obvious sleight of hand -- by suggesting that the true surface of Earth's sister planet had been&#13;\ndeliberately screened from prying eyes with some kind of projector thingie, a galactic-budget special effect --&#13;\nbut it hardly mattered.  Fans of the SF pulp adventure genre saw the wink and the smiles behind the curtain,&#13;\nand knew that they were in the hands of a team of writers who knew and cherished the fond conventions of old,&#13;\nbut whose canvas and ambitions were far larger.  The Venus romance was by no means the last classic pulp trope&#13;\nresurrected as a stage property for the sprawling cast of <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b>, but it was certainly one of the first&#13;\nto signal to North American readers the ride they were in for.&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nNot that I picked up on any of this in 1975.  For me, it was merely a rip-roaring adventure tale, the first of its kind&#13;\nthat I'd ever encountered, and it grabbed me in a way that few books had before (or since).  I lost track of&#13;\nprecisely how many volumes of <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b> I collected and read, but I was a faithful fan for years.&#13;\n&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\nAnd no wonder.  Simply put, <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b> is one of the richest -- if not <i>the</i> richest -- Space&#13;\nOperas ever written.  Astronaut Perry Rhodan's discovery of a stranded Arkon spacecraft on the moon&#13;\ntriggered his first adventure in <b><i>Perry Rhodan #1</i>: Enterprise Stardust</b>, sending&#13;\nRhodan and his team on a journey around the galaxy, where they discovered ancient and terrifying&#13;\nalien technology, helped unify the Earth under one government, assembled a team of human mutants to do battle&#13;\nwith an unstoppable alien menace, and went toe-to-toe with a decadent race of great age and enormous power -- all&#13;\nin the first ten issues.  The influence of a tale of this pacing and scope on the field of science fiction was significant.&#13;\nEven today, few episodes of <b><i>Babylon 5</i></b> -- arguably the finest modern Space Opera, and certainly&#13;\nthe most prevalent example today -- do not contain an element or elements which hearken back to <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b>&#13;\n-- from the decadent fallen Centauri Empire (shades of the Arkons) to the proliferation of ancient and deadly&#13;\nspace relics, and of course the menace of the Shadows themselves (a strong premonition of which appeared in issue 118,&#13;\n<b>The Shadows Attack</b>).&#13;\n&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p><table align=\"left\" border=\"0\">&#13;\n<tr><td>&#13;\n<a href=\"../gif/9805/pr18002.jpg\"><img src=\"../gif/9805/pr1.jpg\" border=\"0\"/></a>&#13;\n<br clear=\"all\"/>&#13;\n<center><font size=\"1\"><i>Art by Alfred Kelsner</i></font></center>&#13;\n</td></tr>&#13;\n</table>&#13;\nOver the next hundred or so volumes, Rhodan and his band of brave adventurers expanded their power base and&#13;\ntook on greater and greater threats.  One unique and fascinating aspect of the <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b> brand&#13;\nof pulp action was that it was not merely of the two-fisted variety.  By about issue 16 or so, Rhodan and Company&#13;\n(like Sheridan and team) represented a world government, with the burdens and responsibilities therein.  To follow&#13;\nRhodan's story was to track the Future History of humanity, across decades and eventually across centuries, as mankind&#13;\npitted itself first against lurking alien dangers, then organized ones, and finally whole Empires and ancient Galactic&#13;\nFederations.  The stakes and&#13;\nscale of the tale built slowly, with plenty of setbacks and unexpected twists, as humanity gradually took its&#13;\nplace amongst the senior races in the stars.&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nUnfortunately, while the German language version continued to build up momentum in Europe, Forry Ackerman's&#13;\ngrand experiment with a monthly pulp paperback in North America ended in 1977, after some 120 issues.  Forry&#13;\ncontinued it on a subscription-only basis until issue 137 before throwing in the towel.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p><table align=\"right\" border=\"0\">&#13;\n<tr><td>&#13;\n<a href=\"../gif/9805/prherr2.jpg\"><img src=\"../gif/9805/pr2.jpg\" border=\"0\"/></a>&#13;\n<br clear=\"all\"/>&#13;\n<center><font size=\"1\"><i>Art by Alfred Kelsner</i></font></center>&#13;\n</td></tr>&#13;\n</table>&#13;\nAnd that, Rhodan fans assumed, was that.  Until the arrival of <i>Vector Enterprises</i> on the scene in September&#13;\nof last year -- and the first appearance of <b><i>Perry Rhodan</i></b> on this side of the Atlantic in almost twenty&#13;\nyears.  Under the leadership of Managing Editor <i>John Foyt</i> and talented translator <i>Dwight Decker</i>,&#13;\nVector Enterprises released <i><b>Perry Rhodan</b></i> as a new bimonthly magazine, starting with&#13;\n<b>1800: Time Lapse</b>, the first issue of a new storyline: <i><b>Bridge to Eternity</b></i>.  And at the&#13;\nalmost criminally bargain price of $1.95 an issue, it was a hard offer to refuse.&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nThe plot of the new issues was familiar in scope to everyone familiar with the 1970s Ace editions.  On the planet&#13;\nTrokan, known as the Second Mars, forced evolution under a Time Lapse field has created something unexpected...&#13;\nsomething that may throw humanity into crisis.  Members of Rhodan's band are called to investigate, and what they&#13;\ndiscover is far more than a temporal anomaly.  As an added bonus, the issue contained Part I of a detailed series&#13;\nsummary, filling in background info on the first 999 issues of the German edition.  Finally, the magazine offered&#13;\nan introduction by none other than <i>Forrest J. Ackerman</i> himself.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n</p><table align=\"left\" border=\"0\">&#13;\n<tr><td>&#13;\n<a href=\"../gif/9806/pr3.jpg\"><img src=\"../gif/9806/pr.jpg\" border=\"0\"/></a>&#13;\n<br clear=\"all\"/>&#13;\n<center><font size=\"1\"><i>Art by Alfred Kelsner</i></font></center>&#13;\n</td></tr>&#13;\n</table>&#13;\nFoyt and his team followed up the initial magazine release in short order with issues 1801, 1802, and 1803,&#13;\nsticking to a more-or-less bimonthly schedule that has demonstrated their commitment.  The issues&#13;\nare thoroughly professional, with quality translations and fine original art, and the series summation which&#13;\nwrapped up in issue 1802 was invaluable. (Now if only they'd bring back the shock-shorts&#13;\nand other short fiction that graced the back pages of the 1970s paperback series -- and first published such folks&#13;\nas <i>Steven Utley</i> -- we'd nominate them for sainthood.)&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nFurther details, and subscription info, is available online at Vector Enterprises' <a href=\"http://www.perry-rhodan-usa.com\">website</a>.&#13;\nFor a complete review of the first three issues, see <i>Mark Shainblum</i>'s article in&#13;\n<a href=\"rho38.htm\">this issue</a> of the SF Site.&#13;\nAnd then be prepared to locate the magazines, and enjoy serial novels which&#13;\noffer complex, involving stories with an old-style mix of character and action. You won't be disappointed.&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\n<i>P.S.</i>  And if anyone out there knows the whereabouts of a Mr. John MacMaster, once of Halifax, Nova Scotia,&#13;\nplease send him my way. Anyone is weclome to contribute to the project. </p><h2>Roadmap</h2><p> These things might happen if someone contributes to the project, but I don't have time to do them myself anymore.<br/><b>Still want me to work on them?</b> Give me more free time by financially supporting developent via <a href=\"http://www.patreon.com/cuchaz\"><img class=\"patreon\" src=\"/images/patreon-small.png\" alt=\"Patreon\"/></a>. </p><ul class=\"list\"><li>Fix bugs reported in Enigma and release v1.0</li><li>Add usability features to make deobfuscating easier</li></ul><h1>Enigma mappings for Minecraft</h1><p> Enigma is currently being used to deobfuscate the Minecraft <span class=\"code\">v1.8.3</span> client. </p><p> These mappings are being collected and managed using an Open Source philosophy on BitBucket. All of the mappings are freely available under a premissive <a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/\">Creative Commons license</a>. You can you use these mappings for any purpose without asking permission, but please abide by the terms of the <a href=\"https://account.mojang.com/documents/minecraft_eula\">Minecraft EULA</a>. Let's stay white-hat here, folks. </p><p> Each version of the mappings lives in its own branch. To download the mappings for a certain version of Minecraft, navigate to that branch on BitBucket and then download the <span class=\"code\">.mappings</span> file. </p><h2>Contributing to the mappings</h2><p> We manage the mappings file using the <a href=\"http://mercurial.selenic.com/\">Mercurial</a> repository on BitBucket and anyone is welcome to contribute. I tried to find a way to make the repo writable by anyone, but there doesn't seem to be an option for that on BitBucket. I suppose that could be a security issue. If you want to push to the repo, just <a href=\"http://www.minecraftforum.net/private-messages/send?recipient=Cuchaz\">send me a request</a> with your BitBucket account name, and I'll give you write access. The goal is to let anyone contribute mappings if they want to. </p><p> Before you start a deobfuscating session, make sure you've pulled the latest mappings from the repo. When you're done, merge/push your changes back to the repo. The file format I've chosen for the mappings is a human-readable line-by-line text format, so hopefully Mercurial will be a useful tool for synchronizing the mappings. We'll see how this works. =) </p><p><b>A word of caution:</b> keep each commit short and don't spend too long working on it. If you build up your commit over several days, it is likely that other contributors will have made commits during that time.
