You can find the basics <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/concepts/loaders/\">here</a> and documentation on how to write a loader <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/development/how-to-write-a-loader/\">here</a>.</p>\n<p>Furthermore you might want to check out the <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/api/loaders/\">loader API</a>.</p>\n<h1 id=\"implementingaloader\">Implementing a Loader</h1>\n<p>So, you are not going to just copy paste some code from this article and feel like you finally understood webpack loaders.<br/>\nEveryday I read comments and articles where people complain about how difficult webpack is, and how everything is buggy and breaks all the time.<br/>\nIf you want it to work properly you will have to understand it. You are a developer, the experience should be nice, but does not need to be as baby proof as what we deliver to our customers.</p>\n<p>First you need to understand the webpack configuration file and its options, which I am not going to cover and assume you have some understanding of.<br/>\nWhen you get the hang of that you can go ahead and start understanding loaders.</p>\n<p>The links to the docs are above, now go and read the first two carefully.</p>\n<p>Done?<br/>\nGreat!</p>\n<p>Really. You probably just did more than 75% of self announced Frontend developers (no disrespect to the real developrs who love the frontend).<br/>\nNow go ahead and write a super simple loader that will <code>console.log</code> the contents of the files it is parsing.</p>\n<p>You can use <a href=\"https://github.com/bananenmannfrau/writing-a-webpack-loader\">this</a> repo as a starting point. Just put your loader code into the file <code>loaders/your-first-loader/index.js</code> and run the build with <code>npm run build</code>.</p>\n<p>There is a simple configuration option missing in the <code>configs/webpack.config.js</code> though.<br/>\nWithout it you will see the following error when building:</p>\n<p><img src=\"/content/images/2017/10/webpackLoaderError1.png\" alt=\"webpackLoaderError1\"/></p>\n<p>If you read the second <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/development/how-to-write-a-loader/\">link</a> you will quickly find what is missing.</p>\n<p>Hopefully I build</code></h4>\n<p>Builds your site for production. Outputs to a <code>dist</code> directory in your project.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#project-setup\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-project-setup\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Project Setup</h2>\n<p><code>react-static</code> needs a few directories and files in the right places to function properly:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><code>static.config.js</code> - A javascript configuration file for react-static. <a href=\"https://github.com/nozzle/react-static/blob/master/examples/basic/static.config.js\">Click here to see an example</a></li>\n<li><code>public/</code> - Anything in this directory will be merged into your static <code>dist</code> directory. All files in this directory can be accessed at the root of your site.</li>\n<li><code>src/</code> - a place for all of your code\n<ul>\n<li><code>index.js</code> - the main entry for your app. This file should export your app as its default export and also handle the rendering of the app when using the development server. <a href=\"https://github.com/nozzle/react-static/blob/master/examples/basic/src/index.js\">Click here to see an example</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#configuration-staticconfigjs\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-configuration-staticconfigjs\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Configuration (<code>static.config.js</code>)</h2>\n<p>A <code>static.config.js</code> file is required at your project root to configure react-static. It must export a <strong>default</strong> object with the following interface:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">export</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">default</span> {\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> getRoutes is the only required method for the entire config.</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> It is an asynchronous function that should</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> resolve an array of route objects. This function</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> should resolve any data the route needs to render eg. blog</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> posts, API data, etc.</span>\n\n      noindex<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">false</span>, <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> Optional. Defaults to `false`. If `true`, will exclude this route from the sitemap XML</span>\n      permalink<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>, <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> Optional. Must utilize the</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> `Html`, `Head`, `Body` and `children` for react-static to work. The optional</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> `staticMeta` prop refers to any data you potentially returned from</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> the `preRenderMeta` and `postRenderMeta` function.</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-en\">Html</span><span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> ({ Html, Head, Body, children, staticMeta }) <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> (\n    <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Html lang<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>en-US<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Head<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n        <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>meta name<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>viewport<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span> content<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>width=device-width, initial-scale=1<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span> <span class=\"pl-k\">/</span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Head<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Body<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>{children}<span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Body<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n    <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Html<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n  ),\n\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> An optional callback, used to modify the webpack config for both dev</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> and production. The function you provide will be passed an instance of</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> webpack-configurator (see https://github.com/lewie9021/webpack-configurator</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> for more information), and an object containing a `dev` boolean, denoting</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> whether you are in development or production mode.</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-en\">webpack</span><span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> (<span class=\"pl-smi\">webpackConfigurator</span>, { dev }) <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> {<span class=\"pl-k\">...</span>},\n\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> The entry location for your app, defaulting to `./src/index.js`</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> This file must export the JSX of your app as the default export,</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> eg. `default export &lt;MyApp /&gt;`.</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> It also handles the rendering of your app while in development mode</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> (including hot reloading). For a brief example, see the Project</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> Setup section above.</span>\n  entry<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>./src/index.js<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>,\n\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> An optional asynchronous function that is pass the JSX component</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> BEFORE it is rendered to a static string. It can return a javascript</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> object that will be made available to a custom Html component</span>\n  preRenderMeta<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">async</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">JSX</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> {<span class=\"pl-k\">...</span>},\n\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> An optional asynchronous function that is passed the statically</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> rendered HTML for each page and returns a javascript object</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> that will be made available to a custom Html component</span>\n  postRenderMeta<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">async</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">staticHTML</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> {<span class=\"pl-k\">...</span>},\n\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> Optional. Set to true to serve the bundle analyzer on a production build.</span>\n  bundleAnalyzer<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">false</span>,\n}</pre></div>\n<h2><a href=\"#components--tools\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-components--tools\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Components &amp; Tools</h2>\n<h4><a href=\"#router-\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-router-\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a><code>&lt;Router /&gt;</code></h4>\n<p>The <code>Router</code> component is react-static's special version of React-Router's <code>Router</code> component. It is to be used in conjunction with other React Router components. By using react-static's <code>Router</code> at the base of your app, you won't have to worry about switching between static routing and browser routing. It accepts a <code>history</code> object like you're used to (to support things like react-router-redux), and also provides a helper method to subscribe to loading events.</p>\n<p>Example:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> { <span class=\"pl-smi\">Router</span> } <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>react-static<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n<span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> { <span class=\"pl-smi\">Switch</span>, <span class=\"pl-smi\">Route</span> } <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>react-router<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">Home</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>./containers/Home<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n<span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">About</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>./containers/About<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n<span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">Blog</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>./containers/Blog<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-k\">export</span> <span class=\"pl-c1\">default</span> () <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> (\n  <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Router<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n    <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Switch<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Route exact path<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>/<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span> component<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span>{Home} <span class=\"pl-k\">/</span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Route path<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>/about<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span> component<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span>{About} <span class=\"pl-k\">/</span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n      <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Route path<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>/blog<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span> component<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span>{Blog} <span class=\"pl-k\">/</span><span <span class=\"pl-k\">/</span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n    <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Switch<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n  <span <code>Router.subscribe(callback)</code>.\nThe subscribe callback will fire whenever the loading state changes.</p>\n<p>Example:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> { <span class=\"pl-smi\">Router</span> } <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>react-static<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-smi\">Router</span>.<span class=\"pl-en\">subscribe</span>(<span class=\"pl-smi\">loading</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> {\n  <span 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 you with all other necessary routing components and utils via <code>react-router</code>.</p>\n<p>These 6z\"/></svg></a><code>getRouteProps(Component)</code></h4>\n<p><code>getRouteProps</code> is an HOC that provides a component with the results of the current route's <code>getProps</code> function as defined in your <code>static.config.js</code>. Here is a simple example:</p>\n<p><strong>static.config.js</strong></p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-c1\">module</span>.<span class=\"pl-smi\">exports</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">=</span> {\n  <span class=\"pl-en\">getRoutes</span><span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> () <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> [{\n    path<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>/top-100-songs<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span>,\n    getProps<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">async</span> () <span class=\"pl-k\">=&gt;</span> ({\n      songs<span class=\"pl-k\">:</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">await</span> <span class=\"pl-smi\">SpotifyAPI</span>.<span class=\"pl-en\">getTopSongs</span>(<span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>li<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>)}\n  <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>ul<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n)\n\n<span viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 6z\"/></svg></a><code>&lt;Head /&gt;</code></h4>\n<p><code>Head</code> is a react component for managing tags in the document's <code>head</code>. Use it to update meta tags, title tags, etc.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>It can be used anywhere in your app.</li>\n<li>If called more than once on a route, it will append and merge them together (and overwrite some tags with the latest tag used).</li>\n<li>For more information, see the <a href=\"https://github.com/nfl/react-helmet\">React-Helmet library</a> that <code>react-static</code> uses to accomplish this.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Example:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> { <span class=\"pl-smi\">Head</span> } <span class=\"pl-k\">from</span> <span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n)</pre></div>\n<h4><a href=\"#prefetch-path\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-prefetch-path\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a><code>&lt;Prefetch path=''/&gt;</code></h4>\n<p>Prefetch is a react component that accepts a <code>path</code> prop and an optional single child to render. When this component is rendered, any data resolved by the <code>path</code>'s corresponding <code>getProps</code> function will be prefetched. This ensures that if the user then navigates to that route in your site, they do not have to wait for the required data to load.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>If the path doesn't match a route, no data will be loaded.</li>\n<li>If the route has already been loaded in the session, the cache will be used instead.</li>\n<li>If multiple instances of the same <code>path</code> are prefetched at the same time, only a single request will be made for all instances.</li>\n<li>If used more often than needed, this component could result in fetching a lot of unused data. Be smart about what you prefetch.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Example:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-js\"><pre><span class=\"pl-k\">import</span> { <span class=\"pl-smi\">Prefetch</span> } <span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> Standalone</span>\n<span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Prefetch path<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>/blog<span <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span>Link to<span class=\"pl-k\">=</span><span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>/blog<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span><span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n    Go to blog\n  <span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Prefetch<span class=\"pl-k\">&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"pl-k\">&lt;</span><span class=\"pl-k\">/</span>Prefetch<span 6z\"/></svg></a><code>prefetch(path)</code></h4>\n<p><code>prefetch</code> is an imperative version of the <code>Prefetch</code> component that you can use anywhere in your It consisted of a webcam in some guy's basement and a whole load of electronic toys you could play with remotely including a model train, an RC mini and a crane. I remember hours of enjoyment using the site especially when I managed to pick up the car with the crane and lower it onto the railway track and ram it with the train.</p>\n<p>It suddenly occured to me that I could re-live the madness in my own home and decided to trial it over the Christmas period from 1st December until 31st December 2017. So far I have dug out my old childhood train set and started building an internet connected controller to control the train, unfortunately budget probably won't stretch to a crane as well although I'll probably put up a Christmas tree within the circle of train track with some internet controlled lights to keep with the festive theme.</p>\n<p>The train is a simple affair with a variable DC current passed through the track between 0 and 12v, initially I thought about cannibalising an existing model railway controller but I soon realised controlling the motor using the PWM output of an Arduino ATMega328PU, a Darlington pair and a H Bridge would probably achieve a decent serial controlled controller at a very low cost, and would be more favourable than buying a model railway controller for conversation as even a simple analog model railway controller retails for around \u00c2\u00a340.</p>\n<p>I sourced a few parts from my electronics stuff drawer and ordered some other items from eBay, first I found a decent 20V AC powersupply capable of deliverying 1A with thermal cut out and some nice protection features in my storage box. Although more work than just getting a straight forward 12V DC powersupply I decided this was worth the effort rather than buying some cheap substandard supply from eBay. I hooked this up with some diodes forming a full wave bridge rectifier along with a smoothing capacitor and an L7812CV voltage regulator to give a nice smooth 12V supply to work with.</p>\n<p>Next as the h-bridge ICs have not arrived from eBay yet I wanted to check I could use PWM succesfully to vary the voltage to the track using some transistor, of course with this configuration I would not be able to change direction, only vary speed. Based on the use case I chose a TIP120 Darlington pair on the ground return from the track. Due to the lack of h-bridges I only used a breadboard at this stage to test the circuit and I kept the ATMega328PU in an Arduino Uno boardpowered over the PC's USB for simplicity and ease of changing stuff around, although for the final project the micro controller will be broken out of the Uno and used directly within the circuit using an L7805CV 5V regulator for power along with a 16mhz crystal and a few 10pF capacitors.</p>\n<p>Here is a very back of napkin style sketch of my setup for testing...</p>\n<img alt=\"\" src=\"https://www.robertputt.co.uk/images/20171008/circuit1.jpg\"/>\n<p>I constructed the above on a breadboard adding a heatsink to the 12V regulator and the TIP120 as I expect these will get pretty warm, then I got to work writing some basic Arduino code to allow setting the PWM duty cycle using serial input. Here is the result:</p>\n<pre class=\"literal-block\">\nint mspeedpin = 9;\nint mspeed = 0;\nint integerValue;\n\nvoid setup() {\n  Serial.begin(9600);\n  pinMode(mspeedpin, OUTPUT);\n}\n\nvoid loop() {\n  integerValue = Serial.parseInt();\n  Serial.println(integerValue);\n  if (integerValue &gt; 150) {\n    mspeed = integerValue;\n    Serial.println(\"Set new speed\");\n  } else if (integerValue == 1) {\n    mspeed = 0;\n    Serial.println(\"Train stopped\");\n  } else {\n    Serial.println(\"Invalid command / speed\");\n  }\n  analogWrite(mspeedpin, mspeed);\n}\n</pre>\n<p>By default the serial gets parsed as 0 if no input is given so I simply ignore items with a 0 input and instead set an input of 1 to set the duty cycle to 0% to stop the tain as an input of 1 would not usually be used as the train only really starts moving at around 60% duty cycle. Below this amount the voltage is too low to get any movement hence adding the if statement ensuring that only values above 150 set the speed, anything below this would risk causing damage to the motor. The serial console in Arduino will now accept the following values:</p>\n<ul class=\"simple\">\n<li>0 = No input, ignore and continue</li>\n<li>1 = Stop the train</li>\n<li>150 - 255 = Vary the speed of the train between ~58% - 100%</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Then I put a train on the track and tried sending a few commands via serial, to my joy it ran around the track with varying speed, when the h-bridge arrives I'll fit it into the circuit to get bi-directional control working before moving on to some basic short circuit protection in case the train falls off the track and causes a short. Following this I'll get it all mounted on some prototyping board and build an API for interacting with the controller over the internet.</p>\n<p>Anyway here is a short video of testing the above, you'll notice the train's speed doesnt vary greatly, unfortunately this model is very old and is a bit all or nothing, I may try and dig out a newer model from my collection as I suspect these would handle the lower voltages better. On the first lap it runs at around 60% duty cycle increasing by 10% on each subsequent lap until full speed and then ramping back down again, the stuttering over on the left hand side is caused by some dirt on the track and is not related to the controller.</p>\n<iframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GuNzo2_p5xg\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\">VIDEO</iframe><p>I will update once the h-bridge arrives and the project is progressing, closer to the go live date I'll link to the control page so you can all have a play.</p>\n\n\n\n\n<ins class=\"adsbygoogle\" data-ad-client=\"ca-pub-7205601062973662\" data-ad-slot=\"4798674690\" data-ad-format=\"auto\"/>\n\n\n        </div>\n        </div></body></html>"}, "15429586": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:34:37", "url": "http://www.barttar.com", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"terms-page-content-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"terms-page-content-sub\">\n<h5 class=\"terms-page-content-sub-title\">\nCreating a barttar\n</h5>\n<p class=\"terms-page-content-sub-text\">\nYou probably remember barttar as the earliest form of trade, while we weren\u2019t there when this was the standard form of trade worldwide,\nthe belief in this pure form of transaction inspired this platform. The passenger who inspired this post was lucky to have been released from the Maricopa County Jail - the city cops found another blond-haired white woman who better matched the description of the petty thief they were looking for.<p>It was 15 miles to get her back to where the police had picked her up.<p>(edit: wording)"], "time": "2017-10-08 23:34:10", "url": "http://www.taxiwars.org/2017/10/ordinary-rendition-public-servants.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-body entry-content\" id=\"post-body-3496441456241487685\" itemprop=\"description articleBody\"><p>\nMedia reports about the predicaments of public servants remind me of the passenger who brought my </p><a href=\"http://www.taxiwars.org/2013/04/origin-of-tcj-moniker.html\" target=\"_blank\">efforts as a taxi driver</a><p> full-circle. \n</p><p>\nShe started out like most the others: the buzz of a fare offer and \"835 yards\" as the distance. When the address came through I turned around, turned right, and arrived at the apartment complex in about 4 minutes. I called the provided number. A woman's voice gave directions to a building in the back of the complex. \n</p><p>\nA group came out; a woman in her 20's got in the cab. An older male stood outside and gave directions to where his truck was parked. As we pulled away the passenger said, in a flustered voice, \u201cI don't know why he messes with her, she's like 20 years younger...\u201d, and this wasn't the first time they'd had to take a taxi or a bus to get the truck back. \n</p><p>\nI didn't care, because I was happy to have a longer trip than someone going across the street with groceries. I broke into my standard line of questions.\n</p><p>\nBefore long she asked me her own question: \"Did you ever pick a girl up downtown, take her to [West-Valley city], and </p><i>she wasn't able to pay?</i><p>\"\n</p><p>\n'I would do that. Let me think.... ... .. .' I glanced at my passenger to jog my memory. Recently: no. Semi-recently: no. Then I remembered, 'THAT WAS A LONG TIME AGO!' I looked at my passenger again, 'Was that... YOU?', and cautiously confirmed that I had. \n</p><p>\nShe said with glee, </p><i>\"THAT WAS ME!\"</i>\n<p>\nI remembered her trip well.\n\n</p><a name=\"more\"/><h3>\nAlmost 2 years earlier...</h3>\n<p>\nI tended to stay in the areas north of the Salt River, but I worked wherever the passengers took me. On that night I'd just gotten off I-17 at 7th St. A fellow was on the off-ramp asking for change. I asked what he was planning to buy. He said he just wanted a cup of coffee. That sounded reasonable, so I gave him a few quarters. \"What's your name?\"\n</p><p>\n\"Maverick, really!\" He quickly produced his state-issued ID card and showed it to me. \n</p><p>\nI was about to drive away when I realized that I'd had all of the coconut pie I could stomach, and that I might as well give the other half away to someone who'd appreciate it. He took the pie gratefully, the light turned green, and I turned south to go under the freeway. Seconds later I was offered a fare to the north, so I turned around. Maverick was strutting along with the pie box, like he'd just won the lottery.\n</p><p>\nThe provided address and phone number was for a cheap motel in downtown Phoenix. A woman promptly appeared when I pulled up and got in the cab. She was obviously distraught, and urgently said \u201cGO GO GO!\u201d\n</p><p>\nShe asked to go to one of the cities in the west valley - it was a bit of a drive.\n</p><p>\nI was more cautious than usual with my standard questions, and my passenger's story gradually revealed itself. Her boyfriend had some sort of cancer which was in and out of remission. They were economically stressed - without jobs, staying with friends,\u00a0 and dependent on the kindness of others to survive. \n</p><p>\nA few hours earlier this passenger had been out walking her dog in the quiet neighborhood around her friend's house. Then someone said, \"YOU, FREEZE!\" huh, whut? \"YOU'RE UNDER ARREST!\" It was a public servant. \n</p><p>\nMy passenger asked why she was under arrest, but the public servant was dismissive, in a \u201cyou know what you did\u201d sort of way. Eventually she learned what she was being accused of. She protested that she hadn't been to the convenience store that night, and that she most certainly was NOT the petty beer thief the public servants were looking for. But the officers were looking for a blonde white woman, and she was the first person they found matching this description. They'd taken my passenger downtown, and began the process of booking her into Sheriff Arpaio's Gulag (\"County Jail\" - the now-deposed </p><a href=\"http://www.taxiwars.org/2017/09/americas-make-work-sheriff-anachronism.html\" target=\"\">Sherriff of Maricopa was notorious for his cruelty</a><p>).\n</p><p>\nSome time later the city cops in the west valley found the petty beer thief they were actually looking for, and they released their mistaken arrestee (my passenger) from the\u00a0 4th Avenue Jail. \u201c... Aren't you going to take me back to [west-valley]?\u201d She thought they would take her back to where she'd been mistakenly arrested, but the public servants told her she could call for a taxi.\n</p><p>\nShe didn't have quarters to use the payphone, and eventually found her way to the cheap motel. The staff lent use of their phone to call the taxi company. Her hope was that the friend whose house she was staying at could pay her fare, but this concern was secondary to getting out of the scary area surrounding Arpaio's Gulag.\n</p><p>\nWhen we were almost to her friend's house a very important question occurred to me: </p><i>\"What happened to your dog?\" </i><p>Maybe I shouldn't have asked, as she didn't know.\n</p><p>\nShe also didn't know the exact address of where she was staying. Eventually the house was found and my passenger went inside. After a few minutes she returned with her friend, who apologized profusely for not having any cash. We tried his prepaid debit card, which was supposed to have funds from a tax refund soon, but it didn't authorize, for any amount. She wanted to make arrangements for later payment.\n</p><p>\nI depended on my passengers being able to pay their fares so that I could buy fuel and otherwise support myself. But it was clear that this woman was genuinely distraught, and she had a good story. I left a card and said she could pay when she could.\n</p><p>\n(The friend said that animal control had been called to collect the dog.)\n\n</p><h3>\nA Most-Appreciative Passenger </h3>\n<p>\nWhen we met again, this woman shared how appreciative she was that I'd helped her out at our first encounter, years before. She'd always wanted to pay me, but had lost my card. How long had it been? Neither of us remembered.\n</p><p>\nShe has a job now, \u201cat a mortuary, of all places...\u201d, and her boyfriend is doing well.\n</p><p>\n\"Did you get your dog back?\" They'd posted fliers around the neighborhood, which led to the return of her dog.\n</p><p>\nShe paid the fare to get to her friend's truck. I didn't remember her earlier fare amount, and took slightly less than was offered. I spent a few minutes looking for notes from that night on my laptop, but nothing turned up in my searches. Before long another fare was offered - 3.5 miles away, at the Sprouts on West Peoria - and I was off for another trip.\n</p><p>\nIt wasn't until working on this write-up that I remembered giving Maverick the pie that night (which was intended for \"the alcoholic\", because it was on sale at Whole Foods &amp; alcoholics are always malnourished, but the intended pie-recipient didn't answer her phone that day). That marks the day of my first encounter with this woman as the closing days of December 2012; the second encounter was in November of 2014.\n\n</p><h3>\nFairness, justice, and anti-justice </h3>\n<p>\n\"Tom\" drove the cab for our little team 5 nights a week. Tom used to be a police officer in the American south. He drives cab for the adventure, and to supplement his pension. One weekend I messaged to say that I'd finished for the day, and had dropped the cab off. He responded that he was at the Italian food place a half mile away.\n</p><p>\nIn our chat that night Tom mentioned smelling really aromatic marijuana on some recent south-Phoenix passengers - not \u201cspice crap\", but something more pleasant. I commented that he used to fight in </p><a href=\"http://howdoigethigh.com/\" target=\"_blank\">the war on plants</a><p>.\n</p><p>\n\"They told me it was a gateway drug, </p><i>and I believed them</i><p>. Now it seems that the plant actually has health benefits.\"\u00a0 Then he remembered a teenager who tried to hide a joint from Police Officer Tom. \"I probably ruined that kid's life,\" he said with a chuckle. It was a long time ago. It was just part of the job.\n\n</p><h4>\nMany types of criminals</h4>\n<p>\nOn the one hand, public servants are tasked with protecting society from violence and predation. On the other hand, politicians have also tasked our public servants with the sick (addicts and mentally ill), the poor, political criminals who haven't hurt anyone, and those who make mistakes.\n</p><p>\nA wise woman I know once said, \u201cwhen a person feels safe, the false ego goes away.\" People who don't feel safe cause problems not because they're bad people who need to be taught a lesson by being thrown in a cage, but because they don't have the resources to make better choices.\n</p><p>\nFinancially-secure people who are arrested for mistakes tend to get the catch-and-release treatment. People with money to burn can hire a good attorney to possibly get them off, or at least to effectively negotiate with the prosecutor on their behalf. My </p><a href=\"http://www.taxiwars.org/who-are-your-lifelines/\">who are your lifelines?</a><p> passenger said he used to have an attorney who could \"take care\" of her clients' problems by schmoozing with the prosecutors.\n</p><p>\nThe media makes a big deal about race, but I think the issue is more one of class: poor white people get traumatized by Justice too.\n\n</p><h3>\nThe Public Servants' Quagmire</h3>\n<p>\nPolice officers have a bit of a predicament: their official motto is to \"protect and serve\", but the politicians have given them no flexibility to fulfill their role.\n</p><p>\nAfter I retired from taxi driving, I spent a couple days at fire school. During the opening ceremony I realized the difference between firefighters and police officers/sheriff's deputies.\n</p><p>\nIf the fire department is dispatched, they will do whatever they can to try to help you. Firetrucks are completely outfitted with all sorts of equipment that might be needed to save someone's day. These include not just fire hoses and axes, but also tools to cut up cars to extract people when the doors won't open, etc. Equipment on this Mesa firetruck was once used to lift the light-rail train off of a drunk who'd passed out on the tracks:\n\n</p><table align=\"center\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" class=\"tr-caption-container\"><tbody>\n<tr><td><a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-C8RTWWduR0Q/Wdpk8Dwy1uI/AAAAAAAAANQ/SDtdS-zQh24S-m7oB_p4G1NKDnCYng6yQCLcBGAs/s1600/Mesa%2BFD%2B-%2BRapid%2BResponse%252C%2BSpecial%2BOperations.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"1200\" data-original-width=\"1600\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-C8RTWWduR0Q/Wdpk8Dwy1uI/AAAAAAAAANQ/SDtdS-zQh24S-m7oB_p4G1NKDnCYng6yQCLcBGAs/s200/Mesa%2BFD%2B-%2BRapid%2BResponse%252C%2BSpecial%2BOperations.jpg\"/></a></td></tr>\n<tr><td class=\"tr-caption\">Mesa Fire Department's Rapid Response/Special Operations Firetruck</td></tr>\n</tbody></table><p>\nNo judgement calls are made by firefighters when responding to the incident at hand. In a future post I intend to tell of the time that I had to call in some firefighters to save the day. After the firefighters had disappeared into the night, the also-dispatched police officers completed their \"investigation\" and decided they didn't need to make the situation worse.\n</p><p>\nDiscretion is the police officer's most important skill. But police are frequently pressured (performance evaluations, etc) to take actions that really just needlessly wreck people's lives. \n</p><p>\nAnother passenger, whom I may expand on more fully, told of the time she was being unruly, and her family called the police for help. After a while those police officers decided they didn't have any way to help, so \"we're going to have to take you downtown.\" Her adult daughter protested, \"THIS IS NOT WHY WE CALLED YOU\", but the police officers were like, \"whatevers\". Arresting people is their job, even if that person really only needs a time-out from their situation.\n\n</p><h3>\nVarieties of Rendition: Ordinary vs. Extraordinary </h3>\n<p>\nDuring the George W. Bush administration, the United States government's use of \"Extraordinary Rendition\" was sporadically covered by the media:\n</p><blockquote class=\"tr_bq\">\n<b>Extraordinary rendition</b> is the government-sponsored abduction and extrajudicial transfer of a person from one country to another that has predominantly been carried out by the United States government with the consent of other countries. [...]<br/>\n<br/>\nThe United Nations considers one nation abducting the citizens of another a crime against humanity. [...] (<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraordinary_rendition\">Wikipedia</a>)</blockquote><p>\nOrdinary rendition is the corollary event, when a person gets transferred from one area to another as a part of normal police operations. Public servants should realize that they have a duty to make sure people are not overly traumatized by their ordinary practices. \n\n</p><p/>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430898": {"score": 1, <figure class=\"media-landscape has-caption full-width lead\">\n            <span class=\"image-and-copyright-container\">\n                \n                <img class=\"js-image-replace\" crypto-currencies operated by getting lots of computers to work together to solve the tricky mathematical problems that generate new digital \"coins\".</p><p>The number crunching is called mining and new crypto-coins are handed out to miners who are the first to solve the complex sums.</p><p>The more computer power that someone can amass, said Mr Ferguson, the more coins they can generate. </p><p>\"There's a huge attraction of being able to use other people's devices in a massively distributed fashion because you then effectively take advantage of a huge amount of computing resources,\"        \n        </figure><p>\"Crypto-coin mining malware is nothing new,\" said Mr Ferguson, adding that the growing value of established cyber-currencies and the emergence of potentially valuable harbouring the script. </p><p>Prof Matthew Caesar, a computer scientist at the University of Illinois, said mining was also starting to cause problems for companies that offered cloud-based computing     </figure><p>Prof Caesar said he and student Rashid Tahir started investigating the problem after conversations with several cloud firms revealed that all of them had experienced trouble with For example, I do not think the addition of ES6 classes was a good decision. It has removed a need for people to deeply understand prototypal inheritance in JavaScript, and further encourages inheritance over composition. However, I have had a valid reason for holding off on using ES7\u2019s async/await (until now).</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"what-is-an-async-function\">What is an async function?</h1>\n<p>Async/await introduces a solution to a problem previously solved by coroutines. It provides a language-level construct for synchronously executing asynchronous actions, making your JavaScript code\u2019s control flow significantly easier to follow.</p>\n\n<p>Below is an example of an async function:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">waitToSayHello</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"k\">async</span><span class=\"p\">()</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n    <span class=\"kr\">await</span> <span class=\"nb\">Promise</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">delay</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"mi\">2000</span><span class=\"p\">);</span> <span class=\"c1\">// Bluebird utility function</span>\n    <span class=\"nx\">console</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">log</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"Hello!\"</span><span class=\"p\">);</span>\n<span class=\"p\">};</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>The code above is extremely clear: wait for 2 seconds and log. Async/await eliminates the need for timeout callbacks by allowing to specify waiting on asynchronous actions.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"why-have-i-not-been-using-async-functions\">Why have I not been using async functions?</h1>\n<p>Async functions become more complicated when you have to handle rejected promises. Take the code below, which fetches a Bookshelf User model by email, adds a token on to it, and returns a response from a server:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"k\">async</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">email</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n    <span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"kr\">await</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">forge</span><span class=\"p\">({</span> <span class=\"nx\">email</span> <span class=\"p\">}).</span><span class=\"nx\">fetch</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n    <span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"kd\">set</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"token\"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"nx\">getToken</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">));</span>\n    <span class=\"k\">return</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">save</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n<span class=\"p\">};</span>\n\n<span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"<a href=\"/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection\" class=\"__cf_email__\" data-cfemail=\"67020310061503270515060a0609130e490a02\">[email\u00a0protected]</a>\"</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">then</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">));</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>Let\u2019s say if <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\"><a href=\"/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection\" class=\"__cf_email__\" data-cfemail=\"aecbcad9cfdccaeeccdccfc3cfc0dac780c3cb\">[email\u00a0protected]</a></code> is not found in the database when the user is fetched, the fetch promise rejects with an error called <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">UserNotFoundError</code>. We want to respond with a 404 for that particular error type and allow all other errors to throw and be caught by our server. There are two ways to handle an error with an async function:</p>\n<ol>\n  <li>A try/catch block inside the async function.</li>\n  <li>A catch block where the async function is called.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>There are <a href=\"https://blog.patricktriest.com/what-is-async-await-why-should-you-care/\">plenty of examples online</a> about the first option, but in this particular case, I want to focus on #2. Here is what our implementation could look like:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"k\">async</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">email</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n    <span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"kr\">await</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">forge</span><span class=\"p\">({</span> <span class=\"nx\">email</span> <span class=\"p\">}).</span><span class=\"nx\">fetch</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n    <span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"kd\">set</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"token\"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"nx\">getToken</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">));</span>\n    <span class=\"k\">return</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">save</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n<span class=\"p\">};</span>\n\n<span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"<a href=\"/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection\" class=\"__cf_email__\" data-cfemail=\"41242536203325012333202c202f35286f2c24\">[email\u00a0protected]</a>\"</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">then</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">))</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"k\">catch</span><span class=\"p\">((</span><span class=\"nx\">e</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n        <span class=\"k\">if</span> <span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">e</span> <span class=\"k\">instanceof</span> <span class=\"nx\">UserNotFoundError</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n            <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">().</span><span class=\"nx\">code</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"mi\">404</span><span class=\"p\">);</span>\n        <span class=\"p\">}</span>\n\n        <span class=\"k\">throw</span> <span class=\"nx\">e</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">})</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>The problem here is that the <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">catch</code> block passes all error conditions to one function callback. If there is more than one error type, you need multiple conditional <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">instanceof</code> checks, which makes your callback longer and more complex. This may not seem like an issue, since we do handle the <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">UserNotFoundError</code>. Nevertheless, we have to re-throw if the error does not match conditional <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">instanceof</code> check. If you forget to re-throw, this could cause your server to hang in that block because it has not escaped asynchronous execution.</p>\n\n<p>Bluebird (and in particular, <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">Promise.coroutine</code>) diverges from async functions because it supports a feature called <a href=\"http://bluebirdjs.com/docs/api/catch.html#filtered-catch\">filtered catch</a>. This feature allows you to specify one or more error constructors to be handled by a specific callback. This is available in many other languages, such as C# and Java, and is incredibly useful for handling different exception types.</p>\n\n<p>Using <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">Promise.coroutine</code> we can make use of this feature in a similar manner to async functions:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"nb\">Promise</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">coroutine</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"kd\">function</span><span class=\"o\">*</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">email</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n    <span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"k\">yield</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">forge</span><span class=\"p\">({</span> <span class=\"nx\">email</span> <span class=\"p\">}).</span><span class=\"nx\">fetch</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n    <span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"kd\">set</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"token\"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"nx\">getToken</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">));</span>\n    <span class=\"k\">return</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">save</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n<span class=\"p\">};</span>\n\n<span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"<a href=\"/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection\" class=\"__cf_email__\" data-cfemail=\"aacfceddcbd8ceeac8d8cbc7cbc4dec384c7cf\">[email\u00a0protected]</a>\"</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">then</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">))</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"k\">catch</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">UserNotFoundError</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"p\">()</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">code</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"mi\">404</span><span class=\"p\">));</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>Filtered catching <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise/catch\">is not supported by the ES6\u2019s native Promise implementation</a>, which is why I have avoided using async/await and have stuck to using <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">Promise.coroutine</code>. The problem is clear: async/await returns a promise that does not support the useful, granular filtered catch that I need to cleanly handle the multiple different types of errors I could experience inside these functions.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"my-solution-to-error-handling-hell\">My solution to \u201cerror handling hell\u201d</h1>\n<p>To get filtered catch support, I need async functions to return a Bluebird promise. Bluebird has a utility function called <a href=\"http://bluebirdjs.com/docs/api/promise.method.html\"><code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">Promise.method</code></a>, which we can wrap our async function with to return a Bluebird promise with filtered catch support:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"nb\">Promise</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">method</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"k\">async</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">email</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span>\n    <span class=\"kd\">const</span> <span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"kr\">await</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">forge</span><span class=\"p\">({</span> <span class=\"nx\">email</span> <span class=\"p\">}).</span><span class=\"nx\">fetch</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n    <span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"kd\">set</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"token\"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"nx\">getToken</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">));</span>\n    <span class=\"k\">return</span> <span class=\"nx\">User</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">save</span><span class=\"p\">();</span>\n<span class=\"p\">});</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>Now, our called promise error handling looks exactly like it did with <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">Promise.coroutine</code>:</p>\n\n<figure class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"language-js\" data-lang=\"js\"><span class=\"nx\">fetchUserByEmail</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"<a href=\"/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection\" class=\"__cf_email__\" data-cfemail=\"3c59584b5d4e587c5e4e5d515d524855125159\">[email\u00a0protected]</a>\"</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"nx\">then</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span> <span class=\"o\">=&gt;</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">user</span><span class=\"p\">))</span>\n    <span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"k\">catch</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"nx\">UserNotFoundError</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"nx\">reply</span><span class=\"p\">().</span><span class=\"nx\">code</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"mi\">404</span><span class=\"p\">));</span></code></pre></figure>\n\n<p>This is much cleaner, and now gives async/await functions all the power of Bluebird\u2019s <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">catch</code>.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"why-is-this-a-big-deal\">Why is this a big deal?</h1>\n<p>Particularly with Node, I find myself performing multiple asynchronous actions that return different error types. Filtered catch allows you to clearly express your exception handling with discrete catch blocks, which has an added benefit of making your error handling code more readable. It is the reason why I still use Bluebird over native ES6 promises, and I will most likely continue to do so until it becomes a feature in native promises.</p>\n\n<h1 id=\"further-examplesreading\">Further Examples/Reading</h1>\n<p>I made an example with a custom error type <a href=\"http://jsfiddle.net/arvyf8r3/\">here on JSFiddle</a>, go check it out!</p>\n\n<p>Another way to solve error handling in async function is to use <a href=\"https://github.com/scopsy/await-to-js\">Dima Grossman\u2019s await-to-js</a> package. Instead of using Bluebird promises, he uses a wrapper to return errors like the Go programming language. The wrapper returns a 2-element array with the first element being an error/null and the second element being the resolved value. The syntax becomes much cleaner with ES6 using destructuring statements, and is an interesting take on the issue. You can read more in his announcement/blog post <a href=\"http://blog.grossman.io/how-to-write-async-await-without-try-catch-blocks-in-javascript/\">here</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Thanks for reading!</p>\n\n          </div>\n\n          </div></body></html>"}, "15429879": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:36:06", "url": "https://www.eventbrite.com/e/live-green-bay-packers-vs-dallas-cowboys-live-stream-8th-oct-2017-tickets-38706516232", "text": "UNAVAILABLE TEXT BY URL https://www.eventbrite.com/e/live-green-bay-packers-vs-dallas-cowboys-live-stream-8th-oct-2017-tickets-38706516232"}, "15429060": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 20:28:03", "url": "https://www.hacklikeapornstar.com/pentesters-do-not-really-make-the-world-more-secure/", "text": "<html><body><div><article id=\"post-1147\" class=\"post-1147 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized\">\n\t<header class=\"entry-header\">\n\t\t<h1 class=\"entry-title\">Pentesters do not really make the world more secure</h1>\n\t\t\n\t</header>\n\n\t<div class=\"entry-content\"><p>\n\t\tMost big clients I have been working with lately have managed to incorporate pentesting into their regular process. Almost every new application is pentested by a consulting company. The findings are presented during a meeting with the Security Officer and the action plan is approved by the project leader\u2026Security is increasing and everything is moving forward right?&#13;\n</p><p>&#13;\nNot quite so. It takes a second pentest a couple of years later, either because of a routine check or following a major upgrade, to realize that </p><em>nothing</em><p> has really changed since!</p><p>&#13;\nI am not talking about RC4 algorithms on OpenSSL, Clickjacking and other dumb vulnerabilities, but Stored XSS, SQL injections, Direct object references\u2026 The sort of vulnerabilities that should not be present on a freaking cash flow application\u2026 Yet here there are, two years later still not fixed.</p><p>&#13;\n&#13;\nI can\u2019t help but wonder who\u2019s fault is that :&#13;\n</p><ul>&#13;\n<li>The project leader for budgetting a full scale pentest at a low 10k</li>&#13;\n<li>The consulting company for assigning the job to an intern to maximize revenues</li>&#13;\n<li>The same intern who had no clue how to remediate an SQL injection, and probably missed 80% of the vulnerabilities?</li>&#13;\n<li>The developer who dismissed the vulnerability because the recommendation was poorly written?</li>&#13;\n<li>The project leader in charge that did not properly validate the remediation actions?</li>&#13;\n<li>The vendor who fixed the vulnerabilities in its new version, but charges 30k for a licence upgrade?</li>&#13;\n<li>The Security Officer with little to no power inside an organization?</li>&#13;\n</ul>&#13;\n<p>&#13;\nWhat I am trying to say is, pentest the shit out of everything, have fun, but do not be so naive as to think that you are making your client more secure\u2026Only they can do that.</p>\t\t\t</div>\n\n\t<footer class=\"entry-footer\">\n\t\t<span class=\"cat-links\">Posted in <a href=\"https://www.hacklikeapornstar.com/category/uncategorized/\" rel=\"category tag\">Uncategorized</a></span>\t</footer>\n\n\t</article>\n\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430783": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:25:56", "url": "http://www.npr.org/2016/04/08/473513620/what-happens-when-fashion-becomes-fast-disposable-and-cheap", "text": "<html><body><div><div id=\"storytext\" class=\"storytext storylocation linkLocation\">\n      <div id=\"res473517744\" class=\"bucketwrap image large\">\n            \n<div class=\"credit-caption\">\n    <div class=\"caption-wrap\">\n        <div class=\"caption\" aria-label=\"Image caption\">\n            <p>\n                As we purchase more clothes, more waste is accumulated. Some companies and grassroots organizations are looking to change that with new initiatives.\n                \n                <b class=\"credit\" aria-label=\"Image credit\">\n                    \n                    Matt Cardy/Getty Images\n                    \n                </b>\n                <b class=\"hide-caption\"><b>hide caption</b></b>\n            </p>\n        </div>\n\n\n            <b class=\"toggle-caption\"><b>toggle caption</b></b>\n    </div>\n\n    <span class=\"credit\" aria-label=\"Image credit\">\n        \n        Matt Cardy/Getty Images\n        \n    </span>\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"enlarge_html\">\n    <div class=\"image_data\">\n        <p class=\"caption\">As we purchase more clothes, more waste is accumulated. Some companies and grassroots organizations are looking to change that with new initiatives.</p>\n        <span class=\"credit\" aria-label=\"Image credit\">\n            \n            Matt Cardy/Getty Images\n            \n        </span>\n    </div>\n</div>\n   </div>\n   <p>When it comes to clothes these days, maybe you should ask: What's your waste size?</p>   <p>You know you have those clothes sitting in your closet: That shirt you spent less than $10 on because it looked cool for a second, or that skirt you only wore once before it went out of fashion.</p>   <p>Fashion cycles are moving faster than ever. <a href=\"http://qz.com/571152/2015-is-the-year-that-upended-the-fashion-business/\">A Quartz article</a> in December revealed how fashion brands like Zara, Gap and Adidas are churning out new styles more frequently, a trend dubbed <a href=\"http://www.npr.org/2013/03/11/174013774/in-trendy-world-of-fast-fashion-styles-arent-made-to-last\">\"fast fashion\"</a> by many in the industry. The clothes that are mass-produced also become <a href=\"https://www3.nd.edu/~jsherry/pdf/2012/FastFashionSustainability.pdf\">more affordable</a>, thus attracting consumers to buy more.</p>   \n   \n\n   <p>\"It used to be four seasons in a year; now it may be up to 11 or 15 or more,\" says Tasha Lewis, a professor at Cornell University's Department of Fiber Science and Apparel Design.</p>   <p><a href=\"http://www.cit.com/middle-market/common-interests/fast-fashion-garners-fast-growth/index.htm\">The top fast fashion retailers</a> grew 9.7 percent per year over the last five years, topping the 6.8 percent of growth of traditional apparel companies, according to financial holding company CIT.</p>   <p>Fashion is big business. Estimates vary, but one report puts the global industry at <a href=\"https://maloney.house.gov/sites/maloney.house.gov/files/documents/The%20Economic%20Impact%20of%20the%20Fashion%20Industry%20\u2014%20JEC%20report%20FINAL.pdf\">$1.2 trillion</a>, with more than $250 billion spent in the U.S. alone. In 2014, the average household spent <a href=\"http://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cesan.pdf\">an average $1,786</a> on apparel and related services.</p>   <p>More styles mean more purchases \u2014 and that leads to more waste created. Journalist Elizabeth Cline writes in her book <em>Overdressed: The Shockingly High Cost of Cheap Fashion</em> that <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/10/books/review/overdressed-by-elizabeth-l-cline.html\">disposable clothing</a> is damaging to the environment and the economy. We are <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&amp;lr=&amp;id=rloiBQAAQBAJ&amp;oi=fnd&amp;pg=PA233&amp;ots=1d1_LSFYFJ&amp;sig=7nBHhN2i3VINNSZivHjvtiokAZY#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\">more likely to dispose of</a> cheaper, mass-produced fashion garments than pricier ones.</p>   <aside id=\"ad-backstage-wrap\" aria-label=\"advertisement\">\n    \n\n    <p id=\"ad-backstage-News_Science_Environment\" class=\"ad-backstage\" data-ad-config=\"{&quot;network&quot;:&quot;\\/6735\\/n6735&quot;,&quot;site&quot;:&quot;NPR&quot;,&quot;zone&quot;:&quot;News_Science_Environment&quot;,&quot;targets&quot;:{&quot;testserver&quot;:&quot;false&quot;,&quot;storyId&quot;:&quot;473513620&quot;,&quot;agg&quot;:&quot;434975886&quot;},&quot;location&quot;:&quot;backstage&quot;,&quot;deferred&quot;:false,&quot;isBetweenContent&quot;:true}\"/>\n\n</aside>   <aside id=\"ad-mobilebackfill-wrap\" aria-label=\"advertisement\">\n    \n\n    <p id=\"ad-mobilebackfill-News_Science_Environment\" class=\"ad-mobilebackfill\" data-ad-config=\"{&quot;network&quot;:&quot;\\/6735\\/n6735&quot;,&quot;site&quot;:&quot;NPRMOBILE&quot;,&quot;zone&quot;:&quot;News_Science_Environment&quot;,&quot;targets&quot;:{&quot;testserver&quot;:&quot;false&quot;,&quot;storyId&quot;:&quot;473513620&quot;,&quot;agg&quot;:&quot;434975886&quot;},&quot;location&quot;:&quot;mobilebackfill&quot;,&quot;deferred&quot;:false,&quot;isBetweenContent&quot;:true}\"/>\n\n</aside>   <p>\"We don't necessarily have the ability to handle the disposal,\" Lewis says. \"The rate of disposal is not keeping up with the availability of places to put everything that we're getting rid of and that's the problem.\"</p>   <p>According to <a href=\"https://www3.epa.gov/epawaste/nonhaz/municipal/pubs/2013_advncng_smm_rpt.pdf\">the Environmental Protection Agency</a>, 15.1 million tons of textile waste was generated in 2013, of which 12.8 million tons were discarded.</p>   \n   \n\n   <p><strong>How To Deal With All </strong><strong>This </strong><strong>Textile Waste?</strong></p>   <p>One way developed nations get rid of their excess clothing is by donating it to developing nations. According to the United Nations, the United States is the <a href=\"http://comtrade.un.org/pb/FileFetch.aspx?docID=5468&amp;type=commodity%20pages\">biggest exporter of used clothes</a>, and the top importing countries of used clothing are India, Russia and Pakistan.</p>   <p>But with the strong dollar and availability of cheap clothing from Asia, <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&amp;lr=&amp;id=rloiBQAAQBAJ&amp;oi=fnd&amp;pg=PA233&amp;ots=1d1_LSFYFJ&amp;sig=7nBHhN2i3VINNSZivHjvtiokAZY#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\">some are worried</a> that demand for exports of secondhand clothing will decline \u2014 thus forcing developed nations to find new ways to deal with post-consumer textile waste.</p>   <p>Fast fashion and the disposable culture also hurt sorting companies that export second-hand clothing.</p>   <p>Adam Baruchowitz, founder of <a href=\"http://wearablecollections.com/\">Wearable Collections</a> in New York City, collects second-hand clothing and sells it to sorting companies. The companies then sort through the clothes, separating those that will be made into other low-grade fiber products and those that will be exported.</p>   <p>Baruchowitz says the most valuable part of a sorting company's business is in selling reusable second-hand clothing. But if the quality is questionable, more of the garments collected might have to head to the shredding bin rather than the second-hand clothes market.</p>   <p>\"It's very damaging to the environment, this fast fashion culture, and it also affects the secondhand market because these clothes aren't meant to be used for so long,\" he says. \"I can't say for sure, but the secondhand H&amp;Ms would probably be in less demand than a garment that was produced with more quality. I'm getting all this stuff from fast fashion and I'm hearing from clients that it's hurting them.\"</p>   <p><strong>Do Retailers' Recycling Programs Encourage Consumerism?</strong></p>   <p>Several clothing retailers have announced <a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/fashion/la-ig-green-incentive-20151011-story.html\">take-back programs</a> that collect used garments from customers to be recycled, sold or remade into other clothing. <a href=\"http://about.hm.com/en/About/sustainability/commitments/reduce-waste/garment-collecting.html\">H&amp;M</a>, for example, has allowed customers to bring unwanted garments \u2014 which will be transformed to recycled textile fibers for new products \u2014 since 2013. The company aims to have \"zero garments going to landfill.\" <a href=\"http://www.patagonia.com/us/reuse-recycle\">Patagonia</a> also recycles and sells used Patagonia products in its stores.</p>   \n   \n\n   <p>It plays into the concept of extended producer responsibility, which means the manufacturer has to take into consideration the product's afterlife.</p>   <p>But does it actually encourage more consumerism? For many stores, customers can get store credit and vouchers for sending in used clothing.</p>   <p>\"If you bring it back to the store and you see something new and you're going to give me a discount, I'm having a buying moment I may not have had before because you're having me back at your store. It's very smart in terms of business,\" Lewis says.</p>   <p>The concept, however, might encourage a different type of thinking: If manufacturers have to think about how they're going to get the most out of the product after it has been worn, Lewis says, it might spur them to start designing products that can be taken apart easily, have better quality, or might be biodegradable, for example.</p>   <p>H&amp;M <a href=\"http://about.hm.com/en/news/newsroom/news.html/en_us/world-recycle-week-2016.html\">introduced new garments</a> made of recycled textile fibers two year ago.</p>   <p><strong>Grassroots Efforts To Counter Fast Fashion</strong></p>   <div id=\"res473514216\" class=\"bucketwrap video youtube-video large\">\n    <p class=\"video-wrap\">\n        <iframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/dTZFGUG9u2U?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\">VIDEO</iframe>\n    </p>\n        <div class=\"credit-caption externalasset\">\n            <p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTZFGUG9u2U&amp;list=PLhQMimdrfRvcd0LlPORCGXcFrek5OYQb4&amp;index=2\">CutiePieMarza</a>, a YouTuber from England, uploads a video of her clothes swap with grav3yardgirl, a Youtuber from Texas.</p>\n\n                <b class=\"credit\">\n                    \n                    <b class=\"source\">YouTube</b>\n                </b>\n        </div>\n</div>\n   <p>A year ago, a few users began uploading YouTube videos of themselves exchanging clothes with friends. It was either that, or they were showcasing how they made new styles out of their old, scrappy clothes.</p>   <p>\"Today is fashion revolution day and I decided to take part in this movement by making a 'Haulternative' video,\" <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTZFGUG9u2U&amp;list=PLhQMimdrfRvcd0LlPORCGXcFrek5OYQb4&amp;index=2\">says CutiePieMarza</a>, a YouTuber from England, in her video. She was exchanging clothes with grav3yardgirl, a YouTuber from Texas.</p>   <div id=\"res473514494\" class=\"bucketwrap video youtube-video medium\">\n    <p class=\"video-wrap\">\n        <iframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/3Kbr-pnXD4A?rel=0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\">VIDEO</iframe>\n    </p>\n        <div class=\"credit-caption externalasset\">\n            <p>Grav3yardgirl, a Youtuber from Texas, uploads a video of her swapping clothes with <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTZFGUG9u2U&amp;list=PLhQMimdrfRvcd0LlPORCGXcFrek5OYQb4&amp;index=2\">CutiePieMarza</a>, a YouTuber from England, as part of the \"haulternative\" movement.</p>\n\n                <b class=\"credit\">\n                    \n                    <b class=\"source\">YouTube</b>\n                </b>\n        </div>\n</div>\n   <p>\"It's part haul, part swap ... she asked me about a month ago if I would be part of this awesome project,\" says grav3yardgirl <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Kbr-pnXD4A&amp;list=PLhQMimdrfRvcd0LlPORCGXcFrek5OYQb4&amp;index=1\">in her video</a>. \"I think it's something mainly going on in the UK.\"</p>   <p><a href=\"http://fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FR_Haulternatives_2016.pdf\">\"Haulternative\"</a> is an alternative to the <a href=\"http://www.npr.org/2013/03/14/174305909/showing-off-shopping-sprees-fashion-haulers-cash-in-online\">traditional \"haul\" videos</a>, where users post videos of themselves parading their latest buys.</p>   <p>It was an activity that was part of the larger <a href=\"http://fashionrevolution.org/\">Fashion Revolution</a> movement started in the United Kingdom that aimed to bring awareness to the source of our garments \u2014 as well as the waste created by our consumerist habits.</p>   <p>\"It's an alternative haul. It's looking at how people can do a different kind of haul, how people can refresh their wardrobe without having to buy new clothes,\" says Carry Somers, co-founder of the movement. \"It's encouraging people to be more conscious when they're shopping.\"</p>   \n   \n\n   <p>Instead of constantly buying new clothes, the movement suggested people buy from vintage stores, make new clothes out of old ones or just swap clothes. <a href=\"http://fashionrevolution.org/\">Fashion Revolution Week</a> will take place April 18-24 and participants are encouraged to upload their \"haulternative\" videos this year as well.</p>   <p>Some companies are experimenting with new ideas. <a href=\"https://www.renttherunway.com/unlimited?nav_location=submenu&amp;action=click_about_unlimited&amp;object_type=top_nav\">Rent The Runway</a>, for example, rents out branded clothes to customers who pay a monthly fee. Those concerned about the mounting waste hopped onto an opposing concept: Instead of buying cheap clothes, invest in slightly costly clothes with good quality that might last you longer. The <a href=\"http://www.npr.org/2016/03/13/470314387/this-jacket-will-last-30-years-guaranteed\">30-year-sweatshirt by Tom Cridland</a> is an example.</p>   <p><a href=\"http://sfenvironment.org/news/press-release/san-francisco-launches-zero-waste-textile-initiative-to-keep-apparel-footwear-linens-out-of-the-landfill\">San Francisco was aware</a> of this problem in 2002 \u2014 and pledged a goal of reaching zero waste by 2020 by encouraging the recycling of clothes, shoes and linen.</p>   <p>\"I think for clothing, because we're a consumer culture, it's hard for me to say don't buy anything,\" Lewis says. \"We can probably slow down how much we buy.\"</p>\n</div>\n </div></body></html>"}, "15429884": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:38:52", "url": "https://blog.brakmic.com/bitcoin-internals-part-2/", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"entry-content \"><p class=\"readingtime_text\">12 minutes read</p><p/>  <p><span>In this installment we\u2019ll be talking about <strong>Transactions</strong>. As we already know a Bitcoin Block contains a <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/primitives/block.h#L23\">Header </a>and a collection of <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/primitives/block.h#L76\">Transactions</a>. We\u2019ve already learned about how important Headers are and how they constitute a back-linked <em>block-chain</em> that helps to maintain the integrity of recorded transactions. Now the two new questions are: W<em>hat does a Transaction look like? </em><strong>and</strong> <em>How do we use it to transfer coins from address to address</em>? And just like in the previous article I\u2019ll be presenting a simplified C++ code here, while the real C++ code will be pointed to via links to <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin\">Bitcoin\u2019s GitHub repository</a>.</span></p><h3><span>Transaction\u2019s Structure</span></h3><p><span>Without wanting to make your reading experience more complicated than it already is, I\u2019ll start with the unpleasant fact first: actually, there are <strong>two types</strong> of <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/primitives/transaction.h#L264\">transactions</a>! <em>Regular</em> ones and C<em>oinbase\u00a0</em>Transactions. And they can be found in each block, side by side. And yes, there\u2019s a reason for that, but before we go any deeper into that matter, let\u2019s first examine the regular transaction\u2019s structure only. This will surely help us a lot to understand more easily the <em>Coinbase</em> Transactions later.</span></p><p/><table><tbody><tr><td>\u00a0<span><strong>Field</strong></span></td><td>\u00a0<span><strong>Role</strong></span></td><td>\u00a0<span><strong>Type</strong></span></td></tr><tr><td><span>Version</span></td><td><span>Indicates the Transaction Format Version</span></td><td><span>numeric</span></td></tr><tr><td><span>NumberOfInputs</span></td><td><span> Number of Entries in the Collection of Inputs</span></td><td><span>numeric</span></td></tr><tr><td><span>CollectionOfInputs</span></td><td><span>Collection Input Entries (BTCs <em>to redeem</em>)</span></td><td><span>vector of objects</span></td></tr><tr><td><span>NumberOfOutputs</span></td><td><span>Number of Entries in the Collection of Outputs</span></td><td><span> numeric</span></td></tr><tr><td><span>CollectionOfOutputs</span></td><td><span>Collection of Output Entries (BTCs <em>to spend</em>)</span></td><td><span> vector of objects</span></td></tr><tr><td><span>LockTimestamp</span></td><td><span>Time-Window <em>allowing the Transactions to be replaced</em> in this Block\u00a0</span></td><td><span> numeric</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><span>At the first sight this complex structure isn\u2019t in any way helping us to understand how a BTC can find its way from sender to recipient. However, if we recall that \u201c<em>Bitcoin thinks in Transactions only</em>\u201d then the whole structure becomes a little clearer. Bitcoin has no senders, recipients or any kind of entities that own BTCs. Transactions are the only available entity that can be used <strong>to reclaim a possession of bitcoins</strong>! </span></p><p><span>Therefore, to send a BTC to an address we first have to prove that we\u2019ve successfully redeemed this BTC from a <em>previous </em>Transaction<em> output</em>\u00a0that\u2019s now a Transaction\u00a0<em>input</em>\u00a0in the current Block. Or more technically: to be able to put a certain amount of BTC into the <em>output</em> vector of our Block we must have been able to redeem the same amount of BTC from some <em>previous output</em>\u00a0vector. It doesn\u2019t have to be a single output as only the final amount of BTC counts. We could also have redeemed BTCs from several previous Transaction outputs just to create a single Transaction output in our own Block. <strong>What\u2019s important is the equilibrium between the incoming and outgoing amounts of BTC</strong>.
