Therefore, to understand how those two collections work together we have to dissect their structures as well.</span></p><h3><span>Transaction Inputs &amp; Outputs</span></h3><p><span>A <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/primitives/transaction.h#L61\">Transaction Input</a> is a structure that comprises of a <em>hash key</em>, an <em>index number</em>, <em>signature script length </em>indicator, the <em>response script,</em>\u00a0and an <em>input sequence number</em>.</span></p><p/><p><span>The first two values, <strong>hash key</strong> and <strong>index number</strong>, are being used together to uniquely identify some previous output we want to redeem in our own Transaction. As we\u2019ve already approached hashes in the previous article, and also have used them to uniquely identify our blocks, the question here is: <em>Why do we need hashes and index numbers within transactions</em>? Let\u2019s look at the structure of Transactions in the picture below:</span></p><p><a href=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/transaction_inputs_outputs-1.png\" class=\"grouped_elements\" rel=\"tc-fancybox-group1466\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-1478\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" data-src=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/transaction_inputs_outputs-1.png\" alt=\"\" data-srcset=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/transaction_inputs_outputs-1.png 877w, http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/transaction_inputs_outputs-1-300x238.png 300w, http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/transaction_inputs_outputs-1-768x609.png 768w\" data-sizes=\"(max-width: 877px) 100vw, 877px\"/></a></p><p><span>As we can easily recognize a <span><strong>Transaction hash key</strong></span> alone wouldn\u2019t be precise enough to select the correct input BTC within a certain transaction. A collection of outputs within a Transaction mostly contains many entries, so we have to point at the right<span><strong> index number</strong></span> within. In the above picture we see a single entry in the left box but there could be hundreds of them. In the right box we see the Transaction input collection that points back to the previous Transaction output collection by selecting one of its entries by using an index number. This is how we create new Transactions:\u00a0</span></p><p><span>a) Refer to a previous Transaction by using its <strong>Hash Key</strong> (<strong><span>green</span></strong>)</span></p><p><span>b) Redeem certain Bitcoins by using <strong>index number</strong>(s) to point to one or more entries that belong to previous\u2019 Transaction output collection (<strong><span>red</span></strong>)</span></p><p><span>c) Create a <strong>new entry in your own Transaction input collection</strong> (this effectively makes incoming BTCs\u00a0<em>available to you</em>, because you can now create <em>new entries</em> in your own Transaction outputs)</span></p><p><span>We remember, <em>Bitcoin thinks in transactions only</em> and the above process is the way how Bitcoin\u2019s blockchain moves BTC from one address to another. Before you can spend any Satoshi you must first point to it in any of the previous transactions and deliver <em>a proof that you\u2019re its owner</em>.\u00a0</span></p><h3>Ownership</h3><p><span>Now that we\u2019ve learned how a certain BTC can be found on the blockchain the next question that comes to mind is: <em>How do we safely store and redeem our BTCs</em>? </span></p><p><span>The answer lies in the entries from the above structure I deliberately avoided to describe: <em>Public Key Script</em>, <em>Response Script</em>, and their<em> length indicators</em>. Each time one claims to be the owner of some BTC a certain script will be executed to check if the claimant can provide needed signatures to redeem and/or spend those BTC. And following the nature of Bitcoin this too is done via Transactions only. This is the reason why transaction inputs &amp; outputs contain certain scripts. However, they don\u2019t get executed like those scripts from our operating systems, for example. Blockchain scripts aren\u2019t shell-scripts or Batch-files. Quite the opposite. <em>Input and output scripts must be executed pairwise</em>. This is because every output script imposes a <em>certain challenge</em> to be <em>solved</em> by its input counterpart. </span></p><p><span>Described in a more simplistic terms, an <strong>output script</strong>\u00a0defines a <em>challenge</em>: \u201c<em>this 1BTC belongs to anyone who is in possession of a private key that can generate this signature I\u2019m carrying with me</em>\u201c. On the other side, the input script would solve this challenge by executing its own script-part thus generating data for comparison. Therefore, the BTC claimed in any input script can be taken from an output script by providing a solution to a certain challenge. We could describe Blockchain as a chain of back-linked blocks that supports a flow of values chained together by back-linked challenge/response scripts.\u00a0\u00a0</span></p><p><a href=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/input_output_scripts.png\" class=\"grouped_elements\" rel=\"tc-fancybox-group1466\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-1482\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" data-src=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/input_output_scripts.png\" alt=\"\" data-srcset=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/input_output_scripts.png 783w, http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/input_output_scripts-300x211.png 300w, http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/input_output_scripts-768x540.png 768w\" data-sizes=\"(max-width: 783px) 100vw, 783px\"/></a></p><h3>Script</h3><p><span>However, we\u2019re not done yet as there\u2019s something else that must be used to process those scripts: <a href=\"https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Script\"><strong>Bitcoin\u2019s Scripting Language</strong></a> itself. Yes, it\u2019s true, Bitcoin has it\u2019s own scripting language. It actually has no specific name, so everyone calls it simply \u201cScript\u201d. It is a programming language but not like the most of those in use today. It\u2019s not a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_completeness\">turing-complete language</a> which means that you can\u2019t write programs or arbitrary complexity, for example those that contain <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_flow#Loops\">loops</a>. The inventor of Bitcoin, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto\">Satoshi Nakamoto</a>, didn\u2019t want Bitcoin to rely on a language that could be (mis)used to execute any kinds of programs. Just imagine a script containing a never ending <em>for-loop</em>\u00a0thus effectively postponing all other operations on the Blockchain to some later date around the end of the known Universe. <em>Bye, bye Bitcoin</em>! </span></p><p><span>Therefore, certain powerful concepts, like loops, have been deliberately excluded from Script\u2019s design. However, do not think that Script is a \u201ccrippled\u201d language incapable of doing anything meaningful. It\u2019s actually very flexible one as it comprises of several powerful commands for fast signature evaluation, de/encryption, verification and so on. We won\u2019t be discussing Script in this installment as it deserves an article on its own. What\u2019s important to know is that during each transaction a certain amount of logic (a <em>program</em>) gets evaluated by using a scripting engine that runs on Bitcoin\u2019s blockchain.</span></p><h3>Coinbase Transactions</h3><p><span>So, after having learned about transactions and how we can move Bitcoins from address to address the whole Blockchain \u201cstuff\u201d should be no problem for you anymore, isn\u2019t it? Well, one thing is missing and this is the<em> actual creation of bitcoins</em>? Where do bitcoins come from? Is there any \u201cprimal transaction\u201d that has created all bitcoins in the past? Well, the answer is no. Bitcoins have not been pre-generated in some distant past, but they continuously get created by <em>mining new Blocks</em>. Each and every Block contains a special transaction called <strong>Coinbase Transaction</strong> whose sole purpose is <em>to generate new bitcoins</em> without resorting to some previous output Transaction entry. Unlike \u201cnormal\u201d transactions that contain certain challenge scripts that have to be solved by response scripts, those new bitcoins come out of nothing and therefore have never had any previous \u201cholders\u201d. </span></p><p><span>Bitcoin\u2019s blockchain needs new blocks<em> to stay alive</em>. But those blocks don\u2019t get generated because \u201cit\u2019s funny\u201d to create them, or because Bitcoin is some nice \u201csocial network\u201d that everyone wants to participate in. Bitcoin and it\u2019s blockchain constitute a <strong>real business</strong> that generates billions of dollars/euros/whatever-fiat. And these days we need lots and lots of computing power to mine new blocks. Certain entities, mostly big companies, who are capable of producing and/or installing specialized hardware for mining blocks, want to be rewarded for their work. And their rewards are those new bitcoins from Coinbase Transactions. Therefore, whenever a new block gets mined the miner who has created this block will add a special transaction and assign a certain amount of bitcoins to him/herself. This is the reward for the miner who has taken care of including our transactions, executing our scripts, and forwarding our bitcoins from address to address. This whole process is vital for Bitcoin to exist. Without mining no blocks can be created and without proper rewards no one would want to mine Blocks in the first place. Therefore, think of BTCs in Coinbase transactions as <em>incentives to create blocks</em>. Because every miner wants to be the one who inserts its own address into the <em>Coinbase Transaction Output</em> the competition keeps the system alive. </span></p><p><span>Bitcoin users want to move their bitcoins around and miners want to get fresh bitcoins. And not only coinbase BTCs, because miners also get a certain share of BTCs for each transaction they put into new Blocks. This is called a \u201ctransaction fee\u201d. All in all, Bitcoin is not only a technology, but also a <em>social contract</em> that comprises of certain entities and incentives.</span></p><p/><p><span>Now the first question regarding the above code would be: <em>Why does the Coinbase Transaction contain Hash and Output Index values if there\u2019s no need to redeem some previous output BTCs</em>? The answer is simple: The values are the same for all Coinbase transactions. Hash value is always <strong>0</strong> and index is<strong> 2\u00b3\u00b2-1</strong>. </span></p><p><span>The really important part is the Coinbase Script that stores the current <em>block height</em> which means <strong>the number of the current block</strong>. If you imagine the blockchain as a sequence of stacked blocks the current height would be <em>the block on top</em> this stack. Additionally, the Coinbase Script can contain arbitrary data that is also being used to generate more randomness which is used when solving the Proof-Of-Work puzzle. </span></p><p><span>In this article we won\u2019t be talking about Proof-Of-Work, so just keep in mind that miners can use the available <em>free store</em> inside the Coinbase Script to create <em>additional data</em> that helps them get <em>more randomness</em> which is of great importance when solving Proof-Of-Work puzzles.</span></p><p><a href=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/coinbase_transaction.png\" class=\"grouped_elements\" rel=\"tc-fancybox-group1466\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-1485\" src=\"data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7\" data-src=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/coinbase_transaction.png\" alt=\"\" data-srcset=\"http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/coinbase_transaction.png 382w, http://blog.brakmic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/coinbase_transaction-178x300.png 178w\" data-sizes=\"(max-width: 382px) 100vw, 382px\"/></a></p><p><span>In the above image we see that each time a new Coinbase Transaction is created the miner inserts a new challenge script that\u2019ll be used later to redeem those new BTC. As a Coinbase Transaction takes no already existing bitcoins but introduces new ones, anyone who can provide a solution to the Challenge Script is the owner of new BTC. This is usually the miner itself. </span></p><p><span>And the last question we have to answer in this article is: <em>How many BTC a miner is allowed to assign to itself</em>? The answer is: I<em>t depends</em>. There is a <a href=\"https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/chainparams.cpp#L77\">hard-coded rule</a> that controls the current mining subsidy. Every 21000 Blocks, or roughly 4 years, the subsidy halves. At the beginning of Bitcoin, in 2009, the subsidy was 50BTC per Block. It then halved in 2012 to 25BTC. Currently, the subsidy is 12,5BTC per Block. </span></p><p><span>Additionally, the miner assigns a certain amount of transaction fees collected from the transactions included in this block. The whole sum is what miners expect to get when mining new blocks. This is how bitcoins come into existence. And the maximum amount of all bitcoins that can be created will be slightly less than <a href=\"https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Controlled_supply\">21.000.000</a>.\u00a0</span></p><h3>Conclusion</h3><p><span>I hope that the whole process of creating Transactions, moving BTC around, and mining Blocks is now a little bit clearer. I know, the technique behind is complex and not that easy to explain, so we can only consume it bit by bit. In future articles we\u2019ll come back to transactions, but with more details regarding the scripting language.</span></p>\n</section>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430910": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:57:05", "url": "http://www.studony.com/sony-music-entertainment-summer-internship-rca-inspiration-2018-franklin-tn-usa/", "text": "<body id=\"readabilityBody\"/>"}, "15429375": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:43:10", "url": "https://electricbikereview.com/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"review-summary-wrapper\"><p class=\"review-summary-text\"><meta itemprop=\"description\" content=\"A portable backup battery pack with one 12 volt adapter, two USB ports and two 110 volt AC standard plug outlets, integrated handle makes it easy to lift and four rubber foot pads keep it from sliding, vibrating or scratching delicate surfaces. The Nomad 20 solar panel sheet uses a magnetic clasp to stay folded and has a convenient zippered pouch on the outside to store accessory cables, plenty of loops to hang it up, multiple output cords including USB, 12 volt and Goal Zero lantern port.\"/>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tA portable backup battery pack with one 12 volt adapter, two USB ports and two 110 volt AC standard plug outlets, integrated handle makes it easy to lift and four rubber foot pads keep it from sliding, vibrating or scratching delicate surfaces. The Nomad 20 solar panel sheet uses a magnetic clasp to stay folded and has a convenient zippered pouch on the outside to store accessory cables, plenty of loops to hang it up, multiple output cords including USB, 12 volt and Goal Zero lantern port...\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15430400": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:34:29", "url": "https://www.salon.com/2017/10/07/does-modern-neuroscience-help-us-understand-behavior_partner/#.WdqcvIQh7Go.facebook", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article__body \" data-reactid=\"95\">\n<p data-reactid=\"97\">Lately, some neuroscientists <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/02/how-brain-scientists-forgot-that-brains-have-owners/517599/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"99\">have been struggling</a> with an identity crisis: what do we believe, and what do we want to achieve? Is it enough to study the brain\u2019s machinery, or are we missing its larger design?</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"102\">Scholars have pondered the mind since Aristotle, and scientists have studied the nervous system since the mid-1800s, but neuroscience as we recognize it today did not coalesce as a distinct study until the early 1960s. In the first ever Annual Review of Neuroscience, the editors recalled that in the years immediately after World War II, scientists felt a \u201cgrowing appreciation that few things are more important than understanding how the nervous system controls behavior.\u201d This \u201cgrowing appreciation\u201d brought together researchers scattered across many well-established fields \u2013 anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, psychology, medicine, behavior \u2013 and united them in the newly coined discipline of neuroscience.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"104\">It was clear to those researchers that studying the nervous system needed knowledge and techniques from many other disciplines. The <a href=\"http://museum.mit.edu/150/113\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"106\">Neuroscience</a><a href=\"http://museum.mit.edu/150/113\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"107\"> Research Program</a> at MIT, established in 1962, brought together scientists from multiple universities in an attempt to bridge neuroscience with biology, immunology, genetics, molecular biology, chemistry, and physics. The first ever Department of Neurobiology was <a href=\"http://neuro.hms.harvard.edu/about-us/history\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"109\">established</a> at Harvard in 1966 under the direction of six professors: a physician, two neurophysiologists, two neuroanatomists, and a biochemist. The first meeting of the Society for Neuroscience was held the next year, where scientists from diverse fields met to discuss and debate nervous systems and behavior, using any method they thought relevant or optimal.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"112\">These pioneers of neuroscience sought to understand the relationship between the nervous system and behavior. But what exactly is behavior? Does the nervous system actually control behavior? And when can we say that we are really \u201cunderstanding\u201d anything?<br data-reactid=\"114\"/>\n<strong data-reactid=\"116\">Behavioral questions</strong><br data-reactid=\"117\"/>\nIt may sound pedantic or philosophical to worry about definitions of \u201cbehavior,\u201d \u201ccontrol,\u201d and \u201cunderstanding.\u201d But for a field as young and diverse as neuroscience, dismissing these foundational discussions can cause a great deal of confusion, which in turn can bog down progress for years, if not decades. Unfortunately for today\u2019s neuroscientists, we rarely talk about the assumptions that underlie our research.</p>\n<aside class=\"pullquote\" data-reactid=\"120\">\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"122\"><p data-reactid=\"123\">By these definitions, we don\u2019t currently \u201cunderstand\u201d the\u00a0brain</p></blockquote>\n</aside>\n<p data-reactid=\"126\">\u201cUnderstanding,\u201d for instance, means different things to different people. For an engineer, to understand something is to be able to build it; for a physicist, to understand something is to be able to create a mathematical model that can predict it. By these definitions, we don\u2019t currently \u201cunderstand\u201d the brain \u2013 and it\u2019s unclear what kind of detective work might solve that mystery.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"128\">Many neuroscientists believe that the detective work consists of two main parts: describing in great detail the molecular bits and pieces of the brain, and causing a reliable change in behavior by changing something about those bits and pieces. From this perspective, behavior is an easily observable phenomena \u2013 one that can be used as a measurement.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"130\">But since the beginning of neuroscience, a vocal and persistent minority has argued that detective work of this kind, no matter how detailed, cannot bring us closer to \u201cunderstanding\u201d the relationship between the nervous system and behavior. The dominant, granular view of neuroscience contains several problematic assumptions about behavior, the dissenters say, in an argument most recently made earlier this year by John Krakauer, Asif Ghazanfar, Alex Gomez-Marin, Malcolm MacIver, and David Poeppel in a <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28182904\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"132\">paper</a> called \u201cNeuroscience Needs Behavior: Correcting a Reductionist Bias.\u201d</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"135\">These authors argue that if we want to understand the relationship between brains and behavior, it would clearly be better to study both: the parts of nervous systems as well as the natural behaviors that shaped its evolution and development \u2013 the behaviors that helped make the nervous system in the first place. Most neuroscience today places a premium on extremely detailed recordings of the smaller components of nervous systems, such as tagging proteins on cell membranes to better photograph single neurons, or building tiny assemblies of metal pins to measure the electrical activity in a region of the brain. Unfortunately, as the authors note, much less value has been placed on the rigorous and detailed study of behavior. Why is there so little interest in nurturing the study of behavior, and such intense interest in detailing the nervous system?</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"137\">The authors suspect a twofold problem: relationships are difficult to study, and technology seems more rewarding in the short term. Understanding the relationship between nervous systems and behavior is undeniably hard. Progress can be slow and challenging to evaluate. On the other hand, exciting advanced technology has made it possible to study the components of brains in unprecedented detail. Technical advances come quickly and with clear, data-based measurements, but their methods often favor simple, data-driven verification questions over knotty, more conceptual questions about behavior.</p>\n<aside class=\"pullquote\" data-reactid=\"139\">\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"141\"><p data-reactid=\"142\">Individual or even groups of neurons cannot see, feel, think, or behave, and yet neuroscientists often talk about them as if they\u00a0can</p></blockquote>\n</aside>\n<p data-reactid=\"145\">These speedy, seemingly clear rewards have convinced many neuroscientists that studying the properties and interactions of individual cells is the best path towards understanding the nervous system and behavior. But just because <a href=\"https://www.nature.com/news/neuroscientists-rethink-how-the-brain-recognizes-faces-1.22091\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"147\">certain neurons</a> in a monkey\u2019s brain change their electrical activity <a href=\"https://massivesci.com/articles/facial-recognition-patches-brain-macaque/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"149\">when that monkey sees a face</a> doesn\u2019t mean that those neurons can \u201crecognize\u201d a face. They are just one tiny part of the process that the whole monkey uses to recognize faces. In other words, scientists can sometimes forget that \u201cthe whole is greater than the sum of its parts,\u201d and that a brain is just part of a human being, not unlike a stomach or a heart. Individual or even groups of neurons cannot see, feel, think, or behave, and yet neuroscientists often talk about them as if they can.<br data-reactid=\"151\"/>\n<strong data-reactid=\"153\">The pull of \u2018publish or perish\u2019</strong><br data-reactid=\"154\"/>\nThe siren call of technology isn\u2019t the only reason why this narrow view of neuroscience seems attractive to researchers. Society, too, creates incentives for researchers to limit their projects. For one, a great deal of money is tied up in developing the technology behind neuroscience tools, and money makes experiments go round. Scientists understandably <a href=\"https://massivesci.com/articles/science-correction-pains-compounds/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"156\">can\u2019t ignore the politics</a> around money.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"159\">Additionally, neuroscience PhD programs have too often become a race to publish as many times as possible, in all the \u201ccorrect\u201d places and with all the \u201cright\u201d people. In order to survive in academia, neuroscientists often have to pass the particular muster of journal editors, who frequently reject behavioral studies for \u201cnot having enough neuro,\u201d as <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/02/how-brain-scientists-forgot-that-brains-have-owners/517599/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"161\">Ghazanfar said in a recent interview</a>, \u201cas if every paper needs to be a methodological decathlon in order to be considered important.\u201d</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"164\">Addressing these points will require a great deal of change, both in science and in society, and history again provides some clues for how we might be better detectives.<br data-reactid=\"166\"/>\n<strong data-reactid=\"168\">Body as a sensor</strong><br data-reactid=\"169\"/>\nIn 1973, psychologist and control theory engineer William T. Powers argued that instead of assuming that brains control behavior based on sensory stimuli, it makes more sense to assume that brains adapt behavior to control what stimuli it gets from the world. Put another way, if we consider \u201cthe body\u201d (a.k.a. all of our parts that aren\u2019t the nervous system) to be the brain\u2019s sensors, then \u201cthe behavior\u201d that we see is the brain moving its sensors so that it can get the input it wants.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"172\">For instance, when we wish to cross the street, we turn our head so that our eyes can look for any oncoming traffic; when we\u2019re in a conversation with a quiet talker, we lean our bodies in and direct our ears towards the speaker to better hear their words. In all these situations, we have a goal, and we move our bodies in order to get the sensory input that lets us achieve our goal.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"174\">Powers\u2019 framework grants that there can be movements without a purpose, but for a movement to be considered behavior it must have a purpose. Thus if we want to study behavior, we need a way to distinguish between behavior and all possible movements. How can we do this?<br data-reactid=\"176\"/>\n<strong data-reactid=\"178\">A new way forward</strong><br data-reactid=\"179\"/>\nThis is where the study of animals, moving freely in their ecological niches, becomes crucial to validate any neuroscientific study of behavior. While we can safely assume that one of the goals of every living creature is to not die, we know from our own experience as humans that survival alone is hardly satisfying: we want, in addition to not dying, to feel safe, healthy, productive, fulfilled.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"182\">Why do factors as subjective as our preferences matter in the quest to understand the nervous system? Powers emphasized that any theory or model of the nervous system must be consistent with our subjective experience of living with one. Thus, detailed descriptions of these two factors \u2013 our subjective life experiences, and the behaviors of free humans and animals \u2013 are just as important as detailed descriptions of nervous systems, because they teach us about the goals of the brain under our study, and thus allow us to pick out behaviors from movements.</p>\n<aside class=\"pullquote\" data-reactid=\"184\">\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"186\"><p data-reactid=\"187\">If we are trying to understand the relationship between thing A (nervous systems) and thing B (behavior), we would do well to study both things with close\u00a0detail.</p></blockquote>\n</aside>\n<p data-reactid=\"190\">Neuroscience isn\u2019t entirely lacking in the kind of detective work that Powers advocates. Neurologist <a href=\"http://www.radiolab.org/story/remembering-oliver-sacks/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"192\">Oliver Sacks</a>\u2019 meticulous notes on his neurological patients\u2019 case histories revealed extraordinary insights into some of the most puzzling aspects of brain function, such as <a href=\"https://www.painscience.com/articles/sixth-sense.php\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"194\">proprioception</a> (knowing where your body parts are without having to look at them), <a href=\"https://www.aphasia.org/stories/happy-birthday-oliver-sacks/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"196\">aphasia</a> (the inability to comprehend or express thoughts through language), and <a href=\"http://www.npr.org/2010/12/03/131785460/Oliver-Sacks-Discusses-Vision-and-The-Mind-s-Eye\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"198\">blindsight</a> (the ability to respond to visual stimuli without consciously seeing). Many of Sacks\u2019 patients were referred to him after they were deemed too difficult to diagnose by other methods. Another example is zoologist Konrad Lorenz\u2019s extensive use of photography and film to research the evolution of behavior. He used <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eqZmW7uIPW4\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"200\">these</a> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eqZmW7uIPW4\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"202\">films</a> not just for analyzing behavior but also to share his observations more fully while teaching or giving talks; if a picture is worth a thousand words, a film can convey things that escape verbal description.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"205\">More of this kind of detective work is urgently needed. The stark differences in how different neuroscientists understand behavior causes enormous confusion and frustration, especially among incoming PhD students. In the current training of neuroscientists, most PhD programs do not discuss the history or goals of modern academic neuroscience. But if we are trying to understand the relationship between thing A (nervous systems) and thing B (behavior), we would do well to study both things with close detail. And if we don\u2019t want to be hindered by potentially false assumptions, we need to be clear about proposed relationships, because that very first assumption will decide exactly what we label as \u201cdata\u201d versus \u201cnoise\u201d.</p>\n<p class=\"oembed\" data-reactid=\"207\"/>\n<p data-reactid=\"209\"><strong data-reactid=\"210\">Lessons from history</strong><br data-reactid=\"211\"/>\nThe past shows us where neuroscience has been and how we can move forward. We first assumed that nervous systems control behavior, then realized flaws in that framework. If the nervous system is just driving behavior, the way a person can drive a car, then studying the parts of the person won\u2019t explain how the car works, or why the person is driving in a particular direction. This idea also recalls the endlessly regressive <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homunculus_argument\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"213\">homunculus argument</a>, where the hard questions \u2013 \u201chow does this behavior happen?\u201d \u2013 are delayed by creating one black box inside another, one mystery just beyond the grasp of the one right in front of you.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"216\">Perhaps it\u2019s time for neuroscience to try out a new paradigm. Even if there is no doubt that neuroscience needs sophisticated technological tools, we need equally sophisticated models of how the many parts of nervous systems work together to make our movements serve specific goals. Already, we can sometimes become lost in the struggle to interpret the sea of data delivered by our tools. It\u2019s time to turn toward new models of the nervous system based on an adjusted set of assumptions.<br data-reactid=\"218\"/>\n<strong data-reactid=\"220\">Peer Commentary</strong><br data-reactid=\"221\"/>\nWe asked other neuroscientists to respond with some commentary to this article. In a very small way, this is how peer-review works in scientific journals. We wanted to give you a taste of what scientific discussion looks like! If you want to know more, feel free to contact the scientists directly via Twitter.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"224\"><a href=\"https://massivesci.com/people/benjamin-bell/\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"225\">Benjamin Bell</a>: This is a really interesting walk through the foundations of neuroscience. But I somewhat disagree with one of the authors\u2019 main assertions, where they claim that researchers focus primarily on the molecular components of the nervous system at the cost of a careful analysis of behavior.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"228\">In my experience, much of modern neuroscience actually works off the behavioral model: researchers carefully study a specific behavior in a model animal and then perturb certain regions or components of its brain and observe the effects on behavior. Just for an example, basically the entire field of sleep research is based on this model.</p>\n<p data-reactid=\"230\">Still, I do agree with the authors that this still takes the shape of a reductionist approach. In order to really understand the relationships between neural mechanisms and behavior, we have to carefully examine only one small aspect of a behavior in the lab. But in nature, this action would be many times more complex and involve much more functionality than we are equipped to measure currently. I fully agree that reductionism in the lab is losing the forest for the trees, but I suspect in order to truly understand the brain, we will need to first break it down into the smallest of cause-effect components possible, and only afterwards we can begin to understand the larger frameworks of the mind.</p>\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"232\"><p data-reactid=\"233\">Kim responds: We\u2019re not saying manipulating the brain is not useful, only that we should know what our assumptions are.</p></blockquote>\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"235\"><p data-reactid=\"236\">We are concerned with the assumption that changes in behavior are caused by perturbing certain regions/components of the brain, which implies that the brain doesn\u2019t respond and change when an external force perturbs it. This perspective on behavior doesn\u2019t account for what we know about the evolution and development of the nervous system, in particular phenomena such as neuroplasticity.</p></blockquote>\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"238\"><p data-reactid=\"239\">The current \u201cbehavioral\u201d methods try to assign \u201cfunction\u201d to circuits by assuming those circuits are fixed and rigid, but this is actually a very important difference between nervous systems and computers, our current favorite analogy for the brain. We now know that nervous systems change and adapt their own structure and physiology all the time. If our goal is to understand behavior by manipulating neural circuits, we need to be much more strict about the assumptions underlying our manipulations, because we aren\u2019t the only ones making manipulations -- the nervous system is also making manipulations on itself.</p></blockquote>\n<blockquote data-reactid=\"241\"><p data-reactid=\"242\">I completely agree that if \u201cbehavior\u201d means any movement output of the organism, studying behavior in the wild would be entirely intractable. We believe that behaviors are movements that serve a purpose for the organism, and the defining aspect of a behavior is not the specific motor output but the goal.</p></blockquote>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429423": {"score": 2, "comments": ["Hello - yes we do. Email andy at thissprint.com", "This looks pretty useful. Are you able to also do the actual research and just report the results?"], "time": "2017-10-08 22:01:02", "url": "https://www.thissprint.com/", "text": "<html><body/></html>"}, "15430403": {"score": 2, "comments": ["Dupe: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=15428277\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;news.ycombinator.com&#x2F;item?id=15428277</a>"], "time": "2017-10-09 01:35:02", "url": "https://thenewstack.io/linkedin-code-review/?utm_content=buffer77b44&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-content\">\n\t\t\t\t<p><em>\u00a0LinkedIn recently passed the milestone of having conducted one million code reviews. The head of the social networking service\u2019s tooling shared a few learned lessons along the way.</em></p>\n<p>Reading and reviewing code is something every engineer does on a daily basis. A formal code review process, however, is a bit different \u2014 it requires every code change to be officially reviewed by another team member before the code goes to production. At LinkedIn, code reviews have been a mandatory part of our development process since 2011. Our goal in requiring code reviews was to scale our rapidly-growing engineering team as smoothly as possible. Good code reviews with meaningful, useful comments can really help with leveling up an entire engineering organization. At LinkedIn, these reviews have become an essential part of quality assurance and knowledge sharing. Embracing code reviews has changed our whole engineering culture for the better in several key ways.</p>\n<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/szczepiq/\" class=\"clearfix infoBlock\" target=\"_blank\">\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"infoBlockTextBlock\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<p class=\"infoBlockTitle\">Szczepan Faber</p>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p class=\"infoBlockText\">Since 2015, Szczepan Faber has been a Tech Lead for LinkedIn Development Tools, the team responsible for tools and workflows that ensure engineering productivity. From 2011-2015, he was core engineer of Gradle 1.x and 2.x., a leading build and automation framework. Szczepan created Mockito framework in 2007, one of the most popular Java libraries, with an estimated user base of 2 million.</p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t</a>\n<p>One of the biggest benefits of implementing company-wide code reviews has been increased standardization in our development workflow. Every team at LinkedIn uses the same tools and process for doing code reviews, which means that anyone can help with reviewing or contributing code for another team\u2019s project. This eliminates problems like \u201cI could fix the bug in their code, but how would I build that code and submit the fix?\u201d This, in turn, helps increase collaboration across different teams in the engineering organization.</p>\n<p>By making code reviews a mandatory process, we\u2019ve also helped foster a healthy feedback culture at the company: engineers are open to giving and receiving feedback in all areas of work, not just in coding because it\u2019s become a routine component of the job. Rather than viewing code reviews as critical or negative, our engineers use both giving and receiving code reviews as opportunities to grow professionally. In fact, high-quality code reviews are an important part of LinkedIn\u2019s promotion process because they provide objective evidence of engineering skill.</p>\n<p>Over the years, we\u2019ve honed several best practices and tips for how to give truly great reviews. Below are some guidelines, in the form of questions, that we suggest asking to help make sure the reviewer and reviewee are getting the most value possible out of a code review.</p>\n<h3>Do I Understand the \u201cWhy\u201d?</h3>\n<p>To facilitate the best review possible and help your team scale, every code change submission should include a design overview that briefly explains the motivation behind the change. It is really hard to offer a high-quality code review when the rationale needs to be inferred from the code change itself. It is fair to ask and expect the submitter to explain their motivation before attempting the code review. This also encourages the submitter to have an explanation in their commit message, increasing the quality of code documentation.</p>\n<h3>Am I Giving Positive Feedback?</h3>\n<p>In an organization full of smart people, clean code and neat test coverage can be taken for granted. As a result, code review feedback tends to focus only on problems and issues found in the code. This is very unfortunate because most people need positive feedback to feel engaged and motivated \u2014 and engineers are no exception. When a reviewer sees good stuff in the code, they should call it out and give positive feedback. This helps improve team dynamics, and often such positive feedback is contagious. As with all code review comments (more on this below), any positive feedback should be specific, explaining why that particular code is well-written.</p>\n<h3>Is My Code Review Comment Explained Well?</h3>\n<p>Whether the feedback is positive or negative, any code review comment should be self-explanatory. What might seem obvious to the reviewer can be unclear to an engineer who receives poorly-explained code review comments. When in doubt, it is better to over-explain than to provide terse feedback that yields more questions and the need for more back-and-forth communication. Explanations can be as simple as \u201creduces duplication,\u201d \u201cimproves coverage,\u201d or \u201cmakes code easier to test.\u201d In addition to making reviewers\u2019 comments clearer, these types of explanations also help reinforce the design principles that the team aspires to meet.</p>\n<h3>Do I Appreciate the Submitter\u2019s Effort?</h3>\n<p>Hard work always needs to be appreciated, regardless of the outcome \u2014 this fosters strong, highly motivated teams. Some code changes are not of the highest quality and will need to be reworked. In those situations, it\u2019s important to still acknowledge the effort that the author put into the changes, even if their code needs reworking. The best way to show appreciation is to put effort into your code review by giving high-quality feedback with decent explanations, acknowledging the good ideas (there are always good things in every code submission!), and using \u201cthank you.\u201d</p>\n<h3>Would This Review Comment Be Useful to Me?</h3>\n<p>Asking this question is an easy and powerful way to validate if the code review comment is necessary. At the end of the day, engineers should view code reviews as helpful development tools, and not sources of unimportant busywork. If you don\u2019t think a particular review comment would be useful to you, then remove it. A classic example of unhelpful code review comments are ones related to code formatting. Code style and formatting should be validated by automated tools, not engineers.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews.png\" class=\"ext-image\" rel=\"external nofollow\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-3155336\" src=\"https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews.png\" alt=\"\" data-id=\"3155336\" srcset=\"https://thenewstack.io/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews.png 860w, https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews-295x300.png 295w, https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews-32x32.png 32w, https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews-50x50.png 50w, https://storage.googleapis.com/cdn.thenewstack.io/media/2017/09/efa28730-codereviews-64x64.png 64w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 860px) 100vw, 860px\"/></a></p>\n<h3>Is the \u201cTesting Done\u201d Section Thorough Enough?</h3>\n<p>At LinkedIn, every code change submission has a mandatory \u201ctesting done\u201d section that needs to be filled out. In the open source world, using GitHub as an example, engineers can submit \u201ctesting done\u201d information in the pull request description. What should be in \u201ctesting done\u201d depends on the gravity of the changes and the current level of test coverage. If the change contains new or altered conditional complexity, it is fair to expect it to be covered in unit tests. Some changes may require running manual testing if the integration test coverage is inadequate. In those cases, \u201ctesting done\u201d should include information about the test scenarios and the outputs. When changes alter the output of the program, it is very useful to include the new output in the \u201ctesting done\u201d section.</p>\n<h3>Am I Too Pedantic in My Review?</h3>\n<p>Some code reviews have so many comments that important issues \u2014 ones that really need to be fixed \u2014 are lost among less important suggestions. Reviews that are too heavy on details for a given team can slow down the review cycle and cause friction for both the reviewers and reviewee. Having clear review expectations, example reviews, and a positive, inviting review culture are great ways to avoid lengthy, exhausting review cycles.</p>\n<p>In summary, having a formal code review process helps improve code quality, team learning, and knowledge sharing. The quality of work increases when every engineer on the team realizes two important things: someone else will read my code, so it better be good, and I\u2019ll have to address any review comments I receive, so I should try to make my code good the first time around to save myself effort later on. When code reviews become an everyday habit, the team practices giving and receiving feedback on a daily basis. This is key for growth and improvement.</p>\n<p>At LinkedIn, we\u2019ve learned a lot from the past one million code reviews, and we aspire to learn even more from the next million. The more effort that\u2019s put into code reviews, the better a team gets at giving great code reviews, the higher the quality of code that is checked in, and the higher the quality of the product that\u2019s built. High-quality code reviews are contagious!</p>\n<p><em>The author thanks James Miller, Oscar Bonilla, Joshua Olson, Andrew Macleod, Scott Meyer, and Deep Majumder for insightful feedback on this article.</em></p>\n<p class=\"attribution\">LinkedIn\u2019s parent company, Microsoft, is a sponsor of The New Stack.</p>\n<p class=\"attribution\">Feature image\u00a0by\u00a0<a href=\"https://unsplash.com/photos/VwFR0ruXR3g?utm_source=unsplash&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_content=creditCopyText\" class=\"ext-link\" rel=\"external nofollow\">JJ Ying</a>\u00a0on\u00a0<a href=\"https://unsplash.com/?utm_source=unsplash&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_content=creditCopyText\" class=\"ext-link\" rel=\"external nofollow\">Unsplash.</a></p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\n\t\t\t\n\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429892": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:39:38", "url": "https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/10/nasa-moon-mars/542340/?single_page=true", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n    \n        <p class=\"injector-promo-wrapper--article-top js-inject-promo\"/>\n        \n\n        <section id=\"article-section-1\"><p dir=\"ltr\">Rumors that the Trump administration was more interested in the moon than Mars began circulating days after the inauguration. Leaked memos published in February <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/02/trump-space-policy-takes-shape/516123/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'0',r'542340'\">revealed</a> the president\u2019s advisers wanted NASA to send astronauts there by 2020, one part in a bigger plan to focus on activities near Earth rather than missions deeper in the solar system. Vice President Mike Pence <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/6/15929084/mike-pence-nasa-speech-us-space-policy-mars\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'1',r'542340'\">spoke</a> vaguely of a return to the moon in a speech in July. In September, the administration <a href=\"http://mashable.com/2017/09/01/nasa-administrator-nominee-moon-james-bridenstine/#sVh__8rXyPq5\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'2',r'542340'\">nominated</a> a NASA chief who extolled the construction of lunar outposts. All signs pointed to a significant shift in the country\u2019s Mars-focused space agenda of the last seven years.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">This week, the Trump administration made it official.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">\u201cWe will return NASA astronauts to the moon\u2014not only to leave behind footprints and flags, but to build the foundation we need to send Americans to Mars and beyond,\u201d Pence said Thursday at the inaugural meeting of the National Space Council, an advisory body his administration <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/03/national-space-council-donald-trump/520725/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'3',r'542340'\">recently revived</a>.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxinjector-wrapper\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxinjector1\" targeting-pos=\"boxinjector1\" class=\"ad ad-boxinjector\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"1\" data-object-name=\"boxinjector\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [300, 350], [1, 3], [320, 520], [320, 430], [1, 4], [1, 1], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[760, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1050, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1024, 350], [1, 3], [1600, 520], [1000, 350], [1600, 500], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-2\"><p dir=\"ltr\">The vice president\u2019s comments marked a pivot from Barack Obama\u2019s directive for a \u201cJourney to Mars,\u201d established in 2010, and harkens to the aspirations set forth by the George W. Bush administration. The Obama administration had maintained that some kind of human activity in cislunar space\u2014the region between the Earth and the moon\u2014was <a href=\"http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/organizations/nasa/nasa-human-spaceflight-plans-focus-announcement-deep-space-gateway\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'4',r'542340'\">necessary to test technology</a> for a mission to Mars, but the efforts would amount to a pit stop, not a destination. While Pence did not provide details on what kind of \u201cfoundation\u201d Americans would build on the moon, the new direction was clear: Americans should be spending more time in their cosmic backyard before flying off into the solar system.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">\u201cIt\u2019s a 180-degree shift from no moon to moon first,\u201d said John Logsdon, a space-policy expert and former director of the Space-Policy Institute at George Washington University.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">The announcement is obviously good news for space-transportation companies and lunar researchers lamenting the country\u2019s 45-year absence from the moon. For those in the Mars camp, many of whom aim for a human mission to the planet by 2033, the news puts their ambitions on shakier ground.</p><aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\" dir=\"ltr\">\u201cMost of the people who are Mars-centered worry that we\u2019ll get stuck on the moon.\u201d</aside><p dir=\"ltr\">The administration\u2019s push for a return to the moon may be unambiguous now, but plenty of questions remain, ranging from the basic, like when and how, to the intriguing, like the role commercial spaceflight companies might play. NASA also wouldn\u2019t be starting from scratch. The space agency has spent the last decade building the Space-Launch System and Orion, a rocket and spacecraft intended to carry people into deep space but also to build a cislunar way station called the Deep-Space Gateway. NASA planned to use the Deep-Space Gateway as a place for astronauts to prep for deep-space journeys, but the new shift could see the station being used for lunar landings.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxright-wrapper\" data-pos=\"boxright\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxright1\" targeting-pos=\"boxright1\" class=\"ad ad-boxright\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"3\" data-object-name=\"boxright\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [300, 600]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-3\"><p dir=\"ltr\">Both time-tested contractors and growing commercial companies will be eager to work on potential lunar activities. Boeing is currently developing a capsule that would ferry people into low-Earth orbit, and SpaceX said its proposed mega-rocket, which is mostly intended to fulfill Elon Musk\u2019s Sim City-esque ambitions for Mars, could contribute to travel to the moon. Musk, well aware of the political benefits of it, leaned heavily into lunar ambitions. \u201cIt\u2019s 2017. We should have a lunar base by now,\u201d he said <a href=\"http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/09/elon-musk-spacex-mars-moon-bfr-rockets-space-science/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'5',r'542340'\">recently</a>. \u201cWhat the hell\u2019s going on?\u201d</p><p dir=\"ltr\">Federal support for moon research is also good news for lunar scientists like Paul Spudis, a scientist at the Lunar and Planetary Institute in Houston who writes frequently in support of a return. He dismissed NASA\u2019s Mars ambitions as unrealistic and a public-relations stunt. \u201cI see the vice president\u2019s remarks not so much as a pivot in policy as a belated recognition of simple reality,\u201d Spudis wrote in an email. \u201cThey don't have have an architecture, they don't have the spacecraft, they don't have the technology, and most assuredly, they don't have the money to bludgeon any difficulties into submission.\u201d</p><p dir=\"ltr\">Mars proponents, naturally, disagree. \u201cWe weren\u2019t anywhere close to being ready\u201d to going to Mars, Logsdon said, but to dismiss the objective as simply publicity is wrong. NASA has invested over the years in some research for the requirements of a mission, including life-support systems and landing technology, he said.</p></section><p class=\"ad-boxinjector-wrapper\"><gpt-ad id=\"boxinjector2\" targeting-pos=\"boxinjector2\" class=\"ad ad-boxinjector\" lazy-load=\"2\" data-object-pk=\"1\" data-object-name=\"boxinjector\"><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[0, 0]\" sizes=\"[[300, 250], [320, 350], [300, 350], [1, 3], [320, 520], [320, 430], [1, 4], [1, 1], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[760, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1010, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1, 3], [768, 350], [768, 520], [640, 360], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/><gpt-sizeset viewport-size=\"[1050, 0]\" sizes=\"[[728, 90], [728, 350], [970, 250], [1024, 350], [1, 3], [1600, 520], [1000, 350], [1600, 500], [970, 350], [760, 350], [1, 4], [1, 5]]\"/></gpt-ad></p><section id=\"article-section-4\"><p>\u201cMost of the people who are Mars-centered worry that we\u2019ll get stuck on the moon, all the resources available will be focused on lunar exploration, and the idea of getting to Mars will slip indefinitely into the future,\u201d Logsdon said.</p><aside class=\"pullquote instapaper_ignore\">\u201cRather than lead in space, too often, we have chosen to drift.\u201d</aside><p dir=\"ltr\">Chris Carberry, the CEO of the nonprofit group Explore Mars, fears the same. Carberry said he\u2019s pleased with the administration\u2019s focus on human spaceflight and doesn\u2019t oppose a pit stop on the moon. But he wonders whether the construction of a full-fledged lunar base could consume enough resources that would delay a Mars mission for decades. \u201cIf we got to the surface of the moon, we need to do it in a way that really is a stepping-stone to getting to Mars, not just an excuse to build a base there,\u201d Carberry said.</p><p>In Washington, NASA\u2019s Mars goals have received bipartisan support, which is typical for space programs in general. In March, Trump signed a NASA funding bill that <a href=\"https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/442\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'6',r'542340'\">included</a> some of the strongest language about a human mission to ever appear in U.S. legislation, listing \u201cachieving human exploration of Mars\u201d as a key objective. The space agency has also been buoyed by interest from a general public bombarded with Hollywood movies about Mars and deep-space travel.</p><p>A renewed focus on the moon brings the United States into some alignment with space agencies in Europe, Russia, India, and China. The European Space Agency <a href=\"http://www.esa.int/About_Us/Ministerial_Council_2016/Moon_Village\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'7',r'542340'\">envisions</a> building a \u201cmoon village.\u201d Roscosmos, the Russian agency, is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/15/moon-shot-russia-launches-recruitment-drive-for-lunar-mission\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'8',r'542340'\">recruiting</a> cosmonauts to be the first Russians to land on the moon in the 2030s. ISRO, the Indian agency, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2008/oct/21/spaceexploration-india\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'9',r'542340'\">launched</a> its first lunar orbiter in 2008 and <a href=\"http://mashable.com/2017/03/02/isro-second-moon-mission-launch-2018/#Tu8xxhSKx5qd\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'10',r'542340'\">plans to send</a> a second mission, this time to land on the surface, next year. China has spent the last decade experimenting in cislunar space with both robotic and crewed missions, and officials have <a href=\"http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2016-04/29/content_24957196.htm\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'11',r'542340'\">said</a> they would put astronauts on the moon by the mid-2030s. A mission to send a rover to the far side of the moon, a first for humankind, is planned for next year. The United States is unparalleled when it comes to exploration of the solar system beyond Earth, but some in the country, particularly in the security community, <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/01/china-space/497846/\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'12',r'542340'\">worry</a> that the country\u2019s cislunar capabilities are rapidly atrophying.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">Pence said this week he believed other spacefaring nations have outpaced the United States. \u201cIn the absence of American leadership, other nations have seized the opportunity to stake their claim in the infinite frontier,\u201d he said. \u201cRather than lead in space, too often, we have chosen to drift.\u201d</p><p dir=\"ltr\">Space-policy experts say it\u2019s too early to say who the winners and losers might be in this new chapter in the country\u2019s space agenda. The administration has promised a robust human spaceflight program, an effort that both moon and Mars proponents can get behind. And the administration didn\u2019t rule out a Mars mission entirely. It just chooses to <a href=\"https://er.jsc.nasa.gov/seh/ricetalk.htm\" data-omni-click=\"r'article',r'link',r'13',r'542340'\">go to the moon</a> in this decade and do the other things\u2014later.</p></section>\n    \n    </div>\n\n    </div></body></html>"}, "15430918": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:58:06", "url": "http://www.studony.com/facebook-core-data-science-phd-intern-2018-london-gb/", "text": "<body id=\"readabilityBody\">&#13;\n&#13;\n</body>"}, "15431297": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:57:07", "url": "https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/08/curing-the-incurable/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-entry text\">\n\n\n<img src=\"https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/gettyimages-520312382.jpg?w=738\" class=\"\"/>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Very rarely, an app comes along that changes your life. I want to tell you about such an app, and how it changed mine. I had nothing to do with its making; I have never installed or opened it on my phone; and yet, I expect that this will be the most personal of the almost 400 pieces I have written for TechCrunch over the years.</p>\n<p>It is estimated that between <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://americanpainsociety.org/about-us/press-room/nih-study-shows-prevalence-of-chronic-or-severe-pain-in-u-s-adults\" rel=\"noopener\">one-third and one-half</a> of adults in the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/news/20110629/100-million-americans-have-chronic-pain\" rel=\"noopener\">United States</a> and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/jun/20/silent-epidemic-of-chronic-pain-affects-nearly-28-million-in-uk-study-suggests\" rel=\"noopener\">United Kingdom</a> suffer from a chronic pain condition, a third of whom \u2014 i.e. tens of millions \u2014 are moderately or severely disabled by it. Those stunning numbers help to explain why, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/prescribing.html\" rel=\"noopener\">according to the CDC</a>, \u201csales of prescription opioids in the U.S. nearly quadrupled from 1999 to 2014\u201d \u2014 but to no avail \u2014 \u201cthere has not been an overall change in the amount of pain Americans report.\u201d</p>\n<p>My wife was, until recently, among that number. She suffered from chronic migraine, a.k.a. 15 or more migraine days every single month, a condition which affects roughly 1% of the population. In her case it came on several years ago, gradually but unstoppably. And while modern medications can work wonders on migraines, this is only true up to a point; after circa 10 medication days per month, migraine meds begin to trigger increasingly vicious migraines themselves, a bitterly ironic phenomenon known as \u201cmedication overuse headache.\u201d</p>\n<p>Those who do not suffer from migraines may not appreciate the extent to which they are far worse than just crippling headaches. A migraine is, rather, as a friend and Harvard professor of epidemiology once put it, \u201clike a slow-motion seizure.\u201d They can and do cause nausea, aphasia, wrenching serotonin crashes, brain fog, holes in one\u2019s field of vision. They can and do reduce you to a shadow of yourself.</p>\n<p>When you suffer from 18-20 migraine days per month, even though they are of varying severity, and even though you can medicate on half of those days, you essentially become disabled. Keeping up with her job as an attorney consumed effectively all of my wife\u2019s available <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoon_theory\" rel=\"noopener\">spoons</a>. Her life shrank to her work, our home, and very occasional outings; and those outings were inevitably tense and fraught with anxiety for both of us, because when you live with chronic migraine, you never know exactly what might trigger one, but you do know that migraine triggers are absolutely fucking everywhere.</p>\n<p>She gave up alcohol. She gave up sugar. She gave up caffeine. She gave up running. She gave up travel, one of her great loves, except when absolutely necessary, because air travel was a reliable migraine trigger, and long car rides weren\u2019t great either. She gave up staying up late. She gave up naps. We became frequent fliers at urgent care clinics and ERs. We consulted with some of the world\u2019s finest migraine specialists. They were wonderful, but they didn\u2019t cure her.</p>\n<p>She tried dozens of prescription medications. She tried Botox. She tried steroids. She tried meditation. She tried an IUD. She tried transcranial magnetic stimulation. She tried everything. She took a fistful of supplements and preventatives every day. She spent a week in a hospital with a port in her arm, getting twice daily infusions of powerful medication. Some of these things seemed to diminish the average severity of her migraines, a little bit; but none diminished their frequency.</p>\n<p>It seems that for a lot of people, including my wife, once a migraine gets going, once that vicious death spiral of cascading neurochemicals has begun, there is no way out. (Relatedly, most anti-migraine medications need to be taken early on in the onset of an attack, or they are useless.) She had tried everything, and nothing seemed to stop them. At least once a month she would be hit by a three-day intractable migraine impervious to every medication, and would spend 72 hours in darkness, shuddering with agony, fighting nausea, eking out a precious few minutes of half-relief from heat or ice packs every now and again, gutting it out for what felt every time like an eternity.</p>\n<p>To be honest we gave up even hoping that her condition might be curable. Migraine is a hereditary disorder, and while hers were the most severe, her sisters, mother, aunts, and cousins are all migraineurs too. I barely dared to hope that the next generation of anti-migraine medications, emerging in the next few years, might reduce her migraines by as many as five days per month. Hope is a real motherfucker, in a situation like this, with a chronic pain condition like this. Hope is always ready to turn around and kick you right in the teeth.</p>\n<p>I promised you this was an article about an app. This is probably a good time to start talking about that.</p>\n<p>The app is, appropriately, called <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.curablehealth.com/\" rel=\"noopener\">Curable</a>. Its treatment program is based on the (thoroughly scientifically grounded) notion that chronic pain tends to slowly rewire the brain to \u201cperpetuate the feeling of pain\u201d \u2014 and that this neurological sensitization to pain can be undone, in whole or in part, via mindfulness and cognitive behavioral therapy. Its founder and CEO, John Gribbin, fought lower back pain for fifteen years himself before overcoming it with this technique.</p>\n<p>It may sound odd that cognitive techniques can overcome and eliminate real physical pain, but there is an sizable amount of hard science behind this, which Curable users are walked through. Lest you think this is a goofy fringe approach, the Mayo Clinic offers a similar <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://intheloop.mayoclinic.org/2017/08/03/from-no-hope-to-relief-from-long-term-pain/\" rel=\"noopener\">multidisciplinary pain program</a>, wherein \u201cchronic pain, unlike the acute variety, [is] treated as a malfunction in perception, whether or not an ongoing physical cause [has] been identified\u201d (7) \u2026 for $40,000 (not to mention an extended stay in Arizona, Florida or Minnesota). Curable, by contrast, is free at first, and ultimately charges all of $5 a month.</p>\n<p>I don\u2019t want to pretend that it will be a panacea for every chronic pain sufferer. It won\u2019t. But I can tell you that in the two months since my wife started using it, she has gone from 18-20 migraine days a month to one or two. Yes, you read that correctly. She has resumed drinking wine, eating chocolate, running and lifting weights, napping, casually booking cross-country &amp; transcontinental flights, and working long, strenuous attorney hours again. We have an appointment with her neurologist later this month \u2026 for a friendly dinner, because it doesn\u2019t look like we\u2019ll be needing his professional services much anytime soon.</p>\n<p>I\u2019ve read a lot of scientific studies about migraine and pain treatments over the last few years. I\u2019m well aware that most of them have a subset of \u201csuper responders\u201d for whom the results are especially dramatic. I know that not everyone who tries Curable will be as fortunate as my wife.</p>\n<p>But Curable is the first attempt I\u2019ve seen to take modern chronic pain treatment, wherein the pain is treated as a reversible consequence of neurological sensitization, and make it easily and readily available to the teeming, thronging, overwhelming masses of people who are suffering; and while I\u2019m obviously heavily biased from my own experience with it, I can\u2019t help but think that an enormous number of them could benefit hugely.</p>\n\n\n<small>Featured Image: Thom Lang/Getty Images</small>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430408": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:35:26", "url": "https://abe-winter.github.io/squares/2017/10/07/snap.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-content\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n    \n\n\n\n<p>Facebook in its history was very briefly cool, and then mom dad &amp; grandma signed up to ruin it.</p>\n\n<p>Snapchat if it survives will stay cool for longer because adults really don\u2019t get it. It\u2019s a new channel for distributing pictures and videos. New channels are selected based on the new generation\u2019s needs and in turn shape how they see the world.</p>\n\n<p>This article is about two trends and how they\u2019ll reshape connectivity:</p>\n\n<ol>\n  <li>changes in technology &amp; media use by young people</li>\n  <li>the lockdown of the common, lightly-censored internet by vendors, insitutions, platforms and governments \u2013 in other words, by squares.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>I think the first is a reaction to the second, and the two together will drive people away from a platform-oriented web delivered by ISPs.</p>\n\n<p>Scroll to the last section if you just want my prediction without the current events.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"nothing-to-hide\">Nothing to hide</h2>\n\n<p>\u201cI don\u2019t mind the police reading my email because I have nothing to hide\u201d is a thing some people say to avoid discussing the social costs of surveillance.</p>\n\n<p>No teenager has ever said this without blushing. Every teenager has something to hide. For the new generation of digital native teens it\u2019s worse, because they\u2019re carrying multiple generations of bad trends on their shoulders:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>trading outside play for TV time in the 70s</li>\n  <li>soccer / minivan helicopter parenting of the 90s</li>\n  <li>being digital natives forces them to live in public if they want to have a life</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>They have smartphones instead of cars, they use drugs &amp; have sex later<sup id=\"fnref:sex-drugs-cars\"><a href=\"#fn:sex-drugs-cars\" class=\"footnote\">1</a></sup>, they\u2019re alone more of the time.</p>\n\n<p>And institutional overreach is exposing the new generation of teens to some serious shit. An appeals court in 09 was totally okay with a principal strip-searching a 13 year-old<sup id=\"fnref:safford-school-v-redding\"><a href=\"#fn:safford-school-v-redding\" class=\"footnote\">2</a></sup>. They ruled that it\u2019s probably illegal but the principal can\u2019t be expected to know that.</p>\n\n<p>In 2015 an appeals court upheld the suspension of a student for making, off-campus, a violent rap video<sup id=\"fnref:bell-v-itawamba\"><a href=\"#fn:bell-v-itawamba\" class=\"footnote\">3</a></sup>. The facts of the case are horrible:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>Bell wrote the rap because of a pattern of sexual harrassment of students by coaches.</li>\n  <li>At a school board hearing, he was faulted for protesting in public rather than through official channels</li>\n  <li>The majority ruled that facebook / youtube speech shared with the school community is \u2018on-campus speech\u2019 and subject to school discipline</li>\n  <li>The opinion is worth a read for its overview of 1st amendment issues at school, for the shocked &amp; upset dissent, and for fun drop-ins like \u2018BONG HiTS 4 JESUS\u2019</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The majority quotes another ruling saying:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>with near-constant student access to social networking sites  on  and  off campus,  when  offensive  and  malicious  speech  is  directed  at  school officials and disseminated online to the student body, it is reasonable to anticipate an impact on the classroom environment</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Their conflation of \u2018offensive\u2019 and \u2018malicious\u2019 attacks speech contrary to the interests of the institution, not speech that harms anybody. If this argument stands it rolls back decades of pro-speech law.</p>\n\n<p>These cases are the reality of institutional education &amp; parenting in this generation. Teenagers have great incentive to be careful about who hears them. The squares have it in for us.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"teenagers--tradecraft\">Teenagers &amp; tradecraft</h2>\n\n<p>One of danah boyd\u2019s research areas is how teens partition their digital accounts. Teens wouldn\u2019t engage in this kind of labor-intensive tradecraft if they didn\u2019t care about who knows what about them. From an interview:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>That\u2019s one of the things that teenagers struggle with about Facebook: how to deal with multiple contexts simultaneously. Usually we address context collapse using alcohol in face-to-face environments, like at weddings. Online we don\u2019t have that, so we have to deal with a lot of awkwardness. So of course people are going to have multiple identities.<sup id=\"fnref:boyd\"><a href=\"#fn:boyd\" class=\"footnote\">4</a></sup></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Is it important to distinguish between snapchat\u2019s ephemeral features and its instagram-like photo-stream features? I think no. Both are incomprehensible to adults. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AgqTufBiTEU\">South Park explains what youth culture sounds like to adults</a>. It\u2019s not strange for youth culture to be passed from person to person furtively in dark allies and under bridges. Novelty and secrecy are inherently linked \u2013 new technology binds to new culture and then becomes associated with youth economics and politics, and then has to stay even more secret. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bpTSVy3yzts\">Mose Allison probably agrees with me</a>.</p>\n\n<p>While I was writing this, a 90s startup known for mailing out floppy disks<sup id=\"fnref:floppy\"><a href=\"#fn:floppy\" class=\"footnote\">5</a></sup> retired their AIM chat service<sup id=\"fnref:aim\"><a href=\"#fn:aim\" class=\"footnote\">6</a></sup>. But the generation of kids who grew up with AIM &amp; SMS brought it with them as they joined the workforce and immortalized their round-robin, attention-deficit communication style in the form of Slack. (I still don\u2019t understand chat at work. In my opinion Slack is a tool for letting your worst performers disable your best performers. Ugh).</p>\n\n<p>We can expect history to repeat itself \u2013 the next generation will bring snapchat expectations to the workplace and shape their workdays &amp; careers around privacy-awareness, decentralization and ephemeral communication. I know email storage is a legal issue; the kids will find a way around it. The law will mutate to meet their needs.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"adults-with-teenager-like-needs\">Adults with teenager-like needs</h2>\n\n<p>In lots of places adults have a teenager-like need for privacy because their countries or communities are run by squares (and I guess some are legit criminals).</p>\n\n<p>Unmarried people in gulf states, for example:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>private communication channels available on social-media networks help foster meaningful relationships</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>If caught engaging in unsanctioned romance, people \u2014 especially women \u2014 face social stigma and harsh punishment from families. They must also contend with religious police, who monitor not only malls and coffeehouses but also online forums.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Ahmad al-Ghamdi, a former chief of the religious police in the city of Mecca, said the force feels threatened by social media because \u201cit makes it harder to supervise people.\u201d He said he resigned from his position in protest of abuses committed by members of the religious police, which is tasked with enforcing Islamic law. Many Saudis say the religious police have increasingly resorted to sting operations, blackmail and beatings in public.<sup id=\"fnref:saudi-adults\"><a href=\"#fn:saudi-adults\" class=\"footnote\">7</a></sup></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>British people, who at last count:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>Can be arrested for not giving up their password<sup id=\"fnref:british-password\"><a href=\"#fn:british-password\" class=\"footnote\">8</a></sup> (sans warrant, of course). (There\u2019s an american cop in jail for this as well<sup id=\"fnref:encryption-cop\"><a href=\"#fn:encryption-cop\" class=\"footnote\">9</a></sup>, albeit with probable cause for the search, and an american JPL engineer who was compelled to unlock a device at the border without probable cause<sup id=\"fnref:jpl-unlock\"><a href=\"#fn:jpl-unlock\" class=\"footnote\">10</a></sup>.)</li>\n  <li>Have an ever-shrinking right to use encryption. I think the new laws affect the ability of vendors (ISPs and VPNs?) to provide encryption tools to consumers without opening a government backdoor. I\u2019m not sure if the UK will pursue the same restrictions for companies and individuals.</li>\n  <li>Can be arrested for watching terrorist recruiting videos, unless they\u2019re a journalist.<sup id=\"fnref:terror-videos\"><a href=\"#fn:terror-videos\" class=\"footnote\">11</a></sup> As if only journalists have a need to be informed about the world.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Facebook users, who as of 17 hours ago are still getting kicked off for talking about breastfeeding.<sup id=\"fnref:vasospasm\"><a href=\"#fn:vasospasm\" class=\"footnote\">12</a></sup> (Although I admire them for not dropping the video of a cop shooting a guy).</p>\n\n<p>Squares with power always want to get in our business. Privacy has for a long time been a defense against that but digital social platforms are often public by default. When squares can\u2019t attack private citizens for their behavior, they go after art \u2013 if you can spare 1:12:05 check out the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d65BxvSNa2o\">PMRC hearings</a>, that time in 1985 when the senate brought in famous musicians to testify about \u2018tipper stickers\u2019 on audio CDs.</p>\n\n<p>Circa 18:10 Dee Snider (twisted sister) says:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>songs allow a person to put their own imagination experiences and dreams into the lyrics. \u2026 Ms Gore was looking for sadomachism and bondage and she found it</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Al Gore responds \u201cyap\u201d and looks pissed. But you should really watch the whole thing.</p>\n\n<p>Journalists and whistle-blowers have teenager-esque needs for secrecy; their work is seldom clearly illegal but often subject to overreach by government and business interests who have privacy needs of their own. Edward Snowden thought he had to teach tradecraft to Laura Poitras before involving her and was conceivably right.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"china\">China</h2>\n\n<p>Speaking of squares \u2026</p>\n\n<p>The chinese are working on \u2018social credit\u2019, a system of lightweight disincentives to \u2018gateway drug\u2019 behavior \u2013 for example, lowering someone\u2019s score for playing too many hours of video games because of the perception that gaming makes people unproductive citizens.
