As originally proposed it addresses both sides of the social contract: reduce corruption in government, reduce laziness and waste in workers.</p>\n\n<p>It hasn\u2019t been implemented yet but they talk about it a lot. It\u2019s not clear what the system would do. Here\u2019s what is clear:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>The part that affects private citizens is getting more PR effort than the part that affects government officials</li>\n  <li>Implementing this will require significant opt-in from digital services \u2013 certainly ISPs, probably also platform operators</li>\n  <li>The demerits would be linked to some kind of institutional disincentive \u2013 probably not jail, probably something like access to college, money, jobs, migration.</li>\n  <li>I haven\u2019t heard anyone describe an experimental framework for identifying <em>which</em> behaviors are harmful to society. I think they\u2019ll be picking rules out of a hat.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>This is disasteful to me, but beyond that, I wonder if it\u2019s something that will backfire. If they don\u2019t carefully study the effects of their incentives, they risk severing hidden behavioral links. What if startup founders are all avid gamers? What if future leaders get their start by chatting with dissidents online?</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"the-fringes\">The fringes</h2>\n\n<p>Creativity comes from the fringes of society and law. Not just art, but the new ideas that keep business competitive. Many societies have experimented with cracking down on fringe groups in order to provide stability and this technically works. Rigid norms &amp; obstacles to mobility can protect the status quo for a while. Caste systems are great at protecting from internal change. But when you provide obstacles to gradual internal change, you slow your ability to innovate &amp; compete, and leave yourself open to violent change from outside.</p>\n\n<p>Some archaeologists think native americans used controlled burns to maintain ecotones, transitional areas between ecosystems, in order to increase the density of food resources<sup id=\"fnref:ecotones\"><a href=\"#fn:ecotones\" class=\"footnote\">13</a></sup>. Eliminating diversity and fringe groups from your society seems like the opposite of this. I\u2019m stretching the metaphor, but people think that wildfires are worse in western forests because managers won\u2019t permit \u2018healthy burns\u2019 to go out on their own. Only you can prevent forest fires, but <em>should</em> you?</p>\n\n<p>My point isn\u2019t to say censorship restrains free association (it obviously does). My point is that platform censorship is one of the forces driving people to decentralized networks &amp; ephemeral messaging. In Hong Kong people are using mesh networks to enable protests.<sup id=\"fnref:hk-mesh\"><a href=\"#fn:hk-mesh\" class=\"footnote\">14</a></sup> The Chinese can censor their internet platforms to prevent free association<sup id=\"fnref:criticism-vs-association\"><a href=\"#fn:criticism-vs-association\" class=\"footnote\">15</a></sup>, they can crack down on anonymity<sup id=\"fnref:anonymity-spring\"><a href=\"#fn:anonymity-spring\" class=\"footnote\">16</a></sup> through platforms and ISPs, but the effect won\u2019t be to eliminate activism \u2013 they\u2019re fertilizing the ground for decentralized communication tech.</p>\n\n<p>The Arab Spring didn\u2019t happen because of the internet. It just started there. Squares don\u2019t get the difference. A real name policy won\u2019t ensure a stable user base in the PRC any more than it will on FB.</p>\n\n<p>Most importantly, remember that to a teenager, mom &amp; dad and the 50-cent party are the same. Which means Chinese activists and helicoptered digital teens will be looking for the same set of tools.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Governments want to rebuild the web as a policing tool and rebuild the fourth amendment to exclude the web. They want backdoors in everything, reduced warrant requirements, and self-policing and censorship by platform operators. They want platform activity linked to your national ID.</p>\n\n<p>It\u2019s easy to read all this as an intentional project to arm governments for tyranny. Instead, I think police leaders are optimizing a single variable \u2013 efficiency of policing. They just want to make current police activities cheap &amp; automatic. Judges are pushing back but not as much as they should. Legislators are mostly indifferent.</p>\n\n<p>Ten years ago social networks seemed ripe for enabling disruption and social change because they make it easy to recruit &amp; communicate with like minded people. It turns out they also make it easy for status quo powers to disrupt revolutions. It\u2019s not even a wash \u2013 in the end police &amp; squares gain more from the web than revolutionaries, because it enables them to reclassify private sphere behavior as public purely by virtue of the fact that it\u2019s visible to them.</p>\n\n<p>In Bowers v Hardwick, the alabama sodomy case from the 80s, Blackmun\u2019s dissent turned on privacy. Would it still be private if the defendants arranged to meet using FB?</p>\n\n<p>In Lawrence v Texas, the case that overturned Bowers, the arresting officer was responding to a malicious tip about a violent intruder and when no intruder was found, he called a DA to find out if he could make an arrest for having sex in a residence. You can interpret this as moral outrage, or as a square testing his boundaries.</p>\n\n<p>Like all institutions, the state &amp; police care about their mission second and power first. With or without malice, regulators are letting squares take the web. Squares don\u2019t need mens rea to do harm. Soon <em>nobody</em> will have nothing to hide.</p>\n\n<p>When your country censors wikipedia, the internet just a tool for social surveillance &amp; ads. At that point let\u2019s shut it down. When the internet becomes useful as a policing tool it will cease to be useful for anything else. Platforms (hello FB) are already eroding the shared web as a permanent archive for information<sup id=\"fnref:fireball\"><a href=\"#fn:fireball\" class=\"footnote\">17</a></sup>.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"get-ready-for-sneakernet\">Get ready for sneakernet</h2>\n\n<p>Snapchat is the cargo cult of a decentralized internet. Next is the prod version.</p>\n\n<p>If you\u2019re looking for \u2018today\u2019 solutions to this problem, decentralize your web use. Run your own email server, move off facebook, host your blog, access the internet via more different connections: VPNs, tor, whatever. Centralization is easy to attack. It\u2019s more costly and less rewarding to attack 10 subtly different platforms than one big one.</p>\n\n<p>As snapchat commercializes post-IPO we\u2019ll see teenagers and college students decamp to legitimately decentralized media.</p>\n\n<p>The \u2018dark web\u2019 will grow: people sometimes use this to mean websites not surfaced on google and sometimes to mean <code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">.onion</code> domains on secret service directories served over tor. Both will matter more in the near future.</p>\n\n<p>If internet privacy tracks its descent, and regulations create liabilities that outweight the benefits of being connected, the next generation of decentralized media will be:</p>\n\n<ul>\n  <li>Distributed digitally but not via networks \u2013 teens (and other private people) will exchange it peer to peer to avoid tracking and censorship</li>\n  <li>Interactive and risky \u2013 there will be a continuum between text, video and games. Computer viruses will spread on the same vectors as STDs (the risky teens trying them first).</li>\n  <li>In places where the internet is locked down, there will be bootleggers helping to distribute</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>This can be a good thing. When information is universal it\u2019s necessarily shallow. A sociology paper from 2015 claims that networks made up of small communities loosely linked to other clusters are better able to share complex ideas.<sup id=\"fnref:boundaries\"><a href=\"#fn:boundaries\" class=\"footnote\">18</a></sup> In the decentralized future, good fences may turn out to make good neighbors in unexpected ways.</p>\n\n<h2 class=\"no_toc\" id=\"notes\">Notes</h2>\n\n\n\n  </div>\n\n  \n</div></body></html>"}, "15430922": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 03:58:55", "url": null, "text": "I never knew hackers could improve a low credit score until i met one on a discussion forum when i googled how to improve my credit score, i read a lady\u2019s comment on how capable the hacker is of solving any problems that has to do with hacking. Tools like `git grep` and the silver searcher took it a step further and actually used your specific configuration for which files were relevant or not. (Remember, we&#x27;re in best guess territory. Just because something is in your .gitignore doesn&#x27;t mean you never want to search it. But it&#x27;s a fine approximation.)<p>Was this a thing back when the BSD and GNU greps were being developed? Was it common for people to have huge directory trees (e.g., `node_modules` or `.git`) lying around that were causing significant search slow downs? Not sure, but it seems to have taken a while for it to become a popular default!<p>There are of course other tricks, and most of those are inspired by changes in hardware or instruction sets. For example, back in the day, a correctly implemented Boyer Moore was critical to avoid quadratic behavior by skipping over parts of the input. But that&#x27;s lessish important today because SIMD routines are so fast that it makes sense to optimize your search loop to spend as much time in SIMD routines as possible. This might change how you approach your substring search algorithm!<p>... so what&#x27;s my point? My point is that while sometimes optimizations are classic in the sense that you just need to change your heuristics as hardware updates, other times the optimization is in the way the tool is used. alt=\"Build status\" data-canonical-src=\"https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/21c4p5fwggc5gy3j?svg=true\"/></a>\n<a href=\"https://crates.io/crates/fd-find\"><img src=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/67aa90f091b4dabbe9a05f94e0aa0cd5bbf18336/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f6372617465732f762f66642d66696e642e737667\" alt=\"Version info\" data-canonical-src=\"https://img.shields.io/crates/v/fd-find.svg\"/></a></p>\n<p><em>fd</em> is a simple, fast and user-friendly alternative to\n<a href=\"https://www.gnu.org/software/findutils/\"><em>find</em></a>.</p>\n<p>While it does not seek to mirror all of <em>find</em>'s powerful functionality, it provides sensible\n(opinionated) defaults for <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_principle\">80%</a> of the use cases.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#features\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-features\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Features</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Convenient syntax: <code>fd PATTERN</code> instead of <code>find -iname '*PATTERN*'</code>.</li>\n<li>Colorized terminal output (similar to <em>ls</em>).</li>\n<li>It's <em>fast</em> (see <a href=\"#benchmark\">benchmarks</a> below).</li>\n<li>Smart case: the search is case-insensitive by default. It switches to\ncase-sensitive if the pattern contains an uppercase\ncharacter<a href=\"http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/options.html#'smartcase'\">*</a>.</li>\n<li>Ignores hidden directories and files, by default.</li>\n<li>Ignores patterns from your <code>.gitignore</code>, by default.</li>\n<li>Regular expressions.</li>\n<li>Unicode-awareness.</li>\n<li>The command name is <em>50%</em> shorter<a href=\"https://github.com/ggreer/the_silver_searcher\">*</a> than\n<code>find</code> :-).</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#demo\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-demo\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Demo</h2>\n<p><a href=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/7f1a80fe54ca14295869160b6e81994ba7947c69/687474703a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f6b544d465356552e676966\" target=\"_blank\"><img src=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/7f1a80fe54ca14295869160b6e81994ba7947c69/687474703a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f6b544d465356552e676966\" alt=\"Demo\" data-canonical-src=\"http://i.imgur.com/kTMFSVU.gif\"/></a></p>\n<h2><a href=\"#benchmark\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-benchmark\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Benchmark</h2>\n<p>Let's search my home folder for files that end in <code>[0-9].jpg</code>. It contains ~150.000\nsubdirectories and about a million files. For averaging and statistical analysis, I'm using\n<a href=\"https://github.com/Gabriel439/bench\">bench</a>. All benchmarks are performed for a \"warm\ncache\". Results for a cold cache are similar.</p>\n<p>Let's start with <code>find</code>:</p>\n<pre><code>find ~ -iregex '.*[0-9]\\.jpg$'\n\ntime                 6.265 s    (6.127 s .. NaN s)\n                     1.000 R\u00b2   (1.000 R\u00b2 .. 1.000 R\u00b2)\nmean                 6.162 s    (6.140 s .. 6.181 s)\nstd dev              31.73 ms   (0.0 s .. 33.48 ms)\n</code></pre>\n<p><code>find</code> is much faster if it does not need to perform a regular-expression search:</p>\n<pre><code>find ~ -iname '*[0-9].jpg'\n\ntime                 2.866 s    (2.754 s .. 2.964 s)\n                     1.000 R\u00b2   (0.999 R\u00b2 .. 1.000 R\u00b2)\nmean                 2.860 s    (2.834 s .. 2.875 s)\nstd dev              23.11 ms   (0.0 s .. 25.09 ms)\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now let's try the same for <code>fd</code>. Note that <code>fd</code> <em>always</em> performs a regular expression\nsearch. The options <code>--hidden</code> and <code>--no-ignore</code> are needed for a fair comparison,\notherwise <code>fd</code> does not have to traverse hidden folders and ignored paths (see below):</p>\n<pre><code>fd --hidden --no-ignore '.*[0-9]\\.jpg$' ~\n\ntime                 892.6 ms   (839.0 ms .. 915.4 ms)\n                     0.999 R\u00b2   (0.997 R\u00b2 .. 1.000 R\u00b2)\nmean                 871.2 ms   (857.9 ms .. 881.3 ms)\nstd dev              15.50 ms   (0.0 s .. 17.49 ms)\n</code></pre>\n<p>For this particular example, <code>fd</code> is approximately seven times faster than <code>find -iregex</code>\nand about three times faster than <code>find -iname</code>. By the way, both tools found the exact\nsame 14030 files <g-emoji alias=\"smile\" fallback-src=\"https://assets-cdn.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f604.png\" ios-version=\"6.0\">\ud83d\ude04</g-emoji>.</p>\n<p>Finally, let's run <code>fd</code> without <code>--hidden</code> and <code>--no-ignore</code> (this can lead to different\nsearch results, of course):</p>\n<pre><code>fd '[0-9]\\.jpg$' ~\n\ntime                 159.5 ms   (155.8 ms .. 165.3 ms)\n                     0.999 R\u00b2   (0.996 R\u00b2 .. 1.000 R\u00b2)\nmean                 158.7 ms   (156.5 ms .. 161.6 ms)\nstd dev              3.263 ms   (2.401 ms .. 4.298 ms)\n</code></pre>\n<p><strong>Note</strong>: This is <em>one particular</em> benchmark on <em>one particular</em> machine. While I have\nperformed quite a lot of different tests (and found consistent results), things might\nbe different for you! I encourage everyone to try it out on their own.</p>\n<p>Concerning <em>fd</em>'s speed, the main credit goes to the <code>regex</code> and <code>ignore</code> crates that are also used\nin <a href=\"https://github.com/BurntSushi/ripgrep\">ripgrep</a> (check it out!).</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#colorized-output\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-colorized-output\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Colorized output</h2>\n<p><code>fd</code> can colorize files by extension, just like <code>ls</code>. In order for this to work, the environment\nvariable <a href=\"https://linux.die.net/man/5/dir_colors\"><code>LS_COLORS</code></a> has to be set. Typically, the value\nof this variable is set by the <code>dircolors</code> command which provides a convenient configuration format\nto define colors for different file formats.\nOn most distributions, <code>LS_COLORS</code> should be set already. If you are looking for alternative, more\ncomplete (and more colorful) variants, see\n<a href=\"https://github.com/seebi/dircolors-solarized\">here</a> or\n<a href=\"https://github.com/trapd00r/LS_COLORS\">here</a>.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#install\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-install\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Install</h2>\n<p>With Rust's package manager <a href=\"https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo\">cargo</a>, you can install <em>fd</em> via:</p>\n<pre><code>cargo install fd-find\n</code></pre>\n<p>Note that rust version <em>1.16.0</em> or later is required.\nThe release page of this repository also includes precompiled binaries for Linux.</p>\n<p>On <strong>macOS</strong>, you can use <a href=\"http://braumeister.org/formula/fd\">Homebrew</a>:</p>\n<pre><code>brew install fd\n</code></pre>\n<p>On <strong>Arch Linux</strong>, you can install the AUR package <a href=\"https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/fd-rs/\">fd-rs</a> via yaourt, or manually:</p>\n<pre><code>git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/fd-rs.git\ncd fd-rs\nmakepkg -si\n</code></pre>\n<p>On <strong>Windows</strong>, you can download the pre-built binaries from the <a href=\"https://github.com/sharkdp/fd/releases\">Release page</a>.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#development\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-development\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Development</h2>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell\"><pre>git clone https://github.com/sharkdp/fd\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> Build</span>\n<span class=\"pl-c1\">cd</span> fd\ncargo build\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> Run unit tests and integration tests</span>\ncargo <span class=\"pl-c1\">test</span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">#</span> Install</span>\ncargo install</pre></div>\n<h2><a href=\"#command-line-options\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-command-line-options\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Command-line options</h2>\n<pre><code>USAGE:\n    fd [FLAGS/OPTIONS] [&lt;pattern&gt;] [&lt;path&gt;]\n\nFLAGS:\n    -H, --hidden            Search hidden files and directories\n    -I, --no-ignore         Do not respect .(git)ignore files\n    -s, --case-sensitive    Case-sensitive search (default: smart case)\n    -a, --absolute-path     Show absolute instead of relative paths\n    -L, --follow            Follow symbolic links\n    -p, --full-path         Search full path (default: file-/dirname only)\n    -0, --print0            Separate results by the null character\n    -h, --help              Prints help information\n    -V, --version           Prints version information\n\nOPTIONS:\n    -d, --max-depth &lt;depth&gt;    Set maximum search depth (default: none)\n    -t, --type &lt;filetype&gt;      Filter by type: f(ile), d(irectory), (sym)l(ink)\n    -e, --extension &lt;ext&gt;      Filter by file extension\n    -c, --color &lt;when&gt;         When to use color in the output:\n                               never, auto, always (default: auto)\n    -j, --threads &lt;num&gt;        Set number of threads to use for searching:\n                               (default: number of available CPU cores)\n\nARGS:\n    &lt;pattern&gt;    the search pattern, a regular expression (optional)\n    &lt;path&gt;       the root directory for the filesystem search (optional)\n</code></pre>\n<h2><a href=\"#tutorial\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-tutorial\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Tutorial</h2>\n<p>First, to see all command line options, you can get <code>fd</code>'s help text by running:</p>\n<pre><code>fd --help\n</code></pre>\n<p>For the sake of this tutorial, let's assume we have a directory with the following file structure:</p>\n<pre><code>fd_examples\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 .gitignore\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 desub_dir\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2514\u2500\u2500 old_test.txt\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 not_file\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 sub_dir\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 .here_be_tests\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 more_dir\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 .not_here\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 even_further_down\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 not_me.sh\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 test_seven\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2514\u2500\u2500 testing_eight\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 not_file -&gt; /Users/fd_user/Desktop/fd_examples/not_file\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2514\u2500\u2500 test_file_six\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 new_test.txt\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 test_file_five\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u251c\u2500\u2500 test_file_four\n\u2502\u00a0\u00a0 \u2514\u2500\u2500 test_file_three\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 test_file_one\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 test_file_two\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 test_one\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 this_is_a_test\n</code></pre>\n<p>If <code>fd</code> is called with a single argument (the search pattern), it will perform a recursive search\nthrough the current directory. To search for all files that include the string \"test\", we can\nsimply run:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd test\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/test_seven\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/testing_eight\nsub_dir/more_dir/test_file_six\nsub_dir/test_file_five\nsub_dir/test_file_three\nsub_dir/test_four\ntest_file_one\ntest_file_two\ntest_one\nthis_is_a_test\n</code></pre>\n<p>The search pattern is treated as a regular expression. To show only entries that start with \"test\",\nwe can call:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd '^test'\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/test_seven\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/testing_eight\nsub_dir/more_dir/test_file_six\nsub_dir/test_file_five\nsub_dir/test_file_three\nsub_dir/test_four\ntest_file_one\ntest_file_two\ntest_one\n</code></pre>\n<p>Note that <code>fd</code> does not show hidden files (<code>.here_be_tests</code>) by default. To change this, we can use\nthe <code>-H</code> (or <code>--hidden</code>) option:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd -H test\nsub_dir/.here_be_tests\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/test_seven\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/testing_eight\nsub_dir/more_dir/test_file_six\nsub_dir/test_file_five\nsub_dir/test_file_four\nsub_dir/test_file_three\ntest_file_one\ntest_file_two\ntest_one\nthis_is_a_test\n</code></pre>\n<p>If we are interested in showing the results from a particular directory, we can specify the root of\nthe search as a second argument:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd test sub_dir\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/test_seven\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/testing_eight\nsub_dir/more_dir/test_file_six\nsub_dir/test_file_five\nsub_dir/test_file_three\nsub_dir/test_four\n</code></pre>\n<p>If we don't give <em>any</em> arguments to <code>fd</code>, it simply shows all entries in the current directory,\nrecursively (like <code>ls -R</code>):</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd\nnot_file\nsub_dir\nsub_dir/more_dir\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/test_seven\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/testing_eight\nsub_dir/more_dir/not_file\nsub_dir/more_dir/test_file_six\nsub_dir/test_file_five\nsub_dir/test_file_three\nsub_dir/test_four\ntest_file_one\ntest_file_two\ntest_one\nthis_is_a_test\n</code></pre>\n<p>If we work in a directory that is a Git repository (or includes several Git repositories), <code>fd</code>\ndoes not search folders (and does not show files) that match the <code>.gitignore</code> pattern. For example,\nimagine we had a <code>.gitignore</code> file with the following content:</p>\n<pre><code>*.sh\n</code></pre>\n<p>In this case, <code>fd</code> would not show any files that end in <code>.sh</code>. To disable this behavior, we can\nuse the <code>-I</code> (or <code>--ignore</code>) option:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd -I me\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/not_me.sh\n</code></pre>\n<p>To really search <em>all</em> files and directories, we can combine the hidden and ignore features to show\neverything (<code>-HI</code>):</p>\n<pre><code>fd -HI 'not|here'\nnot_file\nsub_dir/.here_be_tests\nsub_dir/more_dir/.not_here\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/not_me.sh\nsub_dir/more_dir/not_file\n</code></pre>\n<p>Searching for a file extension is easy too, using the <code>-e</code> (or <code>--extension</code>) switch for file\nextensions:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd -e sh\nsub_dir/more_dir/even_further_down/not_me.sh\n</code></pre>\n<p>Next, we can even use a pattern in combination with <code>-e</code> to search for a regex pattern over the\nfiles that end in the specified extension.</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd -e txt test\nfd_examples/desub_dir/old_test.txt\nfd_examples/sub_dir/new_test.txt\n</code></pre>\n<p>If we want to run a command for each of the search results, we can use the <code>-0</code> option to pipe\nthe output to <code>xargs</code>:</p>\n<pre><code>&gt; fd -0 'test' | xargs -0 wc -l\n</code></pre>\n</article>\n  </div></body></html>"}, "15429391": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:49:12", "url": "https://ehlers.berlin/multi-tenant-react-js-starter/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"kg-card-markdown\"><p>Let me start this article with the requirements that it is going to adress, so you know if you want to continue.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>You have multiple tenants (websites)</li>\n<li>the clients should share components between each other to increase development speed of new tenants</li>\n<li>SSR has to be supported</li>\n<li>build configs are the same, but can be extended</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Since these are quite a few things and a lot of good stuff is already open source I am only going to focus on what needs to be added onto the great <a href=\"https://github.com/kriasoft/react-starter-kit\">react-starter-kit</a>.<br/>\nThe repo will be available for you as a <strong>starter-kit</strong> as well, so you do not need to follow along in code if you do not want to. But make sure to read the article to understand what is happening.<br/>\nI will take some opinionated approaches. Feel free to send me PRs though if you find stuff to improve!</p>\n<p>Okay, lets dig in.</p>\n<h2 id=\"multipletenants\">Multiple Tenants</h2>\n<p>After you have cloned the <strong>react-starter-kit</strong> you will have the following folder structure</p>\n<pre><code>.editorconfig\n.eslintrc.js\n.flowconfig\n.git\n.gitattributes\n.gitignore\n.nycrc\n.stylelintrc.js\n.travis.yml\nCHANGELOG.md\nCONTRIBUTING.md\nDockerfile\nLICENSE.txt\nREADME.md\ndocs\njest\njest.config.js\npackage.json\npublic\nsrc\ntest\ntools\nyarn.lock\n</code></pre>\n<p>So far so good. Our code will still reside in the <code>src</code> folder which looks like this:</p>\n<pre><code>MUtils.js\nclient.js\ncomponents\nconfig.js\ncreateFetch.js\ndata\nhistory.js\npassport.js\nrouter.js\nroutes\nserver.js\n</code></pre>\n<p>To have multiple <em>tenants</em> with different components and configs we start by creating a new folder with some subfolders in there.</p>\n<p>We want to have two tenants <strong>a</strong> and <strong>b</strong> so lets run the following:</p>\n<pre><code>mkdir -p tenants/{a,b}\n\n# folder structure\n# tenants\n# \u251c\u2500\u2500 a\n# \u2514\u2500\u2500 b\n\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now that we have the folders lets copy all the stuff under <code>src</code> into both folders and then remove what we copied from <code>src</code>.</p>\n<h2 id=\"creatingtenanta\">Creating tenant a</h2>\n<p>First off lets update the file <code>src/tenants/a/routes/Home.js</code> with the following content</p>\n<pre><code>import React from 'react';\n\nconst TenantA = () =&gt;\n  &lt;div&gt;\n    &lt;h1&gt;Tenant A&lt;/h1&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;;\n\nexport default TenantA;\n</code></pre>\n<p>Then edit the config file and change the port. I use <code>3005</code>.</p>\n<h3 id=\"updatingthetasks\">Updating the tasks</h3>\n<p>Right now the config from <strong>react-starter-kit</strong> wont pick up our Tenant when starting it with <code>yarn start</code>.<br/>\nTo get this working we need to add an entrypoint to webpack, and a new npm task.</p>\n<p>Inside of <code>tools/webpack.configs.js</code> we can change the clientConfig from a simple Object to a function that takes a tenant as a parameter and then uses the tenant to start at the correct entrypoint. Sames goes for the serverConfig</p>\n<p>The changed parts of the file looks like this:</p>\n<pre><code>const clientConfig = (tenant) =&gt; ({\n  ...config,\n\n  name: 'client',\n  target: 'web',\n\n  entry: {\n    client: ['babel-polyfill', `./src/tenants/${tenant}/client.js`],\n  },\n  .\n  .\n  .\n  .\n  .\n\nconst serverConfig = tenant =&gt; ({\n  ...config,\n\n  name: 'server',\n  target: 'node',\n\n  entry: {\n    server: ['babel-polyfill', `./src/tenants/${tenant}/server.js`],\n  },\n  .\n  .\n  .\n  .\n  export default [clientConfig, serverConfig];\n\n  export function createTenantConfig(tenant) {\n    return [clientConfig(tenant), serverConfig(tenant)];\n  }\n</code></pre>\n<p>Make sure to add <code>()</code> around the <em>clientConfig</em> and <em>serverConfig</em> Objects, so that it is not interpreted as the function body.</p>\n<p>Now that we can pass in the tenant, we need to create a new script under <code>tools/</code> that will bundle our files with the correct tenant.</p>\n<p>Create <code>tools/bundleTenantA.js</code> and add this code:</p>\n<pre><code>import webpack from 'webpack';\nimport webpackConfig, {createTenantConfig} from './webpack.config';\n\n/**\n * Creates application bundles from the source files.\n */\nfunction bundle() {\n  return new Promise((resolve, reject) =&gt; {\n    webpack(createTenantConfig('a')).run((err, stats) =&gt; {\n      if (err) {\n        return reject(err);\n      }\n\n      console.info(stats.toString(webpackConfig[0].stats)); return resolve();\n    });\n  });\n}\n\nexport default bundle;\n</code></pre>\n<p>This is very similar to <code>bundle.js</code> but with the extra import for creating our tenant specific config and the call of it.</p>\n<p>Now we can finally add a new task to <code>package.json</code>. Just follow the example of all the other tasks and add</p>\n<pre><code>\"bundle:tenanta\": \"babel-node tools/run bundleTenantA\"\n</code></pre>\n<p>Bundling for our tenant is now almost working :)</p>\n<h2 id=\"developingtenanta\">Developing Tenant a</h2>\n<p>In order to see our Tenant in the dev environment in the browser we need to create a new <em>start</em> task as well.</p>\n<p>First we update the <code>tools/start</code> script.</p>\n<p>On line 73 and 120 we use the createTenantConfig again, after we imported it, and change to start function to accept a parameter.</p>\n<p>Here are the changes:</p>\n<pre><code>import { createTenantConfig } from './webpack.config';\n.\n.\n.\nasync function start(tenant) {\n.\n.\n\nconst clientConfig = createTenantConfig(tenant).find(\n  config =&gt; config.name === 'client',\n);\n.\n.\n.\n\nconst serverConfig = createTenantConfig(tenant).find(\n  config =&gt; config.name === 'server',\n);\n  .\n  .\n  .\nconst multiCompiler = webpack(createTenantConfig(tenant));\n\n</code></pre>\n<h3 id=\"creatingawrapperscript\">Creating a wrapper script</h3>\n<p>Now create a wrapper scripts at <code>tools/startTenantA.js</code>.<br/>\nThe code is easy and just executes the start script with the correct tenant.</p>\n<pre><code>\nimport start from './start';\n\nconst startTenantA = async () =&gt; start('a');\n\nexport default startTenantA;\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now we just need to add this to the <code>package.json</code>, and we are ready to go:</p>\n<pre><code>\"start:tenanta\": \"babel-node tools/run startTenantA\",\n</code></pre>\n<p>Run <code>yarn start:tenanta</code> and you should be greeted by the starter site with <strong>Tenant</strong> <code>&lt;h1&gt;</code>.</p>\n<h2 id=\"reapingthebenefits\">Reaping the benefits</h2>\n<p>Now you can repeat the steps to create a Tenant <strong>b</strong>. When you are done we can finally see why this approach is helpful when managing multiple tenants.</p>\n<h3 id=\"usingasharedcomponent\">Using a shared component</h3>\n<p>Update both <code>routes/home/Homes.js</code> like this:</p>\n<pre><code>import React from 'react';\nimport Shared from '../../../../SharedComponents/Shared';\n\nconst Tenant = () =&gt;\n  &lt;div&gt;\n    &lt;Shared /&gt;\n    &lt;h1&gt;Tenant &lt;/h1&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;;\n\nexport default Tenant;\n</code></pre>\n<p>and then create <code>src/SharedComponents/Shared.js</code>:</p>\n<pre><code>import React from 'react';\n\nexport default () =&gt; &lt;div&gt;SHARED&lt;/div&gt;;\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now when you start the different tenants they will be using a shared component.</p>\n<h2 id=\"thebenefits\">The Benefits</h2>\n<p>Why use this approach and not f.e. put all shared components in a library?<br/>\nEasy, less problems. Whatever team works on this repo will know if something will break when they change a shared component, because they can run all the tests.<br/>\nAlso all teams will see the PRs.</p>\n<p>If you really need to add some behaviour to a component that no one else needs? Copy and paste, you can still use the cool shared stuff.</p>\n<p>Keeping libraries up to date and seeing how they affect your own repo is much more tedious and includes a lot of headache, like <code>npm link</code> breaking with some webpack configs, or <code>babel</code> not finding the correct loaders if you would like to share building tools.</p>\n<p>In my opinion a big repo is not a problem. All builds can still be specialized by the scripts, just <code>push</code> in some new plugins or loaders etc..<br/>\nIt also makes bootstrapping new sites so much faster, because almost everything is already there. Including a lot of <strong>React</strong> components.</p>\n<h2 id=\"verdict\">Verdict</h2>\n<p>If you have multiple teams in your company, that all builds similar sites, go for it.</p>\n<p>You do not have to use <strong>react-starter-kit</strong> but using such a mono repo for react based stuff can really save from some troubles I have experienced with extracting everything into libraries.</p>\n<h2 id=\"thecode\">The code</h2>\n<p>You can find all the code I changed under <a href=\"https://github.com/bananenmannfrau/multi-tenant-react-starter\">https://github.com/bananenmannfrau/multi-tenant-react-starter</a>.</p>\n<p>Feel free to send PRs. For example shared components are still lacking the ability to use specific css files for the tenants.<br/>\nA custom webpack loader could be used to solve this.</p>\n</div>\n            </div></body></html>"}, "15430933": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:02:11", "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/sep/25/in-praise-of-the-humble-fruit-fly-genetics-research", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"content__article-body from-content-api js-article__body\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" data-test-id=\"article-review-body\">\n<p><span class=\"drop-cap\"><span class=\"drop-cap__inner\">I</span></span>n a series of rooms in the <a href=\"http://www.flyfacility.gen.cam.ac.uk/Services\" title=\"\" data-link-name=\"in body link\" class=\"u-underline\">Fly Facility</a> of the Department of Genetics at Cambridge University, around 5m fruit flies are kept in test tubes at any given time. They\u2019re stored at different temperatures to determine varying lengths of life cycle \u2013 at 25C, it\u2019s about 10 days; at cooler temperatures as long as five weeks.</p>\n<p>Out in the wild, there is no pest quite so sympathetic to human needs as the humble fruit fly. It may have spent the summer feasting on the contents of your fruit bowl, but not until your assembled plums and peaches were starting to rot. But while gastronomic sensitivity is a characteristic to be applauded in a fly, the drosophila, to give it its official title, has more going for it than good table manners.</p>\n<p>For the past century, it has also performed the vital function of a scientific and medical research tool. Today, it\u2019s often the first stop in research into a wide range of human illnesses, including Alzheimer\u2019s disease, Huntington\u2019s disease, spastic paraplegia, cancer and obesity. By comparison with mice and dogs, let alone apes and humans, it\u2019s massively cheap and easy to work with and there is little chance of drawing protest from even the most radical anti-vivisectionist.</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\">\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"pullquote-paragraph\">The males follow the females and put out one wing and vibrate it\u2026 it\u2019s a\u00a0kind of love\u00a0song</p>\n</blockquote>\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon closing inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"closing__svg inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n</aside>\n<p>In many respects its position as a vital research tool is a historical accident. Between 1910 and 1915, the pioneering American geneticist Thomas Hunt Morgan worked on <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> in his renowned Fly Room at Columbia University and showed that genes provide the basis for chromosomal heredity, for which he won a Nobel prize. It was a critical breakthrough, but there was no particular reason that it had to be made via the fruit fly. Yet ever since then, the tiny drosophila has been at the forefront of genetic research. In the 1920s, another American geneticist, Hermann J Muller, demonstrated that radiation leads to genetic mutation in fruit flies. The reason we\u2019re careful about exposure to x-rays is no small part due to Muller\u2019s work.</p>\n<p>But some of the mutations that Muller produced, such as flies with legs coming out of their heads, later played into the postwar period of atomic paranoia, informed George Langelaan\u2019s short story The Fly, which was made into a film first in the 50s and then <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/the-fly\" title=\"\" data-link-name=\"in body link\" class=\"u-underline\">remade by David Cronenberg</a> in the 1980s.</p>\n<figure itemprop=\"associatedMedia image\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" data-component=\"image\" class=\"element element-image img--landscape  fig--narrow-caption fig--has-shares \" Photograph: Sportsphoto Ltd /Allstar\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>In the story and the films, a scientist mutates into a fly, an idea that\u2019s disturbing precisely because we see ourselves as being so utterly different from flies, with their strange bodies and massive, honeycombed heads and distinctly creepy habits. This deep-seated anxiety about flies has led to some famous misunderstandings of biology. The most egregious example was in 2008, when Sarah Palin, running for vice-president in the US presidential elections, told an audience that their money was going \u201cto projects that have little or nothing to do with the public good. Things like fruit fly research in Paris, France. I kid you not.\u201d</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail element-rich-link--not-upgraded\" data-component=\"rich-link\" data-link-name=\"rich-link-2 | 1\">\n<div class=\"rich-link\">\n<div class=\"rich-link__container\">\n<p class=\"rich-link__header\">\n<h1 class=\"rich-link__title\">Adam Rutherford: Sarah Palin and the fruit fly</h1>\n</p>\n\n<a class=\"rich-link__link u-faux-block-link__overlay\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/oct/27/sarahpalin-genetics-fruit-flies\"/>\n</div>\n</div>\n</aside>\n<p>Despite Palin\u2019s clueless misgivings, one of the reasons that flies have become important to much genetic and medical research in relation to humans is that they bear a remarkable genetic similarity to us. The sci-fi fear of a fly\u2019s otherness may well be based, somewhere way down, on its unsettling closeness to us.</p>\n<p>It was Michael Ashburner, the godfather of fruit fly research at Cambridge, who first established that of the genes that in their mutant form cause diseases in humans \u2013 cystic fibrosis being one example \u2013 around 75% have very similar equivalents in fruit flies. When Ashburner started out in the 1970s, flies were kept in milk bottles in a temporary lab on the outskirts of Cambridge. As a result of his foundational work, which includes his classic book <em>Won For All: How the Drosophila Genome Was Sequenced</em>, Cambridge has become arguably the world\u2019s leading centre of fruit fly research.</p>\n<p>Its Fly Facility is run by one of Ashburner\u2019s former PhD students, Simon Collier, who showed me around the labs and fly storage of the facility. He\u2019s been working with fruit flies for 25 years and in that time he\u2019s come to know and appreciate many of their hidden \u2013 to most human observers \u2013 characteristics.</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\">\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"pullquote-paragraph\">It\u2019s pretty straightforward to look at their genome. You just squish them up in a tube and do some simple DNA extraction</p>\n</blockquote>\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon closing inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"closing__svg inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n</aside>\n<p>\u201cIf you take a tube of flies and leave it here you notice that they have behaviours,\u201d he says. \u201cThe males court the females. They follow the females and put one wing out and it vibrates. There\u2019s a guy in Leicester who\u2019s researched this and what they\u2019re doing is producing a kind of love song.\u201d</p>\n<p>Apparently, the females are not looking for a long-term relationship and, indeed, they\u2019re likely in their short life span to have multiple partners. The problem with this for geneticists is that they store sperm so paternity is a disputed issue. To counter the confusion of this flagrant promiscuity, geneticists tend to work with virgin females.</p>\n<p>How can they tell? I ask.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe look in their eye,\u201d Collier says\u00a0drily.</p>\n<figure itemprop=\"associatedMedia image\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" data-component=\"image\" class=\"element element-image img--landscape  fig--narrow-caption fig--has-shares \" data-media-id=\"bdcf2ed5591e5cc85b833fed281eee1ccec0fd7e\" id=\"img-3\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/bdcf2ed5591e5cc85b833fed281eee1ccec0fd7e/0_0_3770_2872/master/3770.jpg?w=700&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=max&amp;s=cb14b8e243fd5beb95a61b41de4c04d7\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"3770\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"2872\"/>\n<a href=\"#img-3\" class=\"article__img-container js-gallerythumbs\" data-link-name=\"Launch Article Lightbox\" data-is-ajax=\"\">\n <span class=\"inline-expand-image inline-icon centered-icon rounded-icon article__fullscreen modern-visible\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 22 22\" class=\"centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg article__fullscreen__svg modern-visible__svg inline-expand-image__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M3.4 20.2L9 14.5 7.5 13l-5.7 5.6L1 14H0v7.5l.5.5H8v-1l-4.6-.8M18.7 1.9L13 7.6 14.4 9l5.7-5.7.5 4.7h1.2V.6l-.5-.5H14v1.2l4.7.6\"/>\n</svg> </span> </a>\n\n<figcaption class=\"caption caption--img caption caption--img\" itemprop=\"description\">\n<span class=\"inline-information inline-icon reveal-caption-icon centered-icon rounded-icon\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 6 14\" class=\"reveal-caption-icon__svg centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg inline-information__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M4.6 12l-.4 1.4c-.7.2-1.9.6-3 .6-.7 0-1.2-.2-1.2-.9 0-.2 0-.3.1-.5l2-6.7H.7l.4-1.5 4.2-.6h.2L3 12h1.6zm-.3-9.2c-.9 0-1.4-.5-1.4-1.3C2.9.5 3.7 0 4.6 0 5.4 0 6 .5 6 1.3c0 1-.8 1.5-1.7 1.5z\"/>\n</svg> </span> A colourised SEM micrograph, magnified 70 times. of the head of a fruit fly, showing compound eye. Photograph: Tom Hartman/Getty Images\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>He shows me a magnification of a load of fruit flies that have been knocked out by carbon dioxide. They\u2019re still twitching but essentially stationary. He points out the differences between males (a bit smaller) and females and shows that young flies \u2013 virgins if you like \u2013 are pale and unpigmented.</p>\n<p>He explains that for research purposes special chromosomes have been developed that enable geneticists to trace exactly what genes have been inherited. With mice, for example, it\u2019s necessary to check gene by gene what\u2019s been inherited, which makes genetic research much more time-consuming and costly.</p>\n<p>Because the fruit fly\u2019s life cycle is so short and they reproduce so fast (sexually maturity is reached within eight days of hatching), drosophila are ideal subjects for the study of inherited traits, including genetic abnormalities, over many generations.</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\">\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"pullquote-paragraph\">The common ingredient in human and fly behaviour is the gene FOXP, closely linked to cognitive development in humans</p>\n</blockquote>\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon closing inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"closing__svg inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n</aside>\n<p>Still, to the layman, even one slightly more versed in the exigencies of scientific research than Sarah Palin, there\u2019s something profoundly counterintuitive about doing genetic research on flies. For one thing, they\u2019re so small. Doesn\u2019t that make it a whole lot trickier?</p>\n<p>Collier shakes his head. \u201cIt\u2019s pretty straightforward if you want to look at the fruit fly\u2019s genome. You just put them in a tube and squish them up and do some simple DNA extraction. What\u2019s more complex is going the other way \u2013 implanting genetic material into them.\u201d</p>\n<p>He takes me to a special lab where this procedure is carried out. They take the fly larvae and strip the eggs off their shells by sticking them in bleach. Then with a long and extremely fine needle, the relevant genetic material is injected into the posterior of the eggs where the germline cells are located.</p>\n<figure itemprop=\"associatedMedia image\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" data-component=\"image\" class=\"element element-image img--landscape  fig--narrow-caption fig--has-shares \" data-media-id=\"531cf2b8000113b38517a168dc197fbf2a8b6ff8\" id=\"img-4\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/531cf2b8000113b38517a168dc197fbf2a8b6ff8/185_325_4133_2192/master/4133.jpg?w=700&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=max&amp;s=da5c5e51ba47cefe79a84c35d8601e14\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"4133\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"2192\"/>\n<a href=\"#img-4\" class=\"article__img-container js-gallerythumbs\" data-link-name=\"Launch Article Lightbox\" data-is-ajax=\"\">\n <span class=\"inline-expand-image inline-icon centered-icon rounded-icon article__fullscreen modern-visible\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 22 22\" class=\"centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg article__fullscreen__svg modern-visible__svg inline-expand-image__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M3.4 20.2L9 14.5 7.5 13l-5.7 5.6L1 14H0v7.5l.5.5H8v-1l-4.6-.8M18.7 1.9L13 7.6 14.4 9l5.7-5.7.5 4.7h1.2V.6l-.5-.5H14v1.2l4.7.6\"/>\n</svg> </span> </a>\n\n<figcaption class=\"caption caption--img caption caption--img\" itemprop=\"description\">\n<span class=\"inline-information inline-icon reveal-caption-icon centered-icon rounded-icon\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 6 14\" class=\"reveal-caption-icon__svg centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg inline-information__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M4.6 12l-.4 1.4c-.7.2-1.9.6-3 .6-.7 0-1.2-.2-1.2-.9 0-.2 0-.3.1-.5l2-6.7H.7l.4-1.5 4.2-.6h.2L3 12h1.6zm-.3-9.2c-.9 0-1.4-.5-1.4-1.3C2.9.5 3.7 0 4.6 0 5.4 0 6 .5 6 1.3c0 1-.8 1.5-1.7 1.5z\"/>\n</svg> </span> Drosophila melanogaster eye colour variations, showing white and red. The white eye gene is sex-linked. Photograph: Alamy\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Given that an egg is about 0.5mm in length (about the size of a grain of sand), and the DNA injected into it is about the volume of a millionth of a drop of water, you can see how delicate an operation it is. It takes about six months to master the minute motor skills necessary to do the job.</p>\n<p>\u201cUsually half the embryos will survive that procedure,\u201d says Collier. \u201cAnd we can breed from them and study them.\u201d</p>\n<p>But study what exactly? And to what end?</p>\n<p>Collier introduces me to two colleagues who are active in fruit fly research, a reader in genetics called Cahir O\u2019Kane and Damian Crowther, a director of neuroscience research and development at the pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca, who still retains links to the Fly Facility.</p>\n<p>We go out to lunch and talk fruit flies. I ask Crowther first of all why he left academic research to go into industry.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe story I tell,\u201d he says, \u201cis friends, and perhaps even enemies, would always introduce me as, \u2018This is Damian, he\u2019s the fly guy\u2019. In my time, I\u2019ve been a registrar in neurology and a research scientist in many areas \u2013 I didn\u2019t think fly guy really summed me up.\u201d</p>\n<p>O\u2019Kane echoes the point and both men agree that fly research has not brought them either the professional or social recognition they believe their work warrants.</p>\n<p>What seems to matter most, in terms of professional appreciation at least, is what is known as \u201ctranslation\u201d, that is, turning the findings of fly research into productive contributions to medical applications for humans. There is little doubt that fly research does contribute, in a wider sense of biological understanding of how all organisms work, but also in specific examples of human disease. However, it\u2019s not easy to make direct links.</p>\n<p>It\u2019s problematic, for obvious reasons, to go from fly tests to human tests; there usually needs to be a whole range of intervening stages in which other scientists take over and, inevitably, take the spotlight and accreditation.</p>\n<p>\u201cI can\u2019t tell you that there\u2019s a drug that I\u2019ve tested on fruit flies [with an artificially created version of Alzheimer\u2019s disease] that\u2019s benefited the fruit fly that\u2019s then gone on to benefit the human,\u201d says Crowther.</p>\n<p>But, he explains, Alzheimer\u2019s involves the overproduction of proteins that form plaque in the brain that destroys neurons. \u201cSo you can make models of flies that produce these proteins, get their own plaque and die,\u201d he explains, \u201cand you can then test various ways of preventing the plaque formations.\u201d</p>\n<p>Fruit flies don\u2019t naturally develop Alzheimer\u2019s, although they have all the genetics of the Alzheimer\u2019s pathway in their brain.</p>\n<p>\u201cYou have to give them human equivalent genes and push it really hard to get them to have Alzheimer\u2019s in three weeks,\u201d explains Crowther.</p>\n<figure itemprop=\"associatedMedia image\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\" data-component=\"image\" class=\"element element-image img--landscape  fig--narrow-caption fig--has-shares \" data-media-id=\"6b69a5635b3faac5150e25c31912a3ae20c8cf67\" id=\"img-5\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/6b69a5635b3faac5150e25c31912a3ae20c8cf67/0_0_3867_2404/master/3867.jpg?w=700&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=max&amp;s=f2943ea58b32e8c952fdece20e21a5cc\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"3867\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"2404\"/>\n<a href=\"#img-5\" class=\"article__img-container js-gallerythumbs\" data-link-name=\"Launch Article Lightbox\" data-is-ajax=\"\">\n <span class=\"inline-expand-image inline-icon centered-icon rounded-icon article__fullscreen modern-visible\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 22 22\" class=\"centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg article__fullscreen__svg modern-visible__svg inline-expand-image__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M3.4 20.2L9 14.5 7.5 13l-5.7 5.6L1 14H0v7.5l.5.5H8v-1l-4.6-.8M18.7 1.9L13 7.6 14.4 9l5.7-5.7.5 4.7h1.2V.6l-.5-.5H14v1.2l4.7.6\"/>\n</svg> </span> </a>\n\n<figcaption class=\"caption caption--img caption caption--img\" itemprop=\"description\">\n<span class=\"inline-information inline-icon reveal-caption-icon centered-icon rounded-icon\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 6 14\" class=\"reveal-caption-icon__svg centered-icon__svg rounded-icon__svg inline-information__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M4.6 12l-.4 1.4c-.7.2-1.9.6-3 .6-.7 0-1.2-.2-1.2-.9 0-.2 0-.3.1-.5l2-6.7H.7l.4-1.5 4.2-.6h.2L3 12h1.6zm-.3-9.2c-.9 0-1.4-.5-1.4-1.3C2.9.5 3.7 0 4.6 0 5.4 0 6 .5 6 1.3c0 1-.8 1.5-1.7 1.5z\"/>\n</svg> </span> Life cycle stages of the fruit fly, Drosophila sp, showing larva, pupa, adult male (dark abdomen) and adult female. Photograph: Ed Reschke/Getty Images\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Instead of thinking of fly research as a direct route to medical breakthroughs, it\u2019s better to see it, Crowther argues, \u201cas a way of doing quick and dirty research\u201d. He believes that because it\u2019s so cheap, it should be used in a multiplicity of ways that might point the direction to more productive lines of research. And where there are drugs that have already been tested on humans and have passed safety requirements but have failed in their efficacy with the targeted complaint, they could be retargeted by first testing them on flies.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe thinking around really bad diseases like motor neurone disease, Huntington\u2019s disease, is if you can get anything to work in a cell culture replicated in an organism, that\u2019s the beginning \u2013 as long as it\u2019s safe \u2013 of quickly getting it to patients,\u201d says Crowther.</p>\n<p>O\u2019Kane is particularly suspicious of overblown claims for translation. For him, the beauty of the fruit fly is that it is a organism that rewards study in a larger context.</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail element-rich-link--not-upgraded\" data-component=\"rich-link\" data-link-name=\"rich-link-2 | 2\">\n<div class=\"rich-link\">\n<div class=\"rich-link__container\">\n<p class=\"rich-link__header\">\n<h1 class=\"rich-link__title\">Can the humble fruit fly help create a flourishing African scientific community?</h1>\n</p>\n\n<a class=\"rich-link__link u-faux-block-link__overlay\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/aug/20/fruit-fly-african-scientific-research-kampala\"/>\n</div>\n</div>\n</aside>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019m interested in it because I think it\u2019s a great system for finding out how living things in general can work. I think by understanding the principles of how flies work then you can make better predictions for humans. The better you understand how we work the more rational you can be about trying to design therapies; I think even without directing your work towards therapy, then you can think more intelligently about therapies five or 10 years down the line.\u201d</p>\n<p>It has been said, not least by Collier, that more is known about the biology of the drosophila than any other animal on Earth. For instance, we know that fruit flies have a kind of built-in compass in their brains that enables a sense of direction. As all animals need to know how they move, it\u2019s not unreasonable to assume that it\u2019s a form of universal computation.</p>\n<p>Another study has shown that male fruit flies that are rejected by a female mate are more inclined to drown their sorrows in food spiked with alcohol than male fruit flies that had successfully mated. Again, a brain chemical that regulates the flies\u2019 appetite and is predictive of their thirst for alcohol has an equivalent that has been linked to alcohol consumption in humans.</p>\n<p>In another study, this time at Oxford, it was found that fruit flies are capable of what might be termed thoughtful deliberation. Rather than making purely impulsive decisions, they take time to react when presented with a difficult choice.</p>\n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\">\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"pullquote-paragraph\">Obviously we're more sophisticated, because we're studying them, they're not studying us</p>\n</blockquote>\n<span class=\"inline-quote inline-icon closing inline-tone-fill\">\n<svg viewbox=\"0 0 33 20\" class=\"closing__svg inline-tone-fill__svg inline-quote__svg inline-icon__svg\">\n<path d=\"M9.002 20c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053A9.968 9.968 0 0 1 4.001 6.5C4.064 2.97 7.414.937 11.003 1l-1-1C3.98 0 .098 4.447.002 10.006c-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994zm17 0c3.85.068 6.932-3.104 7-6.994.068-3.892-3.15-6.937-7-7.006-2.016-.036-3.59.694-4.888 2.053a9.968 9.968 0 0 1-.113-1.553c.063-3.53 3.413-5.563 7.002-5.5l-1-1c-6.022 0-9.904 4.447-10 10.006-.097 5.557 3.35 9.892 9 9.994z\"/>\n</svg> </span>\n</aside>\n<p>In other words, once again their behaviour could be described as human-like. It seems that the common ingredient in both human and fly behaviour is a gene called FOXP, which is closely linked to cognitive development in humans. Flies with defective FOXP take longer to arrive at a decision, just as defects in the human type of FOXP have been correlated with low intelligence.</p>\n<p>It is this long and valuable history of study of the drosophila that should guarantee its continued involvement in genetic research. But much of what has been good about working with flies is now being replicated in human stem cell research, which has the added advantage of being species-relevant. This was the other reason why Crowther moved into the private sector: the competition from stem cells meant that he found it increasingly difficult to get fruit fly-based research funded.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe fly is yesterday\u2019s guy,\u201d he says, \u201cyesterday\u2019s technology. For me, stem cells are the next fruit fly.\u201d</p>\n<p>O\u2019Kane looks quite glum at the prospect and argues that there have been questions over the future of fruit fly research ever since he started his lab 25 years ago. But he maintains that the work he\u2019s done in hereditary spastic paraplegia would have taken 10 times longer to perform with mice. O\u2019Kane has grown to appreciate the rich biological and social development of fruit flies in the time he\u2019s been working with them.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe more you look at their behaviour,\u201d he says, \u201cthe more sophisticated you realise they are. Even in aggression, how a male fruit fly behaves in a fight will depend on his previous experience of fighting with other males and what the other males\u2019 previous experience of fighting is. It\u2019s amazing to think about all the machinery that\u2019s involved to be able to do that. Obviously we\u2019re more sophisticated, because we\u2019re studying them, they\u2019re not studying us.\u201d</p>\n<p>For the time being, until some over-ambitious genetics professor does manage to mutate into a fly, that\u2019s the way the relationship should continue. And both humans and fruit flies, it turns out, can drink to that.</p>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429333": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:33:41", "url": "http://www.fccj.or.jp/number-1-shimbun/item/576-on-my-watch.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"itemFullText\"> <p>\u00a0</p>&#13;\n<p><img alt=\"No1-2015-4Carsten\" src=\"http://www.fccj.or.jp/images/number1shimbun/2015April_photos/No1-2015-4Carsten.jpg\"/><span/></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Island hopping: The author on a South Korean junket to Takeshima that got him <br/>called into the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Confessions of a foreign correspondent </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>after a half-decade of reporting from Tokyo </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>to his German readers</span></p>&#13;\n<p><a href=\"http://www.fccj.or.jp/number-1-shimbun/item/588-5.html\"><span>\u65e5\u672c\u8a9e\u8a33\u306f\u3053\u3061\u3089<br data-mce-bogus=\"1\"/></span></a></p>&#13;\n<p><br/></p>&#13;\n<p><strong><span>by Carsten Germis<br/></span></strong></p>&#13;\n<p class=\"dropcap\">M<span/></p>&#13;\n<p><span>y bags are packed, as the song goes. After more than five years as the Tokyo correspondent for the German daily, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, I will soon leave Tokyo for home. </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The country I\u2019m leaving is different from the one I arrived in back in January 2010. Although things seem the same on the surface, the social climate \u2013 that has increasingly influenced my work in the past 12 months \u2013 is slowly but noticeably changing.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>There is a growing gap between the perceptions of the Japanese elites and what is reported in the foreign media, and I worry that it could become a problem for journalists working here. Of course, Japan is a democracy with freedom of the press, and access to information is possible even for correspondents with poor Japanese language skills. But the gap exists because there is a clear shift that is taking place under the leadership of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe \u2013 a move by the right to whitewash history. It could become a problem because Japan\u2019s new elites have a hard time dealing with opposing views or criticism, which is very likely to continue in the foreign media.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The Nikkei recently published an essay by their correspondent in Berlin about the February visit to Japan of German Chancellor Angela Merkel. He wrote: \u201cMerkel\u2019s visit to Japan was more conducive to criticism of Japan than friendship. With Japanese experts, she discussed her country\u2019s policy to end nuclear power. She talked about the wartime history when she visited the Asahi and when she met with Abe. She also talked with Katsuya Okada, president of the DPJ, the largest opposition party. . . . Friendship was promoted only when she visited a factory run by a German company and shook hands with the robot Asimo.\u201d</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The country I\u2019m leaving is different </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>from the one I arrived in </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>back in January 2010. </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>That seemed harsh. But, even accepting the premise . . . what is friendship? Is friendship simply agreement? Is not true friendship the ability to speak of one\u2019s beliefs when a friend is shifting in a direction that could cause him harm? And surely Merkel\u2019s visit was more complex than just critical.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Let me make my own stance clear. After five years, my love and affection for this country are unbroken. In fact, thanks to the many fine people I\u2019ve met, my feelings are stronger than ever. Most of my Japanese friends and Japanese readers in Germany have told me they feel my love in my writing, especially following the events of March 11, 2011. </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Unfortunately, the bureaucrats at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MoFA) in Tokyo see things completely differently, and it seems some in the Japanese media feel the same way. To them I have been \u2013 like almost all my German media colleagues \u2013 a Japan basher capable of only delivering harsh criticism. It is we who have been responsible for, as the Nikkei\u2019s man in Berlin put it, the two countries\u2019 bilateral relations becoming \u201cless friendly.\u201d</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span><strong>Changing relations</strong></span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The <em>Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung</em> is politically conservative, economically liberal and market oriented. And yet, those claiming that the coverage of Abe\u2019s historical revisionism has always been critical are right. In Germany it is inconceivable for liberal democrats to deny responsibility for what were wars of aggression. If Japan\u2019s popularity in Germany has suffered, it is not due to the media coverage, but to Germany\u2019s repugnance at historical revisionism.<br/><br/></span></p>&#13;\n<p class=\"dropcap\">My tenure in Japan began with very different issues. In 2010, the Democratic Party of Japan ran the government. All three administrations I covered \u2013 Hatoyama, Kan and Noda \u2013 tried to explain their policies to the foreign press, and we often heard politicians saying things like, \u201cWe know we have to do more and become better at running the country.\u201d</p>&#13;\n<p><span>Foreign journalists were often invited by then Deputy Prime Minister Katsuya Okada, for example, to exchange views. There were weekly meetings in the Kantei, the PM\u2019s residence, and officials were willing to discuss \u2013 more or less openly \u2013 current issues. We didn\u2019t hesitate to criticize the government\u2019s stance on certain issues, but officials continued to try to make their positions understood.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The rollback came soon after the December 2012 elections. Despite the prime minister\u2019s embrace of new media like Facebook, for example, there is no evidence of an appreciation for openness anywhere in his administration. Finance Minister Taro Aso has never tried to talk to foreign journalists or to provide a response to questions about the massive government debt. </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>In fact, there is a long list of issues that foreign correspondents want to hear officialdom address: energy policy, the risks of Abenomics, constitutional revision, opportunities for the younger generation, the depopulation of rural regions. But the willingness of government representatives to talk with the foreign press has been almost zero. Yet, at the same time, anyone who criticizes the brave new world being called for by the prime minister is called a Japan basher.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Anyone who criticizes the brave new world </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>being called for by the prime minister </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>is called a Japan basher.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>What is new, and what seems unthinkable compared to five years ago, is being subjected to attacks from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs \u2013 not only direct ones, but ones directed at the paper\u2019s editorial staff in Germany. After the appearance of an article I had written that was critical of the Abe administration\u2019s historical revisionism, the paper\u2019s senior foreign policy editor was visited by the Japanese consul general of Frankfurt, who passed on objections from \u201cTokyo.\u201d The Chinese, he complained, had used it for anti-Japanese propaganda.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p>\u00a0</p>&#13;\n<p class=\"dropcap\">It got worse. Later on in the frosty, 90-minute meeting, the editor asked the consul general for information that would prove the facts in the article wrong, but to no avail. \u201cI am forced to begin to suspect that money is involved,\u201d said the diplomat, insulting me, the editor and the entire paper. Pulling out a folder of my clippings, he extended condolences for my need to write pro-China propaganda, since he understood that it was probably necessary for me to get my visa application approved.</p>&#13;\n<p><span>Me? A paid spy for Beijing? Not only have I never been there, but I\u2019ve never even applied for a visa. If this is the approach of the new administration\u2019s drive to make Japan\u2019s goals understood, there\u2019s a lot of work ahead. Of course, the pro-China accusations did not go over well with my editor, and I received the backing to continue with my reporting. If anything, the editing of my reports became sharper. </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>The heavy handedness has been increasing over the past few years. In 2012, while the DPJ was still in power, I took a junket to South Korea, interviewing former comfort women and visiting the contested island of Takeshima (Dokdo to Koreans). Of course it was PR, but it was a rare chance to see the center of the controversy for myself. I was called in by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for a meal and discussion, and received a few dozen pages of information proving that the island was Japanese.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>But things seem to have changed in 2014, </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>and MoFA officials now seem to </span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>openly attack critical reporting.<br data-mce-bogus=\"1\"/></span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>In 2013, with Abe\u2019s administration in charge, I was called in once again after I wrote about an interview with three comfort women. This also included a lunch invitation, and once again I received information to help my understanding of the prime minister\u2019s thoughts.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>But things seem to have changed in 2014, and MoFA officials now seem to openly attack critical reporting. I was called in after a story on the effect the prime minister\u2019s nationalism is having on trade with China. I told them that I had only quoted official statistics, and their rebuttal was that the numbers were wrong.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>\u00a0</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span><strong>My departing message</strong></span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>Two weeks before the epic meeting between the Consul general and my editor, I had another lunch with MoFA officials, in which protests were made of my use of words like \u201cwhitewash history,\u201d and the idea that Abe\u2019s nationalistic direction might \u201cisolate Japan, not only in East Asia.\u201d The tone was frostier and, rather than trying to explain and convince, their attitude was angrier. No one was listening to my attempts to explain why German media are especially sensitive about historical revisionism.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>I\u2019ve heard of an increase in the number of lunch invitations from government officials to foreign correspondents, and the increased budgets to spread Japanese views of World War II, and the new trend to invite the bosses of foreign correspondents deemed too critical (via business class, of course). But I would suggest the proponents tread carefully, since these editors have been treated to \u2013 and become inured to \u2013 political PR of the highest caliber and clumsy efforts tend to have an opposite effect. When I officially complained about the Consul\u2019s comments about my receiving funds from China, I was told that it was a \u201cmisunderstanding.\u201d<br/><br/></span></p>&#13;\n<p class=\"dropcap\">So here\u2019s my departing message: Unlike some of my colleagues, I do not see a threat in Japan to freedom of reporting. Though many critical voices are more silent than during the DPJ administration, they are there \u2013 and perhaps in larger numbers than before.</p>&#13;\n<p><span>The closed-shop mentality of the Japanese political elite and the present inability of the administration leaders to risk open discussion with foreign media doesn\u2019t really affect press freedom; there are plenty of other sources to gather information. But it does reveal how little the government understands that \u2013 in a democracy \u2013 policy must be explained to the public. And the world.</span></p>&#13;\n<p><span>It doesn\u2019t strike me as funny any more when colleagues tell me that the LDP doesn\u2019t have anyone in the press affairs department who will speak English or provide information to a foreign journalist. Nor does the fact that the present prime minister, who claims to be well traveled, has declined to make the short trip to speak to us at the Foreign Correspondents\u2019 Club.
