In case of the GNM there simply is not enough exhibition space to showcase all 3500 of them at the same time. The CT digitalization project will enable us to create a virtual museum in which digital facsimiles of these instruments are available to anyone with internet access.\u201d</p> \n<p>The team has already digitalized more than a hundred instruments dating back over several centuries \u2013 from the baroque trumpet and the mouth harmonica to the square piano. Different types of CT systems are needed to scan different-sized instruments. The square piano, for example, is X-rayed utilizing a linear accelerator, which is the source of radiation in Europe\u2019s largest CT machine. The XXL X-ray environment consists of two eight-meter-tall steel scaffolding towers and a turntable with a diameter of three meters, housed in a hall covering a surface area of 400 square meters and rising to a height of 14 meters. Smaller string and wind instruments are X-rayed using conventional apparatus. For each test, the object is placed on a turntable between the X-ray source and typically a flat-panel detector, which produces images of very high spatial resolution. A specially designed holder keeps the instrument firmly in place while the X-ray beam penetrates the rotating object. The required dose of radiation varies according to the thickness and density of the material. Depending on the structure and condition of the instrument, the scanning process can take several hours, during which the CT system records several thousand images which are then stitched together to produce a three-dimensional view.</p> \n<p>The researchers aim to publish their results online by January 2018 at the latest. These will not only include the collected CT data but also detailed and comprehensible documentation of all steps in the measurement process. The examination standard defines the CT scanning parameters, and the accompanying set of guidelines provides advice on its application for different instruments.</p> \n<h4>Openly accessible metadata</h4> \n<p>Moreover, at the end of the project, all the technical parameters and metadata will be published in a database developed at the GNM. \u201cIdeally, we would like to be able to digitalize the museum\u2019s entire collection of historical musical instruments and place the 3D images online. Our examination standard defines the best way to go about this task,\u201d says Fuchs. \u201cOne of the many factors that we are now able to quantify is the time needed to digitalize different instruments. For example, a complete X-ray scan of a violin at a resolution of less than 50 microns takes up to 20 hours. This figure can be extrapolated to determine the time needed to scan an amount of x instruments. This produces a specific quantity of voluminous datasets, requiring corresponding amounts of hard disk and network capacity and special software. We have compiled a list of all these requirements.\u201d Another advantage of the standard is that it enables the know-<br/> ledge and experience gained from scanning musical instruments to be applied to other museum collections such as telescopes and other scientific instruments or old weapons.</p> \n<p>Visitors to the \u201cLong Night of Sciences\u201d event in F\u00fcrth on October 21 will have the opportunity to take a look inside numerous historical musical instruments. One of the exhibitions will include a presentation of CT images by Fraunhofer EZRT, selected from among those produced during the project.</p></div>\n        </div></body></html>"}, "15429410": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:57:37", "url": "http://awealthofcommonsense.com/2017/10/taking-financial-advice-from-a-lottery-winner/", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"entry-content clearfix\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-19627\" src=\"http://awealthofcommonsense.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Screen-Shot-2017-09-28-at-9.49.32-AM.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"http://awealthofcommonsense.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Screen-Shot-2017-09-28-at-9.49.32-AM.png 309w, http://awealthofcommonsense.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Screen-Shot-2017-09-28-at-9.49.32-AM-199x300.png 199w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 309px) 100vw, 309px\"/>\n<p>In a 2005 Powerball drawing a strange thing happened.</p>\n<p>There were 110 people who all picked the same exact lottery numbers \u2014 22, 28, 32, 33 and 39. This group picked 5 out of the 6 numbers correctly, good enough for the 2nd prize.</p>\n<p>Having 110 people pick the same numbers across 29 different states was quite rare, considering at most there were 4-5 people who would split the prize in the average drawing.</p>\n<p>Each winner was due to make six figures, making the total payout was $19 million higher than expected. This raised some eyebrows and caused people at the lottery association to look into how this could have happened. After ruling out fraud, they finally figured it out, as told by the New York Times:</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"242\" data-total-count=\"2100\"><em>\u201cOur first winner came in and said it was a fortune cookie,\u201d said Rebecca Paul, chief executive of the Tennessee Lottery. \u201cThe second winner came in and said it was a fortune cookie. The third winner came in and said it was a fortune cookie.\u201d</em></p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"287\" data-total-count=\"2387\"><em>Investigators visited dozens of Chinese restaurants, takeouts and buffets. Then they called fortune cookie distributors and learned that many different brands of fortune cookies come from the same Long Island City factory, which is owned by Wonton Food and churns out four million a day.</em></p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"162\" data-total-count=\"2549\"><em>\u201cThat\u2019s ours,\u201d said Derrick Wong, of Wonton Food, when shown a picture of a winner\u2019s cookie slip. \u201cThat\u2019s very nice, 110 people won the lottery from the numbers.\u201d</em></p>\n<p>If any of these 110 people worked in the investment business they probably would have started their own newsletter \u2014\u00a0<em>My Secret Formula for Winning the Lottery.</em></p>\n<p>I was reminded of this story while reading a New York Times profile on angel investor Jason Calacanis. Calacanis is worried about how technology is going to impact the jobs of millions of Americans and wants to help this group invest in tech to make up for it. His new book is called\u00a0<em>Angel: How to Invest in Technology Startups \u2014 Timeless Advice From An Angel Investor Who Turned $100,000 into $100,000,000.</em></p>\n<p>Here\u2019s the backstory on how he earned his $100 million:</p>\n<p><em>In 2009, the venture capital firm Sequoia\u00a0enlisted Mr. Calacanis as one of its \u201cscouts,\u201d\u00a0an informal network of entrepreneurs who look for promising companies on the firm\u2019s behalf. As part of that program, Mr. Calacanis invested $25,000 on a friend\u2019s crazy-sounding tech-enabled cab company. The friend was Travis Kalanick; the company was Uber. And despite that company\u2019s recent turmoil, the deal has turned into Mr. Calacanis\u2019s biggest win as an angel by far, worth about $100 million on paper.</em></p>\n<p>For those who are unaware, Sequoia Capital is one of the most well-known venture capital firms in the world. So while Calacanis took a huge right risk in this situation and hit the jackpot, I\u2019m not sure how much timeless advice 99.9% of investors can glean from someone who has contacts at one of the best VC firms in the world who made his fortune on a single home run investment.</p>\n<p>Even the best investors in venture capital have a hard time picking and choosing the right deals and investments. Most are complete failures. I know from experience how ultra-competitive this space is and it\u2019s only gotten more so in recent years. Even if you put in the time to educate yourself about angel investing it\u2019s one of the harder areas of the markets to invest successfully in because the opportunity set is so limited and hard to access.</p>\n<p>I have a <a href=\"http://awealthofcommonsense.com/2014/05/investing-hard-adam-sandler-edition/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">theory</a>\u00a0about comedians\u00a0that the more successful (read: wealthy) they become the less funny they become (Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David are probably the exceptions to this rule) because they lose touch with reality or begin to take themselves too seriously.</p>\n<p>This seems to apply to most uber-wealthy people who try to give financial advice to the average person as well.\u00a0I can appreciate successful people who would like to share with others what made them successful. But no amount of books, morning routines, meditation rituals or inspirational quotes are going to make you filthy rich. The circumstances are drastically different than people in the middle class are dealing with. And it\u2019s impossible to replicate luck.</p>\n<p>Obviously, this isn\u2019t always the case. Not all wealthy people are out of touch lottery winners. But people have to temper their expectations when trying to emulate the top 1% of the top 1%. You can be inspired by these people but following their blueprint for becoming wealthy is a different story.</p>\n<p>I\u2019ll give Calacanis the benefit of the doubt and assume he doesn\u2019t have ill intentions here. But most people are better off learning how to get their personal finances in order and investing in themselves than trying to find home run investments that will change their lives.</p>\n<p>Sources:<br/>\n<a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/11/nyregion/who-needs-giacomo-bet-on-the-fortune-cookie.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Who Needs Giacomo: Bet on the Fortune Cookie (NYT)</a><br/>\n<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/technology/when-tech-disrupts-wealth-and-stability-angels-may-be-solution.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Should the Middle Class Invest in Risky Tech Start-Ups? class=\"markdown-body entry-content\" itemprop=\"text\"><pre><code>  _______         _____  \n |__   __|       |  __ \\  \n    | | ___  _ __| |__) | __ _____  ___   _  \n    | |/ _ \\| '__|  ___/ '__/ _ \\ \\/ / | | |  \n    | | (_) | |  | |   | | | (_) &gt;  &lt;| |_| |  \n    |_|\\___/|_|  |_|   |_|  \\___/_/\\_\\\\__, |  \n                                       __/ |  \n                                      |___/  \n</code></pre>\n<p><em>TorProxy is kernel module which routes all network traffic through the Tor anonymity network.</em></p>\n<p>The module uses netfilter hooks in the linux kernel to filter/NAT packets and ensure all outbound traffic is headed for the Tor network.</p>\n<p>The Tor network currently only supports TCP ipv4 traffic so all other protocol packets are dropped, with the exception of DNS packets, these are allowed and are forwarded to the TorDNS proxy to prevent DNS leaks.</p>\n<p>This means no ICMP pings, ipv6, UDP etc...</p>\n<p>Applications do not have to be configured to use the proxy as it uses Tors transparent proxy and NAT's all outbound TCP requests.</p>\n<p>Access to hidden services still has to be performed through the Tor browser.</p>\n<p>Tested on Debian kernel version 3.16.0-4, you will need to have the linux-headers.</p>\n<h1><a href=\"#installation\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-installation\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 can either run the proxy portably within the folder after compilation or install using:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>make install</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>ensure you have the Tor DNS and Transparent Tor proxy running on the following ports:</p>\n<p>add to your torrc configuration file:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>DNSPort 9053<br/>\nTransPort 9040</p>\n</blockquote>\n<h1><a href=\"#usage\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-usage\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 running. Insert the module and your done! Remember to remove the module when you want regular internet access.</p>\n<p>If Tor chooses a new entry relay you may need to refresh the relays table in the module using '-r'.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#arguments\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-arguments\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Arguments:</h2>\n<pre><code>-s insert module and start proxy  \n-i insert torproxy kernel module  \n-r remove torproxy kernel module  \n-t refresh tor relays table\n</code></pre>\n</article>\n  </div></body></html>"}, "15430953": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:07:17", "url": "http://mashable.com/2017/10/06/puerto-rico-fcc-google-project-loon/#Inq6LGlJEEqc", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"article-content blueprint\">\n\n<p>The FCC has given Google permission to deploy its Project Loon balloons over Puerto Rico.\u00a0</p>\n<p>Previously, the helium balloons were able to provide LTE coverage to Peru after extreme flooding. But in that case, Google had already partnered with a telecom provider on the ground, which it depended on to beam the signal to the balloons, for disaster relief.</p>\n<p>In Puerto Rico, <a href=\"http://mashable.com/2017/09/28/project-loon-deployment-puerto-rico/\">Google's innovation lab</a>, X, is starting from scratch. It's unclear if Puerto Rico's stressed telecom companies even have the resources to partner with Google on this endeavor.</p>\n\n<p>But it's worth a try if there's any chance it can help the island's 3.5 million people connect with friends and loved ones. Puerto Rico's infrastructure was demolished by Hurricane Maria. Less than 25 percent of its cellphone towers are back online, and power has only been restored to about 10 percent of the island, according to <a href=\"http://status.pr/\" target=\"_blank\">a site</a> run by the Puerto Rican government.\u00a0</p>\n<p>The FCC announcement came from Matthew Berry, chief of staff to the agency's chairman, Ajit Pai, on Twitter.\u00a0</p>\n<div class=\"twitter-wrapper sort-rerender\"><div><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">BREAKING: FCC issues experimental license to Google to provide emergency cellular service in Puerto Rico through Project Loon balloons.</p>\n<p>\u2014 Matthew Berry (@matthewberryfcc) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/matthewberryfcc/status/916446259598299140?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\">October 6, 2017</a></p>\n</blockquote></div></div>\n<div class=\"twitter-wrapper sort-rerender\"><div><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Kudos to FCC staff for quick work approving Google's application to provide emergency cellular service to Puerto Rico through Project Loon!</p>\n<p>\u2014 Matthew Berry (@matthewberryfcc) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/matthewberryfcc/status/916446899607089152?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\">October 6, 2017</a></p>\n</blockquote></div></div>\n<p><em>Mashable</em> reached out to Google for more details, and will update this story if the company responds.\u00a0</p>\n<p>Project Loon works by relaying a signal beamed from a telecom partner on the ground through its network of balloons floating around 65,000 feet in the air, and then sending that signal down to people with cellphones. In Peru, the project's leader <a href=\"https://blog.x.company/helping-out-in-peru-9e5a84839fd2?gi=a425a3ec3ea2\" target=\"_blank\">said</a> 160 GB of data was sent over an area roughly the size of Sweden, which was \"enough data to send and receive around 30 million WhatsApp messages, or 2 million emails.\"</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</section>\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429930": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:49:34", "url": "https://archive.org/details/AlfredNorthWhiteheadAimsOfEducation1967", "text": "<html><body/></html>"}, "15430955": {"score": 11, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:07:33", "url": "https://www.collectorsweekly.com/articles/california-wine/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry\">\n\t\t\t<p><a href=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10181212/BigTreePairBig.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65923\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10181212/BigTreePairBig.jpg\" alt=\"BigTreePairBig\"/></a></p>\n<p class=\"dropcap\">If you live in San Francisco and want to show off your knowledge of California wine to a few friends from out of town, you might take them to a wine-savvy restaurant like Boulevard, a block or so from the Ferry Building and San Francisco Bay. Scanning the <a href=\"http://static1.squarespace.com/static/55396095e4b067fd7c6e076f/t/566517c8e4b0fe72366c35cf/1449465800522/wine_list.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">multi-page wine list</a>, you\u2019d say something knowing about how hot Kongsgaard is right now, but you\u2019d pass on the $165 bottle of its 2013 Chardonnay and order a $94 bottle of Far Niente\u2014same varietal, same year\u2014instead. Perusing the reds, you\u2019d remark that the $650 price tag for a bottle of 2010 Sine Qua Non Stockholm Syndrome Syrah from the Santa Rita Hills of Santa Barbara County is actually quite reasonable, but that the 2010 Qup\u00e9 Syrah from the nearby Edna Valley is also nice and, at $105, a bargain by comparison.</p>\n<blockquote class=\"left\"><p>\u201cThe main tactic of the newly formed C.W.A. was to wait everyone out.\u201d</p></blockquote>\n<p>These recommendations would be sure to impress. But what if one of your old chums, rising to the challenge of your enological expertise, suddenly turns and asks if <em>you</em> know that the city of Richmond across the bay\u2014home to a noxious Chevron oil refinery and is considered one of the <a href=\"http://lawstreetmedia.com/crime-america-2015-top-10-dangerous-cities-200000/\" target=\"_blank\">10 most dangerous cities</a> with populations under 200,000\u2014was once California\u2019s undisputed wine capital?</p>\n<p>You\u2019d blink, and accuse your pal of pulling your leg, until he starts telling you the story of the rise and fall of the California Wine Association, which, in 1907, built a 47-acre compound there, evocatively named Winehaven.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65926\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65926 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10181924/22-CALWA-map.jpg\" alt=\"Top: In the late 1890s, the California Wine Association sold some of its member's wine under the Big Tree brand. (Courtesy Early California Wine Trade Archive) Above: A 1902 map touts the C.W.A. awards and reach. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Top: In the late 1890s, the California Wine Association sold some of its members\u2019 wine under the Big Tree brand. Click to enlarge. (Courtesy <a href=\"http://earlycalwinetrade.org/\" target=\"_blank\">Early California Wine Trade Archive</a>) Above: A 1902 map touts the C.W.A.\u2019s awards and geographic reach. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>The location was not a whim: In 1906, 10-million gallons of C.W.A. wine had been spilled in the San Francisco earthquake and boiled in the fires that followed. By the time your friend has finished explaining that as many as 12-million gallons of wine and brandy a year were once produced at Winehaven, you\u2019d realize that while you may be able to order a decent bottle of wine in a fancy restaurant, you don\u2019t know beans about California\u2019s wine history, especially before Prohibition.</p>\n<p>Few people do. In fact, if those who shop at BevMo for bargain bottles think about California\u2019s wine history at all, their timeline usually begins in 1976 at the so-called Judgment of Paris, in which a Stag\u2019s Leap Cabernet Sauvignon and a Chateau Montelena Chardonnay, both from the Napa Valley, stunned the international wine world by beating some of France\u2019s most esteemed Bordeaux and Burgundies in a blind tasting.</p>\n<p>To be sure, one would not directly credit the C.W.A. for the Judgment of Paris, but this watershed moment in California wine history didn\u2019t come out of nowhere. Or at least that was my reaction after reading a terrific new book called <a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/dp/1250033225/?tag=colleweekl-20\" target=\"_blank\"><em>Tangled Vines</em></a> by <a href=\"http://francesdinkelspiel.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Frances Dinkelspiel</a>. Even though the main thread of Dinkelspiel\u2019s narrative concerns the events leading up to an arson-caused warehouse fire in 2005, which destroyed 4.5 million bottles of wine worth at least a quarter-billion dollars, the story of the C.W.A.\u2014at one point, it controlled a staggering 84 percent of California\u2019s wine business\u2014figures prominently. What else might Dinkelspiel know about the C.W.A. that didn\u2019t make it into her book? My interest piqued, I decided to call her and find out.</p>\n<p>\u201cIn the 1890s, the California wine industry was a mess,\u201d Dinkelspiel told me when we spoke a few days later over the phone. The economic panic of 1893, she explained, had created a glut of grapes, severely depressing the price of fruit and wine alike. \u201cThe timing was right for someone to get in there and dominate the market in order to stabilize it,\u201d she says.</p>\n\n<p>Founded in San Francisco in 1894, the C.W.A. was comprised of a number of highly influential \u201csomeones,\u201d including the biggest and most successful wine merchants in the city, who had their hands in everything from the ownership of vineyards across the state to wineries and distributorships. By joining together to form the C.W.A., they were effectively colluding\u2014in broad daylight\u2014to create a wine cartel, despite the fact that the Sherman Antitrust Act had just passed in 1890. That\u2019s how bad things were for California grape growers and wine merchants in 1894; the prospect of an antitrust lawsuit brought by the federal government was preferable to the status quo.</p>\n<p>The main tactic of the newly formed C.W.A. was simple\u2014wait everyone out. As the biggest buyer of California grapes and biggest seller of finished product, the C.W.A. could force growers to accept the prices it was willing to pay, lest they get nothing before their fruit rotted. Similarly, if wine sellers in the Chicago, New Orleans, and New York didn\u2019t want to pay the prices the monopoly was demanding for its barrels and bottles of wine, the association could simply hold onto its inventory until the recalcitrant wine merchants had run out of theirs.</p>\n<p>Not surprisingly, such strong-arming did not sit well with growers, winemakers, and distributors not aligned with the C.W.A., which is why, by 1897, an all-out economic wine war was raging between the association and an upstart rival, the California Wine-Makers Corporation.</p>\n<p>Because of its size and deep pockets, the C.W.A. had the upper hand on the economic battlefield. Under the leadership of president Percy Morgan, the\u00a0association abandoned its 1893 tactics, which were designed to stabilize the wine market by holding the line on prices. Instead, it slashed the cost of its wine, undercutting Wine-Makers Corporation wineries. By 1900, that corporation\u2019s three most important members, including the Italian-Swiss Colony winery of Sonoma County, had raised the white flag and joined the C.W.A. At the turn of the 20th century, membership in the C.W.A. was apparently the only way for a big California winery to survive.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65927\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65927 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10182044/CWA-Men-2.jpg\" alt=\"Two of California's most important wine figures at the end of the 19th century were Isaias Hellman (left) and Percy Morgan.\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Two of California\u2019s most important wine figures at the end of the 19th century were Isaias Hellman (left) and Percy Morgan.</p></div>\n<p>The resolution of this battle between the dueling cartels paved the way for an unprecedented $1 million investment\u00a0in the C.W.A. in 1901. The equivalent of around $28 million today, the funding infusion was led by an investment banker and Southern California vineyard owner named Isaias Hellman, who just so happens to be Dinkelspiel\u2019s great-great-grandfather.</p>\n<p>Even without the family connection, the C.W.A. would have found its way into <em>Tangled Vines</em>. But Dinkelspiel\u2019s page-turner had only whetted my appetite for details about the monopoly and the circumstances that led to its creation, so I called up wine writer and publisher <a href=\"http://www.gailunzelman.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Gail Unzelman</a>, whose <em><a href=\"http://www.nomispress.com/califwineassn.html\" target=\"_blank\">The California Wine Association and Its Member Wineries, 1894-1920</a></em>, co-authored with the late wine historian Ernest Peninou, is considered the definitive work on the subject.</p>\n<p>As a publisher of books via <a href=\"http://nomispress.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Nomis Press</a> and a respected wine quarterly called \u201c<a href=\"http://www.waywardtendrils.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Wayward Tendrils</a>,\u201d Unzelman has provided a platform for such esteemed wine writers and historians as Peninou, Thomas Pinney, and Charles Sullivan. As a collector for more than 40 years, she\u2019s filled binder upon binder with wine ephemera such as labels and wine-related postcards, as well as a wine library that now boasts some 4,000 titles, most of them focused on California\u2019s viticultural history.</p>\n<p>\u201cI think it\u2019s about 3,917,\u201d Unzelman corrects me when we speak. \u201cI\u2019m a very organized person, and I can still get through my house,\u201d she adds. \u201cIt\u2019s not like there\u2019s stuff in the hallway\u2014yet.\u201d</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65928\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img class=\"wp-image-65928 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10182116/Calwa10Million.jpg\" alt=\"The C.W.A.'s logo featured Bacchus, the god of wine, and a grizzly bear like the one on California's state flag. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman) \"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">The C.W.A.\u2019s logo featured Bacchus, the god of wine, sailing with a grizzly bear like the one on California\u2019s state flag. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>One of the cornerstones of Unzelman\u2019s book collection is a one-of-a-kind, handmade volume, which came to her almost by accident. \u201cI was at an antiques show in Sacramento,\u201d Unzelman recalls. \u201cI asked a dealer there if she had anything on wine. She said, \u2018No, not really, but I\u2019ve got this old scrapbook here that\u2019s got wine clippings in it.\u2019 It was a nice scrapbook, leather-bound and very thick. It happened to be C.W.A. president Percy Morgan\u2019s scrapbook.\u201d The scrapbook sat in Unzelman\u2019s closet with all her other binders and historical goodies for years, until Peninou came along with his draft of what became <em>The California Wine Association and Its Member Wineries</em>. \u201cThat Morgan scrapbook gave us a lot of information that wasn\u2019t known at the time,\u201d Unzelman says.</p>\n<p>Unlike the board members of the C.W.A., who represented the cr\u00e8me de la cr\u00e8me of the California wine industry, Morgan was a money guy, which is to say he was an accountant, although his business card also bore a second, fancier title, \u201cFinancial Agent.\u201d During the late 1880s, Morgan helped manage the financial affairs of such forgotten San Francisco firms as Nevada Gypsum &amp; Fertilizer Co. and Pacific Auxiliary Fire Alarm Co., but in 1892, he gained a toehold in the world of wine by being named a director of the Samuel Lachman Estate Co., which managed the various holdings of the late Mr. Lachman, including his wine-merchant firm, S. Lachman Company. After their father\u2019s passing, Samuel\u2019s two sons aligned themselves with the C.W.A., turning over their two-million-gallon-capacity warehouse on Brannan Street in San Francisco to the association so it could store its wine there.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65930\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65930 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11082911/BuenaVistaPlaque.jpg\" alt=\"Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma may be designated as State of California Landmark number 392, but it is not the \u201cbirthplace of California wine.\u201d (Via Buena Vista Winery)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma may be designated as State of California Landmark number 392, but it is not the \u201cbirthplace of California wine.\u201d (Via Buena Vista Winery)</p></div>\n<p>Other than the Morgan scrapbook, it\u2019s a safe bet that a good portion of Unzelman\u2019s source materials overlapped with those Dinkelspiel studied at the Bancroft Library on the campus of the University of California at Berkeley. There, she learned about her family\u2019s wine lineage, beginning with her great-great-grandfather\u2019s winery in what was once a dusty speck of a town east of Los Angeles called Rancho Cucamonga. Southern California is where the state\u2019s wine industry began, despite a plaque at the <a href=\"http://www.buenavistawinery.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Buena Vista Winery</a> in the Northern California county of Sonoma, which identifies the 1857 site as State of California Landmark number 392 and the \u201cbirthplace of California wine.\u201d</p>\n<p>In fact, Southern California\u2019s place on the wine-history continuum begins in 1769, when the recently sainted Franciscan Father Junipero Serra founded the first of 21 California missions, including the one at San Juan Capistrano in 1776, where grape cuttings from Spain were planted. A few years later, at Mission San Gabriel Archangel near present-day Los Angeles, the fruit was found to thrive.</p>\n<p>As Dinkelspiel describes it in <em>Tangled Vines</em>, the local Native Americans whose souls were supposedly being saved at Mission San Gabriel \u201cwere treated like slaves\u201d by Father Jose Maria de Zalvidea, who directed them to clear 170 acres of chaparral-covered earth for row upon row of grape vines. \u201cIt was known as <em>La Vina Madre</em>, or the mother vineyard,\u201d Dinkelspiel writes. \u201cBy 1829, the mission may have been producing from 400 to 600 barrels of wine a year.\u201d</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65932\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65932 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11083215/FrancesTapia2.jpg\" alt=\"Author Frances Dinkelspiel in Rancho Cucamonga, near the winery that was once owned by her great-great-grandfather Isaias Hellman. (Via francesdinkelspiel.com)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Author Frances Dinkelspiel in Rancho Cucamonga, where her great-great-grandfather Isaias Hellman once owned the winery founded by Tiburcio Tapia. (Via <a href=\"http://francesdinkelspiel.com/\" target=\"_blank\">francesdinkelspiel.com</a>)</p></div>\n<p>A decade later, in 1839, a former Mexican soldier named Tiburcio Tapia planted even more Mission grapes at the Cucamonga Rancho, about 30 miles due east of Mission San Gabriel. Back then California was still a part of Mexico, so Tapia got his 13,000 acres directly from the Mexican government. Before long, the Cucamonga Vineyard, as it came to be called, covered more than 600 acres of the Rancho, making it a more accurate birthplace of the California wine industry. Sorry, Sonoma.</p>\n<p>By 1848, California was a territory of the United States\u2014statehood followed in 1850. After numerous changes in ownership, which Dinkelspiel covers in often bloody detail in <em>Tangled Vines,</em> in 1870, Isaias Hellman purchased the Cucamonga Rancho and Vineyard in a sheriff\u2019s sale to settle various claims against the Rancho and satisfy its debts. It\u2019s not known for sure if any of the grapes still growing at the Cucamonga Vineyard in 1870 had been taken directly from cuttings at <em>La Vina Madre</em>, but the character of the wine produced there was probably not markedly different from the sweet, sacramental stuff made for Serra and de Zalvidea.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65938\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65938 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11111008/mother-grapevine.jpg\" alt=\"A linen postcard, circa 1930-1945, of the &quot;Mother Grapevine&quot; in San Gabriel. (Via Digital Commonwealth)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">The \u201cMother Grapevine\u201d in San Gabriel, circa 1930-1945. (Via Digital Commonwealth)</p></div>\n<p>This raises an interesting question: What did 19th-century California wine taste like, anyway? \u201cIt\u2019s so undocumented,\u201d Unzelman says. \u201cI had a conversation recently with someone who was looking for tasting notes from that period, but they didn\u2019t describe wine like we do today. They would analyze a wine and say it had good acid, that it was bold, that it was red. Sometimes they might say a wine was \u2018velveteen,\u2019 but they wouldn\u2019t have said it had raspberry, blackberry, or cherry \u2018notes.\u2019 They didn\u2019t talk about wine that way.\u201d</p>\n<blockquote class=\"left\"><p>\u201cA sweet aphrodisiacal scent filled the air. The aroma, cooped up inside a bottle for ninety-three years, rushed out.\u201d</p></blockquote>\n<p>Even so, we do have a few clues. To begin, we know that a sizable percentage of the wine produced in Southern California was fortified with brandy to lengthen its shelf life and increase its alcohol content. One type of fortified wine produced at the Cucamonga Vineyard before and during Hellman\u2019s 40-year ownership of the property was port. Another was Angelica, which was actually an unfermented, fortified, grape-juice-based beverage rather than a wine per se\u2014in wine circles, a blend of this type is called a <em>mistelle</em>.</p>\n<p>If you could time-travel a bottle of Angelica from the Southern California of that era to a restaurant like Boulevard today, it would not make the wine list. This is not a guess. In the middle of the 19th century, the state\u2019s wine was routinely sneered at by wine aficionados and, more importantly, wine merchants in New York, who also purchased wine from local sources in the eastern United States, as well as from European wineries. Before the transcontinental railroad was finished in 1869, California wine had to be shipped in \u201cpipes\u201d (large barrels holding about 125 gallons each) around South America\u2019s Cape Horn.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65948\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65948 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11113314/Barrels-CWA.jpg\" alt=\"A barge of California wine barrels being loaded onto a cargo ship in San Francisco Bay, 1912. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">A barge of California wine barrels being loaded onto a cargo ship in San Francisco Bay, 1912. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>Was it worth the effort? In 1862, a professional wine taster in New York dismissed what was considered one of the best Los Angeles-area Angelicas, made by Sainsevain Brothers, as follows: \u201cA bottle full of it contains I don\u2019t know how many headaches.\u201d</p>\n<p>With praise like that, it makes you wonder why Hellman was so keen to get his hands on the Cucamonga Vineyard in 1870. Dinkelspiel thinks she knows the reason. \u201cI cannot speak to how much he loved wine,\u201d she says of her great-great-grandfather\u2019s motivations, \u201cbut he was very intrigued by the future of wine and agriculture. He was trying to make it a viable business.\u201d</p>\n<p>In 1901, therefore, the C.W.A. represented a new investment opportunity for Hellman in a familiar agricultural sector. Hellman may have had holdings and roots\u2014literally\u2014in Rancho Cucamonga, but he could plainly see that the industry was moving north. Sure, the Mission grapes that produced sweet, fortified wines like port did well in the south, but the climate was poorly suited to varietals that would produce the dry table wines that were becoming increasingly popular for daily drinking. Growers quickly discovered that counties like Sonoma and Napa were better for that. Sorry, SoCal.</p>\n<p>Indeed, in 1870, the same year Hellman bought the Cucamonga Vineyard and its hundreds of acres of Mission grapevines at a sheriff\u2019s sale, more visionary agricultural entrepreneurs were already planting neat rows of Zinfandel grapes in Sonoma. There, and on the other side of the Mayacamas Mountains in Napa, the seeds of the modern age of California winemaking were being sown, which perhaps accounts for the confusion of California\u2019s official historians.</p>\n\n<p>The data tell the tale of this migration north. In 1858, more than 46 percent of all the grapes grown and harvested in California came from the Los Angeles Viticultural District, home to the Cucamonga Vineyard. That year, Napa and Sonoma combined accounted for less than 10 percent\u2019s of the state\u2019s total production. A decade later, though, the two northern California counties were on par with Los Angeles, and by 1890, Napa and Sonoma could claim more than 50 percent of the state\u2019s total acreage in wine grapes, compared to less than 10 percent for L.A. Meanwhile, sweet-wine production was moving to the San Joaquin Valley. In short, Southern California no longer represented the future of California winemaking, and Hellman knew it.</p>\n<p>As a businessman, you\u2019d think Hellman might have balked at the idea of investing in an obvious monopoly, but according to Thomas Pinney in <em><a href=\"http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520269538\" target=\"_blank\">The Makers of American Wine</a></em>, the C.W.A. \u201cescaped attention from the Department of Justice,\u201d because antitrust laws at the time applied only to staple commodities, which the C.W.A. successfully argued wine was not. Similarly, the independent wine firms that became a part of the C.W.A. remained independent in their management after being subsumed into the C.W.A., presenting a veneer of competition between allegedly autonomous members, even though no such competition existed in practice.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65940\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65940 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11111135/CWA-ad.jpg\" alt=\"A C.W.A. ad published in &quot;Pacific Wine and Spirit Review,&quot; late 1890s. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">A C.W.A. ad in \u201cPacific Wine &amp; Spirit Review,\u201d late 1890s. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>But the most important salve against antitrust action, Pinney writes, was the policy of keeping retail wine prices reasonable\u2014if there was no price-gouging, regulators were encouraged to reason, how bad could this so-called monopoly really be? In fact, low prices were fine if you were a consumer, but, as Pinney writes, it \u201cwas of no apparent concern\u201d to regulators that \u201cin order to maintain modest prices, it might be necessary to gouge the grape grower and the winemaker.\u201d In fact, that gouging was exactly what precipitated the formation of the California Wine-Makers Corporation and triggered the wine wars of the 1890s.</p>\n<p>Stabilizing prices turned out to be the simplest part of the C.W.A.\u2019s job. Trickier was controlling its wines\u2019 reputation, which, at the turn of the 20th century, largely meant changing the way wine was bought and sold. To this end, the C.W.A. encouraged the practice of only shipping wine bottled and labeled in California to cities in the Midwest and on the eastern seaboard, since shipping wine in bulk clearly invited fraud.</p>\n<p>Here\u2019s how it worked: Throughout the late 1800s, wine was routinely sold in large barrels known as pipes. Upon receipt of a pipe of perfectly good California wine, local wine merchants would often blend the liquid to suit their tastes. More notoriously, a pipe of eastern rotgut that a merchant may have been forced to acquire in a bulk purchase might be blended with a pipe of much better California wine before being bottled and sold with the local merchant\u2019s \u201cCalifornia-grown\u201d label on it. Naturally, if a consumer bought a bottle of alleged California wine that left a bad taste in their mouth, they\u2019d think twice before buying another, weakening overall demand.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65946\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65946 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11112648/CWA-HQ-1906.jpg\" alt=\"Photo from the July 31, 1906 issue of the &quot;Pacific Wine &amp; Spirit Review,&quot; showing the damage to the C.W.A.'s Fourth Street cellars. (Via archive.org)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">This photo from the July 31, 1906, issue of the \u201cPacific Wine &amp; Spirit Review,\u201d shows the damage to the C.W.A.\u2019s Fourth Street cellars caused by the April 18 earthquake. (Via <a href=\"https://archive.org/stream/pacificwinespiri48sanfrich#page/n413/mode/2up\" target=\"_blank\">archive.org</a>)</p></div>\n<p>The C.W.A. was just beginning to make headway on this ambitious goal of shipping only bottled wine when the San Francisco earthquake struck on April 18, 1906. Since its founding in 1894, San Francisco had been C.W.A.\u2019s main base of business operations, the place where deals were struck and millions of gallons of wine was warehoused in sites across the city. After the ground stopped shaking, this geographic diversification looked like it had been a good idea since most of the C.W.A.\u2019s structures survived. But then came the fires, which consumed\u00a0most of the C.W.A.\u2019s warehouses. According to Charles Sullivan in the April 2006 edition of Unzelman\u2019s \u201cWayward Tendrils,\u201d \u201cOf the twenty-eight commercial wine establishments in the city, twenty-five were destroyed.\u201d</p>\n<p>The most famous C.W.A. survivor was the Italian-Swiss Colony cellar at Battery and Greenwich Streets near the San Francisco waterfront. It still stands there today, thanks to the Colony\u2019s founder, Andrea Sbarboro, who directed employees to flood the warehouse\u2019s roof with water pumped from a spring on the property. \u201cWe fought unceasingly for three days and three nights,\u201d Sbarboro would later write of the battle to keep the fires raging around him from reaching the Italian-Swiss Colony building. Two million gallons of C.W.A. wine were saved.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65933\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11083317/CWA1906PumpingWine4.jpg\"><img class=\"wp-image-65933\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11083317/CWA1906PumpingWine4.jpg\" alt=\"Photos taken by Percy Morgan showing how wine was pumped through fire hoses from C.W.A. headquarters and Third and Bryant Streets to tanks on an awaiting barge. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/></a><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">In these photos taken by Percy Morgan, wine is pumped through fire hoses from C.W.A. headquarters at Third and Bryant Streets to tanks on an awaiting barge. Click to enlarge. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>Another two million were salvaged from the C.W.A.\u2019s main headquarters, at Third and Bryant Streets, but not before \u201cthe wooden tanks and casks came apart in the fire storm,\u201d as Sullivan describes it. The spilled wine might have washed into the streets as it had at other warehouses, but a \u201cplugged sewer line\u201d and the building\u2019s solid concrete walls and floor kept the sloshing wine within the structure. Suddenly, the building itself had become a wine cellar, which enabled the C.W.A. to pump the precious liquid through fire hoses to a small fleet of barges, which were towed to Stockton in the San Joaquin Valley, where the wine was distilled into brandy.</p>\n<blockquote class=\"left\"><p>\u201cOf the twenty-eight commercial wine establishments in the city, twenty-five were destroyed.\u201d</p></blockquote>\n<p>That was an acceptable solution to a difficult circumstance, since the distillation process neutralized the contaminants in the spilled C.W.A. wine, but the marketing plan for 35,000 bottles of wine that had not been destroyed at Third and Bryant was a good deal sketchier. \u201cThese bottles were supposedly cased with a special label as a souvenir of the disaster,\u201d writes a skeptical Sullivan in \u201cWayward Tendrils,\u201d and the wine was advertised as having been \u201cmellowed and ripened and aged by the heat,\u201d a specious claim at best. \u201cOf course this is a very expensive way to produce fine wines,\u201d read another C.W.A. announcement, \u201cand the Association will certainly not endeavor to repeat their success.\u201d</p>\n<p>In fact, Sullivan suggests these 35,000 bottles might never have existed at all, except perhaps in the overheated imagination of a public-relations flack. \u201cI have never seen any such label,\u201d Sullivan writes. \u201cNeither have I read anything about their later release or heard a word from anyone who has ever seen one.\u201d</p>\n<p>Dean Walters hasn\u2019t seen one, either, which is saying a lot since he was long the leading dealer of California wine ephemera. Today, Walters runs the <a href=\"http://earlycalwinetrade.org/\" target=\"_blank\">Early California Wine Trade Archive</a> and is working to create a museum to house his and a few others\u2019 sizable collections. \u201cWe hope to find space in an existing institution to exhibit our materials in a gallery setting and safely archive our materials,\u201d Walters says. \u201cThe intent is to have changing displays focusing on wineries, districts, or special subjects.\u201d</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65891\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/08122744/Winehaven.png\"><img class=\"wp-image-65891 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/08172604/CWA-Lede.jpg\" alt=\"This colorful postcard of Winehaven seems to promise happier, more prosperous times after the trauma of the 1906 earthquake and the fires that followed. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/></a><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">This colorful postcard of Winehaven seems to promise sunnier days after the trauma of the 1906 earthquake and the fires that followed. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>One subject might well be Winehaven, which Percy Morgan set out to build almost immediately after the fires caused by the earthquake had died down\u2014the association would battle its insurance companies, who refused to pay legitimate fire-insurance claims, all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which finally ruled in its favor in 1910. Strategically located at Point Molate in Richmond, Winehaven allowed Morgan to consolidate the C.W.A.\u2019s activities in one place, which he believed would be economically more efficient than having lots of warehouses spread all over San Francisco.</p>\n<p>It was. The east side of San Francisco Bay, which lacked bridges at the time, was also closer to transcontinental railroad lines than San Francisco, while its rail-equipped deep-water dock anticipated the shipping lane that would open through the Panama Canal in 1914. In addition, the pier made it easy to offload grapes grown in Napa and Sonoma counties, which could be sent down the Napa and Petaluma Rivers and across the bay to Winehaven for the fall crush. Some 25,000 tons of grapes were crushed at Winehaven in 1907, and in 1908, workers handled 45,000 tons of fruit, producing more than 675,000 gallons of wine that year.</p>\n<p>Beyond its winemaking, bottling, and storage capabilities, Winehaven offered C.W.A. members cooperage services to help replace the thousands of tanks, barrels, and casks that had been destroyed in the 1906 fires. The oak for such containers had come from Arkansas and Tennessee, but after the 1906 earthquake, suppliers in those states jacked up prices by 40 percent. Coopers at Winehaven, therefore, turned to good old California redwood, which meant wine-storage containers of all sizes could be built for less than half the cost of oak ones.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65941\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65941 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11111740/Winehaven-from-Below.jpg\" alt=\"View of Building One at Winehaven today. Note the braces holding the brick turret in place.\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">View of Building One at Winehaven today. Note the braces holding the brick turret in place.</p></div>\n<p>Architecturally, the crown jewel of Winehaven was Building One, which was clad in brick and featured \u201ccrenelated parapets and turrets on the corners,\u201d to quote Sullivan.\u00a0Like the C.W.A.\u2019s headquarters at Third and Bryant Streets in San Francisco, Building One\u2019s floors and ceiling were made of poured concrete, further reinforced by an inner skeleton of thick steel posts and beams. This construction method proved quite durable, surviving several decades of hard use by the Navy, which converted Point Molate into a fuel depot during World War II, as well as the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, which flattened a freeway and ruptured a section of the bridge between Oakland and San Francisco.</p>\n<p>For Percy Morgan\u2019s purposes, Winehaven was durable enough to help the C.W.A. solidify its hold on the California wine industry. By 1909, the Calwa Distributing Company was formed \u201cto bring the consumer, in glass, the best wines of the California Wine Association,\u201d as Peninou and Unzelman put it in their book. Calwa and Ca-dis-co became two of the C.W.A.\u2019s biggest brands of \u201cpure reliable wines,\u201d as they were advertised.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately, keeping the C.W.A. on its feet after the earthquake and during the construction of Winehaven had come at the price of Morgan\u2019s health\u2014by 1911, he would retire from the C.W.A. after 15 years at its helm, retreating to Europe for three years of \u201crest and recuperation\u201d before returning home to serve on numerous boards (Stanford University among them) and build a three-story, half-timbered mansion south of San Francisco known as Morgan Manor.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65942\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65942 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11112129/Rail-Dock-Final.jpg\" alt=\"Railroad tracks on the deep-water pier at Winehaven made it early to load or unload ships and barges that docked there. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Railroad tracks on the deep-water pier at Winehaven made it easy to load and unload the ships and barges that docked there. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>Despite Morgan\u2019s exit from the C.W.A., the second decade of the 20th century began well for the association. \u201cWhen the 1910 European vintage was virtually wiped out by bad weather,\u201d Peninou and Unzelman write, \u201cthe California wine industry correspondingly prospered.\u201d That\u2019s one reason why, by 1913, the association was investing in numerous improvements and expansions at Winehaven.</p>\n<p>At the same time, though, the C.W.A.\u2019s future was cloudy. The association\u2019s aging leaders were literally dying off, the outbreak of war in Europe in 1914 had slowed exports, and, most ominously of all, the growing Prohibition movement in the United States suggested that it was only a matter of time before the C.W.A.\u2019s very livelihood\u2014selling alcoholic beverages\u2014would be illegal.</p>\n<p>In fact, the association first acted on the threat of Prohibition in 1907, when it began producing grape juice in earnest. By the end of 1909, the C.W.A. was selling both still and sparkling non-alcoholic grape drinks\u2014produced in red (Zinfandel) and white (Muscatel) at a facility in the San Joaquin Valley\u2014under the Calwa brand. \u201cCalwa Grape Juice Steadies the Nerves,\u201d promised one advertisement. The slogan may well have been a subconscious attempt to steady the nerves of C.W.A. officials, too.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65943\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img class=\"wp-image-65943 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11112206/Calwa-Juice-Bottle.jpg\" alt=\"As the clouds of Prohibition loomed, the C.W.A. put more of its energies and resources into non-alcoholic grape beverages such as Calwa. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">As Prohibition loomed, the C.W.A. put more of its energies and resources into non-alcoholic grape beverages such as Calwa. (Courtesy Gail Unzelman)</p></div>\n<p>Other C.W.A. actions betrayed more overt alarm. As early as 1908, the C.W.A. had been slowing its purchases of grapes from its growers, lest its inventories grow <em>too</em> quickly, and in 1909, it published a 62-page booklet promoting the enlightened ideal of temperance versus outright Prohibition, quoting Thomas Jefferson and St. Paul to make its case. Congress didn\u2019t help matters when, in 1915, it raised the tax on the brandy used to fortify port and other C.W.A. products from three to 55 cents per gallon. And then, in 1916, the C.W.A. found itself fighting a pair of pro-Prohibition amendments on the California ballot, reprinting and distributing hundreds of thousands of copies of a booklet titled \u201cHow Prohibition Would Affect California\u201d to help sway public opinion.</p>\n<p>In the end, California voters rejected both measures, but this victory at the ballot box would not derail the Prohibition movement. Since the C.W.A. could see that it would not be long before Prohibition would become the law of the land, it began to rid itself of the millions of gallons of wine it had in storage at Winehaven. But 1917 was a very bad year to be selling wine. By the end of the year, Congress had passed the 18th Amendment banning the \u201cthe manufacture, sale, or transportation of intoxicating liquors,\u201d which was promptly sent to the states for ratification.</p>\n<p>With the market for its goods soft at home, the C.W.A. looked internationally for buyers, but the war in Europe made exports to that region problematic, and even after war ended in November 1918, Europe was an economic shambles, making it a poor customer for California wine. One of the few bright spots in the C.W.A.\u2019s efforts to liquidate its liquid assets came from former C.W.A. nemesis\u2014and 1906 savior\u2014Italian-Swiss Colony, which managed to sell 84,000 cases of its Golden State champagne into Asian markets for more than $1 million.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65915\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65915 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10151340/CWA-Sign-600.jpg\" alt=\"To combat the fraud that occurred when its wine was shipped out of state in barrels and pipes, which could be blended before bottling, the C.W.A. promoted the practice of shipping its wine in bottles.\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">To combat the fraud that occurred when its wine was shipped out of state in barrels and pipes, which could be blended before bottling, the C.W.A. promoted the practice of shipping its wine in bottles. (Courtesy <a href=\"http://earlycalwinetrade.org/\" target=\"_blank\">Early California Wine Trade Archive</a>)</p></div>\n<p>All this made Percy Morgan, the man who had done more than anyone to make the C.W.A. the force it had become, inconsolable. On the morning of April 16, 1920, just three months after the passage of the Volstead Act, which put regulatory teeth in the 18th Amendment, the C.W.A.\u2019s former leader, still in his pajamas, walked into the library of Morgan Manor, raised a shotgun to his head, and pulled the trigger.</p>\n<p>Meanwhile, the increasingly desperate C.W.A. was trying to relocate its grape-juice business from the San Joaquin Valley to Winehaven, but this costly effort failed to generate the revenues needed to keep the enterprise afloat. As for its wine inventory, it was slowly sold as the law permitted\u2014some export licenses were granted after Prohibition, and some of the liquid in the barrels at Winehaven were sold as sacramental wine, bringing the story of California\u2019s wine history full circle.</p>\n<p>As it turns out, a small amount of the wine stored at Winehaven may have been owned by the heirs of Isaias Hellman, who passed away from natural causes about a week before Morgan\u2019s violent end. According to Frances Dinkelspiel, there were two types of Hellman wine that may have been stored at Winehaven at the beginning of Prohibition, port and Angelica, both made from Mission grapes that had been planted as early as 1839 by Tiburcio Tapia. The Hellman wine was not that old\u2014it was crushed in 1875\u2014and it would not be bottled until 1921, when a Santa Rosa company, Grace Bros. Brewing, purchased the C.W.A. name and remaining wine inventory at Winehaven.</p>\n<p>\u201cJoseph Grace was a family friend,\u201d Dinkelspiel says. \u201cI don\u2019t know this for a fact, but I speculate that he found these barrels and bottled them up for the family. During Prohibition, there were a lot of restrictions on wine, but you could make and own a certain amount of \u2018home\u2019 wine. Anyway, that\u2019s what I think happened.\u201d</p>\n<p>Dinkelspiel estimates that probably no more than 600 bottles of her great-great-grandfather\u2019s wine were filled in 1921, about half in port and half in Angelica. One of Dinkelspiel\u2019s cousins ended up with less than a third of those bottles, 175 of which were stored in the wine warehouse that was torched by an arsonist in 2005\u2014the primary subject of her book\u2014obliterating her most tangible connection to her family\u2019s wine legacy. For Dinkelspiel, the warehouse fire was not just a juicy story, it was personal.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65944\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65944 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11112352/Bobby-on-Roof.jpg\" alt=\"Winehaven advocate Bobby Winston on the roof of Building One. \"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">Winehaven advocate Bobby Winston on the roof of Building One.</p></div>\n<p>After reading her book, gulping its chapters like so many glasses of Far Niente Chardonnay at Boulevard, I realized I needed to see Winehaven for myself. To that end, Dinkelspiel got me in touch with Bobby Winston, who owns a publication called \u201cBay Crossings.\u201d In turn, Winston introduced me to Willie Agnew, who is the caretaker at Point Molate and the guy who actually showed us around, doing everything from leading us onto Building One\u2019s sunny roof to unlocking the structure\u2019s mysterious basement.</p>\n<p>As I quickly learned, Winston is one of Winehaven\u2019s biggest boosters. He believes the property, now designated as the Winehaven National Historic District, is a natural spot for thoughtful redevelopment, including a winery. After all, it\u2019s got all that wine history going for it, plus unobstructed views across the bay to Mount Tamalpais in Marin, making it a natural future tourist destination. Having grown during its naval years, Winehaven now stands at 71 acres, which Winston believes make it big enough to support a variety of small businesses, whose rent checks would help pay for its upkeep, similar to the successful private-public partnership at the historic Presidio in San Francisco.</p>\n<p>Today, Building One is still the most iconic structure at Point Molate. Walking the grounds, one can almost picture the site\u2019s winemaking and naval history being told through interpretive displays and exhibits. Wandering inside the empty structure, one can equally imagine the rows of redwood casks, filled with millions of gallons of wine, that must have consumed this now-silent space. The bones of the building would probably support such tonnage still, but the unreinforced brick walls inside and out would be costly to bring up to code\u2014the building\u2019s signature brick turrets are currently held in place by wide rings of aluminum.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65945\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65945 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/11112429/Inside-White-Columns.jpg\" alt=\"The inside of Building One features concrete floors and ceilings, with heavy steel framing throughout.\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">The inside of Building One features concrete floors and ceilings, with heavy steel framing throughout.</p></div>\n<p>Making such band-aid reinforcements permanent, as well as figuring out which of the other remaining Winehaven structures are worth saving, would probably only be a small part of the cost of bringing new life to the historic site. Substantial infrastructure improvements would be required before the first glass of wine was poured in Winehaven\u2019s first tasting room. According to a report prepared by Winston for Richmond\u2019s mayor, Tom Butt, Point Molate lacks electrical power, which is why this section of bayfront is still dark at night\u2014if you ever find yourself driving east across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge after sundown, look to your left, and you\u2019ll see what I mean.</p>\n<p>Plumbing is also a major problem. All of the water to the area flows through a single 12-inch pipe, and there is no collection system to send sewage in the opposite direction. Finally, there\u2019s the road, which is just a single lane in each direction, with little room on either side for widening. And while there\u2019s an exit off Interstate 580 to Point Molate if you are heading west, eastbound visitors must navigate a tangle of poorly marked boulevards, drives, and avenues. All of which explains why Winston, despite his enthusiasm and affection for Winehaven, believes the process of figuring out what to do with the site is probably decades away.</p>\n<div id=\"attachment_65916\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-65916 size-full\" src=\"https://d3h6k4kfl8m9p0.cloudfront.net/uploads/2015/12/10151546/HellmanBottles.jpg\" alt=\"The last two bottles of Frances Dinkelspiel's stash of her great-great-grandfather's wine.\"/><p class=\"wp-caption-text\">The last two bottles of Frances Dinkelspiel\u2019s stash of her great-great-grandfather\u2019s wine. (Via <a href=\"http://francesdinkelspiel.com/\" target=\"_blank\">francesdinkelspiel.com</a>)</p></div>\n<p>For her part, Dinkelspiel has Winehaven to thank for preserving those precious bottles of 19th-century Hellman wine, even if the bulk of her inheritance was torched by an arsonist in 2005. Fortunately, she kept a couple of bottles of Hellman in her home. By the end of <em>Tangled Vines</em>, curiosity about what\u2019s in those bottles has gotten the best of her, so she determines to taste their contents with an expert whose palate is at least on par with that 1862 taster who had written off the best Angelica in Southern California as being little more than a bottle of headaches. In fact, Dinkelspiel found an individual whose palate is no doubt light-years more discerning, a master sommelier named Fred Dame.</p>\n<p>As she tells it in her book, Dame is a tough sell at first, but eventually Dinkelspiel convinces him to let her bring her last bottle of her great-great-grandfather\u2019s port to Dame\u2019s home so they may taste it and let the chips fall where they may. In <em>Tangled Vines</em>, she describes the care Dame takes to break the wax seal from the top of the bottle, and the way he eases the corkscrew into the cork. It crumbles, but is still moist at the bottom, a good sign.</p>\n<p>\u201cAlmost immediately,\u201d Dinkelspiel writes, \u201ca sweet aphrodisiacal scent filled the air. I was standing about four feet away from the bottle yet I could smell the Port\u2019s fumes. The aroma, cooped up inside a bottle for ninety-three years, rushed out.\u201d</p>\n<p>The translucent liquid itself, she writes, is dark amber, \u201calmost the color of the redwood it was once stored in.\u201d And then Dame pours two glasses, and for the first time in her life, Dinkelspiel brings her great-great-grandfather\u2019s wine to her lips. \u201cI lifted my glass and let the Port swirl over my tongue,\u201d she writes. \u201cI wasn\u2019t prepared for the intensity of flavor. Sweetness exploded over my taste buds, followed by a pleasant sharpness.\u201d</p>\n<p>\u201cIt has a wonderful old clay smell that I love,\u201d she quotes Dame as saying. \u201cIt has almost a sour cherry quality to it, like cherries soaked in brandy,\u201d Dame says, concluding with his much-anticipated verdict: \u201cIt\u2019s phenomenal.\u201d</p>\n<p>Maybe that\u2019s why Hellman invested in the Cucamonga Vineyard. And maybe, just maybe, that other Southern California Angelica, ripped to shreds by a grumpy New York taster in 1862, got a bad rap. \u201cI\u2019ve never tasted the Angelica,\u201d Dinkelspiel says. \u201cA family member who has tasted it said it\u2019s very good. I do have one bottle of Angelica,\u201d she adds. \u201cI\u2019m kind of tempted to open it one day, but I haven\u2019t\u2014yet.\u201d</p>\n<p>(<em>Thanks to <a href=\"http://francesdinkelspiel.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Frances Dinkelspiel</a>, <a href=\"http://earlycalwinetrade.org/\" target=\"_blank\">Dean Walters</a>, <a href=\"http://www.gailunzelman.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Gail Unzelman</a>, <a href=\"http://baycrossings.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Bobby Winston</a>, and Willie Agnew for their help with this story. While Steve Bannon, Paul Manafort, and Kellyanne Conway are marquee names you're familiar with, Parscale was in the back room -- operating as the campaign's secret weapon.</p><figure class=\"image pull-none image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/06/d1034cd7-a5ae-47ac-b2be-d3f5d472403d/resize/770x/91ec9c29c304a32342d9a28c7bc69e3c/parscaleint.jpg#\" alt=\"parscaleint.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/06/d1034cd7-a5ae-47ac-b2be-d3f5d472403d/resize/770x/91ec9c29c304a32342d9a28c7bc69e3c/parscaleint.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            CBS News\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>He was hired to run the digital team, but over time came to oversee advertising, data collection and much of the fund-raising. Facebook was going to be how he won.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: And Facebook IS how he won.</p><p>Brad Parscale: I think so.\u00a0 I think Donald Trump won, but I think Facebook was the method \u2013 it was the highway in which his car drove on.</p><figure class=\"image pull-none image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/983421ab-73a9-4e84-be50-bbde124f3d4f/resize/770x/b59a99f865d37b3439fd3e6ff365a6e0/unspecified-2.jpg#\" alt=\"unspecified-2.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/983421ab-73a9-4e84-be50-bbde124f3d4f/resize/770x/b59a99f865d37b3439fd3e6ff365a6e0/unspecified-2.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            Donald J. Facebook was the 500-pound gorilla, 80 percent of the budget kind of thing.</p><p>Facebook's advertising technology helped President Obama in 2012, but today Facebook offers something far more precise and sophisticated. While the president recently tweeted that \"Facebook was always anti-Trump,\" Parscale relied heavily on the company, particularly on its cutting-edge targeting tools.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: One of the best things Facebook did for you, I heard, was penetrate the rural vote. Trump campaign\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah. And, we took opportunities that I think the other side didn't.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Like what?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Well, we had our-- their staff embedded inside our offices.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: What?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah, Facebook employees would show up for work every day in our offices.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Whoa, wait a minute. Parscale said the Trump campaign used the technology to microtarget on a scale never seen before \u2013 and to customize their ads for individual voters.</p><p>Brad Parscale: We were making hundreds of thousands of 'em.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: You make 100,000 ads. </p><p>Brad Parscale: Programmatically. In one day. In one day.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: So 100,000 different ads every day? </p><p>Brad Parscale: Average day 50-60 thousands ads.</p><figure class=\"image pull-none image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/0d5866f8-2a26-4ede-9d54-25175ebaf84b/resize/770x/0207a6e7eefe267a7a36bfe002dccf75/deplorable-demo-cu.jpg#\" alt=\"deplorable-demo-cu.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/0d5866f8-2a26-4ede-9d54-25175ebaf84b/resize/770x/0207a6e7eefe267a7a36bfe002dccf75/deplorable-demo-cu.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><div class=\"caption\"><p>Donald J. Trump campaign ads</p></div><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            CBS News\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>This was all automated.</p><p>Brad Parscale: Changing language, words, colors, changing things because certain people like a green button better than a blue button. How do you know I'd only like a green button?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Because I'd give you the red, blue buttons, you never click on 'em.</p><p>Parscale showed us <em>how</em> they tested: by sending out multiple versions of the same ad with only subtle differences. \u00a0</p><p>Brad Parscale: Here we have an American flag, here we have a face of Hillary. What is it that makes it go: Poof! \"I'm gonna stop and look.\"</p><figure class=\"image pull-left image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/55137bab-85c2-41cc-be07-ab50c0d01173/resize/770x/e0c93caab6c323a37ee539a3de5b79f6/threeaddemo.jpg#\" alt=\"three-ad-demo-cu.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/55137bab-85c2-41cc-be07-ab50c0d01173/resize/770x/e0c93caab6c323a37ee539a3de5b79f6/threeaddemo.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><div class=\"caption\"><p>Three campaign ads with similar appearances but different messages.</p></div><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            CBS News\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>To get people to stop and look, he crafted different messages for different people -- so that you only got ads about the issues you cared about most. He showed us three ads that looked alike.</p><p>Brad Parscale: It's pretty much the identical design. Positive coloring. Different message.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: This is one is tax, this one is childcare, this one is energy.</p><p>Brad Parscale: They were all targeted to different users of whatever platform, in this case it was Facebook.</p><p>Sent out to different people. And it could be each other's next-door neighbors\u2026all in Ohio.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: This one person at 11 Elm Street gets this one and 13 Elm Street gets that one.</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yup, yup.</p><p>Parscale took some heat for taking microtargeting too far because he hired Cambridge Analytica. It's a company that uses so-called psychographics that microtarget ads based on personality. For instance, an extrovert would get one kind of message, a neurotic person another. It's controversial because of its Orwellian overtones.\u00a0</p><figure class=\"image pull-none image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/7a4aa88b-4bd1-46d2-a3ee-f302d2378676/resize/770x/37c2e1d6d037f3dcc4e489a8188f9850/brad-main.jpg#\" alt=\"brad-main.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews3.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/08/7a4aa88b-4bd1-46d2-a3ee-f302d2378676/resize/770x/37c2e1d6d037f3dcc4e489a8188f9850/brad-main.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            Donald J. Trump Campaign\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>After Trump won, Cambridge Analytica said it was key to the victory. But Parscale insists he never used psychographics. He oversaw data collection, polling, advertising both online and on TV, and significantly digital fund raising. By adding donation buttons for people to click on in the online ads, he was able to bring in a record $240 million in small donations.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: How many presidential campaigns had you worked on before this one?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Zero.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Your wife has a wonderful expression about you being thrown into this.</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah.\u00a0 She said that I was thrown into the Super Bowl, never played a game and won.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: That's what it sounds like.</p><p>It's made him a local hero back home in Kansas. He grew up in Topeka, playing basketball \u2013 he's 6 foot 8. After briefly working at a tech company in California, he moved to San Antonio, Texas, and became a marketer. He taught himself to code, opened a small web-design business and went looking for customers.</p><p>Brad Parscale: I started tapping shoulders at a bookstore asking people if they needed a website, when they were buying books on web design.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Yeah, but what-- you're hanging around at a bookstore?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah, a Border's.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: You're hanging around at Border's and say, \"Can you hire me?\" </p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Come-on. </p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: So how did you get involved with the Trump people?</p><p>Brad Parscale: I was sitting at IHOP and I got an email. I was eating a ham and cheese omelet. I was. I get an email and I open it up and it says-- \"This is Kathy K. from the Trump Org-- can you please call me?\" That's it\u2014</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Outta nowhere?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Outta nowhere.</p><p>Six years ago she was looking for someone to design a website for a Trump real estate project. Parscale bid lowest, got the job, and soon many more followed: websites for Eric's foundation, Melania's skincare line, the family's wineries. Then, in early 2015, came another life-changing email:</p><p>Brad Parscale: It said \"Donald Trump is thinking about running for president. We need a website in two days.\" So I wrote back, I said, \"Yeah, I'll do it for $1500.\"</p><p>Lesley Stahl: $1500?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah. And by the end, it was $94 million.</p><p>$94 million is what his company was paid. Much of it was spent on things like buying ads.\u00a0 Parscale learned very fast on the job, with the help of the Republican National Committee. They had amassed a giant database to identify the issues people cared about, and predict how nearly 200 million Americans would vote.</p><p>One reason Parscale thinks President Trump won is because of an issue the RNC database honed in on that he says the Clinton campaign missed:</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Infrastructure.</p><p>Brad Parscale: Infrastructure. It was voters in the rust belt that cared about their roads being rebuilt, their highways, their bridges. They felt like the world was crumbling. \u00a0So I started making ads that would show the bridge crumbling. You know, that's microtargeting them. Because I can find the 1,500 people in one town that care about infrastructure. Now, that might be a voter that normally votes Democrat.</p><p>While he tried to persuade Democrats to vote for Mr. Trump \u2013 the campaign was accused, in a Businessweek article, of trying to <em>suppress</em> the vote of \"idealistic white liberals, young women and African Americans,\" a charge he denies.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Did you micro target by race?</p><p>Brad Parscale: No we did not. Not at all.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Never?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Nope.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Did you post hateful images?</p><p>Brad Parscale: I don't believe so.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: The candidate Trump was never shy about pushing buttons, about pushing prejudices. He used what most people would consider offensive language sometimes.</p><p>Brad Parscale: I don't think the math said that most people saw it as offensive. I think a small group of people saw it as offensive, who have a lot of power.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: But you did mirror him?</p><p>Brad Parscale: We mirrored certain things that he would say, mainly things he said in rallies.</p><p>Many of the messages he sent out were what's known as dark ads. These were separate from the posts the Russians reportedly sent of fake news stories that made Clinton look bad. The <em>ads</em> \u2013 on divisive issues \u2013 were spread using Facebook tools similar to the ones Parscale and the Clinton campaign used.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Facebook has admitted that the Russians spent $100,000 -- at least $100,000 -- on ads to influence the U.S. campaign.
