Yeah, I mean, I wouldn't want that; I'm American.</p><p>But the question is: did the Trump campaign collude with the Russians \u2013 and as the digital director, was Parscale involved?</p><p>Brad Parscale: I think it's a joke. Like, at least for my part in it.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Very few people think it's a joke.</p><p>Brad Parscale: I think it's a joke when they involve myself. 'Cause I know my own activities, and I know the activities of this campaign. I was there. It's just a farce.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: It's a farce that you colluded with the Russians?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah. It's just a joke.</p><p>What about what happened on Twitter? Which was flooded with pro-Trump tweets generated by robots, or bots.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Did you have a hand in generating these bots\u2014</p><p>Brad Parscale: I had nothing to do with bots. I don't think bots work.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: You were called the king of the bots.</p><p>Brad Parscale: I know. It's ridiculous. It's just the craziest thing ever. No one on our team ever sat down with me and said, \"Brad, we should make bots.\"</p><p>Lesley Stahl: But if-- if you see that there are hundreds of thousands of bots floating around with pro-Trump messages, somebody generated it. Where would it come from?</p><p>Brad Parscale: I would imagine there were people, everyday people in America, who thought they were trying to help. I don't know.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: If the bots came from the Russians, would you know?</p><p>Brad Parscale:\u00a0 Nah.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Do you think it might have?</p><p>Brad Parscale:\u00a0 No idea.</p><p>Lesley Stahl: Could it have?</p><p>Brad Parscale: Could be from anybody in the world. </p><p>The House Intelligence Committee looking into the Russian meddling has contacted Parscale and he's agreed to talk to them.\u00a0 \u00a0</p><p>Lesley Stahl: I understand that part of these investigations that are going on is to understand how the Russians knew where to target their campaigns, their messages. They seemed to know specifically where to go-- that were places that helped Trump.</p><p>Brad Parscale: Yeah. First of all, I-- it's not very hard to figure out. Pennsylvania, Ohio, you know. I mean, the same-- I think we've had the same swing states for decades. </p><p>Parscale told us the Russian plotline is pushed by liberals who think they lost because he cheated. The irony, he says, is that it wasn't a foreign entity helping the campaign, but left-leaning American companies like Twitter, Google, and above all Facebook.</p><p>Brad Parscale: These social platforms are all invented by very liberal people on the West and East Coast, and we figure out how to use it to push conservative values. I don't think they ever thought that would happen. I would say the number one thing that people come up to me is, like, \"I just never thought Republicans would be the ones to figure out how to use all this.\"</p><p>Lesley Stahl: So a liberal invents all this stuff and a conservative in the Middle-West figures out how to use it?</p><p>Brad Parscale: And I think we used it better than anyone ever had in history. </p><p>Last month, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced plans to make political ads on the site more transparent. As for Brad Parscale, he's already working on President Trump's 2020 reelection campaign.</p><p><em>Produced by Shachar Bar-On. This allows\nbetter mixing of prose and code in the examples, provides links to\ndownload the examples as both a Python script and a Jupyter notebook,\nand improves the thumbnail galleries.  The examples have been\nre-organized into <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../tutorials/index.html#tutorials\"><span class=\"std std-ref\">Tutorials</span></a> and a <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../gallery/index.html#gallery\"><span class=\"std std-ref\">Gallery</span></a>.</p>\n<p>Many docstrings and examples have been clarified and improved.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-features\">\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"string-categorical-values\">\n\n<p>All plotting functions now support string categorical values as input.\nFor example:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-python\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"n\">data</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"p\">{</span><span class=\"s1\">'apples'</span><span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"mi\">10</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"s1\">'oranges'</span><span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"mi\">15</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"s1\">'lemons'</span><span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"mi\">5</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"s1\">'limes'</span><span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"mi\">20</span><span class=\"p\">}</span>\n<span class=\"n\">fig</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">ax</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"n\">plt</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">subplots</span><span class=\"p\">()</span>\n<span class=\"n\">ax</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">bar</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">data</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">keys</span><span class=\"p\">(),</span> <span class=\"n\">data</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">values</span><span class=\"p\">(),</span> <span class=\"n\">color</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s1\">'lightgray'</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n</pre></div>\n</div>\n<p>(<a class=\"reference external\" href=\"../users/whats_new-1.py\">Source code</a>, <a class=\"reference external\" href=\"../users/whats_new-1.png\">png</a>, <a class=\"reference external\" href=\"../users/whats_new-1.pdf\">pdf</a>)</p>\n\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"enhancements-to-polar-plot\">\n\n<p>The polar axes transforms have been greatly re-factored to allow for more\ncustomization of view limits and tick labelling. Additional options for view\nlimits allow for creating an annulus, a sector, or some combination of the two.</p>\n<p>The <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/projections_api.html#matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_rorigin\" title=\"matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_rorigin\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">set_rorigin()</span></code></a> method may\nbe used to provide an offset to the minimum plotting radius, producing an\nannulus.</p>\n<p>The <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/projections_api.html#matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_theta_zero_location\" title=\"matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_theta_zero_location\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">set_theta_zero_location()</span></code></a>\nmethod now has an optional <code class=\"code docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">offset</span></code> argument. This argument may be used\nto further specify the zero location based on the given anchor point.</p>\n<div class=\"figure align-center\" id=\"id1\">\n<a class=\"reference external image-reference\" href=\"../gallery/pie_and_polar_charts/polar_scatter.html#scatter-plot-on-polar-axis-with-offset-origin\"><img alt=\"../_images/sphx_glr_polar_scatter_002.png\" src=\"../_images/sphx_glr_polar_scatter_002.png\"/></a>\n<p class=\"caption\"><span class=\"caption-text\">Polar Offset Demo</span></p>\n</div>\n<p>The <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/projections_api.html#matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_thetamin\" title=\"matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_thetamin\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">set_thetamin()</span></code></a> and\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/projections_api.html#matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_thetamax\" title=\"matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_thetamax\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">set_thetamax()</span></code></a> methods may\nbe used to limit the range of angles plotted, producing sectors of a circle.</p>\n<div class=\"figure align-center\" id=\"id2\">\n<a class=\"reference external image-reference\" href=\"../gallery/pie_and_polar_charts/polar_scatter.html#scatter-plot-on-polar-axis-confined-to-a-sector\"><img alt=\"../_images/sphx_glr_polar_scatter_003.png\" src=\"../_images/sphx_glr_polar_scatter_003.png\"/></a>\n<p class=\"caption\"><span class=\"caption-text\">Polar Sector Demo</span></p>\n</div>\n<p>Previous releases allowed plots containing negative radii for which the\nnegative values are simply used as labels, and the real radius is shifted by\nthe configured minimum. This release also allows negative radii to be used for\ngrids and ticks, which were previously silently ignored.</p>\n<p>Radial ticks have been modified to be parallel to the circular grid\nline, and angular ticks have been modified to be parallel to the grid\nline. It may also be useful to rotate tick <em>labels</em> to match the\nboundary. Calling <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">ax.tick_params(rotation='auto')</span></code> will enable the\nnew behavior: radial tick labels will be parallel to the circular grid\nline, and angular tick labels will be perpendicular to the grid line\n(i.e., parallel to the outer boundary).</p>\n</div>\n\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"busy-cursor\">\n\n<p>The interactive GUI backends will now change the cursor to busy when\nMatplotlib is rendering the canvas.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"added-matplotlib-ticker-percentformatter\">\n\n<p>The new <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/ticker_api.html#matplotlib.ticker.PercentFormatter\" title=\"matplotlib.ticker.PercentFormatter\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">PercentFormatter</span></code></a> formatter has some nice\nfeatures like being able to convert from arbitrary data scales to\npercents, a customizable percent symbol and either automatic or manual\ncontrol over the decimal points.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"reproducible-ps-pdf-and-svg-output\">\n\n<p>The <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH</span></code> environment variable can now be used to set\nthe timestamp value in the PS and PDF outputs. See <a class=\"reference external\" href=\"https://reproducible-builds.org/specs/source-date-epoch/\">source date epoch</a>.</p>\n<p>Alternatively, calling <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">savefig</span></code> with <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">metadata={'creationDate':</span> <span class=\"pre\">None}</span></code>\nwill omit the timestamp altogether for the PDF backend.</p>\n<p>The reproducibility of the output from the PS and PDF backends has so\nfar been tested using various plot elements but only default values of\noptions such as <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">{ps,pdf}.fonttype</span></code> that can affect the output at a\nlow level, and not with the mathtext or usetex features. When\nMatplotlib calls external tools (such as PS distillers or LaTeX) their\nversions need to be kept constant for reproducibility, and they may\nadd sources of nondeterminism outside the control of Matplotlib.</p>\n<p>For SVG output, the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">svg.hashsalt</span></code> rc parameter has been added in an\nearlier release. This parameter changes some random identifiers in the\nSVG file to be deterministic. The downside of this setting is that if\nmore than one file is generated using deterministic identifiers\nand they end up as parts of one larger document, the identifiers can\ncollide and cause the different parts to affect each other.</p>\n<p>These features are now enabled in the tests for the PDF and SVG\nbackends, so most test output files (but not all of them) are now\ndeterministic.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"orthographic-projection-for-mplot3d\">\n\n<p><a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.html#mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D\" title=\"mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span supplying <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'ortho'</span></code> enables\northographic view.</p>\n<p>Compare the z-axis which is vertical in orthographic view, but slightly href=\"../api/_as_gen/mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.html#mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D\" title=\"mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">Axes3D</span></code></a> now has a\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.html#mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.voxels\" title=\"mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.voxels\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">voxels</span></code></a> method, for visualizing boolean 3D\ndata. Uses could include plotting a sparse 3D heat map, or visualizing a\nvolumetric model.</p>\n<div class=\"figure align-center\" id=\"id3\">\n<a class=\"reference external image-reference\" href=\"../gallery/mplot3d/voxels_numpy_logo.html\"><img alt=\"../_images/sphx_glr_voxels_numpy_logo_001.png\" src=\"../_images/sphx_glr_voxels_numpy_logo_001.png\"/></a>\n<p class=\"caption\"><span class=\"caption-text\">Voxel Demo</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"improvements\">\n\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"add-fill-bar-argument-to-anchoredsizebar\">\n\n<p>The <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">mpl_toolkits</span></code> class\n<code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">AnchoredSizeBar</span></code> now has an\nadditional <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_bar</span></code> argument, which makes the size bar a solid rectangle\ninstead of just drawing the border of the rectangle. The default is <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">None</span></code>,\nand whether or not the bar will be filled by default depends on the value of\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">size_vertical</span></code>. If <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">size_vertical</span></code> is nonzero, <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_bar</span></code> will be set to\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">True</span></code>. If <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">size_vertical</span></code> is zero then <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_bar</span></code> will be set to\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">False</span></code>. If you wish to override this default behavior, set <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_bar</span></code> to\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">True</span></code> or <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">False</span></code> to unconditionally always or never use a filled patch\nrectangle for the size bar.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-python\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"kn\">import</span> <span class=\"nn\">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class=\"kn\">as</span> <span href=\"../users/whats_new-3.pdf\">pdf</a>)</p>\n\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"annotation-can-use-a-default-arrow-style\">\n\n<p>Annotations now use the default arrow style when setting <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">arrowprops={}</span></code>,\nrather than no arrow (the new behavior actually matches the documentation).</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"barbs-and-quiver-support-dates\">\n\n<p>When using the <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiver.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiver\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiver\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">quiver()</span></code></a> and\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.barbs.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.barbs\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.barbs\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">barbs()</span></code></a> plotting methods, it is now possible to\npass dates, just like for other methods like <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">plot()</span></code></a>.\nThis also allows these functions to handle values that need unit-conversion\napplied.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"hexbin-default-line-color\">\n\n<p>The default <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">linecolor</span></code> keyword argument for <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.hexbin.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.hexbin\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.hexbin\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">hexbin()</span></code></a>\nis now <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'face'</span></code>, and supplying <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'none'</span></code> now prevents lines from being drawn\naround the hexagons.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"figure-legend-can-be-called-without-arguments\">\n\n<p>Calling <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.figure.Figure.html#matplotlib.figure.Figure.legend\" title=\"matplotlib.figure.Figure.legend\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">Figure.legend()</span></code></a> can now be done with no arguments. In this case\na legend will be created that contains all the artists on all the axes\ncontained within the figure.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"multiple-legend-keys-for-legend-entries\">\n\n<p>A legend entry can now contain more than one legend key. The extended\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/legend_api.html#matplotlib.legend_handler.HandlerTuple\" title=\"matplotlib.legend_handler.HandlerTuple\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">HandlerTuple</span></code></a> class now accepts two parameters:\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">ndivide</span></code> divides the legend area in the specified number of sections;\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">pad</span></code> changes the padding between the legend keys.</p>\n<div class=\"figure align-center\" id=\"id4\">\n<a class=\"reference external image-reference\" href=\"../gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend_demo.html\"><img alt=\"../_images/sphx_glr_legend_demo_004.png\" src=\"../_images/sphx_glr_legend_demo_004.png\"/></a>\n<p class=\"caption\"><span class=\"caption-text\">Multiple Legend Keys</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-parameter-clear-for-figure\">\n\n<p>When the pyplot\u2019s function <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.figure.html#matplotlib.pyplot.figure\" title=\"matplotlib.pyplot.figure\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">figure()</span></code></a> is called\nwith a <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">num</span></code> parameter, a new window is only created if no existing\nwindow with the same value exists. A new bool parameter <code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">clear</span></code> was\nadded for explicitly clearing its existing contents. This is particularly\nuseful when utilized in interactive sessions. Since\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.subplots.html#matplotlib.pyplot.subplots\" title=\"matplotlib.pyplot.subplots\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">subplots()</span></code></a> also accepts keyword arguments\nfrom <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.figure.html#matplotlib.pyplot.figure\" title=\"matplotlib.pyplot.figure\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">figure()</span></code></a>, it can also be used there:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-default\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"kn\">import</span> <span class=\"nn\">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class=\"k\">as</span> <span class=\"nn\">plt</span>\n\n<span class=\"n\">fig0</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"n\">plt</span><span class=\"n\">fig0</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">suptitle</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"A fancy plot\"</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n<span class=\"nb\">print</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"s2\">\"fig0.texts: \"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"p\">[</span><span class=\"n\">t</span><span \"</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"p\">[</span><span class=\"n\">t</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">get_text</span><span class=\"p\">()</span> <span output:</span>\n<span class=\"c1\"># fig0.texts:  ['A fancy plot']</span>\n<span class=\"c1\"># fig0 is fig1:  True</span>\n<span class=\"c1\"># fig1.texts:  ['A fancy plot', 'Really id=\"specify-minimum-value-to-format-as-scalar-for-logformattermathtext\">\n\n<p><a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/ticker_api.html#matplotlib.ticker.LogFormatterMathtext\" title=\"matplotlib.ticker.LogFormatterMathtext\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">LogFormatterMathtext</span></code></a> now includes the\noption to specify a minimum value exponent to format as a scalar\n(i.e., 0.001 instead of 10<sup>-3</sup>).</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-quiverkey-angle-keyword-argument\">\n\n<p>Plotting a <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiverkey.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiverkey\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.quiverkey\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">quiverkey()</span></code></a> now admits the\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">angle</span></code> keyword argument, which sets the angle at which to draw the\nkey arrow.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"artist-setp-and-pyplot-setp-accept-a-file-argument\">\n\n<p>The argument is keyword-only. It allows an output file other than\n<a class=\"reference external\" href=\"https://docs.python.org/2/library/sys.html#sys.stdout\" title=\"(in Python v2.7)\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">sys.stdout</span></code></a> to be specified. It works exactly like the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">file</span></code> argument\nto <a class=\"reference external\" href=\"https://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html#print\" title=\"(in Python v2.7)\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">print</span></code></a>.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"streamplot-streamline-generation-more-configurable\">\n\n<p>The starting point, direction, and length of the stream lines can now\nbe configured.  This allows to follow the vector field for a longer\ntime and can enhance the visibility of the flow pattern in some use\ncases.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"axis-set-tick-params-now-responds-to-rotation\">\n\n<p>Bulk setting of tick label rotation is now possible via\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axis.Axis.set_tick_params.html#matplotlib.axis.Axis.set_tick_params\" title=\"matplotlib.axis.Axis.set_tick_params\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">set_tick_params()</span></code></a> using the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">rotation</span></code>\nkeyword.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-default\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"n\">ax</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">xaxis</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">set_tick_params</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">which</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s1\">'both'</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">rotation</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"mi\">90</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n</pre></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"shading-in-3d-bar-plots\">\n\n<p>A new <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">shade</span></code> parameter has been added the 3D\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.html#mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.bar\" title=\"mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.axes3d.Axes3D.bar\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">bar</span></code></a> plotting method. href=\"../users/whats_new-4.png\">png</a>, <a class=\"reference external\" href=\"../users/whats_new-4.pdf\">pdf</a>)</p>\n\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-which-parameter-for-autofmt-xdate\">\n\n<p>A <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">which</span></code> parameter now exists for the method\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.figure.Figure.html#matplotlib.figure.Figure.autofmt_xdate\" title=\"matplotlib.figure.Figure.autofmt_xdate\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">autofmt_xdate()</span></code></a>. This allows a user to format\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">major</span></code>, <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">minor</span></code> or <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">both</span></code> tick labels selectively. The\ndefault behavior will rotate and align the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">major</span></code> tick labels.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-default\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"n\">fig</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">autofmt_xdate</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">bottom</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"mf\">0.2</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">rotation</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"mi\">30</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">ha</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s1\">'right'</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">which</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s1\">'minor'</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n</pre></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-figure-parameter-for-subplot2grid\">\n\n<p>A <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fig</span></code> parameter now exists for the function\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.subplot2grid.html#matplotlib.pyplot.subplot2grid\" title=\"matplotlib.pyplot.subplot2grid\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">subplot2grid()</span></code></a>. This allows a user to specify the\nfigure where the subplots will be created. If <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fig</span></code> is <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">None</span></code> (default)\nthen the method will use the current figure retrieved by\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.gcf.html#matplotlib.pyplot.gcf\" title=\"matplotlib.pyplot.gcf\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">gcf()</span></code></a>.</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-default\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"n\">subplot2grid</span><span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"n\">shape</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">loc</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">rowspan</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"mi\">1</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">colspan</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"mi\">1</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"n\">fig</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"n\">myfig</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>\n</pre></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"interpolation-in-fill-betweenx\">\n\n<p>The <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">interpolate</span></code> parameter now exists for the method\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_betweenx.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_betweenx\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_betweenx\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_betweenx()</span></code></a>. This allows a user to\ninterpolate the data and fill the areas in the crossover points,\nsimilarly to <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_between.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_between\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill_between\"><code class=\"xref py py-func docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">fill_between()</span></code></a>.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-keyword-argument-sep-for-engformatter\">\n\n<p>A new <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">sep</span></code> keyword argument has been added to\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/ticker_api.html#matplotlib.ticker.EngFormatter\" title=\"matplotlib.ticker.EngFormatter\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">EngFormatter</span></code></a> and provides a means to\ndefine the string that will be used between the value and its\nunit. The default string is <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">\"</span> <span class=\"pre\">\"</span></code>, which preserves the former\nbehavior. Additionally, the separator is now present between the value\nand its unit even in the absence of SI prefix.  There was formerly a\nbug that was causing strings like <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">\"3.14V\"</span></code> to be returned instead of\nthe expected <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">\"3.14</span> <span class=\"pre\">V\"</span></code> (with the default behavior).</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"extend-matplotlibrc-behavior\">\n\n<p>The environmental variable can now specify the full file path or the\npath to a directory containing a <code class=\"file docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">matplotlibrc</span></code> file.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"density-kwarg-to-hist\">\n\n<p>The <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.hist.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.hist\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.hist\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">hist()</span></code></a> method now prefers <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">density</span></code>\nto <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">normed</span></code> to control if the histogram should be normalized,\nfollowing a change upstream to NumPy.  This will reduce confusion as\nthe behavior has always been that the integral of the histogram is 1\n(rather than sum or maximum value).</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"internals\">\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"new-transformedpatchpath-caching-object\">\n\n<p>A newly added <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/transformations.html#matplotlib.transforms.TransformedPatchPath\" title=\"matplotlib.transforms.TransformedPatchPath\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">TransformedPatchPath</span></code></a> provides a\nmeans to transform a <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.patches.Patch.html#matplotlib.patches.Patch\" title=\"matplotlib.patches.Patch\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">Patch</span></code></a> into a\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/path_api.html#matplotlib.path.Path\" title=\"matplotlib.path.Path\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">Path</span></code></a> via a <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/transformations.html#matplotlib.transforms.Transform\" title=\"matplotlib.transforms.Transform\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">Transform</span></code></a>\nwhile caching the resulting path. If neither the patch nor the transform have\nchanged, a cached copy of the path is returned.</p>\n<p>This class differs from the older\n<a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/transformations.html#matplotlib.transforms.TransformedPath\" title=\"matplotlib.transforms.TransformedPath\"><code class=\"xref py py-class docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">TransformedPath</span></code></a> in that it is able to refresh\nitself based on the underlying patch while the older class uses an immutable\npath.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"stricter-validation-of-line-style-rcparams\">\n\n<p>The validation of rcParams that are related to line styles\n(<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">lines.linestyle</span></code>, <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">boxplot.*.linestyle</span></code>, <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">grid.linestyle</span></code> and\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">contour.negative_linestyle</span></code>) now effectively checks that the values\nare valid line styles. Strings like <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'dashed'</span></code> or <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'--'</span></code> are\naccepted, as well as even-length sequences of on-off ink like <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">[1,</span>\n<span class=\"pre\">1.65]</span></code>. In this latter case, the offset value is handled internally\nand should <em>not</em> be provided by the user.</p>\n<p>The new validation scheme replaces the former one used for the\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">contour.negative_linestyle</span></code> rcParams, that was limited to\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'solid'</span></code> and <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">'dashed'</span></code> line styles.</p>\n<p>The validation is case-insensitive.  The following are now valid:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight-default\"><div class=\"highlight\"><pre><span/><span class=\"n\">grid</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">linestyle</span>             <span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"mi\">1</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"mi\">3</span><span class=\"p\">)</span>   <span class=\"c1\"># loosely dotted grid lines</span>\n<span class=\"n\">contour</span><span class=\"o\">.</span><span class=\"n\">negative_linestyle</span> <span class=\"p\">:</span> <span class=\"n\">dashdot</span>  <span class=\"c1\"># previously only solid or dashed</span>\n</pre></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"pytest\">\n\n<p>The automated tests have been switched from <code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">nose</span></code> to <code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">pytest</span></code>.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"performance\">\n\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"path-simplification-updates\">\n\n<p>Line simplification controlled by the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify</span></code> and\n<code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify_threshold</span></code> parameters has been improved. You should\nnotice better rendering performance when plotting large amounts of\ndata (as long as the above parameters are set accordingly). Only the\nline segment portion of paths will be simplified \u2013 if you are also\ndrawing markers and experiencing problems with rendering speed, you\nshould consider using the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">markevery</span></code> option to <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot\" title=\"matplotlib.axes.Axes.plot\"><code class=\"xref py py-obj docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">plot</span></code></a>.\nSee the <a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../tutorials/introductory/usage.html#performance\"><span class=\"std std-ref\">Performance</span></a> section in the usage tutorial for more\ninformation.</p>\n<p>The simplification works by iteratively merging line segments\ninto a single vector until the next line segment\u2019s perpendicular\ndistance to the vector (measured in display-coordinate space)\nis greater than the <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify_threshold</span></code> parameter. Thus, higher\nvalues of <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify_threshold</span></code> result in quicker rendering times.\nIf you are plotting just to explore data and not for publication quality,\npixel perfect plots, then a value of <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">1.0</span></code> can be safely used. If you\nwant to make sure your plot reflects your data <em>exactly</em>, then you should\nset <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify</span></code> to false and/or <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">path.simplify_threshold</span></code> to <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">0</span></code>.\nMatplotlib currently defaults to a conservative value of <code class=\"docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">1/9</span></code>, smaller\nvalues are unlikely to cause any visible differences in your plots.</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"section\" id=\"implement-intersects-bbox-in-c\">\n\n<p><a class=\"reference internal\" href=\"../api/path_api.html#matplotlib.path.Path.intersects_bbox\" title=\"matplotlib.path.Path.intersects_bbox\"><code class=\"xref py py-meth docutils literal\"><span class=\"pre\">intersects_bbox()</span></code></a> has been implemented in\nc++ which improves the performance of automatically placing the legend.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430024": {"score": 3, "comments": ["a friend of mine implemented a blockchain to connect content "15429940": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:53:18", "url": "https://taxfoundation.org/real-value-100-state-2017/", "text": "<html><body><div><div id=\"post-content\">\n      <p>This map shows the real value of $100 in each state. Prices for the same goods are often much cheaper in states like Missouri or Ohio than they are in states like New York or California. As a result, the same amount of cash can buy you comparatively more in a low-price state than in a high-price state.</p>\n<p>The Bureau of Economic Analysis has been measuring this phenomenon for two years now; it recently <a href=\"https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/regional/rpp/rpp_newsrelease.htm\">published</a> its data for prices in 2015. Using this data, we have adjusted the value of $100 to show how much it buys you in each state.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01.png\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-52858\" src=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01.png\" alt=\"Real Value of $100 State Map 2017\" srcset=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01.png 1355w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01-300x273.png 300w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01-768x698.png 768w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803113208/100-Map-01-1024x931.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1355px) 100vw, 1355px\"/></a></p>\n<p>For example, Ohio is a low-price state. There, $100 will buy you goods that would cost $112.11 in a state at the national average price level. You could think of this as meaning that Ohioans are, for the purposes of day-to-day living, 12 percent richer than their incomes suggest.</p>\n<p>The states where $100 is worth the most are Mississippi ($116.01), Alabama ($115.21), Arkansas ($114.42), South Dakota ($113.38), and Kentucky ($112.87). In contrast, $100 is effectively worth the least in Hawaii ($84.18), the District of Columbia ($85.47), New York ($86.73), New Jersey ($88.18), and California ($88.18). <a href=\"#table1\">See the table at the bottom of this post</a> for a ranking of all 50 states.</p>\n<p>Regional price differences are strikingly large; real purchasing power is 36 percent greater in Mississippi than it is in the District of Columbia. In other words, by this measure, if you have $50,000 in after-tax income in Mississippi, you would need after-tax earnings of $68,000 in the District of Columbia just to afford the same overall standard of living.</p>\n<p>It\u2019s generally the case that states with higher nominal incomes also have higher price levels. This is because in places with higher incomes, the prices of finite resources like land get bid up. (This is especially true in cities.) What is also true is that places with high costs of living pay higher salaries for the same jobs. This is what labor economists call a compensating differential; the higher pay is offered in order to make up for the low purchasing power.</p>\n<p>This relationship is important, although it does not always hold true. Some states, like North Dakota, have high incomes without high prices. Adjusting incomes for price level can substantially change our perceptions of which states are truly poor or rich.</p>\n<p>For example, New Yorkers and North Dakotans earn approximately the same amount in dollars per capita, but after adjusting for regional price parity, North Dakotan incomes can buy more.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03.png\"><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-52856\" src=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03.png\" alt=\"Real Value of $100 Comparison 2017\" srcset=\"https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03.png 1251w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03-300x215.png 300w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03-768x551.png 768w, https://files.taxfoundation.org/20170803112811/100-Map-03-1024x734.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1251px) 100vw, 1251px\"/></a></p>\n<p>This has substantial implications for public policy, which is often progressive with respect to income.</p>\n<p>Many policies \u2013 like minimum wage, public benefits, and tax brackets \u2013 are denominated in dollars. But with different price levels in each state, the amounts aren\u2019t equivalent in purchasing power. This has some unexpected consequences \u2013 people in high price-level states like New Jersey will often pay more in federal taxes without feeling particularly rich.</p>\n<hr/>\n<a name=\"table1\"/>\n<table>\n<caption>Regional Price Parities by State, 2015</caption>\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th>State</th>\n<th>\u00a0Relative Value of "http://linasm.sf.net/", "text": "<html><body><div><section>\n<h1>Welcome</h1>\n<p>Welcome to Linux Assembly libraries project, which provides very fast and SIMD optimized assembly libraries for common and wide used algorithms.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acMost of them were specially developed for data analysis and time series processing,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acbut now they implement much more mathematical and general algorithms and abstraction data types (ADT).\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThese libraries are completely written in flat assembly language (FASM) for x86-64\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acLinux,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acto be used inside C and C++\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acprograms, and\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acmake them very fast on that platform.</p>\n<h2>What does typical program do?</h2>\n<p>What is the reason to use assembly in programs\u00e2\u0080\u00ad? \u00e2\u0080\u00acMay be we shouldn't do this\u00e2\u0080\u00ad?</p>\n<p>Almost all programmers believe that recent C/C++\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00accompilers are so smart to produce very fast and optimized code by themselves,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acand you should not use assembly at all.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad A compiler will do all hard work for you.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acSo relax,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acand don't worry about the code.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad</p>\n<p>It is old myth for lazy programmers\u00e2\u0080\u00ad. \u00e2\u0080\u00acI did the tests and found that most popular compilers are still dummy as many years before.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThey waste lot of program execution time for data transfers among processor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s registers,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acRAM and program stack,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acinstead of real computing that algorithms should do.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acSome scientists even joking that modern processors have efficiency factor of steam engine\u00e2\u0080\u00ad (\u00e2\u0080\u00ac20%\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00ac-\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00ac25%\u00e2\u0080\u00ad) \u00e2\u0080\u00acrunning engineering programs.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acI'm not sure if this is true.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acMay be they are good scientists,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acbut bad programmers.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acAnyway all above sounds not so good if you have big computation task.</p>\n<p>Actually almost all C/C++\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00accompilers can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t provide good usage of SIMD extensions of modern processors and even can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t parallel vector operations automatically and correctly.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acProgrammers should use code hacks to make this available.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acUsually,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acthey write SIMD operations using so called\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \"intrinsic functions\" \u00e2\u0080\u00acor\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \"\u00e2\u0080\u00acbuilt-in functions\u00e2\u0080\u00ad\" \u00e2\u0080\u00aclike this one.</p>\n<pre><span class=\"include\"># include</span> <span class=\"string\">&lt;stdio.h&gt;</span>\n\n\n<span class=\"keyword\">typedef float v4sf</span> __attribute__ ((vector_size (<span class=\"number\">16</span>)));\n<span class=\"keyword\">union v4sfu</span>\n{\n    <span class=\"keyword\">float</span> array[<span class=\"number\">4</span>];\n    <span class=\"keyword\">v4sf</span>  vector;\n};\n\n<span class=\"keyword\">int</span> main (<span class=\"keyword\">void</span>)\n{\n    \n    <span class=\"keyword\">v4sfu</span> a = {<span class=\"number\">1.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">2.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">3.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">4.0</span>};\n    <span class=\"keyword\">v4sfu</span> b = {<span class=\"number\">5.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">6.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">7.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">8.0</span>};\n    <span class=\"keyword\">v4sfu</span> c;\n\n    \n    c.vector = a.vector * b.vector;\n    c.vector = __builtin_ia32_haddps (c.vector, c.vector);\n    c.vector = __builtin_ia32_haddps (c.vector, c.vector);\n\n    \n    printf (<span class=\"string\">\"The convolution of two arrays is = %f\\n\"</span>, c.array[<span class=\"number\">0</span>]);\n    return <span class=\"number\">0</span>;\n}\n</pre>\n<p>Who has an idea what this non transparent instruction \"__builtin_ia32_haddps\" is doing? Do we work with the SIMD registers or reading memory blocks somewhere into RAM? \u00e2\u0080\u00acIn the second case we should read data from CPU cache or extract vector from memory banks.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad If data are not available immediately, then CPU should wait till they are transferred from RAM to processor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s cache or into registers.</p>\n<img class=\"left\" src=\"/img/check_code.png\" alt=\"check_code.png\"/>\n<p>To find what actual code is,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acyou should compile the code you wrote and then revise its assembly output\u00e2\u0080\u00ad (\u00e2\u0080\u00acusually with gcc\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00ac-S\u00e2\u0080\u00ad)\u00e2\u0080\u00ac.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acIf you do everything right and has smart compiler,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acthen you will find that both operands are already placed in XMM registers and then appropriate SIMD instruction\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \"\u00e2\u0080\u00acHADDPS\u00e2\u0080\u00ad\" \u00e2\u0080\u00acis called.</p>\n<p>This small example just show you what is going on under the cover of high level programming languages, and the tasks that your compiler should do to optimize the machine code.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad Not all of them work good, and result programs just waste lot of the time for non required data transfers and executing sequences of extra commands instead of calling one CPU instruction provided by hardware.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acIt is because you can't control the code output and rely on compiler intellect,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acwhich is far away from perfect. In such case an assembly language is good choice for software optimization.</p>\n<h2>Make it fast and simple</h2>\n<img class=\"left\" src=\"/img/fast_code.png\" alt=\"fast_code.png\"/>\n<p>The good way to optimize software is to split its code into several parts.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThe first part is low level and very fast assembly written primitives which use all the power of your hardware:\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acvector processing,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acregister\u00e2\u0080\u0099s operands,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acoptimal CPU cache usage and processor's conveyer loading.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThe second part is high level C/C++\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00accode,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acwhich just calls assembly libraries to implement the main algorithm idea.</p>\n<p>In that case you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t need to write strange and rich of intrinsic functions code.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acYou just write your algorithm like very simple code below.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acEverything works very fast,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acbecause source code of library is optimized for best CPU usage.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acIt is small,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acholds all the data close to execution units.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acNo additional memory reading/writing operations and code has minimum conveyer drops.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acAlso your programs stay clean of mambo-jumbo code like intrinsic functions and dirty hacks to tell compiler how to vectorize data,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acwhich meaning is not clear for most programmers,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acwho are not familiar with CPU\u00e2\u0080\u0099s instructions set.</p>\n<pre><span class=\"include\"># include</span> <span class=\"string\">&lt;stdio.h&gt;</span>\n<span class=\"include\"># include</span> <span class=\"string\">&lt;Array.h&gt;</span>\n\n<span class=\"keyword\">int</span> main (<span class=\"keyword\">void</span>)\n{\n    \n    <span class=\"keyword\">const size_t</span> size = <span class=\"number\">4</span>;\n    <span class=\"keyword\">float</span> a[size] = {<span class=\"number\">1.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">2.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">3.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">4.0</span>};\n    <span class=\"keyword\">float</span> b[size] = {<span class=\"number\">5.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">6.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">7.0</span>, <span class=\"number\">8.0</span>};\n\n    \n    <span class=\"keyword\">float</span> c = Array::SumMul (a, b, size);\n\n    \n    printf (<span class=\"string\">\"The convolution of two arrays is = %f\\n\"</span>, c);\n    return <span class=\"number\">0</span>;\n}</pre>\n<p>By the way,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acthe above code is also scalable,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acand stays the same for variable size arrays.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acAll platform specific code and SIMD instructions are handled by assembly library,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acremaining the main idea of program very clear.</p>\n<p>If you wonder how fast assembly code can be, then just take a look on these <a href=\"/about/benchmarks.php\">benchmarks.</a>.</p>\n<h2>The goal of LinAsm project</h2>\n<img class=\"left\" src=\"/img/project_goal.png\" alt=\"project_goal.png\"/>\n<p>The main purpose of Linux Assembly libraries is to provide very fast and optimized code for programs which are written in high level languages\u00e2\u0080\u00ad (\u00e2\u0080\u00acmostly in C/C++\u00e2\u0080\u00ad)\u00e2\u0080\u00ac.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThe project doesn't concentrate on writing pure assembly programs\u00e2\u0080\u00ad (\u00e2\u0080\u00acit is not efficient\u00e2\u0080\u00ad)\u00e2\u0080\u00ac,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acbut only on assembly versions of common and widely used algorithms, math functions and abstract data types.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acThe libraries can be used in any programming languages which support linking with shared libraries\u00e2\u0080\u00ad (*\u00e2\u0080\u00ac.so files\u00e2\u0080\u00ad) \u00e2\u0080\u00acand can understand C language \u00e2\u0080\u00acfunction names.</p>\n<p>To get more information about the project,\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acplease read\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \"<a href=\"/about/index.php\">About</a>\" \u00e2\u0080\u00acsection.\u00e2\u0080\u00ad </p>\n<p>Detailed information about\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00acthe\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00aclibraries and functions they provide is covered in\u00e2\u0080\u00ad \u00e2\u0080\u00ac<a href=\"/docs/index.php\">project documentation</a>.</p>\n\n</section>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429943": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:53:34", "url": "http://calnewport.com/blog/2017/10/07/jony-ives-iconcern/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"main content blog\" role=\"main\">&#13;\n\t&#13;\n\t\t&#13;\n&#13;\n\t\t\t\t<article class=\"onlyone last\">\t\t\t\t\t<h1 class=\"blogtitle\">Jony Ive\u2019s iConcern</h1>&#13;\n\t\t\t<small>October 7th, 2017 \u00b7 <a href=\"http://calnewport.com/blog/2017/10/07/jony-ives-iconcern/#comments\">13 comments</a></small>&#13;\n\t\t\t<p><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-5867\" src=\"http://calnewport.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ive-596px.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"http://calnewport.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ive-596px.jpg 596w, http://calnewport.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ive-596px-300x169.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 596px) 100vw, 596px\"/></p>\n<p><strong>Ive\u2019s iConcern</strong></p>\n<p>At last week\u2019s New Yorker TechFest conference, superstar Apple designer Jony Ive took the stage.</p>\n<p>At some point during the presentation, Ive was offered a softball question about the ways the iPhone has changed the world. <a href=\"http://www.trustedreviews.com/news/jony-ive-apples-ideas-must-wait-tech-catch-3302682\">Ive\u2019s response was surprising</a>:\u00a0\u201cLike any tool, you can see there\u2019s wonderful use and then there\u2019s misuse.\u201d</p>\n<p>Asked what he meant by \u201cmisuse,\u201d Ive responded: \u201cperhaps, constant use.\u201d</p>\n<p><span id=\"more-5865\"/></p>\n<p>The fact that Jony Ive, the guy who designed the iPhone, is worried about the way people engage his creation, emphasizes an important point: there\u2019s something broken about our current relationship with our technology.</p>\n<p>Our culture was quick to accept the idea that we\u2019d end up checking these things constantly. Yes there is a large cost upfront to develop and manufacture it. But once the machine has been designed and tested, it will never have to be designed again. Design is a one time cost.<p>Once manufacturing is underway, the process is typically made as efficient as possible and made to scale. The work that went into design and testing can now be scaled to thousands or millions of units which is a great return on investment. Each unit has a one time cost for materials used for parts, with some long term maintenence costs.<p>Operation requires only an electric energy draw. If that energy is from a clean source such as solar, this unit isn&#x27;t having much of any further negative impact. Operation could last years or decades depending on design and whether or not the product is superceded, at which time its parts can be recycled. There will probably be a position for food ammo reloader, that keeps the machines loaded with whatever that machine cooks &#x2F; prepares.<p>It would be possible to get rid of the bagger&#x2F;runner, but it&#x27;d probably be cost prohibitive and needlessly complex to assemble the various robots on a line that could also bag properly.<p>At its best, eventually, this system will produce more food (1.5x to 4x I&#x27;d guess), at a lower per customer cost, with superior food safety (including hygiene). Then it&#x27;s a question of how much of that gain gets competed away (benefiting customers) and how much goes into the pocket of the owners.<p>Starbucks will be similar. They won&#x27;t get rid of all their humans, they&#x27;ll reduce their number significantly.<p>It&#x27;s likely to be a decades long, piece by piece, transition. The early results won&#x27;t be spectacular for either customers or franchise owners, it&#x27;ll take many years of gradual improvement.", "That&#x27;s an argument for having a higher-value problem-solving employee around, not an argument for having several lower-value button-pushing employees around.<p>Fewer, higher value employees has been the trend in many industries for the past few hundred thousand years.", "Or for better sensors on the robot. Bill Gates recently <a href=\"https://qz.com/911968/bill-gates-the-robot-that-takes-your-job-should-pay-taxes/\">made a case</a> for taxing companies that own robots, which could delay their implementation and provide some money to retrain people whose jobs are lost. The San Francisco board of supervisors <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/robot-taxes-san-francisco-2017-8\">is considering</a> a so-called robot tax.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"237\" data-total-count=\"2205\">\u201cWe could be looking at over 50 percent of jobs disappearing in the United States over the next 10 to 15 years,\u201d said Jane Kim, a San Francisco supervisor. \u201cAnd it\u2019s not jobs going abroad, or offshoring of jobs. It\u2019s robots.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"476\" data-total-count=\"2681\">There is evidence that automation can have a devastating effect on employment. Commercial robots have already begun to eliminate jobs, according to an <a href=\"https://economics.mit.edu/files/12763\">M.I.T.-Boston University study</a> published in March. Researchers analyzed the effects of industrial robots on local labor markets in the United States from 1990 to 2007, and estimated that adding one robot per 1,000 workers has led to unemployment for up to six workers and has caused a decrease in wages by up to 0.50 percent.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"399\" data-total-count=\"3080\">Some unions are discussing their own strategies for contending with a robot-clogged future. \u201cIt\u2019s something our union and many unions are still studying,\u201d said Ian Lewis, research director for Unite Here Local 2, a union that represents hotel, food service, restaurant and laundry workers in San Francisco and San Mateo, Calif. \u201cWe\u2019re absolutely concerned and trying to grapple with it.\u201d</p>\n<p id=\"#continues-post-newsletter\"/>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"362\" data-total-count=\"3442\">Whatever their effect on employment, new robots are on the way. Mr. Sekar, an inventor with a doctorate in electronics and computer engineering, said he came up with the idea of building a kitchen robot while working as director of engineering for a semiconductor company. Although he loved cooking at home, he said he craved a way of reducing the work involved.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"319\" data-total-count=\"3761\">\u201cI was spending 90 percent of my time doing something sadly repetitive, like chopping ingredients or stirring,\u201d Mr. Sekar said. Soon, he switched his focus to food-service robots for restaurants and offices.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"417\" data-total-count=\"4178\">Mr. Sekar said his robot has the potential to save money for small businesses that install it in office kitchens alongside appliances like coffee machines. Walking a couple of minutes within a building to a salad-tossing robot instead of venturing outside for lunch would mean shorter work breaks and increased productivity, he said. He calls Sally \u201cthe smallest and most affordable cafeteria an office can have.\u201d</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"259\" data-total-count=\"4437\" id=\"story-continues-5\">The robot is being tested in the office of the Redwood City, Calif., technology incubator <a href=\"http://gsvlabs.com/\">GSVlabs</a> and at Calafia Caf\u00e9 and Market A Go-Go, a restaurant in Palo Alto, Calif., with an attached market owned by Charlie Ayers, who is the Chowbotics executive chef.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"388\" data-total-count=\"4825\">This fall, Chowbotics will begin fulfilling orders for 10 robots, priced at $30,000 each, Mr. Sekar said. He envisions his robots producing healthy meals in convenience stores, airports, hotels, hospitals and universities. \u201cYou\u2019re seeing the momentum of Silicon Valley behind it,\u201d Mr. Sekar said. So far, Chowbotics has raised $6.3 million in venture funding from various investors.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"359\" data-total-count=\"5184\">For recipes, Mr. Sekar turned to Mr. Ayers, the former head chef of Google who also has cooked for members of the Grateful Dead. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of passion in what I do creating flavors that will come out of the machines,\u201d Mr. Ayers said. For instance, he said he has devised a menu for an office robot that can serve salads with South Asian ingredients.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"188\" data-total-count=\"5372\">Still, Mr. Ayers says other chefs have criticized him. \u201cMany of my colleagues in the industry are like, \u2018What are you doing to us? You\u2019re going to the machines?\u2019\u201d said Mr. Ayers.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"313\" data-total-count=\"5685\">He responds that he is helping to create jobs because these robots will always need to be filled, maintained and cleaned by people. \u201cThere are going to be logistics companies, cleaning companies, service companies, robot repair companies,\u201d Mr. Ayers said. \u201cHuman interaction with Sally is not going away.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"289\" data-total-count=\"5974\">If Chowbotics succeeds with salads, Mr. Sekar hopes to expand to other cuisines and admits that human workers could then be displaced. \u201cWe\u2019re going to go after other types of food,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to tell what will happen in the future and how this all might impact jobs.\u201d</p><footer class=\"story-footer story-content\">\n    <div class=\"story-meta\">\n It is not hard to picture the potentially catastrophic damage to a company that earns its revenue by online advertising if it were knocked offline, or to an online retailer if an unscrupulous competitor hired a criminal to launch an attack on the former's website at the height of the holiday shopping season. In fact, on multiple occasions we have seen <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/joseph-steinberg/why-half-the-internet-is-broken-right-now.html\">clear examples of the damage that DDoS attacks can inflict</a>. Furthermore, as I discussed earlier this week, criminals are now <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/joseph-steinberg/cybercriminals-threaten-companies-around-globe-with-ddos-attacks.html\">demanding that firms pay them or face DDoS attacks</a> - a 2017 version of classic \"protection money\" extortion.</p>\n<p>Over the past decade various technologies have emerged that help reduce the risk of DDoS attacks - but the capabilities of the criminals launching the attacks have greatly advanced as well. With the mass proliferation of insecure Internet of Things devices and the easy availability of exploit code, attackers have access to a multitude of easily-comprised potential zombies, making DDoS attacks a significant danger.</p>\n<p>Ultimately, the Achilles Heel of many DDoS defenses is that they must absorb large amounts of attack traffic - a process which can utilize a lot of bandwidth and processing power, and be quite expensive. As such, criminals benefit from a tremendous advantage: they normally launch DDoS attacks from \"zombies\" - that is, computers that they have taken control of via malware - so they obtain their necessary resources for free.</p>\n<p>Because of the cost of absorbing large volumes of data, many DDoS protection firms charge businesses for handling huge traffic loads - with Uber-like \"surge pricing\" - making DDoS attacks very expensive even to those organizations that successfully mitigate against them. Other defense firms may charge businesses more up front to ensure profitability even if DDoS attacks do occur, or may terminate customer accounts if a customer turns into a losing proposition. Last year, for example, after criminals launched <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://krebsonsecurity.com/2016/09/the-democratization-of-censorship/\">a massive DDoS attack at security journalist Brian Krebs' website</a> - which was, at the time, protected pro bono by Akamai - <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.zdnet.com/article/krebs-on-security-booted-off-akamai-network-after-ddos-attack-proves-pricey/\">Akamai told Krebs to take his site's protection needs elsewhere</a>. Additionally, even the most robust anti-DDoS infrastructures may be taxed by growing DDoS attacks; there is a limit to how many entities they can adequately protect at once. Hacktivists - that is, hackers attacking parties for activist-type rationales - have even taken down some sites when attacking other sites using the same DDoS protection service.</p>\n<p>I recently spoke with a startup that is working to use the blockchain technology to address these shortcomings, to dramatically reduce the cost of protecting against DDoS attacks, and, ultimately, to render DDoS attacks far less effective. Blockchain, is of course, the technology underlying cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and smart contract systems like Ethereum. It allows for the sharing of information through a nearly-incorruptible digital ledger that is distributed all over the Internet, requires no central authority for management, and protects entries by effectively allowing them to be made only by the parties authorized to do so. I will write a detailed explanation of blockchain in an upcoming piece.</p>\n<p>By using blockchain, Maryland-based <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://gladius.io/\">Gladius</a> is creating a system that would allow people to rent out their unused bandwidth so that it can be used to absorb malicious DDoS traffic and mitigate against attacks. For most adults of working age, the vast majority of the bandwidth of their home Internet connection sits idle during the workday; in much the same way that Airbnb lets people utilize their home to make money when it would have otherwise sat idle and empty, Gladius plans to allow folks to leverage their Internet connections when they would not normally be heavily used. By leveraging the blockchain, Gladius eliminates the middle man between bandwidth providers and those needing it, and eliminates the need to buy bandwidth other than during an actual attack - so, businesses buy only the bandwidth that they actually need. Web site owners could also use the system to accelerate the delivery of content - as computers all over the world could function effectively as remote deliverers of cached data (in what would technically be known as a Content Delivery Network or CDN). Payments on Gladius are done with its own cryptocurrency - GLA - which ostensibly will be bought and sold on crypto exchanges. Gladius will begin offering GLA in an <span> </span><a href=\"https://www.inc.com/video/everything-you-need-to-know-about-icos-in-less-than-2-minutes.html\">Initial Coin Offering (ICO)</a> in October, and plans to go live early next year.</p>\n<p>Like any other startup, Gladius will certainly face challenges, and it is obviously too early to know whether the firm or other blockchain technologies will ultimately capture the DDoS protection market from established businesses, but the advent of a new, democratized model of protection and financial opportunity - allowing for potentially better utilization of resources by everyone across the Internet ecosystem - is certainly an exciting development. Ironically, if Gladius is successful, it will need to implement security to ensure that criminals don't monetize zombies in the future by transforming them from DDoS attackers into rented defenders <em>against</em> DDoS attacks.</p>\n<p>Gladius may be pioneering the use of blockchain for DDoS protection, but it is certainly not the only party using blockchain technology to advance security. I am certain that over the upcoming years we will see other blockchain-based security technologies emerge - offering better models for optimizing the allocation of resources to solve long-established security challenges.</p></div>\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430977": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:11:57", "url": "https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/failure-taught-me-lesson-ill-never-forget-melinda-gates/?linkId=43244080", "text": "UNAVAILABLE TEXT BY URL https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/failure-taught-me-lesson-ill-never-forget-melinda-gates/?linkId=43244080"}, "15430981": {"score": 22, "comments": ["&gt; When prospective business partners meet Mr. Cherkashin, he said, they often ask him if his money is clean.<p>&quot;Yes of course it&#x27;s clean, it was just laundered&quot;", "I&#x27;d love to see a tongue in cheek time series graph titled: &quot;How Much Russians are the Enemy (by public perception)&quot;<p>Feels like we are higher than the seasonal norm these days.", "Well. "15431308": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 05:59:42", "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/10/07/business/wages-versus-unemployment.html?mabReward=ART_ACTM2&recid=0ugw7AAciMITcWhiCkY1hqdfgwc&recp=0&moduleDetail=recommendations-0&action=click&contentCollection=Business%20Day&region=Footer&module=WhatsNext&version=WhatsNext&contentID=WhatsNext&src=recg&pgtype=article", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">When labor markets tighten, wages are expected to rise. Basic economics tells us that when workers are in higher demand, employers should have to pay more for their services. But in recent years, as unemployment has fallen below 5 percent in the United States, wages have not been increasing as fast as in the past. Economists debate the reasons; workers grapple with the consequences.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">The unemployment rate has fallen to a comfortable level, but wage growth is sluggish.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">When the two trends are superimposed, the historical pattern in which wages pick up when unemployment falls has not held this time around.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">This is a global problem. Wages are not rising as fast as expected in many countries, especially Britain, France, the Netherlands and Norway.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">A fundamental refashioning of the labor market has been underway for two decades. Jobs that require middle-range skills have been declining, while those involving skills at both the lower and higher end of the spectrum have been growing. This effectively suppresses wages for many: People in lower-paid, lower-skill jobs \u2014 retail workers, janitors and home health aides \u2014 have little bargaining power to demand higher wages. Middle-skilled workers \u2014 including clerks, call center operators and factory workers \u2014 are being replaced by computers, robots and lesser-paid hands in low-wage countries. Higher-skilled workers are capturing an outsized share of pay.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">Union membership has been declining in much of the developed world. But in the United States, where it\u2019s lower than in most major economies, unions now represent less than 11 percent of the workforce. Economists see this as a critical factor in weak American wage growth, given that most workers do not bargain collectively.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      <div class=\"g-item g-text \">&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n      <p class=\"g-body\">Focusing on the United States again, inequality is worse compared with many other major economies.</p>&#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n    </div>&#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n&#13;\n    &#13;\n      </div></body></html>"}, "15429962": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 23:58:15", "url": "https://github.com/Property404/fetlang", "text": "<html><body><div><article class=\"markdown-body entry-content\" itemprop=\"text\"><h1><a href=\"#fetlang\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-fetlang\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Fetlang</h1>\n<p>Fetlang is a statically typed, procedural, esoteric programming language and\nreference implementation. It is designed such that source code looks like\npoorly written fetish erotica</p>\n<p>Fetlang is not recommended for production use at this moment, especially in\nmedical or military applications</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#example\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-example\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 point</li>\n<li>Transpiles to C</li>\n<li>Case insensitive</li>\n<li>Confusing English-like syntax and unhelpful error messages</li>\n<li>Probably Turing complete</li>\n<li>Extensible - just install your fetish in share/fetlang/fetishes</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#building\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-building\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\"
