license</p>\n</article>\n  </div></body></html>"}, "15429431": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:03:30", "url": "https://xnet-x.net/en/digital-repression-and-resistance-catalan-referendum/", "text": "<html><body><div><section class=\"entry-content\">\n<h3>Successes and failures in the use of digital tools in Catalonia\u2019s rebellion</h3>\n<p>The battle presently being fought in the streets and polling stations in towns and cities throughout Catalonia before, during and after October 1, in which a diverse civil society has come together in huge numbers, putting their bodies and knowledge in the service of the shared goal of defending what is considered to be real democracy, has also had a crucial battleground in the case of the Internet.</p>\n<h3>September 7, 2017</h3>\n<p>On September 7, 2017, the Constitutional Court <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia-court/spains-constitutional-court-suspends-catalan-referendum-law-court-source-idUSKCN1BI2TE\" target=\"_blank\">suspends the law</a> of the referendum in Catalonia. Thenceforth, the Spanish government embarked on legal, police, and administrative persecution of any \u201cdevice or instrument that is to be used for preparing or holding the referendum\u201d, including ballot boxes and papers which were now criminal objects. Websites, apps and tools related with the referendum were closed on the Internet.</p>\n<p>Independently of whether one agrees or disagrees with the decision of the Spanish courts to ban the referendum, the closing of many regular Internet spaces can be viewed, in a great number of cases, as a grave violation of freedom of expression \u2014and especially freedom of political opinion\u2014 which is protected in international treaties and by <a href=\"http://www.europarl.europa.eu/charter/pdf/text_en.pdf#page=11\" target=\"_blank\">Article 11</a> of the European Union\u2019s Charter of Fundamental Rights on \u201cFreedom of expression and information\u201d. While some websites, apps and domains belong to the Generalitat (Government) of Catalonia and were tools directly linked with organizing the referendum, many others were of private individuals or associations, and basically reflect political opinions. It is clear that one thing \u2014arguable or not\u2014 is banning a referendum and quite another is <strong>blocking, while they were at it, the right to express one\u2019s political opinio</strong>n that the referendum should be held.</p>\n<p>In the last few days, Catalonia has been the testing ground of what we have always denounced or, in other words, the fact that the space of the Internet has yet again been subjected to a state of exception which \u201cdemocratic\u201d governments wouldn\u2019t dare to apply to physical space because this violation of rights would immediately be visible. Proof of this is that many of the shut-down websites belong to associations with physical premises but no authority has risked ordering that these centers should be closed.</p>\n<p>Internet access is essential for the exercise of our freedoms and should be considered in itself a fundamental right [<a href=\"https://www.accessnow.org/keepiton/\" target=\"_blank\">#KeepItOn</a>].</p>\n<blockquote><p>If we let the space of the Internet become the first casualty in the curtailment of basic rights, we can be sure that the next step will be to limit those rights in other spaces as well.</p></blockquote>\n<h3>September 13, 2017</h3>\n<p>On September 13 a court order <a href=\"http://www.catalannews.com/politics/item/catalan-government-opens-new-referendum-website-after-original-is-shut-down-by-spain\" target=\"_blank\">shut down the web page <em>referendum.cat</em></a>. Thus began a game of cat-and-mouse between the Spanish government (with its state repression) and the Catalan government. </p>\n<p>Some citizens published the referendum web code in Github. After this, clones of the website began to appear, created by volunteer citizens in domains with names like <em>piolin.cat</em> (where piolin refers to Tweetie Pie, painted on the boat accommodating Spanish police), <em>referendum.ninja</em> o <em>marianorajoy.cat</em>, while alternative sites were also made available by the Generalitat itself. The police operation continues with domains being shut down and access blocked to all these sites as well as many other web pages with opinions about the referendum, including those of associations, sports clubs and private sites. All of this was occurring against a background of politicians being arrested and presidents of civil society associations being charged with sedition.</p>\n<p><strong>In ten days more than <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/27/catalans-compare-spain-to-north-korea-after-referendum-sites-blocked)\" target=\"_blank\">140 websites</a> were blocked</strong>. The project <a href=\"https://ooni.torproject.org/post/internet-censorship-catalonia-independence-referendum/\" target=\"_blank\">OONI</a> by Tor includes a non-exhaustive list of affected domains and information on the type of block.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://xnet-x.net/img/dominio-intervenido-a-disposicion-judicial.png\"><img src=\"https://xnet-x.net/img/dominio-intervenido-a-disposicion-judicial.png\" alt=\"dominio-intervenido-a-disposicion-judicial\"/></a></p>\n<p>As part of this state operation,<strong> the Guardia Civil raided the headquarters of Top Level Domain <em>.cat</em></strong>, confiscating IT equipment and data, and detaining one of its IT staff. This disproportionate measure, which is unprecedented in the European Union, implies the possibility of opening the way for something we have been struggling against for years, namely <strong>domain managers being held responsible for content</strong>.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=22176&amp;LangID=E\" target=\"_blank\">UN</a> Rapporteur on Freedom of Opinion and Expression, the <a href=\"https://www.internetsociety.org/news/statements/2017/internet-society-statement-internet-blocking-measures-catalonia-spain/\" target=\"_blank\">Internet Society</a>, the <a href=\"https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/09/cat-domain-casualty-catalonian-independence-crackdown\" target=\"_blank\">Electronic Founder Foundation</a>, and many other organizations like our own have condemned this blocking of websites and the inordinate digital repression carried out by the Spanish government just days before the referendum was held, which meant that there was no chance to establish their validity, suitability and legality because they left no time to do so.</p>\n<p><strong>In this situation of persecution and very serious violation of rights</strong>, many people, moved by their convictions and without proper legal advice, have exposed themselves to risks which could have been avoided in some cases, and have left their identities at the mercy of a repressive apparatus that needs scapegoats to justify its actions. The open use of names among the alleged authors of the first mirror sites has meant that the authorities are now boasting that they have rounded up the young perpetrators (<a href=\"http://www.europapress.es/catalunya/noticia-libertad-cargos-13-investigados-clonar-webs-referendum-20170925193606.html\" target=\"_blank\">hasta 14</a>). Some of them face very serious charges like \u201c<a href=\"http://www.eldiario.es/cv/val/policia-proreferendum-Valencia-cabecilla-desobediencia_0_692231117.html\" target=\"_blank\">heading a seditious organization</a>\u201d which, as everyone knows, makes no sense at all in a free, open space like the Internet. These are definitely measures that aim to inflict disproportionate punishment so as to bully and intimidate citizens in an attempt to discourage their intense online activity. </p>\n<p>One of the most common errors made by citizens has been their frequent use of servers with few and poor legal guarantees for the client. A case in point is the insistent use of <em>.cat</em>, which falls under the same laws and rules of the Spainsh <em>.es</em> domain. These come under the control of <em>.es</em>, and therefore the Spanish state, which shows no concern for civil rights, in contrast with other generic domains (<em>.net</em>,<em> .org</em>, <em>.com</em>\u2026) with are overseen by ICANN and other organizations that do respect basic rights.</p>\n<p>We believe that it is important to stress that we shouldn\u2019t need martyrs to prove that our struggles are just. We must make every possible effort to ensure that the people who are struggling for their rights don\u2019t suffer reprisals. In this regard, Xnet has tried to give an overall explanation of how to avoid this and other useful information in a <a href=\"https://xnet-x.net/en/how-to-guide-for-preserving-fundamental-rights-internet/\" target=\"_blank\">Guide</a> that seeks to protect people who work with the Internet from unjust repression. This initiative is part of a set of actions designed by the lawyers and organizations of <a href=\"http://www.lafede.cat/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/consells_legals.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">#SomDefensores</a> to defend basic rights.</p>\n<h2>Net Democracy: Distributed Government</h2>\n<p>We have seen a Generalitat that is competent and farsighted in its online activity but, in particular, we also note that the acceleration of events in Catalonia has catalyzed the population into a massive use of digital tools in defense of their basic rights. Unlike similar situations, such as that in Turkey for example, the Catalan institutions have agreed in recent days to <strong>cede and share, in a widely distributed manner, responsibility for safeguarding freedoms</strong>, thus regularizing what we see as the embryo of what could be a <strong>truly transversal democracy worthy of the digital age</strong>, as some of us have already proposed in our discussion of the methodology of the device <a href=\"https://partidox.org/en/\" target=\"_blank\">Red Ciudadana Partido X</a>.</p>\n<p>The president of Catalonia, Carles Puigdemont\u2014thanks also to help from <a href=\"https://www.vilaweb.cat/noticies/els-hackers-que-van-fer-possible-el-cens-universal/\" target=\"_blank\">experts</a> who have actively and continually been engaged in working for the defense of rights (even people like Julian Assange and Peter Sunde publicly offered their counseling)\u2014have recommended the use of <a href=\"https://twitter.com/KRLS/status/909126641145798656\" target=\"_blank\">proxies</a> in social networks in order to gain access to blocked websites. He subsequently announced that <em><a href=\"https://twitter.com/KRLS/status/911482634789953536\" target=\"_blank\">IPFS</a></em> had also been used as a distributed tool for housing the website giving citizens information about where they should go to vote.</p>\n<h3>September 23, 2017</h3>\n<p>On September 23, the <a href=\"http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2017/09/23/59c69496468aeb8c7f8b45bb.html\" target=\"_blank\">High Court of Justice of Catalonia ordered</a> the \u201c<em><strong>blocking of websites and domains [giving this information] which are publicized in any account or official social network of any kind</strong></em>\u201d (). This was not just a matter of a specific list of sites but a general order giving a free hand to forces of security in ordering Internet providers to shut down websites.</p>\n<p>With these new powers, the Guardia Civil blocked the domain <em>gateway.ipfs.io</em> and thereby cut off connection, not only to the referendum website, but also to all content from the Spanish state <a href=\"https://twitter.com/AlexHinojo/status/911900292152791041\" target=\"_blank\">hosted in IPFS</a> through this gateway. The shutdown extended to websites of nongovernmental organizations and movements like <em>empaperem.cat</em>, <em>assemblea.cat</em> and <em>webdelsi.cat</em> which are in favor of the referendum. This carrying out of the court order also extended to GooglePlay, which was forced to withdraw the app allowing people to find information about where to vote.</p>\n<p>Nevertheless, <strong>at all times the whole population of Catalonia has been able to keep informed about polling stations</strong> thanks to continuous <strong>replication and massive use of VPN and anonymous browsing</strong> in order to access sites that were blocked from Spain. This capacity for <strong>action distributed between the government and organized citizens</strong> has been the trend throughout the electoral process, with large-scale use of chats, networks and other tools that have allowed swift circulation of information circulated on the micro-scale and among strangers who are working together to deal with hoaxes, leaks and infiltrations. </p>\n<p>This <strong>networked action</strong> by means of which people have, for example, organized themselves, polling station by polling station, has also been manifest in physical spaces, for example with regard to <a href=\"http://www.ara.cat/tema_del_dia/referendum-Que-gestar-se-Elna_0_1880212030.html\" target=\"_blank\">protecting the ballot boxes</a> from police seizure. For a month, the state security forces and their secret services have been searching all over Catalonia for the ballot boxes and voting papers. Although they have raided printers, media offices and headquarters of political parties and other organizations \u2014sometimes without a court order\u2014 <strong>the ballot boxes were never found, yet they magically appeared in the polling stations</strong>. The ballot boxes and papers were there\u2014they were everywhere\u2014guarded by <strong>small groups, autonomous nodes</strong>, and spread all around Catalonia.</p>\n<h3>October 1, referendum day</h3>\n<p>Finally, even as the referendum was taking place on October 1, the Spanish government tried to block, by every means it could, the possibility of accessing the \u201cuniversal census\u201d app of the entire electoral register.</p>\n<p>The domain <em>registremeses.com</em> where the app was hosted was immediately blocked. The Generalitat quickly supplied the more than 1,000 polling stations throughout Catalonia with alternative IPs for access. We believe that, in this case, it probably would have been better to work with Hidden Service in order to avoid police harassment and DDoS attacks by groups opposing the referendum.<br/>\n<a href=\"http://www.ara.cat/tema_del_dia/Violencia-tambe-digital-contra-referendum_0_1880212015.html\" target=\"_blank\">Internet connection was also interrupted</a> and it is not yet known who is responsible. Could it have been Internet suppliers obeying state orders (although they deny it)?</p>\n<p>However, the polling stations still managed to function, almost all of them routing the smartphones of the volunteers in order to access the Internet.<strong> In the street, people were chorusing \u201cairplane mode\u201d</strong> so as to save network bandwidth for people working inside the polling stations. The operation lasted from 5 a.m.\u2014which is when citizens began filling the streets to protect the polling stations\u2014until midnight when the vote count ended. All this was achieved in the midst of violent charges by National Police with a toll of more than 800 wounded. Despite everything, more than 2,200,000 people came out to vote.</p>\n<h2>Order is the people, equal to equal: disorder is this state and its violence</h2>\n<blockquote><p>The citizens and government of Catalonia have learned and are witnesses to the fact that in the front line of defense of our democracy, digital resistance depends on our use of technological tools which allow us to protect our rights autonomously and in a well distributed manner.</p></blockquote>\n<p>We hope that the Catalan government will never forget this and that its administration will always resist the temptation of the usual kind of discourse that criminalizes tools protecting privacy, encryption and decentralization of the Internet. </p>\n<p>Moreover, when repression was massively unleashed in streets and villages of Catalonia, the social networks and their intelligent use by citizens were once again used to put an end to the blocking and manipulation of information by the mainstream media in Spain, and to let the international media outlets know what was really happening. Perhaps in 2017, many people were already used to this, but it is also highly possible that there have never been so many published videos and photographs documenting <a href=\"https://twitter.com/joncstone/status/914450692416397312\" target=\"_blank\">police violence</a> as there have been this time (https://twitter.com/joncstone/status/914450692416397312). Without the widespread use of social networks to testify and inform, the people of Catalonia would have been totally isolated and crushed with absolute impunity.</p>\n<p>From this point of view, what has been happening in the last few days is historic. This acceleration towards a greater degree of democracy and more power in civil society is happening spontaneously but the ignorance of most people about some aspects of the digital milieu is exposing them to risks and, in this regard, this is what we must make and what we are <a href=\"https://xnet-x.net/en/how-to-guide-for-preserving-fundamental-rights-internet/\" target=\"_blank\">putting evey effort into</a> to achieve.</p>\n<h3>October 1, 2017 as a beginning</h3>\n<p>On October 1, 2017 the politicians were nowhere to be seen. <strong>Only <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unidos_Podemos\" target=\"_blank\">Unidos Podemos</a> could be heard now-and-then, trying to capitalize on our wounded for its own ends. Apart this, there were only grassroots people organizing and acting</strong>, including some members of parliament and councilors who are people like anyone else. Over 24 hours, civil society came together to work for a day in which people could vote and vote on a huge scale and, furthermore, it didn\u2019t fall into the temptation of responding to the state\u2019s provocation in the form of violence, even though hundreds of injured people needed medical attention. There was happiness, anger and fraternity among the most different people. It was incredibly moving. There were no slogans, no shouting, so that people could vote without being coerced in <strong>this display of a valiant, stirring capacity for organization and desire for democracy</strong>.</p>\n<p><strong>On October 1, 2017 we proved that order is the people and disorder is this state. </strong><br/>\n\u00a0</p>\n<p><em><strong>Xnet</strong></em></p>\n<p>\u00a0<br/>\n<em>*Front picture by <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Makrakas/status/914410446647693312\" target=\"_blank\">@Makrakas</a> in Gr\u00e0cia, Barcelona.</em><br/>\n\u00a0</p>\n<div>\n<em>More info provided by the network:</em>\n<p>Association for Progressive Communications (APC) press release:<br/>\n<a href=\"https://www.apc.org/en/pubs/apc-calls-end-restrictions-freedom-expression-catalonia\" from the Spanish government:<br/>\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Anubis\" target=\"_blank\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Anubis</a></p>\n<p>Official web site of the High Court of Justice of Catalonia:<br/>\n<a href=\"http://www.poderjudicial.es/cgpj/es/Poder-Judicial/Tribunales-Superiores-de-Justicia/TSJ-Cataluna/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.poderjudicial.es/cgpj/es/Poder-Judicial/Tribunales-Superiores-de-Justicia/TSJ-Cataluna/</a></p>\n<p>The legal basis in Catalonia comes from the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Catalonia\" target=\"_blank\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Catalonia</a> and several laws approved such as: <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_on_the_Referendum_on_Self-determination_of_Catalonia\" target=\"_blank\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_on_the_Referendum_on_Self-determination_of_Catalonia</a> and the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_juridical_transition_and_foundation_of_the_Republic\" target=\"_blank\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_juridical_transition_and_foundation_of_the_Republic</a>.</p>\n<p>The informative web site www.referendum.cat (Sept 13) was blocked by police with a judicial order to suspend the DNS domain:<br/>\n<a href=\"https://blog.cdmon.com/ca/comunicat-oficial-referendum-cat/\" target=\"_blank\"> https://blog.cdmon.com/ca/comunicat-oficial-referendum-cat/</a></p>\n<p>Replicas of this web site were hosted in Cloudflare, but then ISPs were ordered filters or redirections.</p>\n<p>The site was published in a code repository and replicated in the P2P file system IPFS. A IPFS gateway was blocked in some ISPs, but content was accessible from IPFS clients.</p>\n<p>Some people cloned the sites and were detained and interrogated, in some cases forced to give passwords (even for personal email and social media). For instance the magistrate (public prosecutor or judge) also ordered to block \u201cwebsites or domains that appear in any official account or social network of the members of the Government through which directly and indirectly, even referring to other accounts, was informed, through links, of how to access domains whose contents they keep in relation to which they are now blocked.\u201d</p>\n<p>About the DNS (.cat TLD intervention and domain blockade) mentioned in the netcommons article, an external discussion:<br/>\n<a href=\"http://www.internetgovernance.org/2017/09/20/puntcat-under-fire-internet-vs-political-identities/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.internetgovernance.org/2017/09/20/puntcat-under-fire-internet-vs-political-identities/</a></p>\n<p>Among many others (more than 140) sites, such as assemblea.cat, blocked (different ways depending the ISP) and moved to assemblea.eu.</p>\n<p>The day of the election many schools and poll stations found their Internet connection down. Police closed several poll stations, in several cases with violence, and a small portion of votes were seized by the police.</p>\n<p>Citizens deployed their own mobile and wifi point-to-point links, even batteries for power to allow access to the census application to provide guarantees to the process, such as avoid double voting. VPNs, indirection mechanisms such as Onion routing and alternative ISPs were used to circumvent the traffic filters.</p>\n<p>The census service itself, was stopped the day before with a judicial order, among nearly 30 databases, controlled from the data center of the Catalan government. Replicas were created. These servers were actively blocked and attacked during the day, and some of the interruptions and delays of the voting process were the result of that, and required moving the servers to new IP addressed. People in poll stations were using a web application to use that service for voter validation, and social media was used to share news about changes and events. Many people resorted to Whatsapp, Telegram, Signal groups, Twitter, etc.</p>\n<p>Many, diverse, and powerful DDOS attacks have happened to many web sites related to the process in the last weeks.</p>\n<p>This is still ongoing. Today there is a general strike in Catalonia.</p>\n<p>\u2013 Xnet has published a very good \u201cBasic guide to preseve fundamental rights on the Internet\u201d:<br/>\n<a href=\"https://xnet-x.net/en/how-to-guide-for-preserving-fundamental-rights-internet/#how-to-guide\" target=\"_blank\">https://xnet-x.net/en/how-to-guide-for-preserving-fundamental-rights-internet/#how-to-guide</a></p>\n<p>\u2013 Softcatala has also published a guide \u201cautodefensa digital\u201d:<br/>\n<a href=\"https://autodefensa.softcatala.cat/\" target=\"_blank\">https://autodefensa.softcatala.cat/</a></p>\n</div>\n<div id=\"more-posts\">\n<div>\n<h4><b><em>Last posts on:</em></b></h4>\n\n<h3>Net Democracy. Method, politic R+D</h3>\n\n\n\n\n<h3>Freedom of expression and information</h3>\n\n\n\n</div>\n</div>\n\n<p class=\"entry-links\"/>\n</section>\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15430479": {"score": 11, "comments": ["The article mentions the Great American Desert. Parts of Colorado already were this during the Dust Bowl. In northeast Colorado several natural grasslands were created in places where farming was marginal and areas became depopulated. It&#x27;s such as terrible place to try to grow crops. Windy and dry, some places can go months without precipitation. Anyone farming out there now is living on borrowed time and water and shouldn&#x27;t be surprised that it&#x27;s drying up.<p>Edit: I live in Colorado and visit the grasslands often for killer star gazing and I recommend anyone interested in this subject read:<p>&quot;The Worst Hard Times&quot; about the Dust Bowl and &quot;Cadillac Desert&quot; which is about dam building in the ultra dry west (like Nevada&#x2F;AZ).", "Aquifers everywhere are being destroyed, they cannot be rebuilt. Permanent dust storm on the horizon."], "time": "2017-10-09 01:51:31", "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/10/08/colorado-eastern-plains-groundwater-running-dry/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"body-copy\"><p>WRAY \u2014 Colorado farmers who defied nature\u2019s limits and nourished a pastoral paradise by irrigating drought-prone prairie are pushing ahead in the face of worsening environmental fallout: Overpumping of groundwater has drained the High Plains Aquifer to the point that streams are drying up at the rate of 6 miles a year.</p>\n<p>The drawdown has become so severe that highly resilient fish are disappearing, evidence of ecological collapse. A Denver Post analysis of federal data shows the aquifer shrank twice as fast over the past six years compared with the previous 60.</p>\n<p>While the drying out of America\u2019s agricultural bread basket ($35 billion in crops a year) ultimately may pinch people in cities, it is hitting rural areas hardest.</p>\n<p>\u201cNow I never know, from one minute to the next, when I turn on a faucet or hydrant, whether there will be water or not. The aquifer is being depleted,\u201d said Lois Scott, 75, who lives west of Cope, north of the frequently bone-dry bed of the Arikaree River.</p>\n<p>A 40-foot well her grandfather dug by hand in 1914 gave water until recently, she said, lamenting the loss of lawns where children once frolicked and green pastures for cows. Scott has been considering a move to Brush and leaving her family\u2019s historic homestead farm.</p>\n<p>\u201cThis will truly become the Great American Desert,\u201d she said.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2811913\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter size-article_inline\"><img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"Employees of New Banks Pumps fixed ...\" data-src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=780&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 780w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=810&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 810w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_28928.jpg?w=630&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 630w\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p>Employees of New Banks Pumps fixed a stock tank well on Sept. 12, 2017 in Wray. They were able to get the well working again, but only less than a foot of water was measured in the well hole, leaving the rancher with only a trickle of water to fill the tanks for his cattle.</figcaption></figure>\n<aside class=\"related right\">\n\n<p><a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/tag/colorado-divide/\"><img src=\"http://www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/colorado-divide-logo1.png\"/></a></p>\n<p>This is part of an occasional series examining the issues, values and attitudes that can leave rural and urban residents feeling they live in two Colorados.</p>\n</aside>\n<p>The\u00a0<a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2012/01/16/water-worries-in-colorados-san-luis-valley-come-to-surface/\">agricultural overpumping</a> from thousands of wells continues despite decades of warnings from researchers that the aquifer \u2014 also known as the Ogallala, the world\u2019s largest underground body of fresh water \u2014 is shrinking.</p><p id=\"div-gpt-ad-Cube_Article\" class=\"dfp-ad dfp-Cube_Article\" data-ad-unit=\"Cube_Article\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t</p>\n<p>Even if farmers radically reduced pumping, the latest research finds, the aquifer wouldn\u2019t refill for centuries. Farmers say they cannot handle this on their own.</p>\n<p>But there is no agreement among the eight affected states (Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, South Dakota) to try to save the aquifer. And state rules allow total depletion.</p>\n<p>In fact, Colorado officials faced with legal challenges from Kansas over dwindling surface water in the Republican River have found that their best option to comply with a 1942 compact is to take more water out of the aquifer. The state bought wells from farmers during the past decade and has been pumping out 11,500 acre-feet of water a year, enough to satisfy a small city, delivering it through a $60 million,\u00a0<a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2013/12/20/pipeline-from-colorado-wells-may-ease-republican-river-water-dispute/\">12-mile pipeline northeast of Wray</a> to artificially resuscitate the river.</p>\n<p>The overpumping reflects a pattern, seen worldwide, where people with knowledge that they\u2019re exceeding nature\u2019s limits nevertheless cling to destructive practices that hasten an environmental backlash.\n</p>\n<h3>The drawdown</h3>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2811920\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter size-article_inline\"><img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"Cattle gather around a water hole ...\" data-src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=780&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 780w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=810&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 810w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29505.jpg?w=630&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 630w\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p>Cattle gather around a water hole at a ranch north of Burlington on Sept. 12, 2017 in Burlington. The feeder stream from the South Fork Republican River, one of three tributaries that originate in the High Plains of Northeastern Colorado, is slowly drying up.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The depletion of the High Plains Aquifer has been happening for decades, according to bulletins U.S. Geological Survey has put out since 1988. Colorado farmers this year pumped groundwater out of 4,000 wells, state records show, siphoning as much as 500 gallons a minute from each well to irrigate roughly 580,000 acres \u2014 mostly to grow corn, a water-intensive crop.</p>\n<p>The depth where groundwater can be tapped has fallen by as much as 100 feet in eastern Colorado, USGS data show. That means pump motors must work harder to pull up the same amount of water, using more energy \u2014 raising costs for farmers. The amount of water siphoned from the aquifer since 1950 to irrigate farm fields across the eight states tops 273 million acre-feet (89 trillion gallons) \u2014 about 70 percent of the water in Lake Erie.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2812585\" class=\"wp-caption alignright size-article_inline_half\"><a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg\"><img class=\" lazyload\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"\u00a0\" data-src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i0.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/cd08aquifer.jpg?w=310&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 310w\"/></a><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\">Click the graphic to enlarge it</figcaption></figure>\n<p>On one hand, the industrial center-pivot irrigation techniques perfected after World War II have brought consistency to farming by tapping the \u201csponge\u201d of saturated sediment that links the aquifer to\u00a0surface water in streams and rivers. America\u2019s breadbasket produces $35 billion of crops a year. On the other hand, intense irrigation is breaking ecosystems apart.</p>\n<p>Overpumping has dried up 358 miles of surface rivers and streams across a 200-square-mile area covering eastern Colorado, western Kansas and Nebraska, according to U.S. Fish and Wildlife-backed researchers from Colorado State University and Kansas State University who published a peer-reviewed report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The researchers also determined that, if farmers keep pumping water at the current pace, another 177 miles of rivers and streams will be lost before 2060.</p>\n<p>\u201cIntermittent streams are more likely to be dry. Permanent streams are more likely to become intermittent. Large streams are more likely to be small. Everything has changed,\u201d said KSU conservation biologist Keith Gido, one of the authors.\u00a0\u201cWe have almost completely changed the species of fish that can survive in those streams, compared with what was there historically. This is really a catastrophic change.\u201d</p>\n<p>Disappearing fish species \u2014 minnows, suckers, catfish that had evolved to endure periodic droughts \u2014 signal to biologists that ecological effects may be reaching a tipping point.</p>\n<p>The amount of water held in the aquifer under eastern Colorado decreased by 19.6 million acre-feet \u2014 6.4 trillion gallons \u2014 from 1950 until 2015, USGS records show. That\u2019s an average loss of 300,000 acre-feet a year. Between 2011 and 2015, records show, the water available under Colorado in the aquifer decreased by 3.2 million acre-feet \u2014 an annual average shrinkage of 800,000 acre-feet. Climate change factors, including rainfall, play into the rate of the drawdown.</p>\n<p>If all pumping stopped immediately, it would still take hundreds of years for rain-fed streams and rivers to recharge the aquifer, Gido said.</p>\n<p>\u201cWe\u2019re not living in as sustainable a fashion as we need to be. Much of the damage has been done,\u201d he said, \u201cand restoring what we\u2019ve lost could be difficult.</p>\n<p>\u201cIt is happening all over the world in places such as Pakistan. It causes conflicts. As human populations grow, the demand for water is going to be greater. Conflicts are going to increase \u2014 unless we become more efficient in using the water we have.\u201d</p>\n<h3>Farmers locked</h3>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2811909\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter size-article_inline\"><img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"Rod Lenz, president of the Republican ...\" data-src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=780&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 780w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=810&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 810w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27796.jpg?w=630&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 630w\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p>Rod Lenz, president of the Republican River Water Conservation District, walks pass a storage tank filled with water that will free-flow down a pipeline to a outfall at the Republican River on Sept. 12, 2017 in Wray. The water delivery is part of the Republican River Compact among Colorado, Kansas, and Nebraska.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>For farmers, weaning themselves off groundwater is proving difficult.</p>\n<p>They say they\u2019re trying. They\u2019ve reduced the land irrigated in eastern Colorado by 30,000 acres since 2006. They plan to retire another 25,000 acres over the next decade, said Rod Lenz, president of the Republican River Water Conservation District, who for years has advocated use of technology to grow more crops with less water.</p>\n<p>\u201cWe have come to realize that, yeah, we are overmining it. We are\u00a0acutely aware of that now. There\u2019s a definite attitude to make more than just the natural progression as far as efficiency,\u201d Lenz said, noting state officials monitor pumping and determine how many acres owners can irrigate.</p>\n<aside class=\"related right\"/>\n<p>\u201cWe\u2019re constantly trying to find ways to stay in compliance,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re looking at serious conservation.\u201d</p>\n<p>For years, agriculture experts have pointed to drip-irrigation technology to do more with less.\u00a0 Federal agencies in the past dangled help for farmers who invest. But few in eastern Colorado have installed these systems, largely because they are expensive.</p>\n<p>Farmer and cattleman Robert Boyd, a leader of the Arikaree Groundwater Management District, said the federal government should intervene to ensure survival of High Plains agriculture.</p>\n<p>\u201cDo you want us to be sustainable? Or not? It may come to a point where no one can actually irrigate,\u201d Boyd said.</p>\n<p>He pointed to proposals to divert water from the Missouri River Basin and move it westward through pipelines across the Great Plains.</p>\n<p>\u201cIf the federal government wants agriculture to be sustainable, they need to pump water back toward the mountains. They need to figure out how to get water back toward the higher parts of the rivers,\u201d he said.\u00a0\u201cThe federal government needs to step in and make the states work together to make agriculture \u2014 and urban areas \u2014 sustainable.\u201d</p>\n<p>For now, farmers struggle, increasingly weighing water uncertainties in calculations that include corn prices falling to around $3.50 a bushel in recent years from $7. But drawing down the aquifer does not violate any law in Colorado. The state engineer\u2019s office monitors well levels and requires permits for wells, limiting the number of acres a farmer can irrigate. But there\u2019s no hard limit on how much water can be pumped.</p>\n<p>In contrast, state rules limit <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2011/04/26/south-denver-suburbs-preparing-to-end-reliance-on-super-deep-wells/\">groundwater withdrawals from the Denver Basin Aquifer</a>\u00a0\u2014 a source for many of Denver\u2019s <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2014/12/09/denver-suburbs-drawing-down-groundwater-aim-for-renewable-supply/\">southern suburbs,</a> including Castle Rock and Parker \u2014 to less than 1 percent a year. This is meant to help natural recharge keep pace with human demands.</p>\n<p>But on the High Plains, the situation is like mining intended to fully exploit diamonds or gold.</p>\n<p>\u201cIf you want to have it all back the way it was 150 years ago, you would have to remove everyone from the area. I\u2019m not sure how we could do that today,\u201d deputy state engineer Mike Sullivan said in an interview.</p>\n<p>Sullivan and state engineer Kevin Rein emphasized that thousands of acres no longer are irrigated. \u201cAnd there need to be some more retirements of land to get us into a more balanced situation,\u201d Sullivan said.</p>\n<p>They defended Colorado\u2019s practice of pumping more groundwater out of the aquifer, saying this is necessary to comply with the Republican River Compact. Disputes over river flows have risen as far as the U.S. Supreme Court and Colorado\u2019s legal obligations to deliver water to Nebraska and Kansas are clear.</p>\n<p>\u201cWhat we do with the pumping does help the streams,\u201d Sullivan said. \u201cIt does provide a wet stream. \u2026 We could not meet our (legal) obligation without that today, even if we turned off all the wells.\u201d</p>\n<p>But there\u2019s no end in sight for the drawdown of groundwater.</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2811918\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter size-article_inline\"><img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"Dust flies up as Oscar Ortiz, ...\" data-src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=780&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 780w,https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=810&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 810w,https://i1.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_29370.jpg?w=630&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 630w\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p>Dust flies up as Oscar Ortiz, a pen rider at Cure Feeders, works with the cattle on Sept. 13, 2017 in Idalia. The Cure family ranch sold water rights to 54 of their wells to the Republican River Water Conservation District. The water from those wells is now pumped to a holding tank that will free-flow down a pipeline to a outfall at the Republican River as part of the Republican River Compact among Colorado, Kansas, and Nebraska.</figcaption></figure>\n<h3>Nature exhausted</h3>\n<p>And for farmers who built their world on the High Plains Aquifer, the environmental fallout is increasingly painful. In the rural view, it is a problem that cannot be addressed by farmers alone without help from people in cities. All of the industrial\u00a0<a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2017/03/05/gravel-pit-colorado-farmers-agriculture/\">agriculture is done with urban residents in mind \u2014 the people who consume the crops and cows that farmers grow</a>.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe world population is going to double. And we\u2019re not going to be able to grow more farmland. We\u2019re losing farming ground every day to development,\u201d said Cody Powell, manager of 21st Century Equipment, the John Deere dealer in Burlington, an agricultural hub.\u00a0\u201cYou take away farm ground for development, bring in more people. Who\u2019s going to feed them? The only way to do that is to put water on crops.\u201d</p>\n<p>People in cities increasingly demand environmentally correct crops, which requires more water. \u201cIf they want natural grain-fed cattle, and non-GMO (genetically modified organism) crops \u2014 all that good stuff \u2014 it is going to take water,\u201d he said.</p>\n<p>A farmer can grow more by using pesticides and genetically modified seeds, he said. \u201cWith the same amount of water, you could get twice as much corn.\u201d</p>\n<p>He knows too well the perils of <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2011/03/11/colorado-farmland-goes-dry-as-suburbs-secure-water-supplies/\">losing water. He grew up in southern Colorado\u2019s Arkansas River Valley</a> at a time when Aurora and other Front Range suburbs were buying up rights from farmers. This buy-up to slake growing suburban thirsts ended up killing agriculture across hundreds of thousands of once-irrigated acres.</p>\n<p>And now when Powell goes back, he sees communities \u201coverrun with thugs\u201d near where his grandmother lived. \u201cIt makes me feel sick,\u201d he said.</p>\n<p>In eastern Colorado, the problem now is that <a href=\"http://www.denverpost.com/2015/08/01/colorado-farmers-grow-more-food-on-less-water-amid-rising-competition/\">few can afford to invest in high-efficiency water technology, such as irrigation drip tubes and tape installed underground to eliminate evaporation losses, and soil-sensor systems that let farmers irrigate only when absolutely necessary</a>.</p>\n<p>Federal programs to subsidize installation of this technology have withered. And the overpumping continues.</p>\n<p>\u201cThe fear out here now is not that the aquifer is going to get ruined,\u201d Powell said. \u201cThe fear is that the state is going to shut off wells.\u201d</p>\n<p>And prairie residents practically cringe to see the pipeline northeast of Wray that Colorado uses to convey groundwater away to Nebraska and Kansas to prevent future lawsuits.</p>\n<p>The interstate compact was negotiated back when there was more water and far fewer people, they say.</p>\n<p>\u201cNow we just have weeds. We are feeling the effect of losing the water that Kansas is enjoying,\u201d Scott said from her farmhouse. \u201cIt is robbing families of life. That\u2019s what is happening to us. We should be entitled to the\u00a0water underground.\u201d</p>\n<figure id=\"attachment_2811940\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter size-article_inline\"><img class=\" lazyautosizes lazyload\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" alt=\"A single stock of corn stands ...\" data-src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px\" data-srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=620&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 620w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=780&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 780w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=810&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 810w,https://i2.wp.com/www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/dryland_water_2017_rj_27068.jpg?w=630&amp;crop=0%2C0px%2C100%2C9999px 630w\"/><figcaption class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p class=\"photo-credit\">RJ Sangosti, The Denver Post</p>A single stock of corn stands in a field, in Yuma County, after harvest on Sept. 12, 2017 in Idalia.</figcaption></figure>\n<h3>Past becomes future</h3>\n<p>The depletion means water scarcity increasingly dictates survival.</p>\n<p>It is no surprise to\u00a0historians. In the 1860s, John Wesley Powell\u2019s surveys for the U.S. government warned that the land west of central Kansas was practically a desert. His report \u201cOn the Arid Lands of the Western United States\u201d warned that the only way for people to live here would be by irrigating land. Otherwise, he wrote, the place could not support permanent communities. Tribes for centuries used the Great Plains seasonally as a hunting ground.</p>\n<p>Settlers flocked in during the 19th century, initially relying on dryland farming. This led to massive soil erosion, culminating in the Dust Bowl environmental disaster of the 1930s.</p>\n<p>Industrial irrigation took off during the 1960s, with tens of thousands of wells drilled through the 1980s.</p>\n<p>But now, if people keep pumping, the dry-out will intensify, CSU senior research scientist Kevin Bestgen said.</p>\n<p>\u201cI appreciate it that people now are trying to reduce pumping. The reality is that the bucket they are pumping from does not refill. It is finite. And in order to allow recharge of that aquifer,\u00a0farmers are going to have to get much more severe reductions in pumping levels. It has been going down and down and down,\u201d he said.\u00a0\u201cPeople are getting what they can. This will turn out to be a tragedy. It is in the culture at this point. People want to grow corn now.\u201d</p>\n<hr/>\n<h3>Groundwater levels</h3>\n<p>The map shows the change in groundwater levels for various management districts in the Northern High Plains Basin over the last 10 years. The water level data is collected from wells in the areas. Click an area to see the changes in groundwater levels for 1-, 5- and 10-year periods.</p>\n\n\n<p><em>Source: <a href=\"http://water.state.co.us/groundwater/Levels/Pages/HydroGeo.aspx\">Colorado I don&#x27;t see anything shocking about choosing a buyback over the other two choices. After all, when a company takes investor money in a public offering, the idea is that the money will eventually be returned to investors, plus a profit if possible. A buyback is one way to close out the deal with some of those investors and return that money.<p>Edit:<p>Also, I think there&#x27;s a bit of funny math here possibly contributing to a misunderstanding when the article says things like this:<p>&gt; During that period those companies used 54% of their earnings\u2014a total of $2.4 trillion\u2014to buy back their own stock, almost all through purchases on the open market.
