If Researcher is employed by a for-profit, commercial entity, Researcher's employer shall also be bound by these terms and conditions, and Researcher hereby represents that he or she is fully authorized to enter into this agreement on behalf of such employer.</code></pre></div></div></body></html>"}, "15431016": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:22:21", "url": "http://www.kevinmd.com/blog/2017/10/managing-physicians-like-herding-cats.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post_content\">\n<p>One cold winter night many years ago, someone dropped off a calico cat and her two kittens in our snowy driveway, and we went from a two cat family to a five cat household. I learned a few things from that.</p>\n<p>When I was a resident, two thirtysomething family docs had an office upstairs from the residency program. Ned and Peter precepted us, and they sometimes ran downstairs to ask the director, Dr. Pete, for his input when they had a tough case themselves.</p>\n<p>It was very clear to me that Ned and Peter had a shared vision of how a practice should run, even though I\u2019m sure they weren\u2019t clones of each other. They also seemed to be really in tune with the residency, and one of them later became its director.</p>\n<p><span id=\"more-118444\"/></p>\n<p>My first job after graduation was with two middle-aged doctors in a small Maine mill town. They covered seamlessly for each other, even though they seemed like very different people. I realized quickly that my comfort level with some of the things they tackled in the hospital was never going to catch up with theirs, so I moved on to where I am now the medical director. I did express my discomfort with handling patients in the intensive care unit, for example, and they did tell me they were considering giving it up, but not right away. I was their employee, and although they offered me a partnership, they were the majority and the founding partners.</p>\n<p>The clinic where I ended up spending most of my career is very different, and very typical for medical practices today. We are a nonprofit organization with a board and a chief executive officer. I may be the medical director, but the physicians and nurse practitioners here really answer more to the CEO than to me.</p>\n<p>The providers here are a little like my one-time herd of five cats, gathered under one roof by circumstance rather than from a clear and particular desire to work with each other. Sure, Dr. Brown was my doctor when he worked in the city many years ago, and he came here in part because he knew me, and Dr. Kim had practiced in the next town over and had been curious about us. He did call and talk to me before going very far in negotiations with our CEO, just to make sure he\u2019d fit in, but others came here because of our location or some other reason besides knowing that we would all work well together or that we shared some deep practice philosophy.</p>\n<p>We are not a group practice in the sense that group practices were formed when I started out. So my job as medical director is a lot more like herding cats than leading a group of like-minded visionaries in the early days of the new specialty of family practice. Also, because I care for a full compliment of patients alongside my colleagues and depend on their coverage and cooperation, I am in no position to be heavy-handed in leading our medical staff. I may work to set an example in some cases, by building consensus in others, but I seldom lay down commandments on stone tablets.</p>\n<p>That is a stark contrast to Elijah Lamb at Cityside Medical Group. At his hospital owned mega practice, he isn\u2019t just the medical director, but a hospital vice-president of medical affairs. He is more clearly in the chain of command, and his medical staff knows it. He even fires people.</p>\n<p>Right now, a newly hired provider at my clinic is asking that we not contradict her antibiotic stewardship when she sees another provider\u2019s patient for a bronchitis. I did a \u201cpractice style inventory\u201d several months ago, and we all said we didn\u2019t prescribe antibiotics for a bronchitis of fewer than seven days duration. But Karen knows we often do, and she feels we undercut her by giving in to patients that call us the day after seeing her.</p>\n<p>We have also had several exchanges and meetings about how we handle opioid prescriptions. When one of my colleagues reduced her hours in semiretirement, Dr. Kim inherited many of her patients, and started tapering some off their opiates. Much unrest followed. We had to sit down to find common ground about whether patients could switch from Dr. Kim to another provider just to see if they would reinstate their opioids. We decided, along with our CEO, not to allow internal transfers of that nature. Anything else would likely tear apart the fabric of our group, we reasoned. Interestingly, the retiring physician told us that the patients Dr. Kim had tapered off opioids were people she herself had contemplated doing the same with. She just hadn\u2019t done it yet.</p>\n<p>Do I wish my job was more like Dr. Lambs? Would I be happy seeing a few token patients and spending the rest of my time being a medical administrator? I don\u2019t think so, no more than I would have preferred not to live with five cats of different disposition.</p>\n<p>As a doctor, I never tell my patients what to do. I outline, explain and support my patients in choosing between options. That is how I act toward my colleagues, too. Just like with integrating five cats, it may not be the quickest way to get things done, but in the big scheme of things, it is the only way that really works if you want peace in your house.</p>\n<p><em>\u201cA Country Doctor\u201d is a family physician who blogs at\u00a0<a href=\"http://acountrydoctorwrites.wordpress.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">A Country Doctor Writes:</a>.</em></p>\n<p><em>Image credit:\u00a0<a href=\"http://www.shutterstock.com/?cr=00&amp;pl=edit-00\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener noreferrer\">Shutterstock.com</a></em></p>\n&#13;\n                &#13;\n                                        &#13;\n                                        &#13;\n                &#13;\n                                &#13;\n                                    &#13;\n                    &#13;\n&#13;\n&#13;\n                    &#13;\n                    &#13;\n                &#13;\n                &#13;\n                &#13;\n                &#13;\n                <p class=\"swp-content-locator\"/>\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429256": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:16:52", "url": "https://www.julian.com/blog/startup-competition?hn", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"blog formatted-text w-richtext\"><h2>Why you're stressed</h2><p>For many founders, starting a startup is\u00a0the most stressful thing they\u00a0do <em>in their lifetime</em>. I polled friends\u00a0to identify the sources of that stress: (1) a lack of growth, (2) work/life balance, and (3) <strong>competition</strong>.</p><p>Competition is the outlier because you could argue it's mostly an illusion. It's therefore the easiest one to dispel in a short blog post.</p><p>I've had more than one VC\u00a0tell me they send this post to their founders\u00a0because it's an effective\u00a0therapy session. So hopefully you'll sleep better after reading this \u00f0\u009f\u0098\u0089</p><h3>The anxiety\u00a0of competition</h3><p>Every startup idea I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve had has been haunted by these concerns:</p><ul><li>What if the competition appropriates my entire business into a feature? (Facebook does this to a lot of startups.)</li><li>If I don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t build my product/feature\u00a0<em>immediately</em>, someone will before me, and I\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll have lost this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to get a headstart on press and user adoption.</li><li>What if my competitors' broad market saturation makes it so difficult to entice people to sign up for my product that customer acquisition costs will be unsustainably high?</li></ul><p>Time and time again, these concerns make me seriously question whether a startup is a massive waste of my time. I don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t use the word \u00e2\u0080\u009cmassive\u00e2\u0080\u009d lightly.\u00a0My fear of wasting time is rooted in my sharp awareness of opportunity cost.</p><p>So, how can we overcome this anxiety? By understanding the lifecycle of a startup.\u00a0</p><figure class=\"w-richtext-align-fullwidth\" data-rt-type=\"image\" data-rt-align=\"fullwidth\" data-rt-max-width=\"\"/><h3>Early stage: You're not unique</h3><p>In the early stage, your approach to market must not be \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are unique.\u00e2\u0080\u009d That's what founders love to tell themselves \u00e2\u0080\u0094 because that's\u00a0the message they successfully used to secure funding and hire a team. </p><p>But it's a toxic mindset that fosters anxiety. Instead, you should think of\u00a0your startup as merely cloning\u00a0existing competitors feature by feature.\u00a0Even if that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not the case,\u00a0tell yourself it is in the early stages of your startup.</p><p>When you embrace this copycat mindset, you reduce the anxiety of having to finish your MVP before someone beats you to market. You also get\u00a0the calming luxury of being a laggard. Laggards have a\u00a0vantage point. They\u00a0can prioritize growth viability (instead of novelty) by examining how existing\u00a0competitors acquire\u00a0users then reflecting those acquisition loops in their MVP.\u00a0</p><p>(<a target=\"_blank\" data-rt-link-type=\"external\" href=\"http://a-fwd.com/fr=juliancom06-21&amp;de=juliancom0c-21&amp;uk=juliancom-21&amp;ca=juliancom0d-20&amp;com=juliandotc059-20&amp;asin-com=1591848369\">Traction</a> is a must-read book for understanding\u00a0growth channels.)</p><p>Examples of laggards include what Slack is to HipChat, what GitHub is to Atlassian, and what Spotify is to Pandora. </p><p>If you cling to the desire to be unique instead of\u00a0embracing the copycat mindset, your pursuit of novelty masks the truth of startup\u00a0viability: if you don't have users, it doesn't matter how novel you are.\u00a0</p><blockquote>\u00e2\u0099\u0096 There are no original ideas. But there are original executions. <br/><br/>\u00e2\u0080\u0094 Luke Wroblewski</blockquote><p>Plus, novelty in the software world only exists in the short-term. Everything you\u00a0do\u00a0will eventually be copied \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and copied better. There is nothing proprietary about bits.</p><h3>... and that frees your mind</h3><p>We just covered the practical benefits to not thinking you're unique. But this\u00a0post is about reducing stress, so we need to cover the abstract benefits as well.</p><p>Consider this: Mentally compress the time horizon of your marketplace's competition into a singular moment that your startup forever\u00a0exists in. In this singularity, every new feature you release is\u00a0instantly copied by everyone else. That's what it means to \"compress the time horizon.\"\u00a0</p><p>In other words, no individual product is\u00a0unique. Consequently,\u00a0the only\u00a0momentum your business experiences is the broadening of the marketplace itself. This benefits both you and your competitors. You're are all in this together; you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re along for a ride and you should be grateful you have a ticket.</p><p>You ultimately wind up working with these companies to increase the overall demand for your collective offering. So you might as well get to know your neighbors and get comfortable seeing them at your doorstep every morning. In the long-run, they're your\u00a0friends, not your foes.</p><p>Once you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve adopted this mindset, you cease to look at the startup hustle as a game of\u00a0one-upping competitors. Instead, you see it as a\u00a0more relaxed process of maintaining your status as a <strong>viable</strong> competitor.\u00a0</p><p>That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a much easier burden to bear. Because, if you are perceptive of what your competitors are doing\u00a0and if you have a competent team working on your product, all you have to do is respond to external demand on a reasonable timeline. You don't have to self-impose artificial time pressure to release novel features.</p><p>And when all your competitors\u00a0are veering toward the same feature set, you can stop worrying\u00a0about quarter-to-quarter fluctuations.</p><p>This is how you approach early-stage startup competition. It not only lessens your anxiety, but it redirects\u00a0your focus into something more productive. This trickles down to everyone in your team.</p><p>But what comes after the short-term? What happens when you're in a cut-throat game of live or die, and your\u00a0funding is drying up? This brings us to our discussion of handling\u00a0<em>mid-stage</em>\u00a0stress.</p><h3>Mid-stage: Focus on retention</h3><p>When you fear competition, you're actually fearing two things in particular: <br/>(1) thinning margins and (2) losing the customers you already have. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s it.\u00a0</p><p>The latter is more\u00a0important. You can't increase margins on customers you don't have. And since the mid-stage of your startup is the point at which you've acquired\u00a0healthy customers, let's discuss\u00a0retention. If we can create a reasonable approach to retention, we can greatly reduce our anxiety of\u00a0losing customers to competition.</p><p>Consider this:\u00a0Once every soul on the planet is either on Facebook or WhatsApp, what's Facebook's\u00a0next focus? Retention, of course.\u00a0Retention is always the final step.\u00a0</p><p>Remember that user growth is not the ultimate goal of a business\u00e2\u0080\u008a\u00e2\u0080\u0094\u00e2\u0080\u008arevenue growth is. When your users stick around, you can experiment with new ways to monetize them.</p><p>So appreciate the importance of retention early in the lifecycle of your startup.</p><h3>Retention reality check</h3><p>It is\u00a0much easier for most startups to improve retention by 5% (e.g. improve customer support and make features more sticky) than it is to increase user adoption by 5% (e.g. spend money on ad buys and spend time on business development).\u00a0</p><p>Just saying \"ad buy\" and \"business development\" probably makes your stomach churn (no pun intended). You know what a risk they can be. Meanwhile, improving <strong>customer support</strong> and making your <strong>product stickier</strong>\u00a0are very straight-forward if you take the time to educate yourself. And there's near-zero risk in trying it.\u00a0</p><p>If you aren't focusing on these two things at the mid-stage, you're mismanaging priorities. For a primer, see\u00a0<a target=\"_blank\" data-rt-link-type=\"external\" href=\"http://a-fwd.com/fr=juliancom06-21&amp;de=juliancom0c-21&amp;uk=juliancom-21&amp;ca=juliancom0d-20&amp;com=juliandotc059-20&amp;asin-com=1449335675\">Lean Analytics</a>, <a target=\"_blank\" data-rt-link-type=\"external\" href=\"http://a-fwd.com/fr=juliancom06-21&amp;de=juliancom0c-21&amp;uk=juliancom-21&amp;ca=juliancom0d-20&amp;com=juliandotc059-20&amp;asin-com=0470610123\">Landing Page Optimization</a>, and <a target=\"_blank\" data-rt-link-type=\"external\" href=\"http://a-fwd.com/fr=juliancom06-21&amp;de=juliancom0c-21&amp;uk=juliancom-21&amp;ca=juliancom0d-20&amp;com=juliandotc059-20&amp;asin-com=0307463745\">Rework</a>.</p><p>Not only is a focus on retention less risky, it's also easier:\u00a0You already have well-defined, observable users who want your product\u00e2\u0080\u008a\u00e2\u0080\u0094so \u00e2\u0080\u008athe onus is on you to simply talk with them and react to their concerns appropriately.</p><p>If I\u00a0were to reduce this advice into a quip, it would be:</p><blockquote>\u00e2\u0099\u0096 Effective entrepreneurs aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t concerned about competition; effective entrepreneurs are concerned about users. They look inward, not outward.</blockquote><h3>The power of retention</h3><p>Retention is more important than growth-at-all-costs because a startup with low churn is a startup with\u00a0brand advocates. Brand advocates are\u00a0lifetime users who\u00a0don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t jump ship when a competitor\u00a0introduces a great feature\u00a0you haven\u00e2\u0080\u0099t implemented yet.</p><p>The greater the percentage of your userbase that consists of brand advocates, the stickier your business is, and the less you have to stress about competition blindsiding you with something novel.</p><p>Because when a competitor does release something\u00a0game-changing, you simply respond with 1) the appropriate engineering resources and 2) open communication with your users about your product roadmap. That\u00e2\u0080\u0099s it.\u00a0There\u00e2\u0080\u0099s no difficult validation to work through; the competitor already validated demand\u00a0for you. You can be the laggard who first sees what others did right and wrong.</p><p>(Have you realized yet that I'm describing Apple's approach to market?)</p><p>If you have a product that users depend on and love, they won\u00e2\u0080\u0099t disappear the instant a competitor one-ups you. Not even 4 weeks later. Not even 3 months later.\u00a0Maybe 6+ months later if you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve utterly failed to respond to your changing market.\u00a0</p><p>But several months is a heck of a lot of leeway. And, if you can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t rise to the occasion, then you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re a slow-moving beast who's either the market\u00e2\u0080\u0099s old guard\u00a0or the stubborn upstart that will succumb to a slow death.</p><p>And that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a critical concept that entrepreneurs fearing competition fail to realize:\u00a0<strong>Startups don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t die by being blindsided. They die\u00a0<em>slow deaths</em>.</strong>\u00a0That should be tremendously comforting, because it means you no longer have to be on high alert when you wake up every morning\u00a0or throughout your weekends and vacations; instead, you just have to ensure you never bury your head in the sand for too long.</p><p>Here's the crux of my argument:\u00a0</p><blockquote>\u00e2\u0099\u0096 Appreciating that you always have work to do but never work you must\u00a0do\u00a0<em>immediately</em>\u00a0affords you the peace of mind needed to enjoy\u00a0life while pursuing the startup hustle.</blockquote><p>We're almost done. What's left is understanding the power of long-term retention.</p><h3>Long term: Focus on brand</h3><p>To focus on your brand is to double\u00a0down on retention. It's taking retention from the tangible (product improvements) to the abstract (brand affinity).</p><p>My favorite quote from <a data-rt-link-type=\"external\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://a-fwd.com/fr=juliancom06-21&amp;de=juliancom0c-21&amp;uk=juliancom-21&amp;ca=juliancom0d-20&amp;com=juliandotc059-20&amp;asin-com=0804139296\">Zero to One</a>\u00a0is,\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009cAll companies inherently have monopolies over their brands.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00a0Essentially, Airbnb will forever be the only \u00e2\u0080\u009cAirbnb.\u00e2\u0080\u009d Slack will forever be the only \"Slack.\"</p><p>Consequently, whatever you decide to have your brand stand for is not something that competing brands can ever take away from you. They can only copy you, and they will likely fail when they try because users become jaded when they see blatant mimicry.</p><p>Building off our discussion on retention, the goal with brand ownership is to hone it until you reach a point where your users would feel miserable if they had to deal with your competitor instead. You want them to feel like they would be replacing a part of their identity:\u00a0They would cease to be \"the guy who constantly wears Nike's\" or \"the girl who tells everyone to use Slack.\"\u00a0</p><p>You need your startup to get to the point where when a competitor adds an amazing feature, your users say, \"Damn, that's insanely cool! But... I'm just going to wait until [startup] offers this. Hopefully it's soon, but if they don't, I'll figure out a compromise.\"</p><p><a data-rt-link-type=\"external\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://eepurl.com/ci0ZR5\">MailChimp</a>\u00a0is an example of a strong brand. From visual identity\u00a0to UX, they\u00e2\u0080\u0099ve mastered what it means to be a singular voice in a marketplace. When strong competitors arise, how many of MailChimp\u00e2\u0080\u0099s users do you think are going to jump ship in the short-term? Almost zero.</p><h3>What you need to remember</h3><blockquote>\u00e2\u0099\u0096 Overcome anxiety by focusing on the most pressing\u00a0aspects of your startup given where it is in\u00a0its lifecycle.</blockquote><ul><li>Your company is not unique. Never allow yourself to think that. You\u00e2\u0080\u0099re simply expanding a marketplace that numerous competitors partake in. Your competition is a living organism that will adapt just like you do; they will always exist in some form.</li><li>Retention is king: Every day, fight to carve out a piece of the market that you can call home. A home is where users love to stay.\u00a0Homes don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t grow fast because families (employees and users) don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t grow fast, but\u00e2\u0080\u008a\u00e2\u0080\u0094\u00e2\u0080\u008acrucially\u00e2\u0080\u008a\u00e2\u0080\u0094\u00e2\u0080\u008ahealthy families never fade away. They persist throughout the ages.</li><li>Brands cement retention: When you're part of someone's identity, it hurts to lose you.</li></ul><p>Appreciate these conclusions then don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t stress yourself over competition\u00a0again.</p><p>If you like my startup writing, subscribe below for more posts just like this. I only email once every couple months.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429996": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 00:06:18", "url": "http://www.lmtonline.com/news/article/Downloads-down-under-lag-ex-Soviet-bloc-12261734.php", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body\">\n        \n\n<div class=\"asset_gallery\">\n\n\n          <span class=\"credit\">\n                                            Photo: Bloomberg Photo By Cole Bennetts.\n                                    </span>\n            \n class=\"gallery-overlay-title-container\">\n                        <p class=\"homeLink\">\n                            <span class=\"icon\"/>\n                        </p>\n                        <p class=\"gallery-overlay-title\">Downloads down under lag ex-Soviet bloc</p>\n                        \n                        \n                        <p class=\"gallery-close-overlay fade hdn-analytics\" data-hdn-analytics=\"gallery_overlay_close|article-gallery-12261734|article-gallery-12261734|0\">\n                            <span class=\"icon action\"/>\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n\n</div><p>Australia's A$49 billion ($38 billion) broadband network was meant to spearhead a digital revolution. Instead, the botched project risks becoming a poster child for government mismanagement.</p>\n<p>The nation's biggest-ever infrastructure investment has turned into a political football, plagued by cost overruns and construction delays.</p>\n<p>With the network years behind the original schedule and only about half finished, Australia has slumped to 50th place on a global ladder of internet speeds, behind Kenya and a string of former Soviet bloc nations. Public frustration with the project is boiling over amid mounting criticism that politics is trumping policy across a host of areas from housing to energy and damaging Australia's economic prospects.</p>\n<p>\"We are really an example of how not to do it,\" said Paul Budde, a Sydney-based former adviser to the United Nations on the social and economic benefits of digital development. \"We have ended up with the worst possible solution.\" </p>\n<p class=\"A300-placeholder collapse\"/><p>The network was conceived as a high-speed platform to increase economic output and beam state-of-the-art health and education services to remote corners of the country. The cost of failure would be stark.</p>\n<p>With a substandard internet backbone, it's tougher for workers to move from major cities and ease pressure on house prices in Sydney and Melbourne. It becomes harder to boost productivity, which the central bank says must improve to avoid a decline in living standards.</p>\n<p>Ian Martin, a telecommunications analyst at New Street Research in Melbourne, says the network will never generate enough revenue to recoup its cost and a writedown of between A$20 billion and A$30 billion -- about half the price of its construction -- is inevitable.</p>\n<p class=\"S300-placeholder collapse\"/><p>\"It will never be a success financially, not in terms of ever getting the money back that's been spent on it,\" said Martin. \"To do it as a nationalized government monopoly was clearly the wrong way to go.\"</p>\n<p>The NBN, as the national broadband network project is known, is a story of state intervention, political ambition and a ballooning bill for taxpayers. It sparked a mixture of excitement and skepticism from the outset. </p>\n<p>In 2009, Kevin Rudd's then-Labor government pledged to weave almost every home and business into a fiber-optic network by 2017 at a cost of A$43 billion, with bundles of glass threads transporting an explosion of digital information.</p>\n<p>From the outset, some questioned the economics of using such technology in one of the world's most-sparsely populated countries. During a visit to Sydney in 2010, Mexican telecommunications billionaire Carlos Slim said the bill was too high for the number of homes the network would connect.</p>\n<p>As the 2013 election loomed, the opposition Liberal-National coalition attacked the project -- with its communications spokesman Malcolm Turnbull the chief critic. He proposed assorted technologies to drive down costs, including using existing copper wires to connect premises to a local hub or node, instead of bringing the more expensive fiber-optic cables all the way to a home.</p>\n<p>Turnbull is now prime minister and the blueprint he pledged to complete for A$29.5 billion has boomeranged to plague him. The bill has soared to between A$47 billion and A$51 billion and the network won't be complete until 2020, according to NBN Co., the state-owned company charged with rolling it out.</p>\n<p>\"The whole thing's been a political football from the start,\" said John Hewson, who led the Liberals in the early 1990s and is now a professor at Canberra's Australian National University. \"The governments are the masters of their own demise on the NBN.\"</p>\n<p>The company is straight-jacketed by the government's insistence on a financial return from the network, even though as a wholesaler NBN Co. can't sell directly to the public and set the final price of a connection.</p>\n<p>NBN Co. says it's aiming to increase annual revenue more than five-fold to A$5.4 billion and be cash flow positive in 2021.</p>\n<p>While retailers have complained they're being charged too much to access the network, NBN Chief Executive Officer Bill Morrow has accused them of a \"land grab\" for customers while minimizing capacity purchases. That's led to peak-hour crunches that have left many users complaining of dropouts when using streaming services such as Netflix.</p>\n<p>As customers switch over to the NBN, frustration with download speeds is boiling over, with complaints to the telecommunications ombudsman more than doubling to 7,512 in the second half of 2016 from a year earlier. NBN argues that complaints rose as more people connected to the network.</p>\n<p>Exasperation at a lack of information, coverage holes, service dropouts and delays at being connected were common among the almost 200 public submissions to a 2017 parliamentary inquiry.</p>\n<p>Among them is Louise Degeling, a retired bookkeeper who lives a little more than an hour's drive north of Sydney on the Central Coast. NBN told Degeling in February 2016 her home was ready to go. She's now been told she might have to wait until 2020.</p>\n<p>\"I jumped up and down, I screamed and yelled and got myself into an awful angst,\" said Degeling. \"Whoever designed this piece of rubbish needs to be held to account.\" She has given up hope of getting on the NBN and is using a wireless broadband device instead.</p>\n<p>To be sure, Morrow says NBN will ultimately be \"on the right side of history.\" As the former Vodafone Group executive released his latest business plan in August, he said the network was more than fast enough for most users and can be upgraded to meet demand for higher speeds.</p>\n<p>\"NBN has hit its operational targets for the last 13 reporting quarters -- we are on track to complete the project as promised in 2020,\" NBN said in an email. The network's mix of technologies has allowed it to start delivering services and recouping taxpayer funds much sooner than would have been possible under a nationwide fiber rollout, NBN said.</p>\n<p>Much of the public debate has centered on the choice of technology, pitting Labor's original fiber-to-the-home proposal versus Turnbull's fiber-to-the-node -- where about 40 percent of homes will rely on copper for the final connection.</p>\n<p>Budde, whose career as a telecommunications consultant spans four decades, says the copper network has such a short life expectancy that the government will have to spend billions of dollars next decade upgrading the wires to fiber. Good money after bad, says Budde, who formerly advised Stephen Conroy when he was Labor communications minister overseeing the NBN.</p>\n<p>Last week, the Australian parliamentary inquiry's report into the NBN called for an independent audit of the project's business case and recommended that fiber be used where possible for the rest of the rollout.</p>\n<p>Fiber internet connections in Asia outnumber any other high-speed alternative more than two to one, while developing nations are also skipping older technologies and opting for fiber, according to a UN agency.</p>\n<p>Australia risks missing the next wave of digital innovation as businesses that need faster web connections head overseas, said Matt Barrie, chief executive officer of Freelancer Ltd., the Sydney-based job-outsourcing company that has about 25 million users worldwide.</p>\n<p>\"They're going to all sprout up and grow in Silicon Valley or across Asia and you literally won't even be able to access the services here, let alone start the companies that provide those services,\" said Barrie.</p>\n\n\n    </div>\n\n        </div></body></html>"}, "15430001": {"score": 3, "comments": ["The people who can&#x27;t fathom a future without theit precious iDevices are doomed to suffer the same fate as Blackberry. It receives emails through an unencrypted, unauthenticated SMTP interface and retransmits them through a remote SMTP server that requires modern features such as encryption (SSL, STARTTLS) and/or authentication (SMTP AUTH). mailproxy is primarily useful for enabling email functionality in legacy software that only supports plain SMTP.</p>\n<h1><a href=\"#requirements\" aria-hidden=\"true\" below).</li>\n<li>Run mailproxy from the command line, e.g. <code>python mailproxy.py</code>.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>By default, mailproxy looks for a <code>config.ini</code> in its own directory.\nIf you have placed your config file elsewhere, you can run mailproxy\nusing <code>python mailproxy.py &lt;config_file_path&gt;</code>.</p>\n<h1><a href=\"#configuration\" aria-hidden=\"true\" I know this being written in C++17 is going to turn a lot of people away, but it was a very interesting exercise. I&#x27;m still debating wether or not I should go through the pain of porting this to C++14, as I estimate it would roughly double the size of the library."], "time": "2017-10-08 20:41:11", "url": "https://github.com/FrancoisChabot/abulafia", "text": "<html><body><div><article class=\"markdown-body entry-content\" itemprop=\"text\"><h1><a href=\"#abulafia\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-abulafia\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Abulafia</h1>\n<p>A standalone C++ parsing framework</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://travis-ci.org/FrancoisChabot/abulafia\"><img src=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/fba79162eedfd615a032299fc3e14a9cf9321c68/68747470733a2f2f7472617669732d63692e6f72672f4672616e636f6973436861626f742f6162756c616669612e7376673f6272616e63683d6d6173746572\" alt=\"build\" data-canonical-src=\"https://travis-ci.org/FrancoisChabot/abulafia.svg?branch=master\"/></a>\n<a href=\"https://godbolt.org/g/PT7WsX\"><img src=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/60b5a6f52814f415bd7a74f09c3b17e7f0ca2998/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f62616467652f6f6e2d676f64626f6c742d3337363636362e737667\" alt=\"on-godbolt\" data-canonical-src=\"https://img.shields.io/badge/on-godbolt-376666.svg\"/></a></p>\n<p>Abulafia is a C++ expression templates library that generates parsers. The idea is to let programs contain ABNF-like grammars embedded directly within the code. It's heavily inspired by Boost::spirit::QI, but differs fundamentally from it in a number of respects.</p>\n<p><strong>Quick links</strong></p>\n\n<p><strong>Warning</strong></p>\n<p>Abulafia is still in early development. While many features work as intended, there are still a LOT of work to be done before it can\nbe considered usable in a real environment.</p>\n<p>At the moment, validating parsers (parsers with <code>Nil</code> as the destination type) should work fine accross the board. Feel free to report any and all bugs you encounter related to them.</p>\n<p>Parsing to a value now works in many scenarios, but there are known holes (when dealing with collections of collections for example). These can be worked around using semantic actions in general, but we still want to improve the native handling.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#requirements\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-requirements\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Requirements</h2>\n<p>Abulafia currently requires a C++17 compiler. The level of C++17 compatibility required will be kept at the lowest bar set by the current release of the following compilers:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Microsoft VC++ (2017, update 3) <strong>Currently broken due to an ICE that will be resolved in the next release.</strong></li>\n<li>Clang (5.0.0)</li>\n<li>GCC (7.2)</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Not only will abulafia compile successfully on these compilers, but any code using abulafia's API will as well. This is why, for example, there are no template deduction guides, even if they would make for a nicer interface when dealing with character sets.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#installation\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-installation\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Installation</h2>\n<p>Abulafia is a headers-only library. In order to use it, you just have to make the contents of the <code>include</code> directory available to your compiler. This can be done by either copying its contents to your project's source tree, or setting your compiler's include directories.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#features\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-features\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Features</h2>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>No external dependencies</strong>: The only requirement is a valid C++ compiler.</li>\n<li><strong>Header-based</strong>: There is no building or linking involved, just use the headers in your project.</li>\n<li><strong>Type safety</strong>: Abulafia goes to a lot of trouble to ensure its parsers are valid at compile-time. If your code compiles, the parsers are valid.</li>\n<li><strong>Performance</strong>: Parsers are heavily optimized during compilation, resulting in parsing code that's often faster than hand-written parsers.</li>\n<li><strong>Resumable parsers</strong>: Parsing can be done gradually, as data becomes available. There is no need to accumulate the full source before beginning parsing.</li>\n<li><strong>Parser library</strong>: Abulafia comes with a full library of core parsers that can be composed using overloaded operators.</li>\n<li><strong>Custom parsers</strong>: In the unlikely event that the provided parsers cannot fullfill a project's needs, extending the library with new parsers is fairly straightforward.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#usage\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-usage\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Usage</h2>\n<p>With abulafia, you can write surprisingly complex parsers in a few, very readable, lines of code:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight highlight-source-c++\"><pre>#<span class=\"pl-k\">include</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span>abulafia/abulafia.h<span class=\"pl-pds\">\"</span></span>\n\n#<span class=\"pl-k\">include</span> <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">&lt;</span>iostream<span class=\"pl-pds\">&gt;</span></span>\n\n<span class=\"pl-k\">int</span> <span class=\"pl-en\">main</span>() {\n  <span class=\"pl-c\"><span class=\"pl-c\">//</span> opening bracket, followed by a comma-delimited list of integers, followed by a closing bracket.</span>\n  <span class=\"pl-k\">auto</span> with_brackets = <span class=\"pl-s\"><span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span>[<span class=\"pl-pds\">'</span></span> &gt;&gt; Central Idea</h2>\n<p>Logistic regressions, decision trees, SVMs, neural networks etc have a set of structural choices that one must make before actually fitting the model parameters. For example, within the logistic regression family, you can build separate models using either L1 or L2 regularization penalties. Within the decision tree family, you can have different models with different structural choices such as the depth of the tree, pruning thresholds, or even the splitting criteria. These structural choices are called hyperparameters.</p>\n<p>Taditionally, for a datascientist, building a classification model is an iterative process of coming up with the model, tweak the hyperparameters and test it using test data. If the results are not matching the expectations, this could potentially lead to another iteration of tweaking the model and evaluating it.\nIn this project, am proposing a solution to ease datascientist's iteration turn-around time and improve their efficiency.</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#2-proposal\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-2-proposal\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>2. Proposal:</h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Load your trained model using Spark-ML</li>\n<li>Have a dashboard where the hyperparameters like regularization params, thresholds etc are exposed for user to tweak</li>\n<li>Quickly test the model with the new params on test dataset</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#3-ml-dashboard-inputsoutputs-and-demo\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-3-ml-dashboard-inputsoutputs-and-demo\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>3. ML Dashboard Inputs/Outputs and Demo:</h2>\n<h3><a href=\"#31-dashboard-demo\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-31-dashboard-demo\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>3.1 Dashboard Demo:</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22542670/31316609-3e301304-ac4e-11e7-9019-196ca0c95f5a.gif\" target=\"_blank\"><img src=\"https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22542670/31316609-3e301304-ac4e-11e7-9019-196ca0c95f5a.gif\" alt=\"out\"/></a></p>\n<h3><a href=\"#32-dashboard-inputs\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-32-dashboard-inputs\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>3.2 Dashboard Inputs:</h3>\n<p><strong>Model used for testing in this project:</strong>\nFor the purpose of demo, I've implemented a model using Spark 2.1 ML, to classify news documents into Science or NonScience category. I've done this using K-Fold CrossValidation on a ML Pipeline. Further details on the trained model can be found <a href=\"https://github.com/spoddutur/spark-ml-dashboard/blob/master/README2.md\">here</a>.</p>\n<p><strong>Dashboard Inputs submitted by user:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n<p>Model params: As you can see in the above demo, I have exposed following four parameters of this model for user to play and test:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>LinearRegression - Threshold</li>\n<li>LinearRegression - RegularizationParam</li>\n<li>LinearRegression - Max Iterations</li>\n<li>HashingTF - Number of Features</li>\n</ol>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>Test Data to evaluate: Folder containing the documents to test</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Initial values of the model params displayed in the dashboard:</strong> These params are initialised with their respective default values that the model was trained to have.</p>\n<p><strong>Dashboard Output:</strong>\nTable with 2 columns: DocumentName and ClassificationResult (whether its a science document or not)</p>\n<h2><a href=\"#4-working-with-the-dashboard\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-4-working-with-the-dashboard\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>4. India, USA and World's profile info:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><code>CountryCode IN ('USA', 'WLD', 'IND')</code></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Query total population, mortality rate and population growth information in India, USA and World countries:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><code>CountryCode IN ('USA', 'WLD', 'IND') AND SeriesCode IN ('SP.POP.TOTL', 'SH.DYN.MORT', 'SP.POP.GROW')</code></li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"#cmd-line-args\" Default: $sparkMasterDef\n      -n, --name &lt;name&gt;                            A name of your application. Default: $sparkAppNameDef\n      -p, --akkaHttpPort &lt;portnumber&gt;              Port where akka-http is binded. Default: $akkaHttpPortDef\n\n    Configured one route:\n    <span class=\"pl-v\">1.</span> http://host:port/index.html - takes user to knowledge browser page</pre></div>\n<h2><a href=\"#structure-of-the-project\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"anchor\" id=\"user-content-structure-of-the-project\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"octicon octicon-link\" version=\"1.1\" viewbox=\"0 0 16 16\"><path fill-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z\"/></svg></a>Structure of the project:</h2>\n<ul>\n<li><b>src/main/scala/com/spoddutur/MainApp.scala:</b> The main class from where application execution begins</li>\n<li><b>data/countriesProfile.csv</b> sample data used to query</li>\n<li><b>src/main/resources/application.conf</b>: tweak command line args directly here before building the jar and run spark-submit</li>\n<li><b>src/main/scala/com/spoddutur/web/WebServer.scala</b>: Starts akka-http webserver at the mentioned host and port. Also, registers the routes (index.html).</li>\n<li><b>src/main/scala/com/spoddutur/web/Router.scala:</b>: This is where we can create and register more routes apart from index.html</li>\n</ul>\n<h3><a </footer></div>\n\n        </div>\n<p>White House officials have homed in on President Donald Trump\u2019s Washington transition headquarters as a likely location where chief of staff John Kelly's personal cellphone could have been compromised in late 2016, two<b> </b>U.S. officials familiar with the matter said.</p> \n<p>Kelly, who first served as Trump\u2019s secretary of homeland security, reported the phone had stopped working properly in December after he entered the transition office space, which was made available by the General Services Administration, the officials said. Kelly said it functioned well before that time.</p><p class=\"story-continued\">Story Continued Below</p>\n\n  <p>Although many of Trump\u2019s high-profile meetings with lawmakers and potential Cabinet members before his inauguration occurred in New York at Trump Tower, much of his transition staff worked out of the office space about three blocks from the White House.</p> \n<p>Officials have tried to determine whether Kelly signed onto an insecure wireless network there or whether a hacker, foreign government or some other outside force could have accessed the phone there. </p> \n<p>\"That's where it seems to have started,\" one White House official with knowledge of the review said. The official said the transition building was only one possible site for the breach. Officials have not ruled out other possibilities, such as foreign trips before Kelly joined the administration, though they have not seen evidence for that.</p> \n<p>The White House declined to comment.</p> \n<p>Pinpointing how Kelly\u2019s phone was compromised could help determine who might have been behind the breach or whether other staffers could have been affected. There has been no indication at this point that any other staffers\u2019 devices were compromised, and it is not clear what data, if any, was accessed on Kelly\u2019s personal phone.</p><aside class=\"story-related cl-l db \">\n        <aside class=\"content-group inline-module-playbook\">\n        <section class=\"speedbump layout-bi\">\n        <div class=\"speedbump-item pos-alpha\">\n            <div class=\"spotlight spotlight--flex\">\n                <div class=\"summary link-alt fx1\">\n                    <h2>The most reliable politics newsletter.</h2>\n                                <p>Sign up for POLITICO Playbook and get the latest news, every morning \u2014 in your inbox.</p>\n                    </div>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"speedbump-item pos-beta\">\n            <div class=\"js-tealium-newsletter\" data-subscription-module=\"newsletter_inline_standard_Playbook - POLITICO\">\n                <div class=\"dari-frame dari-frame-loaded\" name=\"inline-module-playbook-full-0000014f-1646-d88f-a1cf-5f46b7bd0000\" data-insertion-mode=\"replace\" data-extra-form-data=\"_frame.path=5c388a2e37218b65f1db610df3d5c42a&amp;_frame.name=inline-module-playbook-full-0000014f-1646-d88f-a1cf-5f46b7bd0000\">\n                            <p class=\"legal-disclaimer\">By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. The White House recently added more secure lockers to the building for storing such devices, though the White House has said it was not related to the incident with Kelly\u2019s phone.</p> \n<p>POLITICO <a href=\"http://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/05/john-kelly-cell-phone-compromised-243514\" target=\"_blank\">reported</a> Thursday that White House technical support staff determined late this summer that Kelly's personal cellphone had been compromised and that he turned it in to the White House. He no longer has possession of the device. </p> \n<p>It remains unclear why Kelly hung onto his personal phone from December, when he believed it stopped working well, until August. Staffers in the White House questioned Department of Homeland Security officials after Kelly turned in the phone about why it took so long for the problem to be caught, two U.S. government officials said, though the conversation was not described as adversarial. </p> \n<p>Many aides have continued to use personal phones despite the warnings, and they have chafed at previous attempts to quell their use. The National Security Agency <a href=\"http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/29/white-house-private-email-nsa-warning-243324\" target=\"_blank\">warned</a> White House staffers during the transition not to use personal devices or email. One fear is that the cameras or microphones on personal cellphones could be turned on without the owner\u2019s knowledge, turning them into clandestine listening devices.</p>\n<p>Numerous White House aides also have used personal email for government business. Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, both of whom are top advisers in addition to being members of the president\u2019s close family, <a href=\"http://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/02/jared-kushner-email-account-white-house-243389\" target=\"_blank\">have used private email addresses</a> that they set up during the transition, including a shared account they used for scheduling.<br/></p>\n\n<div class=\"\"><aside class=\"content-group\">&#13;\n    <div class=\"story-supplement\">&#13;\n        <div class=\"spotlight\"> &#13;\n            <div class=\"summary fs-i\">&#13;\n                <p>Missing out on the latest scoops? Brad Parscale tells Lesley Stahl how he fine-tuned political ads posted on Facebook to directly reach voters with the exact messages they cared most about \u2013 infrastructure key among them -- and had handpicked Republican Facebook employees to guide him. Stahl's report will be broadcast on 60 Minutes Sunday, Oct. 8 at 7 p.m. ET/PT.\u00a0 \u00a0</p><figure class=\"image pull-none image-x-large \" data-ads=\"{&quot;extraWordCount&quot;:50}\"><span class=\"img \"><img src=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/06/d1034cd7-a5ae-47ac-b2be-d3f5d472403d/resize/770x/91ec9c29c304a32342d9a28c7bc69e3c/parscaleint.jpg#\" alt=\"parscaleint.jpg \" srcset=\"https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/10/06/d1034cd7-a5ae-47ac-b2be-d3f5d472403d/resize/770x/91ec9c29c304a32342d9a28c7bc69e3c/parscaleint.jpg 1x\"/></span><figcaption><p class=\"credit\">\n                                            CBS News\n                                        </p></figcaption></figure><p>\"Twitter is how [Trump] talked to the people, Facebook was going to be how he won,\" Parscale tells Stahl.\u00a0 Parscale says he used the majority of his digital ad budget on Facebook ads and explained how efficient they could be, particularly in reaching the rural vote.\u00a0 \"So now Facebook lets you get to\u202615 people in the Florida Panhandle that I would never buy a TV commercial for,\" says Parscale.\u00a0 And people anywhere could be targeted with the messages they cared about. \"Infrastructure\u2026so I started making ads that showed the bridge crumbling\u2026that's micro targeting\u2026I can find the 1,500 people in one town that care about infrastructure. Now, that might be a voter that normally votes Democrat,\" he says. Parscale says the campaign would average 50-60,000 different ad versions every day, some days peaking at 100,000 separate iterations \u2013 changing design, colors, backgrounds and words \u2013 all in an effort to refine ads and engage users.</p><p>Parscale received help utilizing Facebook's technology from Facebook employees provided by the company who showed up for work to his office multiple days a week. He says they had to be partisan and he questioned them to make sure.\u00a0 \"I wanted people who supported Donald Trump.\"\u00a0 Parscale calls these Facebook employees \"embeds\" who could teach him every aspect of the technology. \"I want to know everything you would tell Hillary's campaign plus some,\" he says he told them.</p><p>Both campaigns used Facebook's advertising technology extensively to reach voters, but Parscale says the Clinton campaign didn't go as far as using \"embeds.\" \"I had heard that they did not accept any of [Facebook's] offers.\"</p><p>The conservative Parscale sees an irony in all this. \"These social platforms are all invented by very liberal people on the West and East Coast.\u00a0 And we figure out how to use it to push conservative values. I don't think they thought that would ever happen,\" says Parscale.</p></div>\n    </div>\n\n\t\n    \n\n            <p class=\"copyright\">\n                                        \u00a9 2017 CBS Interactive Inc. This is a feature of\nphp's <a href=\"http://php.net/manual/de/function.parse-ini-file.php\">parse<em>ini</em>file</a>.</p>\n<p>So something like this in e.g. an <code>/etc/php.d/environment.ini</code>:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"ini language-ini\" data-lang=\"ini\"><span class=\"na\">memory_limit</span><span class=\"o\">=</span><span class=\"s\">${PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT}</span>\n</code></pre></div>\n<p>is possible. If you set <code>PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT</code> to <code>2048M</code> in your docker-compose's <code>environment</code> or any of those <code>env_file</code>s,\nit will work.</p>\n<h2><code>fastcgi_param</code> in nginx.conf</h2>\n<p>Even if you might not want to modify your php image, you will usually have a custom nginx.conf in your nginx image.</p>\n<p>So whenever you pass your php requests to a fastcgi handler/upstream, you can use:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"text language-text\" data-lang=\"text\">fastcgi_param PHP_VALUE \"memory_limit=2G\\nsession.save_handler=memcache\";\nfastcgi_param PHP_ADMIN_VALUE \"open_basedir=off\";\n</code></pre></div>\n<p>in nginx\u00e2\u0080\u0098s <code>conf</code>-files. Remember that setting this once for a php fastcgi process will keep the config also for the\nnext requests. Thus use it never or always for the same php fpm pool.</p>\n<p>Using environment variables is not built-in nginx. But if you have lua enabled in nginx, you can retrieve a environment\nvariable like this somewhere before nginx\u00e2\u0080\u0098s <code>http</code>:</p>\n\n<p>and the following in a <code>location</code>/<code>server</code>:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"text language-text\" data-lang=\"text\">set_by_lua $PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT 'return os.getenv(\"PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT\")';\nfastcgi_param php_value \"memory_limit=$PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT\u00e2\u0080\u009c;\n</code></pre></div>\n<h2>.htaccess in apache</h2>\n<p>You can also override the php value in a <code>.htaccess</code> if you are using apache as webserver:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"text language-text\" data-lang=\"text\">php_value memory_limit 256M\n</code></pre></div>\n<p>If you use environment variables here:</p>\n<div class=\"highlight\"><pre><code class=\"text language-text\" data-lang=\"text\">php_value memory_limit %{ENV:PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT}\n</code></pre></div>\n<p>you can use dockers environment variables again to configure the deployment on demand.</p>\n<h2>.user.ini in fastcgi</h2>\n<p>The fastcgi version of php supports <code>.user.ini</code> files in any of the parent directories. So a file like:</p>\n\n<p>will work, too. I spend a week testing the <a href=\"http://releases.ubuntu.com/17.10/\" target=\"_blank\">Beta 2</a> and in this \u201clast minute\u201d review, I document some of the less obvious features/gotchas of Ubuntu 17.10. I also share with you my experience and provide a few workarounds for some problems that I spotted. For a more conventional review, have a look at OMGUbuntu\u2019s excellent <a href=\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2017/09/ubuntu-17-10-beta-2-download\" target=\"_blank\">blogpost</a>.</p>\n<h1>1. Bye bye Unity, Hello Gnome</h1>\n<p><img src=\"http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ubuntu-17.10.jpg\" alt=\"\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-846\" srcset=\"http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ubuntu-17.10.jpg 750w, http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/ubuntu-17.10-300x169.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\"/>For those of you who don\u2019t know me, I\u2019m a creature of habit and an Ubuntu fan-boy, so when Canonical announced that they are <a href=\"https://insights.ubuntu.com/2017/04/05/growing-ubuntu-for-cloud-and-iot-rather-than-phone-and-convergence/\" target=\"_blank\">ditching Unity</a> I was not particularly happy. Nevertheless, even though Unity had some great features and it was particularly appealing to me, I find it a bit pointless to try and go against the flow of the river (manually installing Unity 7, using one of the community forks etc). What it\u2019s done is done and from my point of view one should try to adjust to the new reality or choose a different distro.</p>\n<p>On the positive side, Unity always shipped with a very large number of Gnome programs so most of the applications you used are still available by default. Moreover there are lots of interesting Gnome Extensions that can help you configure your desktop to be more unity-like. For instance the <a href=\"https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/307/dash-to-dock/\" target=\"_blank\">Dash to Dock</a> extension will allow you to customize the Dash (location, launcher button, styles etc) and offers significantly more options than the default forked extension offered by Ubuntu. For those of you who are fond of the Indicator Applets, Canonical <a href=\"https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/615/appindicator-support/\" target=\"_blank\">forked</a> the <a href=\"https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1031/topicons/\" target=\"_blank\">Top Icons Plus</a> extension (which is now <a href=\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2017/09/top-icons-plus-development-paused\" target=\"_blank\">discontinued</a>). For me the official Indicator extension was enough and covered most of the functionalities that I want but your mileage may vary. Another useful extension is the <a href=\"https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1198/start-overlay-in-application-view/\" target=\"_blank\">Stay Overlay in Application View</a> which is a not very intuitive way of saying that you will get the Application View (Gnome\u2019s equivalent of Unity Dash) if you press the Windows/Super button. These 3 plugins were enough for me to reproduce the bare minimum of Unity and make Gnome more user-friendly. For those of you who liked the Global Application Menu/HUD you can use an <a href=\"https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1250/gnome-global-application-menu/\" target=\"_blank\">unofficial plugin</a>; I personally have not tested it.</p>\n<h1>2. A very large number of Applications crash on Wayland</h1>\n<p>Wayland is the default session for Ubuntu 17.10 and replaces Xorg (even though Xorg is still available). Unfortunately at the time of writing the article, a serious bug remained unresolved which led to the crashing of several applications. The <a href=\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/synaptic/+bug/1712089\" target=\"_blank\">problem</a> seems to affect pkexec\u2019ed, su-to-root and gksu/gksudo applications and according to the bug reports popular programs such as synaptic, backintime, gui-ufw and bleachbit do not work. Several workarounds have been proposed such as running <code>xhost +si:localuser:root</code> and then <code>sudo synaptic</code> or switching to Xorg until this is patched. Not the end of the world but definitely annoying.</p>\n<h1>3. Some programs behave differently</h1>\n<p>Even though Unity packed a large number of Gnome applications, most of them were seriously modified. As a result on Ubuntu 17.10 you should expect to find some noticeable differences. For example the Archive Manager does not support exports by drag and drop (maybe it\u2019s a bug?), the save dialog of gedit changed, Nautilus\u2019 navigation and right click menus are different etc. Finally some programs such as the system-config-lvm are not yet available on the latest version.</p>\n<h1>4. S3 Backups hidden on Deja Dup</h1>\n<p><img src=\"http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/deja-dup-s3-770x367.png\" alt=\"\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-851\" srcset=\"http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/deja-dup-s3-770x367.png 770w, http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/deja-dup-s3-300x143.png 300w, http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/deja-dup-s3-768x366.png 768w, http://blog.datumbox.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/deja-dup-s3.png 924w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 770px) 100vw, 770px\"/><br/>\nThe default Backup application of Unity had a very cool feature. By installing a simple plugin, one could take <a href=\"http://mooooo.ooo/deja-dup-s3-backups/\" target=\"_blank\">automated backups on Amazon S3</a>. Deja Dup supports also encryption so this yielded a cost effective and secure solution. Unfortunately the developers of the application decided to <a href=\"https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/DejaDup/Clouds\" target=\"_blank\">Deprecate several storage services</a>, among them Amazon S3. They provide a series of reasons of why they did it, but for me this is a very poor choice. One of their core arguments is that Google Drive is more user-friendly than Amazon S3 for the casual users. Fair enough but I thought that Linux was all about the freedom of customization and choice. Moreover Linux typically attracts a large number of power-users comparing to other conventional operating systems. Removing Amazon S3, a solid cloud storage option, makes Ubuntu poorer not richer in terms of options and usefulness.</p>\n<p>Thankfully for now the plugins are still supported but they are hidden. So if you have setup the required libraries (check the first linked article) and run the following command on terminal <code>gsettings set org.gnome.DejaDup backend 's3'</code> you should still be able to take backups on S3.</p>\n<h1>5. How to disable Keyboard\u2019s Sleep/Hibernate shortcut</h1>\n<p>My laptop manufacturer mapped special operations such as Increasing/decreasing the lighting of the screen and the sound volume on the F1-12 buttons. Thankfully to activate them you need to press them along with the \u201cFn\u201d button. So far so good. Unfortunately, they also had the amazing idea of placing the sleep button next to the sound volume button, which leads to accidents and drives me crazy. On Unity it was relatively straight forward to disable it, either via gui (dconf editor) or via the console using the following commands:</p>\n<pre class=\"brush: bash; title: ; notranslate\" title=\"\">&#13;\ngsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power button-suspend 'nothing'&#13;\ngsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power button-sleep 'nothing'&#13;\ngsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power button-hibernate 'nothing'&#13;\n</pre>\n<p>Unfortunately on Gnome these commands don\u2019t work for my laptop. Thankfully it\u2019s Linux, you can customize everything! So after searching for an hour and reading random forum messages and blogposts, I found the following working solution:</p>\n<pre class=\"brush: bash; title: ; notranslate\" title=\"\">&#13;\nxmodmap -e 'keycode 213 = NoSymbol' #XF86Suspend&#13;\nxmodmap -e 'keycode 150 = NoSymbol' #XF86Sleep&#13;\n</pre>\n<h1>Final thoughts</h1>\n<p>Ubuntu 17.10 looks good and with some customization you can make it more usable. There are some gotchas/bugs/problems but hopefully they will all be addressed before the 18.04 LTS. We all need to keep in mind that this is not a LTS version and Canonical tries to iron out the transition from Unity to Gnome. Having said that, it\u2019s a no-brainer that you should not install 17.10 on a production machine. It\u2019s worth trying it out on your secondary PC or on a Virtual Machine; hopefully this will smooth your transition.</p>\n<p>For me testing Ubuntu 17.10 was a good opportunity to move all of my installation scripts from ugly bash scripts to <a href=\"https://www.ansible.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Ansible</a>. For those of you who have not used Ansible, it\u2019s an open-source free automation engine which simplifies provisioning, configuration and management of servers. You write scripts in YAML and Python, which beats coding in Bash any day. During the process I ended up writing an <a href=\"https://galaxy.ansible.com/datumbox/jprofiler/\" target=\"_blank\">Ansible role for installing Jprofiler</a> since I could not find any existing solution on Ansible Galaxy. I ended up open-sourcing it so if you use JProfiler in your development give it a try. \ud83d\ude42</p>\n<div class=\"authorsure-author-box\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/0d9cf005f5d9fbbe42b6723e723a7f76?s=90&amp;r=g\" srcset=\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/0d9cf005f5d9fbbe42b6723e723a7f76?s=180&amp;r=g 2x\" class=\"avatar avatar-90 photo\"/><p>My name is Vasilis Vryniotis.
