"2017-10-08 22:29:46", "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/06/obituaries/vladimir-voevodsky-revolutionary-mathematician-dies-at-51.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"story-body story-body-2\">\n        <p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"175\" data-total-count=\"1300\" id=\"story-continues-2\">\u201cIf you want to ask how profound his work is, that\u2019s how profound it is,\u201d Dr. Hales said. \u201cIt changes the very meaning of what the equals sign means in mathematics.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"269\" data-total-count=\"1569\">He added: \u201cHis ideas gave a new way for all mathematicians to do what they do, a new foundation. The foundations of math are like a constitutional document that spells out the governing rules all mathematicians agree to play by. He has given us a new constitution.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"240\" data-total-count=\"1809\">Vladimir Voevodsky was born in Moscow on June 4, 1966. His father, Alexander, directed a laboratory in experimental physics at the Russian Academy of Sciences; his mother, Tatyana Voevodskaya, was a chemistry professor at Moscow University.</p><figure id=\"math-promotron\" class=\"interactive interactive-embedded  limit-small layout-sub-medium\">\n    \n    \n    <figcaption class=\"interactive-caption\">\n            <h2 class=\"interactive-headline\">\n            More Reporting on Mathematics        </h2>\n            </figcaption>\n\n        \n    \n    <p class=\"footer\">\n\n        \n        \n        \n    </p>\n</figure>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"299\" data-total-count=\"2108\">Vladimir was kicked out of high school three times, once for disagreeing with his teacher\u2019s assertion that Dostoyevsky, who died in 1881, was pro-Communist. He was also kicked out of Moscow University after failing academically, having stopped attending classes that he considered a waste of time.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"300\" data-total-count=\"2408\">He continued to study mathematics independently, however, and with the mathematician Mikhail Kapranov he published several papers so impressive that he was invited to enroll at Harvard as a graduate student, despite never having applied for admission there and holding no formal undergraduate degree.</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"372\" data-total-count=\"2780\" id=\"story-continues-3\">Once enrolled he again failed to attend lectures \u2014 but his body of research was so astonishing, colleagues said, that no one cared. He graduated in 1992 and remained at Harvard to do a fellowship. After spending several years as a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, he became a professor there in 2002 and remained there for the rest of his career.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"452\" data-total-count=\"3232\">Dr. Voevodsky was awarded the Fields Medal for his discovery of an elusive mathematical object whose existence had been predicted decades earlier. The object provides a sort of mathematical wormhole that allows powerful theoretical tools in one field of mathematics to be pulled through and used in another. He then used those tools to crack a three-decade-old puzzle, giving birth to an entirely new area of mathematics called motivic homotopy theory.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"225\" data-total-count=\"3457\">Soon afterward, however, he abandoned that branch of mathematics for what was perhaps a more quixotic quest, to find the answer to a fundamental question: How do mathematicians know that something they prove is actually true?</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"184\" data-total-count=\"3641\">This question became urgent for him as mathematicians were discovering \u2014 sometimes decades after publication \u2014 that proof after proof, including one of his own, had critical flaws.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"223\" data-total-count=\"3864\">Mathematical arguments had gotten so complicated, he realized, that other mathematicians rarely checked them in detail. And his stellar reputation only made the problem worse: Everyone assumed that his proofs must be right.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"412\" data-total-count=\"4276\">Dr. Voevodsky realized that human brains could not keep up with the ever-increasing complexity of mathematics. Computers were the only solution. So he embarked on an enormous project to create proof-checking software so powerful and convenient that mathematicians could someday use it as part of their ordinary work and create a <a href=\"https://github.com/UniMath/UniMath\">library</a> of rock-solid mathematical knowledge that anyone in the world could access.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"238\" data-total-count=\"4514\">Computer scientists had worked on the problem for decades, but it was territory only a few mathematicians had ever ventured into. \u201cAmong mathematicians, computer proof verification was almost a forbidden subject,\u201d Dr. Voevodsky <a href=\"https://www.ias.edu/ideas/2014/voevodsky-origins\">wrote</a>.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"391\" data-total-count=\"4905\">The problem was that these systems were extraordinarily cumbersome. Checking a single theorem could require a decade of work, because the computer essentially had to be taught all of the mathematics a proof was built on, in agonizing, inhuman detail. Ordinary mathematicians intent on expanding the borders of the field could not possibly devote that kind of effort to checking their proofs.</p>\n<p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"65\" data-total-count=\"4970\" id=\"story-continues-4\">Somehow, computers and humans needed to be taught to think alike.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"361\" data-total-count=\"5331\">Dr. Voevodsky developed a stunningly bold plan for how to do so: He reformulated mathematics from its very foundation, giving it a new \u201cconstitution,\u201d as Dr. Hales put it. Mathematics so reformulated would be far friendlier to computers and allow mathematicians to talk to computers in a language that was much closer to how mathematicians ordinarily think.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"147\" data-total-count=\"5478\">Today, Dr. Voevodsky declared in 2014, \u201ccomputer verification of proofs, and of mathematical reasoning in general, looks completely practical.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"369\" data-total-count=\"5847\">Further, Dr. Voevodsky integrated the computer into the process of doing his own research, describing it as a bit like a video game. \u201cYou tell the computer, \u2018Try this,\u2019 and it tries it, and it gives you back the result of its actions,\u201d he said in an <a href=\"https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/voevodskye28099s-mathematical-revolution/\">interview</a> with Scientific American in 2013. \u201cSometimes it\u2019s unexpected what comes out of it. It\u2019s fun.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"351\" data-total-count=\"6198\">Dr. Voevodsky was at the center of an informal but enormous effort to fulfill his vision, having inspired dozens of researchers to join it. \u201cHe\u2019s been our leader, even though he lets everybody do whatever they want,\u201d said Robert Harper of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. \u201cHe\u2019s this inspirational and spiritual leader by example.\u201d</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"201\" data-total-count=\"6399\">Dr. Voevodsky was especially attentive to young mathematicians. \u201cBy being accommodating, encouraging, listening to people, he generated enormous interest,\u201d Dr. Harper said in a telephone interview.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"105\" data-total-count=\"6504\">He also nurtured deep interests in many other fields, including biology, politics and <a href=\"https://vividha.livejournal.com/photo/\">nature photography</a>.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"110\" data-total-count=\"6614\">Besides Dr. Shalaby, he is survived by their two daughters, Diana Yasmine Voevodsky and Natalia Dalia Shalaby.</p><p class=\"story-body-text story-content\" data-para-count=\"227\" data-total-count=\"6841\">Chris Kapulkin, another colleague, at the University of Western Ontario, said of Dr. Voevodsky in an interview, \u201cHis contributions are so fundamental that it\u2019s impossible to imagine how things were thought of before him.\u201d</p><div id=\"addenda\" class=\"addenda\">\n    <div class=\"story-addendum story-content theme-correction\">\n        <strong> Correction: October 9, 2017 </strong> \n        <p>An earlier version of this obituary referred imprecisely to Dr. Voevodsky\u2019s tenure at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. He was named a professor there in 2002, but he had become a member several years earlier; it was not the case that he \u201cmoved to\u201d the Institute in 2002.</p>    </div>\n</div>\n<footer "2017-10-08 20:25:03", "url": "https://www.inc.com/marcel-schwantes/richard-branson-reveals-3-of-his-own-brilliant-habits-for-successful-leadership.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body inc_editable\" data-editable=\"true\" data-editor-class=\"InlineText\" data-label=\"Body\" data-content-type=\"article\" data-content-id=\"187441\" data-fieldname=\"inc_clean_text\"><p><a href=\"http://inc.com/marcel-schwantes/richard-branson-and-tim-cook-get-up-every-day-at-t.html\">Sir Richard Branson</a> has modeled an unconventional leadership approach that has attracted a cult-like following, as evidenced by some of his best-sellers -- <em><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Like-Virgin-Secrets-Business-2012-09-25/dp/B01NBOL3AV/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8\">Like a Virgin: Secrets They Won't Teach You at Business School</a></em> and, of course, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Screw-Business-As-Usual-Capitalism/dp/0143130544/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8\"><em>Screw Business As Usual</em></a>.</p>\n<p>While <a href=\"http://inc.com/marcel-schwantes/the-work-life-balance-rituals-that-help-richard-br.html\">his most valuable lessons</a> are too numerous to list for one article, three really stand out for me (cited below). They have to do with understanding the human experience at work -- that <a href=\"http://inc.com/marcel-schwantes/11-habits-of-remarkably-likable-bosses.html\">there are certain traits people are innately wired to receive by their leaders</a> in order to feel valued as workers and human beings.</p>\n<p>Richard Branson understands that when his employees' needs are met on a human level, it ultimately impacts his businesses to a greater degree.</p>\n<p>He should know. These are <em>his</em> principles for success, and they've obviously worked for him. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.forbes.com/profile/richard-branson/\">According to <em>Forbes</em></a>, he is now worth over 5 billion US dollars.</p>\n<h2>1. Communicate with your ears.</h2>\n<p>How often we think of communication as \"telling more,\" giving more directions, and sharing more of our point of view when all our most valued employees want is to be heard.</p>\n<p>For Branson, the best of leaders instinctively understand that communication is a two-way street. Here's Branson:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\"Being a good listener is absolutely critical to being a good leader; you have to listen to the people on the front line. That's a very Virgin trait. Listening enables us to learn from each other, from the marketplace, and from the mistake that must be made in order to get anywhere that is original and disruptive.</p>\n<p>An exceptional company is the one that gets all the little details right. And the people out on the front line, they know when things are not going right, and they know when things need to be improved. And if you listen to them, you can soon improve all those niggly things which turn an average company into an exceptional company,\"</p></blockquote>\n<h2>2. Accept that failure is the foundation for success.</h2>\n<p>At Virgin, they encourage and even celebrate failure. There's an underlying theme there that, without trying something new and failing, it's virtually impossible to innovate and grow.</p>\n<p>And Branson has certainly failed over the years. Remember <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/oct/06/sir-richard-branson-failures-vigin-cola-brides\">Virgin Cola</a>? Or even Virgin Brides (with Branson <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/fancy-dress-is-not-just-for-halloween\">donning a wedding gown for publicity</a>?) How about <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/richard-branson-fails-virgin-companies-that-went-bust-2012-4#branson-tried-to-take-on-apple--he-lost-11\">Virgin Pulse and Virgin Digital</a> -- which couldn't stand up to Apple's iPod and iTunes? Branson has horrifically failed with the best of them.</p>\n<p>Here's Branson on failing for success:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\"We've never been 100% sure that any of the businesses we've started at Virgin were going to be successful. But over 45 years, we've always stood by our motto: 'Screw it, let's do it.' Do not be embarrassed by your failures, learn from them and start again. Making mistakes and experiencing setbacks is part of the DNA of every successful entrepreneur, and I am no exception.</p></blockquote>\n<h2>3. Put your employees first, even ahead of your customers.</h2>\n<p>Branson says, \"If you take care of your employees, your employees will take care of your customers, and your customers will take care of your shareholders.\"</p>\n<p>That's the culture Virgin has built over the years -- it starts and ends with having an employee-first mindset. If managers engage their employees, they'll become more loyal and produce better work, which leads to a better customer experience and, at the end of the road, more profits.</p>\n<p>Here's what Branson said in an interview with <em>Inc</em>.'s editor in chief, Eric Schurenberg:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\"If the person who works at your company is 100% proud of the job they're doing, if you give them the tools to do a good job, they're proud of the brand, if they were looked after, if they're treated well, then they're gonna be smiling, they're gonna be happy and therefore the customer will have a nice experience. If the person who's working for your company is not given the right tools, is not looked after, is not appreciated, they're not gonna do things with a smile and therefore the customer will be treated in a way where often they won't want to come back for more. So, my philosophy has always been, if you can put staff first, your customer second and shareholders third, effectively, in the end, the shareholders do well, the customers do better, and yourself are happy.\"</p></blockquote>\n<p>Well stated, Sir. As I've <a href=\"http://inc.com/marcel-schwantes/heres-a-top-10-list-of-the-worlds-best-ceos-but-they-lead-in-a-totally-unique-wa.html\">written in the past</a>, this business practice is increasingly becoming the norm for how <a href=\"http://inc.com/marcel-schwantes/heres-a-top-10-list-of-the-worlds-best-ceos-but-they-lead-in-a-totally-unique-wa.html\">CEOs lead their companies</a> -- even in some of the biggest brands on the planet.</p></div>\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15430474": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 01:49:14", "url": "http://betabeast.com", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"entry-content\">\n\t\t\t<p>Where it all began\u2026 Well, we pretty much started yesterday (10/7/2017). BetaBeast is a website focused on startups. We will release news, information and feature websites and companies that are just getting started.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div></body></html>"}, "15431102": {"score": 12, "comments": ["The first time I learned of reification was when c# added reified generics as opposed to the type erased generics in java.  Made type information easier to see when doing reflection.  No need for &quot;super type tokens&quot; etc.", "That is a very narrow understanding of the word though. Reification is best shown by the automated theorem progress which given constraints reify the program to verify these properties.  (Especially when nested, such as proof of correctness by refinement)"], "time": "2017-10-09 04:48:42", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reification_(computer_science)", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n<p><b>Reification</b> is the process by which an abstract idea about a <a href=\"/wiki/Computer_program\" title=\"Computer program\">computer program</a> is turned into an explicit <a href=\"/wiki/Data_model\" title=\"Data model\">data model</a> or other object created in a <a href=\"/wiki/Programming_language\" title=\"Programming language\">programming language</a>. A computable/addressable object \u2014 a resource \u2014 is created in a system as a proxy for a non computable/addressable object. By means of reification, something that was previously implicit, unexpressed, and possibly inexpressible is explicitly formulated and made available to conceptual (logical or computational) manipulation. Informally, reification is often referred to as \"making something a <a href=\"/wiki/First-class_citizen\" title=\"First-class citizen\">first-class citizen</a>\" within the scope of a particular system. Some aspect of a system can be reified at <i>language design time</i>, which is related to <a href=\"/wiki/Reflection_(computer_science)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Reflection (computer science)\">reflection</a> in programming languages. It can be applied as a <a href=\"/wiki/Stepwise_refinement\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Stepwise refinement\">stepwise refinement</a> at <i>system design time</i>. Reification is one of the most frequently used techniques of <a href=\"/wiki/Conceptual_analysis\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Conceptual analysis\">conceptual analysis</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Knowledge_representation\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Knowledge representation\">knowledge representation</a>.</p>\n<p/>\n\n<p/>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_and_reflective_programming_languages\">Reification and reflective programming languages</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Reification and reflective programming languages\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>In the context of <a href=\"/wiki/Programming_language\" title=\"Programming language\">programming languages</a>, reification is the process by which a user program or any aspect of a programming language that was implicit in the translated program and the run-time system, are expressed in the language itself. This process makes it available to the program, which can inspect all these aspects as ordinary <a href=\"/wiki/Data\" title=\"Data\">data</a>. In <a href=\"/wiki/Reflection_(computer_science)\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Reflection (computer science)\">reflective languages</a>, reification data is causally connected to the related reified aspect such that a modification to one of them affects the other. Therefore, the reification data is always a faithful representation of the related reified aspect <sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify\" title=\"Wikipedia:Please clarify\"><span title=\"The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2017)\">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. Reification data is often said to be made a <a href=\"/wiki/First_class_object\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"First class object\">first class object</a><sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed\" title=\"Wikipedia:Citation needed\"><span title=\"This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)\">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. Reification, at least partially, has been experienced in many languages to date: in early <a href=\"/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)\" title=\"Lisp (programming language)\">Lisp dialects</a> and in current <a href=\"/wiki/Prolog\" title=\"Prolog\">Prolog dialects</a>, programs have been treated as data, although the causal connection has often been left to the responsibility of the programmer. In <a href=\"/wiki/Smalltalk\" title=\"Smalltalk\">Smalltalk</a>-80, the compiler from the source text to bytecode has been part of the run-time system since the very first implementations of the language.<sup id=\"cite_ref-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-1\">[1]</a></sup></p>\n<ul>\n<li>The <a href=\"/wiki/C_(programming_language)\" title=\"C (programming language)\">C programming language</a> reifies the low-level detail of <a href=\"/wiki/Memory_address\" title=\"Memory address\">memory addresses</a>.\n<p class=\"paragraphbreak\"/>\nMany programming language designs encapsulate the details of memory allocation in the compiler and the run-time system. In the design of the C programming language, the memory address is reified and is available for direct manipulation by other language constructs. For example, the following code may be used when implementing a memory-mapped device driver. The buffer pointer is a proxy for the memory address 0xB800000.\n<p class=\"paragraphbreak\"/>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n <span class=\"kt\">char</span><span class=\"o\">*</span> <span class=\"n\">buffer</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"p\">(</span><span class=\"kt\">char</span><span class=\"o\">*</span><span class=\"p\">)</span> <span class=\"mh\">0xB800000</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n <span class=\"n\">buffer</span><span class=\"p\">[</span><span class=\"mi\">0</span><span class=\"p\">]</span> <span class=\"o\">=</span> <span class=\"mi\">10</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n</pre></div>\n</li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Functional_programming_languages\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Functional programming languages\">Functional programming languages</a> based on <a href=\"/wiki/Lambda-calculus\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Lambda-calculus\">lambda-calculus</a> reify the concept of a procedure abstraction and procedure application in the form of the <a href=\"/wiki/Lambda_calculus#Lambda_calculus_and_programming_languages\" title=\"Lambda calculus\">Lambda expression</a>.</li>\n<li>The <a href=\"/wiki/Scheme_(programming_language)\" title=\"Scheme (programming language)\">Scheme</a> programming language reifies <a href=\"/wiki/Continuations\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Continuations\">continuations</a> (approximately, the call stack).</li>\n<li>In <a href=\"/wiki/C_Sharp_(programming_language)\" title=\"C Sharp (programming language)\">C#</a>, reification is used to make <a href=\"/wiki/Parametric_polymorphism\" title=\"Parametric polymorphism\">parametric polymorphism</a> implemented as generics as a first-class feature of the language.</li>\n<li>In the <a href=\"/wiki/Java_(programming_language)\" title=\"Java (programming language)\">Java</a> programming language, there exist \"reifiable types\" that are \"completely available at run time\" (i.e. their information is not erased during compilation).<sup id=\"cite_ref-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/REBOL\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"REBOL\">REBOL</a> reifies code as data and vice versa.</li>\n<li>Many languages, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)\" title=\"Lisp (programming language)\">Lisp</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/JavaScript\" title=\"JavaScript\">JavaScript</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Curl_(programming_language)\" title=\"Curl (programming language)\">Curl</a>, provide an <a href=\"/wiki/Eval\" title=\"Eval\"><code>eval</code> or <code>evaluate</code> procedure</a> that effectively reifies the language interpreter.</li>\n<li>The <a href=\"/wiki/Logtalk\" title=\"Logtalk\">Logtalk</a> framework for <a href=\"/wiki/Prolog\" title=\"Prolog\">Prolog</a> offers a means to explore reification in the context of <a href=\"/wiki/Logic_programming\" title=\"Logic programming\">logic programming</a>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Smalltalk\" title=\"Smalltalk\">Smalltalk</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Actor_model\" title=\"Actor model\">Actor languages</a> permit the reification of blocks and <a href=\"/wiki/Message_passing\" title=\"Message passing\">messages</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> which are equivalent of lambda expressions in Lisp, and <a href=\"/w/index.php?title=ThisContext&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"ThisContext (page does not exist)\">thisContext</a> which is a reification of the current executing block.</li>\n<li><a href=\"/wiki/Homoiconicity\" title=\"Homoiconicity\">Homoiconic languages</a> reify the syntax of the language itself in the form of an <a href=\"/wiki/Abstract_syntax_tree\" title=\"Abstract syntax tree\">abstract syntax tree</a>, typically together with <code>eval</code>.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Data_reification_vs._data_refinement\">Data reification vs. data refinement</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Data reification vs. data refinement\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>Data reification (<a href=\"/wiki/Stepwise_refinement\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Stepwise refinement\">stepwise refinement</a>) involves finding a more concrete representation of the <a href=\"/wiki/Abstract_data_type\" title=\"Abstract data type\">abstract data types</a> used in a <a href=\"/wiki/Formal_specification\" title=\"Formal specification\">formal specification</a>.</p>\n<p>Data reification is the terminology of the <a href=\"/wiki/Vienna_Development_Method\" title=\"Vienna Development Method\">Vienna Development Method</a> (VDM) that most other people would call data refinement. An example is taking a step towards an implementation by replacing a data representation without a counterpart in the intended implementation language, such as sets, by one that does have a counterpart (such as maps with fixed domains that can be implemented by arrays), or at least one that is closer to having a counterpart, such as sequences. The VDM community prefers the word \"reification\" over \"refinement\", as the process has more to do with concretising an idea than with refining it.<sup id=\"cite_ref-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></p>\n<p>For similar usages, see <a href=\"/wiki/Reification_(linguistics)\" title=\"Reification (linguistics)\">Reification (linguistics)</a>.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_in_conceptual_modeling\">Reification in conceptual modeling</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Reification in conceptual modeling\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>Reification is widely used in <a href=\"/wiki/Conceptual_model_(computer_science)\" title=\"Conceptual model (computer science)\">conceptual modeling</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> Reifying a relationship means viewing it as an entity. The purpose of reifying a relationship is to make it explicit, when additional information needs to be added to it. Consider the relationship type <i><code>IsMemberOf(member:Person, Committee)</code></i>. An instance of <i><code>IsMemberOf</code></i> is a relationship that represents the fact that a person is a member of a committee. The figure below shows an example population of <i><code>IsMemberOf</code></i> relationship in tabular form. Person <i>P1</i> is a member of committees <i>C1</i> and <i>C2</i>. Person <i>P2</i> is a member of committee <i>C1</i> only.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Reification_example1.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Reification_example1.png/500px-Reification_example1.png\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Reification_example1.png/750px-Reification_example1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Reification_example1.png/1000px-Reification_example1.png 2x\" data-file-width=\"1303\" data-file-height=\"665\"/></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<p>\nExample population of </p><code>IsMemberOf</code><p> relationship in tabular form. Person P1 is a member of committees C1 and C2. Person P2 is a member of committee C1 only.</p></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The same fact, however, could also be viewed as an entity. Viewing a relationship as an entity, one can say that the entity reifies the relationship. This is called reification of a relationship. Like any other entity, it must be an instance of an entity type. In the present example, the entity type has been named <code>Membership</code>. For each instance of <i><code>IsMemberOf</code></i>, there is one and only one instance of <i><code>Membership</code></i>, and vice versa. Now, it becomes possible to add more information to the original relationship. As an example, we can express the fact that \"person p1 was nominated to be the member of committee c1 by person p2\". Reified relationship <i><code>Membership</code></i> can be used as the source of a new relationship <i><code>IsNominatedBy(Membership, Person)</code></i>.</p>\n<p>For related usages see <a href=\"/wiki/Reification_(knowledge_representation)\" title=\"Reification (knowledge representation)\">Reification (knowledge representation)</a>.</p>\n<h2><span id=\"Reification_in_Unified_Modeling_Language_(UML)\"/><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_in_Unified_Modeling_Language_.28UML.29\">Reification in Unified Modeling Language (UML)</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Reification in Unified Modeling Language (UML)\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Unified_Modeling_Language\" title=\"Unified Modeling Language\">UML</a> provides an <i>association class</i> construct for defining reified relationship types. The association class is a single model element that is both a kind of association and a kind of a class.<sup id=\"cite_ref-6\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> The association and the entity type that reifies are both the same model element. Note that attributes cannot be reified.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_on_Semantic_Web\">Reification on Semantic Web</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Reification on Semantic Web\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"RDF_and_OWL\">RDF and OWL</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: RDF and OWL\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In <a href=\"/wiki/Semantic_Web\" title=\"Semantic Web\">Semantic Web</a> languages, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Resource_Description_Framework\" title=\"Resource Description Framework\">Resource Description Framework</a> (RDF) and <a href=\"/wiki/Web_Ontology_Language\" title=\"Web Ontology Language\">Web Ontology Language</a> (OWL), a statement is a binary relation. It is used to link two individuals or an individual and a value. Applications sometimes need to describe other RDF statements, for instance, to record information like when statements were made, or who made them, which is sometimes called \"<a href=\"/wiki/Provenance\" title=\"Provenance\">provenance</a>\" information. As an example, we may want to represent properties of a relation, such as our certainty about it, severity or strength of a relation, relevance of a relation, and so on.</p>\n<p>The example from the conceptual modeling section describes a particular person with <code>URIref person:p1</code>, who is a member of the <code>committee:c1</code>. The RDF triple from that description is</p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n  <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p1</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">isMemberOf</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">c1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<p>Consider to store two further facts: (i) to record who nominated this particular person to this committee (a statement about the membership itself), and (ii) to record who added the fact to the database (a statement about the statement).</p>\n<p>The first case is a case of classical reification like above in UML: reify the membership and store its attributes and roles etc.:</p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Membership</span>        <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">type</span>              <span class=\"nn\">owl</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Class</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">type</span>              <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Membership</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">ofPerson</span>    <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">inCommittee</span> <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">c1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p2</span>                   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">nominated</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<p>Additionally, RDF provides a built-in vocabulary intended for describing RDF statements. A description of a statement using this vocabulary is called a reification of the statement. The RDF reification vocabulary consists of the type <code>rdf:Statement</code>, and the properties <code>rdf:subject</code>, <code>rdf:predicate</code>, and <code>rdf:object</code>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-rdf_7-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-rdf-7\">[7]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Using the reification vocabulary, a reification of the statement about the person's membership would be given by assigning the statement a URIref such as <code>committee:membership12345</code> so that describing statements can be written as follows:</p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345Stat</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">type</span>        <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Statement</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345Stat</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">subject</span>     <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345Stat</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">predicate</span>   <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">isMemberOf</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span> \n <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345Stat</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">object</span>      <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">c1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<p>These statements say that the resource identified by the <code>URIref committee:membership12345Stat</code> is an RDF statement, that the subject of the statement refers to the resource identified by <code>person:p1</code>, the predicate of the statement refers to the resource identified by <code>committee:isMemberOf</code>, and the object of the statement refers to the resource <code>committee:c1</code>. Assuming that the original statement is actually identified by <code>committee:membership12345</code>, it should be clear by comparing the original statement with the reification that the reification actually does describe it. The conventional use of the RDF reification vocabulary always involves describing a statement using four statements in this pattern. Therefore, they are sometimes referred to as the \"reification quad\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-rdf_7-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-rdf-7\">[7]</a></sup></p>\n<p>Using reification according to this convention, we could record the fact that <code>person:p3</code> added the statement to the database by</p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n  <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p3</span>    <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">addedToDatabase</span>    <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345Stat</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<p>It is important to note that in the conventional use of reification, the subject of the reification triples is assumed to identify a particular instance of a triple in a particular RDF document, rather than some arbitrary triple having the same subject, predicate, and object. This particular convention is used because reification is intended for expressing properties such as dates of composition and source information, as in the examples given already, and these properties need to be applied to specific instances of triples. Note that the described triple <code>(subject predicate object)</code> itself is not implied by such a reification quad (and it is not necessary that it actually exists in the database). This allows also to use this mechanism to express which triples do <i>not</i> hold.</p>\n<p>The power of the reification vocabulary in RDF is restricted by the lack of a built-in means for assigning URIrefs to statements, so in order to express \"provenance\" information of this kind in RDF, one has to use some mechanism (outside of RDF) to assign URIs to individual RDF statements, then make further statements about those individual statements, using their URIs to identify them.<sup id=\"cite_ref-rdf_7-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-rdf-7\">[7]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_in_Topic_Maps\">Reification in Topic Maps</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Reification in Topic Maps\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In an <a href=\"/wiki/Topic_Maps\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"Topic Maps\">XML Topic Map</a> (XTM), only a topic can have a name or play a role in an association. One may use an association to make an assertion about a topic, but one cannot directly make assertions about that assertion. However, it is possible to create a topic that reifies a non-topic construct in a map, thus enabling the association to be named and treated as a topic itself.<sup id=\"cite_ref-8\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_and_n-ary_relations\">Reification and n-ary relations</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Reification and n-ary relations\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In Semantic Web languages, such as RDF and OWL, a property is a binary relation used to link two individuals or an individual and a value. However, in some cases, the natural and convenient way to represent certain concepts is to use relations to link an individual to more than just one individual or value. These relations are called <a href=\"/wiki/N-ary_relations\" class=\"mw-redirect\" title=\"N-ary relations\">n-ary relations</a>. Examples are representing relations among multiple individuals, such as a committee, a person who is a committee member and another person who has nominated the first person to become the committee member, or a buyer, a seller, and an object that was bought when describing a purchase of a book.</p>\n<p>A more general approach to reification is to create an explicit new class and n new properties to represent an n-ary relation, making an instance of the relation linking the n individuals an instance of this class. This approach can also be used to represent provenance information and other properties for an individual relation instance.<sup id=\"cite_ref-9\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n<span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p1</span>\n<span class=\"w\">      </span><span class=\"kt\">a</span><span class=\"w\">       </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Person</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n<span class=\"w\">      </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">has_membership</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"err\">_</span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership_12345</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"p\">.</span>\n<span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"err\">_</span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership_12345</span>\n<span class=\"w\">      </span><span class=\"kt\">a</span><span class=\"w\">       </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">Membership</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n<span class=\"w\">      </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">committee</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">c1</span><span class=\"p\">;</span>\n<span class=\"w\">      </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">nominated_by</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"nn\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p2</span><span class=\"w\"> </span><span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reification_vs._quotation\">Reification vs. quotation</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Reification vs. quotation\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>It is also important to note that the reification described here is not the same as \"quotation\" found in other languages. Instead, the reification describes the relationship between a particular instance of a triple and the resources the triple refers to. The reification can be read intuitively as saying \"this RDF triple talks about these things\", rather than (as in quotation) \"this RDF triple has this form.\" For instance, in the reification example used in this section, the triple:</p>\n<div class=\"mw-highlight mw-content-ltr\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<pre>\n  <span class=\"nn\">committee</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">membership12345</span>   <span class=\"nn\">rdf</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">subject</span>   <span class=\"nn\">person</span><span class=\"p\">:</span><span class=\"nt\">p1</span> <span class=\"p\">.</span>\n</pre></div>\n<p>describing the <code>rdf:subject</code> of the original statement says that the subject of the statement is the resource (the person) identified by the URIref <code>person:p1</code>. It does not state that the subject of the statement is the URIref itself (i.e., a string beginning with certain characters), as quotation would.</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"See_also\">See also</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: See also\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<table role=\"presentation\" class=\"mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox\">\n<tr>\n<td class=\"mbox-image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg/40px-Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg.png\" class=\"noviewer\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg/60px-Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg/80px-Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg.png 2x\" data-file-width=\"391\" data-file-height=\"391\"/></td>\n<td class=\"mbox-text plainlist\">Look up <i><b><a href=\"https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/reification\" class=\"extiw\" title=\"wiktionary:reification\">reification</a></b></i> in Wiktionary, the free dictionary.</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"/w/index.php?title=Reification_(computer_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: References\">edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span></h2>\n<div class=\"reflist\">\n<div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n<ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"cite_note-1\"><span class=\"mw-cite-backlink\"><b><a href=\"#cite_ref-1\">^</a></b></span> <span class=\"reference-text\">J. The situation in Puerto Rico remains <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/puerto-rico-virgin-islands-maria-recovery-colonialism/541908/\">grim</a>. The task of recovery and rebuilding homes and infrastructure on the island\u2014home to 3.4 million people\u2014is daunting. As federal agencies continue to ramp up aid efforts across Puerto Rico, the immense scale and depth of the the impact of Hurricane Maria becomes clearer every day. Gathered here are images from just the past week.</p>\n        </div>\n        </div></body></html>"}, "15431106": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-09 04:50:33", "url": "https://www.vg.no/spesial/2017/undercover-darkweb/?lang=en#ingress", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-content\">\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">The drive from Nashville</span> takes more than 10 hours. That would have given Falte ample time to reflect on what he was heading to do.</p>\n\n                                                <p>He drove across the Smoky Mountains, through lush forests where the trees were aflame with autumn colours. He kept driving. Did he ever stop to consider whether it was right to rape a four-year-old girl? Regardless, he pressed on towards the house in Virginia.</p>\n\n                                                <p>As did Faulkner, all the way from Toronto.</p>\n\n                                                <p><strong>On the dark web, they divided between them a kingdom of like-minded people who admired them and strove to curry their favour.</strong></p>\n\n                                                <p>The supplicants included a man with access to the four-year-old girl. According to a police report, it was he who filmed the assaults. The pictures showed that at least one of the three men raped the girl that Saturday in September 2016.</p>\n\n                                                <div class=\"title-map\">\n                   \n                    <p class=\"date\">September 9th, 2017</p>\n                    <p><h5 class=\"place\">American prison</h5></p>\n                </div>\n                                                <p>The phone line crackles as the man who provided the four-year-old girl to Faulkner and Falte talks to VG from the prison, where he has been for almost a year.</p>\n\n                                                                    <div class=\"hoyre\">\n                        <figure class=\"image-container\">\n                            <img class=\"lazy\" data-src=\"img/arrestert.jpg\" alt=\"Imprisoned man.\"/>\n                            <figcaption>\n                                Imprisoned man.                             </figcaption>\n                        </figure>\n                    </div>\n                \n                                                <p>\u2013 There isn\u2019t much privacy here in the prison, so there\u2019s not much I can say on the phone, he says, and continues:</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I\u2019m not going to lie. It was I who contacted CrazyMonk first.</p>\n\n                                                <p>VG has data showing that this man had visited several of the biggest child abuse websites. He had posted abuse pictures and asked other members for help in finding more.</p>\n\n                                                <p><strong>For him, getting to talk to CrazyMonk, the head of the website, was a big deal. A famous man. To make contact, he showed Falte pictures of the child. That\u2019s how it started.</strong></p>\n\n                                                <p>A few weeks later, Falte arrived at his home. Under questioning, according to court documents, Falte said that during his first visit in 2015 he raped the child \u201cuntil the minor complained\u201d.</p>\n\n                                                <p>That was the first of a five visits to the small house in Virginia. Just after New Year\u2019s Falte came back, this time with Faulkner.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">In interviews with VG</span>, the police say they don\u2019t know why WarHead and CrazyMonk decided to meet, though they had a lot of information about the men.</p>\n\n                                                <p>After the police found the server where the site was stored, in July, they monitored all communications, including private messages between the administrators. The police kept tabs on where they travelled in Virginia, where they spent nights, and which houses they visited.</p>\n\n                                                <p>No one suspected a child was about to be raped.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 But we definitely wondered why they wanted to meet. That question hung over our heads, says Rouse, in Australia.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Some of these men wanted so desperately something beyond just the confirmation they get online. They want to meet people like themselves, if only for a beer, says Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 <em>Why weren\u2019t they arrested before the assault occurred?</em></p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 We had no idea that was going to happen. They never mentioned anything about it in the messages we saw about meeting, says Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>The man who filmed the abuse of the child confirms that was the case. The plans to meet were made in an encrypted chat program, he tells VG.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Police had access to these chats only after obtaining all the passwords from CrazyMonk and WarHead.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Faulkner and Falte say the same in an email to VG from prison in the United States.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 We made sure specifically not to talk about specifics anywhere other than Tox [encrypted chat], and burner phones with dummy burner phone numbers, they write.</p>\n\n                                                <p>They were surprised at how much the agents managed to find during the search.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I was completely confident that they had very little on both of us in terms of evidence that they could use in court, writes Faulkner.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Our machines were fully encrypted, we ran everything in Virtual Machines (VMs), all our removable media was free of anything implicating. They did not know anything about what was going on in Virginia.</p>\n\n                                                \n\n\n\n \n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">In a purely investigative sense</span>, the arrests were a success. Task Force Argos assumed control of all of Faulkner and Falte\u2019s usernames and passwords.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Task Force Argos became WarHead, but nobody outside the team knew.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Griffiths and his colleagues worked frenetically to learn all about Faulkner\u2019s online persona so as to assume his identity without anyone catching on.</p>\n\n                                                <p>That took longer than some Childs Play members liked. Previously, WarHead had been a frequent presence on the site, often posting messages several times a day. Now he was silent.</p>\n\n                                                <p/><blockquote>\u00abDid anybody hear from WarHead within the last 7 days? I'm waiting for a pm from him. Nothing happens.\u00bb</blockquote><p>, a nervous member wrote, using an abbreviation for \u201cpersonal message\u201d.\n\n                                                </p><p>\u00abStrange, her disappearing and this forum going slower and slower......,\u00bb, wrote another. Like most forum members, he used the pronoun \u201cshe\u201d, though the vast majority were men.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Something had to be done. If the forum did not hear from WarHead soon, members would sense he\u2019d been arrested. They might then begin deleting their own tracks. That must not be allowed to happen.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">Online crime has no borders.</span> That\u2019s a problem, but in this case Argos and its partners turned it to their advantage.</p>\n\n                                                <p>It is VG\u2019s understanding that when WarHead surrendered access to Childs Play and Giftbox each forum was stored on servers in separate European countries. Police, lawyers and the suspects themselves refuse to say which.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Police in Australia and the European country saw obvious benefits to having the Australian police, rather than a European force, running the site.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Australian laws give the police unusually broad powers to monitor suspicious activities online.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 During a so-called \u201ccontrolled operation\u201d we get permission from a judge to act in ways that normally would have been considered illegal. We are given the right to commit certain criminal actions and we are exempted from prosecution because we are investigating specific crimes, explains Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>At a meeting this spring in The Hague of the some of the world\u2019s leading investigators of internet-related abuse, Griffiths told of a case in which he hacked into someone\u2019s account on a web forum.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I looked around the room and knew that none of the other investigators had permission to do the same. Technically, it wasn\u2019t difficult. But legally they would not have been allowed, says Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>He thinks that\u2019s a problem.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 It means they lose the opportunity to identify some of the worst offenders on the internet, he says.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 If they had the options we have, I\u2019m sure they would catch people they can\u2019t get today. But it must be done properly, within a given framework. For it to work you have to have certain abilities and controls in place. I feel we have that.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">With permission from the European</span> police partner, Task Force Argos logged on to the server, took over the \u201cChilds Play\u201d site, copied it and moved it to a server in Sydney, as VG discovered in January.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Experts consulted by VG say the transfer was comparable to the way the United States once flew terrorism suspects to countries with lax human rights records for questioning.</p>\n\n                                                                    <div class=\"hoyre\">\n                        <figure class=\"image-container\">\n                            <img class=\"lazy\" data-src=\"https://imbo.vgc.no/users/vg-redutv/images/4c2f1bff5e8cce86c9d4684b8df19188.jpg?t%5B0%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;t%5B1%5D=compress%3Alevel%3D85&amp;t%5B2%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;accessToken=0d0ae0dc3d72311287eb5a4b68dd6593763b17336229292d95fcacd3f4186374\" alt=\"Jon Wessel-Aas\"/>\n                            <figcaption>\n                                Jon Wessel-Aas Photo: Gorm Kallestad / NTB scanpix                            </figcaption>\n                        </figure>\n                    </div>\n                \n                                                <p>\u2013 The logic seems to be the same in this case, says Jon Wessel-Aas, a Norwegian lawyer and specialist in privacy and human rights.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 It is worrying if the police \u201coutsource\u201d investigations to a country where police have freer rein, at least if it\u2019s done intentionally and systematically. But the legal picture is unclear.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Cross-border investigations are demanding, both legally and ethically.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 In the absence of sound regulations, the police in countries with the fewest legal protections can end up with responsibility for an investigation, Wessel-Aas says.</p>\n\n                                                <div class=\"title-map\">\n                   \n                    <p class=\"date\">October 6th, 2016</p>\n                    <p><h5 class=\"place\">\u00abWarhead\u00bb is back</h5></p>\n                </div>\n                                                <p>On Thursday, October 6th, 2016,</p>\n\n                                                <p>Four days after the arrest, \u201cWarHead\u201d was back on Childs Play:</p>\n\n                                                <p/><blockquote>\u00abPhew, what a month that was!. A month of my life that I won\u2019t get back. Although technically most of the really screwed up shit happened in October, not September, hence my late foray into this month\u00bb</blockquote>\n\n                                                <p>Then he reprimanded his subordinates: \u00abSorry again about the late arrival but I did ask the Staff team to step in and cover for me in my enforced absences.\u00bb</p>\n\n                                                <p>He, WarHead, was no longer Faulkner, but Paul Griffiths of Task Force Argos.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Thus began the undercover phase of Operation Artemis.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Within four days of the Canadian\u2019s arrest, Griffith had examined every message WarHead had written. He studied WarHead\u2019s writing style, including the typographical errors he was prone to. He knew the snippets of background history he had revealed online.</p>\n\n                                                <p>He did this during the day. Nights were spent in telephone conferences with colleagues in Europe and the United States.</p>\n\n                                                <p>It was inevitably 2 a.m. in Brisbane when everyone else was available to talk.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">Going undercover online</span> takes more than grammar and personal history. To write like WarHead, Griffiths had to <em>be</em> WarHead. It was a mental effort that he and his task force colleagues disliked.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 When you\u2019re trying to be someone who has written a lot online, who a lot of people know and whose way of writing and expression they recognize, you can\u2019t just show up and use a completely different vocabulary. You have to study the punctuation he uses, as well as the smileys and other characters.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Not even that guarantees success.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 <strong>You need to understand how he feels. It\u2019s destructive. Really difficult. I have been working in this field for 22 years. Seeing pictures has no effect on me anymore. But to sit online and talk like one of these guys ... Every time I\u2019ve done it, I feel like I have to take a shower afterwards.</strong></p>\n\n                                                                    <figure class=\"image-container\">\n                         <img class=\"img-responsive lazy\" data-src=\"https://imbo.vgc.no/users/vg-redutv/images/135de562a770119e6596c71a31fdc4e9.jpg?t%5B0%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;t%5B1%5D=compress%3Alevel%3D85&amp;t%5B2%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;accessToken=ee3786f125bdfe2117872f09138fdc04a36ef6cf3ec793ebb3ea670d3fc2a4b3\" alt=\"Paul Griffiths.\"/>\n                         <figcaption>\n                             Paul Griffiths. Photo: Tore Kristiansen / VG                         </figcaption>\n                     </figure>\n                \n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">Griffiths \u2013 friends call him \u00abGriff\u00bb</span> \u2013 is considered a leading expert on identifying victims and perpetrators based on images.</p>\n\n                                                <p>He has been identifying victims of abuse for 22 years. If one person has abused another, and it was filmed, he most probably has seen it.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 My main motivation is to identify the children and get them out of their horrible situation. That\u2019s how I manage to work with it.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I also have a touch of Asperger\u2019s. At least, that\u2019s what my wife says. She says I have no empathy, says Griffiths with a short laugh.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 That makes it easier to stay in the job.</p>\n\n                                                <p>It also helps that he has a photographic memory, remembering everything as pictures. Even when sifting through millions of pictures, he knows which ones he has seen before, including where and when.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 We have good databases, but I generally find things faster than them.</p>\n\n                                                <p><strong>Five years ago he saw a picture. It was a picture of a naked man. Griffiths knew immediately that he had identified one of the internet\u2019s most ruthless and notorious abusers: Falko.</strong></p>\n\n                                                <p>The man in the photo had a feature that Griff recognized from child exploitation films that Falko had shared online. No one had managed to identify him or the victims, because he was careful never to show his face during the abuses he committed.</p>\n\n                                                <p>But \u201cGriff\u201d recognized a mark on the man\u2019s penis.</p>\n\n                                                <p><strong>That led to Falko\u2019s arrest and lengthy prison term in Kazakhstan. Now he is on the run, after a spectacular escape that involved throwing himself out of a courtroom window and breaking both legs, then escaping from the hospital. But it was \u201cGriff\u201d who found him.</strong></p>\n\n                                                <p/><blockquote>\u00abWe are, I can assure you, as safe as we have always been, and I hope we will always continue to be so,\u00bb</blockquote>\n\n                                                <p>Griffiths wrote in the guise of WarHead.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Members believed him.</p>\n\n                                                <p>For nearly a year, Task Force Argos would harvest information about the members on the website.</p>\n\n                                                <p><strong>Having complete control of the site meant they could see everything that went on there. By reading private messages, deleted messages and email addresses and passwords they could build a profile of the members. They could also add bits of code to the program that controlled the site, enabling them to find members\u2019 IP addresses. They tried a variety of techniques to identify Childs Play members, but decline to discuss them with VG.</strong></p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 If this was war, do you think the general would let you into central command? We do not want to tell these people how we work, and I really hope you don\u2019t either. You won\u2019t get our operating methods, says Rouse.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 We\u2019re trying to do something that has never been done before. So in a way you write your own \u2013 I won\u2019t say \u2018rules\u2019 \u2013 but you write your own script. We use techniques that have never been applied before, and we don\u2019t always know how to prepare ourselves for the results, adds Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>As a sort of anthropologist of the dark, Griffiths learned the culture of this online community of exploiters: what should not be posted on the main site (torture videos); what could be shared in a small, trusted group (torture videos); who among the members were popular and in favour and who were not.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Accessing private messages between members turned up a surprise for Griffiths. Several of them knew the police were now running the site.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 A substantial number knew exactly what had happened. They had exposed us as police and saw through the smokescreen we had put up around WarHead. They knew it was us, but didn\u2019t tell anyone. Those who exposed us talked to each other but didn\u2019t warn anyone else.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">Griffiths tried to write as few posts</span> as possible, but there was one that the Australian police could not escape: WarHead\u2019s monthly status update.</p>\n\n                                                <p>The understanding between WarHead and forum members was that a missing a status update would signal that the site had been taken over by others. That is why the messages were so important, and had to be written in the same style as always,</p>\n\n                                                <p>Under Faulkner\u2019s rules, each status update had to end with a sexual assault picture.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 The assumption was the police couldn\u2019t share such images, making it impossible for us to run the site, says Griffiths, who is originally British.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 In Britain, we couldn\u2019t have done this. But when you\u2019ve worked in this field a long time it becomes obvious what needs to be done and why. Doing this gives us a chance to identify those who commit new assaults. Most of them have probably already seen the photos we share.</p>\n\n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">On January 3rd, 2017</span>, Task Force Argos published WarHead\u2019s monthly update. In it, they wrote about the work WarHead had been doing on the forum, ostensibly to make it more secure for members.</p>\n\n                                                <p>The message was concluded with:</p>\n\n                                                <p/><blockquote>\u00abI hope that some of you were able to give a special present to the little ones in your lives, and spend some time with them. It\u2019s a great time of year to snuggle up near a fire, and make some memories.\u00bb</blockquote>\n\n                                                <p>He ended the update message, as required, with two child abuse images.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 <em>Could this message be seen as encouraging sexual abuse?</em> VG ask.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Well, there\u2019s no ... I mean, you know, says Griffiths.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Things can be read between the lines, but that doesn\u2019t necessarily mean we\u2019re encouraging anything. We may have talked about sexual abuse in a number of different forums and platforms, but we would never encourage abuse.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Sharing any such image is an abuse of that child. However, it is something we can justify as being for the greater good and to prevent ongoing abuse of children.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 <em>How do you think the children in the pictures feel about your sharing pictures of them?</em></p>\n\n                                                <p>He pauses for a second.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I hope they understand that we are trying to catch as many offenders as possible.</p>\n\n                                                                    <div class=\"hoyre\">\n                        <figure class=\"image-container\">\n                            <img class=\"lazy\" data-src=\"https://imbo.vgc.no/users/vg-redutv/images/889732c66cf3de86491d97e51c26401b.jpg?t%5B0%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;t%5B1%5D=compress%3Alevel%3D85&amp;t%5B2%5D=resize%3Awidth%3D1200&amp;accessToken=3c384edcf0819141fb1446f7c90cd1cf1d9de12bf69bf5d76a64e856882984fd\" alt=\"Carissa Byrne Hessick.\"/>\n                            <figcaption>\n                                Carissa Byrne Hessick. Photo: Einar Otto Stangvik, VG                            </figcaption>\n                        </figure>\n                    </div>\n                \n                                                <p><span class=\"inngang\">Carissa Byrne Hessick, a professor of law at</span> the University of North Carolina, questions Griffith\u2019s argument. She is one of the world\u2019s leading legal experts on investigating such abuse.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 It sounds like the police tell one story about how damaging the images are when others share them, and another story when the police share them.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 That\u2019s a kind of hypocrisy I really don\u2019t like. But this sheds light on the argument that any and all sharing of such an image is abuse. If the police say they\u2019re only sharing images that have been shared before, it means the police <em>do not</em> think all sharing is harmful, says Hessick.</p>\n\n                                                <p>She expresses concern upon learning that the police themselves did share child sexual abuse images.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I don\u2019t necessarily think it\u2019s wrong for them to commit criminal acts during undercover operations. My concern is not about them breaking the law. My concern is whether we get enough information about the balance in what they do.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 If the site is used to facilitate the actual abuse of children and the police continue to run it, I question their ability to strike a balance, she adds.</p>\n\n                                                <p>Griffiths claims they do seek balance:</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 There is definitely a balance between what we want to achieve and how we go about it, he says.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 Eventually we get to the point where it isn\u2019t worth running the forum any more. But as long as we\u2019re identifying victims, producers and abusers, we will keep running it.</p>\n\n                                                <p>He tells of a previous operation in which investigators ran \u201cThe Love Zone\u201d website for just a few months. The pictures of her daughter had been less extensively distributed than many others, so each new share carried more significance.</p>\n\n                                                <p>\u2013 I agree with her that the police should compensate the victims, but not with money. If victims could be consulted along the way, it would give them a sense of control.
