"https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/10/05/opinion/sunday/nuclear-north-korea.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiosam&stream=top-stories&_r=0&referer=", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article-body\"><figure class=\"related-asset article-asset-inline\"><figcaption class=\"text-container\"><p class=\"heading\">Nicholas Kristof</p></figcaption></figure><p class=\"p-block\">PYONGYANG, North Korea \u2014 To fly into North Korea on an old Russian aircraft is to step into an alternate universe, one in which \u201cthe Supreme Leader\u201d defeats craven American imperialists, in which triplets are taken from parents to be raised by the state, in which nuclear war is imminent but survivable \u2014 and in which there is zero sympathy for American detainees like <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/19/us/otto-warmbier-north-korea-dies.html\">Otto Warmbier</a>.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Warmbier was the University of Virginia student who was arrested for stealing a poster, then sentenced to 15 years of hard labor and eventually returned to the U.S. in a vegetative state.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cHe broke the law in our country,\u201d said Ri Yong-pil, a senior Foreign Ministry official, adding that Warmbier was returned (a week before his death) as a \u201chumanitarian\u201d act. Another senior ministry official, Choe Kang-il, insisted that North Korea had provided excellent care and spent \u201call the money for nursing\u201d him.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Something in me snapped. I asked how North Koreans could possibly boast about their spending on a young man when he was in a coma only because of them. Choe replied just as hotly that Warmbier had not been mistreated and was in fine condition when he was sent back home.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"4\"/><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cThe U.S. administration, or some people with a certain intention, let him die,\u201d Choe said. \u201cThis must be intended to foster and spread anti-Communist hatred within America.\u201d</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"5\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Officials offered no apology and gave no ground, reflecting a hard line toward the United States that I found everywhere on this visit; Choe derided President Trump as \u201ca crazy man,\u201d \u201ca thug\u201d and \u201ca pathetic man with a big mouth.\u201d I\u2019ve been covering North Korea on and off since the 1980s, and this five-day trip has left me more alarmed than ever about the risks of a catastrophic confrontation.</p><p class=\"p-block\">I was given a visa to North Korea, as were three other New York Times journalists. The U.S. State Department promptly gave us an exemption from the travel ban to North Korea and issued special passports good for a single trip here.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Far more than when I previously visited, North Korea is galvanizing its people to expect a nuclear war with the United States. High school students march in the streets in military uniform every day to denounce America. Posters and billboards along the public roads show missiles destroying the U.S. Capitol and shredding the American flag. In fact, images of missiles are everywhere \u2014 in a kindergarten playground, at a dolphin show, on state television. This military mobilization is accompanied by the ubiquitous assumption that North Korea could not only survive a nuclear conflict, but also win it.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cIf we have to go to war, we won\u2019t hesitate to totally destroy the United States,\u201d explained Mun Hyok-myong, a 38-year-old teacher visiting an amusement park.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Ryang Song-chol, a 41-year-old factory worker, looked surprised when I asked if his country could survive a war with America. \u201cWe would certainly win,\u201d he said.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"10\"/><p class=\"p-block\">These interviews were conducted in the presence of two Foreign Ministry officials, but even if they weren\u2019t, there is no chance that ordinary people would speak freely to a foreign reporter. This is perhaps the most tightly controlled country in the world, so such quotes should be seen as reflecting a government script \u2014 in this case, a disturbingly jingoistic one.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"11\"/><p class=\"p-block\">On past trips (my last was in 2005), we journalists stayed at hotels in the capital and were free to walk around on our own, but this time the Foreign Ministry housed us at its own guarded Kobangsan Guest House east of the capital. At first I thought this was simply to restrict us, but increasingly I saw signs of something more interesting and menacing: The Foreign Ministry was also protecting us from hard-liners in the military or in the security services.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cSomeone might hear you are from America,\u201d and there could be trouble, one official explained.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Hard-liners seem to have gained greater power this year, especially after Trump\u2019s threat to \u201ctotally destroy\u201d North Korea, and we were told that military officers sometimes mock their own country\u2019s diplomats for being wimpish \u201cAmerican cronies.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">Foreign Ministry officials escorted us every time we left the compound, probably both to keep us out of mischief and to protect us from the security agencies.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Yes, all this has been a little discomfiting.</p><p class=\"p-block\">The upshot is that I have felt more constraint than on past visits to North Korea, and considerably more tension. Before, I had been able to see senior generals, but this time the military flatly refused to consider my interview requests. The security forces also refused my request to meet the three Americans whom they still detain, one for two years now, without consular access.</p><p class=\"p-block\">A basic problem is that hard-liners seem ascendant in both Washington and Pyongyang.</p><p class=\"p-block\">In Washington, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is advocating a diplomatic resolution to conflict with North Korea \u2014 but Trump undercut him on Twitter last Sunday and said Tillerson was \u201c<a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/914497877543735296?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&amp;ref_url=http%3A%2F%2Ffortune.com%2F2017%2F10%2F01%2Ftrump-twitter-north-korea-negotiations%2F\">wasting</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/914497877543735296?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&amp;ref_url=http%3A%2F%2Ffortune.com%2F2017%2F10%2F01%2Ftrump-twitter-north-korea-negotiations%2F\">his time</a>.\u201d Trump\u2019s policy toward North Korea is founded on false assumptions that the Supreme Leader, Kim Jong-un, will give up his nuclear weapons, that China can save the day and that military options are real.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"19\"/><p class=\"p-block\">In Pyongyang, North Korea\u2019s capital, which is full of wide streets and monumental buildings, officials also express little interest in the kind of tough compromises that would be necessary to resolve the crisis.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"20\"/><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cThe situation on the Korean Peninsula is on the eve of the breakout of nuclear war,\u201d Choe, the Foreign Ministry official, told me. \u201cWe can survive\u201d such a war, he added, and he and other officials said that it was not the right time for talks with the U.S.</p><p class=\"p-block\">The North Koreans insist that the U.S. make the first move and drop its sanctions and \u201chostile attitude\u201d \u2014 which won\u2019t happen. And the U.S. is equally unrealistic in insisting that North Korea give up its entire nuclear program.</p><p class=\"p-block\">I told Choe that my visit gave me a sense of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu, reminding me of a trip to Saddam Hussein\u2019s Iraq on the eve of the American invasion. The difference is that a war here would be not just a regional disaster but a nuclear cataclysm.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Choe was unimpressed by my warning. He said that Iraq and Libya had made the mistake of giving up their nuclear programs; in each case, America then ousted the regime. He added that the lesson was obvious, so North Korea will never negotiate away its nuclear warheads.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Still, for all the shadow of possible war, North Korea has had some positive changes. The famine is over (although malnutrition still leaves <a href=\"https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DPRK%20Needs%20and%20Priorities%202017.pdf\">one in four children</a> stunted), the economy has developed and government officials are far more open and savvy than a generation ago.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"25\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Officials used to deny that there was ever any crime in North Korea \u2014 but now they freely concede that this country has thieves, that young women sometimes become pregnant before marriage, that inevitably there\u2019s a measure of corruption. (They do deny that North Korea has any gay people.)</p><p class=\"iframe-holder min300 max300\"><span data-iframe=\"//www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/12/02/opinion/100000003267180.embedded.html\" data-lazy=\"yes\" data-min-width=\"300\"/></p><p class=\"p-block\">North Korea is no longer hermetically sealed, and South Korean pop music and soap operas are smuggled in on flash drives and DVDs from China (watching them is a serious criminal offense). There is also an intranet \u2014 a rigidly controlled domestic version of the internet \u2014 and students learn English from about the third grade. At the best schools, like Pyongyang No. 1 Secondary School, the students are extraordinarily bright and they conversed with us in fluent English, with far more sophistication than on my first visit to the same school in 1989.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"27\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Yet this is still North Korea. I asked these kids if they had ever heard of Beyonc\u00e9 or the Beatles; none had. I asked if they had heard of Facebook. One had, because computer software sometimes referred to it, but he didn\u2019t know what it was.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Radios or televisions that might get foreign broadcasts are illegal, and there is no access to the internet except for foreigners and senior officials. When I arrived at the airport, my luggage was closely searched for pernicious publications, and even my phone was examined.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cWho\u2019s this person,\u201d the customs official asked suspiciously when she saw an Asian woman appear frequently in my photos.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cMy wife,\u201d I explained.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cOh,\u201d she said, deflated. \u201cShe\u2019s pretty.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">Each home or village has a speaker, a link from Big Brother, that drums in propaganda each morning. Religion and civil society are not allowed. Government controls frayed during the terrible famine of the 1990s, when perhaps 10 percent of the population died, but the controls have returned with the economic recovery. This is the most totalitarian state in the history of the world, because it has computers, closed-circuit cameras, mobile phones and other monitoring technologies that Stalin or Mao could only have dreamed of.</p><p class=\"p-block\">North Korea is also sometimes simply weird. Triplets are taken from their parents and raised by the state because they are considered auspicious. The personality cult is unyielding, with every adult wearing pins of \u201cthe Great Leader,\u201d Kim Il-sung, who died in 1994, or his son, \u201cthe Dear Leader,\u201d Kim Jong-il, who died in 2011, and their portraits are in every home, every factory, every classroom.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"34\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Every year, people die trying to rescue the Kim portraits from house fires (whether because of genuine loyalty or to win credit with the authorities), and now this Confucian-style reverence is directed to Kim Jong-un, 33, the scion of the dynasty. His name means \u201cjust and merciful,\u201d and the state media are worshipful about his \u201cbrilliant intelligence, military acumen, matchless courage and outstanding art of command,\u201d as one publication put it.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"35\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Do people really believe this stuff?</p><p class=\"p-block\">I\u2019ve interviewed countless defectors over the years, and they say that there\u2019s more disenchantment among the youth and in the China border area, where Koreans realize that their country has been left behind. But the defectors add that many North Koreans, especially older ones and those distant from the China border, genuinely believe in the system and worship the Kim family \u2014 because they know nothing else.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cMuch of the older generation still remains loyal to the regime,\u201d agreed <a href=\"http://jieunbaek.com/\">Jieun Baek</a>, author of a recent book on how information reaches North Koreans. Attitudes are changing among younger people and those involved in the market economy, she said, but she doesn\u2019t foresee a grass-roots uprising any time soon.</p><p class=\"p-block\">What makes this moment so perilous is that North Koreans are steeped in the idea that they have repeatedly defeated the U.S. \u2014 and can do so again. Every single person we spoke to, from officials to students, voiced certainty that if war breaks out, America will end up in ashes and the Kim regime will emerge victorious.</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cU.S. pride will be squished,\u201d predicted Jo Yong-myong, a 20-year-old university student, who thinks war is likely. \u201cThe big nose of the U.S. will be cut off.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">Maybe Kim himself isn\u2019t so recklessly overconfident. But historically, one risk is that dictators come to believe their own propaganda.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"41\"/><p class=\"p-block\">For a glimpse of the state narrative, I visited the huge new museum in Pyongyang that Kim built for the Korean War. It flatly asserts the standard North Korean line that American imperialists started the war in 1950 by invading the North, rather than (as historians say) that the North started it by sending soldiers into South Korea, and it says that American atrocities in Korea were worse than those of Hitler. \u201cThey killed Korean people for their pleasure,\u201d First Lt. Jang Un-hye, 24, our military guide in the museum, told me as she led me by an exhibit devoted to American use of biological weapons in the war (most historians say this is a fabrication).</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"42\"/><p class=\"p-block\">One hall in the war museum, called \u201cDefeat of the U.S.,\u201d showed a huge diorama with an American soldier\u2019s corpse being picked at by crows, with the sound of their caws filling the room.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Next to the museum is the Pueblo, the American Navy ship seized by North Korea in 1968 \u2014 another victory by the Korean People\u2019s Army over the American imperialists! At the border with South Korea is a museum displaying the ax used to kill two American soldiers there in 1976, also presented as a triumph.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Somehow for all the official hostility, North Koreans tend to be friendly to individual Americans. At the new science and technology tower in Pyongyang, I met a 13-year-old boy, Paek Sin-hyok, who daily participates in military parades at his middle school to mobilize for war. It was his first time meeting Americans, and he said his heart was thumping. I asked about the common North Korean expression that \u201cjust as a wolf cannot become a lamb, so an American imperialist can never change his aggressive nature.\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">\u201cWhat about us?\u201d I asked him. \u201cAre we wolves? Or lambs?\u201d</p><p class=\"p-block\">He struggled with how to answer that politely. \u201cHalf and half,\u201d he said.</p><p class=\"p-block\">With this mutual distrust, it\u2019s easy to see how things might go wrong. I suspect North Korea is rational and cares about self-preservation, and I don\u2019t believe that it would fire off a nuclear missile at Guam or Los Angeles just for the thrill. But a dogfight between a North Korean and an American plane could cause a crisis that escalates. Or Trump could order an airstrike on a North Korean missile during fueling on the launchpad \u2014 and that, every North Korean official said, would lead to war.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V1\" data-pn=\"48\"/><p class=\"p-block\">Both sides are on a hair trigger. That\u2019s why in war games, conflicts quickly escalate \u2014 and why the American military estimated back in 1994 that another Korean war would <a href=\"http://www.newsweek.com/2017/05/05/what-war-north-korea-looks-588861.html\">cause </a><a href=\"http://www.newsweek.com/2017/05/05/what-war-north-korea-looks-588861.html\"> one million casualties</a> and $1 trillion in damage. Today, with the possibility of an exchange of nuclear weapons, the toll could be far greater: <a href=\"http://www.38north.org/2017/10/mzagurek100417/\">One recent study</a> suggested that if North Korea detonated nuclear weapons over Tokyo and Seoul, deaths in those two cities alone could exceed two million.</p><p class=\"a-ok-V2\" data-pn=\"49\"/><p class=\"p-block\">My sense is that both sides are fearful of appearing weak and are trying to intimidate the other with military bluster, but that each would prefer a peaceful resolution \u2014 yet doesn\u2019t know how to get there politically. So how do we get out of this mess?</p><p class=\"p-block\">First, Trump should stop personalizing and escalating the conflict. Second, we need talks without conditions, if only talks about talks: I\u2019d suggest a secret visit to Pyongyang by a senior administration official, as well as discussions with North Korea\u2019s ambassador to the United Nations. Third, human rights have to be part of the agenda, backed by the threat of suspending North Korea\u2019s credentials at the United Nations. Fourth, we should support organizations that smuggle information on USB drives into North Korea; this would be cheap and might contribute to change in the long term. Fifth, increase cyberwarfare, which the U.S. has already used effectively against North Korea. Sixth, let\u2019s enforce tighter sanctions, but only if harnessed to a plausible outcome.</p><p class=\"p-block\">Ultimately, the best hope that is realistic may be a variant of what\u2019s called a \u201cfreeze for a freeze,\u201d with North Korea halting its nuclear and missile tests in exchange for a reduction in sanctions and in U.S.-South Korean military exercises \u2014 as an interim step, preserving the long-term goal of denuclearization. Unfortunately, both sides resist this approach; I was disappointed in the lack of North Korean interest.</p><p class=\"p-block\">So if we can\u2019t work out a freeze for a freeze, realistically the next best option is to settle into long-term mutual deterrence. But that would be risky, not least because we have an American president and a North Korean leader who both seem impetuous, overconfident and temperamentally inclined to escalate any dispute \u2014 and the American mainland increasingly will be in the cross hairs of North Korean nuclear warheads.</p><p class=\"p-block\">I leave North Korea with the same sense of foreboding that I felt after leaving Saddam\u2019s Iraq in 2002. War is preventable, but I\u2019m not sure it will be prevented.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429594": {"score": 4, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:36:03", "url": "https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/09/guide-common-types-two-factor-authentication-web", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"field__item even\"><p><a href=\"https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/how-enable-two-factor-authentication\">Two-factor authentication</a> (or 2FA) is one of the biggest-bang-for-your-buck ways to improve the security of your online accounts. Luckily, it's becoming much more common across the web. With often just a few clicks in a given account's settings, 2FA adds an extra layer of security to your online accounts on top of your password.</p>\n<p>In addition to requesting something you <i>know</i> to log in (in this case, your password), an account protected with 2FA will also request information from something you <i>have (</i>usually your phone or a special USB security key). Once you put in your password, you'll grab a code from a text or app on your phone or plug in your security key before you are allowed to log in. Some platforms call 2FA different things\u2014Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), Two Step Verification (2SV), or Login Approvals\u2014but no matter the name, the idea is the same: Even if someone gets your password, they won't be able to access your accounts unless they also have your phone or security key.</p>\n<p>There are four main types of 2FA <a href=\"https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/12/12-days-2fa-how-enable-two-factor-authentication-your-online-accounts\">in common use by consumer websites</a>, and it's useful to know the differences. Some sites offer only one option; other sites offer a few different options. We recommend checking <a href=\"https://twofactorauth.org/\">twofactorauth.org</a> to find out which sites support 2FA and how, and turning on 2FA for as many of your online accounts as possible. For more visual learners, this <a href=\"https://www.accessnow.org/cms/assets/uploads/2017/09/Choose-the-Best-MFA-for-you.png\">infographic</a> from Access Now\u00a0offers <a href=\"https://www.accessnow.org/decoding-two-factor-authentication-solution-right/\">additional information</a>.</p>\n<p>Finally, the extra layer of protection from 2FA doesn't mean you should use a weak password. Always make <a href=\"https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/creating-strong-passwords%20\">unique, strong passwords</a> for each of your accounts, and then put 2FA on top of those for even better log-in security.</p>\n<h3>SMS 2FA</h3>\n<p/>\n<p>When you enable a site's SMS 2FA option, you'll often be asked to provide a phone number. Next time you log in with your username and password, you'll also be asked to enter a short code (typically 5-6 digits) that gets texted to your phone. This is a very popular option for sites to implement, since many people have an SMS-capable phone number and it doesn't require installing an app. It provides a significant step up in account security relative to just a username and password.</p>\n<p>There are some disadvantages, however. Some people may not be comfortable giving their phone number\u2014a piece of potentially identifying information\u2014to a given website or platform. Even worse, some websites, once they have your phone number for 2FA purposes, will use it for other purposes, like targeted advertising, conversion tracking, and password resets. Allowing password resets based on a phone number provided for 2FA is an especially egregious problem, because it means attackers using phone number takeovers could <a href=\"https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/07/10/att_falls_for_hacker_tricks/\">get access to your account</a> <a href=\"https://blog.cloudflare.com/the-four-critical-security-flaws-that-resulte/\">without even knowing your password</a>.</p>\n<p>Further, you can't log in with SMS 2FA if your phone is dead or can't connect to a mobile network. This can especially be a problem when travelling abroad. Also, it's often possible for an attacker to trick your phone company into assigning your phone number to a different SIM card, allowing them to receive your 2FA codes. <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2017/05/fix-ss7-two-factor-authentication-bank-accounts/\">Flaws in the SS7 telephony protocol</a> can allow the same thing. Note that both of these attacks only reduce the security of your account to the security of your <a href=\"https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/creating-strong-passwords#multi-factorauthenticationandone-timepasswords\">password</a>.</p>\n<h3>Authenticator App / TOTP 2FA</h3>\n<p/>\n<p class=\"ace-line\">Another phone-based option for 2FA is to use an application that generates codes locally based on a secret key. Google Authenticator is a very popular application for this; FreeOTP is a free software alternative. The underlying technology for this style of 2FA is called Time-Based One Time Password (TOTP), and is part of the Open Authentication (OATH) architecture (not to be confused with OAuth, the technology behind \"Log in with Facebook\" and \"Log in with Twitter\" buttons).</p>\n<p class=\"ace-line\">If a site offers this style of 2FA, it will show you a QR code containing the secret key. You can scan that QR code into your application. If you have multiple phones you can scan it multiple times; you can also save the image to a safe place or print it out if you need a backup. Once you've scanned such a QR code, your application will produce a new 6-digit code every 30 seconds. Similar to SMS 2FA, you'll have to enter one of these codes in addition to your username and password in order to log in.</p>\n<p>This style of 2FA improves on SMS 2FA because you can use it even when your phone is not connected to a mobile network, and because the secret key is stored physically on your phone. If someone redirects your phone number to their own phone, they still won't be able to get your 2FA codes. It also has some disadvantages: If your phone dies or gets stolen, and you don't have printed backup codes or a saved copy of the original QR code, you can lose access to your account. For this reason, many sites will encourage you to enable SMS 2FA as a backup. Also, if you log in frequently on different computers, it can be inconvenient to unlock your phone, open an app, and type in the code each time.</p>\n<h3>Push-based 2FA</h3>\n<p>Some systems, like Duo Push and Apple's Trusted Devices method, can send a prompt to one of your devices during login. This prompt will indicate that someone (possibly you) is trying to log in, and an estimated location for the login attempt. You can then approve or deny the attempt.</p>\n<p>This style of 2FA improves on authenticator apps in two ways: Acknowledging the prompt is slightly more convenient than typing in a code, and it is somewhat more resistant to phishing. With SMS and authenticator apps, a phishing site can simply ask for your code in addition to your password, and pass that code along to the legitimate site when logging in as you. Because push-based 2FA generally displays an estimated location based on the IP address from which a login was originated, and most phishing attacks don't happen to be operated from the same IP address ranges as their victims, you may be able to spot a phishing attack in progress by noticing that the estimated location differs from your actual location. However, this requires that you pay close attention to a subtle security indicator. And since location is only estimated, it's tempting to ignore any anomalies. So the additional phishing protection provided by push-based 2FA is limited.</p>\n<p>Disadvantages of push-based 2FA: It's not standardized, so you can't choose from a variety of authenticator apps, and can't consolidate all your push-based credentials in a single app. Also, it requires a working data connection on your phone, while Authenticator apps don't require any connection, and SMS can work on an SMS-only phone plane (or in poor signal areas).</p>\n<h3>FIDO U2F / Security Keys</h3>\n<p/>\n<p>Universal Second Factor (U2F) is a relatively new style of 2FA, typically using small USB, NFC or Bluetooth Low Energy (BTLE) devices often called \"security keys.\" To set it up on a site, you register your U2F device. On subsequent logins, the site will prompt you to connect your device and tap it to allow the login.</p>\n<p>Like push-based 2FA, this means you don't have to type any codes. Under the hood, the U2F device recognizes the site you are on and responds with a code (a signed challenge) that is specific to that site. This means that U2F has a very important advantage over the other 2FA methods: It is actually phishing-proof, because the browser includes the site name when talking to the U2F device, and the U2F device won't respond to sites it hasn't been registered to. U2F is also well-designed from a privacy perspective: You can use the same U2F device on multiple sites, but you have a different identity with each site, so they can't use a single unique device identity for tracking.</p>\n<p>The main downsides of U2F are browser support, mobile support, and cost. Right now only Chrome supports U2F, though Firefox is working on an <a href=\"https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/CryptoEngineering#Web_Authentication\">implementation</a>. The W3C is working on further <a href=\"https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/\">standardizing the U2F protocol for the web</a>, which should lead to further adoption. Additionally, mobile support is challenging, because most U2F devices use USB.</p>\n<p>There are a handful of U2F devices that work with mobile phones over NFC and BTLE. NFC is supported only on Android. On iOS, Apple does not currently allow apps to interact with the NFC hardware, which prevents effective use of NFC U2F. BTLE is much less desirable because a BTLE U2F device requires a battery, and the pairing experience is less intuitive that tapping an NFC device. However, poor mobile support doesn't mean that using U2F prevents you from logging in on mobile. Most sites that support U2F also support TOTP and backup codes. You can log in once on your mobile device using one of those options, while using your phishing-proof U2F device for logins on the desktop. This is particularly effective for mobile sites and apps that only require you to log in once, and keep you logged in.</p>\n<p>Lastly, most other 2FA methods are free, assuming you already have a smartphone. Most U2F devices cost money. Brad Hill has put together <a href=\"https://github.com/hillbrad/U2FReviews/blob/master/README.md\">a review of various U2F devices</a>, which generally cost USD $10-$20. GitHub has written<a href=\"https://github.com/github/SoftU2F\"> a free, software-based U2F authenticator for macOS</a>, but using this as your only U2F device would mean that losing your laptop could result in losing access to your account.</p>\n<h3>Bonus: Backup Codes</h3>\n<p/>\n<p>Sites will often give you a set of ten backup codes to print out and use in case your phone is dead or you lose your security key. Hard-copy backup codes are also useful when traveling, or in other situations where your phone may not have signal or reliable charging. No matter which 2FA method you decide is right for you, it's a good idea to keep these backup codes in a safe place to make sure you don't get locked out of your account when you need them.</p>\n\n</div></div></body></html>"}, "15429083": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 20:32:55", "url": "http://dominoqq81.com/download-aplikasi-99-online-bandar-ceme/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post_content entry-content\">\n\t\t\t  \t\t\t\t\t\t \t\t\t\t\t\t                        \t\t\t\t\t<h2><strong>Download Aplikasi 99 Online Bandar Ceme\u00a0</strong></h2>\n<p><strong>Download aplikasi 99 online bandar ceme</strong> judi online melalui browser smartphone mu dengan mudah dan sekarang juga, dapatkan sebuah permainan ceme yang berkualitas tanpa adanya gangguan koneksi yang lambat ataupun koneksi data server yang dimiliki oleh sebuah situs judi online yang dapat menggangu jalannya permainan anda. "http://zipcpu.com/blog/2017/10/07/study-interfaces.html", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-content\" itemprop=\"articleBody\">\n    \n\n<p>If you are looking for raw computational speed,\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s\nare a well known solution.</p>\n\n<p>Unlike\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s,\na <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\u2019s\nspeed is limited by the fact that the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nmust perform its instructions one at a time, even though many algorithms\ncould be made to run faster.  The\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\u2019s\ngeneral purpose nature simpy slows it down when compared to what\ncould be done within an electronic circuit.</p>\n\n<p>While many of the more modern\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\u2019s\nhave eight or more separate processing cores within a single chip,\nthis still doesn\u2019t compare to the sheer parallelism offered within an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Not only can\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s\nrun their algorithms in parallel, but they can also tailor their silicon for\njust your algorithm.  Modern\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\u2019s support\ndivides, floating point operations, and SIMD instructions, many of which may\nhave nothing to do with what you are trying to accomplish.  The\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a> on the\nother hand has a majority of its logic available for you to configure.\nSo, just how many copies of your algorithm do you wish to configure onto your\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a> solution?</p>\n\n<p>For these same reasons,\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s\ncan be faster than\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit\">GPU</a>\u2019s as well\u2013when\nthe algorithm in question isn\u2019t a video algorithm such as the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit\">GPU</a> was optimized\nfor.</p>\n\n<p>While you might consider using an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-specific_integrated_circuit\">ASIC</a>\nto run your algorithm even faster,\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s\nthey tend to be a lot cheaper to debug and manufacture than\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-specific_integrated_circuit\">ASIC</a>\u2019s\nare.  For example, making a mistake on an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a> usually\nonly costs your time to fix it, whereas a mistake within an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-specific_integrated_circuit\">ASIC</a>\ndesign may cost you many millions of dollars.</p>\n\n<p>For all these reasons, if your goal is speed, you may find yourself\nconsidering an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nas your solution.  They are hands down the most economical means of running\nan algorithm faster than a \n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a> can.</p>\n\n<p>Just don\u2019t neglect the speed of your interface while you consider engineering an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nsolution.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"its-the-interfaces-sir\">It\u2019s the interfaces, Sir</h2>\n\n<p>I\u2019ve noticed, as I\u2019ve personally worked with\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s, that the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nfabric has rarely ever limited my algorithm\u2019s speed and performance needs.\nThat\u2019s always been the easy part of the task.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Want to calculate a\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haar_wavelet\">Haar wavelet</a>\ntransform on an image?\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\u2019s have\nenough logic to run the algorithm many times over within them!  You can run\nthe transform horizontally, vertically, no problem\u2013the raw task is easy for an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>.</p>\n\n<p>That\u2019s not the hard part.</p>\n\n<p>The hard part is feeding the algorithm with data, and getting the results back\nout fast enough to be competitive with the alternatives.</p>\n\n<p>Perhaps an example will help explain what I\u2019m talking about.</p>\n\n<p>Years ago, I had the opportunity to work on a really neat\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Positioning_System\">GPS</a>\nprocessing algorithm.  If you are familiar with\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Positioning_System\">GPS</a> processing,\nyou\u2019ll know that the success of a\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Positioning_System\">GPS</a>\nprocessing algorithm is based upon how many correlations you can do and how\nfast you can do them.</p>\n\n<p>In my case, I was starting with a special algorithm that had been demonstrated\nin software, and had proven itself in software on a general purpose\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>.  My problem\nwas that the algorithm ran slower than pond water.  My team needed speed.\nFor other reasons, there was an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nconnected to to our\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nmicrocontroller.  So we asked ourselves, why not use the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nto speed up the processing?</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Specifically, I was interfacing an\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARM_architecture\">ARM</a>\nbased PXA271 <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XScale\">XScale</a>\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>, built by\n<a href=\"https://www.intel.com\">Intel</a> at the time, with a Spartan 3\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>,\nfrom <a href=\"https://www.xilinx.com\">Xilinx</a>.  The\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Positioning_System\">GPS</a>\nalgorithms performance was dominated by the number\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\u2019s\nthe <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nhad to accomplish.  Why not do those\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\u2019s\nwithin the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>,\nand run them that much faster?</p>\n\n<p>If you look at\n<a href=\"https://www.xilinx.com\">Xilinx</a>\u2019s\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\nIP core, they offer a pipelined\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\ncore that can run one\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\nsample per clock\u2013just like they did when I was working on this\nproblem.  Hence, an N point\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\ncosts N clocks to ingest into the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>,\nand after some (short) processing delay it takes N clocks to get the data\nback out.  How much faster could you get?  The\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARM_architecture\">ARM</a>\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\ntook many more clocks than that to process the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>, so this should\nbe much faster, right?</p>\n\n<p>So I built it.</p>\n\n<p>The\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARM_architecture\">ARM</a>\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nand the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nwere both attached on the same physical bus.  That meant I could have the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nsend the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a> the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\ndata over the bus and then read it back when finished.</p>\n\n<p>With a little bit of debugging, I managed to get it all to work.  It wasn\u2019t\nall that hard technically to build, and speed was very important to\nour application.  So, we ran the algorithm with a stop watch, anxiously\nwaiting to see how much faster it would run.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Much to my displeasure, the new\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nenhanced\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\nalgorithm <em>didn\u2019t run any faster</em>.  Indeed, as I recall, I think it even ran\nslower.  I was shocked.  This wasn\u2019t what I was expecting.</p>\n\n<p>That\u2019s when I learned the painful lesson that an algorithm\u2019s speed is dependent\nupon the interface speed that feeds the algorithm.  In our case, the interface\nwas so slow that just transferring the data to the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nand reading the results back took more time to do than to perform the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\nin the first place.</p>\n\n<h2 id=\"learn-the-interfaces\">Learn the interfaces!</h2>\n\n<p>This is one of the reasons why the study of\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\ndesign needs to include a study of interfaces and how to interact with them.\nIndeed, if you look at one of my favorite\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nwebsites, <a href=\"http://fpga4fun.com\">fpga4fun.com</a>,\nyou\u2019ll find a lot of discussions about how to build interfaces.\nThey discuss <a href=\"http://fpga4fun.com/SerialInterface.html\">serial ports</a>,\n<a href=\"http://www.fpga4fun.com/I2C.html\">I2C</a>,\n<a href=\"http://www.fpga4fun.com/SPI.html\">SPI</a>,\n<a href=\"http://www.fpga4fun.com/JTAG.html\">JTAG</a>,\n<a href=\"http://www.fpga4fun.com/PongGame.html\">simple video ports (play Pong!)</a>,\n<a href=\"http://www.fpga4fun.com/HDMI.html\">HDMI</a>,\nand more.  All of these interfaces have their purpose, and the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nstudent is well served by studying how to interact with them.</p>\n\n<p>Sadly, none of them would\u2019ve been fast enough to rescue my\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform\">FFT</a>\nprocessing needs above.  (Although, \u2026 using the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_memory_access\">DMA</a>\ncontroller on the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XScale\">XScale</a>\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit\">CPU</a>\nmight\u2019ve helped \u2026)</p>\n\n<p>So, for this reason, let me recommend to you that before you spend your whole\ndime on making your\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a> run\nsuper fast with multiple copies of your algorithm all running in parallel,\nthat you at least spend as much (or more) of that dime guaranteeing that the\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\ncan read and write your data fast enough to keep your\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array\">FPGA</a>\nbusy running that super-algorithm.</p>\n\n\n  </div>\n\n\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429260": {"score": 24, "comments": ["I think a real takeaway from this article is that long distance space travel will not be truly realistic until we have a way to simulate earth\u2019s gravity on a ship. This wreaks all kinds of havoc on the vestibular system which leads to short-term issues (think motion sickness like on a boat) which some people don&#x27;t have issues with issues, some grow accustomed to, or some treat with drugs (generally some combination of the three) and much longer-term issues that we really don&#x27;t fully understand but can begin to affect cognition and physical well-being beyond the obvious motion-sickness-like events.<p>The Zubrin book mentioned goes into a lot of this and suggests a novel solution of providing a tiny amount of gravity, basically enough that liquids pour, at the end of a very long tether such that there is minimal difference in gravity between your head and feet and minimal speed so you don&#x27;t sense motion. For me, it's something I've been dreaming of for almost a year.</p><p>I contemplated what it would be like to eat this meal so many times. Now that I'm finally here, it doesn't seem entirely real. story--video\">\n    <h3 class=\"story__headline\">The battery revolution</h3>\n    <figure class=\"story__lead media media--video\">\n        <p class=\"video__countdown\">\n            <button class=\"video__play\">Play Video</button>\n            <span class=\"video__countdown-dial\" data-width=\"100\" data-height=\"100\"/>\n            <button class=\"video__cancel\">Don't Play</button>\n </figure>\n</article></div></div>\n</article></div>\n                <div class=\"item\">\n                        <article class=\"story story--stacked \" data-fm-video-player=\"{&quot;autoPlay&quot;:true,&quot;autoPlayMuted&quot;:true,&quot;loadWhenInView&quot;:false,&quot;showCountdown&quot;:false,&quot;accountId&quot;:&quot;3910869709001&quot;,&quot;playerId&quot;:&quot;r1iMXzgF&quot;,&quot;videoId&quot;:&quot;8310205&quot;,&quot;videoPlayerId&quot;:&quot;story-video-player-8310205&quot;,&quot;adOptions&quot;:{&quot;captionText&quot;:&quot;Ad&quot;,&quot;category&quot;:&quot;video-business/video-businessday&quot;},&quot;trackingOptions&quot;:{&quot;autoPlay&quot;:true,&quot;playCountdown&quot;:false,&quot;playIndex&quot;:7,&quot;category&quot;:&quot;video-business/video-businessday&quot;,&quot;contentType&quot;:&quot;Video&quot;,&quot;duration&quot;:&quot;227307&quot;,&quot;headline&quot;:&quot;The battery revolution&quot;,&quot;lastPublishedDate&quot;:&quot;2017-09-14T04:17:58.686Z&quot;,&quot;playMode&quot;:&quot;continuous&quot;,&quot;producer&quot;:&quot;Bloomberg,&quot;,&quot;site&quot;:&quot;theage&quot;,&quot;source&quot;:&quot;Bloomburg&quot;,&quot;videoId&quot;:&quot;8310205&quot;,&quot;nielsenOptions&quot;:{&quot;sfcode&quot;:&quot;dcr&quot;}}}\">\n    <a href=\"/video/video-business/video-businessday/the-battery-revolution-20170914-4y471.html\">\n        <figure class=\"story__lead media media--video\">\n            <img src=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/4/y/4/7/2/image.related.videoThumbnail.190x107.4y471.png/1505362680823.jpg\" alt=\"null\"/>\n                </figure>\n        <h3 class=\"story__headline\">The battery revolution</h3>\n    </a>\n    <div class=\"is-hidden\">\n        <div class=\"module__wof\">\n            <h3 class=\"module__headline\">The battery revolution</h3>\n            <p>Will there be a day when solar plus batteries will start wiping fossil fuels off the grid?</p>\n            </div>\n        </div>\n</article></div>\n                \n            </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<div class=\"module__wof\">\n        <h3 class=\"module__headline\">Stunning views of the Earth from space</h3>\n        <p>The International Space Station is as far as humans go in space these days, but it is at just the right distance to capture astonishing images of Earth.</p>\n        </div>\n    \n</div><p>It's March 2016, and I've been back on Earth, after a year in space, for precisely 48 hours. I push back from the table and struggle to stand up, feeling like a very old man getting out of a recliner.\u00a0</p><p>\"Stick a fork in me, I'm done,\" I announce. Everyone laughs and encourages me to get some rest. I start the journey to my bedroom: about 20 steps from the chair to the bed. On the third step, the floor seems to lurch under me, and I stumble into a planter. Of course, it isn't the floor \u2013 it's my vestibular system trying to read just to Earth's gravity. I'm getting used to walking again.</p><figure class=\"media  media--photo social--sharing\" data-fm-image-sharing=\"twitterTag:'theage'\" data-event-tracking-enabled=\"false\" data-track-data=\"{&quot;name_component&quot;:&quot;Inline_Image&quot;}\" itemscope=\"\" itemprop=\"image\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\">\n    <img alt=\"Scott Kelly inside a Soyuz simulator ahead of his mission. This capsule would be his escape pod in case of a disaster.\" title=\"\" src=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/b/5/image.related.articleLeadwide.620x349.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/><figcaption class=\"media__caption\">\n    Scott Kelly inside a Soyuz simulator ahead of his mission. This capsule would be his escape pod in case of a disaster.\u00a0<cite>Photo: NASA/Bill Ingalls/Courtesy of Penguin Random House </cite>\n    </figcaption>\n\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/b/5/image.related.articleLeadwide.620x349.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"349\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"620\"/></figure><p>\"That's the first time I've seen you stumble,\" Mark says. \"You're doing pretty good.\" A former astronaut, Mark knows from personal experience what it's like to come back to Earth. As I walk by Samantha, I put my hand on her shoulder and she smiles up at me.</p><p>I make it to my bedroom without incident and close the door behind me. Every part of my\u00a0body hurts. All my joints and all of my muscles are protesting the crushing pressure of gravity. I'm also nauseated, though I haven't thrown up. I strip off my clothes and get into bed, relishing the feeling of sheets, the light pressure of the blanket over me, the fluff of the pillow under my head.</p>\n<p>All these are things I've missed dearly for the past year. I can hear the happy chatter of my family behind the door, voices I haven't heard for a long time without the distortion of phones bouncing signals off satellites. I drift off to sleep to the comforting sound of their talking and laughing.</p><div id=\"subscribe-newsletter\" class=\"panel panel--subscribe\" data-channel-key=\"QeFV9eVnngJX9eFB2HyKgQ\" data-newsletter-id=\"10092\" data-authentication-url=\"https://authman.f2.com.au/oauth2/authorise\" data-subscription-url=\"https://api.myfairfax.com.au/services/v3/newsletters/newsletterIdPlaceholder/subscribe\" data-newsletter-env=\"prod\">\n        <p id=\"subscribe-newsletter-success\" class=\"content is-hidden\">\n                <header class=\"header\">\n                    <h2 class=\"heading\">\n                        <span>You will now receive updates from</span>\n                        <span class=\"newsletter-name\">Breaking News Alert</span>\n                    </h2>\n                </header>\n            </p>\n        <div id=\"newsletterSignUpContent\" class=\"content\">\n            <header class=\"header\">\n                <p class=\"newsletter-icon\">\n                    <span class=\"icon--email\"/>\n                </p>\n                <h2 class=\"heading\">Breaking News Alert</h2>\n            </header>\n            <p>Get the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.</p>\n        </div>\n\n        \n\n        \n    </div>\n<p>A crack of light wakes me: Is it morning? No, it's just Amiko coming to bed. I've only been asleep for a couple of hours but I feel delirious. It's a struggle to come to consciousness enough to move, to tell her how awful I feel. I'm seriously nauseated now, feverish, and my pain has gotten worse. This isn't like how I felt after my last mission. This is much, much worse.</p><figure class=\"media  media--portrait-photo social--sharing\" data-fm-image-sharing=\"twitterTag:'theage'\" data-event-tracking-enabled=\"false\" data-track-data=\"{&quot;name_component&quot;:&quot;Inline_Image&quot;}\" itemscope=\"\" itemprop=\"image\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\">\n    <img alt=\"Scott Kelly and partner Amiko in Red Square, Moscow.\" title=\"\" src=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/a/z/image.related.articleLeadNarrow.300x0.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/><figcaption class=\"media__caption\">\n    Scott Kelly and partner Amiko in Red Square, Moscow.\u00a0<cite>Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite>\n    </figcaption>\n\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/a/z/image.related.articleLeadNarrow.300x0.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"0\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"300\"/></figure><p>\"Amiko,\" I finally manage to say. She is alarmed by the sound of my voice.</p><p>\"What is it?\" Her hand is on my arm, then on my forehead.</p><figure class=\"media  media--portrait-photo social--sharing\" data-fm-image-sharing=\"twitterTag:'theage'\" data-event-tracking-enabled=\"false\" data-track-data=\"{&quot;name_component&quot;:&quot;Inline_Image&quot;}\" itemscope=\"\" itemprop=\"image\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ImageObject\">\n    <img alt=\"Twin future astronauts Mark (left) and Scott Kelly, in 1967.\" title=\"\" src=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/a/w/image.related.articleLeadNarrow.300x0.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/><figcaption class=\"media__caption\">\n    Twin future astronauts Mark (left) and Scott Kelly, in 1967.\n\u00a0<cite>Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</cite>\n    </figcaption>\n\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.fairfaxstatic.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/a/w/image.related.articleLeadNarrow.300x0.gyn9iw.png/1507489017468.jpg\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"height\" content=\"0\"/>\n<meta itemprop=\"width\" content=\"300\"/></figure><p>Her skin feels chilled, but it's just that I'm so hot. \"I don't feel good,\" I say.</p><p><strong>Over the past year</strong>, I've spent 340 days alongside Russian astronaut Mikhail \"Misha\" Kornienko on the International Space Station (ISS). As part of NASA's planned journey to Mars, we're members of a program designed to discover what effect such long-term time in space has on human beings. This was my fourth trip to space, and by the end of the mission I'd spent 520 days up there, more than any other NASA astronaut. Amiko has gone through the whole process with me as my main support once before, when I spent 159 days on the ISS in 2010-11. I had a reaction to coming back from space that time, but it was nothing like this.</p><blockquote>\n        <p>This exposure would increase my risk of a fatal cancer for the rest of my life.</p>\n        </blockquote>\n<div> \n <div class=\"cT-imageLandscape lead\">\n  <img alt=\"The International Space Station, where Scott Kelly spent 340 consecutive days.\" src=\"http://www.smh.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/b/2/image.imgtype.articleLeadwide.620x0.png/1507092081451.png\" title=\"\"/> \n  <p>The International Space Station, where Scott Kelly spent 340 consecutive days.<cite><i> Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</i></cite></p>\n </div> \n</div><p>I struggle to get up. Find the edge of the bed. Feet down. Sit up. Stand up. At every stage I\u00a0feel like I'm fighting through quicksand. When I'm finally vertical, the pain in my legs is awful, and on top of that pain I feel a sensation that's even more alarming: it feels as though all the blood in my body is rushing to my legs, like the sensation of the blood rushing to your head when you do a handstand, but in reverse.</p><p>I can feel the tissue in my legs swelling. I shuffle my way to the bath room, moving my weight from one foot to the other with deliberate effort. Left. Right. Left. Right. I make it to the bathroom, flip on the light, and look down at my legs. They are swollen and alien stumps, not legs at all. \"Oh shit,\" I say. \"Amiko, come look at this.\" She kneels down and squeezes one ankle, and it squishes like a water balloon. She looks up at me with worried eyes. \"I can't even feel your ankle bones,\" she says.</p><p>\"My skin is burning, too,\" I tell her. Amiko frantically examines me. I have a strange rash all over my back, the backs of my legs, the back of my head and neck \u2013 everywhere I was in contact with the bed. I can feel her cool hands moving over my inflamed skin. \"It looks like an allergic rash,\" she says. \"Like hives.\"</p><p>I use the bathroom and shuffle back to bed, wondering what I should do. Normally if I woke up feeling like this, I would go to the emergency room. But no one at the hospital will have seen symptoms of having been in space for a year. I crawl back into bed, trying to find a way to lie down without touching my rash.</p><p>I can hear Amiko rummaging in the medicine cabinet. She returns with two ibuprofen and a glass of water. As she settles down, I can tell from her every movement, every breath, that she is worried about me. We both knew the risks of the mission I signed on for. After six years together, I can understand her perfectly, even in the wordless dark.</p><p>As I try to will myself to sleep, I wonder whether my friend Misha, by now back in Moscow, is also suffering from swollen legs and painful rashes. I suspect so. This is why we volunteered for this mission, after all: to discover more about how the human body is affected by long-term space flight. Scientists will study the data on Misha and my 53-year-old self for the rest of our lives and beyond. Our space agencies won't be able to push out farther into space, to a destination like Mars, until we can learn more about how to strengthen the weakest links in the chain that make space flight possible: the human body and mind.</p><p>People often ask me why I volunteered for this mission, knowing the risks: the risk of launch, the risk inherent in space walks, the risk of returning to Earth, the risks I would be exposed to every moment I lived in a metal container orbiting the Earth at 28,100 kilometres an hour. I have a few answers I give to this question, but none of them feels fully satisfying to me. None of them quite answers it.</p><div> \n <div class=\"cT-imageLandscape lead\">\n  <img alt=\"Scott Kelly (at left) undertaking a dangerous space walk outside the International Space Station\" src=\"http://www.smh.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/a/y/image.imgtype.articleLeadwide.620x0.png/1507092076777.png\" title=\"\"/> \n  <p>Scott Kelly (at left) undertaking a dangerous space walk outside the International Space Station.<cite><i> Photo: Courtesy of Penguin Random House Australia</i></cite></p>\n </div> \n</div><p><strong>A normal mission\u00a0to the International Space Station</strong> lasts five to six months, so scientists have a good deal of data about what happens to the human body in space for that length of time. But very little is known about what occurs after month six. The symptoms may get precipitously worse in the ninth month, for instance, or they may level off. We don't know, and there is only one way to find out.</p><p>During our mission, Misha and I collected various types of data for studies on our selves, which took a significant amount of our time. Because Mark and I were identical twins, I also took part in an extensive study comparing the two of us throughout the year, down to the genetic level. The ISS was a world-class orbiting laboratory, and in addition to the human studies of which I was one of the main subjects, I also spent a lot of my time during the year working on other experiments, like fluid physics, botany, combustion and Earth observation.</p><p>When I talked about the ISS to audiences, I always shared with them the importance of the science being done there. But to me, it was just as important that the station was serving as a foothold for our species in space. From here, we could learn more about how to push out further into the cosmos. The costs were high, as were the risks.</p><p>On my previous flight\u00a0to the space station, a mission of 159 days, I lost bone mass, my muscles atrophied, and my blood redistributed itself in my body, which strained and shrank the walls of my heart. More troubling, I experienced problems with my vision, as many other astronauts had. I had been exposed to more than 30 times the radiation of a person on Earth, equivalent to about 10 chest X-rays every day. This exposure would increase my risk of a fatal cancer for the rest of my life.</p><p>None of this compared, though, to the most troubling risk: that something bad could happen to someone I love while I was in space with no way for me to come home.</p><p><strong>I had\u00a0been on the station for a week</strong>, and was getting better at knowing where I was when I first woke up. If I had a headache, I knew it was because I had drifted too far from the vent blowing clean air at my face. I was often still disoriented about how my body was positioned: I would wake up convinced that I was upside down, because in the dark and without gravity, my inner ear took a random guess as to how my body was positioned in the small space. When I turned on a light, I had a sort of visual illusion that the room was rotating rapidly as it reoriented itself around me, though I knew it was actually my brain readjusting in response to new sensory input.</p><p>The light in my crew quarters took a minute to warm up to full brightness. The space was just barely big enough for me and my sleeping bag, two laptops, some clothes, toiletries, photos of Amiko and my daughters, a few paperback books. I looked at my schedule for today. I clicked through new emails, stretched and yawned, then fished around in my toiletries bag, attached to the wall down by my left knee, for my toothpaste and toothbrush. I brushed, still in my sleeping bag, then swallowed the toothpaste and chased it with a sip of water out of a bag with a straw. There wasn't really a good way to spit in space.</p><p><strong>I didn't\u00a0get to spend time outside the station</strong> until my first of two planned space walks, which was almost seven months in. This was one of the things that some people found difficult to imagine about living on the space station, the fact that I couldn't step outside when I felt like it. Putting on a spacesuit and leaving the station for a space walk was an hours-long process that required the full attention of at least three people on station and dozens more on the ground.</p><p>Space walks were the most dangerous thing we did in orbit. Even if the station was on fire, even if it was filling up with poison gas, even if a meteoroid had crashed through a module and outer space was rushing in, the only way to escape the station was in a Soyuz capsule, which also needed preparation and planning to depart safely. We practised dealing with emergency scenarios regularly, and in many of these drills we raced to prepare the Soyuz as quickly as we could. No one had ever had to use the Soyuz as a lifeboat, and no one hoped to.</p><p><strong>I opened\u00a0a food container</strong> attached to the wall and fished out a pouch of dehydrated coffee with cream and sugar. I floated over to the hot-water dispenser in the ceiling of the lab, which worked by insert ing a needle into a nozzle on the bag. When the bag was full, I replaced the needle with a drinking straw \u2013 this way the liquid didn't escape into the module. It had been oddly unsatisfying at first to drink coffee from a plastic bag sipped through a straw, but now I wasn't bothered by it.</p><p>I flipped through the breakfast options, looking for a packet of the granola I liked. Unfortunately, everyone else seemed to like it, too. I chose some dehydrated eggs instead and reconstituted them with the same hot water dispenser, then warmed up some irradiated sausage links in the food warmer box, which looked a lot like a metal briefcase. I cut the bag open, then, since we had no sink, cleaned the scissors by licking them (we each had our own scissors). I spooned the eggs out of the bag onto a tortilla \u2013 conveniently, surface tension held them in place \u2013 added the sausage and some hot sauce, rolled it up, and ate the burrito while catch ing up with the morning's news on <em>CNN</em>.</p><p>All the while I was holding myself in place with my right big toe tucked ever so slightly under a handrail on the floor. Handrails were placed on the walls, floors and ceilings of every module and at the hatches where modules connected, allowing us to propel ourselves through the modules or to stay in place rather than drifting away. There were a lot of things about living in weightlessness that were fun, but eating was not one of them. I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal, relaxing and pausing to connect with other people.</p><div> \n <div class=\"cT-imageLandscape lead\">\n  <img alt=\"I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal. \" src=\"http://www.smh.com.au/content/dam/images/g/y/u/7/b/a/image.imgtype.articleLeadwide.620x0.png/1507092086244.png\" title=\"\"/> \n  <p>\"I missed being able to sit in a chair while eating a meal, relaxing and pausing to connect with other people,\" writes Kelly of life on the ISS. <cite><i> Photo: Marco Grob</i></cite></p>\n </div> \n</div><p><strong>More than 400 experiments </strong>took place on ISS during this expedition. NASA scientists talked about the research falling into two major categories. The first had to do with studies that might benefit life on Earth. These included research on the properties of chemicals that could be used in new drugs, combustion studies that were unlocking new ways to get more efficiency out of the fuel we burnt, and the development of new materials. The second large category had to do with solving problems for future space exploration: testing new life-support equipment, solving technical problems of spaceflight and studying new ways of handling the demands of the human body in space.</p><p>Science took up about a third of my time, human studies about three-quarters of that. I had to take blood samples from myself and my crew mates for analysis back on Earth, and I kept a log of everything, from what I ate to my moods. I tested my reaction skills at various points throughout the day. I took ultrasounds of blood vessels, my heart, my eyes and my muscles. I also took part in an experiment called Fluid Shifts, using a device that sucked the blood down to the lower half of my body, where gravity normally kept it. This tested a leading theory about why space flight caused damage to some astronauts' vision.</p><p>In fact, there was much crossover between these categories of research. If we could learn how to counteract the devastating impact of bone loss in microgravity, the solutions could well be applied to osteoporosis and other bone diseases. If we could learn how to keep our hearts healthy in space, that knowledge could be useful on Earth.\u00a0</p><p>The effects of living in space looked a lot like the effects of ageing, which affected us all. The\u00a0lettuce we grew was a study for future space travel \u2013 astronauts on their way to Mars will have no fresh food but what they can grow \u2013 but it also taught us more about growing food efficiently on Earth. The ISS's closed water system, where we processed our urine into clean water, will be crucial for getting to Mars, but it also has promising implications for treating water on Earth \u2013 especially in places where clean water was scarce.</p><p><strong>I tell\u00a0my flight surgeon, Steve,</strong> that I feel well enough to get right to work immediately upon returning from space, and I do, but within a few days I feel much worse. This is what it means to have allowed my body to be used for science. I will be a test subject for the rest of my life. A few months after arriving back on\u00a0Earth, though, I feel distinctly better. I've been travelling the country and the world talking about my experiences in space. It's gratifying to see how curious people are about my mission, how much children instinctively feel the excitement and wonder of space flight, and how many people think, as I do, that Mars is the next step.</p><p>I also know that if we want to go to Mars, it will be very, very difficult, it will cost a great deal of money and it may likely cost human lives. But I know now that if we decide to do it, we can.\u00a0</p><p><strong>Edited extract from <em>Endurance: A Year in Space, A Lifetime of Discovery</em> by Scott Kelly (Doubleday, $35), published on October 19.</strong></p></div>\n</div></body></html>"}, "15429603": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:39:10", "url": "https://bitsandscrews.com/aols-instant-messenger-service-aim-will-go-permanently-offline-in-december-after-20-years", "text": "<html><body><div><body id=\"readabilityBody\"><p>Error detected by Application Firewall. However, like others have pointed out, sometimes using a regex is quicker, easier, and gets the job done if you know the data format.</p>\n\n<p>Microsoft actually has a section of <a href=\"http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg578045.aspx\" rel=\"noreferrer\">Best Practices for Regular Expressions in the .NET Framework</a> and specifically talks about <a href=\"http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg578045.aspx#InputSource\" rel=\"noreferrer\">Consider[ing] the Input Source</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Regular Expressions do have limitations, but have you considered the following?</p>\n\n<p>The .NET framework is unique when it comes to regular expressions in that it supports <a href=\"http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bs2twtah.aspx#balancing_group_definition\" rel=\"noreferrer\">Balancing Group Definitions</a>.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>For this reason, I believe you CAN parse XML using regular expressions.  Note however, that it <strong>must be valid XML</strong> (<em>browsers are very forgiving of HTML and allow bad XML syntax inside HTML</em>).  This is possible since the \"Balancing Group Definition\" will allow the regular expression engine to act as a PDA.</p>\n\n<p>Quote from article 1 cited above:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p><strong>.NET Regular Expression Engine</strong></p>\n  \n  <p>As described above properly balanced constructs cannot be described by\n  a regular expression. However, the .NET regular expression engine\n  provides a few constructs that allow balanced constructs to be\n  recognized. </p>\n  \n  <ul>\n  <li><code>(?&lt;group&gt;)</code> - pushes the captured result on the capture stack with\n  the name group.</li>\n  <li><code>(?&lt;-group&gt;)</code> - pops the top most capture with the name group off the\n  capture stack.</li>\n  <li><code>(?(group)yes|no)</code> - matches the yes part if there exists a group\n  with the name group otherwise matches no part.</li>\n  </ul>\n  \n  <p>These constructs allow for a .NET regular expression to emulate a\n  restricted PDA by essentially allowing simple versions of the stack\n  operations: push, pop and empty. The simple operations are pretty much\n  equivalent to increment, decrement and compare to zero respectively.\n  This allows for the .NET regular expression engine to recognize a\n  subset of the context-free languages, in particular the ones that only\n  require a simple counter. This in turn allows for the non-traditional\n  .NET regular expressions to recognize individual properly balanced\n  constructs.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Consider the following regular expression:</p>\n\n<pre class=\"lang-none prettyprint-override\"><code>(?=&lt;ul\\s+id=\"matchMe\"\\s+type=\"square\"\\s*&gt;)\n(?&gt;\n   &lt;!-- .*? --&gt;                  |\n   &lt;[^&gt;]*/&gt;                      |\n   (?&lt;opentag&gt;&lt;(?!/)[^&gt;]*[^/]&gt;)  |\n   (?&lt;-opentag&gt;&lt;/[^&gt;]*[^/]&gt;)     |\n   [^&lt;&gt;]*\n)*\n(?(opentag)(?!))\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Use the flags:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Singleline</li>\n<li>IgnorePatternWhitespace (not necessary if you collapse regex and remove all whitespace)</li>\n<li>IgnoreCase (not necessary)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Regular Expression Explained (inline)</h2>\n\n<pre class=\"lang-none prettyprint-override\"><code>(?=&lt;ul\\s+id=\"matchMe\"\\s+type=\"square\"\\s*&gt;) # match start with &lt;ul id=\"matchMe\"...\n(?&gt;                                        # atomic group / don't backtrack (faster)\n   &lt;!-- .*? --&gt;                 |          # match xml / html comment\n   &lt;[^&gt;]*/&gt;                     |          # self closing tag\n   (?&lt;opentag&gt;&lt;(?!/)[^&gt;]*[^/]&gt;) |          # push opening xml tag\n   (?&lt;-opentag&gt;&lt;/[^&gt;]*[^/]&gt;)    |          # pop closing xml tag\n   [^&lt;&gt;]*                                  # something between tags\n)*                                         # match as many xml tags as possible\n(?(opentag)(?!))                           # ensure no 'opentag' groups are on stack\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>You can try this at <a href=\"http://derekslager.com/blog/posts/2007/09/a-better-dotnet-regular-expression-tester.ashx\" rel=\"noreferrer\">A Better .NET Regular Expression Tester</a>.</p>\n\n<p>I used the sample source of:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;html&gt;\n&lt;body&gt;\n&lt;div&gt;\n   &lt;br /&gt;\n   &lt;ul id=\"matchMe\" type=\"square\"&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;stuff...&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;more stuff&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;\n          &lt;div&gt;\n               &lt;span&gt;still more&lt;/span&gt;\n               &lt;ul&gt;\n                    &lt;li&gt;Another &amp;gt;ul&amp;lt;, oh my!&lt;/li&gt;\n                    &lt;li&gt;...&lt;/li&gt;\n               &lt;/ul&gt;\n          &lt;/div&gt;\n      &lt;/li&gt;\n   &lt;/ul&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This found the match:</p>\n\n<pre><code>   &lt;ul id=\"matchMe\" type=\"square\"&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;stuff...&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;more stuff&lt;/li&gt;\n      &lt;li&gt;\n          &lt;div&gt;\n               &lt;span&gt;still more&lt;/span&gt;\n               &lt;ul&gt;\n                    &lt;li&gt;Another &amp;gt;ul&amp;lt;, oh my!&lt;/li&gt;\n                    &lt;li&gt;...&lt;/li&gt;\n               &lt;/ul&gt;\n          &lt;/div&gt;\n      &lt;/li&gt;\n   &lt;/ul&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>although it actually came out like this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;ul id=\"matchMe\" type=\"square\"&gt;           &lt;li&gt;stuff...&lt;/li&gt;           &lt;li&gt;more stuff&lt;/li&gt;           &lt;li&gt;               &lt;div&gt;                    &lt;span&gt;still more&lt;/span&gt;                    &lt;ul&gt;                         &lt;li&gt;Another &amp;gt;ul&amp;lt;, oh my!&lt;/li&gt;                         &lt;li&gt;...&lt;/li&gt;                    &lt;/ul&gt;               &lt;/div&gt;           &lt;/li&gt;        &lt;/ul&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Lastly, I really enjoyed Jeff Atwood's article:  <a href=\"http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/2009/11/parsing-html-the-cthulhu-way.html\" rel=\"noreferrer\">Parsing Html The Cthulhu Way</a>.  Funny enough, it cites the answer to this question that currently has over 4k votes.</p>\n    </div>&#13;\n    </div></body></html>"}, "15429372": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 21:42:25", "url": "https://shotsinshorts.com/ui-avatars-api-helps-generate-avatars-user-initials/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"post-body\">\n\t\t\t<p>If you are frustrated by the limitations of Gravatar like we must pass in the parameters as sub-directories, instead of query-parameters. It can also be considered as an alternative of SVG based user initials avatar generator.</p>\n<p>Whereas What makes it special is that it is very well executed, with a sane and simple API, good performance considerations, and it fits its purpose perfectly.</p>\n<h3>How to use:</h3>\n<p>All requests return\u2019s an image stream to be used directly in a <strong>&lt;img/&gt;</strong> tag.</p>\n<p>Generate an avatar with default settings, for user \u201cJohn Doe\u201d.<br/>\n<em>GET https://ui-avatars.com/api/?name=John+Doe</em></p>\n<p>Generate a blue avatar<br/>\n<em>GET https://ui-avatars.com/api/?background=0D8ABC&amp;color=fff</em></p>\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n<p>It also supports some of the\u00a0Unicode scripts/languages that are not supported by the typical fonts.
