Even among the tech industry's most valuable companies, two of the more visible CEOs, Google's Sundar Pichai, and Microsoft's Satya Nadella, are both Indian. Which is why it might come as a surprise that Asians\u2014especially Asian women\u2014are among the least likely to be promoted into leadership positions, according to a new study from <a href=\"http://www.ascendleadership.org\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"250\">Ascend Leadership</a>, a nonprofit group for Asian professionals.</p><p data-reactid=\"252\">\u201cThat\u2019s why we call the report the Illusion of Asian Success,\u201d says Buck Gee, a former vice president at Cisco and one of the authors of the study. The natural assumption is that if Asians are more prevalent in the workforce, they will be more prevalent at the top. But \u201cwhen you look at the hard data, that is a fallacy,\u201d says Gee.</p><p data-reactid=\"253\">Gee and his co-author Denise Peck, also a former vice president at Cisco, studied a data set of 184,776 employees, 63,299 managers, and 12,856 executives, information collected by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission between 2007 and 2015 from technology companies in the San Francisco and San Jose areas, a group that covers Apple, Facebook, Cisco, Twitter, Intel, HP, and Yelp. (The EEOC has this data because Title VII of the Civil Rights act requires private employers with more than 100 employees to submit confidential reports.)  The study focuses only on the promotion within an organization, not hiring or retention. The authors measured leadership representation by comparing the percentage of entry-level \u201cprofessionals\u201d from a particular group, say Asian women, the percentage of \u201cexecutives,\u201d according to job categories in the EEOC reports, which also includes \u201cadministrative support\u201d and \u201cservice workers.\u201d</p><p data-reactid=\"287\">After sifting through the data, the authors concluded that race is a stronger impediment than gender when it comes to climbing Silicon Valley\u2019s corporate ladder. Representation of white women in leadership roles improved by 17 percent between 2007 and 2015, whereas for all other minority groups, the percentage went down.</p><p data-reactid=\"288\">\u201cWhite women are continuing to benefit from the system of racism, even when they are also experiencing discrimination because of their gender,\u201d says Hannah Lucal, associate director at <a href=\"http://breakingthemold.openmic.org\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"290\">Open Mic</a>, a nonprofit group that works with socially conscious investors. Lucal says that companies should approach the issue with an understanding that sexism and racism are structural issues that always operating in tandem, rather than interpret studies like this as a hierarchy of discrimination.</p><figure class=\"image-embed-component\" data-reactid=\"292\"><p class=\"component-lazy pending\" data-component=\"Lazy\" data-reactid=\"293\"/><figcaption class=\"caption-component\" data-reactid=\"294\"><p class=\"caption-component__credit-container\" data-reactid=\"296\"><i aria-label=\"Photo attribution\" class=\" ui-chart icon icon--16\" data-reactid=\"297\"/><cite class=\"caption-component__credit\" data-reactid=\"298\">Ascend Leadership</cite></p></figcaption></figure><p data-reactid=\"299\">Ascend\u2019s findings revealed unique diversity issues for each segment. For black women, the data pointed to potential hiring and retention issues. There was a 13 percent decline from 2007 and 2015 in the number of black women who even entered the tech workforce. The number of Hispanic women, on the other hand, declined slightly at the professional and managerial level, but they had the worst leadership representation after Asian women.</p><p data-reactid=\"302\">Gee says this study came about because an earlier <a href=\"http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/ascendleadership.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Research/HiddenInPlainSight_Paper_042.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"304\">report in 2015</a> that used EEOC data from companies like Google and LinkedIn ended up on the desk of Jenny Yang, the outgoing commissioner of the EEOC. Yang asked if the lower proportion of Asian executives was the result of discrimination and might be applicable for lawsuits, Gee says. He told her no. \u201cWe have never seen any overt discrimination or policies that create these disparities,\u201d Gee explains. Rather, after conversations with 60 or 70 Asian executives, the authors say they noticed a pattern of cultural traits among some Asians that did not align with leadership expectations in Western corporate culture, such as risk-taking and being confrontational.</p><p data-reactid=\"306\">Gee gave the example of an executive who started the first Asian affinity group at Intel decades ago. He noticed that Chinese engineers were unhappy and not succeeding in Intel\u2019s culture of \u201cconstructive conflict,\u201d which involved heated debates during meetings.</p><p data-reactid=\"307\">\u201cSome people call it unconscious bias. For Asians, it\u2019s actually a very conscious bias,\u201d says Gee. Studies show that assumptions that Asians are good at math, science, and technology make it easier for them to get in the door, but the same bias is reversed when it comes to leadership roles, he says.</p><p data-reactid=\"308\">Department of Labor lawsuits have touched on differential treatment at tech companies based on race. In April, Palantir paid a $1.7 million settlement after a Department of Labor investigation found discrimination against Asian employees. There is an ongoing <a href=\"https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ofccp/ofccp20170118-0\" target=\"_blank\" data-reactid=\"310\">investigation</a> into Oracle for favoring Asian workers in recruiting and hiring for technical roles, but paying white men more than women, black, and Asian employees.</p><p data-reactid=\"312\">Several advocates and investors have pressured publically-traded companies like Apple and Alphabet to better diversify their ranks. In 2015, Jesse Jackson\u2019s group Rainbow PUSH Coalition, a nonprofit, began demanding diversity numbers from tech companies, including showing up at shareholder meetings for Facebook and Amazon. In a statement to WIRED, Jackson said, \u201cTech companies over and over have said they 'must do better' but the fact remains that blacks and Latinos still make up just 2 to 3 percent of the tech workforce, even less representation in the C-suites and board rooms.\u201d</p><p data-reactid=\"313\">Zevin Asset Management, a firm with more than $600 million under management, has made a shareholder proposal to increase diversity at Apple. Pat Miguel Tomaino, an associate director of socially responsible investing at Zevin, has long been concerned about the lack of diversity in the tech sector becoming a material issue that affects hiring talented people and representing the needs of their consumers. Tech has been talking a good game \u201cand then falling on their faces when it comes time to train, properly incentive, and promote those talented people,\u201d costing the company time and money for preventable reasons, he says.</p><p data-reactid=\"314\">Lucal says that the conversation about diversity in the tech industry needs to move beyond just the numbers and examine who has power in terms of influence and decision-making. Otherwise, efforts to improve diversity are limited to who is in the room, and not who is at the table. Studies like this show it\u2019s time for a new table, she says.</p></div></div></body></html>"}, "15429109": {"score": 59, "comments": ["This looks very interesting (and I am interested) but the article seems like a stub. Hence, the submission claiming it was probably the same thing.<p>While we&#x27;re at it, here&#x27;s some other links on this sort of thing all of you might enjoy:<p><a href=\"http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.cs.cornell.edu&#x2F;talc&#x2F;\" rel=\"nofollow\">http:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.cs.cornell.edu&#x2F;talc&#x2F;</a><p><a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;project-everest.github.io&#x2F;assets&#x2F;vale2017.pdf\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;project-everest.github.io&#x2F;assets&#x2F;vale2017.pdf</a><p><a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;project-everest&#x2F;vale\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;github.com&#x2F;project-everest&#x2F;vale</a>", "&gt; I don&#x27;t know Coq well enough to tell you if this is the source code to the CoqASM paper with the quick skim I did before work.<p>It is.<p>See also <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.microsoft.com&#x2F;en-us&#x2F;research&#x2F;publication&#x2F;high-level-separation-logic-low-level-code&#x2F;\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;www.microsoft.com&#x2F;en-us&#x2F;research&#x2F;publication&#x2F;high-le...</a> for details on the program logic (ie. &quot;Hoare triples for x86&quot;).", "src: <a href=\"https:&#x2F;&#x2F;lobste.rs&#x2F;s&#x2F;kewmce&#x2F;x86_proved_coq_library_for_modelling\" rel=\"nofollow\">https:&#x2F;&#x2F;lobste.rs&#x2F;s&#x2F;kewmce&#x2F;x86_proved_coq_library_for_modell...</a>"], "time": "2017-10-08 20:40:45", "url": "https://x86proved.codeplex.com/", "text": "UNAVAILABLE TEXT BY URL https://x86proved.codeplex.com/"}, "15429624": {"score": 3, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 22:43:26", "url": "https://akomljen.com/stateful-applications-kubernetes/", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"kg-card-markdown\"><p>Kubernetes and stateless applications work just out of the box. You can create a replicated application really fast. This is because the application doesn't store any data and simple load balancing will do the job when it comes to scaling it. However, if you want to run any application that stores the data somewhere, you care about the order how the application is started, or you want a stable hostname and network ID, then we are talking about the stateful applications and in Kubernetes world <code>StatefulSet</code> is the type of workload object you need to use. Unlike <code>Deployment</code> there are some differences. This post will help you to get started.</p>\n<h3 id=\"statefulapplication\">Stateful application</h3>\n<p>I will not show just another example of <code>StatefulSet</code> workload definition. There are many examples available out there. So, find one and start it. Now, if you list Pods of stateful application, the first thing you will notice is that the Pods are not named with some autogenerated IDs, instead, you will get something like this:</p>\n<pre><code>$ kubectl get po\nNAME          READY     STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE\nzookeeper-0   1/1       Running   0          31m\nzookeeper-1   1/1       Running   0          31m\nzookeeper-2   1/1       Running   0          31m\n</code></pre>\n<p>As you can see each Pod will get a unique and stable name of the form <code>&lt;StatefulSet-Name&gt;-&lt;Ordinal-Index&gt;</code>. Also, because the controller starts Pods one at a time, <code>zookeeper-1</code> will not be deployed before <code>zookeeper-0</code> is running and ready (you can achieve this with liveness and readiness probes).</p>\n<h3 id=\"headlessservice\">Headless service</h3>\n<p>To ensure stable network ID you need to define a headless service for stateful applications. The definition of headless service is similar to the standard service, but it doesn't have the <code>clusterIP</code>. Simply adding <code>clusterIP: none</code> in yaml definition will create a headless service. Here is one example:</p>\n<pre><code>apiVersion: v1\nkind: Service\nmetadata:\n  name: zookeeper-server\n  labels:\n    app: zookeeper\nspec:\n  clusterIP: None # &lt;--\n  ports:\n  - port: 2888\n    name: server\n  - port: 3888\n    name: leader-election\n  selector:\n    app: zookeeper\n</code></pre>\n<p>In above example we defined headless service just for zookeeper servers, clients could use a standard service. Note that you can always define multiple services for one Kubernetes workload object. So, how is headless service different?</p>\n<p>The main benefit of using a headless service is to be able to reach each Pod directly. If this is a standard service, then the service would act as a load balancer or proxy and you would access your workload object just using the service name <code>zookeeper-server</code>. With headless service, the Pod <code>zookeeper-0</code> could use <code>zookeeper-1.zookeeper-server</code> to talk to <code>zookeeper-1</code> directly. The form is <code>&lt;StatefulSet-Name&gt;-&lt;Ordinal-Index&gt;.&lt;ServiceName&gt;</code>.</p>\n<h3 id=\"poddiscoverywithnslookup\">Pod discovery with nslookup</h3>\n<p>With headless service, we could easily discover other Pods in one <code>StatefulSet</code> workload with a simple tool like <code>nslookup</code>. Let's take a look at those two examples:</p>\n<p>Standard service - you will get the <code>clusterIP</code> value:</p>\n<pre><code>$ kubectl exec zookeeper-0 -- nslookup zookeeper\nServer:        10.0.0.10\nAddress:    10.0.0.10#53\n\nName:    zookeeper.default.svc.cluster.local\nAddress: 10.0.0.213\n</code></pre>\n<p>Headless service - you will get the IP of each Pod:</p>\n<pre><code>$ kubectl exec zookeeper-0 -- nslookup zookeeper\nServer:        10.0.0.10\nAddress:    10.0.0.10#53\n\nName:    zookeeper.default.svc.cluster.local\nAddress: 172.17.0.6\nName:    zookeeper.default.svc.cluster.local\nAddress: 172.17.0.7\nName:    zookeeper.default.svc.cluster.local\nAddress: 172.17.0.8\n</code></pre>\n<p>Those two examples are just to show you how two types of Kuberntes services are different. Something like this cannot be used in start scripts because Pods are started one by one and only the latest pod could discover other pods.</p>\n<h3 id=\"operators\">Operators</h3>\n<p>All looks great, but there is a minor problem with <code>StatefulSet</code> workloads. Kubernetes cannot provide a general solution for stateful applications, so you might need to look at Kubernetes Operators. If you think about this, each stateful application acts differently and it is almost impossible to generalize all of them to <code>StatefulSet</code> and expect to work seamlessly. Kubernetes would need to have a different workload API for each application type and that is not likely to happen. Instead, there are Operators which are created for specific stateful applications. Here are some of them:</p>\n\n<p>So, the question is, should you create or use an Operator for each stateful application? Probably not, and you could just use <code>StatefulSet</code> to work with your stateful application, but scaling it, upgrading and any operational stuff need to be done manually with a lot of testing and planning. Don't expect for Kubernetes to solve that. If you really don't want to run stateful applications inside Kuberntes and you want to use them externally, you could do that too. That is actually a great idea for easier transition of production workloads. Check <a href=\"https://akomljen.com/kubernetes-tips-part-1\">my previous blog post</a> if you want to see how to access external services from Kubernetes, the right way.</p>\n<h3 id=\"conclusion\">Conclusion</h3>\n<p>This was just a small introduction to <code>StatefulSet</code> workloads. There are many great things about it, rolling upgrades are also available from Kubernetes v1.7 and above, but as many other things they are not perfect and I think that Operators are here to solve that. To be precise, Operators are using <code>StatefulSet</code> features and they are just another layer above to make things easier.</p>\n</div>&#13;\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</div></body></html>"}, "15429014": {"score": 2, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 20:14:47", "url": "https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/qvj5vp/piloted-aircraft-flight-speed-record-1967-nasa-air-force-william-knight-x-15", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"article__body\"><p>This week marked the 50th anniversary of the fastest ever piloted aircraft flight, when Major William J. \"Pete\" Knight brought the rocket-powered X-15 A-2 to a speed of 4,520 miles per hour\u2014over six times the speed of sound\u2014in <a href=\"https://history.nasa.gov/monograph31.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">October 1967</a>. </p> <p>This is distinct from the air speed record, because this record necessitates a pilot. The <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2005/jun/HQ_05_156_X43A_Guinness.html\" target=\"_blank\">X-43A</a> jet has since reached speeds of 7,310 miles per hour, setting the air speed record <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2005/jun/HQ_05_156_X43A_Guinness.html\" target=\"_blank\">in 2005</a>, but the aircraft is unmanned. The famed SR-71 represents the fastest piloted jet flight since Knight's famous hypersonic flight half a century ago, though it <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=ZHkAJAq-2HQC&amp;lpg=PA223&amp;ots=9AS2-nsLCs&amp;dq=limits%20on%20General%20staff%20on%20one%20flight&amp;pg=PA223#v=onepage&amp;q=mach&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">never even reached</a> 3,000 miles per hour.</p> <p>We live in a time of <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/gypexq/human-vs-drone-combat-is-the-new-normal\">militarized drone fleets</a>, <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/78d85g/spacexs-latest-rocket-landing-video-is-stunning\">precision landings</a> of orbital rockets, and soon, gigantic <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/xwg5nd/elon-musk-mars-settle-terraform-2024\">Mars-bound rockets</a> (maybe). How has the flight speed record for a piloted aircraft held up for half a century? </p> <p>The answer to this question is buried in the history of the X-15, an unmistakable product of its moment.</p> <p>In 1967, the US military was still financing the <a href=\"http://www.inquiriesjournal.com/articles/749/the-military-industrial-complex-in-the-united-states-evolution-and-expansion-from-world-war-ii-to-the-war-on-terror\" target=\"_blank\">military-industrial complex</a> that emerged during World War II. <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/military-spending/\" target=\"_blank\">While military spending</a> in countries like the UK, France, and Germany plummeted to about one third of their peak war spending after 1946, the US maintained almost half of its military spending. In the 25 years after WWII, America funnelled about $328 billion (adjusted for inflation in the year 2000) annually to its military.</p> <p class=\"article__embed article__embed--ourworldindata\"/> <p>For agencies like NASA and the US Air Force, this spending was used to fund experimental vehicles and technologies.</p> <p>The X-15 \"<a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/centers/dryden/pdf/87756main_H-524.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">research airplane</a>\" was one of over 30 \"<a href=\"https://history.nasa.gov/monograph31.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">X-vehicles</a>\" produced by US military agencies like the Air Force, the Navy, and NASA between 1946 and 1971. These X-vehicles, mainly airplanes and missiles, were experimental technologies designed in hopes of achieving record altitudes and hypersonic speeds. </p> <p>These extreme vehicles were tested in the remoteness of the Nevadan desert, <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/centers/armstrong/news/FactSheets/FS-052-DFRC.html\" target=\"_blank\">with the aim of</a> producing data that could be used to design spacecrafts\u2014specifically, ones that could carry humans. In fact, <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=gb5nBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA171&amp;lpg=PA171&amp;dq=200th+flight+x-15+21+November+1968,&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=35TLkPl6os&amp;sig=l-RUaEL6MJ9IQCBqdjm3PjmKDZs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjZvZawxtfWAhUq5YMKHY2QC-oQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&amp;q=200th&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">Neil Armstrong trained</a> for his Apollo 11 mission by flying the X-15.</p> <p>In order to reach hypersonic speeds, the X-15 was <a href=\"http://www.sierrafoot.org/x-15/pirep1.html\" target=\"_blank\">designed</a> with a rocket engine fueled by ammonia and liquid oxygen. This plane wasn't exactly fuel-efficient: In just 80 seconds, its engine could guzzle down 15,000 pounds of fuel.</p><p class=\"article__blockquote\"><b>Read more: </b><a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/bjvb4w/beware-hypersonic-missiles\"><b>Beware Indestructible 'Hypersonic Missiles'</b></a></p> <p>After dozens of tests at increasingly ambitious speeds, the Air Force wanted to test the X-15's absolute speed limits. Out of the <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/centers/armstrong/news/FactSheets/FS-052-DFRC.html\" target=\"_blank\">twelve people</a> who flew the X-15, Major Pete Knight was a safe pick for the job. He already had three years of experience with the X-15 after being personally recruited from a training program at the Aerospace Research Pilot School.</p> <p>(If Knight's name sounds familiar, it's probably because he's famously homophobic. He <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/no-to-gay-marriage-in-ca/\" target=\"_blank\">introduced the bill</a> that made same-sex marriage illegal in California back in 2000 when he was a state senator.)</p> <p>But despite Knight's experience as a pilot, the risks of the flight were clear. In June of 1967, Knight experienced engine failure while piloting the X-15 <a href=\"https://www.historychannel.com.au/this-day-in-history/knight-sets-speed-record-for-manned-aircraft/\" target=\"_blank\">107,000 feet above Earth</a>. He had to make an emergency landing in the middle of Nevada's Mud Lake. </p> <p>Knight wasn't the only pilot who had to make emergency landings. In fact, they had been happening for years, and injuries <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=gb5nBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA171&amp;lpg=PA171&amp;dq=200th+flight+x-15+21+November+1968,&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=35TLkPl6os&amp;sig=l-RUaEL6MJ9IQCBqdjm3PjmKDZs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjZvZawxtfWAhUq5YMKHY2QC-oQ6AEILDAB#v=snippet&amp;q=injuries&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">were commonplace</a>.</p> <p>One of the most severe X-15 emergency landings was on November 9, 1962. Major Jack McKay <a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/#/details-E62-9170.html\" target=\"_blank\">experienced engine failure</a> and was forced made a high-speed landing in Mud Lake. <a href=\"http://crushing/\" target=\"_blank\">McKay jumped</a> from the X-15 before its violent landing, but not without <a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/#/details-E62-9170.html\" target=\"_blank\">smashing his back</a> <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=gb5nBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA171&amp;lpg=PA171&amp;dq=200th+flight+x-15+21+November+1968,&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=35TLkPl6os&amp;sig=l-RUaEL6MJ9IQCBqdjm3PjmKDZs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjZvZawxtfWAhUq5YMKHY2QC-oQ6AEILDAB#v=snippet&amp;q=injuries&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">and head</a> into the lakebed. McKay eventually recovered and would fly the X-15 <a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/#/details-E62-9170.html\" target=\"_blank\">22 more</a> times.</p> <div class=\"article__media\"><picture class=\"article__image\"><source media=\"(max-width: 25em)\" srcset=\"https://vice-web-statics-cdn.vice.com/images/blank.png\" data-srcset=\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=400:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=600:* data-srcset=\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=650:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=975:* 2x\"><source media=\"(max-width: 53.125em)\" srcset=\"https://vice-web-statics-cdn.vice.com/images/blank.png\" data-srcset=\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=850:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg?resize=1275:* 2x\"><img src=\"https://vice-web-statics-cdn.vice.com/images/blank.png\" alt=\"\" data-src=\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1507309497112-E62-9170~orig.jpeg\"/></source></source></source></source></source></picture><div class=\"article__image-caption\"><p>The damaged X-15 in Mud Lake, Nevada, on the day of Major McKay's crash in November 1962. Image: </p><a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/#/details-E62-9170.html\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></div></div> <p>But when Knight set the piloted speed record, the flight went off without a hitch. On the October 3 flight, <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/centers/armstrong/news/FactSheets/FS-052-DFRC.html\" target=\"_blank\">Knight accelerated</a> to 4,520 miles per hour and was able to keep control of the aircraft.</p><p>Although the X-15 was a record-breaking aircraft, it wasn't safe to fly. Just weeks after Knight's flight, Major Michael Adams died during an experimental X-15 flight.</p> <p>Adams was sent to test the X-15's altitude limits, and was able to climb <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/centers/dryden/news/X-Press/stories/2004/073004/ppl_adams.html\" target=\"_blank\">50 miles</a> above Earth, into the <a href=\"https://scied.ucar.edu/atmosphere-layers\" target=\"_blank\">Thermosphere</a>. That's high enough for a satellite to <a href=\"https://scied.ucar.edu/shortcontent/thermosphere-overview\" target=\"_blank\">enter orbit</a> around the Earth, but the Air Force explicitly incentivized pilots to reach these dangerous heights. In fact, the Air Force <a href=\"http://www.thecharterstore.com/blog/north-american-x-15/\" target=\"_blank\">awarded astronaut wings</a> to pilots who reached fifty mile-altitudes.</p> <p>But as Adams tried to descend, electrical disturbances damaged the X-15's guidance and reaction controls. Adams lost control of the plane, which spun at hypersonic speeds as it plunged to the ground below. Suffering from vertigo, Adams was unable to exit the plane and died when the X-15 crashed into the Mojave Desert. He was 37.</p><p>Despite this tragedy, the X-15 was flown nine more times in the following year. Major Knight was scheduled to take it on its 200th flight in November 1968, but after <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=gb5nBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA171&amp;lpg=PA171&amp;dq=200th+flight+x-15+21+November+1968,&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=35TLkPl6os&amp;sig=l-RUaEL6MJ9IQCBqdjm3PjmKDZs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjZvZawxtfWAhUq5YMKHY2QC-oQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&amp;q=200th&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">a series of technical problems</a> the flight was cancelled and the X-15 was officially retired. And while X-vehicle experimentation <a href=\"https://history.nasa.gov/monograph31.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">ran until 1971</a>, no test was designed to break the speed record for piloted aircrafts set by the X-15.<br/></p> <p>So why haven't we broken the speed record for piloted aircrafts in 50 years?</p> <p>It's possible that with the success of the Apollo program and the development of powerful nuclear weapons, the US simply lost interest in testing the boundaries of piloted flight speeds. </p> <p>But after the loss of Adams's life and close calls with pilots such as McKay, NASA also started to more carefully evaluate when pilots are necessary.</p> <p>This caution is evident in NASA's current approach to research aircrafts. A <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/fs-108-afrc.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">NASA fact sheet</a> regarding its Prototype-Technology Evaluation and Research Aircraft (PTERA) explains that all testing is conducted in a laboratory:</p> <p class=\"article__blockquote\"><i>\"The ability to alter PTERA's configuration allows cost-effective testing of unconventional designs that might otherwise be too dangerous or expensive to test with a full-scale, crewed aircraft.\"</i></p> <p>Pilots may be safe from dangerous hypersonic flight tests, but this risk may have shifted toward people on the ground. American, Chinese, and Russian air forces currently <a href=\"http://www.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/1177338/accelerating-hypersonics-development/\" target=\"_blank\">are all conducting</a> hypersonic drone tests. In fact, these countries have <a href=\"https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/bjvb4w/beware-hypersonic-missiles\">already developed</a> hypersonic missiles that can travel more than 3,000 miles per hour.</p> <p>These weapons could become commonplace in future warfare, which is an unsettling prospect. Imagine cheaply made, unmanned aerial vehicles that bomb areas and leave, all before people on the ground even hear the detonation. </p> <p>X-15 testing undoubtedly raised important ethical concerns about the relationship between humans and their hypersonic creations. Although its piloted flight speed record has stood for fifty years, these ethical concerns are far from obsolete.</p><p><b> <i> Get six of our favorite Motherboard stories every day </i></b><b><i><a href=\"http://motherboard.club/\" target=\"_blank\">by signing up for our newsletter</a>.</i></b></p></div>\n            </div></body></html>"}, "15429116": {"score": 1, "comments": [], "time": "2017-10-08 20:42:25", "url": "https://medium.com/@iacobson/subscribe-genstages-under-umbrella-1fceec366633", "text": "<html><body><div><div class=\"section-inner sectionLayout--insetColumn\"><h1 name=\"ceca\" id=\"ceca\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf--leading graf--title\">Subscribe GenStages Under\u00a0Umbrella</h1><h2 name=\"3c25\" id=\"3c25\" class=\"graf graf--h4 graf-after--h3 graf--subtitle\">GenStage Under Umbrella\u200a\u2014\u200aPart\u00a04</h2><p name=\"14eb\" id=\"14eb\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--mixtapeEmbed\">This is the last article in the GenStage under Umbrella series, and the shortest. We made quite some progress. We have <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">a working application and tests are passing</strong>. GenStages are sending and receiving the expected information across the Umbrella apps.</p><p name=\"8e51\" id=\"8e51\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">We miss just one more thing: automate the GenStage subscriptions. As you remember, we manually subscribed the consumers to the producers in our tests, like so:</p><pre name=\"d7fc\" id=\"d7fc\" class=\"graf graf--pre graf-after--p\">GenStage.sync_subscribe(MyUkApp.ReceiveConsumer, to: Converter.ReceiveProducerConsumer)</pre><p name=\"0f74\" id=\"0f74\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--pre\">In the last article, we saw why it is not possible to handle the subscriptions in the GenStage <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">init</code>. Basically, we do not have control over the application start order in a \u201cflat umbrella\u201d architecture. So we cannot guarantee that the producer is up when the consumer tries to subscribe.</p><p name=\"6299\" id=\"6299\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">What can we do about it?</p><p name=\"d0fe\" id=\"d0fe\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">At <a href=\"https://www.fitzdares.com/careers/ruby\" data-href=\"https://www.fitzdares.com/careers/ruby\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Fitzdares</a>, we use this <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">GenStage under Umbrella</strong> architecture for one of our current Elixir projects. So we\u2019ve been working on this small hex package called <a href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/umbrella_stage/readme.html\" data-href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/umbrella_stage/readme.html\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">UmbrellaStage</a>. Its only function is to subscribe GenStage consumers to the producers.</p><p name=\"07d1\" id=\"07d1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Under the hood, it\u2019s a <a href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/elixir/master/Registry.html\" data-href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/elixir/master/Registry.html\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Registry</a> that tracks the GenStage processes across all apps. The registry stores also the subscriptions details. As soon as a producer-consumer pair of processes becomes available, it subscribes them.</p><p name=\"b59d\" id=\"b59d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">For the moment the package implements only <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\"><a href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/gen_stage/GenStage.html#sync_subscribe/3\" data-href=\"https://hexdocs.pm/gen_stage/GenStage.html#sync_subscribe/3\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">GenStage.sync_subscribe/3</a></code>.</p><h3 name=\"3b03\" id=\"3b03\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Automated Subscriptions</h3><p name=\"354d\" id=\"354d\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">Let\u2019s add UmbrellaStage to our <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">Stockr</code> app. We will add the package in our <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">Shared</code> application <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">mix.exs</strong>: <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">{:umbrella_stage, \"~&gt; 0.1\"}</strong></code>. Then run <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">mix deps.get</code> to install the package.</p><p name=\"cb4b\" id=\"cb4b\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">Now look for all <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">GenStage.sync_subscribe/3</code> in our tests and delete them. If you will try to run the tests again, they will fail, as the GenStages are no longer communicating with each other.</p><p name=\"c9b4\" id=\"c9b4\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">It\u2019s time to add the UmbrellaStage configuration in each GenStage. It contains information about the GenStage type, as well as the producer names and options. Add the following configurations at the top of the GenStages, right after <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">use GenStage</code>.</p><figure name=\"4754\" id=\"4754\" class=\"graf graf--figure graf--iframe graf-after--p\"/><p name=\"d320\" id=\"d320\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--figure\">The UmbrellaStage hex package will work only with named producers (and producer_consumers).</p><p name=\"97b1\" id=\"97b1\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\">And finally, the last step. In each GenStage <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">init</code> function call <code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\">umbrella_sync_subscribe()</code>. That\u2019s it. Now you can rerun the tests and they will pass. <strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">The consumers will subscribe to their producers as soon as both starts.</strong></p><p name=\"5428\" id=\"5428\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">You can find the full code for our </strong><code class=\"markup--code markup--p-code\"><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\">Stockr</strong></code><strong class=\"markup--strong markup--p-strong\"> app on GitHub: </strong><a href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/blog_stockr\" data-href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/blog_stockr\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/iacobson/blog_stockr</a></p><h3 name=\"40a4\" id=\"40a4\" class=\"graf graf--h3 graf-after--p\">Your Turn</h3><p name=\"89c7\" id=\"89c7\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--h3\">Here we are at the end of this long series. I am very interested to hear your opinion or experiences with GenStage in Umbrella projects. Personally, I find it pretty cool. Please leave a comment with your thoughts, possible concerns, ideas, etc.</p><p name=\"ef76\" id=\"ef76\" class=\"graf graf--p graf-after--p graf--trailing\">Also, if you would like to see more features in the <a href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/umbrella_stage\" data-href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/umbrella_stage\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">UmbrellaStage</a> hex package, use the <a href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/umbrella_stage/issues\" data-href=\"https://github.com/iacobson/umbrella_stage/issues\" class=\"markup--anchor markup--p-anchor\" rel=\"nofollow noopener\" target=\"_blank\">issues</a> to request it.
